name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Colleagues, at the end of the day yesterday, Tunisia was once again bereaved by a terrorist attack in the heart of its capital that claimed the lives of 14 members of the presidential guard.  On behalf of our institution, I would like to condemn this abject act in the strongest possible terms and to assure the Tunisian authorities and the Tunisian people of our unwavering support. Our thoughts and solidarity also go out to the families of the victims. In less than two weeks, ladies and gentlemen, the terrorists have struck in Beirut, Paris, Bamako and, again, Tunis, sowing pain and amazement every time. This borderless terrorism shows once again that we are all concerned by this fight. This fight will be long, but we will fight it with determination, respecting our democratic foundations and in the framework of cooperation that we need to strengthen with our allies and partners.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the recent terrorist attacks in Paris (2015/2972 (RSP)."

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, you have just recalled this new barbaric act which was committed in Tunis and I think that the Council is absolutely joining you in condemning this cowardly attack and expressing our sympathy, all our thoughts to the courageous Tunisian people. In the same way, I would like to reiterate our thoughts of sympathy for the victims, their families, the city of Paris and all the other victims of terrorism, and you have spoken about it. Today, more than ever, we need solidarity in the face of this scourge of terrorism.  A decided action, capable of defending our freedoms, our values, but also the security of our fellow citizens. We need the broadest and most intense European cooperation possible, and it must involve all those who are ready to engage with us in this relentless fight against those who sow terror by blindly killing. Never before have we needed a strong and determined Europe, capable of acting in a fast, coordinated and solid way. The Presidency, after the Paris attacks, immediately convened an extraordinary "Justice and Home Affairs" Council on 20 November, after which ambitious actions were decided. The Council has decided to confirm its commitment to counter-terrorism with a focus on operational measures. It is essential to mobilize all energies to achieve results and make our societies safer. Let me now elaborate on the measures that have been taken.  With regard to the NRL, the Council aims to quickly achieve the implementation of this scheme at European level. The Presidency hopes to reach an agreement with Parliament at the next trilogue and we are fully aware of the importance for you of concluding the negotiations on the data protection package. The Presidency reiterates its commitment to finalize the negotiations before the end of the year.  With regard to the trafficking of firearms, the Council is trying to combat illegal arms trafficking more effectively within the European Union, drawing on revised texts and operations carried out within the framework of the so-called political cycle of the European Union to combat serious international organised crime. The Presidency will begin discussions on the Commission's proposal for a revision of the Firearms Directive, which the Commission has just presented, as early as this week.  With regard to the strengthening of external border controls, Member States are committed to immediately implementing the necessary systematic and coordinated controls at external borders, including on those enjoying the right to free movement. The terrorist at the Jewish museum in Brussels had a European passport, the terrorists who acted in Paris in January, Copenhagen and again in Paris on 13 November had European passports for some of them. I call on Parliament to take into account this reality and the expectations of our fellow citizens.  A modernization of the border control systems of Schengen member states will be implemented by March 2016. For third-country nationals, Member States will systematically register, including fingerprinting, third-country nationals entering the Schengen area, and carry out systematic security checks using the relevant databases. Finally, Member States will strengthen the controls at the most exposed external borders, including deploying, where the situation requires, rapid border response teams and police officers to ensure that screening and security checks are carried out in a systematic manner.  With regard to the exchange of information, the Council is committed to implementing a series of actions aimed at using the tools put in place to the maximum of their capabilities and enabling the most effective cooperation possible. Member States will thereby ensure that national authorities systematically introduce data on all suspected foreign terrorist fighters into the SIS II database.  The Council welcomes the establishment of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre within Europol on 1 January. The new Europol regulation, on which we hope to reach an agreement without delay, should be consistent with the mandate and objectives of the centre, including the internet content reporting unit. Member States will deploy counter-terrorism experts to the centre to form a enhanced unit to support cross-border investigations capable of providing rapid global support to investigators in the event of a major terrorist incident in the European Union.  The Council calls on the Commission to present a legislative proposal to allow Europol to systematically cross-reference its databases with those of SIS II. In terms of combating the financing of terrorism, the Council called on the Commission to put forward proposals to strengthen, harmonize and improve the competence and cooperation of financial intelligence cells, and to ensure that these cells have timely access to the necessary information in order to enhance the effectiveness and efficiency of the fight against money laundering and terrorist financing. The Council also recommends strengthening control of non-bank payment methods.  As part of the judicial responses to terrorism and violent extremism, the Council welcomes the signing by the Eu in Riga on 22 October of the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention of Terrorism and its additional protocol on foreign terrorist fighters. It welcomes the Commission's intention to present a proposal for a directive updating the framework decision on the fight against terrorism before the end of this year. The Commission also recommends improvements to the Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS) and preventive actions.  All of these measures require a demanding follow-up; Council will take care of that. Our firm and determined response must be done calmly, in accordance with fundamental rights and in accordance with our charter, which remain our guiding principles.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. Mr President, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, we will remember this Friday 13 November, the day when an unrelenting fate has descended on the City of Lights. So many destroyed biographies, unfinished dreams, interrupted journeys, and unenforceable plans and projects.  We share the mourning of the French and we will support the reaction of the Republic. Today, even more than tomorrow, I say "Long live France and its Republic", which is also ours. (Applause) I would like to repeat to this high house what I said immediately after the terrible attacks in Paris. I warn against dangerous, pernicious amalgamations of putting refugees, asylum seekers, migrants and terrorists on an equal footing. Those who perpetrated and fomented the attacks in Paris are exactly the same people who force the unfortunates of this planet to flee. No amalgam! (Applause) We must not turn misfortunes into oratory effects. We must not give in to this temptation, in fact dramatically ridiculous.  I mean here that we must safeguard the spirit of Schengen. Yes, the Schengen system is partly comatose and those who believe in Europe, its values, its principles and its freedoms will have to try - and they will do - to resuscitate the spirit of Schengen. If the spirit of Schengen leaves our territories and our hearts, we will lose more than Schengen. A single currency makes no sense if Schengen falls. It should be noted that Schengen is not a neutral concept, an innocuous concept, but that it is one of the centrepieces of European integration. I would like, once again, to appeal to the Member States to do what they have promised. President Schmit this morning elegantly recalled a number of decisions carried out by the Council and the Member States. We must continue in this direction and the Commission will do everything in its way to ensure that the Member States are made to remember their commitments. We will have to see better than before the immediate neighbours of the European Union. The collective performance of Jordan and Lebanon is admirable, so we must assist with enthusiasm the peoples in question who bear a heavy burden in the context of the refugee crisis. We tend to focus on our cooperation with Turkey. We mustn't forget the others. That is why, months ago, the Commission proposed, and the Council had adopted, the establishment of a trust fund for Africa, which covers EUR 1.8 billion. It was a decision that was not taken, as is often said and as can be read almost every day, at the valletta summit. This is a decision that the Member States, on the basis of a Commission proposal, had taken several weeks earlier, with this additional remark which Member States have committed to provide themselves with an additional EUR 1.8 billion to bring this trust fund to Africa to EUR 3.6 billion.  We intend to ensure that the promises are fulfilled and we are grateful to the Luxembourg Presidency, whose speed we welcome, for moving forward with the revision of the European legislation on firearms, and in particular on the deactivation of it. We in the Commission believe, as do others, that the European Passenger Register should be set up, including for intra-European flights. I am aware that this proposal will raise many questions, but it is clear that the PNR must also find application with regard to intra-European flights. I believe that the Secret Service needs to cooperate better. Together with Guy Verhofstadt, Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Belgium at the time, we attended two or three European Councils after the attacks in New York. Already, a week after the attacks in New York, we, the heads of state and government, had promised ourselves that the Secret Service would function better and in a concerted way. This was not the case. Today, we are told that the Secret Service must cooperate in the best possible way. I would like us to achieve this necessary cooperation between the secret services this time.  (Applause) In keeping with President Schmit's remarks, I would like to confirm that in December the Commission will propose a text on the creation of a border guard and coastguard corps, which is a necessity to better protect our external borders. On Sunday, a summit will be held with the 28 Member States and Turkey, which will focus on the refugee crisis. I'd like to to pay tribute here to First Vice-President Timmermans for a remarkably well-conducted work, when, on three occasions, I believe, he went to Turkey to discuss with the Turkish authorities the ways of cooperation that we can establish with that country. We will adopt a joint action plan with Turkey and, for the rest, we are negotiating the details of these arrangements. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for his excellent work. When I came home on friday night after an appointment, I was actually looking forward to a football match between Germany and France and then, like all of us, I was shocked when I turned on the TV and saw the pictures from Paris. We are all deeply saddened and in mourning. First of all, our thoughts are with the victims. Unfortunately, God's often talk too quickly about the perpetrators and too little about the victims. That is why our thoughts are first and all with the victims and their families. (Applause) It is prudence and determination is needed. First of all, prudence. When I saw the pictures, of course, I also thought of Charlie Hebdo – a few months ago in Paris. And there was a name in my mind, Ahmed Merabet. He was a policeman, a French policeman who stood guard at Charlie Hebdo and defended Charlie Hebdo. And he was a Muslim. Also last Friday, a week ago, many Muslims were murdered by madmen, by terrorists. That is why we must first of all be aware that it is not Muslims, it is not Islam that is our problem, but insane extremists and terrorists who are our problem. It would be a victory for the terrorists if we allowed an entire religious group to now be under general suspicion. (Applause) I would like to emphasise a second principle, which the President of the Commission has already mentioned: refugees who come to Europe are victims of terrorism and not perpetrators. That is why a mix-up that is now being carried out by some populists and extremists in the political sphere is inadmissible. That, too, would be a victory for the terrorists if we put all refugees under general suspicion. (Applause) Thirdly, ladies and gentlemen, the terrorists hate our way of life, freedom, the joy of life, tolerance, democracy. That is why we must not allow ourselves to question our nature. I have great respect for the people of Paris, for the people of France, who are just showing that they do not let terrorists destroy their way of life. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. back to Ahmed Merabet, a policeman who paid with his life to defend our freedom. Ladies and gentlemen, in front of the European Parliament in Brussels are soldiers, young men protecting our work. That is why I would like to say thank you to all the authorities who hold their heads every day for our safety. Thank you for that! (Applause) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which As a politician, of course, there is a lot going on when we talk about these issues. It goes through one's mind, President Schmit, that we in the Council can actually copy and paste. For many years, the same thing has been decided in the Council, the same speeches are constantly being made, and unfortunately nothing is happening. You have to make sure that something finally happens! That is what the people of Europe expect. And we, too, internally, must be critical of each other. That would come to mind as a politician. I hear the French Minister of the Interior appealing to us as a Parliament that we should finally deliver results on PNR. And here I have to say on the part of my group: we deliver! For months, for years, we at PNR have been of the opinion that this has to come. And many other colleagues, the Socialists and Democrats in particular, voted against PNR in the European Parliament's Home Affairs Committee. I must also say to the French Minister for the Interior: please talk to your group if you believe that we are not making progress! (Applause) But, frankly, ladies and gentlemen, I do not want to put this reciprocal reckoning at the heart of my speech. I had thought about it, but I do not want to do it, because I want to promote, namely, to work together, to tackle the issues with each other, to move forward with PNR, to move forward with Europol's issues, to take the lead in the data protection directive, in the fight against the financing of terrorism, so that we can get results there, and in terms of data retention, so that we can get them throughout Europe. Our investigative authorities need this data! Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she That is what drives us. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats want to achieve results, and we want to achieve this together in Europe. We must be aware that it is a challenge for the whole of Europe, for all of us in European responsibility. I appeal to everyone not to talk in the next few weeks, but to finally put action into action! (The speaker was thus agrees to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: "blue card" question. I thank President Weber for expressing his solidarity with the French Republic, but I am surprised by his stigmatizing remarks and the climate of conflict he maintains, while we are all mobilized to bring the PNR to fruition. We have seen the instrumentalisation of a coherent position of the Socialists who, in the LIBE committee, voted against a text which did not take up any of the French demands, and which allowed and wanted the negotiations to begin in order to achieve a PNR by the end of the year. I hope, Mr Pittella, that Mr Weber will support us so that we can achieve this NRL together by the end of 2015.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Berés! Just last night, a motion was tabled by the Socialists to amend today's Dati report on radicalisation to remove the target of completing PNR by the end of the year. Thankfully, the motion has now been withdrawn by the Socialists. I would like to express my thanks for this. I would also like to make it clear that we should end these debates. I have also tried to say this: we should end these debates, and we should now work together to tackle the issues, and I hope that the Socialists will be prepared to do so. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe will not be changed by terrorism. By remaining ourselves, we will wipe out terror. For many of our cities – I am thinking of Paris, brussels – this is the most difficult time since the Second World War. Never have our fellow citizens felt so threatened. We all feel a great vacuum inside: but this must not become Europe's 11 September. We must not allow fear and the logic of emergency to become normal; we must not fall into the blackmail of terrorists who want to push us towards division. This is the time for unity and responsibility! Those who think of gaining electoral support by splitting the European front, trumpeting the false equation – juncker said, Weber said – 'refugee = terrorist' is an enemy vulture of European citizens. We need cold blood, we need more Europe, closer Europe to France, to François Hollande, to all French citizens, close to Tunisia, stronger in the world, wherever these bastards are 60.  Hollande invoked Article 42 and the member states' response must be yes. But we can go further, we can go beyond the intergovernmental dimension by affirming Community European measures. That is why the Eu ropean Union, as President Juncker said, is having taken up the initiative in the field of security and defence. Well, Mr Juncker has been able to announce greater flexibility in the application of the Stability Pact for security expenditure. This flexibility must apply to all States of the Union that invest in security. It is clear, in fact, that we will win the battle against terrorism if we invest economically and politically in prepared intelligence services and if we facilitate their coordination at European level. We need not only more technology: we need "superexperienced" human resources, capable of addressing the new profile of jihadist terrorism. More Europe also means applying Schengen in its entirety and not dismantling it, because within the Treaty there are already measures that can and must be implemented to ensure greater and better protection at the external borders. Our group has worked and will work consistently to ensure that an agreement is reached on the European PNR by the end of the year. Together we also want to guarantee citizens' rights in the area of privacy, and so the two dossiers on European PNR and data protection go together, as mandated by this Parliament.  In order to defeat terrorism, we also need real reflection on our society. It is clear that there are other causes too, but let us not forget the conditions of unemployment, misery and segregation in which areas of our cities live, where some young people grow up who may be more tempted by the charming and macabre siren of terrorism. Europe must reaffirm its model of a cohesive and supportive society and it must be made clear that Islam is part of the identity of this continent and that it has nothing to do with Daesh's ideology of death. In foreign policy too, Europe must make Europe. Funding channels must be cut; we must isolate Daeh politically, we must strike at the business, criminal circuit, money laundering, trafficking in human beings, the hypocrisy of certain realities in the Gulf. Europe must act as Vice-President Mogherini is doing, ensuring a role as a mediator weaver between states and actors on the ground. We need a broad coalition that also includes the Muslim countries in the region, together, of course, with the European Union, Russia and America in order to defeat terrorism.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, on Friday 13 November I was with other Conservatives and Reformists in Tunisia, where we were taking part in a conference on building a Muslim democratic movement. We knew then, as we saw the pictures coming in from Paris, as we shared the grief of the people of Paris and of France, that it could all happen again in Tunisia – and sadly that is what came to pass overnight. Our solidarity should be not only with the people of France but also with the people of Tunisia and with all the victims of terrorism and Daesh. (Applause)  One of the terrorists involved in the Paris attacks spent his nights drinking alcohol and smoking cannabis, and another never went to the mosque. Two British terrorists ordered a book before they fled to Syria last year. The name of that book: Islam for Dummies. Yet all these terrorists claim to be carrying out these acts in the name of Islam, and are prepared to slaughter innocent people on a Friday night in Paris – people eating dinner, watching a rock band, just going about their own business. It could have been in any of our cities. It could have been aimed at any of us but, sadly, there is method to their madness. Firstly, they hope to inspire copycat attacks and recruit more terrorists. Fortunately, the vast majority of Muslims will not fall for this. Secondly, even though most victims of Daesh attacks are in fact Muslims, they want, through these attacks on our cities, to provoke a backlash – to convince Muslims that Islam is despised in the West. We all need to come together to show them that they will not succeed. In the aftermath of the attacks there have been the inevitable statements about the incompatibility between Islam and Western democracy. We may even hear some of that in this Chamber today. But let us be inspired by the words of Antoine Leiris, who lost his wife, Hélène, in the Bataclan. He told the terrorists: ‘I will not give you the gift of hating you.’ How brave he must have been to write those words to people who had just murdered his wife – to people who had shattered his life, to people with a love for death, who attacked a city known for its love of life. It is at times like this that our humanity must become stronger and not descend into a spiral of hatred and blame. We need to come together to learn the lessons, to strengthen our resolve and to develop our response – a response that must be measured and proportionate. For if, every time they attack us, we erode our freedoms, there may eventually be no freedoms to defend. The balance between security and liberty will always be hotly debated, but we should debate this delicate balance without accusations, without any of the insults I see flying across this Chamber, and without questioning political opponents’ determination to fight terrorism, because this whole House needs to come together to agree on clear and tangible measures to strengthen our protection, such as introducing the passenger name record system by the end of the year. The ECR rapporteur, Timothy Kirkhope, will deliver on this, working with all the other Groups and also addressing the concerns about civil liberties. Better sharing of intelligence between national agencies is another such requirement. This does not mean we need an EU intelligence agency; the answer is not always more Europe. The answer is to build trust between the agencies of the nation states to make sure they share the intelligence that they have. Stronger external borders – building on last week’s Home Affairs Council – are also essential, because so long as the EU’s external borders are weakened, there will be calls for its internal borders to be strengthened. However, we should not pretend that every terrorist crosses borders to come into the EU. Many, sadly, were born and were radicalised in EU Member States – some searching for an identity or a sense of belonging, others radicalised in prison; some violent individuals looking for a new cause, others vulnerable and fooled into believing in a violent shortcut to paradise in a world of temptation. Better integration must be part of the solution, for where there are young people who feel that they do not belong to the country in which they live, where they are ghettoised, ISIS/Daesh will see them as potential recruits. These are all important debates that we will have in the months ahead. But today, whether you believe in a United States of Europe or whether you believe in a Europe of nation states, we should all unite to state a simple message: we will not surrender to hatred. We will not surrender to intolerance. We will not surrender our freedoms. You can attack us, you can injure us, but you will never break us. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Here I am, Mr Kamall, the last government. I have listened with great interest and admiration to your very beautiful speech and have a question for you. Do you realise that there are people in the ranks of the political group you are chairing here in the European Parliament who are spreading anti-Islamism, who are saying terrible things about Muslims, and are you willing to get involved in preventing such things from happening in your political group?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – I find the premise of your question interesting, although I disagree with you fundamentally on this. Let me be quite clear. We have heard statements from politicians and almost all political groups about Islam, and some against Islam, in the last few weeks and months. Now is not the time – if there ever is a time – to be posing such cheap political questions in this debate. What we should be doing is coming together across the Chamber to show these terrorists that we are united in the face of their hatred.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, I want to continue where Mr Kamall ended his intervention and say that I was also shocked by the way that we have behaved since 13 November as politicians. Instead of showing unity - we have seen it again in this debate this morning - we throw insane accusations at each other. In the French language, there is an expression for this: we speak of "political politics games", to which we sometimes play and which exploit the tragedy of Paris, ladies and gentlemen, to score easy points in elections, let us say against Europe, against refugees, against Islam and even against the European Parliament. We will hear it in a few moments. Marine Le Pen will do it again.  I find this undignified and it is above all unworthy to say: "You are responsible for terrorism, because you have not reached an agreement on the PNR". I must tell you, ladies and gentlemen, that the exact opposite is true, because the reality is that this Parliament had proposed from the outset a regulation - not a directive - with direct and immediate effect to create a single system at European level, which would be transnational in order to avoid precisely the systematic failures that we see every time that either national intelligence service that knew the criminals did not pass on the relevant information to the country. The events took place. This was the case in 2004 in Madrid, as was the case in 2005 in London, and this is now the case again in Paris.  We make the same observation every time. And what do we have on the table? It's a directive. In the best case scenario, it will take at least two years to implement it and, moreover, it is twenty-eight NRPs that we will create in the European Union. I believe that at least there should be a mandatory exchange of information between these 28 systems, but of course, Minister, the Member States refuse it. So, I ask you today, who is responsible for the absence of the NRL?  I was President of the European Council, I was there with Jean-Claude Juncker on 11 September 2001, when we were able to create in six months - Jean-Claude, you remember - the European arrest warrant which was a mandatory system, not like the measures you have just listed, which are always voluntary, voluntary and whose application depends on the will of the States. For the record, Mr Weber, only Mr Berlusconi was against and negotiated a transition period, for himself, I suppose, of almost ten years. It was not until 2014 that the system came into effect in Italy.  So let's stop making political quarrels here in this house. It's too easy to launch attacks like this! What is imperative now is unity and solidarity around France; I would even say a common front, a Europe united in the fight against Daesh and terrorism. This would be the best tribute we can pay to the 130 young people who perished, who were shot during the attacks in Paris. It is in the same spirit that I will today call for the creation of a European intelligence agency. Mr Cazeneuve, the French interior minister, is right when he says that we must fight terrorism urgently and focus on the immediate implementation of the many measures that have been taken since the Charlie Hebdo attacks. But we still find that ten months later, a dozen states have not yet transferred the data required by the Schengen computerised system - twelve states for ten months that do not transfer the necessary elements! In my view, governing means not only implementing the measures that have been decided, but also planning and preparing for the future, especially in the fight against terrorism. Terrorists, ladies and gentlemen, know no borders, so we must also have a security and intelligence capability that also crosses borders. Let's take the case of Abdeslam, who is still on the run - it's still screaming! He was checked on the night of the attacks by the French police in Cambrai, he was able to continue on his way because the police did not know him, but I can tell you that the Belgian police did know him! Well, I'm telling you that with a European intelligence agency serving all European police, Abdeslam would certainly have been arrested. That is the reality that citizens need to be told. If we have to choose between sovereignty and security, I choose the security of our fellow citizens, which must prevail over sovereignty. It is in this spirit, Mr Juncker, that I have sent you and Mr Avramopoulos a concrete proposal on how to do this. In the same we also have to show unity and solidarity with France in the use of Article 42. We did not discuss this today because - let us be honest - for far too long we have outsourced our problems: inside the Union to France, as in Mali; and, outside the Union, to the Americans. If the Americans do nothing, nothing happens - as in Syria, for example. A European military coalition around France has to break this stalemate, eradicate Daesh and also facilitate a political solution. I hope that this coalition around France on Article 42 may be the start of a real European Defence Community and foreign policy. Again, I repeat: this is the best tribute we can pay to the 130 young people who were victims in Paris. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, you mentioned the contradiction between sovereignty and security, but is it not true that national sovereignty and security actually go in harness? Was it not actually the mess instituted by the collapse of the unsustainable Schengen area that compromised people’s security, including in France a few days ago? And is it not the case that sovereign states need to take responsibility for their own security to protect their citizens?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – We can see what it means! If national sovereignty means what we have seen in Spain, what we have seen in London, and what we have seen in Paris, I do not think there is proof that national sovereignty can guarantee the security of our people. Clearly, as I said, terrorism knows no borders, but our intelligence and security services still have to cope with borders. That is the contradiction we have to address.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Parliament demonstrated unity last week and I hope it will do so today when it comes to condemning the terrorist attacks in Paris, In Tunis, In Bamako and wherever in the world for what they are: attacks against people, against our values, against everything that really constitutes our civilisational experience, our civilisational coexistence in this century. There is no excuse, no justification. Everyone must know: you don't kill people! But let us also not be swearing or abusing the concerns, with the feelings of grief of people who have witnessed the attacks, either directly or through the media.  There have been two sentences in the last few days, some of which have been repeated today and which I think are very important: terrorism cannot be confused with the refugee issue: and refugees have just fled the terror that we are experiencing in Europe. In reality, however, not much remains of this appeal to reason and decency.  I would remind you of Mr Orban, his sentence: all the terrorists were migrants. A sentence that is as contemptuous as it is sneaky. Because all non-terrorists are and were migrants. All human beings are migrants. Mr Orban is a migrant. Is Mr Orban, and the question may be asked, a terrorist? In the light of the terrorist attacks, we should make it clear that, in my view, the closure of borders between Member States within the European Union, the debate on ceilings, the rejection of refugees and the macabre definition that we are currently experiencing, of so-called safe countries of origin, are precisely part of this false debate, this abuse. This is not only run by a few, but we have prime ministers from our European Union here, we have party leaders here, it goes right through.  Please do not repeat the mistakes of 9/11! What gains in security, cooperation and development have the war against Afghanistan, Iraq and Libya brought to the international community? Terrorism against terrorism is the worst of all responses. Neither airstrikes nor drone strikes have dehydrated the roots of terrorism. I would also refer here to the statements made by the American drone pilots, who have said precisely that their way of waging war has led to the recruitment of new terrorists. Bringing suffering to civilians cannot be our answer.  Join Turkey and Russia at war? No thank you! Together with Russia and Turkey, to launch a political diplomatic offensive? Yes, absolutely! I think that must also be our response to yesterday's developments. As the EU, we have other possibilities, different responsibilities. We should be aware of that. I am thinking here of the situation in the banlieues, but also in other conurbations of European metropolises. This is where we must start with an offensive to integrate and create prospects for young people. We have – and I would also like to point this out – a debate on a new sustainable neighbourhood policy. I would strongly like to support that. That can and must be our answer. I would like to point this out.  Otherwise, please talk about stopping arms exports! Let us not just talk about the sources of finance that need to be withdrawn, we are also talking about stopping exchanges or allowing them to trade in oil and cultural goods. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you and good morning. Thank you for taking the question. You speak about tackling the root causes of terrorism. Would you agree with me that to blame the poor – particularly in urban areas, as has been said today – and to say that somehow to live in poverty and to be disadvantaged is an excuse to go forward into this kind of radicalisation is an insult to all of the decent, good working poor across Europe who have high standards and are just as outraged by this as anyone else? If people have not got a job, have not got work, they should get on their bike and look for it! (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Well, I am used to a number of absurd questions, but you have not listened to me either.  I said as a first sentence: there is no excuse, no justification for anyone to resort to terror and murder people! Point, off! But then we must also be able to talk about the situation, the hopelessness and the lack of prospects, especially of young people in many conurbations, including the European Union.  What does one have to do with the other? I do not put it in a direct context. But I say we have to take care of it. Because this was a misguided integration policy, a non-integration, and that is always a problem, and that is what we have to deal with.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, like all of you, I was deeply shocked by the attacks in Paris two weeks ago, and like all of you, my thoughts are with the victims and their loved ones, I would say to all the victims, those in Paris, Beirut, Sinai and elsewhere. But beyond these emotions, our responsibility as policy makers is not to give this or that measure to our citizens to reassure them, but to take concrete, evidence-based measures that address problems. The first fact is that most of the terrorists who have carried out attacks in recent decades in Europe were known to the police and intelligence services, but not all, simply because the information, the intelligence is not shared. Even though they were known as dangerous people, they were not subjected to the necessary surveillance, simply because of a lack of resources. The first lesson we need to learn is to make intelligence sharing the rule and to give ourselves the means to use that information. From this point of view, the immobility of the governments of the Member States has contributed to the attacks being able to take place. In the face of this, we understand that the response of wanting to put all of our societies under constant surveillance is both inadequate and democratically unacceptable. Inadequate, because it is not the information that is lacking, but its sharing and exploitation. Unacceptable, because in a democracy there is a basic principle which is the proportionality between the measures adopted and the desired effect, and that nothing can justify the widespread supervision of our societies. China is trying and failing to prevent terrorist acts. On the other hand, of course, Mr Schmitt, we must tackle the arms trade, we must tackle the financing of terrorism, we must tackle the abuse of the internet used to spread hate speech and violence. So much for the immediate response. Yes, Mr Cazeneuve, you are right, Europe must recover, but the Europe that must be taken back is that of the Member States which remain bowed to their national self. They have still not realized that when it comes to security, as in so many other matters, there is only shared sovereignty. Now, I think we will not be able to save the money to answer three questions. First, what is the effect of our multiple interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya and elsewhere on the terrorist threat? Do these interventions reduce or increase it? I think the question is open.  Secondly, what about our successful relationship with this successful Islamic state - I mean Saudi Arabia. A state that flouts fundamental rights, crucifies, beheads and cuts off its hands, but with which we have excellent relations - I still remember Mr Valls not long ago. But what do you want? Our addiction to oil makes us dependent on people like that. You have understood that the energy transition is not only an ecological issue, it is also a strategic issue and a security issue. The third question we have to ask ourselves is probably the most fundamental. The other embarrassing fact is that the terrorists who have acted in recent decades have grown up here, have passports , as you said Mr Schmit, I believe - from here. Why have our societies become fertile ground? I am under no illusions, we will still hear hate speech and violence for decades to come. We must ensure that our societies are not fertile ground for these discourses, that they fall flat, and here we can ask ourselves the question of a society where everyone's competition with all is the rule, where consumption is the only horizon, where exclusion progresses every day, where ethnicity or religion is increasingly a factor of exclusion. One wonders how all of this contributes, but is not the sole cause, to the increased risk of terrorism. I know that emotions are strong, I think we must resist the temptation to be overwhelmed by them, because if our societies carried by these emotions were to be tense in a security retreat, the terrorists would have won! I conclude, Mr President, by recalling that France, which was attacked two weeks ago, has put freedom, equality and fraternity at the heart of its republican values. I believe that it is by keeping what was a promise to all our citizens and all the citizens of the world that we will be able to live safely in free, open and democratic societies.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You mentioned Saudi Arabia. I wanted to ask you, do you think these inhumane practices in Saudi Arabia are the work of extremists? Do these inhumane practices have mass public support? But let's leave this one anemocratic country.  Pakistan is a democratic country. Do you think Asia Bibi has been on death row for six years because that is what extremists want? Can honest liberal politicians change anything because these inhumane practices have massive public support? Please answer this question.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Marek, I do not have a precise answer to this question, simply because I do not live in Saudi Arabia.  What I do know is that the saudi regime is spreading a form of Islam that is probably the most totalitarian and fascist in the world. Are citizens asked for their views in Saudi Arabia? I do not remember hearing about elections in what is an absolute monarchy. I do not think that Saudi citizens, and especially citizens, are being asked for their views on whether it is right to crucify, behead or stone. I think few human beings like and support this kind of thing.  In any case, it is a regime with which we are allied when in fact it embodies the successful Islamic State. This is the model Daesch wants to emulate.

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by offering my condolences, on behalf of my Group, to the families and friends of those who were tragically slain in Paris. The attacks really brought home to us the danger that we face on our streets today. If we are to deal with the greatest threat that we and our children face in this century – that of Islamic fundamentalism – we must resolve the situation in Syria. We must first realise who our enemy is, and who our enemy is not. We must not see foreign policy through the eyes of the student common room. We must realise that geopolitics is not black and white; there are very often grey areas, and we must be grown up enough to say that sometimes my enemy’s enemy is my friend, just as we did in the Second World War with Joseph Stalin. We need to put together a grand coalition of nations including not just the Western powers but also Russia, China, India and Muslim nations as well. We must come together to cut out the cancer of radical Islamism which brought carnage onto the streets of Paris and, I believe, will attempt to repeat the same evil on the streets of another European city sometime soon. We need to admit, too, that Bashar al-Assad is not a threat to global peace by comparison with the Islamism of Islamic State. But we must also look at ourselves and ask whether our policies have aided the terrorists – and sadly, the answer is yes. This place is in denial. You are clinging to Schengen and freedom of movement of people, just as Neville Chamberlain clung to appeasing Hitler when it was obvious to all that this man could not be dealt with. The obsession with these policies, and the failure to admit that you have been wrong, are placing the lives of our citizens in danger. I warned in this Chamber six weeks ago – to howls of derision – that freedom of movement of people in Europe would, in the end, lead to freedom of movement of jihad, and, unfortunately, I was proved correct. We must take a hard look in the mirror and ask whether our tolerance is leading to intolerance – and again, the answer must be yes. Last week I took a walk around the Brussels suburb of Molenbeek. I was saddened by what I saw, but unfortunately I was not surprised. It is a snapshot of everything that has gone wrong with the failed policies of political correctness and aggressive multiculturalism. It is a ghetto where many home-grown jihadists live, egged on by Saudi-sponsored Wahhabism. So, if we are to take steps to solve the crisis that we face, we must first cut out its source – which is the problems in Syria – through a global coalition. But at the same time we must take preventive action at home by reinstating border controls and clamping down on Saudi-sponsored Wahhabism, which is a growing, clear and present danger within many of our communities. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: blue-card question. – Mr Nuttall, do you agree with me that in the past, appeasing Stalin brought enormous atrocities to other regions, like my region (Central and Eastern Europe), that and currently appeasing Putin brings atrocities to countries like Ukraine and other countries of Central and Eastern Europe as well?

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card answer. – If we did not do a deal with Stalin – and I am speaking as a historian here – then we would now probably be living in a Nazi- dominated Europe. So we had to do it; we did not really have a choice. Equally, at the same time, you talk about appeasing Putin. Putin is on our side. The real threat in the world today is Islamic fundamentalism. If we have to do a deal with the devil, we must do so to ensure that we cut this cancer out of our society.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, France went through an absolutely appalling ordeal on Friday 13 November. I think the first respect for the victims is to name what murdered them. However, no more in the mouths of our French leaders than in all the speeches I have heard this morning, I have not heard the killer name. The murderer is not terrorism. Terrorism is the weapon in the killer's hand.  The murderer is the ideology he carries and in the name of which terrorism kills. This is Islamist fundamentalism and you have to say it, because if you do not say it, if you are not able to name the enemy, then obviously you will not be able to fight it. But maybe it bothers some of you to name him. Because naming it means questioning a number of international friendships. This raises the question of whether, in fact, we can continue to have Saudi Arabia and Qatar as allies. This raises the question of Turkey's ambiguity with regard to Islamist fundamentalism. This forces us to face each other and to think that, yes, all the international agreements we have made, the international alliances we have made, are actually pushing us today objectively to be allies of Islamist fundamentalism rather than to be the enemies of it.  So I propose that these alliances be changed and I consider that all those who fight against Islamist fundamentalism should be seen as allies, without any reservations. This obviously involves Muslim countries fighting against Islamist fundamentalism: Egypt, the United Arab Emirates. It also, of course, goes through Russia. It goes through Iran. So, as part of this grand coalition, we can consider being effective against Islamist fundamentalism.  But in many respects , I am obliged to say as well - France's alienation from stupid European policies is now an obstacle to the return of French security. At the forefront of these idiotic policies is the issue of mass immigration, which is the breeding ground for communitarianism and the answer to the questions you are asking yourself. But why are there terrorists who were born in our territories, in Europe? Well, because mass immigration has led to communitarianism and communitarianism is the breeding ground in which Islamist fundamentalism comes to seek and recruit its future soldiers.  The European Commission announces that three million migrants will arrive in the European Union next year. Of course we do not put a line of equality between migrants and terrorists. But the fact remains that what I denounced in this Parliament in September, namely the infiltration of jihadists amid the flow of migrants, is a reality. That reality killed last Friday. You can pretend not to see that, but that reality is there and you cannot ignore it. To continue to leave these flows of migrants uncontrolled when you know full well that the Union and the countries bordering the Union are totally unable to control anything, let alone the identity of those who arrive, is to deprive ourselves of the means to combat this terrible danger.  So, I'm telling you, we want to get back to our national borders. We do not trust Europe's borders, which are a real sieve. Today, the French borders are again temporarily controlled. We will do everything in our power to ensure that they are controlled absolutely definitively. You talk about controls, intelligence, but what controls? Passports held by terrorists are not false passports. These are real passports issued by the Islamic State in the administrations they have taken control of, in Syria. This, too, is a reality that must be looked at in the face.  In the same way, you have imposed austerity on us. This austerity forced us to disarm. It is because of austerity that the Union has imposed on countries that we have fewer military personnel, that we have fewer policemen, that we have fewer gendarmes, that we have fewer customs officers. We no longer want your austerity policy. We no longer want you to decide what the priority is in our budget. Again, we want to regain our budgetary sovereignty and decide that it is more useful for us today to give a budgetary priority to the security of our territory. We are the ones who want to decide this! Since November 13, the state of French spirit has changed. The European institutions must understand that, for us, nothing will ever be the way it was before. The madness of migration, the hatred of borders, the "austerity" obsession, the poor choices in international alliances have become dangers clearly identified by the French. A growing minority shared our views on these issues. There is no doubt that the gaze is now overwhelmingly lucid. We will continue to denounce these dangers in order to defend the security of the French people in the face of the actions that I consider criminal of the European institutions.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, for decades, indeed, the majority of this Parliament, the governments of the Member States and the European Commission have encouraged the mass immigration of populations that are too often heterogeneous in relation to our peoples, our values, our history, our aspirations. Multicultural society is a multi-conflict society. You have encouraged the granting of our citizenship, including to people who were not worthy of it and who had not asked for it. You demanded that those who were even guilty of crimes and crimes remain in our territories, the behaviour of which should have led to their immediate and final expulsion. You have destroyed the borders you want, today, in haste and confusion, to restore at least temporarily. You have tolerated, or even financed, proselytizing activities, Islamist extremists interpreting their sacred texts as justification for their calls to crime.  Today you are reaping the bitter fruits of your policies. Do you think you are absolve yourself of your responsibilities by expressing your compassion?  You believe you are doing this by requiring a record of all air passengers whose companies are already keeping track, disarming hunters or honest citizens, as if the terrorists had registered their weapons with the administration.  The information, we have it, what we need is action but you are no longer able to.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Madam President, on behalf of the French delegation of the Group of the European People's Party, I would like to express my gratitude to all our colleagues, to our partners, to the Presidency, Minister, and to the Commission for their expressions of sympathy. After the migration crisis, Islamist terrorism makes us touch, on the one hand, the impotence of our States when they want to act alone and, on the other hand, one of the fundamental weaknesses of the European Union. Even when it has legal jurisdiction, it does not have the administrative means, let alone the financial means to apply directly itself. It must rely on the goodwill of the Member States and their services, and that is where everything gets bogged down. With regard to the fight against terrorism, the first action plan was adopted after 11 September 14 years ago. What's the case? A European counter-terrorism coordinator has been established. It has no staff, no budget. Worse, we have developed effective means and we are now discovering that they are all shockingly under-used by the member states' services. This is the case with Europol, as is the case with Eurojust, as is the case with the SIS II information file, which we took seven years to develop together. As for the NRL, I see that responsibility is being blamed. I hope we do not wait for the next attack. In conclusion, we are able to legislate in good weather. This Parliament likes to teach moral lessons to the world in all weathers, but when there are serious crises, we are not able to prevent or manage them. We need a political Europe. Let's organize it, organize ourselves to do politics and not just good feelings.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, I would first like to thank all the colleagues who sent messages of solidarity with the French republic to the French delegation and also to thank the colleagues here in the European Parliament who have allowed the national anthem, the Marseillaise, to be heard in our Chamber.  But to those who confuse French identity with the migration issue, to those who forget that French identity is linked to hospitality, I want to recall the words of the President of the Republic before the Greek Parliament when, on an official visit last October, he reminded us that we must address the intelligence of the peoples and not arouse their fears.  In this sense, we must show solidarity with what happened in Paris, Saint-Denis, but also in Beirut, Bamako or Tunis. We must provide a European response to this situation. We need more internal security, more external security, more internal solidarity, more external solidarity.  Inner solidarity - this is of course the PNR. We are mobilized to get it and I hope that by the end of the year, rather than putting oil on the fire, we will reach this necessary agreement, which is part of the system, we know that.  With regard to external security, the French request for the mobilization, for the first time, of Article 42, paragraph 7, shows us how much we need to make progress in order to establish a Europe of defence and not suffer, helplessly, the disintegration alongside us of the Syrian State. Mobilizing a foreign policy.  Internal solidarity, because we cannot allow a situation to develop where the terrorist threat and the flaws in the system are too quickly unravelling agreements reached laboriously between the Member States and generating and fertilizing amalgams. We must not forget the essentials: Syrian refugees are first and foremost the victims of the same enemy as ours, namely Daesh.  We must also ensure that our economic policies dry up the soil on which terrorists recruit in our neighbourhoods, in our territories. Finally, external solidarity, because, as Chancellor Merkel said here, we must also rethink our policy so that, in these countries, the state can be built, democracy exists and people live with a view to living in decent conditions. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Blue card question. Today is World Day against Violence against Women. It does not believe that, in the fight against terrorism too, we must invest and do more, on the part of Europe, at cultural level, to ensure that what happens in Europe does not happen, unfortunately, in many realities where Islamic fundamentalism reigns: respecting women, allowing them to live as all European women live should be a priority. I believe that we must also defeat the culture that leads to the women's police in Raqqa and to having caged women sold for $10 to Isis fighters.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: "blue card" answer. "It is certain that Mr Tajani's blue card was in response to my intervention, but I want to share with him this conviction which is that when diplomats have not seen the situation of women in Afghanistan deteriorate, and have taken too long to understand that when the situation of women is reached, the whole civilization is affected. We continue to pay the price. I therefore, ladies and gentlemen, quite agree that the issue of the status of women is also an element on which democracies must be mobilised without interruption.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – The political structures of the Arab world are weakening, before our eyes radical Islamism is gaining strength, responsible for acts of terror in Iraq, Syria, Israel, Lebanon, Libya, Mali, Tunisia and more recently also on the territory of the European Union on several occasions, in France – including most recently Paris – and Copenhagen. I offer my condolences to the families of all victims and loved ones, regardless of their nationality or religion. I believe that this situation requires our great mobilisation and solidarity, the cooperation of the closest capitals, the mobilisation of community opportunities. However, I question the constructive role of countries such as Russia because of their aggressive involvement in the neighbourhood and their actions towards their own society. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – You said at the very end that you questioned the role of a country such as Russia. Would it not be very good to see that, just after these tragic events, the world, the United States, the European Union, Russia, even Saudi Arabia are perhaps finding a common road map. And let's understand that terrorist organizations are global. That is why politics must also be global. Why are you now blaming Russia, which has shown itself to be acting constructively?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I question the role of Russia, because there is a record of inspiring terrorist activity by the current regime of Russia towards members of its own society, as well as in the neighbourhood. For example, there are the so-called ‘green men’ in Ukraine.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Madam President, first of all, on behalf of the French colleagues in my group, I want to thank you each and every one of you for your heart-hearted messages of friendship and support. Paris has been touched in what is most precious: its youth. It was his children who were injured, his children who were murdered. Paris suffers, but Paris continues to live and stand thanks to solidarity, the unity of its people, the whole country and Europe.  What do these terrorists who have chosen to become the enemies of our society, our values, our way of life want? They want life to stop. That's why we'll continue to live. They want war between us. That is why we will not renounce mutual understanding in any way. And they want us to be scared. That is why we must take all the decisions to protect, truly protect, and defend, truly defend our fellow citizens!  This is what we expect, what we demand from European leaders, heads of state and government. Because, as we know, the threat is there. It is serious and it is sustainable. The urgent need is for a Europe of security and intelligence. A true European PNR, the sharing of data of terrorism suspects, the creation of a file listing foreign fighters, systematic checks at the external borders of Schengen are measures expected by all, terrorism having no borders.  The urgency is to mobilize against totalitarian fanaticism that kills, tortures, beheads, crucifies, rapes. The major powers, the United States, Russia, the European Union, and the regional powers, including Turkey and Iran, must unite to intensify the fight against the Islamic State. But at the same time, and this is essential, they must work towards a political solution to stabilize Syria. Tunis, Bamako, Paris, Beirut, Sharm el-Sheikh, Baghdad, Ankara, the list of recent attacks is long, too long. The times we're going to live are going to be difficult. They will require that European leaders live up to the events and that the peoples of Europe remain united, united and standing. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – I just want to say that I sympathise with the French people tremendously but, Ms de Sarnez, you and Mr Verhofstadt seem to think that the answer to this is to set up a pan-European police state. I do not think that. I think that the various nations should work together – the various security authorities of the various states should work together. But we should not have a pan-European police state. Do you agree with me on that? I am sure such was not your intention.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: "blue card" answer. What we owe to the victims, ladies and gentlemen, what we owe to the 130 dead in Paris and the hundreds injured is a response characterized by the firmness and guarantee of the safety of our fellow citizens. The first of freedoms is security.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, Mr President, let me begin by bowing to the victims of the crimes committed in Paris and Saint-Denis, as well as those in Lebanon, Yemen, Mali, Tunis, the tourists of the Russian plane, the victims of Ankara, those from Cameroon, but also those from Syria, Iraq and elsewhere. I would also like to thank all those of you who sent messages of solidarity to France after the murderous madness it suffered. We are always overwhelmed, upset, bruised by these lives stolen in the prime of our lives, by the massacre of this beautiful, fiery and smiling youth, who have fallen under the fire of bloody fanaticism.  Our urgent duty today is to bring to life human solidarity, citizen unity, to do everything to ensure that our fellow citizens of the Muslim faith are not confused with murderous obscurantism. Our duty is to make people aware that refugees are not the cause of terrorism, but that they are the first victims. Our duty is to contribute to the security and protection of our citizens, with in mind that security will be all the stronger as freedoms and democracy are preserved. Our duty is to reflect on the past, on the causes that may have produced these abominations. Among them were the wars that destroyed Iraq, then Libya. The murky alliances with the purveyors and financiers of the new fascisms, the current reorientations of political, diplomatic and military strategies, placing them under the aegis of the United Nations, are first steps. But it is time to get the Monarchies out of the Gulf and Turkey - which yesterday shot down a Russian plane fighting Daesch - from their murky games and clearly support the Kurdish forces acting on the ground to push back the Islamic State.  Lessons must be learned from the positive role of public services and thus out of the current budget rationing. It is time for human investment in the commons of the police, health, customs, justice, local authorities, education and culture. At the same time, we need to rethink European security and justice cooperation to make it effective. Finally, there will be no way out if the people are not given new hope, which is why the European Union should take the initiative of major Euro-Mediterranean and Euro-African reconstruction and co-development plans in the area of infrastructure and services, in order to enable the people to access the human common good. Consider that if we stopped military spending for a single week, it would allow all children to access school. All over the world, for the past few days, the Marseillaise, our French national anthem, has been resounding. May with him live everywhere, in the congress of lives, the triptych of our Republic: freedom, equality, fraternity. (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, I would like to ask our colleague, Mr Le Hyaric, if, after all these terrorist attacks in Europe, it is not time to establish a European Union counter-terrorism agency, with its own intelligence services and specialised military counter-terrorism forces?  Do you agree, Mr. Le Hyaric, that the time has come to do so?

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: "blue card" answer. What I see is that there have been provisions, the first time under Mr Solana's responsibility, on two occasions, the first time under Mr Solana's responsibility. I believe those provisions were revised in 2008 and we are not in a position to coordinate our intelligence and security services today.  Therefore, yes, we need European cooperation, but not just a security apparatus. Security, yes! Security, I don't think that's the right way. It also involves human development, as I just said earlier.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking all the colleagues who have supported us in the face of the horror that France has experienced. Today we share the grief of the families and loved ones of the victims, the pain and the shock of the wounded. We share the horror that struck the French, but also experienced by other countries, victims of barbarism, such as Tunisia yesterday. I thank all public services for their dedicated work and hard work. We must also salute the solidarity shown by citizens who have helped complete strangers, who have opened their doors to those foreigners who sought refuge in chaos.  But some of the words taken in this Chamber do not seem to me to be up to the task. Some reactions are nauseating, aiming to use this drama for political purposes to attack their political opponent. You hold up our values - freedom, equality, fraternity - without recognizing the solidarity that underlies them, without grasping the humanist message of a nation that, struck by hatred, has responded with tolerance.  To act effectively, let us ask ourselves about the world in which we live and shape with our laws. Radicalization, hatred, wars do not come from nothing, there is fertile ground for jihadism: the inequalities and oppression that are growing stronger every day. It is also a society in which some refer to refugees fleeing acts as scapegoats as the attacks of 13 November. So, as a response on our territory, they want to smoke us with announcements as symbolic as ineffective: the loss of nationality, the proliferation of laws of general surveillance. We are wasted precious time in convincing the public that these security gadgets are the solution to the terrorist risk.  I would not have words harsh enough to denounce the lack of cooperation that allowed the intolerable to happen. Already in January, the heads of state and government promised us more cooperation, coordination between police and judicial services. Yet, ten months later, they come to us again the same promise, even though we have proof that the sharing of information between France, Germany and Belgium might have prevented this macabre Friday the 13th. How ironic to learn that it is thanks to third states that the French authorities have been able to find the accomplices of the terrorists! Let us break down our intelligence services, share our information, European-citizens the fight against terrorism, create a European prosecutor's office, fight seriously against arms trafficking and tackle the illicit financing of terrorism. Let's finally be clear-headed. As for our foreign policy, France and the European states have for too long supported dangerous links with Qatar and Saudi Arabia, and I would like to end by saying that our democracy, which is their target, must be our weapon. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. Mrs Rivasi, you have made some very interesting remarks and I share them to some extent, particularly when you denounce the dangerous links we have had with Qatar and Saudi Arabia.  Nevertheless, you have also made more obscure and for me more disturbing remarks on the ground for the development of terrorism in Europe. So I ask you the question bluntly: do you accuse the National Front of being for anything in the development of Islamist terrorism in France? Thank you for giving a clear answer.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: "blue card" answer. "Mr. Lebreton, listen to the National Front, you bring everything back to this. But there is more important than the National Front. There has been a sense of exclusion among these populations. This is a failure in terms of integration that would have been possible at the level of the different suburbs and different territories. This is where there is a breeding ground for exclusion that could lead to jihadism.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, please could I just say that, because of the importance of the debate, I have allowed a blue card. But I just want to say that it may be impossible to allow blue cards for every single speaker because we do have a formal sitting at 12 noon. So I would ask you to respect that.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after the horror, the mourning and the sorrow, a politician has a duty to face reality with lucidity. It is time to become aware of the crippling angelism that characterizes part of this Parliament. I take as an example what Mr Verhofstadt pointed out, namely the blocking of the PNR file for four years under the pretext of respect for individual freedom. But too much freedom kills freedom and undermines human rights.  It is also time to name things by their right name. Why talk about Daesch? This exotic name remains nebulous and does not reflect reality.  The criminologist, Alain Bauer, rightly pointed this out. The name "Islamic State" captures exactly the reality. We are dealing with a state and that state is slaughtering in the name of a religion. It is in the name of this religion that he destroys our treasures of civilization, that he massacres his own compatriots and it is out of religious hatred that he kills our youth who are guilty of loving music and wine. He hates our freedom to believe or not to believe in God.  As stupid as it was, it wasn't Bush's America's intervention in Iraq in 2003 that created chaos. This intervention served only as a match. It's a long-smouldering fire. The colonization of settlements that overwhelms France has been ideologically and politically organized by our governments for more than thirty years. It is not surprising that the Islamic State is recruiting its terrorists here. What are the responses to the strikes of these states in Syria? I am not sure that these strikes in Syria calm the young people of our suburbs, young radical Islamists revolted. We have an immigration problem. It is uncontrolled and unassimilated immigration that jeopardizes the balance of our societies. To say so is neither racist nor xenophobic.  We must denounce the complacency of our rulers towards Qatar, as everyone has said here, and towards Saudi Arabia. Under the pretext of juicy commercial interests, we treat as partners states that advocate radical Islam and have the cynicism to refuse to accept migrants, even Muslims...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: My condolences go out to the many victims of terror in Paris and their families. It is not only the French citizens who are shocked, but all European citizens.  The perpetrators are called criminal terrorists or extremists. I am telling you, Mr President, these were not ordinary criminals or extremists. These were well-educated citizens with normal jobs. They were devout Muslims driven by an ideal, the ideal of global Islam. They were martyrs for the glory of Allah, heroes of the religion of peace. For example, they are seen in their own circles and so they are seen by most of the world's Muslims. The problem is not IS. The problem is Islam. Islam cannot be reconciled with our Western values and I ask this Parliament the question of conscience: do you want to guarantee the dominance of our Western values in the EU? Then you must fight Islam. We must stop foreign funding of mosques, deport hate imams and close national borders for Muslim countries. If we don't, the next attack is only a matter of time. It's up to you.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, the recent attacks in Paris serve as a brutal reminder of the dangers from terrorism right in the heart of Europe. In my own constituency, the Paris attacks have cast the minds of our people back to the days when IRA terrorists bombed our capital city. Having endured this threat for many years, the message from the people of Northern Ireland to Paris and France is: we stand with you in solidarity and vow to work with you to combat the evil of terrorism. I also hope that the Sinn Féin Members of this House will have the decency to apologise for the intervention made by their party colleague when he stated that he did not consider ISIS to be terrorists. What a repugnant view to hold! This fight can only be won by tackling the infrastructure of terror and the radicalisation of youth with a strong coalition of those dedicated to the cause of democracy and freedom and a clear strategy to win. I and my party await such a strategy to be outlined by our own Prime Minister and will not be found wanting if such a strategy will deliver clear actions against the terrorists. Let us stand together to defeat such evil and support the victims of terror.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Madam President, this is the second time in two days that Mrs Dodds has insulted and defamed our colleagues at Sinn Féin. We therefore ask you once again that this matter be brought before the Office of Parliament. It is unacceptable for colleagues to be insulted and defamed in a democratic debate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We note your comments. Colleagues have the option of replying to catch-the-eye, but we note your comments and take them on board.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, terrorists will attack us, but they will not defeat us if we maintain international cooperation; if we maintain the unity of all political forces; if we support what cops, judges and prosecutors do; and if we respect the dignity of the victims of terrorism. The pain of the victims delegitimates any attempt to justify violence. The Islamic State is an international threat. He doesn't ask if we're from the north or south, left or right, to kill us. For them we are guilty, we are unfaithful for the mere fact of being free, and that is why we deserve to die. Jihadism is an ideology, it is not a religion. Jihadism hates freedom, so all of us who love freedom must be against terrorism, united by freedom and life, whatever our religion. And we must be constant. We can't legislate in the attack. When they stop killing, we relax. We think they're gone, but they never leave, they're always there. If they don't kill anymore, it's because they can't kill anymore, not because they don't want to kill anymore. We have to keep this in mind: they are always preparing for their next attack. And we should always be preparing our next law against them. Ladies and gentlemen, freedom and security are not antagonistic terms. There is no freedom without security, there is no freedom that should not be assured. Security is the guarantee of the freedom of the European people.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, coming from Madrid, the city that suffered the greatest attack on European territory, one wonders, a decade later, how much we have learned and how far we have made in the prevention and fight against radicalism and terrorism. The answer is that it has not been enough, that we have not advanced or learned what is necessary.  It has not been enough when it comes to information: we still do not share the information needed to attack terrorism. It has not been enough when it comes to cutting off the sources of funding of terrorist groups.
