It has not been enough in the social response: austerity policies have further damaged education, integration, social services, public services...  Nor has it been enough to structure a common Union foreign policy that responds coherently to conflicts, where these radicalisations and terrorist groups are fed. Nor have we done what is necessary to build a European response.  Indeed, today the Council presents us with a number of measures which we support, but many of these measures were available to the Member States, which have not used them.  There has been an anti-terrorism strategy since 2015. There is a counter-terrorism coordinator. Europol exists. There is Eurojust. There is the COSI. So let's use what we have and launch the new instruments. But if we only have one national response, terrorists will use the security gaps between states. If we only react to the attacks, they will determine the agenda and the time when they do us the most harm.  If we are unable to avoid partisan struggle, we will fall into the struggle of European values and will not be able to ensure their validity.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Allow me to speak as a Fleming who spent much of his childhood in Brussels and around Brussels. "My Brussels, I'm in your pocket. A warm coat, your inner city." They are the opening words of a popular Flemish song that still give me chills, because my childhood is largely there in the narrow streets of Brussels. And my heart bleeds when I hear that the Paris attacks were set up and planned in Molenbeek.  The question is not what went wrong. The question is: where to start? A wrong Belgian and European asylum and migration policy in combination with inefficient local structures. Brussels, a city of 1.1 million inhabitants, separate region, own parliament and government. In addition, the city has combined 19 mayors and six police zones - yes, you hear it well - with an electoral policy characterized by laissez-faire laissez-passer, which took precedence over the need for integration and integration. Radicalisation and criminals easily found their European base here.  The time for purposeful inaction is over. Priority must be given to security, tackling radicalism, tackling organised crime and the illegal economy. For the fight against international terror, we are also looking at the Union, with strong Member States working together. We urgently need to get rid of the European Union's high 'dream factory content'. Protecting our citizens starts at the union's external borders. If we do not do so, this Union will be doomed.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, after every attack, like everybody else, I feel grief, shock, horror, and anger at the murderers. I also feel mounting frustration because what follows is a familiar ritual by now. First, we get a lot of solemn statements about our shared values (but quite frankly, I have heard some statements here that make me doubt whether we have shared values). Then we hear a lot of solemn statements about democratic values, fundamental rights and the rule of law. Much of this is lip service, because a raft of new measures is announced after every single attack, but their effectiveness is doubtful. The Council and Commission have so far refused an evaluation on the basis of Article 7, as requested by this House. Maybe now they will finally do it. Implementation of the measures by the Member States is patchy and inadequate. Then there is a near obsession with electronic mass surveillance – whereas what is needed is much more investment in human intelligence, in people on the ground who know what is going on in the banlieues and in Molenbeek. Why do we tolerate the existence of ghettos in our cities that are no-go areas for the police – where the police do not even dare to get out of their cars – so they cannot know what is going on? Let us start investing in human intelligence. Lastly, with regard to the passenger name record (PNR) proposal, I am asking the Council and the Commission to stop the campaign of lies. It is a lie to suggest that this House, or even – as is sometimes claimed – the centre-left groups in it, are blocking a PNR system. We have voted, we are committed, we are working on this issue: but commitment does not mean a blank cheque, ok? This is democracy: we are entitled to our views. We are negotiating, and now it is for the Council to move. The ball is in their court.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: Madam President, I thank the colleagues and institutions who have joined us, the French, in the ordeal.  France, ladies and gentlemen, has always defeated its aggressors and will do so once again on this occasion. Without getting lost in the fantasies of security and, I hope, without losing sight of the principles that animate the best of its republican history.  In the moment we live, the main virtue, it seems to me, is discernment. We would benefit, here as elsewhere, not to speak of a war of civilization, because what we are experiencing is not a war of civilization for the reason that Daesch is not a civilization but a totalitarianism. This is not a war of civilizations because they are not warriors that we face but cowardly assassins who attack helpless people and by surprise.  As for discernment, Islam is no more involved in this matter than any other belief. Once again, religious fundamentalism is the mask of a war for money and money. We must also give up stigmatizing poverty as a source of crime. The crime has no social origin. Crime has an ideological and human origin. He starts from all walks of place. It would be good if we did not point the finger so rudely at this or that neighbourhood when the children of the rich as well as those of the poor can be swept away by the folly of death. And if we have to make a point here, let us remember the responsibility that has been taken by all those who have wanted to weaken states in their regal missions. In my country, there are 12,000 fewer police officers, the army has been reduced by 20%. All of this was one of the causes that contributed to the lack of resources to deal with the blows we were about to take. We must put an end to this policy of weakening the public service. As has been said, we must put an end to this benevolent blindness and amnesia towards such and such countries which are merely practising in large and with the institutions of the State what a group like Daesch and others are doing. The cause of terrorism lies in the wars between the powers to control an area of the world where immense wealth is controlled and where immense wealth occurs. It is therefore by stopping the war that terrorism will be stopped. It is not by making up the entire population of Europe that we will learn anything more than what we already know about the risk it contains. The cause of terrorism is in war. It's the war that needs to be stopped. The cause of terrorism is in the money. It is these circulations that must be stopped. I am in favour of a universal coalition, for it is universal humanity that is being called into question; a universal coalition under the authority and aegis of the only body with universal jurisdiction: the United Nations. In this moment, let us share the motto of the Enlightenment appropriated by my homeland and proposed to all humanity: "freedom, equality, brotherhood"; not "PNR for everyone"!

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: – Madam President, the recent terrible attacks have not been the first in Europe. We knew about the threat, and we owe it to the victims to reconsider if our actions are delivering effective security or not. Already after 9/11, joint investigation teams were set up under Europol and Eurojust to enforce the cooperation of the Member State authorities. However, for 14 years this has barely been used, and there is no money, no personnel and no political will from the Member States to strengthen European cooperation, in particular for going after terrorist suspects in Europe. In Europol, information sharing is almost dysfunctional, as large numbers of Member States do not share information on known suspects and risks. If this were different today, we would perhaps have prevented a number of recent attacks. But instead of learning from our mistakes, we just go on with the same ineffective measures we have taken. The current proposal by the Council on an EU PNR directive is in fact an extraordinarily expensive model of 28 silos full of completely irrelevant information on innocent travellers. At the same time, we have already known for years who is on which plane in Europe, but we did not follow up on alerts regarding known suspects travelling to Syria and back to the European Union. This is why we need to focus. We need targeted information-sharing and joint investigations. This is what we should deliver and spend our money on – nothing else.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, following the Attacks in Paris, which we all strongly and unreservedly condemn, the risk that fear will once again dictate the political line in Europe and do so in the wrong way is high. Declaring war on terror with more war and terror is not the solution. Since 11 September, the UNITED States has been followed by new victims, new terrorist groups, destabilisation in areas of the world and migratory flows. History teaches us that most terrorist organisations are neutralised through political processes aimed at eliminating all forms of support for terrorist groups and not through the direct use of military force. The terrorist threat today does not just come from outside but is lingers within Europe: we have seen that several of those responsible for the attacks turn out to be young, European citizens who were born here, who live here, and who are also the economic and social factors responsible for social exclusion, inequalities, discrimination, lack of integration, which predispose them to violence. We should therefore ask ourselves whether these economic and social factors, these European economic and social policies, are not also unsuccessful and complicit in the formation of this terrorism. We must therefore focus on preventing radicalisation through education, tolerance, mutual respect for cultures and social inclusion.  We must also overcome the reticence of states to increase the exchange of intelligence information, which is essential in the fight against terrorism, which is of a cross-border nature. The hope is that, in the name of security, fundamental rights will not once again be violations.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: – Mr President, there is a problem with the interpretation. I hear only Dutch on all channels, so maybe they are the only ones who are working here!

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Apparently everything is in Flemish on all channels. Anyway, we will try to move on.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Also from the Austrian side, from my party, from the Freedom Party in Austria, solidarity with France and compassion for the bereaved! But it is also the time today to speak here in clear terms – whether you remember Charlie Hebdo, this cowardly attack on freedom of expression, whether it was the cowardly attack on the Jewish Museum in Brussels or now the massacre in Paris that affects us all.  Of course, it is clear that you are sitting on the shards of a multicultural society. They are also sitting on the shard of a failed security policy, where their eyes have been closed and their heads put in the sand, when it became clear that in certain Islamic Islamist circles the situation is becoming more and more radicalised.  In order to draw the right conclusions now, also out of respect for the victims in Paris, one can only say that you must make a U-turn on your policy. You have to close the borders. They must ensure that extremism and Islamism are banished from Europe.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the Communist Party condemns the deadly criminal attack in Paris and expresses its condolences to the families of the wronged. ISIS is a criminal mechanism created, trained, equipped by the United States, NATO and its allies. It is used as a pretext for the intensity of repression, the restriction of popular freedoms, the targeting of migrant refugees, the strengthening of racism and xenophobia.  The main question is who exploits and will then take advantage of the long-dead murderous blow. Already, with provisions and mechanisms long in place, such as Article 42, the European Union is promoting a new round of escalation of repression against peoples and imperialist intervention in the region.  At the heart is competition for energy in the Middle East and Africa, which claim a position of power between the United States and powerful European Union states in competition with Russia and China. The people must be vigilant. This is also highlighted by turkey's dangerous downing of a Russian aircraft with NATO cover. No new imperialist intervention, no involvement of Greece in the dangerous plans of the European Union, the US and NATO.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, after the tragedy in Paris, we are still largely in the time of mourning, but also in the time of the investigation, which is far from over, and this obliges us to keep a lot of composure and to exercise a great deal of caution before drawing conclusions about the dysfunctions that will have to be identified.  There is no doubt, however, that a conscience test will be required at all levels. Even today, I have heard Europe being often questioned in this regard. The Union will not be able to exempt itself from this review, but it must also be recognised that the trial is a bit fast in areas such as internal security, counter-terrorism and intelligence, where the bulk of prerogatives remain national prerogatives, with States scrupulously and jealously watching that this is still the case.  It is also true that the European institutions, including this Parliament, will not be able to refuse to face the scale of the threat and the essential adaptation of our security arrangements. Many of us have forgotten that the Schengen model of course provides for freedom of movement, but in a secure area at its external borders and well coordinated inside. These dimensions have been dramatically neglected and need to be addressed urgently! The NRNP, we have talked about a lot, is a collective tool that is not a magic wand, of course, but which has an obvious use in dealing with the scale and plasticity of suspicious movements on our continent. So we have to get to work, without delay and with realism.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We will only defeat terror if we act together – internally, but also externally. That is why we Social Democrats welcome the Vienna talks, the initiative of Federica Mogherini and some foreign ministers to bring together the fighting groups in Syria together with the Us, Russia, Iran and Saudi Arabia. Bombs may be a necessary part of our struggle, but they will not bring a solution unless there is a common vision, a common plan for the future of Syria. Secondly, it is precisely close cooperation with the Arab and Muslim states that is essential for us. I would remind you of King Abdullah II's speech in Jordan in March in this House. For it is not a question of defending the Christian West against the Islamic world, but of defending civilised humanity against well-organised criminals. Mr Schmit, I would like to thank Mr Schmit for his You have announced what the Council intends to do and decide in the near future. I welcome it, and I would like to believe it. After all, people want to see action, they want answers to their questions: what is being done about those who finance terror? What is being done about those who allow this funding? What is being done about those who buy the oil from the terrorists and organise the art theft? And what is being done not only to equip our intelligence services in the best possible way, but also to finally force them to cooperate? And when do we finally forbid ourselves to export weapons that make these wars, these terrorist states, capable of acting? I am not talking about the illegalons – anyway – I am talking about the legal but not legitimate ones. And here a German Member is speaking, I know what I am talking about. The people of our homeland do not expect more minutes of silence and resolutions from those who govern them, but action – visible, consistent and common in the EU!

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I have been listening to this empty debate for more than an hour with great disappointment, dear colleagues. Apparently, most either do not understand or do not want to understand the reasons for another attack on European citizens and civilization. Islamic radicalism is not just terrorism, it is a real military attack on Europe. Multiculturalism and integration do not work and will not work in Islamist slums in Europe.  The real enemy is in power in Saudi Arabia and Turkey, which finance and organize The Islamic State. With the wave of illegal immigrants returning to Europe, European jihadists are returning to sow death, chaos and destruction. As we welcome these teddy bear people to the stations, we will send our loved ones by candlelight into the squares, dear gentlemen. Mr Juncker, the fact that you are speaking the same thing after Charlie Hebdo and today, it speaks to me that you have not tried to learn anything new. The Commission's proposal is partly ridiculous, inappropriate and unworkable. An immediate closure of the external borders, a halt to the migrant flow, the extradition of illegal immigrants, the dismantling of Islamist slums in Europe, the physical destruction of Islamic State is needed. Everything else, dear colleagues, is another empty talk.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, let me first, once again express my condolences to the victims and their loved ones. The horrors that took place in Paris, the shock of these barbaric attacks on these young men, have no possible justification. To the victims, to the Parisians and to the French, I would like to say that we are with you. We feel your pain, we share your anger and we have the same determination to fight together these cowardly terrorists. The solidarity expressed by a large part of the European population proves that the spirit of Europe and European values really exist. Unfortunately, our common policy is not yet up to the level of solidarity of our citizens.  Protectionist and selfish nationalism still far too often trumps the idea of European unity. In the days and months ahead, more work will be needed together. We need a European NRP system. However, what will be the purpose of this system if the member states' intelligence services are not prepared to exchange information. But together we can turn on the light that will light up the night. Together, we can defend our values and our society and together we will overcome hatred and then reflect the spirit of the City of Light.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – We are trying to convince us that terrorism has no religion, but it is clear that today terrorists are seeking to use religion as an incentive to commit terrorist acts in the rest of the world. It is also clear that terrorists are trying to take advantage of refugees. We don't have a day to get someone with a gun in our hands to shout about the great Allah, kill people, and kidnap hostages. And by the way, we must recognise that this is a consequence of the politicians and policies that have given birth to the Arab Spring, autumn or winter. Spark is enough to cause a fire, even the most modern means are not enough to extinguish it. When it covers a large area, the wall of fire is extinguished not by water, but by other fire. Let us not allow the fire of terrorism to spread such a wall of fire.  Uncontrolled migration in Europe must not be from tomorrow, as must europe's external borders open to refugees. It is necessary for the intelligence services of the States of the Community to exchange available information on potential dangers expeditiously and to prevent their activities accordingly. If necessary, deportation from the European Union. European society today needs security most. It is for his assurance, not for the welfare of refugees, that we should pay full attention.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European The horrific massacre in Paris was more than just a terrorist attack. The beginning of an open war, not just against France, but against Europe. This war has several fronts. One is the act of terrorism, the threat of it, the instrection of anarchy. The other is flooding Europe with migrants, including terrorists. If we don't stop them, millions will come next year. The chances of their integration are minimal, building their own parallel society, jeopardising Europe's identity. I quote Angela Merkel from 2010: 'the multicultural society has failed'. We're at war. EU decision-makers who do not act accordingly but bury their heads in the sands of false tolerance are guilty of war crimes.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I welcome the Commission and also the Council, ladies and gentlemen. I am a little saddened by the fact that the old game is already starting again here today: the European Parliament is scolding the Member States and the Member States are saying that the European Parliament is not acting. I do not think it makes sense to reproach each other, but to ask me who would prefer to analyse the security gaps and close them together. Whether this starts with the PNR system, which is a system for identifying not only known but also unknown serious criminals, but whether this is also the European list of dangers, which is still not standing and is still not brought together at European level.  But then we would also need automatic data matching, for example with the PNR system or with Eurodac or with the future Smart Borders package, because we want to let ordinary travellers travel normally, but identify the criminals who want to enter our country or Europe or want to leave and go to war. If we were simply to accept such normal and sensible proposals! I am always fascinated when it comes to data protection. On the one hand, Jan Philipp Albrecht claims that we can now exchange data freely. At the same time, I am aware of the many obstacles that lead police officers to say: I cannot cope with this in everyday life, because before I make a mistake in it, I prefer not to do anything. So we need to do things for police officers in such a way that they can exchange them effectively and use them accordingly. We must also give Europol the staff to do so, and then I would like the Greens to say yes to this.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In the mourning for the victims of Paris, a word quickly mixed: war. We must shut down this linguistic rhetoric! The United States had declared a war on terror, justifying, among other things, Guantanamo and torture. The assassins are serious criminals and murderers, and their attacks are indiscriminately directed against people and have only one goal: to destroy democratic and open societies. They must not achieve this goal! Yes, we need to examine our security policy; Debunking gun control, terrorist propaganda on the Internet, preventing the financing of terrorist networks and adapting police training and staffing. But all reforms will be ineffective if Member States do not finally cooperate more effectively, use existing measures and exchange knowledge. The European safety net at the moment sometimes looks like a Swiss cheese. It is therefore irresponsible and wrong to give the impression in the public debate that individual measures, such as the storage of passenger data, could directly create greater security. And there are still many unanswered questions. It is precisely in this area that an nuptling by the ECJ, as was the case recently with Safe Harbour or data retention, would be problematic, because it would shake confidence in our ability to act. In principle, it is true that we need a change in the situation in Syria, and in view of the radicalisation here in Europe, we must put an end to social and social exclusion in the long term. Integration measures are not nice additions, but an integral part of a policy of internal security and the safeguarding of internal peace.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The horrific terrorist attacks in Paris have shown us terror in its worst form, a terror that is all that matters indiscriminate killing. As long as we have such people in the country – such terrorists – there can be no security. There are always possibilities for attacks. In other words, the only way is for us to really drain the milieus in which this radical fundamentalist Islamism thrives, to refer those who operate these milieus as undesirable seofs of the country. But we can only do this with people who are not citizens of European countries. We can only do this with foreigners. That is why we must also bring citizenship law into contact. We must also re-create the possibility of we being able to deprive immigrants who have been naturalised – such as these terrorists – or their sons of citizenship. I believe that this security risk will no longer be a different way.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen today we are called upon, with respect for the victims of terrorism and with responsibility to the citizens who sent us here, to take decisions. We must be organized, united, in solidarity.  Let us end with the pan-European database, with the PNR. Let us organise the guarding of external borders and decide on transnational cooperation with internet control and management companies, bearing in mind that there are currently 14,000 jihadist profiles on Twitter alone.  The security of the citizen is not a matter of political perception or ideology, it is a matter of political decision. We have an obligation to ensure the freedom of the citizen, which is linked to his security. Terrorism has come to inseten fear and panic. Europe's answer is that it has mastered the policy of open borders and the free movement of citizens and ideas. That's what we're going to stay on, that's why we're going to fight.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, at the moment it is hard to evaluate the impact of the latest attacks in Paris on European society and its fundamental values. Our core system of values, liberties and democratic rights has been shaken. It is our responsibility to ensure that nothing similar happens again, by adopting a more efficient framework of social integration – not assimilation but social integration – combating radicalisation and, first and foremost, neutralising the root causes of the extremist behaviour of terrorist organisations. In order to establish a safer environment, we have to define a balanced framework in which security and liberty can coexist, as you cannot be free without being secure. We must speak more to the alienated, self—isolating communities in which violent ideologies find recruits, in order to share the humanistic values of Europe with them. Another problem right now is the fighting in Syria. There is a high risk that Daesh, knowing they are about to lose ground in Syria, will take further action in Europe and transfer their operations and their attacks to Europe. We have to be prepared for that. But what still remains unanswered is why, today, we see so little intelligence sharing among our Member States. Why are terrorist organisations still being actively financed, considering that the whole banking industry is more or less in the hands of the western world? Why is Europe today still unable to work jointly with Arab leaders to reform the Islamic South? Why is Europe still unable to control its Schengen borders properly? And one final question: with one of the two seats of the Parliament in a state of emergency and the other on the highest level of alert against terrorism, what more can we expect?

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to pay tribute to the victims and the survivors of the brutal terrorist attack in Paris and their families. Having been through and experienced such terrorism in my own area of Northern Ireland, and having been through a terror lock-down such as is facing the people of Brussels at this present time, this is nothing new. Words alone will not defeat these terrorists. It will take action – and always remember that this is designed to strike fear into the masses. There is absolutely no excuse for this kind of violence, whether it is political or religious. There are some, sadly, who try to equivocate and even come close to justifying these cowardly attacks. But I hope I can speak for this entire House when I say that all terrorism is wrong and can never be justified. Earlier, my colleague from Northern Ireland, Ms Dodds, was chastised for what she said about the Sinn Féin Members. I wholly agree with what she said and now, Mr President, you can report me to the Bureau too.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, Paris was targeted because Paris is the embodiment of what Europe stands for. They meant to make us all feel unsafe living our lives. We cannot let that happen. We need a much stronger approach to radicalisation on the ground and online, we need to root out the hate preachers and to come down harder on foreign fighters. We have also heard a lot about how it is our policies on migration that are somehow to blame. Let me be clear: these attacks were perpetrated by murderers, not persons who are running away from persecution, from terror and from precisely these murderers. Let us not allow these attacks to breed intolerance, because this would play right into ISIS’s hands to turn our communities into their recruiting ground. At the same time, we cannot bury our heads in the sand. People have real fears and these must be addressed. This means that we do need stronger EU—level security legislation, like a PNR system. We need to know who is coming in and we must insist that all Member States fulfil all their legal obligations, for example by fingerprinting everyone arriving.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I think we all agree that we are currently facing the greatest test since the European Union has existed. Da'esh is an existential threat to our democracy and our civilisation. Da'esh is a culture of death that wants to destroy everything: our history, people's trust in each other and, in an excessive way, innocent people. We must fight back, we must defeat this enemy – and I say enemy – once and for all. To do this, we need determination, coherence, prudence and a long breath. There are no quick solutions, there is no miracle cure, nor is there time for partisan political controversy. Above all, we must be honest: Da'esh is a global, cross-border phenomenon. Unfortunately, we also have to take note of the fact that these terrorists have European roots. The foreign fighters - more than 5,000 foreign fighters - are in these areas. We need a European response. There is only one European response to this, not a national one. In other words, foreign policy. And there is great progress here when it comes to Syria. However, we should also support those who are already fighting against Da'esh – in Kobani, in engal, it was kurds and Yazidis who fought and defeated these terrorists. We need dialogue with the constructive forces – that is the majority of Sunni Muslims. We need this dialogue and we need to conduct it seriously. We need deradicalisation work in Europe – I am very glad that we are voting on the Dati report today – and we need an effective security policy. Here, too, there are positive proposals from the Council. I would like the Council to have been so active on the refugee issue as well.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, "he who misrepresents things contributes to the misfortune of the world," Albert Camus [Kami] said, and perfectly described the moment in which we live. And after the attack on Charlie Hebdo in January this year, many still refused to call things by their real names, and they also disobeyed warnings that terrorists were also hiding among the afflicted in the refugee column. Political correctness has become a dogma, and the security of our citizens has been pushed into the background. It is regrettable and shameful that 130 innocent people must be killed and nearly 400 wounded for the police to go on raids against extremists who have actually long been known to law enforcement and security forces. We must not pay tribute to the Paris victims only with a candle, flowers, prayer or touching words, but above all with determination in the fight against Islamic and every other extremism.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, your comments about the victims and France have touched and moved us, but the time is no longer simply for compassionate speech.  The Paris attacks and the investigation in Brussels have revealed a truth that we may find difficult to accept. The threat is no longer outside or at the gates of the European Union, the terrorists are on our territory and can strike anyone at any time. It is therefore time for action for the safety of our citizens.  The first step is to put in concrete implementation of the tools that we already have, which perhaps could have prevented these tragedies. Several frontex provisions are not effective, such as the establishment of rapid response capacity or the creation of European border guard teams. What for? Discussions on the NRL are still stalled. What for? We have to weigh in on international relations, including article 47, paragraph 2, but we cannot wait.  We can therefore report on security and strategy measures to the Council. Let's do it, but let's do it now.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, after the Paris attacks we rightly said: ʽnous sommes unis.ʼ Today we have to show the same unity in learning the lessons. Counter-terrorist police in my own East of England constituency told me that the checking of passports against the terrorist database at the external border and restricting the flow of firearms in mainland Europe would improve our security in Britain, too. And as one of five Members of the European Parliament security-cleared to read EU intelligence, I say that European nations can do much better in sharing their intelligence against our common threat. To the High Representative, I say that that when France invokes the Treaty’s mutual defence clause, we have to make a meaningful response and that our efforts at the Vienna peace table are essential. But part of the obligation for all who sit there must be to cut off the flow of terrorist finance.  Europe should never compromise its values. Unity with our friends in Brussels, hoping that life can return to normal as quickly as possible there, because we defeat terrorists by refusing to allow them to disrupt our lives. Unity with our Tunisian friends, because we do not say that only European lives matter, and we believe we should combat radicalisation in partnership with all countries where terrorists are recruited. Unity with refugees, because they are fleeing the very same violence which we saw on the streets of Paris, and because all life is sacred. And unity with people of Muslim faith in Europe and the world, because in Europe, we say ISIS is wrong. We are Christian states; we are Jewish states; and we European states are Islamic states – not you.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Mr President, I have to say I am reassured by some of the practical measures being expedited by the Council, and this House must not get in their way. Perhaps we can see that human rights – and I use that term loosely, in its expanded sense – has become a rather distorted trump card. We need to re-evaluate the operation of international human rights conventions and charters in the light of today’s circumstances rather than those of 70 years ago. The system is out of balance and, even in my own country, the United Kingdom, some of the most effective operational security methods have been systematically under attack. As in every crisis, we have again heard the cry for ‘more Europe’ from the usual suspects. Rest assured: there is excellent liaison between the security services of Britain and France and Germany and many other European countries. We do not need an EU security service but rather greater resources, and more professionalism in those countries where it is lacking. I do not have time to talk about the bizarre invocation of Article 42(7) of the Treaty on European Union, but that is another indication of where people are using this crisis to take forward an entirely different agenda.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I really appreciate the fact that I was rapporteur for that report and you wanted to get some extra time for that, but thank you very much anyway.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Yes that's true. The Democrats must stand together. Yes that's true.  We must not draw short-sighted conclusions and, yes, it is true that it also has something to do with the causes that we have to look at in the people who sin here in this way. But I'm no longer interested in talking about it forever. But I am now interested – and the citizens, by the way – of doing something concrete so that they can cross the streets again tomorrow in Cologne, Düsseldorf, Brussels or London without fear. Then I am annoyed that in many places we just don't get to Potte.  As far as passenger data is concerned, it has just been said that it is a lie to be told politically. But why is there no vote in our committee, why is there no majority? That fails because of someone who says no. Or Mr Albrecht, who has just said that would also be the wrong concept, that it would be far too costly. Yes, there is a problem!  I am relatively sure that the issue of cooperation between intelligence services, early information, is very central, and that is why we perhaps really need to think about whether this, which we always negotiate with each other in the context of data protection, is also right in these times. I want to live safely and I want us as politicians to make sure that people don't have to fear for their lives tomorrow. Then you have to question one or the other. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European We're all in mourning today. We mourn those who lost their lives in Paris on 13 November, as well as those killed by terrorists in Beirut, Bamako or Tunis. We share the pain of all those who have lost family members, loved ones, children. We share the helpless anger, fear and uncertainty, because we don't know where a similar drama can happen tomorrow or the day after. This fear and anger encourages us to look for someone or something to blame, who is to blame for the inexplicable. And we point the finger at immigrants, refugees, Islam, Schengen, the whole EU. But these aren't real answers. These are merely tools of the far right, of inciting fear and hatred. It's a lying and dangerous game, because the real answers aren't that simple.  Today we have a choice between two paths. One way is the path of national selfishness, exclusion, exclusion, mutual trust and solidarity, where fences and fear of otherness separate nations and people. The other way is the path of respect, acceptance, inclusion, trust and cooperation that the European Union, multicultural Europe, has already walked. We can only get over today's crisis if we continue to believe boldly and trust in our values, in the strength of our community, if we stand by what Europe means today.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, my condolences to France and all the victims and countries suffering from terror. We are facing persistent, deadly and indiscriminate attacks. I want you to recap: 446 people have been killed in the last month. They kill, we debate. As legislators, we have an inescapable responsibility, and it is to respond to this challenge. This response is based on a number of urgent priorities. I list them: Europol Regulation, with the Internet Content Notification Unit; PNR, before the end of the year; the European Counter-Terrorism Centre (the UNCT); increase operational cooperation and, in particular, within the scope of the Operational Action Plan on Firearms; strengthen external borders by implementing them with RABIT and police units. I also urgently call for the launch of the new legislative proposals, Mr Avramopoulos: smart borders, updating the Frontex Regulation and the FIUs. All this, Mr President, we owe it to the citizens and also to the victims. It's our contribution as legislators.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the threat posed by the attacks is a greater threat than any other, because in the face of distant violence, in traditional theatres of war, we think that we know the dynamics, that we have the means to combat it, even though we have made many mistakes. But in the face of violence close to massacres in europe's neighbourhoods, in our daily places, we feel, in addition to fear, the anxiety of the incomprehensible. Why here? And why on the part of young people who sometimes have European passports? It is difficult to understand the reasons: but it cannot be just madness, so that a young man raised with us is attracted to a fanatical choice and kills other young people like him and, together, the ideals of freedom and tolerance. We certainly need immediate security responses, but there is something else that is very uncomfortable to do, something more: it is a response in terms of culture, of dialogue, to give each person of different culture and religion his dignity, within a shared framework. There is a work of prevention and integration that must be done in schools, and of education. The space of coexistence and coexistence is never the result of chance but the result of intelligent demanding work of training. If we do not do that, it will not be enough to save us from closing borders and raising barriers, because discomfort and revolt go beyond walls and the Internet will do the rest. Security, of course, must be immediate. We are calling for common intelligence and it is essential to tackle the thorny problem of arms trafficking, oil smuggling and covert financing of terrorist networks.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we do not want controversy, let alone 'political politics'. But we want and need some clarity, a little truth. We must get out of the asphyxiating rhetoric of political correctness, which Even Pope Francis has repeatedly stigmatized as hypocritical language. Ladies and gentlemen, it is true that we have a responsibility to combine two fundamental values: security and individual freedom. So I do not say this in my own words but in the words of Carlo Nordio, an important and esteemed Italian magistrate: freedom, when it is restricted by law according to a higher interest, collective defends itself. That must be clear! Abstract principles of benevolence are not enough. If we really want to defend our values, which derive from the dual Greek-Enlightenment and Judaeo-Christian traditions, we must do what the Council has said: we need solidarity in action, but decisive solidarity, capable of defending our citizens.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Minister, beyond the pain, grief and bruising caused by the Paris attacks, our duty as Europeans is to rise to this challenge, to fight those who want to destroy and divide us.  The 500 million Europeans understood this right away. The Islamic State, on November 13, wanted to attack not only Paris, France, but Europe as a whole. It is what we represent in our diversity that is under attack. We are at war, at war to defend our freedom, our values and our way of life, at war to protect our children, the children of our homelands. This fight, we must lead it by more Europe for better control of Europe's external borders, more Europe for the establishment of a European intelligence and counter-terrorism centre within Europol, more Europe to fight jihadist websites that have a devastating effect on a certain youth within our European cities , more Europe to combat the financing of terrorism: the sale of oil, weapons, works of art and cigarette smuggling.  It is also in order to better face the terrorist challenge that the Schengen tool must be fully implemented, as Jacques Delors, our former President of the European Commission, pointed out a few days ago. Yes, we need more Europe to protect us and it is because we will have more Europe that we will fight not only the terrorists, but also the nationalists in Europe.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Mr President, the Paris attacks were not just an attack on France. They were an attack on the whole of Europe. It was the values of western democracies, which France embodies, that were hit, and people from many portuguese countries too, who were murdered. We're at war, a hidden war, a coward, no classic rules, but not less lethal. Terrorism is not combated with romantic proclamations. It's not enough to say we won't give in to fear. You have to act. We must fight to eliminate extremism that is attentive to our values, our way of life, our very existence. We can't feel kidnapped in our own house. The first solidarity of European leaders, without forgetting others, must be with our peoples, which we cannot put at risk with our decisions. Everything should be considered: R&R, smart borders, the deployment of sources of funding, monitoring of social networks and other modern forms of communication, use of all military forces, closure of indoctrination sites in Europe, reassessment of conditions of attribution and loss of nationality, if necessary, and, of course... We're done, Mr. President, saying europe is old, but it doesn't have to be weak. Europe must face medieval insanity and will win. Win.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Dear Plenum! In this Chamber, we often hear condemnations of terrorist attacks on European soil.  They are inexcusable and I am sorry for all the victims of Paris. But I am also sorry for all the innocent civilian casualties in Syria, Iraq, Palestine and so on. We are not serious about effectively stopping the war in Syria and resolving conflicts in the Middle East. Because in this, the real causes of terrorist attacks must be searched. Once again and most strongly so far, the stability of Europe and the Middle East has been shown to be closely linked. The cancer of instability is a problem for the Palestinian people. As a result of its split, Europe has remained powerless in the attacks on Iraq. Equally helplessly, we are now discussing refugees, this colonial damage to a broken Syria that is largely unafter caused from Europe, and we now bear its greatest burden – financially, morally, socially and more. It is precisely because of this fact that we should be all the more united in front of the US and also russia with demands to stop the war. Instead, once again, we are hiring ourselves completely partial and populistly by setting barbed wires, spreading stereotypes and hate speech. We are creating material for ourselves for internal schism and mistrust, from which only extremists of all kinds, unfortunately, populist politicians, benefit. If, in the future, we do not think and speak with a common language that includes the discourse of Christian, Muslim and other European religious communities, but includes both left and right ideologies, and above all if we do not act with a wide-open mind and mind, then the reality can very quickly happen to us when Europe is no longer the continent of such self-economic peace. Discussions about the operators of terrorist attacks and the causes of them will then be of complete meaning. So let's activate, together and now.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to point out that the Paris attacks have created a European solidarity which, for once, has not remained at the level of words. As we know, for the first time, the mutual defence clause of Article 42, paragraph 7, has been activated, and the European Union has therefore chosen to give a substance to this solidarity of the Member States.  It is now a question of taking another step towards the effective implementation of this commitment. I believe that the Member States, including my own, Romania, need to coordinate quickly. We need joint action because war is war. This requires means, it requires troops, including military redeployments. On the other hand, it should be noted that the caliphate is attacking in various places, not just in Europe, and that solidarity is not just about the war in Syria.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we think we know what is going to happen, but it is not true. This is not true, not only because we are facing unprecedented trials; this is not true, especially since we find it difficult to read reality and deal with it, as close as we are between the need to guarantee security for citizens who are afraid and lost and not to lose sight of the idea of a Europe that is the cradle of open democratic civilisation and the rule of law. In this context, it is likely that the governments of Paris and Brussels could not do otherwise than the measures taken. However, I wonder whether we are equally aware of the risks behind the protracted states of urgency, which inevitably point the finger at Muslim communities and their neighbourhoods and which makes every Maghrebi, in many circumstances and at certain times of the day, the individual suspect that it will be legal to stop, search, interrogate and detain.  There are already lessons behind us, such as the one that has come to us since 17 October 1961 in Paris, which we must not forget. Daish is certainly the most barbaric and cruel of jihadist movements but he is not without strategy. So be careful how we move to avoid objectively promoting what we want to fight, namely recruitment.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European My deepest sympathies go out to the victims' relatives in France and anywhere in the world. After Paris, living in Brussels over the weekend, it became clear that the first and most important task of the European Union, the Member States, is now to protect its own citizens, institutions and values. Guaranteeing Europe's security is the key to preserving freedom. European citizens expect us to be honest at last. To protect our borders for their safety, so that the influx of people can't be used by terrorists. Because if not, all this undermines the Schengen system, and if the Schengen acquis is destroyed, the whole of European integration will be lost. Because without security, only fear, isolation, mistrust and the rise of extremism await Europe. And that is not the Europe we want.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, I extend my deepest condolences to the families of victims of the Paris attacks. We stand united against terror. Paris was an attack against us all. Let us not forget too that every day is Paris somewhere in the Muslim world. Only yesterday we witnessed another terrorist attack in Tunisia. In order to bring the perpetrators to justice and to prevent further attacks, better EU intelligence cooperation, data-sharing and surveillance are crucial. This is why I applaud the most concrete step taken so far to increase European security: the decision to launch a European counter-terrorism centre under Europol supervision. The centre will bring together leading counter-terrorism specialists from each Member State. They will work together under one roof on operational coordination. Fear cannot be countered only by increasing security. We must counter it with facts, and the facts are clear: Muslims are not the enemy. In our battle against extremism, Muslims in Europe and abroad are our allies. Amid fear and pessimism we must remain true to our values, upholding freedom and human rights while providing security to our citizens.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his work 80% or more of the dead of Islamist terror are Muslims. In this respect, we must never fall into the trap of being a fight against Islam or that migration, refugees, are being lumped together with terror. At the same time, following what has been done to the French people, where we have all expressed our great regret, I would also like to say that national services are to blame. It is not a question of clearing Schengen, of closing borders, of finally committing us, as the previous speaker rightly said, to our secret services and security agencies. Is it true that only five Member States are fulfilling their obligations to provide Europol with all the data? Is it true that there is no decent exchange of information with Frontex, that Frontex does not get the data? These hats of all countries control us citizens and listen to us, but they are not in a position to exchange the data necessary for the security of our citizens. It must be clear here that the Member States of the European Union are failing in terms of the security of the citizens of the European Union. This should be made clear that the solution lies, not that the rights of citizens or migrants are being limited.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, there is no consolation for French mothers whose children were murdered in Paris on the night of 13 November, or for those in Madrid in 2004, or for the hundreds of thousands of Syrian, Iraqi, Tunisian, Nigerian, Malian mothers.  The threat is global; jihadist terrorism strategy is global. And so the only smart answer has to be global.  We need a more united Europe than ever before, and that is why it is regrettable to hear, even today, the nationalist right and the far right of this Parliament trying to take advantage of this situation. You see, I tell you: refugees are not the ones dealing with ISIS oil. It's not the refugees. Yes, of course, the key is security, but it's not the only key.  Let us not give terrorists the trophy they crave most, which is precisely the failure of our system of freedoms, the failure of our democracy and our complicity in the destruction of universal human rights. If we do that, we'll be just giving the victory to the terrorists.  The threat is global. Security is key, but it's not the only key. Because if we jump above our values, we'll be giving the terrorists a trophy.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: – Mr President, I know well the nature of terrorism because three ETA terrorists shot dead my brother and his wife. That was 17 years ago in Seville, but the result, the death of two innocent young men, does not vary from what the terrorists of Paris were looking for: depriving us of our holiest right, the right to live. That is why I hope that so much suffering from the victims will serve to effectively legislate against terrorism, without confusing our right to security with an attack on freedom. Because, to be free, you have to be alive first. I ask you, especially those who have always stopped the legislative instruments aimed at protecting citizens, to support them without complexes this time, because respect must not be confused with passivity. Today, more than ever, we need a European directive for the victims of terrorism. And you know why? Because anyone can be victims; because, together with the victims of Paris, our society has been a victim. And I wish I could look the terrorists in the face, to tell them that I'm not afraid and I'm not going to give them my freedom or my desire to live.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work he has I believe that the most important task of the state is to ensure and protect the safety of its citizens. I want our children to go to school in the morning without fear and that parents who are at home or at work can also be sure that their children will return home after school.  Many measures that can increase security in the Member States are on the table, some of them for many years. Many things have just been mentioned by colleagues – Monika Hohlmeier has mentioned it and many others: PNR, allowing automatic data matching within Europe, the creation of a dangerous file and data protection that does not become the protection of perpetrators. All this is on the table. I appeal to all members of this House to work constructively to ensure that we finally implement the necessary measures and put forward proposals. I also appeal to you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, to force the Member States to tackle massively now what has been on the table for so many years.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: Mr President, just a few days ago, the coordinator of the Paris attacks, Abaaoud, boasted in an interview with Dabik, Daesch's official propaganda body, that he said: "I was able to come and go, despite the fact that I was being chased by all the intelligence services".  Yes, this terrorist struck by a European arrest warrant, sentenced by default to twenty years' imprisonment, was able to travel europe several times, coming and going from Syria, to and from Cologne to Istanbul, without ever being intercepted. In the face of this, Europe must take three initiatives. First, to tighten access to external borders, not only for foreigners but also for European nationals. Second, respond to frontex's requests, which officially reiterated that only 40% of its needs were met by the States. Finally, of course, adopt the NRL that has been debated enough for so many years. Europe is both a major source of recruitment and a priority target. Too disunited, she's powerless. The urgency is to ensure that, in the face of this terrorist challenge, it is no longer the problem but the solution.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – The horrifying images of the cowardly attack in Paris will haunt us for a long time to come. So many victims, so many young people whose lives came to an abrupt end in a concert hall, a restaurant or on the street. No wonder we're looking at politics. It is logical that Europe should be looked at. We all have a great responsibility here, Parliament from left to right, Member States, Commission, to ensure the safety of our citizens and it is high time we took that responsibility. This is not about new proposals, as some members would like us to believe here. These are proposals that were on our agenda long before Paris: PNR, the anti-terrorism centre, the Internet reporting unit, europol's mandate, things that we have sometimes been talking about for years. Although some members have tried again here today, this cannot be explained to any European citizens.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Mr President, my heart is beating for the French people today. The time of trial must become the time of the gathering for Europe. In the face of terrorism, Europe must be stronger, firm and united than ever before. Citizens' confidence in the effectiveness of external border controls must be restored through concrete actions: systematic and mandatory checks on all passports, including European passports, because foreign fighters are Europeans, the registration of all migrants, including their fingerprints, the updating of all databases , increasing the exchange of information between services and strengthening our police and judicial cooperation by giving more resources to Europol and Eurojust. This year, the European NRL directive, including for intra-European flights, must be adopted. The financing of terrorism must also be addressed. Mr President, I refuse any amalgamation. Fundamentalism is not Islam, terrorists are not refugees. Those who flee the same terror and fear must find refuge and tolerance in our country.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, last year there were 17 000 terrorist attacks all over the world. Anybody can be a victim of extreme Islamic terrorism, and terrorism has to be the public enemy for all of us. Four areas are key: real coordination between Member States and intelligence services; preventive data collection, analysis and automatic exchange; destroying e-communication among terrorists; and cutting out the sources of finance for terrorism. We should not sacrifice privacy and freedom on the altar of security, but neither should we sacrifice security on the altar of privacy – for that simply means sacrificing people on the altar of terrorism because of our inability to act. We need concrete solutions: among them, PNR for intra-EU flights; a legal basis for the internet referral unit for fighting internet mobilisation of terrorists; cooperation with social media on the removal of illicit content; resources for a counterterrorism centre in Europol; a data protection package with clear roles for law enforcement in providing security; and smart borders.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we will not tire of repeating it: our first reaction is to stand in solidarity, in solidarity with the Parisians, in solidarity with the French. It is not France that is under attack but Europe, our freedoms and our values.  Nevertheless, solidarity should not mean turning a blind eye to our dysfunctions. I'll make three points. The first is the management of our external borders and police, judicial and intelligence cooperation between Member States. The results are still largely inadequate.  There are also significant gaps in the linking of different databases. The second point relates to external action. On the one hand, it is better to cooperate with third countries, in particular to dry up the financing of terrorism and, on the other hand, it is necessary to anticipate the consequences and the continuation of our actions on the ground. The weakening or destruction of the Islamic State must not leave the field open to other security threats. Third, it is important to strengthen our work on preventing radicalization. That's the great lesson of these attacks. An analysis, including sociological, of people and their diverse profiles is necessary. The security response is not enough.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen of the Social Democrats, the Greens and the Liberals, I take you at your word when we now take the urgent decisions together without further blockades in order to fulfil our political responsibility for the safety of the people of Europe now and immediately: the collection of passenger data also for intra-European flights, measures against the illegal arms trade, systematic checks on persons at the EU's external borders, registration of third-country nationals, , massive security of the external borders – I welcome President Juncker's initiative to strengthen border and coast guards – permanent full exchange of suspect files in Eurodac, strengthening Europol, strengthening Frontex, controlling financial flows, prevention, data retention – this must of course be fulfilled in full respect of the rule of law, fundamental rights and data protection! I also take the Council at its word to end the blockades of refusal by individual Member States. We who ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: Mr President, after the attacks, it is normal for France and Europe to experience a period of recollection. But after the time of recollection, the real questions will have to be asked.  First question. In the past two weeks, police in France and Belgium have seized several hundred weapons. Who can believe for a moment that these weapons have been located for seven days? We knew where those guns were. We didn't go looking for them. What for? Second question. In France, there are a hundred radical mosques. What are we waiting for to close them? The third question concerns the NRL. Our Minister of the Interior came to Brussels to say that he wanted a PNR. That's a good thing, too. But why does he not say that a number of Members of his own majority here in the European Parliament have slowed down the adoption of this NRP? I have dozens of questions like that. So I am speaking to the French government and to all European governments: stop saying, as you have done since "Charlie", that you are going to fight terrorism. Stop saying it and do it! Don't communicate, stop postures, stop incantation, stop amateurism and act!

name: Frank ENGEL
text: Mr President, let us still try not to overbid the total isolationist and security. It is not by dismantling Schengen that we will be getting closer to those who are already here and who plunge us into a climate of insecurity.  The hundred mosques, which Mr Juvin spoke of, have not been closed, although they are known to preach the most monstrous radicalism. Such mosques exist throughout our continent, we do not need a permanent state of emergency to enforce criminal law in all its current acuity, to arrest those who preach hatred and to close the relays and channels of radicalism and radicalization on our territory. Those who want to harm us are in most cases, if not in all cases, already at home. We must fight them at home, we must not fight those who seek refuge to flee the same terrorists as those who attack us in these sad times.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think I am the only Irish speaker here today and that is unfortunate in some respects, because if there is one thing that Paris showed us, it is that there is no single country, no single city, no football stadium, no restaurant, no individual in the Western world which is not now a target for the terrorists of ISIS. That means we need to unite to fight them. Only a while ago I saw a tweet from the Irish Daily Mirror which underscores the point I am making. It says ISIS has released an English-speaking video threatening the United Kingdom. Therefore, action is needed. Above all, I think we have to bring in the PNR directive as soon as possible. That is absolutely vital. Secondly, we are involved in the data protection that has been referred to. We need clear rules, and in particular we need to guarantee the safety of individuals. If we do not, we are going to finish up with a situation where we have freedom in theory but no safety in practice.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, condolences to the victims of these attacks which strike us all and infinite solidarity with France and with all the countries which suffer terrorism in their own flesh; but European citizens have the right to a legislative response that guarantees and strengthens their security in the face of fear and helplessness, and that requires learning some things realistically.  The first is that this is not a debate about aliens or immigration or asylum; not even about Islam. Because we have to learn that it will be impossible for us to prevail if we do not get the cooperation of Islamic communities in our domestic politics and in our foreign policy – Islamic communities that suffer and fight terrorism as well.  And the second is that the attacks that have hurt us the most – Paris, Madrid 2004 – were not perpetrated by people who came by plane: they inhabited and inhabited among us. And so it is essential to strengthen the 'European intelligence community' to know how they act on networks, how they move their money globally, how we can intercept, freeze and confiscate it, and how we can defend our values without surrendering our rights or our freedoms.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, I was lucky. My own family in Paris that night were not in the bar; they were not at the match and were not at the concert. This could have happened to any of us. Terrorism is never justified and we must be united in the fight against terror, united across countries and, importantly, united across different faiths. We must give the security services the tools they need to do their job. If they want better sharing of data, let them have better sharing of data. If they want to know who is getting on an aeroplane, let them see the passenger name list. This is to keep the rest of us safe, so that we can continue to travel and trade across borders. Our national experts have a huge amount of experience in many countries in fighting against terrorism, and it is not this House’s role to stand in their way. Give them the tools they ask for.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Yesterday we debated the report on radicalising young people who are going abroad. Today we heard a lot of voices here in Parliament. And I have to tell you, they are fairly united. I hear a lot of calls here for more Europe. I hear calls here, like guy Verhofstadt, for a European intelligence service. I hear agreement here on the stricter protection of our external borders. I hear voices going up here to vote on the PNR this year.  I have to tell you, ladies and gentlemen, I am actually going out of this as a convinced European, but I would like to ask you one thing, Council and Commission. Do it now! Let's check those boundaries! Let that go in, this year! Let us ensure that this unity is implemented!

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we regret the victims of the terrorist attacks in Paris, Tunis and Beirut and stress the need for an immediate defeat of ISIS.  But we must also realise the need for an immediate end to foreign interventions and wars in the Arab world. Because it is the foreign interventions and socio-economic inequalities that have created the monster of terrorism which, to this day, unfortunately continue to be supported by the West and its allies. Unfortunately, the innocent peoples are reaping what the imperialist interventions of the United States and the dominant circles of the Union have reaped.  However, the fear that has prevailed must not allow authoritarianism and the legalisation of repressive measures to limit individual rights and freedoms. We must also not allow migrants, refugees and Muslims to be targeted for what is happening. After all, terrorism also acts every day in Iraq, Libya, Lebanon and Syria, killing innocent people and creating new waves of refugees.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has The Paris attacks require a calm and objective response. Because the fear is there, everyone feels it. But what we must not do is use our reactions to terrify people and to attack the democratic freedoms, the fundamental freedoms that we have fought for on this continent for years and centuries. The attacks– I am convinced – prove that it would now be the wrong way to push ahead with even more unrelated surveillance, even more data storage.  It is not justified to involve the entire population here. After Charlie Hebdo, even after Charlie Hebdo, it was not possible to find the perpetrators who have now carried out these attacks in Paris by increasing the haystack. France has PNR, they are already doing this, and it has not been possible to prevent that. In other words, we must remain at the democratic level of fundamental rights, more cooperation between the Member States, between police investigations and intelligence services under the umbrella of Europol and Eurojust.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, I feel like I am in a parallel world here when I read in the media today that the French Social Democrat Prime Minister Manuel Valls spoke of no more refugees, of closing the borders, and, on the other hand, I hear from socialists, the left and the Greens here that we need open borders, a pseudo-welcome culture, because they do not want to see that we have a migration of peoples in Europe – an invasion – an invasion . , and do not want to see that about 70% of those arriving from Syria or Iraq are not genuine refugees. I can therefore recommend that you take the opinion of the Social Democrat Prime Minister from France very, very seriously. In this way, I would like to give you what he also said in the South German, namely: the control of the EU's external borders is essential. Anyone who does not understand this will have to say that the citizens will tell us that this is enough, Europe!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the tragic events in Paris for which we regret have not happened suddenly or unnecessarily. They are the results of mishandling of politics and wrongs committed over time by all the countries of Europe. For many years we have opened our borders and accepted hundreds of thousands of legal and illegal immigrants. We give them citizenship very easily. We create multiracial, multi-religious and multicultural societies, with the naivety to believe that we will be able to assimilate these people.  That's not the case. We cannot give them the desired standard of living and this makes them feel hatred against the societies that host them. But we continue to constantly open our borders and accept thousands more illegal immigrants in which there are dangerous jihadists. They cooperate with their existing like-minded people and manage to destroy the countries of the infidel West. So let us work together to tackle this great threat to humanity and Europe.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the debate today came at the right moment. It was very timely, very constructive and it sent very strong signals. Allow me once again to come back to a concern that has been raised by many of you today, namely the link between migration and terrorism and the link between religion and terrorism. I will repeat what I said last night in this place – and President Juncker has said it this morning: we must absolutely dissociate those who are in need of international protection – of our protection – from those who are seeking to attack our values, the very fundamental values of our societies. It is those same terrorists who refugees are fleeing from. Let me also once again remind you that almost all the perpetrators of the latest attacks on European soil were European Union citizens, and not all were of Muslim origin. We have to ask ourselves why these young people, who are born and bred here, decide to leave, to forsake our communities and, finally, to turn against us. Daesh wants us to think in opposites, in black and white and to feel the antagonism that they are creating and fomenting. Let us not fall into their trap. Let us not give in to fear and panic. Honourable Members of Parliament, of various political affiliations, we are all smarter than that and we know that a united European response is the only answer to the threat. Together we can improve our resilience to terrorism and address the complex causes of radicalisation. We are all collectively safer in unity and should come together. We are moving forward on the PNR negotiations and will ensure a fully operational and effective instrument, which will of course respect proportionality. As regards the checks at our external borders, in parallel with our package on European border and coast guards, we are exploring the need to include possible modifications to the provisions of checks of European Union citizens against databases for public order and internal security reasons. In the meantime, Member States should use all the tools available to control external borders. The tools are there. Moreover, as many of you mentioned Schengen, let me make this clear: Schengen is the most tangible example of our greatest achievement in the European integration process. It is only by making full use of Schengen that we will be able to react to the threats. But we also need more trust among ourselves to share intelligence – many in this room today have said this – and prevent the possibility of a repetition of the horrendous attacks like those in Paris. Europe cannot stand without trust between all of us – among the EU institutions, among the Member States and among citizens. That is why it is so crucial that Member States send, not just their experts, but also their intelligence to the counter—terrorism centre in Europol, which will be fully operational on 1 January 2016. It is unity, solidarity, resilience, determination and cooperation that will fight terrorism. It is a moment for more Europe.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of these heinous crimes and the threats which, alas, persist, we need a real political will to act together and I believe that is the great lesson of this debate.  The fight against this Islamist terrorism, against jihadism - and we are not afraid of words - must be relentless and comprehensive. It will be long and requires consistency, but also discernment. Nothing would be worse than amalgamation. We must work together, tirelessly, to implement the measures we have decided. All institutions must engage quickly in strong action. I have heard the strong will to achieve the adoption of the European NRL before the end of the year. The presidency is ready, it will contribute to it.  Our best response to terrorism is first of all our strong commitment to our values, to our open and democratic society based on equality, non-discrimination and integration, and our refusal to be intimidated. But it is also, I repeat, with you, our ability to put together our strengths, our capacity to exchange information, and finally, to show cohesion and coherence. That's right, rhetoric is no longer enough, solidarity cannot be limited to being simply declaratory.  Ladies and gentlemen, we need concrete solidarity and the solidarity clause of Article 42, paragraph 7, has been invoked. There was unanimous and full support from all Member States at the Council on 17 November. It must now be implemented both internally and externally, including through offers of material assistance and support. Strengthening our foreign policy, our foreign policy, as well as our security and defence policy is on the agenda.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – Jihadist terrorism has a precise target: democratic-liberal institutionalism that favors the affirmation of critical thinking. The attacks in Paris a few days ago reveal this will. Terrorists know that fear is a silent poison that can dissolve the foundations of this model of political and social organization: they want to innocuous it through these horrible acts.
