The European Union, which has as its own design the protection and promotion of human rights, must react vigorously and intelligently to this threat: it must move towards improving its capacity for repressive response, both internally and externally. This will lead to increased cooperation between Member States in the areas of security and defence policies, with this also entailing increased sharing of sovereignty.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – How many have we learned from the fight against radicalism and terrorism and in prevention since the 9/11 attacks in Madrid? The answer is that it has not been enough: we have not advanced or learned what is necessary. It has not been enough when it comes to information and intelligence: we still do not share the information needed to attack terrorism. Nor has it been in terms of cutting off the sources of funding of terrorist groups or for structuring a common foreign policy that responds coherently to conflicts, from which these radicalization processes and terrorist groups feed. Nor have we done what is necessary to build a European response. In fact, today the Council presents us with a number of measures which we support, but many of them were already available to the Member States, which have not used them. There has been an anti-terrorism strategy since 2015, there is a counter-terrorism coordinator, Europol, Eurojust... Let's use the tools we have and launch the new instruments without falling into an improvisation dictated from panic. Let us not allow terrorists to determine our agenda and protect our European values.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – In the wake of the terrible attacks in Paris and the terror threat in Brussels, it is crucial that we join forces in Europe to arrive at a swift and decisive response. Without a rapid exchange of information on suspicious passengers between national security services, terrorists within Schengen can cross the border far too easily.  We therefore want the European Passenger Data Exchange (PNR) to be operational by the end of the year. We call on the other parties to finally make decisions on this crucial dossier that has dragged on for too long. We must also move quickly to ensure that the effective implementation of effective common control of Europe's external borders is effective. In addition, the development of a European border and coastguard is absolutely a priority, coupled with the establishment of 'smart border controls' of everyone entering the Schengen zone (again) - including from us, EU citizens - and the automatic exchange of that data within the Schengen Information System (SIS). We also need to accelerate and act on the role of the Internet and social media in radicalisation and recruitment. Providers must assume responsibility and actively cooperate in removing illegal or radicalized content.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. These recent terrorist attacks in Paris that have killed 132 people and injured more than 415 are a terrible tragedy that has marked us and will mark us for a long time to come. I would like to pay tribute to the families of the victims and to show my full support to the police who are doing an outstanding job.  However, after this period of mourning, we must make the observation and provide the right answers to the problems. We must put an end to this colander European Union, abolish the free movement of Schengen and re-establish genuine control at the national borders of the Member States and not those of the Union, which it cannot keep.  The Union and our leaders must realis that uncontrolled mass immigration to Europe no longer has the means to assimilate and that we can no longer take in 'migrants' even though many Europeans are no longer able to find housing, food or work.  Finally, we must act on the ground of military operations to fight Daesh with all the actors fighting terrorism and to end our relations with countries like Qatar or Saudi Arabia, which openly finance terrorism.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – How many have we learned from the fight against radicalism and terrorism and in prevention since the 9/11 attacks in Madrid? The answer is that it has not been enough: we have not advanced or learned what is necessary. It has not been enough when it comes to information and intelligence: we still do not share the information needed to attack terrorism. Nor has it been in terms of cutting off the sources of funding of terrorist groups or for structuring a common foreign policy that responds coherently to conflicts, from which these radicalization processes and terrorist groups feed. Nor have we done what is necessary to build a European response. In fact, today the Council presents us with a number of measures which we support, but many of them were already available to the Member States, which have not used them. There has been an anti-terrorism strategy since 2015, there is a counter-terrorism coordinator, Europol, Eurojust... Let's use the tools we have and launch the new instruments without falling into an improvisation dictated from panic. Let us not allow terrorists to determine our agenda and protect our European values.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – Just a few months after Charlie Hebdo journalists were executed in cold blood, the attacks of 13 November reinforce the danger posed by Islamic terrorism. In the wake of the massacre, the evidence of human solidarity was truly moving, and the encouragement and messages conveyed to the French people showed that the world still has resources of vitality. European leaders must be held accountable, because the danger of terrorism shows no signs of stopping, quite the contrary. The fact that terrorists attacking European states are mainly citizens of the Union, born or raised in Europe, radicalised in the meantime, reinforces the belief that the inclusion policies implemented so far are ineffective. Another aspect to consider is the discovery among the bombers of a possible Syrian immigrant, who came to Europe this year, which raises serious questions about the speech that refugees can be received without any control, even though the Syrian passport discovered at the site of one of the attacks was false. In order to ensure Community security, it is not sufficient for only one Member State to take the necessary measures, which is why I believe that, now more than ever, a strong effort is needed to restore a new 'European concert' to combat terrorism.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – The attacks last week in Paris have marked this session with grief, and I deplore those actions that took the lives of 130 innocent people. I want to express my deepest sympathy for the victims and families of those who died last Friday in Paris, and also to those who suffered at the hands of recent terror attacks in Beirut and Mali. Europe is struggling to deal with new and evolving situations, and in this struggle I stand against fundamentalism, against bigotry, against sectarianism and against racism. Allowing any of these ideologies or mind-sets to seep into our society would pose a threat to the peaceful coexistence and democratic future all of us aspire to. We must use our political standing to go beyond these senseless acts of terror and to the root causes of despair in countries such as Syria and Eritrea. We must stand united in our defiance of such acts of murder and united in our solidarity with Paris, and other communities destroyed by violence.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. The brutal terrorist attacks in Paris over the past few days have shocked us and left us breathless. While we are debating here, another city in the heart of Europe, our European city, Brussels, is under siege, its citizens locked up in their homes with tanks on the streets. War is no longer on the doorstep of our homes, it is in our homes and we must do something.  The European Union must have a genuine common foreign and security policy. We must all stand united against terrorism in Europe and against this phantom Islamic State, which is nothing more than a gang of criminals who are keeping the Western world in check with their savagery and contempt for the lives of others, but also for their own, because they are ready to blow themselves up in order to kill. In order to win against those who have the death cult, we must be united and convinced defenders of our values, our being Christians, the value of life and solidarity. Our division is a strength for the Daesh rebels, far fewer than we are, but who exploit our inability to coordinate.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. "We live in fear today, as if our safety had been called into question. And it was. And our values attacked. And they were. That's what we have to do. But Freedom and Security are not opposite concepts. In good rigour there is no freedom without security or security without freedom. When we are in emergency situations, exceptional measures are required, but only for the period strictly necessary to neutralize the threat. In the long run we must seek the necessary and proportionate measures to combat the threat. On a subject as sensitive as the fight against terrorism, a united front is required. The extremes are already trying to polarize the discussion. It is therefore up to the moderates not to give in to the easy path and to effectively combat these criminals while preserving our core values, such as fundamental rights or the Schengen area. Already in January of this year he said – what are new instruments of or the reinforcement of existing ones, if their future is the same as those we have here: are they little or nothing used? In the heat of the moment, it is up to decision-makers to act with weight and not forget why they attack us: we are free. To give in to our core values would be to grant a victory to the terrorists.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Terrorism strikes at the very core of the structures on which societies drive. Stating that it is an attack on our liberty, freedom and democratic values, is stating the obvious. In addressing it one must ensure that we do not allow the terror and shock it creates to destabilise on freedoms, on social interaction as well on economies. Our response must be proportionate to the threat, but to identify the severity of values of the threat each country requires mutual intelligence and security support. Sharing of our security knowledge intelligence is key to empowering each other’s security. Terrorism blatantly shows that no country can be secure on its own; European security is established and entwined with that of other countries.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – Terrorism focuses on instilling fear within people’s hearts and disrupts people'’ lives. But if we allow terrorism to obstruct our everyday lives, to destroy our way of life and our lifestyles, then we allow terrorism to win. We cannot allow terrorists to create a divide within our union, because this is exactly what terrorism feeds on: we must be united in the face of terrorism. We can only do this by taking the initiative in the field of security and defence. For this reason we must go above and beyond and move from an inter-governmental policy. We must safeguard Schengen, a fundamental pillar of the construction of Europe, by making our borders stronger, and this is why I look forward to the upcoming Frontex regulation. We must arm our intelligence services with the necessary tools while ensuring the exchange of information at European governmental level between intelligence services. Furthermore, we must implement EU-PNR, in line with strong data protection safeguards. We must fight fundamentalism through unity and not through more fear. We must implement next-generation solutions to next-generation issues with bravery and courage, encompassing our European values in our European response.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. Since the Charlie Hebdo attacks of January, the violent attacks in central Paris on Friday 13 November have once again shaken France, thus striking not only at the heart of Europe as a whole, but above all at its identity, values and fundamental freedoms. The Union, its institutions and the Member States must now act firmly and unitedly in the challenge posed by fundamentalist terrorism. That is why it will be necessary to draw up a common strategy, involving the creation of a European intelligence system and taking immediate measures to combat terrorism, such as the strengthening of Europol and the opening of the European Counter-Terrorism Centre.  In order to provide concrete answers to these hate-laden attacks, the Member States must finally overcome jealousies, mistrust and sometimes rivalries which have all too often slowed down the construction of a more integrated and therefore safer European Union. The time has come to make a qualitative leap forward in the completion of the European Union's integration project, including in areas such as intelligence and security, without this abdicating our rights acquired in 60 years of history, such as freedom of movement.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Deep and sincere condolences must be offered to the families and loved ones of the victims in Paris, but also to the whole of France. We must make it clear that, after the terrorist massacre, it is not only France and its metropolis that are bleeding, but that this was an attack on our common values, which we want and will protect. The confirmation that the so-called 'massacre' is behind the massacre is a confirmation that there is a need for a european union to take part The Islamic State must be the last warning for all democratic countries to come together and unequivocally oppose the religious terrorism embodied by this vile organisation. The terror in Paris is proof that fanatics will stop at nothing and that they are constantly improving their ways of spreading violence and cruelty. However, tragedy has several dimensions. In doing so, we cannot allow it to become a perverse tool for defending the various xenophobic views that we are forced to face, particularly in the context of the ongoing refugee crisis in Europe. The fear that these views spread and support over the barbarism and violence represented by religious fanaticism certainly cannot prevail. On the contrary, it makes us even weaker, and that is exactly what the Paris killers are trying to achieve. It is therefore important to focus not on spreading hatred. The response should be a determination to combat violence, radicalism and extremism in any form.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: in writing. – We have to be very careful not to lose our balance: on the one hand there are the freedoms we cherish and which are, among others, at the core of our Western values, and on the other hand making sure that these terribly tragic events do not occur again. What we urgently need is much more cooperation between the security apparatus of and among the European countries. They jealously guard their information – secrets, if you will – instead of sharing intelligence with the neighbour. We also must not fall into the trap of those who would like to equate the refugees with terrorists. That is an absolute shameless political game. Those unfortunate people have been fleeing the very same atrocious attacks that were committed in Paris – they had seen and experienced these kinds of acts in Aleppo, in Homs, in many Syrian towns on a daily basis. As far as we know, not a single one of the terrorists was a refugee; on the contrary, they were citizens of, or born in, Belgium or France. And they bought tickets to travel to Turkey and then on to Syria. There is absolutely no reason to mix up refugees with terrorists.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. – As evidenced by the attacks in France, USA, Spain, England... but also Tunisia, Turkey, Lebanon or Saudi Arabia, the terrorist threat of a jihadist nature is global. The answer must therefore be coordinated. France has invoked the collective defence clause in Article 42(7) of the EU Treaty. In this context, which reminds us that we are partners obliged to protect each other, complemented by the framework of the United Nations and NATO, it is absolutely urgent to get to work to create a European counter-terrorism police, with unified command, and to share the tasks of actions abroad in a coordinated and unitary manner in accordance with the advantages , assets and possibilities of each Member State. None of us will be sure if you don't have the support of others.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – The Paris attacks show that we need more Europe for the safety of our citizens: less Europe has made it easier for terrorists to murder. Governments are responsible for political leadership to establish European coordination of intelligence services, police and judicial cooperation, which need to have enhanced resources and capabilities and not continue to be reduced by disastrous austerity policies, which also foster the ghettos from which terrorists came from.  We need to work for peace and security in the neighbourhood - it is the conflicts there that come into our door! We need a common security and defence policy within the framework of a coherent common foreign and security policy. And well we need consistency: to say that "we are at war" is to give terrorists a political status, to play them. We must attack the sources of terrorist financing: arms trafficking, oil, money laundering, calling to account all funders and facilitators, many playing double play, such as Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Turkey. Finally, Mr Weber's accusation to the Socialists that they had tried yesterday to make amendments to the PNR in the Dati report is false. It is a dirty blow against the convergence we need to fight terrorism.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – How many have we learned from the fight against radicalism and terrorism and in prevention since the 9/11 attacks in Madrid? The answer is that it has not been enough: we have not advanced or learned what is necessary. It has not been enough when it comes to information and intelligence: we still do not share the information needed to attack terrorism. Nor has it been in terms of cutting off the sources of funding of terrorist groups or for structuring a common foreign policy that responds coherently to conflicts, from which these radicalization processes and terrorist groups feed. Nor have we done what is necessary to build a European response. In fact, today the Council presents us with a number of measures which we support, but many of them were already available to the Member States, which have not used them. There has been an anti-terrorism strategy since 2015, there is a counter-terrorism coordinator, Europol, Eurojust... Let's use the tools we have and launch the new instruments without falling into an improvisation dictated from panic. Let us not allow terrorists to determine our agenda and protect our European values.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – Expressing my sincerest condolences to the victims of the Paris terror attack and the great solidarity to the French Republic, I want to make it clear: terrorists cannot, must not and will not win. Europe must remain true to its values: freedom and an open society without creating divisions by religious or national standards, because that is exactly what terrorists want. In all this, Europe must have one and a unified attitude. Europe must immediately unite all forces, especially all those security services that directly care about the security of our security. We must also unite all countries that are ready without calculations to destroy the Islamic State which is the greatest threat to world peace. We need to lead the coalition and involve Russia, the U.S., Iran, Turkey and all the actors who will be ready to win this new world war.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – Brussels is on its fifth day of highest alert, with a direct terrorist threat. Will the deaf also know that the football game has been cancelled, the shopping centres have closed, the subway is not running, the kindergartens are closed? Will they know in time when the danger has passed? On Monday evening, the whole of Belgium waited tensely in front of television sets for the Belgian Prime Minister's announcement on whether the level four terror alert would remain on Tuesday, whether the metro would restart the next day, whether children should be allowed to go to school. Prime Minister Charles Michel's words, however, could not be understood by the deaf because a sign language interpreter was not present at the press conference. It is regrettable that there was no information available to the deaf and hard of hearing either after the Paris attacks or in the exceptional situation in Brussels. There is no adequate solution at European or Member State level in the European Union and the deaf are therefore a high-risk group.  Hungary a good example: in the event of the recent flooding on the Danube, Viktor Orbán's briefing was a sign language interpreter to ensure that our desican fellow citizens were also informed in their mother tongue about what to do, the danger or how it would go away. In addition, in Hungary, the National Disaster Management Service operates an app called EMERGENCY, which can be downloaded free of charge to smartphones and tablets, which allows anyone to get instant written information on the dangers lurking in their immediate vicinity on their smartphone, or even about nationally issued warnings and alerts.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – All those who spoke today condemned the notion that migrants are terrorists. I agree that the equation migrants = terrorists is unacceptable. But let's talk about what can happen if we don't listen to security policy experts, psychologists and other experts. Hundreds of thousands of people come to Europe uncontrollably. Many to save their bare lives. These include economic migrants who do not require international protection. They come in such quantities that Europe cannot integrate them all. Try to imagine what will happen to those who do not receive asylum. We're going to have to send hundreds of thousands of people home. We don't even know where they are at the moment. Many of them came to Europe without registration. Without work and money, they'll be frustrated and unhappy that they didn't get away with it. Under certain circumstances, they can become easy prey for crime. There are already more than 100 attempts to recruit for the ranks of the Islamic State. This is what responsible politicians have to count on. We must say as soon as possible what we will do about those who are already in Europe. But also how quickly we will achieve the situation so that people can apply for asylum or the possibility of being employed in the EU from the outside, and they did not have to cross half of Europe first and pay smugglers for it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. – The recent terrorist attacks in France demonstrate the pressing need to form an international force capable of fighting and defeating the self-proclaimed Islamic State. For the first time in the history of the Treaty of Lisbon, France has used Article 42(7), which provides for a solidarity clause in the event of aggression against an EU country. It is an article that has never been used in the history of our Union. I understand that, in addition to attacks on strategic targets, countries must stop funding the Islamic State, stop acquiring oil resources from ISIS and try to build a real economic blockade so that they run out of resources to finance their activities. The European Union must take a leading role on the international political scene, building the necessary bridges with the US and Russia to defeat ISIS, and it is essential to improve the education of our young people in schools, prevent the radicalisation of young people and improve control and surveillance systems at EU borders.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. "We have witnessed a series of tragic events in recent weeks. The crash of the Russian plane and the terrorist attacks in Beirut and Paris have killed more than 400 people. This affects hundreds of families, as the victims were parents, husbands, wives, children, siblings, the loss of whom is not easy to cope with. We soon realized that the series of attacks did not end there, not a week passed and the drama continued in Mali. The recent attacks were not directed against a specific target group, anyone could have fallen victim regardless of religion, nationality or colour, and that is what terrorizes European citizens. They don't dare go out, they're alarmed by the sirens of the police car. Parents are worried about sending their children to school because, after frequent bomb scares, it doesn't seem like a safe place anymore. European values have been attacked and we have a duty to provide adequate protection – this must be our top priority! At this difficult time, it is particularly important for the European Union to act as a credible and active actor in the fight against terrorism, and we must provide the necessary tools to do so.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: in writing. – The criminal attacks in Paris have brought guerrilla war onto the streets of Europe, directly affecting the individual security of the European citizens. Two conclusions: first, that Euro-Atlantic security gets abruptly an internal dimension, to complement the external one we were used to until now. Second, that those two dimensions have to be connected and the instruments the EU has to deal with each of them have to be integrated, preferably in one single spectrum, starting with intelligence, then police, then civil defence, then gendarmes and, finally, the armed forces. Technically, that raises two problems: intelligence sharing among the EU’s own agencies and among the MS should be significantly increased and, second, how to use the armed forces in preserving the internal security of the MS. Apart from new regulations and instruments, the EU should engage in a review of the existing ones, of which quite a number do exist but have never been used! In a larger sense, every response we come with should try to preserve the right balance between privacy and public security and attempt – as much as possible – to avoid making our lives even more miserable, thus denying an indirect ‘victory’ to terrorism.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – While the whole world sympathizes with Paris and condemns terrorism, I think it is important to recall that terrorism also happens every day in countries farther from the European Union, with the Middle East and North Africa most affected, and of which it often turned a blind eye until the same happened on European soil. On the same day that all thoughts and prayers were directed towards Paris, lebanon was also a day of mourning. Lebanon mourned the 43 victims of a suicide bombing in Beirut, victims of an attack that left two hundred wounded. According to a UN estimate, 10,000 children and 250,000 adults have been killed in Syria in 4 years, people are being persecuted, driven from their homes and killed. In Nigeria, Boko Haram has abducted at least 2,000 women and girls in a year and has killed more than 10,000,000 civilians in the past few years, while more than 250,000 people are in exile. In the last year alone, 32,658 people have died in terrorist attacks. Terrorism has no faith, no nationality, nothing to do with culture and civilization. Terrorism is the crime I condemn most deeply, and I ask that all mechanisms be used to put an end to this crime.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – Eleven months after the attacks on Charlie Hebdo and the kosher store in Paris, we continue to talk about the need to step up the fight against terrorism at European level. The same measures we discussed in January, we are also discussing now – the adoption of the Passenger Data Directive, the tightening of arms trade controls within the EU, better cooperation between different security services, the prevention of radicalisation among European citizens.  That is why I insist on the rapid strengthening of controls at all the EU's external borders – after the attacks of 13 November in Paris, my country Bulgaria introduced 100% checks on all those passing through the Bulgarian-Turkish border. The security of Europe's external borders must be ensured in order not to question the free movement of persons in the EU and Schengen.  To this end, it is necessary by the end of 2015. to adopted the Passenger Data Exchange Directive – it is unacceptable at the moment that European services cannot track when foreign fighters leave Europe and, more importantly, when they return to commit an act of terrorism. We don't have to wait for more victims to bring these urgently needed measures to an end. European citizens expect us to take swift action to bring back the sense of security in the EU.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. – Many of us believe that Europe will not be changed by terrorism. I, on the other hand, believe that Europe will change in terms of the effects of this "black Friday" – this is the most difficult moment since the Second World War! We have all felt the threat even if we try not to fall prey to fear. I am afraid that the emergency situation will become the norm. I do not want to say that 'refugee is synonymous with terrorism' but, under the current conditions, in which we fail to control our borders, I believe that many fundamentalists, as we have already seen, will take this opportunity to move within the European area. That is why I would like to stress that an increase in financial investment in security measures at the EU's external and internal borders is indispensable. To defeat terrorism we must, before our fellow citizens, here and now, have a clear and real picture of the Islamic State (although it is crazy to call it STAT). International forces must, first of all, find a way to cut off its funding channels, its vital flow: the business circuit. This area must be isolated despite financial interests - this is the only way we will defeat terrorism.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The attacks that hit France have awakened the consciousness of Europe and the world. Yet Daesh is waging war in the Middle East and perpetuating terrorist acts in many countries for several years. Just yesterday, Tunisia was hit. It is time for the European Union to move from words to action and finally and quickly to fight terrorism. It is about protecting its peoples and preserving its values. We must achieve the establishment of a European NRL before the end of the year. The police and intelligence services of the Member States need to cooperate better and the fight against arms trafficking must be considerably strengthened. More funding is also needed to prevent radicalisation and thus fight terrorism at its root. In addition to the military attacks carried out by France in particular, the Union and the Member States have a responsibility to participate in the dismantling of the financial channels that maintain Daesh, money being the nerve of war. All EU states must feel concerned. Daesh does not target a nationality. It strikes the free world and its values, our freedoms, our model of life, peace.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – Following the terrible events in Paris, we must articulate clearly and loudly what our values are, from which we must not retreat: equality of all people in no difference, mutual respect and democracy as the only way to solve public problems. And that must be respected by anyone who wants to live here.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – The terrorist attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015 have dramatically awakened us all – thankfully, at last most responsible European governments and leaders – that the EU can only stand together against this threat in full unity, both in Europe and in the Middle East. I believe that it is time for the solidarity on which the Union is based to really prevail in the areas of law enforcement, intelligence and military cooperation.  In agreement with the initiatives taken so far by Member States and jointly, such as measures to restrict trade in arms, control passenger traffic and dismantle the base of the IA, I stress that the end result cannot be a permanent closure of European borders or the surrender of our European principles on civil liberties. Faced with such a serious common challenge, it is particularly shocking that there are politicians in Europe (especially Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban) who are using the current dramatic situation to spread their populist demagogy and, even after Paris, have allowed themselves public statements that "all terrorist immigrants" or the Commission's quota proposal on the distribution of migrants is "aimed at spreading terrorism on our continent".  I am convinced that, with a joint international and European effort, we will one day finally overcome the terror of terror; however, the political poison that reinforces the approach reflected in such statements in our citizens will have an even longer effect. I therefore call for a strict and consistent common European rejection of such dangerous policies and rhetoric.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The terrorist attacks in Paris have left the French capital in mourning and have also caused a wave of sadness in Europe. In order to fully understand the mechanisms that lead to such tragic events, we need to think about what the bombers really want to achieve by wreading death and terror. The targets of islamic state extremists in Europe are different from those in the Middle East. There, by spreading anarchy and chaos, they seek to expand their power in terrorized territories. In Europe, on the other hand, the goal must not be to increase its influence, because here ISIS will never gain power. So one suspects that Islamic extremists are talking about something else. For example, to create a wave of hatred in Europe against Muslims and representatives of other minorities in order to bring about a wave of violence. Riots, destruction of property, and eventually racially motivated murders in turn could provoke counter-attacks by Muslims against indigenous peoples and lead to a kind of religious war, a war of civilization. Perhaps the destruction of Europe with the hands of Europeans is a dream scenario for Islamic fundamentalists. That is why it is so important that, even in the face of bloody terrorist attacks like the last one in Paris, we should not allow acts of retaliation and revenge against innocent people. This is a great challenge for the European Union and the Member States.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Written. – Terrorism transcends borders. Not only the borders of the EU Member States, but also the borders between EU and non-EU countries. Terrorism is a global problem. As with climate change, that other global problem, it's nonsense to think that folding back on one's own state can solve the problem. Countries on their own, no matter how big or small they are, are unable to cope with global problems. After all, climate change does not stop at national borders, nor does radical ideas and terrorism. More cooperation is therefore needed, not less. Enhanced cooperation within the EU but also internationally.  Within the EU, this involves greater cooperation between intelligence services, the maximum sharing and exchange of information (while respecting the privacy of ordinary citizens) and the creation of a European intelligence service. All this in combination with proper control of our external borders so that Schengen can be maintained. But more cooperation is also needed between the EU and third countries to stop terrorism and to help countries like Syria move towards a transition to a democratic state. Only an international coalition can do that. Anyone who thinks that one country can create a safer world individually is wandering.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – Never during its existence for more than half a century has the EU been subjected to challenges similar to those we experience today, when the forces that set out to break up European construction from within meet those that tear apart the Union from the outside. The Paris attacks have already reached their goal, because fear and mistrust seem to encompass us all. The EU's response and Member States' responses will make a difference whether Paris is 11 September of the Union or not. At the same time, the highest stake is the EU's greatest conquest, namely the free movement area. The EU ceases to exist in the absence of free movement. If the Schengen Agreement no longer responds today to the challenges that we all face, then the agreement must be amended. It is just that, an agreement and a regulation agreed by the Member States and which they must also adapt to the realities. The amendment of this agreement must not in any way raise barriers in the EU, but adapt security measures and European cooperation to the new realities. The double measure, the hypocrisy and endless repetition of the same speeches without the facts following put our Union at risk.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. – I would like to express my sincere condolences to the families and loved ones of the victims of the terrorist attack in Paris. This tragedy has confirmed the inhumanity of fanatics calling themselves the Islamic State and has exposed weaknesses in the security of the whole of Europe. The answer to the terrible act that has killed innocent people must be more cooperation and solidarity between our peoples. We are weaker than when we act together. The European project is not threatened by terrorists or refugees, but by populism, demagoguery and small-thinky, promoted to a political principle. I believe and hope that neither the tragedy in Paris nor the efforts of irresponsible people who want to abuse it to strengthen their own power will undermine Europe's project as a community of freedom, security, prosperity and solidarity.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Dear President Mattarella. Thank you for being here today. Mr President, your personal history shows a constant and profound commitment to the defence and strengthening of the European project. The European institutions were part of your first visit abroad as President of the Republic and in all your speeches in Italy and abroad you always remember not only the need for the European project for Italy, but also the roots and strength of your country's Pro-European vocation. Today you will address a Parliament and a European Union that is still deeply shaken by the attacks and the terrorist threat. A terror that shocked us all, which had as its objective our Europe, our values, our youth. Italy has united with great solidarity with the people of French and Italy itself has lost an exemplary citizen of its own. Yesterday, Mr President, you were in Venice, where the funeral of Valeria Solesin, the young researcher of the Sorbonne killed by terrorists at the Bataclan, was held in St Mark's Square. Her smile, her face, her commitment to volunteering, her research and her call for women to participate in the world of work will remain indelible and demonstrating what divides Valeria Solesin's Europe from the murderous madness of jihadist terror. The whole of Europe is gathered around the family of Valeria Solesin and all the victims of terror.  Europe is threatened by crises and global problems. It must rise to the challenges we face. As you yourself said when you spoke to members of the European Parliament in Italy, the choice is between a Europe that tackles phenomena and governs them, and a Europe that suffers events without being able to guide them.  Italy is on the side of the answer. It was the driving force and inspiration behind European integration, even when the rest of Europe was not yet ready to follow economic governance and the common immigration policy.  Dear President Mattarella, thank you for being here today and I give you the floor.

name: Sergio Mattarella
text: President. Mr Schulz, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the European Parliament for giving me the privilege of addressing this House, which represents the peoples of the Union. I am taking the floor at a particularly dramatic time for all of us. Europe is wounded: Brussels, Copenhagen, London, Madrid and Paris are painful and ineradicable lacerations on the body of our Union.  We are still dismayed by what happened in Paris and we are all trying – together – to address the pain that has been felt by the families of the victims, the physical and moral suffering of the injured, the sense of anguish and insecurity in our communities. I would like to reiterate once again, with force, total and unconditional solidarity with France, its institutions, its people, and particularly the families affected by this immense tragedy. Yesterday, as President Schulz has just mentioned, we said goodbye to Venice, to Valeria Solesin, an Italian girl, a European girl, whose young life was cut short, with heinousness, along with that of 129 other people. I would like to combine the memory of Valeria Solesin with the memory of this Day to combat violence against women. In Paris, our everyday lives, our conception of being together, our habits were affected: that way of being, thinking and living that is precisely and characteristic of the citizens of the Union. This year we recalled the 70th anniversary of the end of the Second World War and, last year, the centenary of the beginning of the First World War. Two tragedies from which the immense suffering was born, the idea of a Europe that knew how to unite rather than fight has grown and rooted itself. The European Union is the result of this long and vital process that is still under way and it is the progressive integration that has enabled our fellow Europeancitizens to experience a period of peace and social, cultural and economic development unique in the history of our continent. A story that has produced rights and increased protections for all. The Europe that you represent was born of solidarity, of former enemies who were able to unite in the name of common values, of former cold war adversaries who have been able to create, in recent years, the largest area of democracy and freedom that ever existed, making a decisive contribution to stability and peace.  However, this is no longer enough. We are all being asked today, with arrogance, for more responsibility, more initiative, more cohesion. Only in this way will we be able to overcome the arrogant challenges that terrorism brings to our homes, having bloodied the Middle Eastern, African and Asian lands, which are still seriously affected, as last week in Bamako and yesterday in Tunis. The contrasts of the bipolar era have helped to push European countries to stand together. Today, from the east and from the south, new strong instability has come to our borders. It is more essential than ever to promote – together – intelligent neighbourhood policies in order to share peace-building strategies, isolating all extremism. The European Union is, in the international context and in the collective imagination, a point of reference for every person, people or State that bases its existence on peace between nations, freedoms and respect for citizens' rights. A political embankment against obscurantism. That is why they are attacking us head-on, as has also happened to the United States of America.  I am addressing a Parliamentary Assembly which represents the people of Europe and which, at the same time, is the guardian of the plurality of identity that enriches our Being Europeans: the battle that sees us engaged not in a short time, requires unity. Unity and determination, in order to combat, together, all violence and to guarantee full security for our fellow citizens; preserving the essential defence of freedom and rights.  The architecture of the European institutions is based on the values of democracy, tolerance and acceptance. In view of the enormous migratory pressures coming from countries where terrorism originates and in the light of the dramatic events in Paris, the question today is whether some of these principles should not be called into question, starting with the free movement of persons. Hence the recurring temptation to close the borders, both external, by blocking the way for those fleeing war zones or hunger, and internally, by compressing one of the many great freedoms that we have laboriously made the right of our citizens. I believe that we must face these challenges in the light of the values for which we declare our fight.  Answers that are only apparently simple do not help us, either ideally or in terms of appropriate and effective solutions. On the ideal one, because they push us to renounce the fundamental principles of our being rights that we have built and that we have a duty to protect, for us and for future generations. Simplifications are not even persuasive in terms of lasting solutions, because the phenomena we are witnessing are global in nature and no country alone is able to face them, however strong it may be, however proud it may be, like everyone else, of its history.  During the Second World War, democracies, starting in the United Kingdom, did not wonder how to save themselves alone, but instead knew how to call for the greatest international mobilization of consciences. Today it is up to the European Union to hold firm the helm of civilisation and humanism. It is through an effective increase in cooperation between the Member States – from security apparatus to intelligence activities – that we will be able, together, to defeat terrorism, to make our citizens safer and to protect our way of life. It is only by working together more – and not less – that we could rise to this challenge, including in the field of the common foreign and defence policy.  We must not forget that sixty years of progressive integration, while respecting differences, specificities and traditions, have created a European demos: a growing fusion of our society which has produced concrete and visible results in terms of rights, protections, sensitivities and ways of leading one's life, from one end of the Union to the other, from Lapland to Cyprus, from the Danube Delta to the Algarve. A single Area of European Freedom, which we cannot lose but which, on the contrary, we must be able to extend, in order to protect the good of security.  The Union has produced European law – presided over by the Court of Justice – which is part, in many areas, of the daily lives of our citizens: a common heritage that they could no longer do without. And you, the legislators in this Parliament, know this better than anyone. The voice of the citizens of Europe, who have stood up in recent days to call for the fight against barbarism, has been a testimony to Europe's pressing demand for unity.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with an apparent paradox: on the one hand, we have witnessed the progressive emergence of this new European demos; on the other hand, the Union and its Member States are showing fatigue, increasing difficulties in dealing with and resolving, together, the crises that have affected them. It was the result of the international financial crisis, which did not leave the sovereign debts of states unscathed; It has been the result of the serious crisis which has depressed the economies of many Member States of the Union, with serious repercussions in terms of social cohesion. In recent years, the need to be able to look far has not always guided us, and if we can learn from it and global solutions to global problems must be given. We need to move from the emergency logic, which has characterised the approach to crises in recent years, to a long-term vision, which allows the Union to develop policies that stimulate growth, create jobs and permanently reduce inequalities. This is the way to guarantee our citizens a prospect of economic and social progress and to ensure that Europe plays a leading role in the emerging world.  Thus, for example, with regard to monetary union, the report of the five Presidents sets out a path on which, I hope, appropriate political and methodological convergences can soon be reached – because time is short – defining the indispensable role of the European Parliament in order to guarantee its democratic foundation.  The institutions – and the European institutions are no exception – are strengthened if they know how to renew themselves, if they know what can be improved without yielding to destructive or paralysing pressures. For example, in terms of completing the single market or applying the principle of subsidiarity more effectively between the Union and the Member States. We must be able to make choices of greater unity in all the areas in which we are committed.  The free movement of persons, put under pressure – as I have said – both by the phenomenon of migration and by the threat of terrorism, has as its logical corollary the strengthening of cooperation between the Member States for the protection and management of the common external border and, secondly, for the creation of common institutions capable of managing migratory flows. Only those who do not want to see can pretend that they do not know where the painful caravan of people going back to Asia and the Middle East, Africa to Europe, comes from. They repeat the tragedy of the Jews fleeing Nazism; of the hundreds of thousands of prisoners of war who roamed Europe in the aftermath of the Second World War in search of hearths that had been destroyed; of the refugees whose community homes suddenly had become part of another country. They are the heirs of those who, at the risk of their lives, went through the Berlin Wall; of the citizens who, defying the minefields, were trying to cross from Hungary to Austria.  The world is on the move, on the legs of millions of women, children, men, often victims of cruel human traffickers: it is a helpless army, marching in search of its own salvation. What can we oppose their reasons for? It is not they who are fleeing death and violence, our enemy. They are heading for Europe, seen not only as a place of prosperity but even more as an area of freedom, the protection of rights and peace. We must defend Europe's security, but we cannot disfigure it in order to make it less attractive.  Rather, Europe as a whole needs to update its rules in order to deal with a phenomenon that is different, by nature and by size, from the time when the asylum rules were written. The Dublin Agreements capture a reality and a past that is no longer there. That is why they are outdated: overcome by reality, which is an inflexible judge. The need is to define new rules based on the principles of humanity and security, solidarity and responsibility, and in any case adapted to the new reality before us.  The choice, in the final analysis – and not only in the field of migration – is, I would like to repeat, here too, before you, as legislators of Europe, between a Union that tackles phenomena by trying to regulate them and a Europe that suffers events without being able to govern them, with the consequent increase in internal imbalances and mistrust and mistrust between the Member States.  Our values will affirm their authenticity and consolidate their authority if they are able to receive gratitude and admiration for the welcome and help given to those in difficulty. This message would help to water down the propaganda of hatred and death sown by fundamentalist terrorism, in so many countries, from the Middle East to Africa and also – as the sad reality of these days reminds us – in the cities of Europe.  At the meeting between the European Union and African countries in Valletta in recent weeks, as well as in the diplomatic activities under way with Turkey, some important first steps were taken. We have defined strategies and made clear commitments. It is now a question of honouring the offers of aid to countries along the Balkan and Eastern Mediterranean routes and of following up the commitments made with African countries on development cooperation and mobility. It is right to help them, and this seems, moreover, to be the only way to be perceived as credible partners and to be able to call for greater cooperation on returns, in order, moreover, to prevent migratory flows from having even greater and completely unstoppable dimensions in the near future, and also to prevent terrorism from finding additional breeding grounds in other countries in difficulty.  The need for greater and better Europe is felt with particular intensity, at this troubled time, also in terms of foreign policy. A process of increasing régionalisation is under way in the world. Increasingly manifest and structured macro-areas will be called upon to assume responsibility for managing the balance of the planet. It is a phenomenon that is born and develops by looking with appreciation – often with admiration – at our experience, at the model created by the European Union.  The world needs Europe and it needs a united Europe. Of a Europe that knows how to complete its organic design, and I am thinking of the Western Balkans area. The Union can foster the international convergences necessary for Syria, Iraq and Libya by seeking shared choices that effectively counter the forces of disorder and terror. Yesterday's tragic events confirm its urgency. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the vote in May 2014, the citizens expressed the inescapable need for a change of pace on the part of the Union's institutions, in order to overcome any delay with regard to the indication of that horizon of values contained in the Treaties and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. I look with great respect and confidence to this House. The European Parliament has always played a leading role and Italy is one of the supporters of this institution, convinced as it is of its essential role in the process of gradually deepening the political issue of the European Union and consolidating its democratic foundation.  If the world turns to the example set by the European Union for non-dissimilar forms of growing peaceful cooperation elsewhere, the European shipyard cannot remain halfway there. We can't look back, other than to assess what we've left behind of mistrust, rivalry and confrontation which, in the last century, devastated us. Designing the future, starting from the difficulties and challenges we are experiencing, is the way to govern the present well, with its problems so serious.  I would like to remind you, once again, of Jean Monnet's statement: 'We cannot stop when the whole world is on the move'. In the wake of this exhortation, I wish you all the best of good work in the service of Europe and peace. (Parliament stood up and applauded the speaker)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes). - Before the votes:

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I have asked to speak on a point of order since this morning, but I understand that we had the serious issue of discussing criminal acts of terrorism in Paris.  The question I want to raise concerns the way in which the Bureau works during the discussions. When the Bureau announces to the House a specific decision it will have to abide by it by the end of the debate, and I would like to make it clear: last night there were two important issues left for discussion, health and safety at work and the gender gap in pensions.  The President-in-Office announced that during the discussion of these two issues there would be no catch-the-eye procedure. I confirmed this with him and he told me that he insists on this decision. Following this decision, which I respected, I left the Chamber for the debate.  When I was outside the semicircum - away - I found, because I watched the debate, that I finally changed the rules and proceeded to catch-the-eye procedure on the last topic. I therefore want an explanation on this matter, and above all, Mr President, to have clear conditions with regard to the debates at the beginning of the debate.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Yes, Mr Marias, I do. We are looking into the facts, I will examine it and then I will tell you.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The budget for 2016 has been adopted. Congratulations to the rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Deprez. Thank you for your hard work and very, very careful work, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I will be very brief.  I wanted to be there when you are going to approve the European Union budget. As a representative of the Presidency, I just wanted to rejoice in the very good cooperation we have had with Parliament and the Commission. We have managed to conclude the negotiations on time and the very good news is that, for the first time in a long time, the Member States have unanimously approved this budget. This proves that we have found a compromise that suits both. I would like to congratulate the Chairman of the Committee on Budgets, Mr Jean Arthuis, the rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Deprez, as well as Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial and Mr Geier, for their tireless work, and above all the Commission which has inaugurated, I believe, a more transparent procedure in order to reach a compromise more quickly and to avoid costs and reasons for anger in order to arrive with more serenity. I would also like to point out that we have reached agreement on administrative and personnel issues which, I believe, has made the horizon clearer and which, in fact, reinforces the inter-institutional confidence that we really need in these difficult times in the face of the budgetary challenges we face. But the budgetary challenges are simply a reflection of the tragedies affecting Europe, the budget being, of course, an important element, but perhaps not the most difficult, as we know and as the previous discussion and the excellent speech of the Italian President also showed us very well.  Therefore, in the face of these great difficulties, it is good to have budgetary serenity.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee on 14 November 2015 was approved by Parliament and the Council.  The budgetary procedure was carried out in accordance with Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It is now closed with these decisions. I note hereby that the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2016 has been definitively adopted. I shall now sign this budget under your witness.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to make a point of order under Rule 186 of the Rules of Procedure. That is what my group has asked – we all looked deep in the eye here on Monday and agreed to extend the existing mandate of the TAXE Committee – to call on the Conference of Presidents to take appropriate action so that we can do so this week. This was rejected by the Tabling Desk, saying that we were interfering with the competences of the Conference of Presidents. However, I do not see how an invitation to the Conference of Presidents to do something interferes with competences. In this respect, I would ask you to decide whether you could decide on the admission of this request in accordance with Rule 170(3) of the Rules of Procedure. Secondly, I would like to ask whether it is true that the PPE-DE, S&D and ALDE have met, to the exclusion of the Greens and the Group of the Left, in order to decide on a new, narrower mandate, in order to avoid other unpleasant questions for people like Mr Gramegna – he is there – or Mr Juncker or Mr Dijsselbloem. This is totally unacceptable, and I am asking for clarification on this.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr de Masi, I would like to thank mr de Masi for his excellent On the last point, I cannot give you any clarification. The political groups must express their opinion on this. On the request you first made, you have written a letter to the Tabling Desk. I am now grateful that the Tabling Desk has given me this letter. I learned from the letter that you held me responsible for the Tabling Desk decision. But I only found out about it through your letter, so that was clear. My second point is that the Conference of Presidents will decide tomorrow, as far as I know, on the establishment of a so-called TAXE II Committee. In any case, this has been requested because today, with this Theurer/Ferreira report on the TAXE-I Committee, we are voting on a final report which is part of the mandate. In other words, I have heard your request. I assume that the content of your request will also be discussed tomorrow in the Conference of Presidents. Today, however, we are closing the TAXE-I Committee with this report. However, if we have concluded the TAXE-I Committee with the adoption of this report, then we cannot extend the mandate. That is a contradiction in itself. That is why the Tabling Desk has said that your amendment – incidentally, it has just been tabled by you – is not admissible.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, on Monday commitments were made here in session. If you had legal doubts about the validity, Mr President, then it was up to you to express them. Besides, you don't refrain from expressing yourself at all times about everything, so if you had something to say you had to say it at that time. What you just said is wrong, legally wrong! There is no problem with a special committee tabling a report, voting a report, voting two or ten, if it pleases. It is not for you to pronounce Martin Schulz's legal interpretation. We have a legal department for that and the legal department has not spoken in that regard.  Commitments have been made by the President of the EPP Group, by Mr Peter Simon on behalf of the Socialist Group, these commitments must be kept. Tomorrow, therefore, I am waiting for the Conference of Presidents to extend the mandate of the TAXE Committee as promised. It is not a question of TAXE 1, 2, 10 or 69, if you will. Your abuse of power, Mr. President, is starting to tire everyone here. We are not, here, subject to King Schulz! (Applause from his group)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, the President is responsible for interpreting the Rules of Procedure. If there are any doubts, the Bureau of this House, if necessary the Conference of Presidents, will deal with it, if necessary the AFCO Committee, which will then interpret it. The fact that you are now claiming that my interpretation is wrong is your right. But you do not have the right to say that Martin Schulz interprets the Rules of Procedure as Martin Schulz. I do so in my capacity in office. If you don't agree with that, ... (Interjections) I have kindly listened to you to the end, perhaps you have the same courtesy. If you do not agree with this, that is your right not to agree with it. You have just made that clear.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, may I make a point of order? For Rules of Procedure we are supposed to be able to vote properly, aren’t we? You are going at a very fast speed that means we cannot get our hands up and down in the right place. Are you just going by the voting list of the Socialists and the Liberals in front of you, or are you actually looking at the vote? Because we cannot get our hands up and down in the right place. This is not a very good advert for the public gallery.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Firstly, sir, I am trying to be very careful about this. I follow every check call. I think that some other things in the public gallery cause more horror than these things.

name: Julia REID
text: – Mr President, you are going so fast, the interpreters cannot keep up and the interpreters are getting it wrong! (Uproar)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: You can also follow it on the screens, then it is relatively easy.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, this was a disgrace to democracy. The speed at which you went through that voting list was obscene. I intend to send a copy of it to every Member of the House of Commons, the House of Lords and the Scottish Parliament to show what a farce this place is. If that is your idea of democracy, this place is a joke. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr President, you are free to send a text or a link to every Parliament in the world, where our votes and our debates are reproduced. I am sure colleagues are very interested.  However, any colleague is also free to send appropriate excerpts of Mr Coburn's appearances to Parliament.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, I believe our Parliament offers training courses for Members. Perhaps UKIP Members could be offered a training course first in parliamentary democracy and second in learning how to read.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Corbett very much for his rather interesting intervention. If I might explain the problem to you, Mr Corbett, the difficulty is that there is one thing on a screen, there is another thing being said in one language, it is being translated into English, there are constant mistakes in that, we are reading the voting lists at exactly the same time and mistakes are made when that entire process takes something like five to six seconds. There is something deeply wrong with a democratic system in which we do not know whether people have voted in favour or against. Even President Schulz, earlier, was calling votes as having gone against when they had actually gone in favour, or in favour when they had actually gone against. That is a fundamental nonsense and surely, Mr Corbett, if you believe – and you are, I believe, a true believer – in the institutions and structures of this place, then you should be on our side on this one! You should be standing up against things that are going wrong, but you are not. And I look around and I see your Labour colleagues – my Labour colleague in the north—east was smiling, joking and clapping at any suggestion that we can get things done more quickly. That is a nonsense, an absolute nonsense! So can we please at least have the semblance of democracy in this place for once? It would be nice. Sadly, with regard to the anti—democratic comments of those who just want to get lunch quicker: lunch is not more important than democracy. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: So again. But listen to an answer is also part of democracy. But you don't seem so interested in answers.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: I would like to congratulate you on the way in which you conducted this meeting and with the speed and efficiency with which you have done so. And for those who found it difficult: there are screens showing exactly what mood there is. So, you are my favorite chairman and I would like to see you back on this chair many more times.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to join in, perhaps in a slightly calmer tone. I understand German really well, and when I hear the interpretation in the headphones and at the same time you, it happens often enough that you ask "Who is against?", but in the headphones there is the interpretation, where the question is asked: "Who is for this?". This is not related to the screens. I can see here too which point is decided, that is not a problem. But when it come to the vote by show of hands, you are already a question further. There are really often very complicated and confusing situations. I don't mean that badly, but you ask too quickly. I am also opposed to the way in which the gentlemen say that they do not have to roar so much. But I really have trouble with that. Personally, I have no problem with you, because I can listen to the German. But when a colleague from Italy or Hungary says that, I am so confused, I have no idea how to vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr! I would like to express my thanks for your objective tone and I would like to try to respond to it in a truly factual way. We have 24 official languages here, and it is absolutely impossible for anyone who understands Finnish to sit in the Portuguese cabin at every meeting. In other words, we also have a number of languages that are interpreted in the relay. The second interpreter has to wait for the first interpretation to be there. The English colleagues are still in a very privileged situation. But a number of colleagues sitting in this House have even become accustomed to it with Greek colleagues: this 'kat' is called 'against'! So I personally have never felt in any way misled by the "for", "against". That is one thing. So we cannot wait for that to be in every interpretation. Today, I believe, we have had 101 roll-call votes and at least as many open votes. If we invest ten more seconds for each vote, until every language is there, then we will completely swell. In other words, we must ensure efficiency. I've gotten used to talking to no one if someone thinks I've made the wrong decision. Suffice it for a colleague to call 'Check', then I will check the vote. Otherwise, I think I was wrong today. Today I really felt insecure about some things, because it was really confusing. Then I said of myself that we are doing an electronic check. Otherwise, this is a relatively easy exercise. If you look closely at the fact that three large groups are pointing in the same direction, then it may not seem entirely satisfactory to you, but then it is clear where the majority is, and then you can give a little gas. Because if you only count 750 colleagues for one minute, that's already 12 man-hours. If we save ten minutes, that is 120 man-hours in which you can work something more sensibly.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, please, my earlier remarks were intended really in response to Mr Corbett’s rather rude remarks directed towards those of us in UKIP. I completely understand the difficulties that you face. The reason you face these difficulties is, of course, that there are often in Strasbourg over a thousand times when we have to vote in a single week. It makes this something where you have time pressures which perhaps you should not have, and certainly in Westminster we would not have a problem like this one. What I would say, though, is that if we are trying to cram so much into just a couple of days a month in Strasbourg and in Brussels, maybe there is a problem with the scheduling of debates and votes. We have already heard from Mr Moraes that there were all sorts of problems and I had exactly the same problem. I tried to speak in a debate last night in the catch-the-eye where catch-the-eye was cancelled. Now if we are not having a proper debate, then the question should surely be that we need to have enough time allocated so that we can have debates, and we need to have enough time allocated for the vote. I would make that point very much independently of my feelings about this place and the institutions because, fundamentally, things should be done in the right way and they are not being done in the right way at the moment. Please do not take that as a personal criticism, I am not criticising you personally, although of course I was criticising the Member, who was quite insulting.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr What I am most opposed to is your patronising and arrogant attitude towards certain Members of this House. I am absolutely convinced that you have a political opinion, but it is not up to you to place any emphasis whatsoever on political convictions when acting as president of the meeting. You should remain completely neutral and your personal political views are completely irrelevant. You're going to treat everyone equally in this House, and i'm afraid you're not.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I have twenty-six years of experience in this Chamber, and I fully understand the difficulties of your role. I believe that beyond this question of form, there is a fundamental problem that has been raised by our British colleague, namely that in reality we are voting too many texts and our texts are far too confusing and far too verbose. They are not concise enough and are, it must be said, far removed from the European legal ideal. When I entered this Parliament, the Strasbourg session really lasted a week. It ended on Friday and even Friday afternoon. As a result, there were three actual voting sessions. However, for some time now, all the votes have actually been concentrated on Wednesdays at noon. A neighbour of Ms. Le Pen was complained that she had voted for her once or twice, but on that day, for example, the voting session lasted two and a half hours. It must be understood that a number of colleagues also have physiological obligations, which can sometimes lead them to abstain from participating in our European democracy.  Therefore, I am not incriminating you at all. There are two remedies. A short-term remedy is to learn that in German dafar, dagegen, enthaltung, it means for, against and abstention, in Greek, iper, katà, apochi, etc. It does not take much experience to assimilate the language of each presiding officer. The other, more serious remedy, the substantive remedy, is to vote less and vote for them better.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Firstly, if I was partisan, I would be very grateful if you would write me what you mean in concrete terms, then I am ready to deal with you. I have only reacted allergically because words have been spoken here – that it is a disgrace, that it is complete nonsense – and that a language has been chosen which I personally consider to be unparliamentary and not relevant. I would also like to say once again that we used to have more opportunity for speaking time and for votes. We met earlier until Friday morning. I think that would be more efficient. So we cannot say, on the one hand, that we want more speaking time, on the other hand, we want to constantly saw Strasbourg on a chair leg and, thirdly, we complain that it is too crowded. I would also like to point out that we have fewer voters in Brussels than here in Strasbourg.  Otherwise, I would like to end the debate now and would give colleagues the opportunity to come to their explanations of vote. That concludes the vote.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions, there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it recovers resources from the European Data Protection Supervisor by returning certain amounts not spent by that Supervisor during the previous financial year. This report stresses that all these surpluses should be geared towards aid and management of the refugee crisis, as well as humanitarian aid to Syria. This should be a priority line for the Union's resources during the 2015 financial year due to its size and the serious humanitarian situation faced by refugees. It is to make these resources available for these objectives of aid to migrants and I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We supported this report as it calls on the Member States to use part of the allocation, in particular the one which comes from EU revenue, EUR 2.3 billion, to be used for the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and UN agencies supporting refugees and humanitarianism.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The project aims to revise the forecasts of traditional own resources (tariffs), the budgeting of the remaining balances of VAT and GNI own resources in 2014 and the budgeting of the balance of VAT and GNI own resources in 2015 and the updating of forecasts for other revenues. Revenues from customs duties were in excess of EUR 800 million, the remainder of the 2014 VAT and GNI balances and the 2015 balance of EUR 7.1 billion, and unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines of EUR 1.47 billion. In total, this reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 EU budget by 9.4 billion euros, for France by 1.45 billion euros. However, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis and, in particular, to distribute immigrants in rural areas. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This amending budget refers to the return of money to Member States which is rightfully theirs and which lies outside the scope of the 2015 budget. This needs to be done. However, the report criticises Member States and brings the subject of migration into it, making highly critical comments. That is a nonsense; the money does not belong to the EU and it is not for the EU to lecture Member States about how they should spend it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to approve draft amending budget No 8. It adjusts forecasts of traditional own resources (customs) and includes in the budget the remaining amount of VAT and GNI balances for 2014 and 2015.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: Nicolas BAY
