text: In writing. The Commission's proposal follows a revision of the EU's 2015 budget revenue forecasts. As a result, revenues were much higher than expected: a surplus of 9.4 billion euros. Therefore, it was decided to reduce the contribution of the Member States by an equivalent amount, i.e. EUR 1.45 billion for France: a decision which I can only welcome. However, the report recommends using this "windfall" to finance the management of the migrant crisis (including their distribution in rural areas). In these circumstances, it was out of the question to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this report which takes note of the draft amending budget No. 8/2015 presented by the Commission and the Council's position on it. The rapporteur deeply regrets that this draft amending budget results in a reduction of EUR 9.403 billion in Member States' contributions to the EU budget, but does not propose any compromise to reallocate these funds to finance the refugee crisis, whether it is aid to NGOs, funding the fund for Africa or the reception in refugee camps of countries neighbouring conflict zones.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I have chosen to abstain on the report on the draft amending budget, which concerns own resources and the European data controller. While I am pleased that this revision of traditional own resource forecasts, in particular tariffs, leads to a reduction in the contribution of Member States to the European Union budget for the year 2015 by EUR 9.4 billion - for France EUR 1.45 billion - I cannot hide my objection to the rapporteur's exhortation to use these additional funds available for an "unprecedented reception of refugees in Europe's cities and regions". The crisis of recent months and the context of insecurity, which has notably uncovered the use by Islamist fundamentalists of inconsequentical migration flows to enter Europe and commit attacks force us to take stock of reality and stop funding this mass immigration, which represents a danger not only to our security. , but also an impossibility in terms of our economic and social capacity to welcome.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 There are still ambiguous passages in the report that I do not agree with, which is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No 8/2015 covers, interlessing, a revision of the forecasts relating to traditional own resources (customs duties) worth EUR 800 million; budgeting of the remaining balances of VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) own resources for the 2014 financial year amounting to EUR 5 723.9 million; or the budgeting of VAT and GNI own resources balances for 2015 for EUR 1 409.4 million. This results in a decrease of EUR 9.4 billion in the contribution of GNI-based Member States. Parliament attempted to link this dossier with the negotiation of the 2016 budget through a joint statement with the Council sending a clear political signal to devote some of this revenue to trust funds for Syria and Africa.  But the Council has refused. That is why, in this resolution which I have supported, Parliament deeply regrets that a firm commitment to the use of some of these resources to address the refugee crisis could not be reached and hopes that Member States will fulfil their previous commitments.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which examines draft amending budget No 8/2015, as it adjusts the forecasts of traditional own resources (customs) and includes in the budget the remaining amount of VAT and GNI balances for 2014 and 2015. The European Parliament stresses that additional financial resources are needed to overcome the current refugee crisis. Notes, furthermore, that the financial obligations of the Member States to the African Trust Fund, the Syrian Trust Fund and the United Nations agencies providing support to refugees, which were reaffirmed at the informal meeting of EU Heads of State and Government on Migration on 23 September 2015, have not yet been fulfilled. The European Parliament notes that further financial efforts will be needed to provide humanitarian assistance on transit routes and to manage the problems that arise in accepting an unprecedented number of refugees in European cities and regions.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft araking of budget No 8/2015 provides for a revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (duties): the remaining amounts of value added tax (VAT) and GNI balances for 2014 and the 2015 VAT and GNI balances are entered in the budget. Draft araking budget 8/2015 also updates the forecast for other revenue and foresees a reduction of EUR 123 474 in the EDPS's budget for both commitments and payments. As a result of the draft amendment, member states' GNI-based contributions will be reduced by EUR 9.4 billion. The adoption of draft araks for budget 8/2015 forms part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016. This was accepted by the Hungarian People's Party delegation in the European Parliament, so I supported the report in line with hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the draft amending budget. The amendments relate mainly to a reduction in Member States' GNI-based contributions, which will reduce as much as EUR 9.4bn. While these funds could be used to deal with the current migrant crisis, Member States within the Council have preferred to repay to national budgets. In this light, I find it even more extraordinary that countries do not pay sufficiently in trust funds for Africa and Syria, in breach of commitments already made. And this is despite the remaining funding for the national budgets that are promising them by adopting this amending budget. Further financial efforts will therefore be needed to address the migrant crisis in order to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes. This assistance is urgently needed by the countries most exposed, including Slovenia.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report, which refers to the revision of traditional own resources forecasts. The report encourages Member States to use the extra money to tackle the current refugee crisis.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The Commission has revised its own resource forecasts. Revenues from customs duties were 800 million euros higher. In addition, the remaining 2014 VAT and GNI balances and the 2015 balance amount to EUR 7.1 billion, while unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines, amount to eur 1.47 billion. This additional revenue reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 budget of the European Union by 9.4 billion euros, or 1.45 billion euros for France.  Nevertheless, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of the reduction in their contribution to the common budget to increase funding for infrastructure to accommodate illegal migrants. The current migration crisis facing Europe is desired by the Commission to put downward pressure on wages in order to promote the competitiveness of large multinationals.  Although this draft amending budget frees up additional budgetary room for France, I abstained on this text which encourages states to increase funds to accommodate illegal migrants.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Draft Amending Budget (PBR) No. 8/2015: Own resources - European Data Protection Supervisor. This report provides for a correction of the EU budget, namely a revision of the forecasts on traditional resources, the inclusion in the budget of the outstanding VAT and VAT balances for 2014 and the inclusion in the budget of the VAT and VAT balances for 2015. In addition, as a result of draft amending budget No 1/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 2002 amending Regulation (EC) No 8 there will be a reduction of EUR 123 474 in commitment and payment appropriations to the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor, as well as a reduction in member States' contributions based on VAT of EUR 9,4 million. 8 will be EUR 9 403.4 million, which is a reduction in Member States' contributions to the EU budget.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Amending budget number 8 concerns the revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources (EU duties) and the balances relating to VAT and gross national income (GNI). In particular, a cut of EUR 123,000 to the EU Data Protection Supervisor and a eur 9.4 billion reduction in Member States' GNI-based contributions are expected. These are undoubtedly positive elements. In this text, however, the rapporteur (Spanish, S&D) indulges in political comments that cannot be shared and out of place. It regrets, in fact, that the Member States have not yet been able to reach an agreement to use these economic returns to finance trust funds for Africa, Syria and the UN refugee agencies that were also confirmed at the recent Valletta Summit. Let us be clear: our delegation supports some of the choices of financial commitment to direct aid to humanitarian crisis areas. This could help to limit illegal immigration flows. What we do not agree with is the tone of reprimand towards the Member States: if there is still no agreement on how to act, it is also because of the serious mistakes made by the EU institutions in the management of the whole immigration affair.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, own resources and the European Data Protection Supervisor.  In line with what the report says, I regret that it was not possible to reach a final compromise in conciliation on the use of the re-entry of draft amending budget No 8/2015 to deal with the refugee crisis.  Further financial efforts will therefore be needed to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes and to meet the challenges of welcoming more refugees into European cities and regions that have never been higher.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is an annual report which takes stock of the calculation and miscalculation of contributions by Member States to the EU Budget. In part, it calls on the Member States to use part of the allocation, in particular the one which comes from EU revenue, EUR 2.3 billion, to be used for the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and UN agencies supporting refugees and humanitarianism.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I understand that the draft amending budget from Member States’ contributions to the Union budget can alleviate the current refugee crisis and provide humanitarian assistance.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 8/2015 results in a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in Member States' contributions to the Union budget as a result of changes in both revenue and expenditure forecasts. I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report rightly notes that Member States' promises to finance the Trust Fund for Africa, Syria and the United Nations Agencies, as well as to support refugees, were reaffirmed at the informal meeting of Heads of State or Government. It is also noted that further financial needs and efforts will be required to provide humanitarian aid along transit routes and to address the challenges posed by the reception of the unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions. That is why we are treating the report positively.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the Council's position on the draft amending budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 approves a more rational distribution of burdens between Member States in the Union budget.  I voted in favour of this proposal on the basis that it is correct, since the revision of the forecasts in conjunction with the inclusion of new revenue in the budget and the reduction of appropriations are indications of more sound financial management.  At the same time, however, very important elements of the report are the indication that significant additional financial instruments are needed to deal with the current refugee crisis and criticism of the fact that no compromise has so far been reached in the context of the conciliation between the Council and the European Parliament to deal with the refugee crisis.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 presented by the Commission.  Parliament took note of the eur 9 403.4 million reduction in Member States' contributions to the Union budget, endorsed the Council's position and instructed the President of Parliament to carry out ordinary legal publicity and the transmission of the resolution to the Council, the Commission, the Court of Auditors and national parliaments.  Parliament stressed the need for additional financial resources for the current refugee crisis and noted that member states' financial commitments for trust funds for Africa and Syria and UN refugee assistance agencies had not yet been honoured.  The overall reduction in contributions amounting to EUR 9 403.4 million includes a reduction of EUR 123 474.00 in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor, a sum obtained from the saving of EUR 56 160 for transitional allowances and the reimbursement to the EDPS of EUR 67 314 following the amending budgets adopted by the Management Board of the Translation Centre.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft amending budget for the financial year 2015. I believe that this is a fair proposal and in line with the times of crisis we are going through, considering three main aspects: the draft amending budget provides an update of the forecasts for other revenue, provides for a reduction of EUR 123 474 in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor and also entails a reduction of EUR 123 474 in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor and also entails a reduction of EUR 123 474 in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor. , a decrease of EUR 9.4 billion in Member States' contributions. That is why I support the report.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Result of the adjustment of a set of indicators, this draft amending budget revises down contributions for the financial year 2015. In total, Member States will be reimbursed by around EUR 9.4 billion which will therefore be withdrawn from the Union budget. At a time when the Union is facing a refugee crisis which requires a strong mobilisation of funds, in particular by the Union, I find it regrettable that an agreement has not been reached in the negotiations with the Council. Instead of using these to meet the commitments made under the Migration Agenda outside the Community budget (such as trust funds for Syria and Africa or the UNITED NATIONS World Food Programme), Member States decided to receive the money and leave for a decision later.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving the amending budget for the financial year 2015, because it provides for the revision of certain technical measures concerning the reduction of Member States' contributions to the Union budget and the reduction of commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor. Measures are also noted in the draft amending budget on the application of customs duties and the updating of forecasts of other revenue.  Of primary importance are also the provisions and the financial allocation necessary to deal with the current refugee crisis: this document provides for the allocation of substantial additional financial resources to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes and to meet the challenges related to the reception of a large number of refugees in europe's cities and regions.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Additional financial means are necessary to address the current refugee crisis and further financial efforts will be needed to provide humanitarian assistance along the transit routes and to manage the challenges posed by the reception of unprecedented numbers of refugees in Europe’s cities and regions. This is now our main priority.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 8/2015 concerns a revision of the forecasts relating to traditional own resources (customs duties, + 0.8 billion euros), the accounting of the rest of the VAT and GNI balances for 2014 (+ 5.7 billion euros) and the accounting of VAT and GNI balances for 2015 (+1.4 billion euros); it is also planned to update the forecasts of other revenues (+1.5 billion euros) and a reduction of 123 474 euros in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor. Amending No 8/2015, in all its elements, therefore results in a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in Member States' contributions to the Union budget.  On the basis of this proposal, I am voting in favour, as it is estimated that the Member States will use these additional resources to devote them to the issue of immigration.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it recovers resources from the European Data Protection Supervisor by returning certain amounts not spent by that Supervisor during the previous financial year. This report stresses that all these surpluses should be geared towards aid and management of the refugee crisis, as well as humanitarian aid to Syria. This should be a priority line for the Union's resources during the 2015 financial year due to its size and the serious humanitarian situation faced by refugees. It is to make these resources available for these objectives of aid to migrants and I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns a revision of the forecast of EU income from customs duties (decrease of EUR 9.4 billion) and thus readjusts the projected funds made available to the EU to spend on particular items. The same report reacts to changes and underlines that substantial additional financial means are necessary to address the current refugee crisis.  It notes that Member States’ financial pledges for the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and UN agencies supporting refugees, reconfirmed at a number of recent council meetings, have not yet been met. Member States were lagging behind by EUR 2.3 billion on their commitments at the beginning of November 2015 – this when further financial efforts are needed to provide humanitarian assistance along the transit routes and to manage the challenges posed by the reception of unprecedented numbers of refugees. As I agree with providing as much assistance as possible to both the refugees and to those communities trying to help them, I have supported this report with my vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes a correction to the 2015 EU budget to increase the contribution of Member States, which has decreased by EUR 9.4 billion, thanks in part to unexpected revenues of EUR 2.3 billion from competition-related fines and higher than expected tariffs. According to the rapporteur, their financial commitments to the allocation funds for Africa and Syria still have a deficit of 2.3 billion. It calls on Member States to honour their promises on the draft amending budget 8/2015, to feed the two EU funds to help refugees and migrants in Syria, and to tackle the root causes of migration to Africa. Considering that it is necessary for Member States to implement the decisions they committed to earlier this year, I supported this report.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Draft araking budget 8/2015 provides for a revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (duties): the remaining amounts of value added tax (VAT) and GNI balances for 2014, as well as the 2015 VAT and GNI balances, are entered in the budget. Draft araking budget 8/2015 also updates the forecast for other revenue and foresees a reduction of EUR 123 474 in the EDPS's budget for both commitments and payments. As a result of the draft amendment, member states' GNI-based contributions will be reduced by EUR 9.4 billion. The adoption of draft araks for budget 8/2015 forms part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016. This was accepted by the Hungarian People's Party delegation in the European Parliament, so we supported the report in line with hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report called for the use of this year's eu budget surplus for the reception of migrants. While this year's revenues were 9.4 billion higher than expected, this money should have gone to the EU's contributing states. Indeed, the member countries finance the European Union to the tune of several billion euros each year. France should therefore recover part of its visibly overvalued contribution, recovering 1.45 billion euros. This report, instead of giving back to France what it belongs to, aims to encourage states to use this budget surplus to receive migrants in rural areas. That is not acceptable. If I support the reduction of the French contribution, I cannot bring myself to see it allocated to migrants. That's why I abstained.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ This concerns many annual adjustment exercises with the overall impact on revenue amounting to a decrease in the GNI—based contribution from Member States to the EU budget of EUR 9.4 billion. For the UK, this equals GBP 1.2 billion. The UK Government estimated that when the 2015 gross payment for the annual VAT and GNI adjustment is considered, the transfer from the EU to the UK amounts to approximately GBP 630 million. This technical exercise has nevertheless become politicised by Parliament. The rapporteur attempted to link this annual adjustment to the migrant crisis during the budget negotiations, pressuring Member States to use their decreased contributions to the EU budget to match the Commission’s EUR 2.3 billion expenditure on the Trust Funds for Africa and Syria. The UK Government is the leading contributor to humanitarian aid in the EU, if not to these specific Funds.  Despite Parliament’s attempted overreach, I can vote in favour of this report due to the decrease in Member States’ GNI—based contribution to the EU budget, and in the knowledge that Parliament’s attempt to link the annual adjustment to Trust Funds will have no legal effect.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have decided to support this Draft amending budget because it is a regular annual adjustment exercise. After an initial attempt to link this annual adjustment to the migrant and refugee crisis, the Council has been able to successfully refuse this as this would have clearly been without a legal basis, and nor have the Member States ever committed to match the Commission’s expenditure.  Nonetheless, with these changes, the procedure was de-politicised and in fact now represents a decrease in Member States’ GNI—based contributions, which I fully support.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Stresses that significant additional financial instruments are needed to address the current refugee crisis, such as funding the Trust Fund for Africa, and Syria.   We believe that it is wrong for the institutions to manage the refugee crisis, because the European citizen and his security are not prioritised.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States have made financial commitments of EUR 2 300 million for the Africa Trust Fund and the Trust Fund for Syria. These commitments are not being fulfilled. This amending project results in a reduction in national contributions of EUR 9 400 million in which EUR 2 300 million corresponds to fines and a surplus in relation to what was foreseen in customs duty revenues. These revenues are from the EU budget. Member States should deliver the surplus of EUR 2 300 million for the commitments they have made to trust funds, and the same amount is coincidental. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it aims to strengthen the provision of funds to migrants.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft budgetary correction No 8/2015 concerns the revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (customs duties), the budgeting of the missing balance sheets of THE VAT and GNI (Gross National Income) for 2014 and the VAT and GNI balance sheets for 2015. This results in a decrease of EUR 9.4 billion from Member States' contributions to the EU budget, based on their GNI. The amending budget project also intends to update the forecast from other sources of revenue. It also provides for a reduction of eur 123 474 in both the authorisation appropriations and payment appropriations of the European Data Protection Supervisor. We have argued that, if this type of money is made, the money should not be returned to the Member States - which mainly benefits the richest countries - but that it should remain in the EU budget, strengthening the (meager) cohesion funds. In this case, Parliament proposed that the funds be allocated to trust funds for Africa and Syria, as well as to refugee support agencies. The European Commission and the Council have not accepted this, which is regrettable in this report. All the more so, there is a delay of EUR 2.3 billion in transfers of funds for the management of the refugee crisis.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft EU amending budget for 2015, as it is now necessary to coordinate further financial efforts to provide humanitarian assistance and to meet the challenges of taking in an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 8/2015 contains the most up-to-date estimates of other revenue. The budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor is widely expected to be reduced by EUR 123 474, as there will be a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in GNI-based contributions from Member States.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. As far as this draft amending budget is concerned, I can only abstain: although there are understandable measures, such as the 9.4 billion reduction in Member States' GNI-based contributions, there are too many political considerations on the part of the rapporteur, which I believe to be wrong.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as I think it is wrong for the institutions to manage the refugee crisis since the European citizen and his security are not prioritised.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Substantial additional financial means are necessary to address the current refugee crisis. I therefore approved the Council position on Draft amending budget No 8/2015.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on Draft Amending Budget No 8/2015: Own Resources and the European Data Protection Supervisor, as I consider the work of the European Data Protection Supervisor to be an important activity for the benefit of citizens and myself argues for strong, practicable data protection at work in the form of the "chapter solution" (Article 82), including in the area of the General Data Protection Regulation.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. It needs sufficient financial resources to address the root causes of the current refugee crisis. At the same time, good integration of the refugees that have already arrived must be ensured. For a solution, it is also important to honour financial commitments for existing trust funds, such as Africa and Syria.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Draft amending budget No 8/2015, which underlines that substantial additional financial means are necessary to address the current refugee crisis. It is regrettable that despite the unprecedented refugee crisis we are currently witnessing, Member States’ financial pledges for the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and to UN agencies supporting refugees, reconfirmed at the informal meeting of EU Heads of State and Government on migration of 23 September 2015, at the European Council of 15 October 2015 and at the Valletta Summit of 11-12 November 2015 have not yet been met.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I lent my support to this report as it addresses the forecast of the EU income from customs duties which therefore highlights a readjustment of funds available to the EU to be used on other items. The report also shows how, unfortunately, Member States are behind in their financial promises for the Africa Trust Fund, Syria Trust Fund and certain UN agencies who support refugees in their migration to Europe.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The draft amending budget No. 8/2015 covers, among other things, forecasts for traditional own resources (tariffs) and the 2014 and 2015 balances of VAT and GNI (Perception of a percentage of each state's gross national income). Tariff revenues are 800 million euros higher, while the cumulative 2014 and 2015 balances of VAT and GNI are 7.1 billion euros. To this must be added 1.47 billion euros in competition-related fines. In total, this means 9.4 billion euros less for the Member States, of which 1.45 billion euros for France. However, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources for migrants, in particular to welcome "an unprecedented number of refugees in the cities and regions of Europe".  That is why I did not vote for this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I have cast a positive vote on the Gardiazabal report. It calls for outstanding issues that will be left out of the budget to be approved now, in particular refugee aid and a promised and unpured African trust fund.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Own resources and European Data Protection Supervisor because it was noted that further financial efforts will be needed to provide humanitarian assistance along the transit routes and to manage the challenges posed by the reception of unprecedented numbers of refugees in Europe’s cities and regions.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution as I am in complete agreement with the budgetary amendment. Prudent and sound financial management of the budget is vital. It is important to note that additional financial efforts will be necessary to address the current refugee crisis. Further financial assistance will also be needed to provide humanitarian assistance along the transit routes and to manage the challenges posed by the reception of the unprecedented numbers of refugees entering Europe’s cities and regions.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution notes that the impact of Draft amending budget No 8/2015 is a EUR 9 403,4 million reduction in Member States’ contribution to the Union budget. It is, however, highlighted that additional means are needed to address the refugee crisis, both along the transit routes and for their reception in Europe’s cities, and that the financial pledges for the agencies supporting refugees are still lagging behind by EUR 2,3 billion. Even though a firm compromise could not be reached to use the reflow to address the refugee crisis, I have voted in favour of the resolution since the position of the Council was approved and the Amending budget adopted. By the way, in my opinion the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Draft budget amendment No 8/2015 is about revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (duties). It provides for the entry into the budget of the remaining amounts of value added tax (VAT) and GNI balances for 2014, as well as vat and GNI balances for 2015. Draft araking budget 8/2015 also updates the forecast for other revenue and foresees a reduction of EUR 123 474 in the budget of the EDPS, both in terms of commitments and payments. The adoption of draft araks for budget 8/2015 forms part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016. This was accepted by the Hungarian People's Party delegation in the European Parliament. I therefore supported the report in line with hungarian interests and the position of the People's Party.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Council's position on draft budget amendments No 2012/2013. 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 - own resources and the European Data Protection Supervisor, as this revises the forecasts of traditional own resources, and enters in the budget the remnants of the own resources balance for 2014 and 2015. It is important to stress that this amendment reduces member states' contribution to the budget of the European Union. In my view, however, additional funding is needed to contribute to mitigating the effects of the refugee crisis, which poses a challenge to the Union budget. I therefore believe that the means of this amendment should have been clearly directed towards solving this problem.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text is a draft revision of the revision of the forecasts of traditional own resources, the budgeting of the remaining balances of VAT and GNI own resources in 2014 and the budgeting of the balance of vat and GNI own resources in 2015 as well as the updating of forecasts for other revenues.  The Commission has revised its own resource forecasts. As a result, customs duties were more than EUR 800 million, the remainder of the 2014 VAT and GNI balances and the 2015 balance of EUR 7.1 billion, and unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines of EUR 1.47 billion. In total, this reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 EU budget by 9.4 billion euros, for France by 1.45 billion euros.  The text calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis.  I abstained.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report on the draft amending budget No. 8/2015. This project reviews national contributions to the EU budget in light of changes in gross national product (GNP). Member States will thus benefit from a reduction in their contributions of EUR 9.4 billion compared to the previous ten years. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this report. It concerns draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015 establishing an EU trust fund for the crisis in Syria and Africa. Although there are some points in favour, I do not know how the systemic and structural problems of the region and their impact on Europe can be solved by means of additional payments.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it concerns mainly the revision of the forecast of own resources resulting in a decrease of Member States’ GNI-based contributions. Although agreeing to the reflow to the Member States, this report encourages Member States to use the extra money to address the current refugee crisis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft araking of budget No 8/2015 provides for a revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (duties): the remaining amounts of value added tax (VAT) and GNI balances for 2014 and the 2015 VAT and GNI balances are entered in the budget. This was accepted by the Hungarian People's Party delegation in the European Parliament, so I supported the report in line with hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The report is unacceptable because it seeks to curtailing the payments of rich central countries at the expense of peripheral countries. Member States that take away the markets of others and crippling their economies and create a quasi-colonial situation and represent the interests of their multinational companies to the end should not be allowed to receive new benefits. This is particularly true in the current precarious situation, when the migrant flood threatens to have unpredictable consequences.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's motion for a resolution on draft amending budget No 8/2015. DAB 8 leads to more efficient management of resources and consequently leads to a reduction in member states' transfers to the EU of more than EUR 9 000 million. At the same time, it distributes resources taking into account the financial needs useful to provide humanitarian assistance along migration transit routes and to meet the challenges related to the reception of migrants.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The Commission has revised its own resource forecasts. As a result, customs duties were higher by EUR 800 million, the remainder of the VAT and GNI balances in 2014 and the 2015 balance by EUR 7.1 billion, and unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines of EUR 1.47 billion. In total, this reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 EU budget by 9.4 billion euros, or, for France, 1.45 billion euros.  However, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis, and to put in place "additional financial efforts (...) to reach an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions." It is clear that this lesser contribution cannot satisfy such an objective. So I abstained.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it recovers resources from the European Data Protection Supervisor by returning certain amounts not spent by that Supervisor during the previous financial year. This report stresses that all these surpluses should be geared towards aid and management of the refugee crisis, as well as humanitarian aid to Syria. This should be a priority line for the Union's resources during the 2015 financial year due to its size and the serious humanitarian situation faced by refugees. It is to make these resources available for these objectives of aid to migrants and I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not support budget increases, the EU should look elsewhere for savings, for example in spending on its promotion or in many nonsensical subsidies.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Member States have reduced their contribution to the Union budget by €9 403.4 million, which together with the increased expenditure caused by the refugee crisis puts the European Union at a disadvantage. Also, Member States do not fulfil their financial obligations related to the Trust Funds for Africa and Syria and un agencies providing assistance to refugees.  According to the Commission's latest estimates, Member States should pay another €2.3 billion in aid. The draft budget amendment includes a revision of own resources, the introduction of the remainder of own resources resulting from VAT and GNI for 2014 and 2015, and forecasts of other own resources.  I supported mep Eider Gardiazabal Rubial's report because I believe that budget changes are necessary so that the European Union can better cope with emerging situations. While there is insufficient resources in the budget to refocus on tackling the refugee crisis, Member States are expected to fully deliver on their commitments.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Given the multidimensional and structural complexity of the European Union's governance system, regular reports on the implementation and planning of its budget are undeniably necessary, so that both the transparency of the system can be guaranteed and the annual objectives and targets set are more effective. In support of draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, I would also like to join in this parliamentary report that member states should realise this commitment as soon as possible with the commitment to overcome the refugee and migrant crisis, as well as the African and Syrian Trust Funds, UN agencies and other objectives. Problem solving can be different, but the most logical option would still be not to wait for them to start knocking at our door, but to try to encourage efforts to deal with them preventively. If this is not possible, however, because the problems are already actually here, we must not be passive and imagine that we will not be affected by all this – especially when there are completely specific obligations that must be fulfilled.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 1/2012. 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Own resources and European Data Protection Supervisor, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this project. We welcome the Commission's efforts to revise its forecasts on its own resources, revisions that reduce the contribution of Member States to the 2015 European budget by 9.4 billion euros (a decrease for France of 4.45 billion euros). On the other hand, we cannot accept that this report, at the same time, encourages Member States to 'take advantage' of this reduction in their contributions in order to free up more resources for migrants.  The Commission's use of this reduction in contribution prevents us from supporting this report.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The "draft amending budget no. 8/2015: own resources and European Data Protection Supervisor" sees me as in favour. This report concerns a revision of the customs duty forecasts, together with an accounting of the rest of the VAT and GNI balances for 2014, with the vat and GNI 2016 balances being entered in the accounts, providing an update to the forecasts of other revenue.  There is a reduction in commitment appropriations of EUR 123 474 and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor.  The effect is to achieve a reduction of EUR 9 403.4 million in Member States' contributions to the Union budget. It is also right to have substantial additional financial resources for the effective management of the refugee crisis, together with the forecasts for humanitarian assistance.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report but regret that no firm compromise could be reached in conciliation to use the reflow from Draft amending budget No 8/2015 to address the refugee crisis.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of draft amending budget No 8/2015. This draft, in fact, takes note of the necessary additional resources needed by the Member States to deal with the refugee crisis, thereby reducing the contributions due by them to the Union budget by as much as EUR 9 403.4 million.  Despite this need, the project does not fail to observe that the various financial commitments by Member States have not yet been honoured, for example those relating to the Trust Fund for Africa or the Trust Fund for Syria and the UN refugee assistance agencies.  On the other side, the project highlights the need for further financial efforts to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes and to meet the challenges of welcoming refugees.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In principle, I support the idea that aid is provided on the ground. However, the increase in financial resources without appropriate accompanying measures will not have the desired effect. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report, with its innocuous title and unrelated to its real political purpose, pushes the irresponsibility of the European parliamentary institution to the extreme. On the one hand, it approves an amending budget which reduces the contribution of The Member States by 9 billion. On the other hand, it warns that the same Member States are far behind their financial commitments to deal with the migrant crisis, particularly towards Africa, Syria and several UN agencies. At the beginning of November, 2.3 billion emergency appropriations announced at various exceptional summits of heads of state and ministers since the beginning of the year had still not been paid. While Parliament has the opportunity to vote against such an aberration proposed by the Council, this report endorses it, while "deploring" that such room for manoeuvre could not be used to deal with the migrant crisis. And finally, he "expects that states will honour their commitments." I am voting against such a demonstration of the futility of the votes of the European Parliament.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The project involves revising the forecasts of traditional own resources (tariffs), budgeting the remaining balances of VAT and GNI own resources in 2014 and budgeting the balance of VAT and GNI own resources in 2015 and updating forecasts for other revenues.  Indeed, the Commission has revised its own resource forecasts. As a result, customs duties were more than EUR 800 million, the remainder of the 2014 VAT and GNI balances and the 2015 balance of EUR 7.1 billion, and unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines of EUR 1.47 billion. In total, this reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 EU budget by 9.4 billion euros, for France by 1.45 billion euros.  However, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis. In particular, it invites them to use this financial windfall to manage the distribution of migrants in rural areas. As a result, I abstained on this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution approving the Council's position on draft amending budget No 8/2015.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Following the submission of the Commission and taking into account the Council’s position, I chose to support this report, which highlights the various measures agreed by the Commission, Council and Parliament to balance the additional funds required from Member States.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the report on the draft amending budget No. 8/2015. This update is necessary to address the current refugee crisis with additional financial resources. Tens of thousands of Syrians have been driven into exile because of the unrest and violence that have shaken their country for more than 18 months. It is clearly essential to reach additional financial efforts to provide humanitarian assistance to all these refugees in the long term.  I deeply regret that the vast majority of Member States have not yet made the financial commitments they have promised for the African Trust Fund, which currently stands at EUR 200,000 million out of EUR 1.8 billion, the Syrian Trust Fund and the UN agencies helping refugees. I reaffirm that refugees must benefit from the fundamental principle of non-refoulement, under which they must be able to flee very difficult humanitarian situations.  The lack of democracy, discrimination, inequality and resource limitation can only be overcome if we move towards consensus and cooperation.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft amending budget concerns the revision of estimates of own resources, revenue and balances for 2015 and proposes a reduction in Member States' contributions to the Union budget. The European Parliament notes that the financial promises have not yet been fulfilled by the states. Additional funding is currently needed to tackle the refugee crisis. I regret that a final decision has not been reached on the use of the outflow of funds from amending budget No 8/2015 to deal with the crisis. However, I believe that the commitments in question will be respected by the Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Draft Amending Budget No 8/2015 (DAB 8/2015), which relates to a revision of the forecast of Traditional Own Resources (customs duties), the budgeting of the leftovers from the 2014 VAT and GNI balances, the budgeting of the 2015 balances as well as an update on the forecast on other revenues like fines and a reduction in appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft budget amendment No 8/2015 submitted by the Commission on 19 October 2015 is about the revision of the traditional own resources forecast and updates the forecast for other revenue. The review notes that Member States' contribution to the EU budget is projected to decrease by EUR 9.4034 billion in 2015.  The Council adopted its position on the plan on 10 November 2015. In its report, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets recommends that Parliament take note of the Commission's draft and the Council's position in this area. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse the rapporteur's position on the need for considerable additional financial resources to deal with the current refugee crisis. I regret that the financial commitments made by Member States to the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and the UN agencies providing support to refugees have not yet been realised, causing a delay of EUR 2.3 billion at the beginning of November 2015, according to Commission data. It is essential that Member States honor the commitments made earlier.  I advocate additional financial reinforcement to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes and to manage the challenges posed by the reception of an unprecedented number of refugees in europe's cities and regions.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The draft amending budget 2015 8/2015 concerns the revision of the Commission's revenue forecasts for 2015. Indeed, the Commission has revised its own resource forecasts. As a result, customs duties were higher by EUR 800 million, the remainder of the VAT and GNI balances in 2014 and the 2015 balance by EUR 7.1 billion, and unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines of EUR 1.47 billion. In total, this reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 EU budget by 9.4 billion euros, or, for France, 1.45 billion euros.   However, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis, and to put in place "additional financial efforts (...) to reach an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions."  It is clear that this lesser contribution cannot satisfy such an objective, which is why it would be problematic to give a blank-seing to this report.  So I abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This report on the draft amending budget for 2015 indicates that the revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources and the reduction of commitment and payment appropriations on the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor lead to a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in Member States' contributions to the EU budget. It calls on the EU to make additional financial efforts to provide humanitarian aid along transit routes and to welcome an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions. For my part, I am very against this measure, because I consider it preferable to finance humanitarian aid to refugees in countries close to the places of conflict and to secure the Union's external borders as a priority. That is why I abstained in the vote on this text.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which will have the impact of a EUR 9 403,4 million reduction in Member States’ contributions to the Union budget.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ We supported this report as it calls on the Member States to use part of the allocation, in particular the one which comes from EU revenue, EUR 2.3 billion, to be used for the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and UN agencies supporting refugees and humanitarianism.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report calls for additional funding to deal with the refugee crisis. I abstained because a further increase in financial resources will not be able to cope with the refugee crisis until the funds are used incorrectly and in a targeted manner. However, the report also has good aspects, because it notes that the Member States are lagging behind in their payments.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The draft amending budget foresees an adjustment to the adjustment of the adjustment of customs duties, updates the forecast of other revenue and reduces the budget of the EDPS. Regrettably, no agreement was reached on the use of funds recovered from this draft amending budget in the refugee crisis.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions, there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The migration crisis that Europe has been facing for some time, as we all know, requires the use of substantial financial resources and unfortunately the efforts that we have all made, the Member States and the Union, so far do not seem to be enough. In this regard, while I regret the failure to reach an agreement on the re-use of the 2015 budget in support of the migrant emergency, and being confident that everyone's commitment to the issue will remain alive, I have decided to vote positively.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 From draft budget modification no. 8/2015 a reduction in Member States' GNI contributions of EUR 9.4 billion. This is due to a major economic crisis in the Member States.  I regret that commitment appropriations and payment appropriations have been reduced in the European Data Protection Supervisor's budget of EUR 123 474. The tasks and tasks carried out by the European Supervisor are important because they ensure compliance with strict privacy rules through the monitoring and processing of personal data by the EU administration to ensure compliance with privacy rules, advises EU institutions and bodies on all aspects of personal data processing and related policies and legislation, handles complaints and conducts investigations, cooperates with Member States' national authorities to ensure consistency in data protection, and monitors new technologies.  I hope that Member States will fulfil their commitments to the Trust Fund for Africa, the Trust Fund for Syria and the UN agencies providing assistance to refugees, as the refugee crisis is one of the biggest problems and challenges we must face and actively start addressing.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The draft amending budget 2015 8/2015 concerns the revision of the Commission's revenue forecasts for 2015. Indeed, the Commission has revised its own resource forecasts. As a result, customs duties were higher by EUR 800 million, the remainder of the VAT and GNI balances in 2014 and the 2015 balance by EUR 7.1 billion, and unanerved revenues, including competition-related fines of EUR 1.47 billion. In total, this reduces the contribution of Member States to the 2015 EU budget by 9.4 billion euros, or, for France, 1.45 billion euros.   However, the report calls on Member States to take advantage of this reduction in their contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis, and to put in place "additional financial efforts (...) to reach an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions."  It is clear that this lesser contribution cannot satisfy such an objective, which is why it would be problematic to give a blank-seing to this report.  So I abstained.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The refugee and migrant crisis needs to be well and timely addressed, worryingly the lack of agreed assistance to African and Syrian funds and UN agencies dealing with refugee assistance. I therefore support the Union's determination to provide additional funding on the refugee crisis, in particular for the provision of humanitarian aid on transit routes. In this way, we tackle two fundamental hot spots of the problem: the areas from which refugees come, and the routes they take. Since Croatia is one of the important transit countries, additional assistance will certainly allow the Croatian authorities to continue to treat the same quality, organized and with full consideration according to the difficult fates of these people.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I believe that in times of the current refugee crisis and attacks on our security, we need to truly take into account the basic tool of all the measures we plan to adopt to the budget. Changes to budget No. 8/2015 make it clear that work needs to be done to encourage states to fulfil their GNI contributions. Given the individual problems faced by Member States, I think that solving this problem will become more complex. As the challenges and problems of Member States located along transit routes go beyond their capabilities, solidarity between all Member States is now needed.  Consequently, I support draft amendment to budget No. 8/2015: Own resources and European Data Protection Supervisor Eider Gardiazabal Rubial.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 8/2015 concerns a revision of the forecasts for traditional own resources (customs duties), the accounting of the rest of the VAT and GNI balances for 2014 and the accounting of VAT and GNI balances for 2015. Draft amending budget No 8/2015 also provides for a reduction of EUR 123 474 in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor.  Although I voted in favour of the draft amending budget adopted on 19 October, I regret the fact that it was not possible to reach a final compromise, in conciliation, on the use of the remaining amounts of the draft amending budget to deal with the current refugee crisis.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Gardiazabal Rubial report on the draft amending budget 8/2015 on own resources and the European Data Protection Comptroller, relating to the revision of national contributions to the EU budget. Without any problems, this report received broad support.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour because I believe that there is a need to strengthen the means in view of the current refugee crisis.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to abstain because this report focuses on reducing the Member State contributions, but it also strongly deplores that the Member States are lagging behind in payments to help with the migrant and refugee crisis. Regardless of the reductions, there is an issue relating to paying out money for the Africa and Syria Trusts. In October, all cuts to the budget were voted against and as a result the budget increased to EUR 157.4 billion in commitments and EUR 143.5 billion in payments. The African Trust Fund amounts to EUR 1.8 billion and this money is allocated to examine the root causes that create irregular migrations and displaced persons. The Trust Fund for Syria is worth EUR 40 million, however already EUR 4 billion has been given to the refugee crisis. We are owed money from the EU due to the additional GBP 1.7 billion that was demanded from the UK Government by the EU, plus any savings that are made by the reduction in Member State contributions will end up back in the budget to promote the Security 7 Citizenship agenda and Global Europe; both of which we do not support.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The draft amending budget No 8/2015 covers, interlessing, a revision of the forecasts relating to traditional own resources (customs duties) worth EUR 800 million; budgeting of the remaining balances of VAT and Gross National Income (GNI) own resources for the 2014 financial year amounting to EUR 5 723.9 million; or the budgeting of VAT and GNI own resources balances for 2015 for EUR 1 409.4 million. This results in a decrease of EUR 9.4 billion in the contribution of GNI-based Member States. Parliament attempted to link this dossier with the negotiation of the 2016 budget through a joint statement with the Council sending a clear political signal to devote some of this revenue to trust funds for Syria and Africa.  But the Council has refused. That is why, in this resolution which I have supported, Parliament deeply regrets that a firm commitment to the use of some of these resources to address the refugee crisis could not be reached and hopes that Member States will fulfil their previous commitments.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is sounding the alarm by pointing out that significant additional financial resources still need to be made available to deal with the current refugee crisis. The adopted text also deplores the fact that Member States have not yet honoured the financial commitments made in favour of the Trust Fund for Africa, the Syrian Trust Fund and UN agencies helping refugees, which were reiterated at the informal meeting of heads of state and government on migration on 23 September 2015, the European Council on 15 October 2015 and the Valletta summit on 11-12 November 2015. Additional financial efforts are needed to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes and to reach an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions. I also deeply regret that no solid compromise has yet been reached on the use of reimbursements generated by the draft amending budget No. 8/2015 to deal with the refugee crisis.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to present draft amending budget No 8 to the 2015 general budget, which concerns a review of the traditional own resources forecast (customs duties), the budgeting of the missing VAT and GNI balance sheets for 2014, the 2015 VAT and GNI balance sheets and an update of the forecast for other revenues. The overall revenue impact is a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in member states' contributions to the European financial cake. There is also a reduction of EUR 123 474 for both the authorisation appropriations and the payment appropriations of the European Data Protection Supervisor. In the present case, where there is a need for budgetary adjustments, I agree with the rapporteur on the need for more financial means to deal with the current refugee crisis and the urgency of allocating the EUR 2.3 million in transfers of funds destined for this crisis and which are in arrears. To regret the lack of commitment in the conciliation. However, Member States are expected to be able to honour the commitments made.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which acknowledges the changes made to the 2015 budget and particularly in terms of member states' contributions. This text takes note of the fact that the 2015 amending budget foresees a reduction of more than EUR 120,000 of appropriations from the European Data Protection Supervisor's budget, but also a reduction of EUR 9,400 million in Member States' contribution to the EU's general budget in 2015.  At the same time, this report reminds us of the need for greater budgetary capacity to respond to the refugee crisis we are facing. I also support the call in this report for Member States to honour their financial commitments to the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and UN agencies helping refugees.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Council's position on draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, presented by the Committee on Budgets. This project provides for a reduction of EUR 123 474 in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor and entails a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in Member States' contributions to the European Union budget.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I have cast a positive vote on the Gardiazabal report. It calls for outstanding issues that will be left out of the budget to be approved now, in particular refugee aid and a promised and unpured African trust fund.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it recovers resources from the European Data Protection Supervisor by returning certain amounts not spent by that Supervisor during the previous financial year. This report stresses that all these surpluses should be geared towards aid and management of the refugee crisis, as well as humanitarian aid to Syria. This should be a priority line for the Union's resources during the 2015 financial year due to its size and the serious humanitarian situation faced by refugees. It is to make these resources available for these objectives of aid to migrants and I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because the money that is owed to the UK (1.2 bn) has to be returned anyway. This report calls for the money to go the refugee crisis, which I think should be up to nation states.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution because the amending budget concerns the revision of traditional own resources /customs/, the inclusion of the remaining VAT and gross national income balances for 2014 and the inclusion of VAT and GNI balances for 2015. The amending budget also contains the latest estimates of other revenue and also foresees a reduction of EUR 123 474 in the data protection supervisor's budget in respect of commitment appropriations. The approved draft amending budget also proposed a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in member states' contributions based on gross domestic product. The resolution concludes that Member States have not yet fulfilled their financial commitments for the African Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and the UN refugee support agencies, and therefore condemns the fact that, according to Commission data, the amount of member states' unfulfilled financial commitments amounted to EUR 2.3 billion at the beginning of November this year. Nevertheless, Member States are expected to fully comply with the commitments.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \ u2012 Draft amending budget No 8/2015 concerns the amendment of the forecast on traditional own resources and the inclusion in the budget of (remaining) VAT and GNI balances for 2014 and 2015. In addition, the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor provides for a reduction in commitments and payments of EUR 123 474. Revenues from customs duties, VAT and GNI and certain fines were much higher than expected, resulting in a decrease of as much as EUR 9.4 billion in GNI-based contributions from Member States. Despite the fact that this is an automatic technical adjustment, we can see that this recovery will make a positive contribution in the budgetary negotiations with the Council on the amount of much-needed financial commitments in the area of migration and humanitarian aid, which is why I voted in favour of the vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Own resources are long-term necessary for budget stability, so it is essential that the European Union establishes a system of own resources to ensure the stability of this budget.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report because draft budget modification No. 8/2015 refers to the revision of the traditional own resources (customs) forecasts and the introduction into the budget of the rest of the own resources balance resulting from VAT and GNI for 2014, and the balance of own resources resulting from VAT and GNI for 2015. This draft budget changes also update the forecasts of other own resources.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 Draft Budget Modification (NIP) No. 8 for 2015 refers to the following: - revision of traditional own resources (customs) forecasts - introduction into the budget of the rest of the VAT and GNI own resources balance for 2014 - the introduction into the budget of the VAT and GNI-based own resources balance for 2015.  - Update of forecasts for other revenues The selection procedure for the new European Data Protection Supervisor and its assistant was not completed when preparing the draft budget for 2015. Therefore, the decision was taken to act prudently and require appropriations in the amount necessary to finance the most expensive scenario, namely the replacement of both EDPS members. Finally, a former EDPS aide was appointed as the new EDPS, which is why part of the temporary allowances will not be used (EUR 56 160). Overall revenue impact is a €9.4 billion reduction in GNI contributions. I support this proposal because I think it is necessary to update the budget in accordance with the developments.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and welcome the reduction in member countries' contributions to the EU budget.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on the draft amending budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, own resources – European Data Protection Supervisor. In order to deal effectively with the refugee and migrant crisis that we have seen recently, we also need additional financial resources in addition to a single policy. Countries located on the so-called Balkan route, including Slovenia, are the busiest countries and need additional financial assistance. Nor have we yet provided all the funding for the Trust Fund for Africa and Syria, for which member states have committed in recent months.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Stresses that significant additional financial instruments are needed to address the current refugee crisis, such as funding the Trust Fund for Africa, and Syria.  We believe that it is wrong for the institutions to manage the refugee crisis, because the European citizen and his security are not prioritised.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft araking of budget No 8/2015 provides for a revision of the forecast for traditional own resources (duties): the remaining amounts of value added tax (VAT) and GNI balances for 2014 and the 2015 VAT and GNI balances are entered in the budget. Draft araking budget 8/2015 also updates the forecast for other revenue and foresees a reduction of EUR 123 474 in the EDPS's budget for both commitments and payments. As a result of the draft amendment, member states' GNI-based contributions will be reduced by EUR 9.4 billion. The adoption of draft araking budget 8/2015 forms part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating delegations of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I contributed to the resolution on the basis of this report, by which the EP approved the use of the surplus generated by the Commission's own revenue accounts (essentially VAT), resulting in a reduction in the member states' contribution on a GNI basis by around EUR 9.4 billion this year. I stress, however, that my vote does not generally mean full support for the surplus-back method or for this specific solution. The related reservations, which were also highlighted in the report, once again raise the need for greater flexibility and faster adaptation to practical challenges in the planning and use of EU budget appropriations.  In agreement with this report, I also regret that, due to the limitations of the budgetary ceilings and the resistance of the Member States, it was not possible again to realloduce the indicated resources to support the management of the current most urgent EU challenge, the refugee crisis, in the framework of security and external relations expenditure (Chapters 3 and 4). I regret this, in particular, in the light of the fact that the majority of Member States are still not, or are not contributing sufficiently, to replenishing new instruments outside the Community budget relating to the refugee crisis, such as funds set up to alleviate migratory pressures from Syria and Africa.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. With this text, we criticise Member States that have not yet honoured financial commitments to the Africa Trust Fund, the Syria Trust Fund and UN refugee agencies, which were reiterated at the informal meeting of heads of state and government on migration on 23 September 2015. 15 October 2015 and the Valletta Summit on 11-12 November 2015.  I regret that, according to the Commission, the Member States were behind by EUR 2.3 billion at the beginning of November 2015.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which amends the EU budget for the financial year 2015. This draft amending budget concerns a revision of the forecast of Traditional Own Resources (customs duties), the budgeting of the remainder of the 2014 VAT and GNI balances, and the budgeting of the 2015 VAT and GNI balances. Furthermore, it foresees a reduction of EUR 123 474 in both commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor and it results in a decrease in GNI-based contributions from Member States of EUR 9.4 billion. It should be noted, however, that additional resources will be needed to tackle the refugee crisis.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
