text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the draft budget amendment, which relates to the revision of traditional own resources forecasts and to the European Data Protection Supervisor, as this amendment will reduce Member States' contribution to the 2015 budget by a total of €9.4 billion.  However, I should note that this report inappropriately included a proposal to redirect some of these funds to address the current refugee crisis. In particular, I strongly oppose the rapporteur's position that this fulfils financial commitments to the Trust Fund for Africa, the Trust Fund for Syria and the UN agencies providing assistance to refugees, as I believe that Member States must independently decide how to fulfil their obligations.  However, as there is no legal basis for this request and the Council refused to accept that proposal, it remained only a recommendation which would not have a legal effect. That's why I supported the report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the Council position on draft amending budget No 8/2015 for the financial year 2015, own resources – I supported the European Data Protection Supervisor, as the European Parliament notes that member states' contributions to the Union budget have been reduced by EUR 9,403.4 million at the expense of the refugee crisis, and additional financial assistance will be needed to provide humanitarian aid along transit routes.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I have cast a positive vote on the Gardiazabal report. It calls for outstanding issues that will be left out of the budget to be approved now, in particular refugee aid and a promised and unpured African trust fund.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. EU revenues turn out to be higher than expected. The text therefore envisages reducing the contribution of the Member States, i.e. EUR 1.45 billion for France. But this report obviously calls on them to take advantage of the reduction in their planned contributions to free up more financial resources to deal with the migration crisis, and to put in place "additional financial efforts (...) to reach an unprecedented number of refugees in Europe's cities and regions."  It is clear that this lesser contribution cannot satisfy such an objective, which is why it would be problematic to give a blank-seing to this report.  So I choose abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Further financial efforts will be needed to provide humanitarian assistance along transit routes and to address the challenges of taking in an ever larger number of refugees in European cities and regions. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I have cast a positive vote on the Gardiazabal report. It calls for outstanding issues that will be left out of the budget to be approved now, in particular refugee aid and a promised and unpured African trust fund.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council position on Draft amending budget No 8/2015 of the European Union for the financial year 2015, Own resources and European Data Protection Supervisor because I agree that it is necessary to allocate the funding accordingly to the possibilities and priorities, while respecting the agreements on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management. The resolution also underlines that substantial additional financial means are necessary to address the current refugee crisis.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it recovers resources from the European Data Protection Supervisor by returning certain amounts not spent by that Supervisor during the previous financial year. This report stresses that all these surpluses should be geared towards aid and management of the refugee crisis, as well as humanitarian aid to Syria. This should be a priority line for the Union's resources during the 2015 financial year due to its size and the serious humanitarian situation faced by refugees. It is to make these resources available for these objectives of aid to migrants and I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this draft amending budget because it emphasises the need to allocate substantially more financial resources to resolve the refugee crisis. Unfortunately, this report rightly points to the fact that Member States have not yet fulfilled the contributions they have promised in relation to EU trust funds.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In principle, I support the idea that aid is provided on the ground. However, the increase in financial resources without appropriate accompanying measures will not have the desired effect. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. Measures to provide additional financial resources "to address the challenges posed by the reception of an unprecedented number of refugees in European cities and regions" cannot be in the spirit of a responsible policy for the peoples of Europe. A clear 'no' is required here until the question of repatriation has been resolved.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on 'Amending Budget No 8/2015 on Own Resources and the European Data Protection Supervisor'. It is a standard exercise, in particular to adapt the annual contributions of the Member States to events. In sum, the Member States will be relieved.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this report, which strengthens a key institution to tackle migration, the refugee crisis, but also to safeguard the interests of European citizens.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the amending budget No 8/2015 as the current circumstances need a quick and flexible reaction. The European institutions are committed, thanks to this correction, to strengthening commitment appropriations for immigration policy and humanitarian policy: this is good news. The current migration crisis requires a commitment from all Europeans and their institutions. I welcome the budget rectification agreement.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Draft amending budget No 8/2015 concerns a revision of the forecasts relating to traditional own resources (customs duties, + 0.8 billion euros), the accounting of the rest of the VAT and GNI balances for 2014 (+ 5.7 billion euros) and the accounting of VAT and GNI balances for 2015 (+1.4 billion euros); it is also planned to update the forecasts of other revenues (+1.5 billion euros) and a reduction of 123 474 euros in commitment and payment appropriations in the budget of the European Data Protection Supervisor. Amending No 8/2015, in all its elements, therefore results in a reduction of EUR 9.4 billion in Member States' contributions to the Union budget.  This is essentially a technical amending that I voted in favour of, also considering that it estimates that the Member States will use these additional resources to devote them to the issue of immigration, which is of fundamental importance at this time.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft budgetary correction No 8/2015 concerns the revision of the traditional own resources forecast (customs duties), the budgeting of the missing VAT and GNI balance sheets for 2014 and the 2015 VAT and GNI balance sheets, resulting in a decrease of EUR 9.4 billion from member states' contributions based on their GNI. You also want to update the forecast from other sources of revenue. In addition, this grinding project provides for a reduction of EUR 123 474. We abstained.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The migration crisis is affecting Europe, especially nations such as Italy, which, given its geographical location, are inevitably the point of access for most migrants. In order to deal with this crisis, exceptional measures are needed, which will also make it possible to exceed the budget envisaged. Article 11 of the Regulation establishing the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework provides for the possibility of using the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of exceptional expenditure; It was therefore decided to use this special instrument to allocate an amount of EUR 1.5 billion. Although I am opposed to the overall agreement on the EU budget, I felt that such a measure was necessary because we need an immediate response to deal with and manage the immigration emergency in Europe. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument which will allow the implementation of immediate budgetary measures in relation to the European Agenda on Migration. In this way, the budget may be amended to add the necessary items for European policies for the reception of migrants, which will enable housing or employment plans, asylum policies, with the speeding up of the resolution of asylum claims, and maritime rescue operations. We are faced with a joint competence shared by the Union and the Member States, so our favourable vote presupposes a will of the States which we have not been seeing in practice. We are confident that the expenditure we have approved will be spent on what is really intended and does not end, as we have seen so far, by spending on strengthening the Fortress Europe.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We supported this report as it was necessary to mobilise funding to finance measures to address the refugee crisis and migration, especially in the context of the humanitarian approach.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In response to the refugee crisis, the European Agenda on Migration provided not only for a number of operational and legislative emergency measures, but also for budgetary measures to implement these proposals immediately. In order to deal with this exceptional situation, the flexibility instrument will be used to increase the budget in 2016 by a total of EUR 1 530 million beyond the ceilings of headings 3 and 4. Given the need to address the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis, I welcome this budgetary step.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Not surprisingly, the irresponsible statements of the Commission and several prominent members of the European Parliament immediately led to a dramatic increase in the number of refugees, most of them economic immigrants. This is certainly not new, but the current crisis has led to a belated awareness among the European population and some of their leaders of the urgency of re-establishing border control. Overwhelmed by the migration crisis they have largely caused, unable to stem the flow of foreigners to Western countries, the European Union authorities, in order not to lose face and give the illusion that they are acting, thought it useful to increase European funds for immigration in the draft budget for 2016. They agreed to mobilise an additional EUR 1.53 billion over the next four years, of which 710 million will be allocated directly to the 2016 budget. The failure of the Schengen area and the dangers of mass immigration require the elimination of europe's paltry funding in relation to the migration problem and to give states full control of all their borders.  So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s approach to the refugee crisis is fundamentally wrong, and therefore I cannot support more taxpayers’ money being spent on it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise a flexibility instrument to deal with the refugee crisis. I support the mobilisation of EUR 1 530 million. The amount of the commitment appropriations of EUR 100 million shall be eur

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report recommends the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to deal with the migration crisis... EUR 1.53 billion. Knowing how the Eurocrats want to "face" this crisis, that is to say by encouraging it, I voted against this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this report, which endorses the mobilization of the budgetary flexibility instrument for 2016 in order to provide additional funds for the management of the problem of migration and refugees, the magnitude of which requires a significant increase in financial resources. This is in fact the carry-over to fiscal 2016 of the amounts not used on the 2014 and 2015 budgets.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I could only object to this report, which is in line with the compromise on the 2016 budget and aims to finance the management of uncontrolled flows of migrants into Europe. This report concerns the flexibility instrument and the conciliation committee has decided on a EUR 1.53 billion credit for the migrant crisis above the ceilings of headings 3 and 4 of the draft budget. This is an aberration when we know that, for several years now, Brussels has been urging the peoples of Europe to be suicidal in austerity and that on the other hand, they are ready to finance, not to mention uncontrolled immigration, which nevertheless represents a real danger in terms of security and a structural impossibility in terms of reception. Once again, through the budget, the reality emerges that the European Union prefers the other to itself.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the flexibility instrument to deal with the refugee crisis because this appropriation results, albeit in part, in sharing the financial commitment to managing the phenomenon among all Member States.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. With this decision, Parliament warns that the 2016 deadlines for headings 3 and 4 of the budget do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures in the field of migration and refugees, and agrees with the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations and with the proposal for the allocation of corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 734.2 million 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, EUR 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019.  It also warns that the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument once again demonstrates the imperative need for a more flexible Union budget. For all this, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilising the Flexibility Instrument for emergency budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis. Hundreds of thousands of refugees are flooding into the European Union, and it is therefore necessary to reallocate finances and provide funds to deal with migration and refugees. In urgent circumstances, the Commission has proposed to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument and to supplement the financing from the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 by EUR 1 504 million. The amount of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 100 million in order to finance measures under the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 After considering all options for realloding commitment appropriations within Chapters 3 and 4 in the EU budget for 2016, it became necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument in favour of commitment appropriations. Therefore, the European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument in order to complement the resources in the European Union's general budget for 2016 with commitment appropriations of EUR 1 506 million in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 3 to finance measures taken under the European Agenda on Migration. On the basis of the above, the European Parliament has adopted the use of the Flexibility Instrument in the form of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 1 530 million. As the use of the Flexibility Instrument is part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating bodies of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016, I supported the report in line with Hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed resolution. Tackling the migrant crisis within the EU is a huge resource that countries cannot provide on their own. A common approach to managing and solving this problem is therefore necessary. In order to provide funds for migration and refugees within the EU budget, it is therefore necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument. In the specific case, this means that the use of that instrument under the EU budget will reallocate EUR 1.5 billion to finance activities in this area for the next 4 years. This will be eur 734.2 million in 2016, EUR 654.2 million in L. 2017, EUR 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019. The fact is, therefore, that a large amount of funding, both from the EU and the Member States, will go to cope with the migrant crisis in the coming years, so it is crucial that solutions to limit the migrant waves be found as soon as possible. Moreover, the pressures on public finances, particularly in the areas of social, education and healthcare, will only be more intense in the coming years, which will mean less funding for other areas, such as stimulating economic growth. Action to limit the number of fugitives is therefore necessary.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on mobilising the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures to tackle the refugee crisis marks a decisive step in the implementation of a manoeuvre that touches on a sensitive issue for the European Union. It is a very positive sign that the document provides for appropriations, totalling EUR 1 530 million until 2019, to ensure greater flexibility in the EU budget; a concrete decision, which recognises the need to mobilise urgent resources to deal with a situation that seriously challenges the whole EU.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support the Flexibility Instrument Mobilisation Report for urgent budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis. The proposal is related to the 2016 Budget and it was agreed to mobilise funds for measures to tackle the refugee crisis. This is the first use of this instrument to this extent, which speaks volumes about the seriousness of the current refugee crisis.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The Commission had already proposed in its initial budget to mobilise the flexibility instrument to the tune of 123.9 million to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis. It was already a lot. Instead of taking the necessary measures in the face of this migratory pressure, i.e. the re-establishment of controls at Europe's borders, and the end of Schengen, with the return of these migrants to their territories of origin, the Commission decides to revise its position by proposing in its amending letter 2/2016 a considerable increase in appropriations of EUR 1.5 billion. As for the conciliation committee, it has added more to reach the huge sum of 1.53 billion, the bulk of which would be for the years 2016/2017. So I'm voting against that funding.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Agenda on Migration is an area of Union action of particular topicality and importance, given the scale of the historical, social and political events that the Euro-Mediterranean area is experiencing. That is why we believe it is a priority to allow the Member States of the Union to mobilise resources, even extraordinary resources, to deal with the emergency in the best possible way and with all the promptness and speed of intervention that the events that are constantly developing in recent weeks are suggesting to us.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. In its initial draft budget, the European Commission provided for the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to the tune of EUR 123.9 million to finance measures to welcome illegal migrants. However, given the scale of the problem, the Commission decided to revise its position by proposing in its amending letter an increase in appropriations of EUR 1.5 billion. The conciliation committee, meanwhile, agreed on an amount of 1.53 billion euros allocated to the migrant crisis. It is quite scandalous that the European Commission is squandering taxpayers' money at a time when Member States are facing a structural economic crisis characterized by mass unemployment, rising social inequalities and an unprecedented increase in the poverty rate. The current macroeconomic conditions do not allow for the taking in of these illegal migrants whose arrival is strongly encouraged by the European institutions in order to meet the cheap labour needs of large multinationals. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in the context of the immediate budgetary measures set out in the European Agenda on Migration in the light of the recent financial challenges of the migrant and refugee crisis. In this context, there is a urgent need for massive involvement by the relevant European authorities to ensure a continuous and unimpeded process. Therefore, mobilising the flexibility instrument to complement funding to the EU general budget for the 2016 financial year is a solution to existing financial problems. Unused annual amounts available for flexibility instruments in the 2014 and 2015 financial years should be used for this mobilisation. The amounts foreseen for redistribution are EUR 734.2 million in 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, EUR 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote relates to the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to finance measures related to the "refugee crisis". Payments of €734.2 million were allocated in 2016, €654.2 million in 2017, €83 million in 2018 and €58.6 million in 2019. This measure was necessary due to the exhaustion of the budget lines for these items for the 2016 financial year. Our delegation strongly opposes most of the Union's planned measures in the field of immigration. Sometimes, however, the option chosen is a vote in favour of EU budget appropriations so that, at least the financial commitment, is shared by all EU Member States. Apart from the firm opposition to certain attitudes of the European institutions, the political position with which I am voting in favour today is to point out the need for more resources and greater concrete commitment on the part of the European Union, without too much burden on the Member States (including Italy) that are most easily faced with the migration emergency.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilising the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline , budgetary cooperation and sound financial management. As indicated in the report, the mobilisation of this instrument indicates the absolute need to ensure greater flexibility for the Union budget in order to finance the urgent measures that must be put in place to respond to the growing flow of migrants to Europe and the refugee crisis. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which mobilises EUR 1 504m through the flexibility instrument to finance measures in the field of migration. The current situation in Europe with regard to newly arriving refugees and migrants made this vote necessary within EU rules for raising the ceilings available for expenditure in this field.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I approve to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 11 of the Regulation establishing the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework provides for the possibility of using the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of exceptional expenditure that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings. This is the case with regard to the issue of immigration, since the measures envisaged by the EU Commission exceeded the limits for the year 2016 provided for in heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and, to a small extent, also in heading 4 (Global Europe).  It was therefore decided to use this special instrument to the amount of EUR 1.5 billion. Payment appropriations will amount to €734 million in 2016, €654 million in 2017, €83 million in 2018 and €58 million in 2019. While I am opposed to the overall agreement on the EU budget, I believe that this measure is necessary for an immediate European response to the management of the immigration emergency, which now affects different European fronts.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The various crises that the European Union has been facing for years, from economic to migration, have often led to the use of the flexibility instrument of the European budget. This is also what happened to finance and implement in 2016 the actions included in the European Agenda on Immigration that required an increase in resources of 1,530 million euros, made possible thanks to the amounts not used in the budget years 2014 and 2015. Having already allocated all the budget remains available to deal with the refugee crisis in Europe, it means that no additional amount can be returned to the 2017 financial year so that in the event of emergency situations budgetary flexibility can be pushed to a ceiling of EUR 471 million per year. It is quite clear that the political debate on budgetary flexibility needs to be reopened, because in times of difficulty and uncertainty, political and economic developments may require frequent adjustments and the Union must be able to intervene, to strengthen its policies and, if necessary, to activate extraordinary measures. I voted in favour of this report in the hope that we will start thinking about this issue.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report refers to the adoption of the Commission's proposal to mobilise the flexibility mechanism to supplement funding in the EU's general budget for 2016 , in addition to the ceiling in section 3, with an amount of EUR 1.504 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures under the European Agenda on Migration. We agree with the above proposal.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the "proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility mechanism for immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis" will allow more funds to be released to better deal with the refugee issue, which is why I voted in favour.  The European Parliament's resolution highlights the need to give more flexibility to the Union budget in order to deal with exceptional crises, and in this direction all our future efforts must be made. Taking measures to alleviate the migration and refugee crisis must be a priority for all of us.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The report deals with the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis.  Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013 of 2 December 2013 establishing the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020 authorises the use of the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of clearly identified expenditure that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework.  Having examined all the possibilities for realognating appropriations, the Commission proposes to mobilise the flexibility instrument, for which the ceiling of the available annual amount is EUR 471 million, amounting to EUR 1 504.0 million above the ceiling of heading 3 of the multiannual financial framework in order to finance support for measures to manage the refugee crisis.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because, as agreed by the Council, we need to deal with the migration emergency and for this we need resources.  The proposal would explain the need to mobilise the flexibility instrument for commitment appropriations for the financial year 2016, going even further than the ceiling of heading 3, in order to be able to better address the case of migration to Europe. I believe that the problem of immigrants today is the main problem facing the EU, and that is why I believe it is right to release substantial funding to improve and better manage the current situation. Europe must show an important sign of unity and strength in this situation, and this proposal seems to me to be more than appropriate.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 As I advocated from the outset, the European response to the refugee crisis had - essentially - two levels of approach: one, immediate, to cope with the humanitarian emergency, and the other to look at the root problems. In this context, a number of immediate measures were adopted, such as strengthening the operational and human resources of the Frontex and EASO agencies and the temporary relocation mechanism. On parliament's proposal, the financial support provided to Member States will be the same for all relocated refugees.  As the report points out, the difficulty in providing funds to respond to this crisis, as well as the mortgage of funds for the coming years if we are faced with another unexpected event, highlights the lack of budget flexibility and the need for a larger Community budget.  We should be commendable for the measures adopted and the improvements made by Parliament, but here too we see how the Union does not yet have all the tools necessary to meet the challenges posed by this crisis.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision approving the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to finance migration and refugee measures. This is a very serious problem which shows no sign of diminishing. Indeed, the escalation of conflict in the Middle East and Africa, which we have been witnessing in recent weeks, is increasing the phenomenon of refugees even more. In view of the exhaustion of the amounts planned for the financial years 2014 and 2015, it was necessary to provide for additional amounts to ensure resources in the period 2016-2018. This operation once again shows the need to ensure greater and more appropriate flexibility for the EU budget.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament decided to vote in plenary without amendment and debate regarding the reports amending budget on own resources and European Data Protection, Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for payment of advances in the 2016 budget. Parliament has reached a compromise on these reports at committee stage. The migration crisis is a challenge which needs to be faced through adequate resources, and thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework provides for the possibility of using the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of exceptional expenditure that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings. We are referring to immigration issues and, to a small extent, to the heading of global Europe.  It was therefore decided to use this special instrument to the amount of EUR 1.5 billion. Payment appropriations will amount to €734 million in 2016, €654 million in 2017, €83 million in 2018 and €58 million in 2019. The call for the mobilisation of this instrument is an integral part of the agreement on the European Union budget for 2016, although it is voted separately. My vote on this report is positive.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument which will allow the implementation of immediate budgetary measures in relation to the European Agenda on Migration. In this way, the budget may be amended to add the necessary items for European policies for the reception of migrants, which will enable housing or employment plans, asylum policies, with the speeding up of the resolution of asylum claims, and maritime rescue operations. We are faced with a joint competence shared by the Union and the Member States, so our favourable vote presupposes a will of the States which we have not been seeing in practice. We are confident that the expenditure we have approved will be spent on what is really intended and does not end, as we have seen so far, by spending on strengthening the Fortress Europe.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The immigration crisis has long ceased to be an internal problem for individual Member States only and affects the European Union as a whole. Managing the migration and refugee crisis requires considerable financial resources that no one was able to foresee when the 2014-2020 financial framework was set. The ceilings for Heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Global Europe) of the budget for 2016 will certainly not allow adequate funding for urgent crisis needs. It has been calculated that, following the relocation of appropriations under these ceilings, the eu general budget for the financial year 2016 needs to complement the financial resources beyond the expenditure ceilings by EUR 1 506 million under Heading 3 and EUR 24 million respectively under Heading 4. Parliament's decision will allow for a regulation of annual amounts not used in previous years under the Flexibility Instrument. Considering this initiative to be justified, I voted in favour of the decision.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the current migration situation needs also a budgetary response.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to mobilise as much as possible the instrument of budgetary flexibility, in order to allocate more funds to migration management efforts. Parliament reaffirms that the mobilisation of this instrument, planned in the multi-year financial framework (2014-2020), proves how imperative it is that the Union's budget be more flexible, in view of the rapid evolution of the European agenda. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – After considering all options for realloding commitment appropriations within Chapters 3 and 4 in the EU budget for 2016, it became necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument in favour of commitment appropriations. Therefore, the European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument in order to complement the resources in the European Union's general budget for 2016 with commitment appropriations of EUR 1 506 million in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 3 to finance measures taken under the European Agenda on Migration. In addition to the eur 1 506 million ceiling for chapter 3, the Conciliation Committee convened for the 2016 budget also adopted the proposal of the Parliamentary delegation to use an additional EUR 24 million under the Flexibility Instrument, in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 4, to address the external dimensions of the challenges posed by the refugee crisis. On the basis of the above, the European Parliament has adopted the use of the Flexibility Instrument in the form of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 1 530 million. As the use of the Flexibility Instrument is part of the package of agreements developed by the negotiating bodies of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016, we supported the report in line with Hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report concerns the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to deal with the migration crisis. Like the compromise on the budget which wanted to allocate the surplus funds of the European Union to the reception of migrants, this report encourages the use of funds for the same cause. In wishing to allocate more than EUR 123 million to the reception of migrants, the Union is not reasonable. In doing so, it also exceeds the ceilings allowed for "citizenship and security" that it had set itself. I will always strongly oppose the use of the European Union's budget, which is already too important for the usefulness of this institution. I voted against this report.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument allows for the financing of expenditure which could not otherwise be financed within the limits of the ceilings under the multiannual financial framework (MFF). The amount under consideration in this proposal is EUR 1.5 billion, and I have some concerns about this mobilisation. There is still room for redeployments within the budget to tackle the migrant crisis. However, the true scale of these redeployments may only be realised when Commissioner Georgieva’s performance-based budgeting is fully underway. This exercise is expected to provide an evidence-base for deprioritising from wasteful and unnecessary budget lines.   The proposal mobilises the Flexibility Instrument for the maximum possible amount (the annual ceiling is set at EUR 471 million in 2011 prices and any unused portion of this amount can be carried over for three years). This could hamper the ability to respond to unforeseen circumstances in later years, and could call into question the suitability of current MFF ceilings in next year’s mid-term review. Nevertheless, use of the Flexibility Instrument is something the UK has argued for before. Moreover, the extraordinary scale of the migrant crisis is a textbook case of an ‘unforeseen circumstance’ for which the instrument was intended.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the idea that more funds are needed to tackle the migrant crisis, but nevertheless I abstained in the report "Mobilising the Flexibility Instrument for Immediate Budgetary Measures under the European Agenda on Migration". I have taken such a position, as I am concerned by the fact that the mobilisation of these funds exceeds the agreed budgetary ceilings and spends all the money allocated to dealing with the so-called cases of 'unforeseen circumstances'. Exceeding budgetary ceilings may call into question the sustainability of the Union budget, and the spending of all available resources provided for in the Flexibility Instrument will hamper the Union's ability to respond to other 'unforeseen circumstances' in the coming years. Instead of setting aside more funds and tightening the budget, the Commission should review budget lines with poor implementation levels and make savings to finance measures to tackle the migrant crisis.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Unused annual amounts available under the flexibility instruments for the financial years 2014 and 2015 should be used to address the refugee crisis. Amounts corresponding to EUR 1.5 billion At a time when there are Member States of the Union which are plagued by the crisis, they are the first countries to be classified as countries of collection of migrants and must, in accordance with EU rules, take care of them throughout their stay there. Countries, such as Greece, which are unable to take care of their own citizens.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 After considering all options for realloding commitment appropriations within Chapters 3 and 4 in the EU budget for 2016, it became necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument in favour of commitment appropriations. Therefore, the European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument in order to complement the resources in the European Union's general budget for 2016 with commitment appropriations of EUR 1 506 million in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 3 to finance measures taken under the European Agenda on Migration. In addition to the eur 1 506 million ceiling for chapter 3, the Conciliation Committee convened for the 2016 budget also adopted the proposal of the Parliamentary delegation to use an additional EUR 24 million under the Flexibility Instrument, in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 4, to address the external dimensions of the challenges posed by the refugee crisis. On the basis of the above, the European Parliament has adopted the use of the Flexibility Instrument in the form of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 1 530 million. As the use of the Flexibility Instrument is part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating bodies of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016, we supported the report in line with Hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to address the serious refugee problem, negotiations between the EP and the Council resulted in an agreement for the 2016 budget which goes beyond the margins available under heading 3 and, to this end, it was necessary to mobilise the entire Flexibility Instrument, amounting to EUR 1530 million. In this way, we strengthen the agencies linked to migration and refugees, the funds and programmes that support the mechanisms for responding to and welcoming refugees arriving in Europe, as well as the funds and programmes to act on the cause of the problem and combat its causes. For these objectives, we have gone from EUR 2 billion to EUR 4 billion in the 2016 budget. The European Union has therefore guaranteed the conditions to be able to support the refugees it receives internally and, at the same time, to act at the origin of this problematic phenomenon – i.e. externally – by investing in prevention and strengthening humanitarian aid and development and cooperation instruments. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it provides too much money to migrants.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The flexibility instrument has the function of ensuring greater flexibility of the Multiannual Financial Framework in order to respond to unforeseen circumstances justifying the exceeding the ceilings of budgetary securities, with the maximum annual amount of this instrument being EUR 471 million (at 2011 prices). This proposal replaces that of the European Commission, which proposed mobilising EUR 123 966 698 for Title 3 ('Security and Citizenship') from the EU budget, in order to support measures to address the management of the refugee crisis.  It is then proposed to mobilise EUR 1504 million of this instrument to allow the limits of Title 3 to be exceeded in this same amount, using unused funds in previous years 2014 and 2015. Payments will be made by 2019 (€710 million in 2016, €652.9 million in 2017, €82.7 million in 2018 and €58.5 million in 2019). We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must find additional funding in its budget to address the migration crisis. The European Commission is proposing to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement the 1504 million in the General Budget of the European Union for 2016. This will lead to the complete exhaustion of the Flexibility Instrument for the financial year 2016 and also to the exhaustion of the unused amount from 2014 and 2015.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Our delegation strongly opposes most of the Union's immigration measures. In this case, however, we are voting in favour because we are asking all Member States for a concrete commitment to take action in the face of the immigration emergency.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Unused annual amounts available under the flexibility instruments for the financial years 2014 and 2015 should be used to address the refugee crisis. Amounts corresponding to EUR 1.5 billion Euro. at a time when there are Member States of the Union which are plagued by the crisis, yet they are the first countries to be designated as countries of collection of migrants and must, in accordance with EU rules, take care of them throughout their stay there. Countries, such as Greece, which are unable to take care of their own citizens. For the above reasons I am voting against this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument in the amount of EUR 1 530 million in commitment appropriations. Due to the pressing needs, a significant additional amount needs to be mobilized to finance mitigation measures in the face of the migrant and refugee crisis.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the allocation of immediate budgetary measures for the management of the migrant crisis. We are facing an unprecedented crisis and we need to use the instruments at our disposal, reiterating that solidarity must always go hand in hand with responsibility.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on mobilising the flexibility instrument in favour of immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis because I believe that the EU must show solidarity and unity in the face of epochal challenges, such as that of refugees. I believe that Europe is witnessing not a transitory phenomenon, but the consequence of the serious crises and wars that devastate different parts of the world, the global increase in poverty and inequality, the constant denial of the right to a dignified life and peace for a large part of the world's population.  The phenomenon of migration is the main challenge of our century, and I therefore believe that it is necessary to support the EU budget, through the Flexibility Instrument, those countries that are at the forefront of managing flows, so that they can implement policies to take care of and welcome asylum seekers. I also believe that this decision clearly shows the seriousness of the moment and that the issue of financial resources for emergencies in the coming years must be addressed as soon as possible and appropriately by the Member States.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I abstained today in the vote on the report on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for Emergency Fiscal Action under the European Agenda on Migration, as I support the concern – the EU's ability to act in this crisis situation. At the same time, I see the application of the accelerated procedure as a very bad tool without sufficient consultation of Parliament and its committees.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. I support the use of the flexibility instrument. We need sufficient financial support to meet the challenges of the ongoing refugee crisis. Right now, it is once again clear how important it is for the EU to have sufficient flexibility in its budget planning.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this mobilisation of funds, given that efficient management of the refugee crisis should be a priority for the EU. The mobilisation of this fund is also budget neutral over the period of the multiannual financial framework.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this budgetary procedure to utilise the Flexibility Instrument as a financial support in addressing the refugee crisis in Europe. In the current timeframe, where we witness daily large volumes of refugees arriving in Europe after an arduous journey escaping from conflict, I fully welcome this mobilisation of funding.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes report, which agrees to mobilize EUR 66.1 million in payment commitments in two years (52.9 million in 2016 and 13.2 million euros in 2017) to address the refugee and migrant crisis, taking advantage of the very limited Budget Flexibility Instrument. It's a small number, but voting against it would be worse, by not mobilizing it.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which allows for the mobilisation of funds on the grounds that the refugee crisis facing Europe is critical and must be a priority for the EU. The mobilisation of this fund will be budget neutral over the term of the MFF period.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis because substantial additional financial means are necessary to address the current refugee crisis and the 2016 ceilings for heading 3 and heading 4 do not allow for an adequate financing of urgent measures in the field of migration and refugees.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a Decision of parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of a flexibility instrument for urgent budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis in accordance with point 12.  An interinstitutional agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and cooperation on budgetary issues and good financial management, as the situation arises, it is obvious that the flexibility of the Union budget is essential to address external and unpredictable challenges, such as the refugee crisis. In addition, in this way it is possible to promptly and effectively reduce the negative effects of such situations. However, the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument will mitigate the consequences of the crisis, although it is clear that the mobilised amount of EUR 1 530 million will not be sufficient with a visible need for synergy action by the international community.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The statements of the Commission and several prominent members of the European Parliament immediately led to a dramatic increase in the number of refugees, most of them economic immigrants. This is certainly not new, but the current crisis has led to a belated awareness among the European population and some of their leaders of the urgency of re-establishing border control. Overwhelmed by the migration crisis they have largely caused, unable to stem the flow of foreigners to Western countries, the European Union authorities, in order not to lose face and give the illusion that they are acting, thought it useful to increase European funds for immigration in the draft budget for 2016. They agreed to mobilise an additional EUR 1.53 billion over the next four years, of which 710 million will be allocated directly to the 2016 budget. The failure of the Schengen area and the dangers of mass immigration require the elimination of europe's paltry funding in relation to the migration problem and to give states full control of all their borders.  I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow colleagues and I voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague José Manuel Fernandes' report on mobilising the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European migration agenda. Thanks to this flexibility mechanism, the agencies EASO, Frontex and Europol will be allocated 30, 60 and 30 million euros respectively to cope with the exceptional influx of refugees on European soil. In addition, EUR 2,672 million from the 2016 budget will be spent on managing this crisis and EUR 150 million will be spent on strengthening the Union's humanitarian aid. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which mobilises the flexibility instrument to reallocate part of the budget to deal with the refugee crisis. It was indeed necessary to have more resources in place to best manage this exceptional situation.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report deals with the proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for Emergency Fiscal Action under the European Agenda on Migration. On the one hand, this is intended to provide funds from the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and, on the other hand, to call for more flexibility for the EU budget. Since I do not believe that the use of this instrument is justified, I do not agree with this report.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and decision. Activating the Flexibility Instrument to finance measures under the European Agenda for migration shows once again how important it is to ensure the flexibility of the European budget. Today’s reality cannot be any more clearly predicted, nor can one clearly distinguish between the areas of policy and action due to their interlinkedness and horizontal nature. The EP, EC and the Council should consider this when negotiating next multiannual financial framework and come up with innovative and flexible solutions. I am also pleased that in the general budget the EP managed to reverse most of the cuts proposed by the Council. Today we need to prioritise not only investments into EU economy and R&D but even more to citizens’ security. Facing the challenges of addressing numerous massive crises around the EU and the refugee flows, the proposed budget cuts lack touch with reality. As member of the WG on financial instruments, I especially stress flexibility to be able to allocate adequate resources to tackle the root causes of the refugees crisis. Only flexibility can make it possible to allocate necessary resources to assist people in their home countries

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument, as due to urgent needs, it is necessary to mobilise an additional amount to finance measures to alleviate the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument appeared together with the Commission's Letter of Amendment 2/2016 of 14 October 2015. This mobilisation concerns an amount of EUR 1.5 billion above the ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) under heading 3 and EUR 24 million in heading 4 and is intended to finance support measures for the management of the refugee crisis. In principle, I am in favour of approving funds to deal with the migration and refugee crisis and of using the flexibility instrument in exceptional circumstances. However, I believe that there are more opportunities for redeployment of funds in the 2016 budget. There are a number of budget lines with poor implementation and no demonstrable EU added value that could be cut to help address the migration and refugee crisis. This requires a comprehensive EU approach, as we presented at ALFA weeks ago. These include measures such as comprehensive control of the EU's external borders, the establishment of transit zones outside the Schengen area and the consistent repatriation of rejected asylum seekers. As this is still pending, I abstained.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 After considering all options for realloding commitment appropriations within Chapters 3 and 4 in the EU budget for 2016, it became necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument in favour of commitment appropriations. Therefore, the European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument in order to complement the resources in the European Union's general budget for 2016 with commitment appropriations of EUR 1 506 million in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 3 to finance measures taken under the European Agenda on Migration. In addition to the eur 1 506 million ceiling for chapter 3, the Conciliation Committee convened for the 2016 budget also adopted the proposal of the Parliamentary delegation to use an additional EUR 24 million under the Flexibility Instrument, in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 4, to address the external dimensions of the challenges posed by the refugee crisis. On the basis of the above, the European Parliament has adopted the use of the Flexibility Instrument in the form of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 1 530 million. As the use of the Flexibility Instrument is part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating bodies of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016, I supported the report in line with Hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration. The report allows the mobilisation of flexibility instrument for extra expenditures concerning Security and Citizenship (in the field of migration) from 2016 until 2019. I support this report, therefore I voted in favour, although I wish there was an even stronger budgetary support especially for the countries that are badly hit from the economic crisis due to the continuous austerity measures.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – I cannot say that the EU is mis-handling the so-called refugee crisis, because it is essentially not treating it at all. Superficial brainstorming and conflicting statements by prominent leaders of the Member States. Meanwhile, internationally recognized security experts are talking about a quasi-war situation. While I myself warned him of the dangers years ago. At the very least, this report is a step forward in providing some financial means to deal with the crisis and should therefore be supported.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Fernandes' report. The reason for my agreement lies in what this measure represents: Europe's awareness of the need for a further effort to manage the crisis and refugees. The measure concerns, in fact, an extraordinary mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, amounting to EUR 1 504 million, in support of measures to manage the refugee crisis. This is a concrete measure to help us deal with the emergency, which now takes on ordinary connotations.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed decision by Parliament and the Council on the mobilization of the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis amounting to EUR 1.530 billion in commitment appropriations, of which EUR 734.2 billion for the 2016 financial year. It is indeed imperative to strengthen the flexibility of the European Union budget to support the Member States facing the unprecedented migration crisis on our continent.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the mobilization of the flexibility instrument for immediate budget measures to deal with the refugee crisis. In its initial draft budget, the Commission proposed the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to the tune of EUR 123.9 million to finance measures to manage the migrant crisis above the ceiling of Heading 3 on Citizenship and Security. However, given the scale of the problem, the Commission has decided to revise its position by proposing an increase in appropriations of EUR 1.5 billion. As this report is the continuation of the compromise on the 2016 budget and proposes ever-increasing European funding for the management of the migration crisis, we can only oppose it.  We need to re-establish borders and put an end to mass immigration rather than constantly increasing budgets to accommodate migrants.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. The N-VA delegation believes that the Commission should have done more with the funds already available under heading 3 (Security and Citizenship). In this way, it could have shifted inefficient or unused resources before having to resort to the flexibility instrument. However, as addressing the asylum crisis is a priority for the N-VA delegation, it voted in favour of this Commission proposal in the European Parliament.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument which will allow the implementation of immediate budgetary measures in relation to the European Agenda on Migration. In this way, the budget may be amended to add the necessary items for European policies for the reception of migrants, which will enable housing or employment plans, asylum policies, with the speeding up of the resolution of asylum claims, and maritime rescue operations. We are faced with a joint competence shared by the Union and the Member States, so our favourable vote presupposes a will of the States which we have not been seeing in practice. We are confident that the expenditure we have approved will be spent on what is really intended and does not end, as we have seen so far, by spending on strengthening the Fortress Europe.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument appeared together with the Commission's Letter of Amendment 2/2016 of 14 October 2015. This mobilisation concerns an amount of EUR 1.5 billion above the ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) under heading 3 and EUR 24 million in heading 4 and is intended to finance support measures for the management of the refugee crisis. Increased funding is indispart to address the migration and refugee crisis. I am therefore in favour of using the flexibility instrument in these exceptional circumstances. It is important and right that the EU also makes an appropriately high financial contribution. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it because, in my opinion, it is about financing the EU's mistaken and harmful migration policy.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Due to the proportional increase in the refugee and migrant wave, a large sum should be urgently mobilised to finance measures to alleviate the crisis.  The total amount of the flexibility instrument for the 2016 financial year, which includes unused amounts from the 2014 and 2015 financial years, has been fully spent and emergency measures cannot be adequately financed due to the ceilings. I supported the proposal to mobilise the financial instrument by €1 530 million in commitment appropriations. I also agree to the allocation of appropriate payment appropriations over the next 4 years. The refugee and migrant wave affecting the Republic of Croatia requires increased funds unforeseen by the budget, so the need for budget flexibility, including the allocation of funds among members depending on the needs of the migrant crisis, has been highlighted.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 While the Member States of the European Union and its institutional predecessors have for decades been destinations that are desirable to migrants and refugees, the situation developed in recent years overshadowed almost all, even the most appalling, predictions. This led to the community budget adopted for the following year no longer adequate in relation to the challenges that the institutions it finances and the tasks it has to deal with on a daily basis. Thanks to the existence of a budgetary aid in the European Union, such as the flexibility instrument, it will be possible to remedy this budgetary deficit in a sufficiently effective way. On the other hand, I would like to join the report's call for an increase in the 'degree of flexibility' of the flexibility instrument, as it is now possible to carry over the funds to 2017 in order to consistently exceed the annual ceiling for the flexibility instrument. It would simply not be wishing that our Community would inadvertently become, at least partially unprepared for, potential challenges, the number of which, as one can imagine, on the basis of the precedents of the last few years, is temporarily unwilling to decline.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The financing of European Agenda on Migration measures in the context of the refugee crisis requires ensuring that funds are earmarked in advance for their funding. To mobilise the Flexibility Instrument, the proposed decision sets out the funds for 2016-2019 at almost €1.6 billion, of which €734.2 million for 2016. The management of these resources must be subject to strict control.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility mechanism for immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management , because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against this mobilization. This report is only an extension of the compromise on the 2016 budget, which we had already opposed. This budget provides substantial European funding for the management of the migration crisis and the reception of migrants, which we strongly oppose.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that Parliament made sure that all the resources available in the EU’s multiannual financial framework (MFF) will be tapped to deal with the ongoing refugee and migration crisis, which needs to be tackled both within the Member States and in countries close to the conflicts from which migrants are fleeing. The agreement includes EUR 1.6 billion on top of the Commission’s original proposal.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Favourable to the report on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in favour of budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis. The mobilisation is intended to finance the support of measures to manage the refugee crisis through a series of payment appropriations spread over various budget years, amounting to 1,504.0 million euros. In view of the urgent needs, a large additional amount must be mobilised to finance measures to alleviate the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft in commentary approves the extraordinary mobilisation of the flexibility instrument to the amount of EUR 1 530 million in commitment appropriations and approves the allocation of payment appropriations amounting to EUR 734.2 million in 2016, €654.2 million in 2017, €83 million in 2018 and €58.6 million in 2019. I believe that such an instrument should be used, and I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal, because of the absolute need to ensure greater flexibility for the Union's budget in relation to the social and economic crisis of refugees that the Union is preparing to tackle in the most decisive way.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. A further extension of the use of these funds without appropriate accompanying measures does not serve any purpose. The proposal to make the budget even more flexible would lead to a bottomless pit. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report notes that, in the 2016 budget, which the same rapporteur also proposes to approve in another report, the appropriation ceilings are "insufficient" to finance decisions on migration and refugees. While there is still time to amend the 2016 budget, this report calls for the use of the "flexibility instrument" under austere pressure from states. This is a legal artifice that allows us to exceed the budget voted in case of unforeseen hazards or emergencies. But using it before the budget has even been stopped is a pure diversion of procedure. And it is all the more aberrant that this instrument of overtaking will thus be "exhausted in its entirety" before the year has even begun. By the way, this illicit method will lead to new unpaid payments or delays in payment, as these budgetary commitments made over the budget are not covered by payment appropriations to meet them. With this kind of manoeuvre, the European Union is thus preparing not to pay for the emergency measures it has decided for migrants for several years. I am voting against this report, complicit in the cynicism of the European Union in this crisis.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. EU authorities are increasing EU funding for immigration in the draft 2016 budget. They have therefore agreed to mobilise an additional EUR 1.53 billion over the next four years, of which 710 million will be allocated directly to the 2016 budget. It should be noted, however, that through their irresponsible statements, the Commission and some influential members of Parliament have exacerbated the refugee crisis we are currently experiencing. Moreover, this financing plan is derisory given the scale of the problem, only sovereign states can effectively stop this migratory flow. The member therefore opposes this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council concerns the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures in order to address the refugee crisis that Europe is experiencing. In view of the urgent need to mobilise an additional amount to finance the expenditure of the measures to manage the refugee crisis, I voted in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which supports the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument, as it a positive step towards solidarity between Member States in tackling the refugee crisis. The resolution also highlights the need for the Union budget to be more flexible to adequately handle the various unforeseen challenges that arise.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Given the importance of migration flows, it is necessary to mobilise the flexibility instrument for commitment credits. This will supplement the financing of the EU's general budget for the 2016 financial year with a commitment of EUR 1.504 billion to finance measures under the EU's migration agenda. It was equally important to act on the external dimension of the refugee crisis, by mobilising the flexibility instrument for an additional EUR 24 million. These available credits come from deferring unused amounts from the flexibility instruments of previous years, in this case in the 2014 and 2015 financial years. As I usually say, it is imperative that the European Union's budget be flexible to adapt to the realities we face in a globalised world.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The deepening of the refugee crisis in recent years has had a significant impact on European society and individual Member States. Furthermore, tackling the crisis requires immediate budgetary measures at EU level, because many urgent measures in the area of migration and refugees, which are very difficult and often intolerable for The Member States, need to be taken and subsequently properly financed. For this reason, the Commission proposes to release commitment appropriations from the Flexibility Instrument. I must point out that if all the actors involved at EU and Member State level do not start to deal with the situation comprehensively from the ground up, we are in danger of the problem growing into dimensions that the EU itself will have difficulty financing.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis, which is extremely important.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The so-called Flexibility Instrument is used to finance clearly defined expenditure which would not be eligible for financing under the ceilings assigned to other chapters. The Commission noted that, due to urgent needs, significant additional appropriations should be used to finance measures to alleviate the migration and refugee crisis, and therefore proposed the adoption of a Decision of the Parliament and of the Council to supplement Chapter 3 of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 with a commitment appropriation of EUR 1 506 million and Chapter 4 with a commitment appropriation of EUR 24 million against the Flexibility Instrument. In its report, the Committee on Budgets considers the Commission's proposal to be justified and recommends its adoption to Parliament. I voted in favour of the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report concerns the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to deal with the migration crisis. It follows the compromise on the 2016 budget reached by Parliament and the Council.  Indeed, in its initial draft budget, the Commission proposed the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to the tune of EUR 123.9 million to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis above the ceiling of heading 3 (citizenship and security). However, given the scale of the problem, the Commission decided to revise its position by proposing in its amending letter an increase in appropriations of 1.5 billion euros (the conciliation committee agreed on an amount of 1.53 billion euros).  The allocation of payment credits would be as follows: 710 million euros in 2016; 652.9 million in 2017; 82.7 million in 2018; $58.5 million in 2019. This report is the continuation of the compromise on the 2016 budget which imposes substantial European funding to make states pay the cost of the migration crisis, which is organised by European elites against the will of the peoples.  So we can only oppose it.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1311/2013, in Article 11, provides for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument up to an annual ceiling of EUR 471 million (2011 figures) to allow the financing of specifically identified expenditure which could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings. Given the urgent need to deal with the migration and refugee crisis, it is essential to mobilise an additional amount to finance support measures.
