I support the Rapporteur's position on the mobilisation of this instrument on the crucial need for the Union budget to be more flexible. These additional appropriations are only possible thanks to the transition of unused amounts from the flexibility instruments for the 2014 and 2015 financial years. For the above in the report and the need to create immediate budgetary mechanisms to deal with the refugee crisis, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to deal with the migration crisis. It follows the compromise on the 2016 budget reached by Parliament and the Council. Indeed, in its initial draft budget, the Commission proposed the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to the tune of EUR 123.9 million to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis above the ceiling of heading 3 (citizenship and security). However, given the scale of the problem, the Commission decided to revise its position by proposing in its amending letter 2/2016 an increase in appropriations of 1.5 billion euros. The conciliation committee, meanwhile, agreed on an amount of EUR 1.53 billion allocated to the migrant crisis above the ceilings of headings 3 and 4.  The allocation of payment credits would be as follows: 710 million euros in 2016; 652.9 million in 2017; 82.7 million in 2018; $58.5 million in 2019. As this report is the continuation of the compromise on the 2016 budget and proposes substantial European funding for the management of the migration crisis, we can only oppose it. So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls for mobilising the flexibility instrument for a sum of EUR 1.530 billion in commitment appropriations to finance the European response to the migration crisis that affects it. This text reminds us that the ceilings of heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Heading 4 (Europe in the World) for the 2016 financial year do not fully finance urgent measures in this area, such as securing external borders by recruiting additional staff in the Frontex agency. In order to complete the 2016 budget and to comply with the rule of the annual ceiling of 471 million euros of payments under the flexibility instrument, the report recommends that payment credits be spread over several years and amount to 734.2 million euros in 2016, 654.2 million euros in 2017, 83 million euros in 2018 and 58.6 million euros in 2019.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I think it is important for the EU to demonstrate that it is capable of rapid and flexible decision-making, not only at a theoretical level, but also in practice, which will greatly advance the resolution of urgent matters. The migration crisis that Europe is facing today requires exactly the same measures on our part.  That is why I am in support of redirecting large sums of money to crisis management, because if we have reserves and resources, we must make use of them now, thereby facilitating the work of agencies such as Frontex, Europol and Easo, as well as improving the situation in the countries most affected by the migration tide.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which will bring more flexibility for the Union’s Budget, especially addressing the refugee crisis.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. – I supported this report as it was necessary to mobilise funding to finance measures to address the refugee crisis and migration, especially in the context of the humanitarian approach.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report with my vote today, which paraphrases the negotiations between the representatives of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in the context of migration measures. The budgetary implications of the recent migration phenomenon in the EU, the preparation of Member States to provide living conditions to these people are extremely important, and these costs were not anticipated in 2013 when the 2014-2020 budgetary framework was negotiated and approved. It was a necessity at this time that this flexibility instrument, which will allow the use of EUR 1.506 million, be approved and the Commission should be given the green light for the relocation of funds in the new context.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported an increase in migration appropriations in the 2016 budget using the flexibility tool. This is a clear priority for which maximum resources need to be used. An additional budget injection of EUR 1.5 billion will allow us to really put our strength into successfully managing the refugee crisis. They will need to be closely supervised so that they are directed towards meaningful and effective projects and do not end up in a black hole. One example may be to improve the management of the external borders in order to bring the migratory flow under control. In any event, the European dimension of external border control needs to be strengthened.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report on the mobilisation of the Flexible Instrument for Emergency Fiscal Action under the European Agenda on Migration gives its support for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument of EUR 1 530 million. This was rejected by me, as this mobilisation has already failed to have the desired effect in the past.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to approve the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to take immediate budgetary measures to bail out the financial funds allocated to the management of the migrant and refugee crisis.  The aim is to reallocate unused budgets in the 2014 and 2015 financial years to finance migration and refugee measures for the period 2016-2019 to the tune of EUR 1.530 billion. An additional EUR 734.2 million will be allocated in the 2016 financial year, so that the European Union can respond to the urgency of this crisis.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the need for additional resources for urgent action in the area of migration and refugees.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Also reiterating in relation to this decision that the migrant emergency requires a huge financial effort for the union as a whole, I appreciated the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, within the framework of the 2016 budget, for 1 506 million euros. Further emphasising the need to ensure greater flexibility for the Union budget in dealing with emergency situations, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The problem of the refugee crisis will not be solved by itself. On the contrary, by turning your head to the other side, the problem will get bigger. I believe that the problem needs to be addressed at the point of its emergence and that we must ensure that people have the conditions to stay in their home and their homeland.  But this is a process that requires political will and participation by all. At the moment we must help the countries under the greatest pressure of the refugee wave, as trends show that the influx of new refugees will not stop so soon. According to the data of the Ministry of the Interior of the Republic of Croatia, almost 420 000 migrants have entered the Republic of Croatia since the beginning of the migration crisis.  However, so far only 9 have applied for asylum in the Republic of Croatia.  According to some estimates, the refugee crisis generates a daily cost of HRK 2 million. The actual costs so far are difficult to estimate, because not all bills arrive simultaneously, and some ministries finance costs from their own budget and their funds will be reimbursed later.  On 6 November 2015, the European Commission granted €16.4 million from crisis funds to the Republic of Croatia for the incurred costs of managing the refugee crisis. I support the Budget Committee's report on the mobilisation of flexibility instruments, which will be earmarked to manage the refugee crisis.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to deal with the migration crisis. It follows the compromise on the 2016 budget reached by Parliament and the Council. Indeed, in its initial draft budget, the Commission proposed the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to the tune of EUR 123.9 million to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis above the ceiling of heading 3 (citizenship and security). However, given the scale of the problem, the Commission decided to revise its position by proposing in its amending letter 2/2016 an increase in appropriations of 1.5 billion euros. The conciliation committee, meanwhile, agreed on an amount of EUR 1.53 billion allocated to the migrant crisis above the ceilings of headings 3 and 4.  The allocation of payment credits would be as follows: 710 million euros in 2016; 652.9 million in 2017; 82.7 million in 2018; $58.5 million in 2019. As this report is the continuation of the compromise on the 2016 budget and proposes substantial European funding for the management of the migration crisis, we can only oppose it.  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Two things are important about this proposal for a decision to mobilise flexibility instruments. First, additional resources are needed to ensure and support the necessary measures on the refugee crisis and migration in a quality way. Secondly, this case shows that more flexibility is needed for the Union budget in general. In this light, I welcome the decision to mobilise the flexibility instrument to the amount of EUR 1 506 million in commitment appropriations e-euro. "Security and citizenship" and 24m euros from Heading 4. "Global Europe".

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. —There is no doubt that more budgetary resources need to be taken into account for a range of EU funds and bodies that control the entry and functioning of Schengen in order to overcome the challenges of border control, freedom of movement within the Union and European solidarity. Syria is a key focal point, but not the only one, and the problem needs to be seen comprehensively within the EU's new foreign and security policy strategy by bringing together external, security-defence, development, humanitarian and trade mechanisms so that the EU, together with the US and other strategic partners, acts more engagedly as a global actor and finds solutions to the causes of the crisis. Council Regulation No 1001/2013 1311/2013 provides for a Flexibility Facility for financing, in the financial year in the financial year, of clearly temporary expenditure that cannot be financed under the ceilings available for one or more other headings up to EUR 471 million (in 2011 prices) which can be used for a maximum period of 3 years (n+3). Given the possibilities in this Regulation, I consider it justified to mobilise EUR 1.504 million through the Flexibility Facility for this matter. I hereby emphasize that to this day over 440 000 refugees have entered croatia as a transit country, so it is very important to strengthen the management of external borders because we must not allow the Mediterranean to be a place of danger for those who want to live in Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of using the flexibility instrument to finance some urgent measures to address the external dimension of the challenges posed by the refugee crisis. The mobilisation concerns a total amount of EUR 1 504 million in the multiannual financial framework. In view of the fact that the ceilings under headings 3 (Security and Citizenship) and 4 (Global Europe) provided for in the 2016 EU budget were not sufficient, it was necessary to use this instrument. To this end, an allocation of EUR 734.2 million in 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, EUR 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019 is expected. I also believe that the use of the flexibility instrument is a clear signal of the need to ensure greater flexibility in the EU budget in such a way as to be more responsive in providing responses to crisis situations.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes report on mobilising the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European migration agenda. This will include the proposed allocation of corresponding payment credits amounting to EUR 734.2 million for the 2016 financial year, EUR 654.2 million for fiscal 2017, EUR 83 million for fiscal 2018 and EUR 58.6 million for fiscal 2019.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The current refugee crisis requires adequate funding of the urgent measures envisaged under the European Agenda on Migration. However, the ceilings on expenditure under Category 3 (Security and Citizenship) and Category 4 (Global Europe) do not address the external dimension of the challenges. It is therefore necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement the financing of the general Union budget for the financial year 2016, beyond the ceilings, with more than EUR 1506 million for category 3 and a further EUR 24 million for category 4. Additional appropriations will be made possible by the transition of unused amounts of the flexibility instruments for the 2014 and 1015 financial years. To this end, the European Commission proposes to reallocation of commitment appropriations, allocated over several financial years, with an estimated EUR 734.2 million in 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, EUR 83.0 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019. It should be noted that this redeployment makes it possible to finance the measures adopted, as provided for in Article 11 of the Regulation establishing the MFF. In view of what has been said, I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this flexibility instrument because the instrument focuses on an amount for EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations to deal with the migration crisis. A further EUR 24 million is being allocated for Global Europe to help refugees and migrants seek employment and social justice under the heading of Global Europe. The key points surrounding this instrument focuses over four years from 2016 to 2019 for a total of EUR 1.3 billion, the largest amounts are spread over 2016 & 2017. In 2016 EUR 734.2 million has been allocated and for 2017 EUR 654.2 has been allocated.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution.  The current refugee crisis facing the European Union is historic and calls for a response that combines responsibility, courage and respect for our European values. This means providing the Union with the necessary budgetary resources to finance the planned emergency measures.   We know that the ceilings of "Security and Citizenship" and 4 "Europe in the World" for the 2016 financial year do not allow adequate funding for these measures. That is why we are mobilising today the flexibility instrument for a total of EUR 1.530 billion in commitment credits, these additional credits coming from the unused amounts of flexibility instruments in the 2014 and 2015 financial years. In addition, no amount will be deferred to fiscal year 2017.  Now it will be necessary to ensure that the measures decided will be implemented and that each of the stakeholders concerned will fulfil its commitments.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The solidarity instrument is mobilised in order to provide the sums of EUR 1 506 million in category 3 (Security and citizenship) and EUR 24 million in category 4 (Global Europe), to be used to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis. It also adds the proposal to allot payment appropriations of EUR 734.2 million in 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, EUR 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. With this decision, Parliament warns that the 2016 deadlines for headings 3 and 4 of the budget do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures in the field of migration and refugees, and agrees with the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 1.53 billion in commitment appropriations and with the proposal for the allocation of corresponding payment appropriations of EUR 734.2 million 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, EUR 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019.  It also warns that the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument once again demonstrates the imperative need for a more flexible Union budget. For all this, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In the context of the European Union's general budget for the 2016 financial year, the flexibility instrument is used to provide EUR 1,506 million in commitment credits under heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and EUR 24 million in commitment credits under heading 4 (Europe in the World). Given the urgent need, these amounts will be used to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis, and I welcome that. Based on the profile of expected payments, payment credits corresponding to the mobilization of the flexibility instrument will be as follows: 734.2 million euros in 2016, 654.2 million euros in 2017, 83 million euros in 2018 and 58.6 million euros in 2019.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Europe has been experiencing, in particular for the past year, a long and difficult challenge with the continuing wave of migrants/refugees seeking a new breath in the old continent to restart their lives. However, this situation has in some cases been translated into tragic outcomes and, for this reason, the European Union has sought to respond, taking into account the instruments at its disposal. To this extent, the EU adopted a model for financing urgent migration measures, which was proposed by the European Commission by mobilising the Flexibility Instrument. The proposal was to increase the allocation of payment appropriations by an additional EUR 1506 million (on the heading "security and citizenship") and EUR 24 million under the heading "Global Europe", which is additional, basic and essential aid, given the dramatic development of this situation. Therefore, using this instrument to finance measures to manage the refugee crisis seems to me to be a necessary and justifiable decision for the activation of this extra procedure, and I have therefore given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report as a reminder of how flexible the European Union's budget must be in dealing with crises and their consequences. This text mobilises the flexibility instrument to support exceptional measures to manage the refugee crisis to the tune of EUR 66.1 million. The European Union must stand in solidarity and provide assistance and contribution in resolving the current migration crisis.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it brings immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee emergency. The multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 authorises the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument, which provides staggered payment appropriations over various budget years for a total amount of EUR 1 506 million. Specifically, the text provides for the full mobilisation of the flexibility instrument in 2016 to manage the refugee crisis.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes report, which agrees to mobilize EUR 66.1 million in payment commitments in two years (52.9 million in 2016 and 13.2 million euros in 2017) to address the refugee and migrant crisis, taking advantage of the very limited Budget Flexibility Instrument. It's a small number, but voting against it would be worse, by not mobilizing it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument which will allow the implementation of immediate budgetary measures in relation to the European Agenda on Migration. In this way, the budget may be amended to add the necessary items for European policies for the reception of migrants, which will enable housing or employment plans, asylum policies, with the speeding up of the resolution of asylum claims, and maritime rescue operations. We are faced with a joint competence shared by the Union and the Member States, so our favourable vote presupposes a will of the States which we have not been seeing in practice. We are confident that the expenditure we have approved will be spent on what is really intended and does not end, as we have seen so far, by spending on strengthening the Fortress Europe.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for more EU spending, which I am against.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this budgetary procedure because the mobilisation of these funds should be and is a priority of the EU.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Refugees who are in danger of life must be helped. It is also important to allocate sufficient funds, because we are facing the biggest refugee crisis. However, with this form of application of budgetary measures, we also need to focus on how to use these funds specifically and ensure that their transparent use is checked. I have missed such an important instrument in this case, which is why I abstained when voting on the Mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Agenda on Migration cannot be addressed without funding. That is why the Commission has proposed to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument beyond the ceiling and to replenish the appropriations in the general budget of the Union for the financial year with EUR 1 504 million in commitment appropriations to finance measures in the context of the migration crisis in Europe.  In addition to this amount, at Parliament's suggestion, the Conciliation Committee agreed to release an additional EUR 24 million. The release of €1 530 million of commitment funds from the Flexibility Instrument will very effectively help to address, both immediately and in the longer term, the problems of migrants in individual Member States, which would not be able to cover the costs of hotspots, transitional accommodation, the provision of health and social assistance, humanitarian aid and the fight against smugglers within their own budgets.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In order to complement the financing of actions under the European Agenda on Migration from the 2016 general budget, the Commission proposed the use of the Flexibility Instrument, exceeding the ceiling of Heading 3 by EUR 1,504 million. In the context of the negotiations on the 2016 budget, the Conciliation Committee agreed to this surplus ceiling and endorsed Parliament's proposal to apply the Flexibility Instrument to 24 million above the ceiling of Heading 4 in order to address the challenges of the refugee crisis. The total amount of the Flexibility Instrument for 2016 is thus fully utilised. Since the ceilings of headings 3 and 4 of the 2016 budget do not allow the financing of emergency measures in the area of migration and refugees, I support the measure to use a total of EUR 1 530 million from the Flexibility Instrument. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument appeared together with the Commission's Letter of Amendment 2/2016 of 14 October 2015. This mobilisation concerns an amount of EUR 1.5 billion above the ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) under heading 3 and EUR 24 million in heading 4 and is intended to finance support measures for the management of the refugee crisis. In principle, I am in favour of approving funds to deal with the migration and refugee crisis and of using the flexibility instrument in exceptional circumstances. However, I believe that there are more opportunities for redeployment of funds in the 2016 budget. There are a number of budget lines with poor implementation and no demonstrable EU added value that could be cut to help address the migration and refugee crisis. This requires a comprehensive EU approach, as we presented at ALFA weeks ago. These include measures such as comprehensive control of the EU's external borders, the establishment of transit zones outside the Schengen area and the consistent repatriation of rejected asylum seekers. As this is still pending, I abstained.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The issue of the refugee crisis requires immediate and effective action, given its urgent need for a pragmatic solution to the situation, so it is really important that the Union budget is more flexible.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because the refugee crisis requires the mobilising of additional appropriations to fund migration and home affairs policy. In my view, unused annual amounts from flexibility instruments from previous years should be used. Furthermore, I believe that payment appropriations corresponding to the envisaged mobilisation of the flexibility instrument should be distributed over several budget years (€710 million in 2016, €652.9 million in 2017, €82.7 million in 2018 and €58.5 million in 2019) all in line with the annual budgetary procedure.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. After having examined all possibilities for reallocating appropriations, the Commission proposes to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for the amount of EUR 1.5 billion through the Flexibility Instrument to finance measures in the field of migration. This includes unused annual amounts available for the Flexibility Instruments of previous years (2014 and 2015). That amount shall be used to finance measures for managing the refugee crisis. The refugee crisis is, and must continue to be, a priority for the EU and so I am supportive of this much—needed funding.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ European Council Regulation No 2012 1311/2013, which set multiannual financial frameworks for the period 2014-2020, allows the activation of the so-called multiannual financial frameworks for the period 2014-2020. A flexible instrument, allowing unforeseen costs to be financed. After an in-depth review of all the options for redistribution of funds, it has proved necessary to allocate an additional EUR 1 504 million from the already temporary financial framework to finance measures in the migration sector. This figure includes eur 123 966 698, proposed by the Commission for use in the same sector through the Flexible Instrument in the original draft budget for 2016, however it was abolished and replaced by this proposal. The reallocation of funds in line with the activation of the Flexible Instrument is as follows: • EUR 710 million for 2016 • EUR 652.9 million for 2017 • EUR 82.7 million for 2018 • EUR 58.5 million for 2019 I support the allocation and redistribution of funds, as I believe that in the current migration situation efforts should be financially supported to address it.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. While I agree with the increase in EU funds to deal with the refugee crisis, I have two fundamental comments on this particular proposal. Firstly, I do not agree with the Commission's assertion that it has already exhausted all available possibilities for transferring resources within a given budget heading. Secondly, I reject the purpose of using these funds, as most of the approved package is intended to finance compulsory refugee redistribution schemes, which I reject as a matter of principle.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis. In the conciliation procedure between the European Parliament and the European Council, we agreed to make further use of the flexibility instrument of EUR 24 million in addition to the increase in the EU budget for 2016 for the refugee crisis. The refugee and migrant crisis is taking on greater proportions by the day, and that is why we need to increase resources and help the countries that are most stressed. To date, over 250,000 refugees and migrants have crossed Slovenia, which represents more than 10% of the Slovenian population.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament resolution agreeing to increase the funding of measures related to the migration crisis to a total of EUR 1 506 million. This could result in EUR 734.2 million available in 2016. I believe that, of course, the current situation cannot be addressed only by increasing the budgetary resources, but to the current needs based on the exceptionality of the situation, we need to respond and ensure smooth security funding.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Unused annual amounts available under the flexibility instruments for the financial years 2014 and 2015 should be used to address the refugee crisis. Amounts corresponding to EUR 1.5 billion Euro. at a time when there are Member States of the Union which are plagued by the crisis, yet they are the first countries to be designated as countries of collection of migrants and must, in accordance with EU rules, take care of them throughout their stay there. Countries, such as Greece, which are unable to take care of their own citizens.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 After considering all options for realloding commitment appropriations within Chapters 3 and 4 in the EU budget for 2016, it became necessary to use the Flexibility Instrument in favour of commitment appropriations. Therefore, the European Commission has proposed to use the Flexibility Instrument in order to complement the resources in the European Union's general budget for 2016 with commitment appropriations of EUR 1 506 million in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 3 to finance measures taken under the European Agenda on Migration. In addition to the eur 1 506 million ceiling for chapter 3, the Conciliation Committee convened for the 2016 budget also adopted the proposal of the Parliamentary delegation to use an additional EUR 24 million under the Flexibility Instrument, in addition to the ceiling in Chapter 4, to address the external dimensions of the challenges posed by the refugee crisis. On the basis of the above, the European Parliament has adopted the use of the Flexibility Instrument in the form of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 1 530 million.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I myself contributed to the European Parliament's approval of the use of the Flexibility Instrument, in addition to the 2016 budget allocation of EUR 1 530 million, allocated over the next four years to supplement Community and Member State expenditure on the refugee crisis. In this context, we had to acknowledge that, in addition to the current budgetary structure and regulation, rigid budget chapter ceilings make it not possible to finance such even more pressing tasks within or above a given budget chapter (chapters 3 and 4, where appropriate). For this reason, this report also highlighted the importance of making budget training and regulation more flexible, which I consider urgent. Furthermore, I am concerned that the use of the Flexibility Instrument now decided is essentially due to the transfer of residues from 2014 and 2015, but that such a residue cannot be expected in 2017 under the Flexibility Instrument.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The current situation of the influx of refugees is one of the most serious challenges facing the European Union today. Within a dozen months, European migration policy had become completely inseparable from the realities. Therefore, the European Commission's proposal to mobilise the flexibility instrument beyond the Multiannual Financial Framework to finance measures to manage the migration and refugee crisis seems most appropriate.  The EU budget should become a more flexible tool to respond to emerging needs and challenges. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of mobilising this instrument and providing additional resources for crisis management.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a decision on mobilising the flexibility instrument for immediate budgetary measures to deal with the refugee crisis, in line with point 12 of the 2 December 2013 inter-institutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on Budgetary Discipline. , budget cooperation and good financial management.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ More financial means are necessary to address the refugee crisis and I therefore supported the proposed mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to address it. The immediate budgetary measures will be used within the framework of the European Agenda on Migration. Thanks to the mobilisation, the general budget of the EU for the financial year 2016 will be complemented by EUR 1 504 million in commitment appropriations beyond the ceiling of the expenditure heading Security and Citizenship. I welcome that the European Parliament underlined also the external dimension of the challenges posed by the refugee crisis and proposed to further mobilise the Flexibility Instrument by EUR 24 million beyond the ceiling of expenditure heading Global Europe. In total, it was approved to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument for an amount of EUR 1 530 million in commitment appropriations, which will be allocated between 2016 and 2019.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒The request to mobilise the flexibility budgetary instrument was published in October and mobilisation requires an additional €1.5 billion to fund measures related to the migration and refugee crisis.  The spending of these funds is planned for the following projects: emergency assistance in the asylum, migration and integration fund system and an internal security fund; increasing FRONTEX's operational capabilities; increase staff in the three main migration agencies and finally increase funding in AMIF-Asylum, AMIF-Return and ISF-Borders. In principle, I fully agree with the indisputable fact that significant additional resources are needed in this segment, and that the flexibility instrument must be launched in certain emergencies, such as the one europe is currently in. While I voted yes as a result, I must express my opposition to this specific proposal for measures, as I do not think that the Commission has made a sufficiently careful and detailed analysis of all the possibilities for the most efficient extraction of money from the budget by eliminating projects without proven added value before burdening the budgets of individual Member States of the Union with the amount it requires. I also oppose the forced scheme of realisation of refugees, as I believe that only the Member States are the ones that should decide; each of them knows best the specificity of their situation in the fight against the refugee crisis.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and common line On 13 December 2013, I supported the financing from the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, as I believe that this instrument should complement the financing from the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 and thus allocate more resources than planned to finance actions management of the refugee crisis.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes report, which agrees to mobilize EUR 66.1 million in payment commitments in two years (52.9 million in 2016 and 13.2 million euros in 2017) to address the refugee and migrant crisis, taking advantage of the very limited Budget Flexibility Instrument. It's a small number, but voting against it would be worse, by not mobilizing it.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 Recently, in the context of the refugee crisis, I have warned of the need to increase the relevant budgets for its management, protection of the EU's external borders, etc. In general, I therefore welcome the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures. However, I do not agree with the system of mandatory quotas for Member States, and i therefore do not support the mobilisation of realisation funds under this mechanism. That is why I abstained.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument appeared together with the Commission's Letter of Amendment 2/2016 of 14 October 2015. This mobilisation concerns an amount of EUR 1.5 billion above the ceiling of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) under heading 3 and EUR 24 million in heading 4 and is intended to finance support measures for the management of the refugee crisis. Increased funding is indispart to address the migration and refugee crisis. I am therefore in favour of using the flexibility instrument in these exceptional circumstances. It is important and right that the EU also makes an appropriately high financial contribution. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. It is fundamental that Europe is able to react as soon as possible to this very European crisis and mobilise as much money as possible to make easier the integration of the hundreds of thousands of people who are arriving in Europe, running away from their war-torn homeland.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is a continuation of the compromise on the 2016 budget and proposes substantial European funding for the management of the migration crisis to which I am opposed.   So I'm voting against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the Flexibility Instrument will be used to provide a commitment appropriation of EUR 1 506 million in Chapter 3 (Security and Citizenship of the Union) and EUR 24 million in commitment appropriations in Chapter 4 (Global Europe). These amounts should be used to finance measures to address the refugee crisis. The use of this instrument under Article 11 of the MTM Regulation once again highlights the crucial need for the EU budget to be more flexible. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes report, which agrees to mobilize EUR 66.1 million in payment commitments in two years (52.9 million in 2016 and 13.2 million euros in 2017) to address the refugee and migrant crisis, taking advantage of the very limited Budget Flexibility Instrument. It's a small number, but voting against it would be worse, by not mobilizing it.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The Commission has proposed to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument beyond the ceiling for Heading 3 and to add EUR 1 504 million to the General Budget of the Union for the financial year 2016. The amount of commitment appropriations amounting to EUR 100 million in order to finance measures under the European Agenda on Migration.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis, in accordance with point 12 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management.  I agree that due to the urgent needs, it is necessary to mobilise an important additional amount to finance measures to alleviate the migration and refugee crisis and that it is necessary to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to complement the financing in the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, beyond the ceilings of heading 3 by EUR 1 506 million and heading 4 by EUR 24 million to finance measures in the field of migration and refugees. The unused annual amounts available for the Flexibility Instruments of the financial years 2014 and 2015 should be used for this mobilisation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This action is carried out by mobilizing the Flexibility Instrument in the amount of EUR 1 530 million in commitment appropriations for immediate budgetary measures dealing with the refugee crisis. Because of its nature, I think it's convenient to vote on your behalf.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument which will allow the implementation of immediate budgetary measures in relation to the European Agenda on Migration. In this way, the budget may be amended to add the necessary items for European policies for the reception of migrants, which will enable housing or employment plans, asylum policies, with the speeding up of the resolution of asylum claims, and maritime rescue operations. We are faced with a joint competence shared by the Union and the Member States, so our favourable vote presupposes a will of the States which we have not been seeing in practice. We are confident that the expenditure we have approved will be spent on what is really intended and does not end, as we have seen so far, by spending on strengthening the Fortress Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution because it is imperative that people in Europe respond in a timely manner to the refugee crisis. In doing so, it is essential to gather sufficient financial resources to deal with this crisis.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This text aims to enable the financing of the plan to relocate asylum seekers within the European Union. The first relocations were finally able to take place at the beginning of October, but to date only 150 asylum seekers have been able to benefit from the scheme. While several Member States are questioning most of the commitments they have made in this area and, which should concern 160,000 potential asylum seekers and refugees, since they are only Syrians, Eritreans and Iraqis who have arrived from Greece and Italy, I felt it was important to support the continuation of this minimum plan. The release of 66.1 million euros for the 2015 financial year has already taken place, but in order to promote the integration of these refugees and their reception in other Member States, for the coming years, the European Commission has called for the implementation of measures, including exceptional financial measures, and proposes to allocate EUR 734.2 million in 2016, EUR 654.2 million in 2017, 83 million in 2018 and EUR 58.6 million in 2019.  I obviously voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. An urgent response to this situation in the Balkans is needed. This unstoppable and significant flow is of greatest concern from a humanitarian point of view, the situation of which has worsened in recent days, with the imposition by several countries of discriminatory and illegal barriers to the movement of persons on the basis of their nationality. Measures that add to acts of violence and extortion committed by the authorities on the destiture and vulnerable. These funds, which the EU so much touts, are primarily intended to accentuate the aggressive and xenophobic nature of europe's current emigration policy, betting on the persecution, expulsion and stigmatisation of migrants. The only compaginable response is needed with some of the values and principles that the European Union likes to proclaim, but does not practice; the only commisable response to the human rights of those fleeing the misery, chaos and war that the European Union has helped to sow and actively nourish; that is: the immediate creation of safe and legal migratory routes that disarticulate trafficking networks.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. A further extension of the use of these funds without appropriate accompanying measures does not serve any purpose. The proposal to make the budget even more flexible would lead to a bottomless pit. I therefore reject this report.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The cessation of additional funding of EUR 1.528 billion by 2019 for further measures in the field of migration and refugees cannot be in the interests of European future-preservation. Nor are any upper limits visible. It is totally unacceptable to offer financial measures in the area of dealing with the 'refugee' crisis with the option of unbridled increases, leaving the causes of the poverty refugees unchanged.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I have refused to support the European Parliament resolution on the use of the flexibility instrument for emergency budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration. Essentially, it is a question of the budgetary implementation of European refugee policy. Since I consider the European refugee policy to be a mistake, I consequently do not want to provide a budget for it. In particular, quotas must and will fail, while the resettlement of refugees has already hit the wall at the start.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds because the refugee crisis is a critical and urgent priority for the EU. I deplore our own UK Government’s inaction on this subject, lagging behind public opinion, and its continued refusal to take a European approach to what is clearly a European problem. Much more must still be done at a European level on common asylum procedures.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 It is not enough to talk about the migration crisis, but it is necessary to take concrete measures to mitigate its negative impacts on EU Member States and their citizens. These measures cost money. At the same time, however, the current crisis and the huge wave of refugees is an extraordinary event that the EU budget did not foresee. It is therefore necessary to mobilise the flexibility instrument in order to use the existing budgetary reserves in order to cover these extra costs.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, in the same direction as the majority of the Committee on Budgets and most political groups, helping to deal more effectively with the refugee crisis facing Europe.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Frontex and Europol should have sufficient resources to protect the external borders of the EU Member States, as they can actually help manage the migration crisis better. However, this report also allocates funds to the relocation mechanism, so, of course, I did not support it, because I do not agree with the redistribution mechanism from the beginning.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument amounting to EUR 1 530 million in commitment appropriations and EUR 806 million in payment appropriations to complement the financing of migration policy, reinforcing headings 3 and 4: 'Security and citizenship' and 'Global Europe'.  Today, due to the refugee crisis, the EU has found the need to establish, in order to address it, a number of measures that promote the well-being, not only of refugees, but also of all Member States receiving large flows of people. The problem is the absence of margins available within the multiannual financial framework to address mobilization funding. It is therefore necessary to mobilize additional appropriations in order to deal with this situation; otherwise, the EU's economic structure would not have the capacity to serve such high numbers of refugees, nor could it guarantee them well-being.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Article 11 of the Regulation establishing the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework provides for the possibility of using the flexibility instrument to allow the financing of exceptional expenditure that could not be financed within the available ceilings of one or more headings.  This is the case with regard to the issue of immigration, as the measures provided for by the EU Commission exceeded the limits for the year 2016 provided for in heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and, to a small extent, also in heading 4 (Global Europe). It was therefore decided to use this special instrument to the amount of EUR 1.5 billion. Payment appropriations will amount to €734 million in 2016, €654 million in 2017, €83 million in 2018 and €58 million in 2019.  The call for the mobilisation of this instrument is an integral part of the agreement on the European Union budget for 2016, although it is voted separately. Although I am opposed to the overall agreement on the EU budget, this measure is necessary in order to provide a European response to the management of the immigration emergency, which now affects different European fronts.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument for immediate budgetary measures to address the refugee crisis. In this case, the Flexibility Instrument was to be mobilised under the proposal to finance the European Agenda on Migration, with the proposal stating that all options for reallocating funds under the existing budget were considered. However, I do not agree with this reasoning and am of the opinion that the current budget provides opportunities that could still be used, especially in relation to the transfer of funds from areas with low added value. This would not exhaust the funds under the Flexibility Instrument as proposed, but could be carried over to the next financial year to cover possible emergencies. The second fact, for which I was unable to give my vote by mobilising the Flexibility Instrument, was that the Flexibility Instrument should provide funding for both relocation systems, a temporary as well as a permanent system for relocating asylum seekers, which I do not support, as I believe that solidarity between states should be based, in particular, on the principle of voluntaryity and not on compulsory quotas.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The flexibility instrument has the function of ensuring greater flexibility of the Multiannual Financial Framework in order to respond to unforeseen circumstances justifying the exceeding the ceilings of budgetary securities, with the maximum annual amount of this instrument being EUR 471 million (at 2011 prices). This proposal replaces that of the European Commission, which proposed mobilising EUR 123 966 698 for Title 3 (Security and Citizenship) from the EU budget, in order to support measures to address the management of the refugee crisis. It is then proposed to mobilise EUR 1504 million from this Instrument to allow the limits of Title 3 to be exceeded in this same amount, using unused funds in previous years 2014 and 2015. Payments will be made by 2019 (€710 million in 2016, €652.9 million in 2017, €82.7 million in 2018 and €58.5 million in 2019). We voted in favour, obviously taking into account the urgency of giving humanitarian and inclusion support to migrants and refugees. We hope that these funds will be mobilised for this purpose, not to finance the repression.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this disaster fund for Europe because it has been allocated EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations. The maximum ceiling for this fund is EUR 500 million per annum; we oppose commitment appropriations, as they only increase the budget. The money that the Member State claims has already been paid by the membership fees that they pay to the EU; it is clearly a case of getting your own money back.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the severe floods in Central Europe in 2002, the EU has set up the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF), to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations and to demonstrate solidarity with the population of disaster-affected regions. Unfortunately, the bureaucratic procedures for accessing funds are very complex and the quotas that can be agreed are really derisory. I have put two questions on this subject: one to the Council and one to the Commission, calling precisely for an increase in the appropriations allocated to the Fund and for the procedures to be streamlined. The report adopted examines Article 4a of regulation (EC) establishing the Solidarity Fund, which provides for the possibility of mobilising it for a maximum amount of EUR 50 000 000 for the payment of advances and for the entry of the corresponding appropriations in the general budget of the Union. This report calls for a sum equal to the ceiling of EUR 50 million in appropriations, commitment and payment for the payment of advances to be mobilised within the framework of the general budget set for 2016. I hope that this measure will speed up the European Union's response in the event of major natural disasters. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary for the European Union Solidarity Fund to have the necessary resources in each exercise to be able to respond as quickly as possible to the catastrophes that occurred in any Member State of the European Union. The situations of natural disasters taking place in Europe need a rapid response and this proposal establishes the provision of funds in order to be able to react as quickly as possible and to be able to alleviate the effects on the citizens of the affected regions. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable Member States to receive financial support when faced with an emergency caused by large-scale or regional natural disasters. The report envisages the 2016 budget of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment credits in order to pay the amount set to the applicant states in advance. This is a positive step that will speed up the payment of funds in emergency situations. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not agree with the principle of the Solidarity Fund and therefore voted against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund in order to provide funds for the payment of advances from the 2016 budget. The Aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the EU to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express solidarity with disaster-stricken regions in Europe. This proposal for a solution does not concern a specific natural disaster, which aims to include an amount of EUR 50 000 000 in the EU budget for 2016, which will consist of commitment and payment appropriations, in order to allow timely and effective payment of advances in the event of any natural disaster next year. I agree that the advance should be paid at the request of a Member State and only after the Commission has carried out a preliminary assessment of the relevant EUSF application. The amount of the advance should not exceed 10 % of the estimated amount of the financial contribution and should not exceed EUR 30 million. Eur.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to enable the European Union to respond to major natural disasters. The Regulation on the MFF for the period 2014-2020 allows the fund to be used up to an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million, in addition to the ceilings of the relevant chapters of the financial framework.  The proposal for a current decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. Instead, it aims to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the EU budget for 2016 in order to pay advances on time and efficiently in the event of a disaster next year. Thus, the granting of aid to the countries concerned can be accelerated by means of the advance before the final award decision is taken. I supported the adoption of this report because it is important that the countries and territories affected by the disaster receive the aid to which they are entitled as soon as possible.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this disaster fund for Europe because it has been allocated EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations. The maximum ceiling for this fund is EUR 500 million per annum; we oppose commitment appropriations, as they only increase the budget. The money that the Member State claims has already been paid by the membership fees that they pay to the EU; it is clearly a case of getting your own money back.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report aims to enable advances from the EU Solidarity Fund to Member States suffering from a major natural disaster, with the aim of speeding up the aid process where it is justified. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I am grateful for the rapporteur's work on mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund on the payment of advances under the 2016 budget. I voted in favour of it as this Fund is a resource of the Member States in case of need which is used appropriately and very usefully for those Member States which request it. It is not simply a form of financial assistance from the Union but helps to send a clear political message of solidarity while providing much-needed aid to the citizens concerned.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is common sense and, for once, is putting in place genuine European solidarity. The Solidarity Fund provides Member States with rapid and effective financial support in the event of a natural disaster or regional disaster. As we have seen with the recent floods in Croatia, for example, it is an indispensable instrument, so this proposal which aims to include in the 2016 budget the sum of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment credits in order to pay in advance to the Member States that need it will only lead to better management of crises such as these. It should also be noted that the new provision allows for an advance of up to 10% or EUR 30 million, without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilization of funds. A simplification of an instrument of mutual aid to which I could only be in favour.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Solidarity Fund is an important instrument of support that Europe makes available to Member States affected by major natural disasters. Its effectiveness depends mainly on two variables: flexibility and speed of activation. As this report considers and improves both aspects, I voted in favour of it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by serious natural disasters and to express European solidarity to disaster-affected regions. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating their accession in the event of a serious natural disaster, i.e. where direct total damage exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's gross national income. It can also be mobilized in the event of a regional catastrophe. The proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a specific catastrophe, but seeks to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances in the event of a disaster next year and thus ensure the availability of budgetary resources by improving the effectiveness of the Fund. That's why I voted for it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which examines the possibilities of mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances. The Objective of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) is to enable the European Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with disaster-stricken regions in Europe. This Fund provides financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating EU membership in the event of a major natural disaster, i.e. where the total direct damage caused by this disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion. Its funds may also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster. It should be noted that the advance may be paid at the request of a Member State and after an preliminary assessment by the Commission of the relevant EUSF application. The amount of the advance should not exceed 10 % of the estimated amount of the financial contribution and should not exceed EUR 30 million. The advance shall be paid without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilisation of the EUSF and the European Commission shall recover the amounts of the advance unduly paid to the Member States. The European Parliament recalls what the EUSF is not just a source of other types of EU financial assistance, but it also helps to send a clear political signal of solidarity and provide much-needed assistance to the citizens affected. The rapid response capability, including the payment of the advance, will therefore help the European Union to achieve these objectives.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) was set up to enable the European Union to respond promptly to major natural disasters and to express solidarity with europe's disaster-affected regions. The Regulation on the MFF 2014-2020 allows the fund to be used up to an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million (at 2011 prices), in addition to the ceilings of the relevant chapters of the financial framework. The proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. It aims to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the EU budget for 2016, so that advances can be paid on time and efficiently in the event of a disaster next year. The European Parliament has therefore agreed to add the proposed amounts to the 2016 budget. As the proposal entitled 'Using the EU Solidarity Fund for advance payments for the 2016 budget' forms part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating bodies of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016, I supported the report in line with hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. The EU Solidarity Fund is one of the most important items of the EU budget that enables emergency response to emergencies caused by major natural disasters be quickly responded to. It is also an expression of European solidarity with the regions affected. Under the legislation, the fund's funding is capped at $500 million a year. The proposed decision does not concern a specific natural disaster, but only provides for an amount of EUR 50 million for commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances in the event of an accident occurring next year. Slovenia has also benefited from the Solidarity Fund several times, most recently in the event of a catastrophic smlatter in January 2014, which made it easier for it to deal with the consequences. I have unreservedly supported the proposed decision.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the Solidarity Fund Activation Report to pay advances in the 2016 Budget. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexily in an emergency manner. The Fund's activation provision to pay advances allows for timely availability of budgetary resources and faster disbursement of assistance to candidate countries in the event of an accident in 2016.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. Regional or larger natural disasters affect poor and wealthy nations indiscriminately. In this context, it is clear that one of the European Union's roles is to put in place systems to ensure solidarity between Member States. The aim here is to be able to respond quickly and in a timely manner to the needs of the affected states and, in order to do so, to include in the 2016 budget the sum of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations. This measure being intended to speed up the process of granting emergency aid I vote for.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable Member States to receive financial support when faced with an emergency caused by large-scale natural disasters.  The proposal envisages a 50 million euro commitment and payment appropriations in the 2016 budget to pay requesting Member States in advance in the event of natural disasters in order to speed up the efficiency and speed of payments. This provision ensures the availability of budgetary resources and allows for a rapid disbursement of aid to the affected countries through the payment of an advance (up to 10% or EUR 30 million) before the final allocation decision is taken, knowing that the unduly paid advances are recovered from the Member State concerned. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to speed up the procedure for granting aid to a Member State in the event of an emergency.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I was in favour of the Report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF): the payment of advances in the 2016 budget because any instrument that can contribute quickly, efficiently and with flexibility to address emergencies must be encouraged. The objective of the Solidarity Fund is to enable the EU to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to show solidarity with the regions of Europe affected by a catastrophe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and countries at the negotiating stage for accession to the Union in the event of a 'major natural disaster', i.e. if the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion at 2011 prices or 0,6 % of the COUNTRY's VAT, the lowest amount of them being retained. We must be aware that the Solidarity Fund is not only a form of financial assistance provided by the EU, but it is also an important means of conveying a clear political message of solidarity, providing much-needed support to the citizens affected.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to demonstrate solidarity with the regions affected by these events.  The Fund may provide financial support to Member States and countries engaged in accession negotiations that have been affected by major natural disasters, i.e. if the total direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion, or 0.6% of the GNI of the country concerned, whatever the lower amount. It can also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster. The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 (Article 10) allows the mobilisation of the Fund up to an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million, above the limits of the relevant financial framework headings. The proposal aims to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year. The aim is to speed up the granting of aid to the countries affected by paying an advance before the final decision is taken.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management, for the payment of advances in the 2016 budget. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to show solidarity with the regions affected by these events.  However, this proposal is not linked to a specific case of natural disaster. Its aim is to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year. With this measure, the granting of aid to the countries affected will be speeded up by the payment of an advance before the final decision is taken, thereby improving the effectiveness of the Fund.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which is not linked to a specific conflict situation but instead provides EUR 50 million in the EU Budget as a commitment to helping a country which requires assistance from this fund.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this disaster fund for Europe because it has been allocated EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations. The maximum ceiling for this fund is EUR 500 million per annum; we oppose commitment appropriations, as they only increase the budget. The money that the Member State claims has already been paid by the membership fees that they pay to the EU; it is clearly a case of getting your own money back.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the mobilisation aims to respond in a rapid and efficient manner to urgent situations and to show solidarity with the populations of regions.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund should enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations and to show solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions. A ceiling of EUR 500 million is set for this Fund.  Mr Christoforou's report calls for a sum equal to the ceiling of EUR 50 million of commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances to be mobilised within the framework of the general budget of the European Union set for the financial year 2016. I voted in favour of this proposal as it could speed up the EU's response in the event of major natural disasters.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Through the positive support of this proposal I believe that the possibility of the Solidarity Fund in terms of speed, flexibility, efficiency and service of the objective is significantly improved so that the EU is close to citizens and society. The Main Mission of the Solidarity Fund is to mobilise in emergency situations when natural disasters occur in EU member countries. The political message is strong and clear. It is a message of solidarity that is actually being implemented by providing the necessary assistance to the citizens of the EU member countries at difficult and critical times when their immediate financial support is needed. These initiatives, on behalf of the Commission and the European Parliament, are upgrading the Union's social policy, creating a real sense of EU solidarity with European citizens and giving the mark of a better Europe. A Europe that directly and effectively supports citizens when they need financial support and support.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund is a positive step towards streamlining cooperation between Member States, but also for the sound management of the Union's financial data.  Trying to improve existing structures, particularly in an area of emergency response, must be a priority for all of us. The expression of solidarity is one of the essential elements of European construction and the proper, rapid and trouble-free operation of the Solidarity Fund is essential.  In view of the considerable assistance that Member States can receive in exceptional cases to deal with natural disasters, as well as the delays that usually occur until the final adoption of the request for assistance, I voted in favour of this proposal, which provides for the mobilisation of EUR 50 000 000 for the payment of advances at the request of the affected Member State.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. The report concerns the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to demonstrate solidarity with the regions affected by these events, through financial support to member states and countries engaged in accession negotiations.  The current proposal is not linked to a specific case of natural disaster; rather, it aims to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year. This is in order to speed up the delivery of aid to the countries affected, by paying an advance before the final decision is taken, thereby improving the effectiveness of the Fund. The EP recalls that the EU Solidarity Fund is not only another form of EU financial support, but also helps to send a clear political message of solidarity.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it makes the Fund more effective by anticipating payments before the final concession decision is taken. I agree with the rapporteur that the EU Solidarity Fund is not just another form of EU support, but also helps to send a clear political message of solidarity, a point on which I believe the EU must commit itself with every instrument it deserves. The European Union will only be able to achieve these objectives by means of a timely response capacity, which will then be able to take the form of an advance. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to ensure rapid, effective and flexible aid to the population of a Member State, as well as to countries negotiating their membership in the event of a major natural disaster. It aims to include in the General Budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in payment and authorization appropriations for the payment of advances in an efficient and timely manner in the event of a disaster next year. This is the direct result of a new provision in the 2014 amending Regulation, strongly advocated by the European Parliament, which aims to speed up the disbursement of aid to the affected countries by paying an advance before taking the final decision on granting aid, enhancing the effectiveness of the fund. I support this report, as the EUSF, in addition to providing assistance to affected citizens, also contributes to sending a clear political message of solidarity. Rapid response capability, including advance payment, will help the Union achieve these objectives.

As Europeans we need to express solidarity with one another in moments of need. That is why I supported this report with my vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to speed up the payment of aid to affected countries under the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF), by granting an advance before the final allocation decision is taken. The text envisages the eu's general budget for 2016 being included in the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations.  The EUSF aims to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by large-scale natural disasters, by providing a maximum of EUR 500 million to the affected European regions. The advance can only be made after a preliminary assessment by the Commission of the EUSF request, it may not exceed 10% of the expected financial contribution and cannot be more than EUR 30 million.  Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal provides EUR 50 million in 2016 for the payment of advances, ensuring that funding can be made available to natural or regional disasters as quickly as possible. In order to be eligible for financial assistance under the EUSF, Member States must have experienced non-insurable damage totalling 0.6% of GNI. Regions at NUTS level 2 of an eligible state must have experienced non-insurable damage totalling 1.5% of that region’s GDP. The ECR Group recently voted in favour of financial assistance under the EUSF for instances of severe winter conditions in Bulgaria and flooding in Greece at the beginning of 2015.  I can vote in favour of this report, given its largely technical nature, and previous support for the principles and objectives of the EUSF. No amendments were made by any political group at committee stage.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a Decision of Parliament and the Council on the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11. An interinstitutional agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary matters and on good financial management, in order to pay advances for the 2016 budget, as this allows for much more efficient and faster action in the event of emergencies caused by natural disasters.
