Over the past years, we have witnessed natural disasters that have not been followed by appropriate and effective measures in the short term. Entering €50 million in the 2016 budget to enable prepayment can certainly contribute to mitigating such situations and provides concrete support to affected countries. Such a thing also contributes to reaching a greater level of solidarity and credibility of the European Union.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable Member States to receive financial support when faced with an emergency caused by large-scale or regional natural disasters. The proposal envisages a 2016 budget of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations with the aim of paying the amount set to the applicant states in advance, thereby accelerating the efficiency and speed of the action.  I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this disaster fund for Europe because it has been allocated EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations. The maximum ceiling for this fund is EUR 500 million per annum; we oppose commitment appropriations, as they only increase the budget. The money that the Member State claims has already been paid by the membership fees that they pay to the EU; it is clearly a case of getting your own money back.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Lefteris Christoforou's report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances in the 2016 budget. The aim of this text is to mobilise EUR 50 million to give advances to Member States in the event of a disaster in 2016 and thus better help the victims. This will allow a rapid and effective disbursement of the European Union Solidarity Fund. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to include in the general budget of the Union for the year 2016 the amount of 50 million euros in commitment appropriations. This will speed up the payment of aid to affected countries by granting an advance before the final allocation decision is taken, in order to strengthen the effectiveness of the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report is a proposal for the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to make advance payments available in the 2016 budget. In principle, there is no objection to the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, since it was set up to mitigate the consequences of natural disasters. Now, however, EUR 50 million from this fund is to be invested in the EU's general budget for 2016 and reserved for disasters there. This creates the problem that a possible reallocation of these funds will be facilitated in the future, which will no longer ensure that earmarking is guaranteed. For these reasons, I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this provision, as it ensures the timely availability of budgetary resources and allows for a faster disbursement of assistance to affected countries.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) was set up to enable the European Union to respond promptly to major natural disasters and to express solidarity with the disaster-affected regions of Europe.  The Regulation on the MFF 2014-2020 allows the fund to be used up to an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million (at 2011 prices), in addition to the ceilings of the relevant chapters of the financial framework. The proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. It aims to allocate EUR 50 million in the Union budget for 2016 in the form of commitment and payment appropriations in the event of a disaster that may occur next year, with a result of timely and efficient payment of advances. The European Parliament has therefore agreed to add the proposed amounts to the 2016 budget.  As the proposal "using the EU Solidarity Fund for advance payments for the 2016 budget" is part of the package of agreements drawn up by the negotiating bodies of the European Parliament and the Council for the adoption of the EU budget for 2016, we supported the report in line with Hungarian interests and the position of the PP group.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: In writing. The report reiterates that Parliament's proposal for a decision is not linked to a specific disaster. It aims to mobilise the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances, in the event of a disaster, for the sum of EUR 50,000,000 in commitment and payment credits. The mobilization is done at the request of the country concerned and after preliminary assessment by the Commission. It is important to note that this is not only a rapid financial response, but also a political sign of solidarity with people affected by "major natural disasters" or regional ones. For this reason, I voted for it.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Natural disasters have increased, largely due to forced, ill-considered and unsustainable progress. It is of the utmost importance that the countries that suffer them receive aid as soon as possible, and therefore only the report on the creation of a general and rapid use of the European Social Fund can be supported. Moreover, this is a clever technical solution that does not require extra cover, but greatly expedites the payment.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament and the Council provides for the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations and to demonstrate solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions.  I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Lefteris Christoforou's report as it provides for an allocation of EUR 50 million for 2016 for the management of emergency situations in the first part of next year.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable Member States to receive financial support when faced with an emergency caused by large-scale natural disasters or regional disasters.  The proposal envisages a 50 million euro commitment and payment appropriations in the 2016 budget to pay requesting Member States in advance in the event of natural disasters, thereby speeding up the efficiency and speed of payments. This provision ensures the timely availability of budgetary resources and allows for a rapid disbursement of aid to affected countries through the payment of an advance before the final allocation decision has been made. The advance is paid without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilization of the Funds, and the unduly paid advances are recovered from the Member States.  Since this is a measure to speed up the process of granting emergency assistance, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary for the European Union Solidarity Fund to have the necessary resources in each exercise to be able to respond as quickly as possible to the catastrophes that occurred in any Member State of the European Union. The situations of natural disasters taking place in Europe need a rapid response and this proposal establishes the provision of funds in order to be able to react as quickly as possible and to be able to alleviate the effects on the citizens of the affected regions. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I prefer voluntary solidarity between states and citizens with each other when an event occurs that requires foreign assistance.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Solidarity Fund was created to assist Member States in response to emergencies caused by major natural disasters. The Fund can provide financial assistance to Member States and countries involved in accession negotiations in the event of 'major natural disasters'.  I supported MEP Christoforou's report concerning the activation of the EUSF within the general budget of the European Union. The EUSF contributes to sending a clear political message of solidarity and provides much-needed assistance to citizens.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. – What has been warned is also prepared. Consequently, the adoption of this draft parliamentary resolution was quite logical, since it would be possible to increase the effectiveness of the European Union Solidarity Fund in the event that, under The Goody God, there is a natural disaster in the territory of the EU Member States or candidate countries, which would require the contribution of EUSF resources. While EUR 50 million (in fact not more than 10 % of the total amount requested and a maximum of EUR 30 million) may not amount too much to the extent of the damage caused by natural disasters, this money could undeniably cover at least part of the most urgent costs in the event of a crisis, before the rest of the aid reaches its beneficiary. The European Union Solidarity Fund has been in operation for 13 years and has helped during this time to overcome the effects of not only a natural disaster in different parts of Europe. And while, of course, I would not be very reluctant to have its resources ever needed in principle, I am quite pleased that such an instrument exists and continues to bring its contribution to the cohesion and cooperation of the Member States of the European Union, both in peaceful and appalling circumstances.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed Decision allocates EUR 50 million to the EU Solidarity Fund for 2016 to pay advances so that emergency assistance in disaster areas can be flexibly and effectively provided to the population. Aid shall be effective if it is provided in a timely manner. I therefore appreciate the possibility of paying advances.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management in order to provide for advances in the 2016 budget , because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this mobilization. This EU Solidarity Fund provides assistance to Member States in the event of large-scale natural disasters or regional disasters by providing financial support. This proposal suggests that the 2016 budget should include EUR 50 million to pay the applicant Member States in advance in the event of a disaster, thereby speeding up the efficiency and speed of payments.  As this is a measure to expedite the process of granting funds in an emergency, it is best to vote for it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The current proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a specific disaster. Instead, it aims at entering into the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances in a timely and efficient way in the event of a disaster occurring next year.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances in the 2016 budget. The European Union Solidarity Fund enables Europe to respond quickly to the emergency situations of the population in disaster-affected regions by providing the necessary assistance to the affected areas.  The aim of this proposal is to include in the general budget of the European Union for 2016 the total amount of EUR 501 million through commitment and payment appropriations in the event of disasters occurting next year.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to cope as quickly and efficiently as possible with emergency situations in a spirit of solidarity with the populations of disaster-affected regions. Article 4a(4) of Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 provides that the Fund may be mobilised up to a maximum of EUR 50 000 000 for the payment of advances, which was the case, in the present case, for the year 2016.  The current proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council, which I support by voting in favour, is not linked to a specific case, but rather aims to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 a certain amount in commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The rapporteur's proposal would facilitate the reallocation of funds for purposes other than the fund' plans. I do not want the Fund to be misused in this way.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report authorises the release of EUR 50 million from the EU Solidarity Fund, in the form of advances made on the 2016 budget. This Solidarity Fund is intended to help people or regions affected by disasters. Moreover, it is necessary to resort to such advances because the current year's appropriations are exhausted due to structurally insufficient budgets.  By resorting to such advances, it is foreseeable that the 2016 budget, still under the sign of austerity, will also be exhausted well before the end of next year. And so continues the EU's budgetary collapse now illustrated by all the votes on this subject. In order not to deprive the victims of disasters of such advances, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable Member States to receive financial support when faced with an emergency caused by large-scale or regional natural disasters. The proposal envisages a 2016 budget of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations with the aim of paying the amount set to the applicant states in advance, thereby accelerating the efficiency and speed of the action. Since this is a measure to speed up the process of granting emergency assistance, I am voting in for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund is not linked to a particular disaster. It aims to allow the inclusion in the general budget of the European Union for 2016 of an amount of EUR 50 million in payment and authorisation appropriations for the payment of advances in a timely manner in the event of a disaster next year. This is a preventive measure entered at budget level. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it proposes to make finance available so that the Union will be able to adequately handle the various unforeseen challenges that may arise next year.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund is, as its name suggests, not only a technical tool but an act of solidarity with the affected regions of the Member States and developing countries. It is a strong political signal that makes me say that Europe is much more than an international organisation with distant institutions, it is a project to live together.  Our world reflects the interdependence of all in a necessary solidarity. Our main challenge in a globalized world is that of unity, of humanity, that is, of being able to live in solidarity with all peoples. I am pleased that the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council mobilises a maximum annual ceiling of EUR 500 million for the period 2014-2020 and that the Fund can be mobilised up to EUR 50 million in payment and commitment appropriations for the rapid and effective payment of disaster advances the following year.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund has been set up to ensure the payment of advances in emergencies caused by natural disasters. It results from the expression of European solidarity and assistance to the damaged countries participating in the accession negotiations in the event of major disasters. The proposal aims to include a reserve amount in the Union budget for 2016, which will be available to pay an advance in the event of a disaster before a decision is taken to grant an advance. Parliament has made a significant part in enforcing the new provision. I see the proposal positively to improve and increase the efficiency and mobilisation of the Fund.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in agreement with the report on Mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide for payment of advances in the 2016 budget. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the Union to respond in a rapid, efficient and flexible manner to emergency situations and to show solidarity with the population of regions struck by disasters. That is why I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) was set up to enable the European Union to respond to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with europe's disaster-stricken regions. The Multiannual Financial Framework Regulation 2014-2020 allows the fund to be used up to a top of EUR 500 million per year. According to a provision of Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 amending the conditions for the use of the Fund, the disbursement of aid to the countries concerned can be accelerated by means of an advance payment before the final award decision, amounting to a maximum of 10% of the expected financial contribution.  The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council to allocate EUR 50 million in the form of commitment and payment appropriations in the Union budget for 2016 in order to pay advances in a timely and efficient manner in the event of a disaster next year. In its report, the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament recommends that Parliament approve the proposal for a decision. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up with the aim of putting the European Union up to the level of emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to be able to show European solidarity with europe's affected regions. I support the current proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council, stressing that it is not linked to a specific disaster. This proposal aims to devote in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in payment and authorisation appropriations for the payment of advances in an efficient and timely manner in the event of a disaster next year. I believe that this measure is necessary, as it accelerates the disbursement of aid to the affected countries by paying an advance before the final decision on the allocation of aid is taken, thereby enhancing the effectiveness of the EUSF.  I endorse the rapporteur's position by recalling that the EUSF is not only another form of EU financial support, but it is also the transmission of a clear political message of solidarity, which provides the necessary assistance to affected citizens.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The proposal envisages a 2016 budget of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment credits in order to pay requesting Member States in advance in the event of natural disasters, thereby speeding up the efficiency and speed of payments under the EU Solidarity Fund.  This provision, newly introduced by the 2014 Amendment Regulation (Article 4 bis), ensures the timely availability of budgetary resources and allows for a rapid disbursement of aid to affected countries through the payment of an advance (up to 10% or 30 million euros) before the final allocation decision is taken. The advance is paid without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilization of the Funds, and the unduly paid advances are recovered from the Member States.  The Christoforou report recommends that the amounts proposed by the Commission be included in the 2016 budget.  As this is a measure to speed up the process of granting emergency assistance (natural disasters, etc.), I have decided to vote for this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in the context of the 2016 budget. This text endorses the Committee's proposal to mobilise this fund for a total of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment credits to ensure the rapid and efficient disbursement of advances to Member States suffering from disasters in 2016.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity to disaster-stricken regions within Europe. I have voted for this report that aims at entering into the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances in a timely and efficient way in the event of a disaster occurring next year.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the provision of advance payments in the 2016 budget calls for the Solidarity Fund to be used to provide EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances. I voted against this report because I do not consider the use of the Solidarity Fund to be appropriate here.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which allows the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for the 2016 financial year. The EUSF is designed to help a Member State suffering from a major natural disaster, national or regional. The aim here is to anticipate the allocation of 50 million for 2016, so that this envelope is immediately available for a quick and effective payment in the event of a proven disaster, thus allowing the costs to be advanced before the final allocation decision.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The most important response rate is the response rate for disasters and major natural disasters. The EU Solidarity Fund will be transferred to the EU Solidarity Fund with the aim of speeding up the provision of assistance in a situation where it is very urgently needed.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this disaster fund for Europe because it has been allocated EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations. The maximum ceiling for this fund is EUR 500 million per annum; we oppose commitment appropriations, as they only increase the budget. The money that the Member State claims has already been paid by the membership fees that they pay to the EU; it is clearly a case of getting your own money back.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and reiterate the ideas expressed earlier about the need for greater flexibility for the mobilisation of European funds, given the current crisis and emergency situations. I wholeheartedly support the allocation of further economic aid to the EU Solidarity Fund and I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Croatia was hit by severe natural disasters in 2014, from the ice storm and winter to the flood that followed heavy rainfall in May. The European Solidarity Fund has helped financially repair the damage caused. Although the state authorities carried out the necessary actions and repairs, only the time of remediation of damages with the repair of family houses and outbuildings took relatively long, preventing the continuation of the normal life of the large population of the affected area for about a year. Where a severe natural disaster occurs such as a flood or earthquake affecting a large number of people, swift, sufficient and well-targeted assistance to the affected area is of great importance for the trust of those affected in the institutions of the State and the Union. Rapid intervention prevents undesirable consequences such as illnesses, accidents, environmental pollution and job losses, but also facilitates the recovery of the affected area to stop being a recipient of aid as soon as possible and continue its economic and every other life form of its citizens. This is why I supported the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund to pay advances in the 2016 budget. In this way, the European Union shows concern and solidarity for its citizens, allowing for timely financial interventions when assistance is most needed.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The proposal envisages a 50 million euro commitment and payment appropriations in the 2016 budget to pay requesting Member States in advance in the event of natural disasters, thereby speeding up the efficiency and speed of payments from the EU Solidarity Fund.  This provision, newly introduced by the 2014 Amendment Regulation (Article 4 bis), ensures the timely availability of budgetary resources and allows for a rapid disbursement of aid to affected countries through the payment of an advance (up to 10% or 30 million euros) before the final allocation decision is taken. The advance is paid without prejudice to the final decision on the mobilization of the Funds, and the unduly paid advances are recovered from the Member States.  The Christoforou report recommends that the amounts proposed by the Commission be included in the 2016 budget.  As this is a measure to speed up the process of granting emergency assistance (natural disasters, etc.), I have decided to vote for this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal to ensure advance payments and commitments made in the 2016 budget as part of the activation of the EU Solidarity Fund in the amount of €50,000 000. Given that it is a fund whose fundamental function is to respond to natural disasters that my country has also used multiple times, timely assistance is important, if not the most important, element of assisting affected countries.  In this regard, I agree with the rapporteur that strengthening the capacity to respond quickly and pay an advance is a clear political message of solidarity. Croatia faced the complexity of the application procedure and the approval of aid funds in case of severe floods that hit Southeast Europe, so from the perspective of closeness to the citizens who needed this form of assistance, I support this proposal.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the EU to respond to emergency situations caused by major natural disasters and to demonstrate solidarity with the regions affected by these events.  Following a new provision of the 2014 Regulation (Article 4a), strongly desired by the European Parliament, it will be possible to enter in the General Budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the timely payment of advances, should disasters occur.  I believe that the EUSF is one of the best, concrete examples of the spirit of solidarity that should always be at the basis of the integration process. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for the Christoforou report on the mobilization of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances in the 2016 budget. An amount of EUR 50,000,000 is made available for the payment of advances through appropriations in the GENERAL BUDGET of the Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour because I believe that it is important to mobilise the EU Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this disaster fund for Europe because it has been allocated EUR 50 million in commitment appropriations. The maximum ceiling for this fund is EUR 500 million per annum; we oppose commitment appropriations, as they only increase the budget. The money that the Member State claims has already been paid by the membership fees that they pay to the EU; it is clearly a case of getting your own money back.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This EP proposal is not linked to any specific disaster. It aims to set out in the 2016 general budget the amount of EUR 50 million for advances in the event of a disaster, increasing aid efficiency and speed.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by serious natural disasters and to express European solidarity to disaster-affected regions. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating their accession in the event of a serious natural disaster, i.e. where direct total damage exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's gross national income. It can also be mobilized in the event of a regional catastrophe. The proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a specific catastrophe, but seeks to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances in the event of a disaster next year and thus ensure the availability of budgetary resources by improving the effectiveness of the Fund. That's why I voted for it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) aims to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by large-scale natural disasters and to express Europe's solidarity with the affected European regions. The Fund thus has the capacity to provide financial assistance to Member States and accession countries in the event of a "major natural disaster", i.e. if the total amount of direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's gross national income. It can also be mobilized in the event of a regional disaster. The conditions for the mobilization of the EUSF are set out in the corresponding basic act (regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 of the Council), amended in 2014 (REGULATION (EU) no 661/2014). The present proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council, which I voted on today, is not linked to any particular catastrophe. Rather, it aims to include in the general budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of 50 million euros in commitment and payment credits for the quick and effective payment of advances in the event of a disaster next year.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution aims to include, in the general budget of the Union for 2016, the amount of EUR 50 million in appropriations for authorisation and payment to meet the payment of advances, in balanced and effective terms, in the event of a disaster next year, mobilising, to this end, the European Union Solidarity Fund, which was created precisely to respond to emergency situations. This is a guarantee measure that is legally welcomed by the amendment to Article 4a of Regulation (EU) No 661/2014. To that extent, I deserve my vote in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report, which reiterates how flexible the European Union's budget must be to deal with crises and their consequences. I voted in favour of this text which approves the decision to mobilise 50 million euros in advance of the 2016 budget for the Union Solidarity Fund. This fund allows the EU to financially support a Member State or region in the event of a major natural disaster. It is important to continue to promote a united and united Europe.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances in the 2016 budget, as the Solidarity Fund makes it possible to deal with emergency situations caused by serious natural disasters.  Bearing in mind that Italy has also often used these funds to deal with floods or fires, I agree with supporting the mobilisation of a sum of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations, which will be used by the European Union to help states affected by emergency situations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. It enables 50 million euros for any catastrophes that may occur. The issue is perverse, because this money has been enabled, which would be necessary for the refugee crisis, in order to prevent futuribles when a current and urgent challenge is happening. In the discussion on the budget he was a workhorse, and it is an imposition of the Council, which wanted to avoid spending funds for the refugee crisis. Voting against it also cannot be done because it enables a fund that may be required for important issues in the future. I voted in favour, as long as I understand that the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund is necessary, but I understand, at the same time, that a critical review of how these mobilisations are carried out is necessary.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary for the European Union Solidarity Fund to have the necessary resources in each exercise to be able to respond as quickly as possible to the catastrophes that occurred in any Member State of the European Union. The situations of natural disasters taking place in Europe need a rapid response and this proposal establishes the provision of funds in order to be able to react as quickly as possible and to be able to alleviate the effects on the citizens of the affected regions. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was created to respond to major natural disasters and express European solidarity with the affected regions within Europe. The Fund was set up following the severe floods that devastated Central Europe in the summer of 2002. Since then it has been used 70 times in response to different types of environmental disasters, including floods, forest fires, earthquakes, storms and droughts.  The proposal for a decision that I supported today is not linked to a specific case of natural disaster, but aims to include in the EU general budget for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, as the UK does not qualify for this type of payment. The UK Government should decide on what foreign aid it should send.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this budgetary procedure because it will ensure the timely availability of budgetary resources and allow for a faster disbursal of assistance to countries which have been affected by disaster. The European Union Solidarity Fund aims to enable the EU to respond rapidly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations, and I totally embrace the solidarity that this fund presents with those struck by unfortunate circumstances.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund was set up to allow the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters, while at the same time showing its solidarity with disaster areas in Europe. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that this fund should be increased by an additional EUR 50 million for 2016, so that any advance payments can be made. I was therefore in favour of this resolution.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Solidarity Fund responds to and expresses solidarity with disaster-hit states, regions and areas in Europe. A Member State may apply for assistance if the direct damage caused by the disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion or 0.6% of the country's GDP, which is lower. In view of the fact that the process between the application and the approval of the aid is lengthy and the affected regions need immediate assistance in the form of an advance, but not exceeding 10 % of the envisaged contribution from the Solidarity Fund. Providing an advance can provide the necessary assistance to the affected citizens immediately, but it is also a clear signal of EU solidarity towards the affected regions. For this reason, the European Union Solidarity Fund is mobilised under the EU general budget for the financial year 2016 to provide €50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances on natural disasters.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to enable the Union to respond quickly and effectively to emergencies and to show its solidarity with the population of disaster-affected areas. The MFF Regulation for the period 2014-2020 allows the fund to use up to an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million. This proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council is not linked to a particular disaster, but is about ensuring that advances from the general budget of the European Union for 2016 of EUR 50 million are paid so that the EU can respond to potential disasters in a timely and flexible manner in the coming year. The effectiveness of the Fund must be improved and the payments of aid to affected countries in the form of advances must be accelerated before the final approval of the Solidarity Fund, which is why I voted in favour of the vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I share the expressions of European solidarity translated into the EU Solidarity Fund towards areas affected by natural disasters or other serious crises, and I therefore strongly agree with the need for a rapid response on the part of the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this report, as the European Union Solidarity Fund enables an emergency response quickly, flexibly and effectively and shows solidarity towards populations from regions affected by disasters. The fund's funds must not exceed the maximum amount of 500m euros, as set out in Article 10 of the EEA. Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2013/2013 1311 /20133. Furthermore, Article 4a of paragraph 4. Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 2012/2002 the amount of EUR 50 million is projected to be made available for the disbursement of advances through appropriations in the General Budget of the Union. I therefore supported the proposal to activate the €50 million amount for the payment of advances.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This proposal aims to help Member States receive faster financial support due to a natural disaster than is possible through the ordinary procedure. To that end, it is appropriate to allow the payment of an advance at the request of the affected Member State shortly after the application to the Commission for a financial contribution from the Fund.  A Member State may request payment of an advance payment. If the conditions are met and sufficient budgetary resources are available, the Commission may, through an implementing act, take a decision on the award of the advance and pay it out without delay. The advance amount shall not exceed 10 % of the expected amount of the financial contribution and shall in no event exceed EUR 30 000 000. When the final amount of the financial contribution is determined, the Commission shall take into account the amount of the advance before the payment of the remaining amount of the financial contribution. The Commission shall ensure the recovery of unduly paid advances. I support this Council proposal because I think this proposal will send a clear message of solidarity and provide the necessary assistance to the affected citizens. The payment of advance payments is one way in which the Union can help.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it is mainly a measure of a technical nature to facilitate the provision of funds for victims of natural disasters.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to pay advances in the 2016 budget. I support the reallocation of €50 million from the Solidarity Fund, which is otherwise intended to provide financial assistance to countries affected by natural disasters to the general budget of the European Union for 2016 for commitment appropriations and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances in the event of an accident that would happen next year. Solidarity is one of the foundations on which the European Union has been built, and I therefore support strengthening the effectiveness of the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) was set up to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with disaster-affected areas in Europe. The EU must be flexible when there are grounds for compensating Member States affected by natural disasters.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) was set up to enable the European Union to respond promptly to major natural disasters and to express solidarity with europe's disaster-affected regions. The Regulation on the MFF 2014-2020 allows the fund to be used up to an annual ceiling of EUR 500 million (at 2011 prices), in addition to the ceilings of the relevant chapters of the financial framework. The proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. It aims to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the Eu budget for 2016 in order to pay advances on time and efficiently in the event of a disaster next year. The European Parliament has therefore agreed to add the proposed amounts to the 2016 budget.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Christoforou's text on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in line with point 11 of the 2 December 2013 inter-institutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management. , for the payment of advances as part of the 2016 budget.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ In this report, the European Parliament endorsed forward planning and readiness to act quickly when natural disasters strike. The current Commission proposal is not linked to a specific disaster. Instead, it aims at entering into the EU general budget for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances in case that a disaster occurs next year. I voted in favour of it, because it will help to speed up the disbursement of aid to affected countries through the payment of an advance before the final award decision has been taken and will thus enhance the effectiveness of the European Union Solidarity Fund.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund mobilising €50 million in the draft general budget for the disbursement of advances for 2016.  In 2002, the European Union Solidarity Fund was established to provide financial assistance to countries affected by a major natural disaster or regional emergency disaster. In my view, it is of utmost importance to ensure that this support is available very quickly in the event of a disaster, which will be achieved through this mobilisation, although the amounts of these advances are limited to 10 % of the expected financial assistance (or no more than EUR 30 million).  I believe that by being ready for an immediate response, we are sending a clear political message of solidarity and much-needed assistance to the affected citizens.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management for the payment of advances in the 2016 budget, as the aim of the European Union Solidarity Fund is to move quickly , respond effectively and flexibly to emergencies and demonstrate its solidarity with the population in the areas affected by the disaster. As I believe that we must also have a rapid response strategy by paying an advance to help the Union achieve these objectives, I support the introduction into the general budget of the Union for 2016 of an amount of EUR 50 million for commitment and payment appropriations for the timely and efficient payment of advances in the event of accidents.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. It enables 50 million euros for any catastrophes that may occur. The issue is perverse, because this money has been enabled, which would be necessary for the refugee crisis, in order to prevent futuribles when a current and urgent challenge is happening. In the discussion on the budget he was a workhorse, and it is an imposition of the Council, which wanted to avoid spending funds for the refugee crisis. Voting against it also cannot be done because it enables a fund that may be required for important issues in the future. I voted in favour, as long as I understand that the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund is necessary, but I understand, at the same time, that a critical review of how these mobilisations are carried out is necessary.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The EU Solidarity Fund aims to enable Member States to receive financial support when faced with an emergency caused by large-scale natural disasters or regional disasters.  The proposal envisages a 50 million euro commitment and payment appropriations in the 2016 budget to pay requesting Member States in advance in the event of natural disasters, thereby speeding up the efficiency and speed of payments.  Since this is a measure to speed up the process of granting emergency assistance (natural disasters, etc.), I am voting in support.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSA) was set up to enable the European Union to respond to major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with europe's disaster-stricken regions. The Fund shall provide financial assistance to Member States and accession negotiating countries in the event of 'major natural disasters'. The proposal for a current decision by the European Parliament and the Council was not made in the context of a specific disaster. Instead, it aims to allocate EUR 50 million in commitment and payment appropriations in the EU budget for 2016 in order to pay advances on time and efficiently in the event of a disaster next year. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund. It enables 50 million euros for any catastrophes that may occur. The issue is perverse, because this money has been enabled, which would be necessary for the refugee crisis, in order to prevent futuribles when a current and urgent challenge is happening. In the discussion on the budget he was a workhorse, and it is an imposition of the Council, which wanted to avoid spending funds for the refugee crisis. Voting against it also cannot be done because it enables a fund that may be required for important issues in the future. I voted in favour, as long as I understand that the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund is necessary, but I understand, at the same time, that a critical review of how these mobilisations are carried out is necessary.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The objective of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) is to enable the Union to respond to emergencies caused by major natural disasters and to express European solidarity with disaster-stricken regions in Europe. The Fund may provide financial assistance to Member States and countries negotiating membership of the Union in the event of a major natural disaster, i.e. where the total direct damage caused by this disaster exceeds EUR 3 billion. In 2011, or 0.6% of the country's gross national income, whichever is the lower. Its funds may also be mobilised in the event of a regional disaster.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in accordance with point 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management to provide for payment of advances in the 2016 budget. For the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the European Union Solidarity Fund shall be mobilised to provide the sum of EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances, where this Decision shall enter into force on the day of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This action mobilisations a sum of EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances for the financial year 2016. This aims to enable the European Union to respond to emergencies caused by serious natural disasters and themselves to express European solidarity with disaster-affected regions in Europe. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary for the European Union Solidarity Fund to have the necessary resources in each exercise to be able to respond as quickly as possible to the catastrophes that occurred in any Member State of the European Union. The situations of natural disasters taking place in Europe need a rapid response and this proposal establishes the provision of funds in order to be able to react as quickly as possible and to be able to alleviate the effects on the citizens of the affected regions. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this proposal because it will strengthen the effectiveness of the European Solidarity Fund. I am convinced that this measure will speed up the payment of the aid by paying an advance before a final decision has been taken.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We are talking about the inclusion of EUR 50 000 000 in the 2016 budget in payment provisions and commitments for mobilising the European Union Solidarity Fund. It is a question of implementing the direct result of the new provision adopted in 2014 when amending Regulation (EU) No 661/2014, in Article 4a—A. This proposal is not linked to any specific disaster, it will only serve for the EU Solidarity Fund to be mobilised in advance before the formal and final decision to mobilise and allocate aid, so that a potential catastrophic event occurring during 2016 is responded in time and more effectively.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The rapporteur's proposal would facilitate the reallocation of funds for purposes other than the fund' plans. I do not want the Fund to be misused in this way.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am convinced that the Solidarity Fund is a fundamental instrument for reacting and responding to natural disasters affecting European territory. The proposal presented aims to include in the General Budget of the Union for 2016 the amount of EUR 50 million in funds intended for the timely and efficient payment of advances, should disasters occur next year. This is a very important position on which Parliament has fought hard and firmly.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund to make advance payments available in the 2016 budget. There are a number of things in the EU that I agree with as an original supranational task, because they cannot be solved just as well at local, regional or national level. This includes cross-border cooperation and mutual financial assistance in the event of accidents. Here, European cooperation brings added value, which I would like to support through my vote.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council regarding Mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to provide for payment of advances in the 2016 budget. I support this newly-introduced provision, as it ensures the timely availability of budgetary resources and allows for speedier disbursement of assistance to affected countries through the payment of an advance before the final award decision has been taken, thus enhancing the Fund’s effectiveness.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU Solidarity Fund serves to financially assist Member States in the event of large-scale natural disasters. Slovakia has in the past used assistance from this fund to deal with the consequences of the wind whirlwind in the High Tatras and in the floods that have affected the whole of Central Europe. The resolution adopted does not concern a specific event that would require European solidarity, but it is about increasing the effectiveness of future aid by making part of the funds possible in the form of an advance before a proper decision is taken to activate the Fund. This will make it possible to respond more quickly to the needs of the disaster-stricken Member State and will make aid more effective.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for Mr Christoforou's report, which strengthens the spirit of solidarity in the Union, while improving the mechanism for providing assistance to EU citizens immediately and quickly.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, in accordance with paragraph 11 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management in order to finance the payment of advances under the 2016 budget. I have done so because I believe that the main purpose of the Solidarity Fund is to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergencies and to stand in solidarity with the people of the regions affected by disasters. It is essential that the EU responds quickly and effectively to those Europeans affected by a catastrophe. This instrument serves as a political message to Europeans, sometimes detached from the 'Brussels' decisions. This is a political message of solidarity as it provides much-needed assistance to citizens while providing a quick response thanks to the advance system.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union Solidarity Fund should enable the Union to respond quickly, efficiently and flexibly to emergency situations and to show solidarity with the people of disaster-affected regions. A ceiling of EUR 500 million is set for this Fund. Article 4a of the Regulation (EC) establishing it provides for the possibility of mobilising the Fund up to a maximum amount of EUR 50 000 000 for the payment of advances and the entry of the corresponding appropriations in the general budget of the Union.  That is why this report called for a sum equal to the ceiling of EUR 50 million of commitment and payment appropriations from the European Union Solidarity Fund for the payment of advances to be mobilised within the framework of the general budget of the European Union set for the financial year 2016.  I support this proposal, which could speed up the EU's response in the event of major natural disasters.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to include in the 2016 budget the advance payment of EUR 50 000 000 in payment appropriations and authorisation appropriations in the context of mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund. It is a question of implementing the direct result of the new provision adopted in 2014 when it was amending Regulation (EU) No 661/2014 in Article 4 thereof. This proposal will only serve to ensure that the EU Solidarity Fund is mobilised in advance, before the formal and final decision to mobilise and allocate aid, so that a potential catastrophic event occurring during 2016 is responded to in time and more effectively. We voted for it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund to pay advances in the 2016 budget, which provides for an amount of EUR 50 000 000 in commitment and payment appropriations for the payment of advances, as I believe that this will enable the Union to respond quickly, effectively and flexibly to emergencies and show solidarity with the population in the areas affected by accidents.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by saying that I congratulate you on how effectively you are leading the meeting, so that the opposite voice may be heard here. And now to the explanation itself. I supported the European Union budget for next year, even though it is increased by EUR 10 billion, and this must also be explained to our constituents and our citizens in the Czech Republic. This is because money is being raised for security and, above all, for migration and security policy. It is clear that at present more money will need to be put into guarding the external border, more money on agencies such as FRONTEX. Without more money, we can hardly ensure the security of the European Union and the fight against international terrorism.  Otherwise, I also welcome the fact that the budget has increased money for certain programmes, which relate in particular to the education of young people. I consider this to be particularly important, such as the Erasmus programme, because, in my opinion, educating young people is one way to show the young generation how the European Union is beneficial to this generation.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I am glad that we have confirmed the 2016 budget and can therefore work properly. That's the one story. Secondly, as a member of the Committee on Agriculture, I would like to deplore a little, because our Committee on Budgets rejected all the proposals of the Committee on Agriculture, not only those that cost money, but also those proposals that do not cost money. That annoyed me a little bit. I would simply ask my colleagues to take a more serious assessment and approve the good proposals of the Committee on Agriculture and Agriculture next time, and then I will also find it a little easier to approve the next budget.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – In support of the adoption of the draft Community budget for 2016, I would like to express specific support for the purpose of regularly verifying the effectiveness of the spending of budgetary resources. For example, according to point 36 of the Annex to the Inter-Institutional Agreement, representatives of the European Parliament, the Council, the Commission will meet at political level for this purpose at least 3 times in 2016. Of course, even at other levels, including in the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets, in the various controlling bodies elsewhere, the Community budget for next year will be examined and analysed more regularly so that its implementation is fully in line with the objective and challenges pursued. Looking at the various spending plans for cohesion policy, I would like to draw attention to the fact that it would be very reluctant for the european Regional Development Fund, the Cohesion Fund or the European Social Fund and other similar spending to be negatively reflected in interregional development. But in general, I voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The euro crisis is one of the main contributors towards SME financial problems and continuous EU regulations that hinder SME progress. Many EU regulations are hindering employers to take on new employees and train them up to keep abreast of regulations. The Horizon 2020 Programme has been allocated EUR 31.8 million; it has already been allocated EUR 150 million. Erasmus is a Europe-wide education programme that allows students to have mobility throughout Europe and has been allocated a further EUR 6.6 million. Security & Citizenship has been allocated EUR 1.5 billion, and a further EUR 150 million will be mobilised to help Turkey to deal with the crisis. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. \u2012 The Christian Democrats are clear that the long-term ambition is to gradually reduce EU spending on agricultural, labour market, regional and industrial policies. Since the European Parliament's position in the run-up to the budget negotiations was characterised by a contrary approach, I voted against this at an earlier stage. On the other hand, I now voted in favour of the agreement between Parliament and the Council because the EU must have a budget in order to function and in view of the fact that all the Member States support the deal.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached by the Conciliation Committee for the 2016 budget because it emphasizes the refugee crisis while continuing to invest in R&D policies. In addition to continuing the Youth Employment Initiative following its evaluation, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the dairy crisis.   I regret that I was unable to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment by Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  Finally, it should be emphasized that this is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting the pressing gravity of current needs. Therefore, while mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument will complement the financing of the general budget of the European Union for the 2016 financial year by exceeding the upper limits of those headings, we will have to continue to work to address the structural problems that the European budget has during the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, despite containing some positive items, it means continuing with the logic of austerity which prevents the increase in the EU budget to deal with all payments. This report approves the outcome of the Conciliation Committee containing some positive measures, such as the maintenance of Horizon 2020, resources for the refugee crisis, measures for dairy farmers, etc. However, the result remains unsolving the payments that the EU will have to make in 2017 to Member States, deferring these problems because of the refusal to increase the resources available to the EU budget. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The 2016 budget was reconciled between the three major EU institutions, the Commission, the Council and the European Parliament. This agreement was presented to Parliament for a vote. Several things to be highlighted in this text: the substantial increase in Erasmus' appropriations; additional funds allocated to farmers in part to offset the consequences of the Russian embargo; Additional funds for "multimedia actions"; Strengthening humanitarian aid; or additional funds for external action and the migration crisis.  The budget provides EUR 2 billion to help Member States facing the migration crisis. This is just the beginning. In the coming years, national taxpayers will be increasingly punctured. Does the Commission not expect to welcome an additional 3 million immigrants in the next three years? Finally, commitments amounted to 155 billion euros (compared to 145.3 in 2015) and payment credits to 143.8 billion (141.2 in 2015), significantly above the 2015 appropriations.  France will have to continue this budget to the tune of 23.65 billion euros, a record. I logically objected.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose the 2016 budget for many reasons, as outlined in Committee. Much money could have been saved in a variety of areas but there was a lack of political will to do it. On the other hand, it pushes the commitment allocations still higher and seems to me to be kicking the can down the road to a future budget. It is not a responsible budget.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached by the Conciliation Committee for the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations.   It emphasizes the refugee crisis while continuing to invest in research and development policies. On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis.   I regret, however, that I was unable to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment by Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  Finally, I would like to stress that this is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting that, in view of the pressing seriousness of current needs, the 2016 deadlines for headings 3 and 4 do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures where it is most needed.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Union budget for the following year.  The commitments in the EU budget for the following year (the maximum value of commitments for future accounts) would amount to EUR 155 billion and payments (actual amounts to cover previous commitments) amount to 143.8 billion euro.  "Negotiations with the Council of the EU have achieved more funding to manage the migrant crisis, promote youth employment and strengthen economic competitiveness." The annual budget of the European Union, which is jointly approved by the Council of the EU and the European Parliament, represents just over 1% of the European Union's gross domestic product. 88% of the annual EU budget is spent in EU Member States, 6% in foreign countries and the remaining 6% is spent on eu institutions.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The euro crisis is one of the main contributors towards SME financial problems and continuous EU regulations that hinder SME progress. Many EU regulations are hindering employers to take on new employees and train them up to keep abreast of regulations. The Horizon 2020 Programme has been allocated EUR 31.8 million; it has already been allocated EUR 150 million. Erasmus is a Europe-wide education programme that allows students to have mobility throughout Europe and has been allocated a further EUR 6.6 million. Security & Citizenship has been allocated EUR 1.5 billion, and a further EUR 150 million will be mobilised to help Turkey to deal with the crisis. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This was a compromise between Parliament and the Council amending the draft 2016 budget on the margins. In total, the appropriations will be higher than in 2015 (155 billion for commitment appropriations compared to 145.3 in 2015 and 143.8 in payment credits against 141.2), this to deal with the migration crisis. The increase in the salaries of EU civil servants is expected to reach 2.4% in 2016, or in real terms, 1.5% increase.  The French contribution to the 2016 EU budget is expected to reach 23.65 billion according to the finance bill. I obviously voted against this gabegie.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I supported this report, which approves the 2016 budget. Compared to the Council's initial proposals, this budget provides for increased funding to deal with the refugee crisis, it strengthens spending in important areas such as research and development as well as support for SMEs. Parliament has thus secured an additional EUR 800 million for the distribution of refugees across the European Union and additional funding to support neighbouring countries. This work will be supported by increased funding from agencies dealing with migration-related issues. Frontex will be able to hire an additional 60 people, while the BEA and Europol will be able to create an additional 30 positions. In addition, we have secured an additional EUR 18 million for financial assistance to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA).  However, it will be necessary to remain vigilant and combative if budgetary levers are to be properly used to boost quality employment and strengthen the fight against poverty.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Written. \u2012 The EU budget for 2016 represents an increase of 1.8% compared to the 2015 budget. That is well above inflation of 0.11%. The large number of people coming to the EU for asylum and migration requires more resources from the Member States and the EU to manage this problem in better ways.  With this in mind, the EU is rightly cutting back on several other policy areas, but it should have been much stronger. This includes the European Parliament's budget, which is increasing by 2.4% compared to this year. The significant increase in the EU budget shows that the EU still wants to do too much, including achieving economic growth and employment, the pre-eminent activities of the Member States.  The crises of recent years should have led to the understanding that Europe can better confine itself to its core tasks: cross-border problems in which the EU must achieve results, such as cooperation with member states for a compassionate and equitable approach to refugees and migrants, as well as an effective approach to the persistent problems surrounding the euro and the too high levels of debt. It is absolutely positive that Commissioner Georgieva really wants to set priorities, but that must lead to a more efficient budget.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs of the 2016 budget report as well as everyone who has worked on it. It's been many hours of negotiation until we got to today's vote. For our part, we have secured the maximum possible funds for migration and refugees, SMEs, students and the Horizon 2020 research programme. From that point of view they are budgets according to the moments we live in.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this joint draft of Parliament and the Council on the 2016 budget, because it is completely irresponsible, even scandalous. Indeed, if I can only approve aid to farmers, I am surprised that it is so paltry - with a package of 500 million and aid of 197 million as a result of the extension of the Russian embargo - in comparison with the money that will be dedicated to the management of the migration crisis, as if welcoming refugees was more important than supporting people already in precarious situations on our territory. : humanitarian aid has been increased by 150 million euros, as well as an additional allocation of 34 million euros to Turkey, despite the diplomatic ambiguities shown by Turkey, particularly in the fight against Islamist terrorism. On the other hand, how can we grant an increase in the salaries of EU staff (up 2.4% in 2016), even though Brussels has been imposing drastic austerity on the peoples of Europe for years, and the staff of the institutions as a whole already have many advantages? Finally, it seems inconsistent to increase the commitment appropriations to 155 billion euros from 145.3 in 2015, and payment credits to 143.8 billion compared to 141.2 in 2015.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's joint draft general budget for the financial year 2016 does not address the problems of structural costs or make cuts in all the waste that would be absolutely necessary at a time of crisis such as the current one.  For all these reasons, I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached for the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations.   It emphasizes the refugee crisis while continuing to invest in research and development policies. On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis.   I regret, however, that I have not been able to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment from Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  It should be emphasized that this is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting that, in view of the seriousness of current needs, budget deadlines do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures where it is most needed. We will therefore have to continue to work to address the structural problems of the European budget during the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with sections of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. With regard to the financing of the YEI, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission recall that reducing youth unemployment remains an important and common political priority and reaffirms its determination to make the most effective use of the available budgetary resources to address this problem, in particular by allocating them to this Youth Employment Initiative. In the mid-term review/review of the Multiannual Financial Perspective (MFF), the Commission will take into account the results of the evaluation of the YEI and, if necessary, submit proposals for the extension of the initiative until 2020.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 EU funds for Hungary were also provided in 2016. Attempts to link the payment of cohesion funds to the implementation of the rules on quotas for the relocation of migrants have been averted. It is an outstanding achievement that eur 2 billion has been allocated to the appropriations for programmes contributing to the management of the migration crisis. The majority of the additional resources, in line with the Hungarian Government's position, are spent in countries that are on the front lines of the crisis and contribute to the management of conflicts that strengthen the immigration wave at the place where they arise. I consider it a success to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund (IPA) previously proposed by the Council, as these instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. In addition to effective financial support, maintaining the level of the Pre-Accession Fund also sends an important political message and encouragement for candidate countries. I also supported the joint project 'Diverse Europe'. In this context, €1 million will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination. On the basis of the above, I supported the report in line with the people's party position.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The representatives of the European Parliament and the Council ask us for our approval of the agreement they have reached in the conciliation committee for the 2016 budget. It is clear that commitment appropriations have increased to 155 billion euros from 145.3 billion euros in 2015, or 6.7%, and payment credits to 143.8 billion euros compared to 141.2 in 2015 or 1.8%; these increases are very significant and do not reflect sufficient management effort.  It should also be noted that this budget allocates EUR 2 billion to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis because they have not been able to stem this submersion and organise the return of these migrants to their countries of origin. This colossal sum is four times larger than that allocated to farmers who are suffering from the policies decided by Brussels. Finally, salaries of institutional staff increased by 2.4% against an estimated inflation of less than 1%. For all these reasons I vote against it.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report is indicative of the mistakes made by the European institutions in the strategic choices they have to make to promote economic growth, employment and the reduction of social inequalities. Firstly, an additional EUR 197 million will be granted to farmers whose incomes have fallen as a result of the Russian embargo stupidly decided by the Commission.  Secondly, an additional EUR 135 million will be increased to strengthen the humanitarian aid budget for illegal migrants even in countries outside the European Union such as Turkey.
