Finally, the salaries of EU staff are expected to increase by 2.4% in 2016 compared to the 1.2% originally planned, which speaks volumes about the willingness of the European institutions to rationalise their spending. Unlike the Member States that are being imposed indigestible austerity measures, the European Union does not have a budgetary diet, resulting in an increase in the contribution of countries to EUR 23.65 billion for France. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The key priorities for the 2016 budget are to provide support for job creation, growth and investment. Thus, by proposing to create the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Commission proposed maximising the use of the European Union budget to meet existing needs. The EU budget aims to legitimise the EU's actions and position it as a stronger global player in the new migration policy. Given the discrepancies between regions, but also between Member States, through allocated funds, the EU shows its solidarity and readiness to bridge existing gaps. I voted in favour of the report on the 2016 Budgetary Procedure: a joint project, taking into account the huge needs that the EU currently has in all sectors, needs that can only be addressed through a well-defined budgetary framework and directed towards specific priorities.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 'no' vote is, first of all, a political vote. In this case, the Deprez and Fernandes report stems both from the special budgetary procedure and from the practice of the inter-institutional agreements in force between the EP, the Council and the EC. The joint text in question contains: the list of budget lines which have not been modified in relation to the Council's position; the amounts for each heading of the financial framework; amounts by budget line; consolidated document with amounts and lines modified during conciliation. The annex to the report is, therefore, a sort of extract from the 2016 budget, as agreed by the three institutions involved in the procedure.  Consequently, just as our delegation's vote was against the draft budget for 2016, we must also confirm the vote against on this occasion. Among the items contained in the agreement reached in the Conciliation Committee we have pilot projects and funding for actions with which we share only a small part.  The 2016 budget also does not address the problem of certain structural costs that are not sufficiently cut and support for costly and unsuccessful policies that our delegation does not support in any way.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached for the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations.   It emphasizes the refugee crisis while continuing to invest in research and development policies. On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis.   I regret, however, that I have not been able to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment from Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  It should be emphasized that this is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting that, in view of the seriousness of current needs, budget deadlines do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures where it is most needed. We will therefore have to continue to work to address the structural problems of the European budget during the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the EU budget for 2016.  It reflects the position of the European Parliament, which has succeeded in making its voice heard at conciliation committee meetings. The priorities of this budget are employment, competitiveness, the management of the refugee crisis and the agricultural crisis. There will be an increase in budgets for youth job search programmes as well as coSME, Horizon 2020 and Erasmus programmes. An additional EUR 500 million will also be mobilised for dairy farmers affected by the Russian embargo. Member States will also be helped to deal with the migration crisis. I am particularly sensitive to the funding of the pilot project on the creation of European coastguards, which I have proposed and which has been taken up by the European Commission. The European Union needs an ambitious budget to meet the many challenges ahead of us in 2016.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Union's joint draft general budget for the financial year 2016, approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure.  The 2016 budget is primarily aimed at identifying the financial means necessary to meet the challenges of the moment, namely to stimulate growth, create jobs and tackle the migration crisis. In this direction, I welcome the commitments for research and development and therefore for Horizon 2020 and for young people. Reducing youth unemployment must remain a priority and resources for the Youth Employment Initiative must be used to the full. However, I believe that more could have been done to support European farmers: EUR 698 million is in fact too few to respond to the extension of the Russian embargo on imports of certain agricultural products from the EU and to the very difficult situation affecting the dairy and pigmeat sectors in particular.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The euro crisis is one of the main contributors towards SME financial problems and continuous EU regulations that hinder SME progress. Many EU regulations are hindering employers to take on new employees and train them up to keep abreast of regulations. The Horizon 2020 Programme has been allocated EUR 31.8 million; it has already been allocated EUR 150 million. Erasmus is a Europe-wide education programme that allows students to have mobility throughout Europe and has been allocated a further EUR 6.6 million. Security & Citizenship has been allocated EUR 1.5 billion, and a further EUR 150 million will be mobilised to help Turkey to deal with the crisis. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million. The COSME programme is designated to aid SME throughout the EU and beyond has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I approve the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the final approval of the agreement on the EU's 2016 budget, as defined by the conciliation concluded in the Council. The final figure is set at 155 billion in commitments and almost 144 billion in payments.  I voted against because I am not satisfied with the final agreement reached and, in my opinion, conciliation has failed on two key issues. , demonstrating a total lack of commitment and credibility. The final outcome says nothing about the dramatic issue of payments, which will recur in the coming years until we reach a certain breaking point.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. We are pleased that a compromise has now been reached with the support of an overwhelming majority both in the Council and in the European Parliament. However, we abstain from voting on the EU budget for 2016. The budget presented will use the budgetary framework in full until 2020. This means that the EU is ill-equipped to deal with unforeseen events in the period up to 2020. We cannot support this. We recognise that extraordinary efforts are needed to help the hundreds of thousands of refugees who come to Europe in these months. That is why we have also voted in favour of moving money to this area within the framework of the existing budget. At the same time, we are adamant that there is no need to inject more funds into the EU budget. We believe that priority must be given to the existing budget , for example by gradually phasing out agricultural aid. Likewise, we reiterate our clear position that no additional funds should be allocated to the remuneration of EU staff. Finally, we continue to stress the need for new, common and clear rules to ensure better control of funds made available to parliamentarians for clerical purposes, support for European political parties and so on.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The budget is rightly focused, on the one hand, on trying to tackle the unprecedented refugee and migration crisis and, on the other hand, on promoting competitiveness and economic growth, creating new jobs as well as supporting and developing small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship throughout the European Union. I believe that in order to achieve these objectives, states and businesses and citizens must be made easier to exploit programmes, absorb funds and make use of the possibilities offered to them by the budget. Citizens and businesses should be facilitated in trying to raise capital and participate in programmes, not be distressed and wiped out by the incredible disastrous European bureaucracy. Through our positive vote in the budget, it is stressed that it is everyone's responsibility for the EU budget for 2016 to succeed. But if it is to succeed, unemployment, especially among young people, must be reduced next year, new small and medium-sized enterprises created, existing ones must be closed down and EU bureaucracy reduced to a minimum.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. Parliament approved the EU budget, with commitment appropriations of EUR 155 billion and payment appropriations of EUR 143.9 billion, as agreed with the Council. As far as the management of refugees is concerned, the sum provided for in the original proposal of EUR 1.6 billion has been approved, in addition to contributions from the Member States of more than EUR 2 billion to finance funds for Africa and Syria. In addition, extra resources were approved for SMEs through the COSME programme (EUR 14.2 million), for the Horizon 2020 programme (EUR 184 million), for infrastructure to connect Europe (EUR 150 million) and for the Erasmus+ programme (EUR 6.6 million).

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report by rapporteurs José Manuel Fernandes and Gerard Deprez on the 2016 EU General Budget Joint Draft, approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure. I believe that this document has been competently prepared, in a clear and comprehensive manner and with analyses and conclusions made on an ad hoc basis. For these reasons, also along the lines of my political group, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement undoes all the cuts that the Council proposed to the Commission’s draft budget, but also reinforces the expenditure commitment by more than EUR 2.8 billion over the Commission’s draft budget. In fact, several programmes that are pivotal to promoting jobs saw their funds rise above the Commission’s proposal, such as the EUR 31.8 million for Horizon 2020 (a research and innovation programme), EUR 14.2 million for COSME (a programme to fund SMEs) and EUR 6.6 million for Erasmus+ (a programme to support youth education).

The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support my colleague José Manuel Fernandes's report on the 2016 Budget and congratulate him on the excellent work produced by meeting all deadlines and taking advantage of all available budget margins. The Rapporteur was consistent with his 3 E policy: Employment, Business and Entrepreneurship. I congratulate him on the tenacity with which he forced the Council to back down from the unjustified cuts he had made in relation to the European Commission's proposal and which were mainly damaging Horizon 2020 under the tutelage of Commissioner Portuguese Carlos Moedas. I congratulate him on his fight to put an end to the late payments scandal and I regret that it has not been possible to close the €11 billion gap between commitments and payments. I congratulate you on the significant increase in double appropriations to deal with the refugee crisis. I congratulate you on the Joint Formal Declaration on the Youth Employment Initiative and I hope that it will be achieved in a continued and broad support for programmes aimed at tackling this scourge, which also reveals an unequal Europe between countries where unemployment is residual and those where a large percentage of citizens fear for their future.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has definitively adopted the EU budget for 2016, providing, following the agreement with the Council, €155 billion in commitment appropriations and €143.9 billion in payment appropriations. For some programmes, such as Horizon 2020, Cosme and Erasmus+, commitment appropriations have been increased, to the benefit of SMEs that make up a large part of Europe's industrial fabric and young people. It is important to stress that Parliament, together with the Council and the Commission, has reiterated that reducing youth unemployment remains an important and shared political priority that must be tackled with determination, making the best use of the financial resources available also through the Youth Employment Initiative. In addition, many other resources will be committed to managing the migration emergency and infrastructure to connect Europe.  Having said that, I felt I had to vote in favour.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I support the compromise reached with the Member States. I particularly welcome the fact that we can use the available resources provided for in the MULTIannual EU financial planning to deal with the refugee and migration crisis. In doing so, we are showing that we, as a Parliament, are successfully using our influence to adapt the budget to the current challenges.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement reached between Parliament and Council on the EU Budget for 2016 foresees more funding for migration, jobs and competitiveness; I thus voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report sees the final approval of the agreement on the EU's 2016 budget. The final figure is set at 155 billion in commitments and almost 144 billion in payments. The issue of immigration (Heading 3) has been identified as the top priority, but we are not satisfied with the final agreement because the EP did not want to listen to the Council's request to identify lines that might not be considered as priorities, while on the other hand the Council continued to postpone the issue of payments, demonstrating a total lack of commitment and credibility. For the reasons specified above, my vote on this issue is against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, despite containing some positive items, it means continuing with the logic of austerity which prevents the increase in the EU budget to deal with all payments. This report approves the outcome of the Conciliation Committee containing some positive measures, such as the maintenance of Horizon 2020, resources for the refugee crisis, measures for dairy farmers, etc. However, the result remains unsolving the payments that the EU will have to make in 2017 to Member States, deferring these problems because of the refusal to increase the resources available to the EU budget. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 With the adoption of the report on the joint draft text of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 has finally been adopted. The budget includes a comprehensive package of 89 pilot projects/preparatory actions with a total commitment appropriation of EUR 64.9 million, as proposed by Parliament. This package for next year includes my initiative for a pilot project launched in the LIBE Committee of the EP, titled 'A Diverse Europe', specifically aimed at eliminating various forms of discrimination against indigenous minorities, including through education, training and for a.  A total of EUR 1 million has been allocated to the pilot project, of which EUR 500 000 will be available to minority communities and applicants through calls for proposals next year. I voted in favour of the adoption of the budget.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this procedural report which simply approves the joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee in relation to the 2016 budgetary procedure, which consists of a number of agreements taken together including the list of budget lines not modified, compared to the draft budget or the Council’s position; summary figures by financial framework headings; line-by-line figures on all budget items; and the consolidated document showing the figures and final text of all lines modified during the conciliation.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Supporting EU farmers, improving infrastructure or helping countries struggling with the flow of Syrian refugees: all EU operations have a financial aspect - so their funding must be provided in the budget. However, the budgetary figures approved by Parliament usually differ from those agreed by governments in the Council, so I believe that the two institutions must seek common ground.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report defines the EU budget for the 2016 financial year and is the result of a compromise agreement between Parliament and the Council. Parliament's negotiators secured the cancellation of most of the cuts proposed by the Council and negotiated more funding for countries on the front line on migration, humanitarian aid, the European research and development programme Horizon 2020, youth and small and medium-sized employment initiatives and the vocational and student mobility funding programme, and the vocational and student mobility funding programme. Erasmus. The agreement provides for 155 billion euros in commitment credits and 143.9 billion euros in payment credits for 2016.  Considering that the 2016 financial guidelines address future priority issues, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2016 budget procedure, which calls for more funding for humanitarian aid as well as to support growth through SMEs and the European research programmes Horizon 2020 and Erasmus.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The 2016 budget first addresses the challenges facing the European Union in migration, refugee reception and foreign policy.  It highlights growth, innovation and employment, in line with previous budgets, the financial strengthening of the Horizon 2020, Erasmus or COSME programmes going in the right direction.  On these issues, it is a question of finding a necessary balance between investment and budgetary rigour. Implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe (EFSI) is one of the challenges of this Parliament. We will be judged on its success.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 EU funds for Hungary were also provided in 2016. Attempts to link the payment of cohesion funds to the implementation of the rules on quotas for the relocation of migrants have been averted. It is an outstanding achievement that we have raised by EUR 2 billion the programmes contributing to the management of the migration crisis. Most of the additional resources will be spent in countries that are on the front lines of the crisis, in line with the hungarian government's position, and will help to address the conflicts that have strengthened the wave of immigration at the place where they were created. I think it is important to stress that a reversal of the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund (IPA) previously proposed by the Council has also been achieved. These instruments have a decisive impact on the accession efforts of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. In addition to effective financial support, maintaining the level of the Pre-Accession Fund also sends an important political message and encouragement for candidate countries. With the final vote, the EU budget for 2016 will be able to provide the resources for the EUR 500 million milk rescue package. All obstacles will be removed from the fact that Hungarian dairy farmers will receive the 2.9 billion HUF EU aid in time.  On the basis of the above, and in line with the people's party position, I supported the report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. This is a rigorous budget, increasing by only 1.6% while we need to invest 15 million in building security and computer system security. It is also a reform budget, marked by a rigorous framework for the hiring of local assistants, so that abuses, even real abuses, are quickly detected and do not happen again. Finally, it is an inter-institutional loyalty budget through which Parliament confirms its target of reducing its workforce by 5% on a specific timetable until 2019. It should be stressed, however, that this 2016 EU budget is a transitional budget before the necessary revision of the financial outlook next year.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – An outstanding achievement is the increase of EUR 2 billion in programmes contributing to the management of the migration crisis. Most of the additional resources will be spent in countries that are on the front lines of the crisis, in line with the Hungarian Government's position, and will help to address conflicts that strengthen the immigration wave at the place where they arise. For Hungarian Ps, it is a success to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund (IPA) previously proposed by the Council, as these instruments have a decisive impact on the accession aspirations of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. In addition to effective financial support, maintaining the level of the Pre-Accession Fund also sends an important political message and encouragement for candidate countries. With the final vote, the EU budget for 2016 will be able to provide the resources for the EUR 500 million milk rescue package. All obstacles will be removed from the fact that Hungarian dairy farmers will receive the 2.9 billion HUF EU aid in time. We also supported the joint project "Diverse Europe" by Pál Csáky and Kinga Gál. In this context, €1 million will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination. On the basis of the above, we supported the report in line with the people's party position.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report for the 2016 European Union budget validates edifying developments in the management of public money in Europe.  Thus, aid to migrants will be 6 times greater than that devoted to farmers who are directly suffering from The policies of Brussels.  Another example: while France's revenue levies will rise again to EUR 23.65 billion in 2016, at the same time the European Union will increase the salaries of EU staff by 2.4%, while inflation will be only 1%, at a cost of 100 million euros. This financial waste that gets worse every year can no longer last, so I objected to this report.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The Parliament and the Commission have been pushing for a larger budget rather than de-prioritising less important spending programmes and re-allocating funds to short and medium term priorities. The ECR Group called for a ‘reprioritisation’ of the EU budget to meet pressing needs, while respecting the need to address the abnormal level of unpaid bills. The resulting agreement of the Conciliation Committee moves somewhat in this direction but there remain highly problematic elements within the budget which I would oppose.  Only 800 million of margin remains for payments in 2016 leaving little room to cope with further unforeseen circumstances. This is likely to put pressure on the MFF ceilings during next year’s mid-term review, when these slim margins will inevitably be strained. Some European money needs to be targeted at the ongoing migration crisis. However, there is significant scope for redeployment of funding in multiple Headings from budget lines with low implementation rates and poor absorption capacity.     The UK delegation has consistently argued against any increase in the EU budget. It should live within its means as agreed in the MFF. The same budgetary rigour applied to national spending should be applied to EU spending. The result of the Conciliation Committee does not sufficiently satisfy these principles.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted not to support this agreement. In my opinion, there is a need for additional support but not at the overall expense of Member States, which are already under a lot of pressure. In fact, there should be more funding available to handle the crisis but still too much money is distributed in an inefficient way. Just a simple sending of large amounts of money does not solve the problem. We need targeted support. Currently, as announced under this budgetary procedure, there is a lack of available margins under a number of headings and a lack of redeployment from wasteful budget lines to priority areas.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 A budget that has appropriations for the Turkish occupying forces of the Territory of the Republic of Cyprus and indirectly finances the increase in the number of illegal immigrants on the territory of the old continent cannot be classified as European.  The European Union needs to change direction now that it has time, because it will soon be too late.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. The agreement represents a small increase in the budget due to increased efforts, particularly to deal with the current refugee situation, but also measures to boost growth in the EU. An additional factor contributing to the additional need for increased budgets is that many of the previously planned projects have started and need payments. I would have liked these changes to have been dealt with by redeployments within the existing budget, but I have nevertheless chosen to vote in favour of the final agreement.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 This process has developed in an extremely positive way, respecting all the political priorities set by Parliament, in particular with regard to supporting the promotion of employment, boosting the economy, enhancing knowledge and research in the growth strategy and strengthening the European Union's internal and external solidarity capacity. The overall EU budget for 2016 is €155,004.2 billion in authoritato payment appropriations and €143,885.3 million in payment appropriations. These amounts represent a strengthening of the amounts foreseen, compared to the initial budget proposed by the European Commission, by more than EUR 2.8 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 2 150 billion in payment appropriations. The budget has been pushed to the limit of what is possible, using all possible resources and the entire flexibility instrument to respond to the challenge of promoting employment and aid to refugees, and all budget margins of the lines related to employment, social and territorial cohesion and internal and external solidarity have also been exhausted.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it provides for a significant increase in the French contribution to the European budget.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report presupposes the validation and adoption of the joint text agreed in the Conciliation Committee, which concerns the EU budget for 2016. The agreement, as you would expect, does not change the bottom line of the criticism we have directed at the EU budget, which justified our vote against it at second reading and which now justifies that same vote against. This joint text allows, for example, that eur 11 075 000 be subtracted from the budgetary lines for the protection, design and control of plant and animal pests, as well as to the Fund for emergency measures related to animal and plant health, in Title 3 of the Multiannual Financial Framework.  Despite the increase in commitments for Horizon 2020, COSME and Erasmus+, payment appropriations have been cut by EUR 460 100 000. Cuts in the whole on budgetary lines relating to the promotion of sustainable rural development (-EUR 87 000 000), cuts in the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (-EUR 127 259 355) and the Cohesion Funds (-EUR 43 693 564) and rural development programmes (-EUR 33 000 000). The European Parliament is committed to reducing around 179 jobs by 2019, with 60 in 2016 expected to end up with 60.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Eu ropean Union's joint draft general budget for 2016 because there are major issues in several areas, including a lack of redistribution of resources to priority areas and a possible worsening of commitments and payments.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. We voted in favour of the EU budget in 2016 because it goes without saying that the EU must have a budget. On the other hand, we voted against the demands made by Parliament's majority for the negotiations with the Council. What has now been decided was the only option for a functioning Europe.  We welcome the fact that the agreed budget prioritises the challenges posed by the refugee issue and that research and development are a priority. We regret that this is done by increasing the budget as a whole and by not making savings corresponding to the scale of the priorities.  In the long term, we want to reduce agricultural subsidies, industrial subsidies and those parts of regional policy that make well-functioning economies dependent on regional subsidies. The EU should give priority to the infrastructure, research and long-term capacity of the internal market to develop an effective foreign policy and jointly strengthen control over our borders.  This should be done within the current long-term budget and should be based on respect for taxpayers' money and the strained budgetary situation of the Member States.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on this budget can only be negative. The EU has done so many things wrong, but the worst thing is that it is still making mistakes. From the defence of 'made in', to the single currency, to the management of immigration, it is a total failure.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 A budget that has appropriations for the Turkish occupying forces of the Territory of the Republic of Cyprus and indirectly finances the increase in the number of illegal immigrants on the territory of the old continent cannot be classified as European. For the above reasons I am voting against the report. The European Union needs to change direction now that it has time, because it will soon be too late.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the many positive aspects in the agreement with the Council on budget, such as the provisions for Erasmus, COSME and Horizon 2020 Programmes, the Youth Guarantee, which is essential to fight youth unemployment and the increase in funding for development policies which is fundamental for the migration agenda. In particular, the prolongation of the Youth Unemployment Initiative shows that we are committed to reducing youth unemployment, which remains a high and shared political priority. We have to make the best possible use of budgetary resources available to tackle this issue.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 EU funds for Hungary were also provided in 2016. Attempts to link the payment of cohesion funds to the implementation of the rules on quotas for the relocation of migrants have been averted. It is an outstanding achievement that we have raised by EUR 2 billion the programmes contributing to the management of the migration crisis. Most of the additional resources will be spent in countries that are on the front lines of the crisis, in line with the Hungarian Government's position, and will help to address conflicts that strengthen the immigration wave at the place where they arise. For Hungarian Ps, it is a success to reverse the reduction of the Pre-Accession Fund (IPA) previously proposed by the Council, as these instruments have a decisive impact on the accession aspirations of the candidate countries, such as Serbia and the Hungarians in Vojvodina. In addition to effective financial support, maintaining the level of the Pre-Accession Fund also sends an important political message and encouragement for candidate countries. With the final vote, the EU budget for 2016 will be able to provide the resources for the EUR 500 million milk rescue package. All obstacles will be removed from the fact that Hungarian dairy farmers will receive the 2.9 billion HUF EU aid in time.  We also supported the joint project "Diverse Europe" by Pál Csáky and Kinga Gál. In this context, €1 million will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination.  On the basis of the above, we supported the report in line with the people's party position.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the joint text of the 2016 budgetary procedure agreed by the Conciliation Committee following the evaluation of the European Parliament's report on it.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations.   The report emphasizes the refugee crisis, while continuing to invest in R&D policies.  On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue with the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis.   I regret, however, that I have not been able to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment from Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  In addition, I would like to emphasize that this is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting that, in view of the seriousness of current needs, budget limits do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures where it is most needed. We will therefore have to continue to work to address the structural problems of the European budget during the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I welcome the successful conclusion of the negotiations with the Council and the Commission on the 2016 budget of the European Union. I would particularly like to highlight the increases in research, for small and medium-sized enterprises, for international cooperation, as well as, of course, the necessary allocation of 1.5 billion from the reserve fund for the refugee emergency.  Precisely in a state of economic crisis, the EU budget can play a decisive role as a stimulus for growth and investment, and I hope that the new season inaugurated with the Juncker Plan can continue and be increasingly linked to the EU's budgetary policies.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the report on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the 2015 budget year approved by the Conciliation Committee in the context of the budgetary procedure, as I consider the savings efforts made there to be partly too little and partly wrongly focused. I would have liked a bolder approach.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The joint draft EU general budget for the financial year 2016 has been approved by the Joint Committee. It is a good compromise and achieved without the "dramatic" scenes and threats of rejection that have taken place in recent years.  The overall level of commitment appropriations for 2016 was set at EUR 155 billion. This leaves the margin below the 2016 MFF ceilings of EUR 2.3 billion. Under the Flexibility Instrument, EUR 1.5 billion will be allocated to the 'Security and Citizenship' heading and EUR 24 million to commitments under the Global Europe heading.  I am pleased that the issue of reducing youth unemployment remains a common political priority. It is important to make optimal use of budgetary resources, in particular the Youth Employment Initiative. Furthermore, an important point is the gradual elimination of the backlog of outstanding payment applications under the cohesion programmes 2007-2013. Efforts should be made to improve the monitoring of any unpaid bills, mainly through the establishment of an early warning system. From 2016, the state of implementation of the budget will be actively monitored and the budget appropriations will reduce the backlog accumulated at the end of the year to around EUR 2 billion. I am pleased that the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission will continue to summarise the state of implementation of payments and forecasts at special regular interinstitutional meetings.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The 2016 budget responds to the current challenges. More funding will be made available to deal with the refugee crisis and financial support will be provided to the labour market to create new jobs. At the same time, financial resources will be made available for agriculture, which has been heavily burdened by the Russian conflict.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2016 budgetary procedure, which declares that the European Union’s general budget for the financial year 2016 has been definitively adopted and arranges for its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The adoption of the 2016 budget has not been easy. The Commission, Parliament and the Council have developed arduous negotiations, but finally we have a budget that uses all available margins to increase the items for such important programmes as Erasmus +, COSME (aimed at helping SMEs) or migration policy. Parliament stresses with today's vote that the challenges facing Europe require the use of all possible funds.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Since the publication of the Commission’s Draft Budget in May 2015, a number of significant events have occurred with budgetary implications, relating to Greece, the agricultural sector, and most importantly the migrant and refugee crisis. However, instead of de-prioritising less important spending programmes and re-allocating funds to short and medium term priorities, the Parliament and the Commission have focused their efforts on pushing for a larger budget. The UK delegation has consistently argued against any increase in the EU budget. The EU budget should live within its means as agreed in the MFF. We believe the same budgetary rigour applied to national spending should be applied to EU spending. The result of the Conciliation Committee does not sufficiently satisfy these principles. This is not to say that the Draft Budget is without any positives. An increase of funding for research and innovation programmes like Horizon 2020 is a very much welcome addition. Nevertheless, there remain a number of highly problematic elements which I cannot support. It is for these reasons that I voted against.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted against it. Although the outcome of the negotiation is not the worst possible and the budget increases and improves that of previous years, it is a budget that remains ridiculous, containing strong securitarian elements, which does not meet the challenges of the EU (refugee crisis, economic crisis, ecological challenges, etc...) and which mobilisations an investment plan with sesgade effects and uncertain results. It raises EUR 155 billion of credit commitments, a margin of EUR 2 331.4 million, and, as far as it matters, in payment commitments – which is actually spent – EUR 143.8 billion and a Flexibility Instrument of EUR 1.506 million. It follows a line prone to a European model favourable to large transnational companies, where the Youth Employment Initiative will be progressively diminished and where outstanding and unresolved issues are dealt with with statements with rhetorical effects.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached for the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations. On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis. name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Without budgetary resources to live up to our ambitions, any European policy can only be in vain. Faced with the challenges we face (refugee crisis, employment) I have supported the strengthening of our European funding for 2016 in key areas such as education, research and development, as well as support for SMEs. An additional EUR 800 million will be spent on the distribution of refugees across the EU, while additional posts can be created at frontex, the European Asylum Support Office and Europol.  In addition, we wanted to focus on jobs and growth: an additional EUR 31.8 million is planned for the "Horizon 2020" research and development programme; An additional EUR 14.2 million to support SMEs through COSME; and an additional EUR 6.6 million to help young people who are taking education or training under the Erasmus programme.  Finally, together with my Socialist colleagues, we are concerned about the EU's inability to tackle its payments crisis and the accumulation of unpaid bills. We will need to reframe our fiscal outlook in the mid-term review of the multi-year fiscal framework, which will take place in 2016.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure because it is of utmost importance to reduce youth unemployment. In the report it remains a high and shared political priority, and to this end they reaffirm their determination to make the best possible use of budgetary resources available to tackle it, and in particular the Youth Employment Initiative.

On the basis of the above, we supported the report in line with the people's party position.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2016 budgetary procedure. In particular, I was very pleased with the joint statement on the Youth Employment Initiative (YEI) that was agreed between the three Institutions, including the commitment by the Commission, after drawing lessons from the YEI evaluation, to make proposals for the continuation of this initiative till 2020, which Parliament and Council undertake to examine rapidly. Furthermore, I fully support the request by Parliament for a 500 million package of measures to support farmers, especially in the dairy sector as well as additional measures following the Russian embargo. A small additional reinforcement for fisheries was also agreed.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as the proposals are in line with the EU budgetary framework and in accordance with financial rules.

name: Roger HELMER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The euro crisis is one of the main contributors towards SME financial problems and continuous EU regulations that hinder SME progress. Many EU regulations are hindering employers to take on new employees and train them up to keep abreast of regulations. The Horizon 2020 Programme has been allocated EUR 31.8 million; it has already been allocated EUR 150 million. Erasmus is a Europe-wide education programme that allows students to have mobility throughout Europe and has been allocated a further EUR 6.6 million. Security & Citizenship has been allocated EUR 1.5 billion, and a further EUR 150 million will be mobilised to help Turkey to deal with the crisis. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament on the 2016 budget amounts to €155 billion in commitment appropriations and €143.8 billion in payment appropriations. This represents an unjustified increase of 6.7% in commitments and 1.8% in payments compared to 2015. It is true that additional funds have been allocated to tackle the migration and refugee crisis (€1.1 billion) and to the Youth Employment Initiative (€473 million), which is to be welcomed in principle. But almost all margins have been used up, rather than re-setting priorities in the budget. Even the Council argued that Parliament must limit its priorities, as the increases proposed by Parliament collectively exhaust margins in the areas of growth and employment (heading 1a), cohesion (heading 1b) and security and citizenship (heading 3). This jeopardises the functioning of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). In future, therefore, there will be no room for manoeuvre for a number of budget lines, as the ceilings have already been reached or even exceeded. I cannot agree to an ever-increasing EU budget without real prioritisation. That is why I voted against the report. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. We voted in favour of the EU budget in 2016 because it goes without saying that the EU must have a budget. On the other hand, we voted against the demands made by Parliament's majority for the negotiations with the Council. What has now been decided was the only option for a functioning Europe. We welcome the fact that the agreed budget prioritises the challenges posed by the refugee issue and that research and development are a priority. We regret that this is done by increasing the budget as a whole and by not making savings corresponding to the scale of the priorities.  In the long term, we want to reduce agricultural subsidies, industrial subsidies and those parts of regional policy that make well-functioning economies dependent on regional subsidies. name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the European Union's draft budget for 2016, which has been adapted to take account of the agricultural crisis and the migration crisis. The European Parliament approved by an overwhelming majority this budget, which amounts to a total of 155 billion euros in commitment appropriations and 143.9 billion euros in payment appropriations. For example, a package of 500 million euros has been mobilised to support dairy farmers and farmers who are suffering from the repercussions of the Russian embargo. For the management of the migration crisis, 2.7 billion euros have been mobilised from the 2016 budget envelope and 150 million euros will be spent on humanitarian aid. Let us now hope that these available funds will be used wisely.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the common draft general budget of the European Union for the 2016 financial year, adopted by the Mediation Committee as part of the budgetary procedure, on the basis that I think it takes into account the challenges facing the Union.  In the first place, a flexibility instrument has been strengthened to enable better emergency and contingency management. Furthermore, particular attention has been paid to growth, job creation and the YeI, and european programmes supporting such measures and activities. Measures have also been taken to help farmers, strengthen humanitarian action, and mitigate the consequences of the refugee crisis. In my view, the budgetary process needs to maintain a high level of transparency, clarity and consistency of European policies in order to balance it and meet real needs.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Representatives of the European Parliament and council representatives in the budget reconciliation committee agreed on an agreement for the 2016 budget. Among the points of interest are: the substantial increase in Erasmus' credits; funds allocated to farmers, some of which offset the consequences of the Russian embargo; Funds for multimedia actions; Increased humanitarian aid; or funds for external action on the migration crisis.  The budget also provides EUR 2 billion for aid to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis (four times less than the funds allocated to the farmers' crisis).) Billions more will have to be asked of national taxpayers, since we know that the Commission expects to take in 3 million migrants on top of what was planned. Finally, the commitments amount to 155 billion euros (compared to 145.3 in 2015) and the payment credits to 143.8 billion (141.2 in 2015), well above the 2015 appropriations.  I naturally voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Along with my colleagues, I voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. – It is important that the EU budget for next year is sufficient to deal with issues such as the migration crisis and security concerns. As the ALDE draftsperson on the LIBE opinion to the budget, I pushed for more funding in order to better secure the EU’ borders. This is a key priority in my view, as without properly secured external borders, the Schengen Agreement will be at great risk. I am pleased that the Parliament as a whole backed the increase to the Frontex budget as well as for the European Agenda on Security. This is a step towards better managing the current crisis. While I am not in favour of the relocation mechanism for refugees, I respect the decision of the Member States to implement this, which of course requires related financial appropriations.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez on the 2016 budget procedure, a joint conciliation project. The 2016 budget is resolutely geared towards jobs and solidarity, as the EPP wants, with EUR 155 billion earmarked for these two objectives. Parliament has succeeded in reducing the Council's budget cuts and increasing commitment appropriations for the Horizon 2020, COSME and Erasmus programmes, which support innovation, business and young people. In addition, EUR 500 million will be allocated to help dairy farmers. The 2016 budget also provides additional resources to manage the refugee crisis both inside and outside the EU to combat the sources of this crisis.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which perfectly reflects the political priorities mentioned in 2015 by the European Parliament, which are to be included in the 2016 budget. It was indeed necessary to respond to an exceptional crisis, the migrant crisis, by a significant increase in the European budget. We also need to strengthen competitiveness by creating decent and quality jobs.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I do not agree with the report on the approved joint draft general budget of the European Union. The budget is to be adopted as proposed by the Council. Increases are set in areas with added value (research and development, SMEs, etc.), but also reductions in the overall budget. As a result, the set-off in 2016 will have a lower budget than in the previous year. This is desirable, but I think the budget is still too high.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2016 European Union budget at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. I believe that the Negotiators of the European Parliament have achieved a good result in the negotiations with the Council of Europe. In this context, I would like to highlight the funding for five new jobs for the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators, whose main task is to monitor the EU's wholesale gas prices. The European Union imports more than half of the energy needs, and at the same time the regions from which these energy sources come are becoming increasingly unstable, thus jeopardising the security of energy supplies. That is why the European Commission has established an Energy Union strategy. In order to achieve the objectives of this strategy, it is important to ensure the functioning of the European Union's internal market, where the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators plays a major role. However, additional staff and, consequently, resources are needed to carry out this important task. However, these five people are still not enough to cope with the enormous and responsible workload, so the European Parliament must continue to work towards the resources in each year's budget to ensure the agency's working capacity. In the light of the above considerations, I voted in favour of next year's European Union budget.

In addition to effective financial support, maintaining the level of the Pre-Accession Fund also sends an important political message and encouragement for candidate countries. With the final vote, the EU budget for 2016 will be able to provide the resources for the EUR 500 million milk rescue package. All obstacles will be removed from the fact that Hungarian dairy farmers will receive the 2.9 billion HUF EU aid in time.  We also supported the joint project "Diverse Europe" by Pál Csáky and Kinga Gál. In this context, €1 million will be available to applicants to finance minority programmes to combat discrimination.  On the basis of the above, I supported the report in line with the people's party position.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – In essence, this is a formal vote, since it is intended to fix the previously adopted budget envelopes. Nevertheless, I thought it important to vote no, because it cannot be expressed enough that I do not agree with the unsustainable neoliberal economic policy model, which is being pushed further. And the budget is nothing more than an expression of economic policy, that is, in this case, the road to a dead end.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the green light on the joint text of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. Parliament's delegation is satisfied with the budget drawn up and with the agreement reached between Parliament's representatives and the Representatives of the Council, which provides for EUR 155 billion in commitments and EUR 143.8 billion in payments.  The text provides for the allocation of around EUR 1.5 billion in funding, both to deal with the management of the migrant emergency and to promote employment in Europe. In this respect, it is essential to respond to the challenges of employment, especially among young people. It was also decided to allocate an extra EUR 500 million to farmers in order to help them cope with the crisis in the dairy sector. Finally, with regard to the migration crisis, action will be taken through the reinforcement of executive agencies, such as Frontex, and through increased funds for programmes related to the management of the problem from its origins.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I supported the European Union's joint draft general budget for the 2016 financial year, approved by the conciliation committee, as did a large majority of MEPs.  This project sets the total amount of commitment and payment appropriations for 2016 at 155.004 billion and 143.885 billion euros respectively.  We also wanted to introduce a joint declaration to insist on monitoring budget implementation throughout the year. This budget should help Member States cope with the migration crisis on our continent, particularly through emergency assistance to states on the front lines of the refugee influx.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the agreement for the 2016 budget. In total, this 2016 budget provides EUR 2 billion for aid to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis. It is shocking to say the least that European leaders allocate four times more resources to the management of the migration crisis than to farmers who are suffering from the policies decided by Brussels. Moreover, this amount is completely paltry in view of the migration submersion that EU Member States are facing.  Indeed, the Commission now expects to take in 3 million migrants on top of what was planned. It is equally scandalous that the salaries of staff in EU institutions will increase by 2.4% while inflation in the euro area is less than 1%, all at a cost of EUR 100 million.  Finally, the levy on France's revenues in the 2016 finance bill will rise to a record level: 23.65 billion euros.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. 'As indicated in the 2016 budget, additional resources should be used to address the asylum crisis. For the N-VA, investment must be made primarily in strengthening Europe's external borders, encouraging reception in the region so that refugees can stay safely close to their region, and improving cooperation between European intelligence services. These measures should help us to prevent new asylum dramas.  On the positive side, the 2016 budget remains within the spending limits of the multiannionary financial framework and that the EU uses this budget to focus on the competitiveness of our economies.  The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament approves the 2016 budget for these reasons, but warns of unjustified euphoria. For example, the fact that the European Parliament needs two more years to reduce its civil service by 5% is unacceptable. After all, the EU, like national governments, must do more and better with less.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, despite containing some positive items, it means continuing with the logic of austerity which prevents the increase in the EU budget to deal with all payments. This report approves the outcome of the Conciliation Committee containing some positive measures, such as the maintenance of Horizon 2020, resources for the refugee crisis, measures for dairy farmers, etc. However, the result remains unsolving the payments that the EU will have to make in 2017 to Member States, deferring these problems because of the refusal to increase the resources available to the EU budget. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament on the 2016 budget amounts to €155 billion in commitment appropriations and €143.8 billion in payment appropriations. This represents an unjustified increase of 6.7% in commitments and 1.8% in payments compared to 2015. It is true that additional funds have been allocated to tackle the migration and refugee crisis (€1.1 billion) and to the Youth Employment Initiative (€473 million), which is to be welcomed in principle. But almost all margins have been used up, rather than re-setting priorities in the budget. Even the Council argued that Parliament must limit its priorities, as the increases proposed by Parliament collectively exhaust margins in the areas of growth and employment (heading 1a), cohesion (heading 1b) and security and citizenship (heading 3). This jeopardises the functioning of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 (MFF). In future, therefore, there will be no room for manoeuvre for a number of budget lines, as the ceilings have already been reached or even exceeded. I cannot agree to an ever-increasing EU budget without real prioritisation. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Overall, I oppose the EU budget as voted on, without even taking into account our amendments to save considerable funds.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Council of Europe Regulation No 2012 1311/2013 Sets out a multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 to help the European Union cope with the objectives of growth and youth employment policy objectives as successfully as possible.  Every year, an annual budget is also adopted, which also aims to respond to the challenges expected in that year. Thus, the 2016 budget puts items related to innovation, entrepreneurship and youth employment at the forefront, with particular attention given to budget flexibility to respond to the immigrant crisis, the crisis in the agricultural sector and the crisis in Greece. I supported the report by Gérard Deprez and José Manuel Fernandes, as I believe that responsible investment of budgetary resources is essential for achieving growth and development in the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the European Union's joint draft general budget for the financial year 2016, adopted by the Conciliation Committee in the context of the budgetary procedure, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This joint project is the result of negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council for approval by these two institutions. Among the shocking findings of this budget, we note that 2 billion euros are planned to deal with the migration crisis, 4 times more than the amount allocated to help the farmers who are victims of Brussels!

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, all sections, finds my favorable photo. A great deal of foresight has been done and the results are appreciable with regard to the 'closed' budget lines, i.e. those confirmed and not modified by the Council or Parliament, and the increase in staff in some decentralised agencies. The issues discussed within it are urgent and very important issues, such as youth unemployment or payment forecasts. All the more so at this time, it is extremely important to have appropriations adapted to the commitments that Europe must meet effectively.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that the budget for 2016 has been adopted and that Parliament’s priority of enhancing the EU's competitiveness translates into extra resources for small and medium-sized enterprises (EUR 14.3 million), funds for Horizon 2020 (EUR 184.5 million) and funds for the infrastructure tool Connecting Europe Facility (EUR 150 million) to reinstate some of the money previously diverted from them to the Juncker Investment Fund, and funding for the student exchange programme Erasmus+ (EUR 6.6 million). Parliament also persuaded the Council and the Commission to make a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative, which is currently under review, in 2016 and to keep the level of unpaid European bills at a sustainable level.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 My approval of the draft general budget for the financial year 2016 is explained by the consideration that the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission recognise the measures taken to phase out the backlog of outstanding commitments from the 2007-2013 cohesion programmes and to improve the monitoring of any arrears of unpaid invoices under all headings. A future commitment to avoid similar backlogs is also reiterated, including through the establishment of an early warning system.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report, which marks the conclusion of budgetary conciliation with the Council.  The extreme weakness of the European budget, which does not even reach 1% of the Union's GDP, is well known. But it should also be stressed how much, within this budget, the Council is reluctant to release payment credits (in short the currency actually available for payments from European administrations and agencies) and only grants sufficient authorisations of commitment (permission to initiate the procedure for future payment). Similarly, while the new 2014-2020 programme provides for various easing mechanisms to meet the needs - safety margins, flexibility instruments - Member States have constantly tried to oppose their use.  Parliament's negotiators have secured the use of these instruments to address minimal humanitarian and economic emergencies. The aim is to finance the reception of refugees, and to provide the investment fund with the Juncker plan. These are the reasons that deserve a favourable vote, to avoid any situation of unnecessary blocking. But I deeply regret that a programme such as the Youth Employment Initiative, a top priority in Europe, has not been refinanced by the Council this year.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. It is to be welcomed that a lower budget is to be spent than in 2015, but the commitment appropriations are too high, especially with regard to the flexibility instrument. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report endorses the compromise position on the 2016 budget negotiated in obscure committees by its president Martin Schulz, as is now the european use at odds with all democratic traditions.  Apart from a few crumbs, the pious wishes expressed by Parliament in its July and October reports will go unfully. At the end of the haggling over this new austerity budget, we discover major redeployments leading to major cuts in the common agricultural policy, in particular in the lines designed to improve the treatment of livestock and to control more intelligently against plant pests. Breeders and winemakers who are fighting for the survival of quality agriculture will appreciate it.  Finally, for the most ridiculous, the EU's 2007-2013 arrears of payment soap opera continues. While their resorption was to be total in 2014, and then in 2015, the report dares to congratulate itself that they will still be 2 billion at the end of 2016! Which country or company would accept that money due be paid between 4 and 9 years late? No economic and social life is possible with such a European functioning. I'm voting against such bad fiscal policy.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Representatives of the European Parliament and council representatives in the budget reconciliation committee agreed on an agreement for the 2016 budget; These are the key points: the substantial increase in Erasmus' funds, the funds allocated to farmers, some of which offset the consequences of the Russian embargo, funds for multimedia actions, increased humanitarian aid and funds for external action on the migration crisis. The budget also provides EUR 2 billion for aid to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis, which is only the beginning, as 3 million migrants are expected to be taken in.  Finally, the commitments amount to 155 billion euros (compared to 145.3 in 2015) and the payment credits to 143.8 billion (141.2 in 2015), well above the 2015 appropriations. France will have to contribute a record 23.65 billion euros to this budget. I am voting against this project, of course.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The conciliation consists of direct negotiations between the two co-legislators (Parliament and Council) within the Conciliation Committee with a view to reaching an agreement in the form of a joint draft. This agreement was reached and the report approves the joint draft, then agreed by the Conciliation Committee, on the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016. I voted in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the various measures agreed by the Commission, Council and Parliament to balance the additional funds required from Member States.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approves the joint text on the 2016 budgetary procedure in agreement with the Conciliation Committee. The document submitted consists of files, lists, aggregated data and final texts, which provide a summary overview of the 2016 budget, amending budget No 8/2015 and joint declarations by the European institutions. I have long been of the opinion that the European budget should be investment and support the competitiveness of the Member States and their regions. I am pleased that EUR 14.3 million has been allocated to small and medium-sized enterprises under the budget, EUR 184.5 million for the EU programme for Research and Innovation Horizon 2020 and EUR 150 million for infrastructures. The good news for young aspiring people is that an increase of EUR 6.6 million in the Erasmus+ student exchange programme budget has been pushed through. I believe that the funds will help young people to obtain a quality education, which they will then apply in professional life.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on 2016 budgetary procedure because I am in agreement with the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On 24 June 2015, the Commission adopted a draft general budget for the European Union for the financial year 2016. On 17 September 2015, the Council forwarded its position on the draft to Parliament, which adopted a resolution on this on 28 October 2015 and proposed budgetary amendments. On this basis, the Budgetary Conciliation Committee between Parliament, the Council and the Commission approved a joint draft text of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, which parliament's delegation to the Conciliation Committee recommended to Parliament for adoption in its report. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In the 2016 budget, the overall level of commitment appropriations is set at EUR 155,004.2 million and the overall level of payment appropriations at EUR 143,885.3 million. I am voting in favour of this report, which allows for an increase in the funds to finance SMEs and youth programmes, these two are key mechanisms for strengthening the competitiveness of the European Union and encouraging the training of young people. I would also like to highlight the adoption of the Smart Port Cities Pilot Project, which I have proposed in the middle of the Parliamentary Committee on Transport and Tourism and which will now enter into force with a view to creating a European network of port and smart cities.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Representatives of Parliament and the Council to the Budget Reconciliation Committee reached an agreement for the 2016 budget for approval by both institutions.  The main changes are marginal. In the end, the 2016 budget is expected to see its commitment appropriations increased to 155 billion euros (compared to 145.3 in 2015) and payment appropriations to 143.8 billion (141.2 in 2015), well above the 2015 appropriations.  This 2016 budget provides 2 billion euros for aid to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis. It is shocking to say the least that European leaders are allocating four times more resources to managing the migration crisis than to farmers who are suffering from the policies decided by Brussels.  Equally scandalous is the fact that the salaries of staff in EU institutions will increase by 2.4%.  Finally, France's revenue levy (PSR-EU) in the 2016 finance bill will rise to a record level of 23.65 billion euros.  So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the EU budget for 2016. Although the funds allocated to the ITER, Galileo, Copernicus and EGNOS programmes have decreased by EUR 120 million, which I regret, some budget cuts have been corrected by the vote of the European Parliament.  In particular, I approve the increase in commitment appropriations of around 32 million euros for Horizon 2020, 14 million euros for COSME and 6.6 million euros for Erasmus. EUR 500 million has also been allocated to support the dairy sector and the agriculture sector more generally, as part of measures to compensate for the revenue losses caused by the Russian embargo.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Excellent work, that carried out by representatives of the European Commission and the Council and colleagues in Parliament's Committee on Budgets. Against a background of financial constraints, the budget approved today keeps this House's political priorities firm: growth and employment, support for SMEs through the recovery of margins for Horizon 2020 and COSME, culture and citizenship.  In particular, in the areas of culture and education, the increase of over EUR 6 million for Erasmus+, certainly the programme best known to our fellow citizens, is a positive sign that will help not only the exchange of competences, but also mutual understanding between European citizens, which is much needed today, at a time when we are seeing walls being built where walls had been torn down in the past. A positive sign is also the agreement reached in conciliation to maintain stable commitments and payments for both 'Creative Europe' and 'People's Europe'. In view of the emergencies with which we are familiar, starting with the refugee crisis, for which no less than EUR 1.5 billion is allocated, and on which we hope the Member States will play their part, both in terms of economic and logistical resources, it should not be underestimated how culture builds citizenship and social inclusion.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report, as it contains particularly important elements in responding to the migration crisis: strengthening the Frontex and Europol agencies in particular.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The overall level of commitment appropriations in the 2016 budget is set at EUR 155 004.2 million and the overall level of payment appropriations in the 2016 budget is set at EUR 143 885.3 million. I have voted for this report that will definitively adopt the European Union’s general budget for the financial year 2016 and arrange for its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report for the 2016 budgetary procedure endorses the joint statements of Parliament, the Council and the Commission and sets the overall level of commitment and payment appropriations for the 2016 budget. I abstained because, in addition to positive aspects such as the promotion of small and medium-sized enterprises and aspects of increasing efficiency, the budget also includes some unnecessary expenditure on agencies.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report follows negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council on the EU's general budget for 2016. I welcome the work of the European Parliament in maintaining the budgetary envelopes for the Erasmus programme, the protection of European farmers and research programmes. Nevertheless, the European Union's budget for 2016 remains anchored in a global framework that is one of austerity, budget cuts, which sacrifice some essential programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, which will not be renewed. The budget for fiscal year 2016 suffers from a lack of structural flexibility that will not respond to the emergencies of tomorrow, and the management of the migrant and refugee crisis will be particularly affected. For these reasons, I vote against it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. There is a substantial need to increase funding to deal with the refugee crisis, and it is important that EU Member States contribute, at least to the extent permitted, to african, Syrian and UN funds.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The euro crisis is one of the main contributors towards SME financial problems and continuous EU regulations that hinder SME progress. Many EU regulations are hindering employers to take on new employees and train them up to keep abreast of regulations. The Horizon 2020 Programme has been allocated EUR 31.8 million; it has already been allocated EUR 150 million. Erasmus is a Europe-wide education programme that allows students to have mobility throughout Europe and has been allocated a further EUR 6.6 million. Security & Citizenship has been allocated EUR 1.5 billion, and a further EUR 150 million will be mobilised to help Turkey to deal with the crisis. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteurs for their work and supporting the position on approving the 2016 budget, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the EU budget for 2016.
