In my work and activities as a member of the European Parliament, among other initiatives, I fully support the efforts in the spheres of education, combating youth unemployment, development of entrepreneurship and SMEs and research and innovation. I welcome the decision for Erasmus + to receive a 30 percent increase over 2016, reaching an EUR 1.8 billion budget for next year, which will tremendously boost education exchanges. Moreover, the escalating migration crisis urgently requires further investment. Therefore, I am in favour of the budget and, in particular, the increase of funding in these fields.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. —The time and circumstances in which the European Union finds itself today require particular boldness and urgent and decisive action. On the one hand, a refugee wave that has no end in sight is flooding Europe as terrorist attacks worry our peoples. On the other hand, we are faced with instability in our eastern neighbourhood and the pressure this crisis has on Union agriculture. The economic crisis from which we have only just begun to draw on fragile feet, and the package of measures that should accelerate stalled economic growth is only at its beginning.  The key word is trust. Trust in ourselves that we can overcome the current circumstances and that we can make Europe, as well as our Member States, more resilient and stronger.  I supported this budget because it instills confidence. He responds to priorities and recognizes the needs of today. Money to tackle refugees and strengthen external border control is provided, and money to boost economic growth and employment is also provided, especially one to boost youth employment. The budget recognises the importance of research-based progress and better connectivity. Also, the budget instills confidence because of the identified needs in the agricultural sector. The 500 million additional funding available almost immediately for those hardest hit in the dairy sector is the answer european food producers want and need to hear.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Representatives of Parliament and the Council to the Budget Reconciliation Committee have reached an agreement for the 2016 budget for approval by both institutions.  The main changes are marginal. In the end, the 2016 budget is expected to see its commitment appropriations increased to 155 billion euros (compared to 145.3 in 2015) and payment appropriations to 143.8 billion (141.2 in 2015), well above the 2015 appropriations.  This 2016 budget provides 2 billion euros for aid to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis. It is shocking to say the least that European leaders are allocating four times more resources to managing the migration crisis than to farmers who are suffering from the policies decided by Brussels.  Equally scandalous is the fact that the salaries of staff in EU institutions will increase by 2.4%.  Finally, France's revenue levy (PSR-EU) in the 2016 finance bill will rise to a record level of 23.65 billion euros.  So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support the adopted text on the 2016 EU budget, which amounts to €155 billion in commitments and €143.9 billion in payments, as agreed by parliament and the Council on 14 November. In particular, I welcome Parliament's success in ensuring maximum funding for immigration and refugees, Horizon 2020, SMEs and students participating in the Erasmus Programme. I consider it particularly important to encourage European competition as seen in the additional funding for SMEs (€14.3 million), horizon 2020 funding (€184.5 million), €150 million for connecting Europe Facility and Erasmus+ funding (€6.6 million). I am pleased that a compromise of all institutions has been reached on the allocation of funds for this purpose. I am also pleased that Parliament has persuaded the Commission and the Council to promise to continue the Youth Employment Initiative in 2016, which is an initiative of the S&D Group, and to keep the level of unpaid bills at a sustainable level. I believe that the new budget is progress compared to last year and provides a balanced framework for functioning in the coming year, respecting the current monetary situation, but also stimulating growth and development.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the agreement reached for the EU budget for 2016 in the mediation process, which sets a total level of €155 billion for commitments, or €143.89 billion for payments. It is necessary to highlight the complex circumstances in which the negotiations were conducted. Indeed, the EU faces security threats following the terrorist attack in Paris, as well as an unprecedented humanitarian and refugee crisis that requires urgency and effectiveness of joint action and allocation of funds. The 2016 budget is in the function of growth, jobs and solidarity, which are also priorities of the PPE Group.  I believe that all financial resources and mobilised flexibility instruments have been used to effectively tackle the EU's unemployment and migration crisis. In this context and from the point of view of Croatia, an increase of EUR 14.3 million in COSME (SMEs) programmes is essential, ERASMUS+ (boosting youth education) by €6.6 million, as well as €2 billion in liabilities and €500 million in payments provided for the European Fund for Strategic Investments guarantee fund aimed at strengthening the economy.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of next year's draft budget, which, with its EUR 155 billion, is the highest in history, because Europe cannot afford to go the other way in the current situation. The migration and security crisis facing the European Union must be addressed with sufficient funding. I therefore supported an increase in funding for neighbourhood policy, foreign policy, development and humanitarian aid, as well as the mobilisation of the EUR 800 million flexibility instrument to help Member States cope with migration waves. I also supported the necessary increase in staff and contributions to decentralised and executive agencies, which are in a worrying and unbalanced situation of increasing tasks, on the one hand, and underfunding on the other. Namely, eurojust, Frontex, Europol, the European Medicines Agency and the European Chemicals Agency. Although migration and security policy are currently the most discussed issue, we must not forget the fragile economic situation in which the Union and its Member States find their place. The European Union is experiencing economic growth, but its economic recovery is very slow and, moreover, driven mainly by the export factor. I therefore supported an additional EUR 53 million for the Horizon 2020 science programme, the COSME SME support programme and the Erasmus+ training programme.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2016, which the Commission presented on 24 June 2015. I believe that the budget was designed according to the correct evaluation criteria and that it effectively intercepts the needs of citizens. Parliament has managed to secure the maximum possible amount for the financing of migration emergency management, small and medium-sized enterprises, Erasmus students, the EU Horizon 2020 research programme and to help countries cope with the influx of Syrian refugees.  I would like to point out that, with regard to the issue of citizenship security, it is necessary to maintain, if possible by increasing them, the appropriations for policies linked to asylum and immigration funds, as well as those related to internal security and Frontex. The EU's 2016 budget will amount to €155 billion in commitments and €143.8 billion in payments.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The negotiations were very quick and effective and I would like to welcome it. I note that once again the fight against European subsidies paid to fighting bull breeders has not lasted long. The Council simply did not take on the amendments they had pushed. Again, I repeat: the CAP does not subsidise bullfighting, it is the States that decide the final direction of aid. Fighting bull breeders are breeders like any other in the eyes of Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. – (PT) I voted in favour of the understanding that this budget has succeeded in strengthening the amounts foreseen in relation to the initial budget proposed by the European Commission and closing with the Council a budget that supports job creation, boosts the economy and values knowledge and research in the growth strategy.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this conciliation on the basis that instead of reducing the budget there are large increases in certain programmes that are not justified and do not contribute towards fruitful aims and objectives for the beneficiaries that the programmes are meant to support. The euro crisis is one of the main contributors towards SME financial problems and continuous EU regulations that hinder SME progress. Many EU regulations are hindering employers to take on new employees and train them up to keep abreast of regulations. The Horizon 2020 Programme has been allocated EUR 31.8 million; it has already been allocated EUR 150 million. Erasmus is a Europe-wide education programme that allows students to have mobility throughout Europe and has been allocated a further EUR 6.6 million. Security & Citizenship has been allocated EUR 1.5 billion, and a further EUR 150 million will be mobilised to help Turkey to deal with the crisis. The COSME programme is designated to aid SMEs throughout the EU and beyond, and has been allocated a further EUR 14.2 million.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Addressing the root causes of migration in Africa, helping refugees in Member States, improving competitiveness by helping businesses, protecting farmers or supporting youth employment and mobility in learning: these are some of the key areas of the 2016 budget approved by Parliament this lunchtime. In addition to the 143.9 billion needed to recover its expenses, the EU is committed to allocating EUR 155 billion to various projects.  A delicate balance between the union's many legitimate needs, it represents only about 1% of the gross national income of the 28 Member States and only 6% is spent on administrative costs, which twists the neck of conventional wisdom about a so-called costly 'European bureaucracy'. It is a Europe in order now that can take its action in a large range of sectors that directly impact the daily lives of Europeans, even if adjustments are already to be feared, not least because of the refugee crisis and the fund soon allocated to Turkey to deal with them.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the General Budget of the European Union for the 2016 financial year, which follows a more and faster discussion than in previous years.  Thanks to the European Parliament, the budget does not include certain budget cuts proposed by the Council of Member States, including refugee aid and economic development aid, setting a total commitment of EUR 155 billion.  In a context where Europe is facing an unprecedented influx of refugees, it seems essential to support the allocation funds for Africa and Syria. In economic matters, it makes sense to give priority to SMEs with an increase of 184.5 million euros for Horizon 2020 funds for innovative SMEs. In the field of transport in particular, I support the creation of six new positions within the European Aviation Safety Agency that will enable it to meet the new tasks entrusted by the new aviation package. I regret, however, that the European Railway Agency has not seen its number of posts increase while the scope of its competence has been significantly expanded.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached for the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations.   It emphasizes the refugee crisis while continuing to invest in research and development policies. On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis.   I regret, however, that I have not been able to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment from Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  It should be emphasized that this is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting that, in view of the seriousness of current needs, budget deadlines do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures where it is most needed. We will therefore have to continue to work to address the structural problems of the European budget during the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In the 2016 budget, which I voted on, the total amount of commitment appropriations amounts to 155 billion euros, with a margin below the ceilings of the multi-year financial framework for 2016 of 2.3 billion in commitment appropriations. The total amount of 2016 payment appropriations amounted to 143.9 billion euros, an increase of 1.8% over the 2015 budget. The flexibility instrument is used to provide EUR 1.5 billion in commitment credits under heading 3 (Security and Citizenship) and EUR 24.0 million in Commitment Credits under Heading 4 (Europe in the World), as part of measures to respond to the refugee crisis. Compared to the Commission's initial proposal, there are increases of EUR 31.8 million for the commitment appropriations for Horizon 2020, 14.2 million for the COSME programme (improving access to finance for SMEs) and 6.6 million for Erasmus, which I welcome. For the heading 3 "security", the level of commitments is set at 4.052 billion euros, with no margin below the spending ceiling of the heading and with mobilization of 1.5 billion under the flexibility instrument.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the joint draft eu general budget for the financial year 2016 was adopted by the Conciliation Committee in the framework of the budgetary procedure. I am in favour of the adoption of this report, which approves the 2016 Budget, and the amounts of EU contributions in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations for decentralised agencies and executive agencies.  I would also like to point out, as a positive point, the adoption of the overall package of 89 pilot projects/preparatory actions, amounting to an overall amount of EUR 64.9 million, as proposed by Parliament, as well as the amount of EUR 50.8 billion for Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion (1/3 of the total Union budget), of which EUR 46.6 billion of this amount (92%) investment in growth and jobs, one of the EU's political priorities.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of the 2016 budget, which raises the commitments to 155 billion euros and the payment appropriations to 143.9 billion euros. I would also like to point out that it meets all the requirements that Parliament had requested and therefore includes an additional EUR 1.6 billion compared to the Commission's original proposal. Indeed, the final budget 2016 provides more than 2 billion euros to respond effectively to the refugee crisis. The external dimension of the refugee crisis has been given greater budgetary capacity. It is particularly our Mediterranean neighbours who will be the recipients of European aid, in order to support them in the management of the migration phenomenon.  The 2016 budget also focuses on issues of competitiveness and employment. As Parliament had stated, an increase in funding for the Horizon 2020 programme is planned, as well as the Erasmus programme and the youth employment initiative.  This budget does not forget, as Parliament had hoped, to respond to the agricultural crisis and mobilises EUR 698 million for the dairy sector and pork producers.  Budget 2016 will effectively address the challenges we face.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Joint Draft General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, approved by the Conciliation Committee, which provides commitment appropriations of EUR 155 004.2 million and payment appropriations of EUR 143 885.3 million. The report aims to make full use of the margins of the priority programmes for growth and employment and provides an additional allocation to the Horizon 2020 programme, EUR 500 million to support farmers, especially in the dairy sector, and a joint declaration on the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted against it. Although the outcome of the negotiation is not the worst possible and the budget increases and improves that of previous years, it is a budget that remains ridiculous, containing strong securitarian elements, which does not meet the challenges of the EU (refugee crisis, economic crisis, ecological challenges, etc...) and which mobilisations an investment plan with sesgade effects and uncertain results. It raises EUR 155 billion of credit commitments, a margin of EUR 2 331.4 million, and, as far as it matters, in payment commitments – which is actually spent – EUR 143.8 billion and a Flexibility Instrument of EUR 1.506 million. It follows a line prone to a European model favourable to large transnational companies, where the Youth Employment Initiative will be progressively diminished and where outstanding and unresolved issues are dealt with with statements with rhetorical effects.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. We are pleased that a compromise has now been reached with the support of an overwhelming majority both in the Council and in the European Parliament. However, we abstain from voting on the EU budget for 2016. The budget presented will use the budgetary framework in full until 2020. This means that the EU is ill-equipped to deal with unforeseen events in the period up to 2020. We cannot support this. We recognise that extraordinary efforts are needed to help the hundreds of thousands of refugees who come to Europe in these months. That is why we have also voted in favour of moving money to this area within the framework of the existing budget. At the same time, we are adamant that there is no need to inject more funds into the EU budget. We believe that priority must be given to the existing budget , for example by gradually phasing out agricultural aid. Likewise, we reiterate our clear position that no additional funds should be allocated to the remuneration of EU staff. Finally, we continue to stress the need for new, common and clear rules to ensure better control of funds made available to parliamentarians for clerical purposes, support for European political parties and so on.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, despite containing some positive items, it means continuing with the logic of austerity which prevents the increase in the EU budget to deal with all payments. This report approves the outcome of the Conciliation Committee containing some positive measures, such as the maintenance of Horizon 2020, resources for the refugee crisis, measures for dairy farmers, etc. However, the result remains unsolving the payments that the EU will have to make in 2017 to Member States, deferring these problems because of the refusal to increase the resources available to the EU budget. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this text as it calls for more EU spending, which I am against.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At the present time, Europe is facing a number of problems in many areas, such as the migration crisis, europe's current security problem and the fight against terrorism, or the continuing Russian embargo and milk market crisis after quotas have been liquided. In view of the many and very diverse challenges, it is important to ensure that, during this period of uncertainty and security, the EU budget is sufficiently flexible and focused on clear priorities based on the concrete results to be realised. We should already realise that only a few suddenly emerging problems will be solved just as quickly. Many of them require time and a number of concrete actions over the years. For example, it is difficult to expect that the migration challenge will be resolved soon. This problem will enter successive phases, which at the moment are difficult to identify and predict when even their scope is difficult to quantify precisely.  In the current situation, the focus should be on ensuring the security and adequate protection of the EU's external borders through joint actions, information exchange and a coherent action plan for the services in the Member States. It is also necessary to have crisis measures that are available in the context of unforeseen expenditure.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the joint text of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, which was approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure.  The joint text includes the following sections: the 2016 budget, the 2015 budget – amending budget No 8/2015 and joint declarations. The total amount of commitment appropriations in the 2016 budget amounts to EUR 155 004.2 million. Overall, for 2016, a margin of EUR 2 331.4 million in commitment appropriations remains below the ceiling of the multiannual financial framework. The Joint Declarations recall that reducing youth unemployment remains a high and common political priority and, to this end, reaffirm their determination to make the best use of available budgetary resources to address it, and in particular the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. A year ago, the three institutions agreed on a budget for the year ahead. The compromise proposal shows, inter alia, the Union's willingness to go a step further in the fight against youth unemployment, which is one of the most pressing problems of today. Youth unemployment remains unacceptably high in the EU. As many as 8.7 million young people are expected to be unemployed, according to the 2015 Youth Report. I am pleased that the compromise proposal increases the financial commitments for the Erasmus+ programme by as much as EUR 6.6 million. Four million young people are expected to go abroad by 2020, and a recent study on the effects of this programme shows that young people with international experience are twice as likely to be unemployed as much as possible. In addition, I also welcome the joint commitment of the three institutions to make the best use of European funds to combat youth unemployment and to consider proposals to continue the implementation of the Yei initiative until 2020. Both commitments confirm that facilitating and speeding up the integration of young people into the labour market remains one of the European Union's main priorities, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the agreement between Parliament and the Council on the General Budget of the European Union for 2016, in which our proposal for the allocation of the Union's financial resources reflects the need to address the priorities for action that have recently emerged. We have ensured that the maximum available appropriations are devoted to the migration and refugee crisis, in line with what the Commission has proposed and against the cuts proposed by the Council, totalling over EUR 1 billion. Additional resources are also planned to strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs, to combat youth unemployment and to promote sustainable growth, with the increase in appropriations for Horizon 2020, Cosme and Erasmus+, which partly restore the sums that were originally allocated to the EFSI fund provided for in the Juncker Plan, without neglecting compensation for farmers affected by the Russian embargo on imports of European food products. Particular attention has been paid to research and innovation, real drivers of competitiveness, to consolidate efforts in the construction of technologically advanced digital infrastructures. It is therefore a forward-looking budget based on an idea of inclusive and sustainable development.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The agreement between the Council, the Commission and Parliament on the 2016 budget amounts to €155 billion in commitment appropriations and €143.8 billion in payment appropriations. This represents an unjustified increase of 6.7% in commitments and 1.8% in payments compared to 2015. It is true that additional funds have been allocated to tackle the migration and refugee crisis (€1.1 billion) and to the Youth Employment Initiative (€473 million), which is to be welcomed in principle. But almost all margins have been used up, rather than re-setting priorities in the budget. Even the Council argued that Parliament must limit its priorities, as the increases proposed by Parliament collectively exhaust margins in the areas of growth and employment (heading 1a), cohesion (heading 1b) and security and citizenship (heading 3). This jeopardises the functioning of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). In future, therefore, there will be no room for manoeuvre for a number of budget lines, as the ceilings have already been reached or even exceeded. I cannot agree to an ever-increasing EU budget without real prioritisation. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 By approving the proposals, we expressed our support for education, job creation, small and medium-sized enterprises and their further development and competitiveness, the importance of regional cooperation, as well as the serious and no less topical themes of migration, asylum and their future resolution.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I was happy to support the COMPROMISE proposal for the EU budget for 2016. With €155 billion in commitments and €143.9 billion in payments, this is the highest ever EU budget. In particular, resources for security and internal as well as external management and management of the migration crisis have been significantly increased. I am pleased that all available funds for the current EU Multiannual Financial Framework have been used to address the migration crisis, involving an additional EUR 1.6 billion. For example, these funds will allow for better external border control or a much-needed increase in the number of Europol, Frontex or EASO staff, which are undoubtedly key actors in managing the current migration crisis and must therefore be supported as much as possible. I consider the increase in funding for SMEs in the COSME programme to provide new impetus for the development of the European economy to be a very positive aspect of the approved EU budget for 2016. Last but not least, I would like to highlight the push for an increase in funding for science and research (Horizon 2020) and the Erasmus Plus student exchange programme.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because all budget lines not amended by either the Council or Parliament and the lines in which Parliament accepted council amendments during their separate reading have been confirmed. The total level of commitments in the 2016 budget is set at €155,004.2 million. Furthermore, the report shows that the amount of payment appropriations in the 2016 budget is €143,885.3 million. The EU contribution in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations, and the number of posts for all decentralised agencies are set at the level proposed by the Commission in the draft budget.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission proposes a draft annual budget for the European Union and then Parliament and the Member States agree on each individual number in the draft. Supporting EU farmers, improving infrastructure, helping countries dealing with the immigration of Syrian refugees are activities for which money must be earmarked in the budget. Adopting a European budget is a big decision because it requires complex preparations.  MEPs presented priorities and defined a draft budget based on them. The draft defines EUR 155 billion in liabilities and EUR 143.8 billion in payments. The budget is around 1% of the gross national income (GDP) of all EU Member States and the administrative cost is a small part of this (less than 6%). Countries pay their national contributions and collect excise duties on behalf of the EU, while being beneficiaries of all EU policies and programmes.  I support the proposal for a draft budget for 2016, as the envisaged funds should stimulate stronger economic growth and development, address crises and migration, improve student education and experience, and reduce unemployment through student programmes.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal as I reject the substantial increase in the European Union budget. The EU budget has huge scope to reduce it, and the proposal to increase it is therefore completely torn from reality.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the report on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the budgetary procedure. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Budgets, I have actively participated in the conciliation procedure in which the European Parliament and the European Council have reached agreement on the budget. I welcome the fact that in the European Union budget for 2016 we have managed to reach an agreement whereby we have earmarked more funds for the Youth Employment Initiative, the face of the migrant crisis, small and medium-sized enterprises, Erasmus+, the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and the Horizon 2020 research programme.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 A budget that has appropriations for the Turkish occupying forces of the Territory of the Republic of Cyprus and indirectly finances the increase in the number of illegal immigrants on the territory of the old continent cannot be classified as European. The European Union needs to change direction now that it has time, because it will soon be too late.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption by the European Parliament of the European Union budget for 2016. I considered that, as a result of the Conciliation Committee procedure, an interinstitutional compromise had been reached on the basis of which it could cover Community expenditure at the level of commitments for the following year, amounting to EUR 155 billion and almost EUR 144 billion as payment appropriations, broken down by chapter and in its priorities.  As a key aspect, I considered that the consultations, in large part to the EP's action, have led to an increase in european economic growth and job creation within the budget, as well as the share of aid for research and training.  I consider it equally important that the resources needed to deal with the refugee crisis unexpectedly and as a burden for the EU in the Community and in the Member States have been supplemented by an additional EUR 800 million.  In addition, the composition and adoption process of the EU budget for 2016 once again highlight the need for more flexible and more cooperative attitudes and more modern funding planning methods than at present, in particular on the part of the Member States and the Council. I trust, and as a Member, I will work to ensure that this aspect is applied in the forthcoming MFF review in 2016.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Despite the growing difficulties in financing the migration crisis, the European Parliament and the Council of the EU, representing the Member States, unanimously agreed to increase the 2016 budget. It was therefore decided to provide €4 billion to respond effectively to the increasing number of migrants arriving in Europe. However, next year's budget also includes room for other priorities, in particular those on promoting economic growth and job creation. Moreover, thanks to EP interference, more money will also be spent on research and development, thereby responding to the challenges facing the European Union.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The negotiated deal on the EU budget for 2016 sets the commitment appropriations at EUR 155 billion and payment appropriations to EUR 143.88 billion. The joint text includes elements that our Parliament fought for: additional allocations for Horizon 2020 (+EUR 31.82 million in commitments), the COSME programme (+EUR 14.28 million) and Erasmus+ (+EUR 6.62 million). This is on top of the additional EUR 303 million for Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility already secured by Parliament earlier in 2015, during negotiations on the EFSI. My only concern regards the Youth Unemployment Initiative. While I welcome the Commission’s proposals on the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative until 2020, I regret the fact that no new commitments could have been found for the Youth Employment Initiative. With 4.6 million young people unemployed in the EU, I believe that more investments in reducing the number of young people unemployed are needed to guarantee an adequate response and remedy to the problem. To conclude, I believe the conciliation text presents a good compromise that will help Europe deal with some of its most immediate challenges, therefore I voted in favour of the text.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Deprez on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the 2016 financial year, approved by the conciliation committee as part of the budget procedure. With this vote, we approved the joint draft agreed to by the Conciliation Committee

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2016 EU budget, which is a result of a compromise between the Parliamentary Committee on Budgets and the Council. Although there is a possibility of financial difficulties in the near future related to the current crises, this budget should be sufficient for the areas of employment, enterprise and growth. The overall level of commitment appropriations in the 2016 budget is set at EUR 155 004.2 million and of payment appropriations at EUR 143 885.3 million. The Flexibility Instrument for 2016 is mobilised for an amount of EUR 1 530 in commitment appropriations. The 2016 payment appropriations related to the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument in 2014, 2015 and 2016 are estimated by the Commission at EUR 832.8 million.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. After bitter negotiations, the European Parliament managed to move the lines of the European Union budget in 2016. While the Council proposed real bloodletting, with a reduction of 564 million commitment appropriations and 1.4 billion payment appropriations compared to the Commission's proposal, MEPs joined forces and succeeded in reversing this irresponsible position. For employment, we have achieved an increase up to the ceilings of the multi-year financial framework, i.e. EUR 189.3 billion. For the investment, in addition to the EFSI endowment, additional funds will be available for Horizon 2020 (EUR 31.8 million), the European Research Support Programme, Erasmus (EUR 6.6 million) and SMEs (EUR 14.2 million).  For migrant assistance, we have exceeded the ceilings of the financial framework thanks to the mobilization of the flexibility instrument to the tune of 1.53 billion euros.  A black spot, but a big one, the youth guarantee will have a year 2016 without commitment credits.  Most importantly, we reached all the ceilings of the budget framework in the third year. It is time to open our eyes to our budgetary indigence.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 During the vote, I supported the general draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 because the report contains a significant report on the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative. This is a very important point for the Member States. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have jointly indicated that reducing youth incapacity remains a key and common political priority. To this end, all EU institutions reaffirm their determination to make optimal use of budgetary resources to address this problem.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The migration wave that has lashed Europe has long since taken on the hallmarks of a genuine humanitarian and security catastrophe, and the mobilisation of the flexibility instrument at the moment only confirms that we have welcomed the crisis unprepared. Unfortunately, this is just further evidence that the Commission is not thinking long-term, but is coming from error to error, which is then paid dearly by European taxpayers. The war in Syria did not start yesterday, and refugees have been leaving the country for a very long time. It was clear from day one that Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan could not receive millions of people forever and that if we did not stop the war, the columns would move towards Europe.  I therefore give my decisive voice against such destructive crisis resolution measures that, despite the apparent debacle, continue to persist.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016, approved by the Conciliation Committee in the budgetary procedure, as we put the european Union's competitiveness at an important point within the budget, thus also increasing the headings for migration and refugees, for the Horizon 2020 research programme, for small and medium-sized enterprises and for the Erasmus+ student exchange programme.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted against it. Although the outcome of the negotiation is not the worst possible and the budget increases and improves that of previous years, it is a budget that remains ridiculous, containing strong securitarian elements, which does not meet the challenges of the EU (refugee crisis, economic crisis, ecological challenges, etc...) and which mobilisations an investment plan with sesgade effects and uncertain results. It raises EUR 155 billion of credit commitments, a margin of EUR 2 331.4 million, and, as far as it matters, in payment commitments – which is actually spent – EUR 143.8 billion and a Flexibility Instrument of EUR 1.506 million. It follows a line prone to a European model favourable to large transnational companies, where the Youth Employment Initiative will be progressively diminished and where outstanding and unresolved issues are dealt with with statements with rhetorical effects.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. In total, this 2016 budget provides EUR 2 billion for assistance to Member States on the front line of the migration crisis. It is shocking to say the least that European leaders allocate four times more resources to the management of the migration crisis than to farmers who are suffering from the policies decided by Brussels. Moreover, this amount is completely paltry in view of the migration submersion that EU Member States are facing. Indeed, the Commission now expects to take in 3 million migrants on top of what was planned.  It is equally scandalous that the salaries of staff in EU institutions will increase by 2.4% while inflation in the euro area is less than 1%, all at a cost of EUR 100 million.  I vote logically against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the budgetary procedure, the Conciliation Committee approved a joint draft text of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted against it. Although the outcome of the negotiation is not the worst possible and the budget increases and improves that of previous years, it is a budget that remains ridiculous, containing strong securitarian elements, which does not meet the challenges of the EU (refugee crisis, economic crisis, ecological challenges, etc...) and which mobilisations an investment plan with sesgade effects and uncertain results. It raises EUR 155 billion of credit commitments, a margin of EUR 2 331.4 million, and, as far as it matters, in payment commitments – which is actually spent – EUR 143.8 billion and a Flexibility Instrument of EUR 1.506 million. It follows a line prone to a European model favourable to large transnational companies, where the Youth Employment Initiative will be progressively diminished and where outstanding and unresolved issues are dealt with with statements with rhetorical effects.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission will actively monitor throughout the year the state of implementation of the 2016 budget under the agreed payment plan; In particular, the appropriations provided for in the 2016 budget will allow the Commission to reduce the number of outstanding payment claims under the 2007-2013 cohesion programmes by the end of 2016 to around EUR 2 billion. Eur.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the joint text on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 approved by the Conciliation Committee under the budgetary procedure. With this resolution we approved the joint text agreed by the Conciliation Committee, which consists of the following documents taken together;  – a list of budget lines not modified, compared to the draft budget or the  Council’s position; – summary figures by financial framework headings; – line-by-line figures on all budget items; – a consolidated document showing the figures and final text of all lines modified during the conciliation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. After reaching an agreement in conciliation, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of a budget in which significant achievements have been made for 2016. It is worth noting the mobilisation of the Flexibility Instrument to manage the refugee crisis, the 500 million euro package of support for farmers following the crisis in 2015, especially in the dairy sector, or the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Fernandes-Deprez report on the agreement reached for the 2016 budget because it gives the green light to the use of extraordinary resources to deal with extraordinary situations.   It emphasizes the refugee crisis while continuing to invest in research and development policies. On the other hand, in addition to having achieved a commitment to continue the Youth Employment Initiative after its evaluation over the coming months, it serves our agricultural and livestock sector, affected by the Russian veto and the milk crisis.   I regret, however, that I have not been able to include a larger increase in payments for 2016 or a political commitment from Member States to use extraordinary revenue and thereby finance their share of the European Agenda on Migration.  This is the first time that the Flexibility Instrument has been used, reflecting that, in view of the seriousness of current needs, budget limits do not allow adequate financing of urgent measures where it is most needed. We will therefore have to continue to work to address the structural problems of the European budget during the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework in 2016.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The outcome of the conciliation, given the points made in the final approval, does not allow me to vote in favour because two key issues have been ignored. Firstly, Parliament has neglected the Council's request for the establishment of budget lines which can be considered non-priority and possibly reducible, making it more difficult to actually reduce waste, without allowing any significant cuts in many items which we believe could be reduced. In addition, instead of focusing on the sensitive issue of payments, the Council has persisted in postponing this problem, which is constantly reoccurring every year; In so doing, we will be meeting the increase in the accumulation of payments which will lead to the creation of an inevitable flaw in the system, leading to an ever greater loss of credibility and seriousness in the eyes of all, both as regards Parliament and the Council. Therefore, for the above reasons, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this report because, despite containing some positive items, it means continuing with the logic of austerity which prevents the increase in the EU budget to deal with all payments. This report approves the outcome of the Conciliation Committee containing some positive measures, such as the maintenance of Horizon 2020, resources for the refugee crisis, measures for dairy farmers, etc. However, the result remains unsolving the payments that the EU will have to make in 2017 to Member States, deferring these problems because of the refusal to increase the resources available to the EU budget. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this common text because it is clear that the European Union must have sufficient resources to deal with the refugee crisis. There must be more resources to protect Europe's external borders. The external borders of Greece, Italy, etc. are also the external borders of all individual Member States, and so I voted in favour of this text which, among other things, gives more money to Frontex. It is a necessary step forward to keep the current crisis under control and to safeguard Schengen.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In a framework of major budgetary constraints in the national contributions to the Union budget, some concerns should be noted. Firstly, we draw attention to the €11 million cut that will directly affect budget lines dedicated to the protection, testing and control of plant and animal pests. This cut, in a framework where climate change provides the emergence of several epidemic crises, leaves us at least apprehensive. There is talk of a significant increase in youth employment programmes, but we have to realise that Erasmus+ represents a minimal part of the budget and that, therefore, the 30% increase will unfortunately not have much of an impact. We also note that the European Parliament is committed to reducing around 179 jobs by 2019, with 60 posts expected to be finished in 2016. Finally, one last word on the strengthening of funds for emigration. It could be positive, were it not for the deliberate purpose of promoting persecutory solutions that will contribute to perpetuating the problem, rather than solving it with a genuine policy of solidarity and support for development.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. It is to be welcomed that a lower budget is to be spent than in 2015, but the commitment appropriations are too high, especially with regard to the flexibility instrument. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The general budget of the European Union sets a number of politically incorrect priorities. Spending finances only on concealing symptoms, rather than wanting to change the causes, is not responsible to taxpayers. It must therefore be rejected in order to safeguard European interests in life and the future.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the 2016 budgetary procedure and on the general budget. The EU budget is bloated, finances a wide range of tasks that cannot be decided at EU level and therefore violates the principle of subsidiarity as well as national responsibility. The budget is in line with the principle of perpetual stumbling: the EU was born out of the common agricultural policy, but today it has grown out of it. Nevertheless, a large part of the budget is used to subsidise the agricultural sector. The budget therefore reflects that the EU has only become ever more, but rarely wiser. It is time for fundamental and detoxifying reform. Only then can we think again about approving the budget. Until then, I can only say no.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint text regarding the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016. The joint text touches important areas where the EU needs to strengthen its involvement, such as: full mobilisation of the EU Flexibility instrument in 2016 for immediate budgetary measures under the European Agenda on Migration; additional allocation to the Horizon 2020 programme; further support for farmers (especially in the milk sector); statement for the Continuation of Youth Employment Initiative, following the evaluation in 2016.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this initiative of the Committee on Budgets, in accordance with the decision of the Conciliation Committee, the product of which is the proposed text.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 The current budget is close to the ceilings of the agreed limit of the Multiannual Financial Framework for the years 2014 to 2020. The approval of the EU budget for the financial year 2016 would violate the agreed limit and a necessary and substantial increase in the MFF, and I do not support such spending.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 The final approval of the agreement on the 2016 EU budget was voted on today; the final figure is EUR 155 billion in commitments and almost EUR 144 billion in payments, a sort of middle ground between Parliament's proposal and the Council's proposal.  Parliament has managed to achieve an increase in Heading IA that would partially offset the EFSI cuts at Horizon 2020, while there has been substantial convergence in identifying the issue of immigration as a top priority. In Heading V (administrative expenditure), the Council has managed to achieve modest reductions, and has insisted that the European Parliament should also commit itself to reducing its staff by 5%.  However, I do not consider the agreement reached to be satisfactory and I believe that conciliation has failed on two key issues: Parliament did not want to listen to the Council's request to identify those lines that may not be considered as priorities and therefore possibly reducible, while on the other hand the Council itself wanted to continue to postpone the issue of payments, demonstrating a total lack of commitment and credibility. The final outcome 'satisfies' Parliament in its façade, but nothing says in substance on the dramatic issue of payments, which will recur in the coming years until a certain breaking point is found.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I am pleased that the negotiations on the EU budget for 2016 have been so smooth this year and that a compromise has been reached. It is also pleased that increased funding for Erasmus+ has been included among the priorities in the budget. This is an important signal that the EU is funding to support youth exchanges with the EU and neighbouring countries. We have sought funding for pilot projects and preparatory actions in Title 3 and these measures have also been ensured, but not in full. We are also gradually improving the proportion between current payments and commitments already due, catching up with previous years. This is very important. In the future, we should seek greater stability for proven projects, improve the length of the prospects for guaranteed funding, and improve the financing of those projects that provide knowledge of the state of culture in Europe and its financing mechanisms.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund to ensure the payment of advances under the 2016 budget. Unlike previous cases of mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund, this case did not relate to a specific event, but proposed in advance to mobilise a solidarity fund of up to EUR 50 million to cover advances for 2016. I agree with this measure because it will allow for a faster response in the event of emergencies that could occur in 2016, thereby helping the countries affected by a natural disaster to obtain a deposit more quickly and to cope with at least the most necessary expenditure. Such a rapid response, made possible by the mobilisation of the Fund, is invaluable in the event of natural disasters.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 In a framework of major budgetary constraints in the national contributions to the EU budget, we see here the cut of EUR 11 million, which will directly affect the budget lines dedicated to the protection, the control and control of plant and animal pests. There is talk of a significant increase in youth employment programmes, but given that Erasmus+ represents a minimal part of the EU budget, a 30% increase in this programme will not have much impact. The European Parliament is committed to reducing around 179 jobs by 2019, with 60 jobs expected to be finished in 2016, which means an increase in redundancies and a decrease in the quality of services. This is not a fairer budget, with greater contributions from the member states that have the most wealth, but a restrictive budget.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the joint draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 because it reflects political priorities, as it brings an increase in funding for humanitarian aid, Horizon 2020, Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, erasmus+ and the financing of migration measures in the Member States that bear the highest share of the refugee crisis, and also contains a commitment to continue the youth employment initiative and reduce backlogs in unpaid accounts.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The health of citizens is a key priority of the European Union (EU), so the Commission's draft implementing decision authorising the use of diethyl sulphthalate appears nonsensical and contrary to fundamental principles. Phthalates are chemicals obtained by industrial distillation from petroleum, which are commonly added to plastic to make it flexible. However, they are not all the same: some are considered harmless to human health, while others are very dangerous. Diethylylphthalate (DEHP) is an endocrine disruptant; this substance is already classified as toxic to reproduction and is included in the list of substances extremely worrying by the REACH Regulation, that is, those substances for which the likelihood of serious effects on human health or the environment is scientifically proven. This resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft. The health of citizens, for us in the 5 Star Movement, is always in first place and for this reason my vote was positive.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I consider the authorization of use for DEHP, a substance whose toxicity as an endocrine disruptor is widely demonstrated — being unacceptable — and may cause cancers, malformations and infertility, among other adverse health affections. An initiative, moreover, confirming, together with paralysis in the regulation of endocrine disruptors, that the Commission puts the interests of multinationals before public health in this area. Such authorisation cannot be justified for technical reasons, taking into view the existence of substitutes for that chemical, and puts the health of workers exposed to it at risk. This is a serious precedent and I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because Article 1 of REACH states that the aim of the regulation is to ensure a high level of protection of human health and the environment, and that only substances that do not adversely affect human health and the environment are put on the market. The proposal of the Commission to authorise through an implementing act DEHP in PVC plastic in spite of grave concerns regarding the impact of this chemical on human health is deeply worrying. DEHP has been shown in animal studies to damage the liver, kidneys, lungs and reproductive organs of males.  This chemical is a phthalate which is a member of the family of ‘gender-bending’ chemicals.  By authorising this chemical the Commission would be putting cheap plastic goods ahead of the risks to male fertility and misformed sex organs in prenatal and neo natal males.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Diethylhexyl phthalate (DEHP) falls under the category of so-called endocrine disruptors. These are chemicals that can have a harmful effect on the human hormonal system. For example, they can lead to breast cancer, infertility, diabetes or even Alzheimer's. DEHP is mainly used as a plasticizer in the recycling process of plastic objects. This fabric is found in all consumer goods of daily use, such as textiles, furniture and building materials. Scientific tests have shown that DEHP affects the hormonal system of mammals and can even lead to irreversible consequences for human reproduction. Against this background, and because there are already less harmful, usable and cheaper alternatives, I fully support this resolution, which opposes a permit for recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The purpose of the text is to obstruct the marketing authorization of DEHP, an endocrine disruptor. This product is present in many everyday elements consisting of recycled PVC. For the time being, the Commission refuses to make a proposal on endocrine disruptors. Therefore, the only levers available to parliamentarians are objections to delegated and enforcement acts. Indeed, the commercial stakes are high and the Commission shows little interest in the health cause and the citizens.  That is why I opposed it by voting against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise that there are concerns with this chemical; however, this is a matter which should be dealt with by the Member States themselves. I do not have enough information to know at what pace the use of this chemical should be phased out.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which opposes the authorisation of phthalate bis, because it is dangerous for humans and especially for male fertility.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the rejection of this resolution, which deals with the authorisation of the use of the substances bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP). DEHP is a well-known dangerous chemical. This substance is classified as a substance of very high concern because it is dangerous for the reproductive system, has adverse effects on the endocrine system and has negative effects on the environment. I therefore support the call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft that would reject applications for authorisation of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 Phthaates are commonly used to soften PVC. Based on years of studies on their environmental and health impact, we can make a sharp distinction between low molecular weight phtalates containing short hydrocarbon chains and high molecular weight phtalates containing a long hydrocarbon chain. The results of a large number of studies, including those of a number of independent organisms, have shown that phtalates with high molecular weight do not pose any health risk to the human body. The competent bodies of the EU have therefore decided that they should not be labelled restrictively and should not be added to the list of substances to be authorised.  At the same time, low-weight people, which are also on the list of "substances of high concern", have a harmful effect on the hormone system of mammals and have a harmful effect on reproduction, and are currently ingencum into their authorisation. As the Commission is accountable to European citizens and the protection of citizens and the environment from hazardous chemicals is a priority, I supported the decision. This means that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision and submit a new draft decision to Parliament and the Council rejecting the granting of authorisation.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this report which rejects the Commission's decision on the authorisation of the use of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP. Studies have shown that this component is harmful to living organisms.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. DEHP is a dangerous product and alternatives to this product exist. I believe that, given the evidence, it cannot be used and allowed for applications in consumer goods. For example, cases of genital malformations have been found in infants exposed in utero to DEHP. In electronics, for example, the product is already banned and there are substitutes.  I therefore voted in favour of this report in order to ban DEHP, again deploring the Commission's stubborn refusal to make a proposal on endocrine disruptors, the work under way gives hope of a proposal by the end of 2016.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions supported in this resolution, which is a mere act of opposition to the authorisation for the uses of di-2-ethylphthalate (DEHP), which is totally for its own ends, by the Greens and the GUE. That is why I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. DEHP is included in Annex XIV to the REACH Regulation, due to its classification as a toxic substance for reproduction. In fact, it was one of the first six compounds to gradually disappear under the Regulation. On 12 November, the European Commission presented a draft implementing act on DEHP. According to the opinion of the Risk Assessment Committee, applicants for the grant of authorisation did not demonstrate that the health risks to workers arising from the requested uses are adequately monitored in accordance with the REACH Regulation and that authorisation should not be granted on this basis. The Socio-Economic Analysis Committee also confirmed that there were significant deficiencies in the applicant's socio-economic analysis, including the total lack of a health impact assessment identifying risk to workers. I have therefore supported Parliament's motion for a Resolution which considers that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds the powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 and demands its withdrawal and the submission of a new one rejecting applications for authorisation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which advises on the authorisation of the use of the chemicals bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP). The Commission is accountable to European society for protecting citizens and the environment from dangerous chemicals, while promoting innovation, including in the area of safer chemicals and products, in order to foster a resilient economy. The European Parliament therefore considers that the Commission's decision to authorise the use of the substances bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006. The European Parliament is concerned about human health and environmental protection and therefore calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft to reject applications for authorisation of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this decision because it is a substance that has been proven to be reproductively toxic. DEHP is an endocrine disruptor used as a plasticizer, but it's time to ban it and start using less dangerous compounds instead. DEHP in PVC is widely used in everyday consumer products, such as textiles, furniture and building materials. But since it is not chemically attached to plastic, it easily gets into the environment.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This resolution aims to prevent the approval of DEHP, a derivative of phthalate, already identified for its endocrine disrupting properties and retrioxic risk. It is present in many everyday products (products made from recycled PVC, from shoes to windows). An initial application for marketing authorisation had failed, but this time, against all odds, the Commission is ready to authorise it. I supported this resolution and therefore voted in favour.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because Article 1 of REACH states that the aim of the regulation is to ensure a high level of protection of human health and the environment, and that only substances that do not adversely affect human health and the environment are put on the market. The proposal of the Commission to authorise through an implementing act DEHP in PVC plastic in spite of grave concerns regarding the impact of this chemical on human health is deeply worrying. DEHP has been shown in animal studies to damage the liver, kidneys, lungs and reproductive organs of males.  This chemical is a phthalate which is a member of the family of ‘gender-bending’ chemicals.  By authorising this chemical the Commission would be putting cheap plastic goods ahead of the risks to male infertility and misformed sex organs in prenatal and neo natal males.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This resolution aims to prevent the authorisation of DEHP, a derivative of phthalate. This product is already identified for its endocrine disruptor properties, i.e. a source of physiological and reproductive abnormalities. DEHP is present in many everyday products and can easily be spread by contact. There are also alternatives identified as reliable. However, the European Commission is ready to allow it on the market, because behind the purely health issues, its ban would have trade consequences especially with the United States, which does not want new regulations in this area to affect their exports of agricultural products. Unlike the Commission, whose priority is to maintain good trade relations with the United States, we consider the health of our fellow citizens to be paramount. It turns out that this product has particularly harmful properties. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) may lead to undesirable effects with regard to the endocrine system of at least one animal species. This substance is of major concern because the serious effects lead to human health problems. Given the effects not at all beneficial to both animals and humans, I believe that urgent measures must be taken to unblock this situation. We cannot be pursued solely by financial interests, given that although the Risk Assessment Committee (CER) has recognised the way DEHP acts on the endocrine system, the Committee for Socio-Economic Analysis (CASE) is of the opinion that the economic benefits of using this substance are greater than the risks it entails to human health. I have expressed my favour in favour of this report because I believe that we are responsible to the European public for protecting our citizens and the environment from hazards, such as hazardous chemicals.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Objection to a draft Commission implementing decision: The Commission is asked to withject it and submit a new one rejecting applications for authorisation for the formulation of soft recycled PVC containing DEHP. In September 2014, ECHA recommended the authorisation of DEHP for use in specific applications, including recycled soft PVC. The reasons given by the Greens and GUE, the promoters of the objection, appear to be largely dictated by their usual injury to the chemical industry.  I therefore voted against.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the fact that bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) is a known toxic substance, classified by the REACH Regulation as a toxic substance of high concern, affecting reproduction, which is scientifically proven, as well as the endocrine system in the environment. Applicants have not fulfilled the conditions for granting the authorisation, as they have not demonstrated that all risks in the procedures applied are adequately controllable. They have also not demonstrated that the socio-economic benefits gained from the processing of this substance are greater than the risks that would be required in the use of DEHP, as well as the absence of suitable alternatives. There are much safer alternatives to the substances, materials, procedures and technologies used on the European market. What I think must be taken seriously are innovation and the principles of the circular economy. That is why I raised the objection to the granting of an authorisation to use bis phthalate(2-ethylhexyl).

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the objection under Article 106 of the Regulation concerning the granting of an authorisation for the uses of di-2-ethylphthalate (DEHP). DEHP is classified as an extremely worrying toxic substance, due to its endocrine disrupting properties in the environment. This endocrine interference activity has been scientifically proven and has adverse causal effects on human health. In fact, exposure to DEHP during the adolescent development phase can cause irreversible effects on the organism, with serious consequences even serious for reproduction that can occur for the first time even after many years. The text before the House proposes that the Commission withdraw its draft implementing decision and present a new one, in which it undertakes to reject applications for authorisation for the use of materials containing DEHP. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This was a very important resolution despite it not being binding as it is an implementing act and not a delegated act. However, it was important to vote in favour of this resolution in order to signify to national governments the dangers of DEHP as these governments still have to decide on whether they accept the Commission’s draft decision to authorise DEHP.  The proposal of the Commission to authorise DEHP in PVC plastic in spite of grave concerns regarding the impact of this chemical on human health is deeply worrying. DEHP has been shown in animal studies to damage the liver, kidneys, lungs and reproductive organs of males. This chemical is a phthalate which is a member of the family of ‘gender-bending’ chemicals.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled product containing soft DEHP PVC, i.e. die-ylylphthalate.  Phthalates are chemicals, obtained by industrial distillation from petroleum, which are commonly added to plastic to make it flexible. Phthalates are found everywhere, from floors to disposable bottles, from synthetic clothing fabrics to toys. These substances are classified as toxic, which can be replaced by a number of other less dangerous substances.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection requesting the rejection of the exemption for the authorization of DEHP phthalate for recycling, as phthalates are substances harmful to human health and DEHP is identified as a potentially carcinogenic substance. They can be easily replaced in production with safer materials. For this reason, I do not support their recycling and reintroduction to the European market.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – MEPs clearly expressed the view that the Commission must not allow the recycling of plastics that contain phthalates (DEHP). This substance is classified under EU law as toxic to reproduction, and Member State representatives in the EU Chemicals Agency are unanimous about its endocrine disrupting properties. Such hazardous chemicals pose threats to human health and the environment. It makes no sense to allow them to remain present in recycled PVC materials. This is a matter of particular concern to the health of workers who would be manipulating these materials. I congratulate my fellow colleagues who decided to oppose the view that the economic benefits outweigh the risks to human health. We cannot determine what a safe level for endocrine disruptors is, so we must not be making judgements about supposed trade-offs, when the science points to links between the exposure of pregnant women to this type of phthalate and birth defects in baby boys. I hope the Council of EU Member State governments will agree with Parliament when they vote on this matter, so that we can force the hand of the Commission and sort these substances out of the recycling bin.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The resolution states that the Commission is accountable to the European public for protecting citizens and the environment from hazardous chemicals, as well as for promoting innovation, including in the field of safer chemicals and products in order to promote a resilient economy. We agree with the resolution, which will be forwarded by the President to the Council and the Commission.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the Commission's implementing decision authorising the use of phthalate di (2-ethylexyl) ester, commonly known as DEHP, is essentially opposed to authorising the use of a dangerous substance that threatens the entire population every day.  It has already been scientifically proven that the use of DEHP in a range of everyday products poses a risk to embryos, newborn children and pregnant women. At the same time, it causes a number of endocrine disorders that often become apparent with a long delay.  Therefore, authorisation for the use of this substance is against the objectives and basic principles of REACH and we must support any initiative that defends these principles. For all the above reasons, I have decided to support this resolution.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection, pursuant to Rule 106 of the Regulation, to the granting of an authorisation for the uses of DEHP. Indeed, the European Commission has presented a draft decision, which has not yet been approved by the Member States, authorising the recycling of old plastic containing DEHP into new PVC products. DEHP is considered to be a dangerous and toxic substance that interferes with the endocrine system of mammals, as is scientifically proven, and is banned from the REACH Regulation on the registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemicals.  Parliament is concerned that it has not been demonstrated that the health risks to workers have been adequately controlled and stresses the seriousness of the negative effects that can be caused by DEHP. The EP therefore rejects the granting of an authorisation for the uses of DEHP.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, as DEHP has been identified as an extremely worrying substance as it meets the criteria of substance having properties that disrupt the endocrine system for which the likelihood of serious effects on human health is scientifically proven. In addition, scientific studies have shown that exposure to DEHP, during sensitive time windows of development, can cause irreversible effects in development planning with serious consequences for development and reproduction. Finally, given that the Commission has a responsibility to protect European citizens and at the same time to promote innovation, including with regard to safer substances and chemicals in order to promote a resilient economy, I call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft rejecting applications for authorisation.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with what the rapporteurs have said about the rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of soft recycled PVC containing DEHP, especially as applicants have not demonstrated the level of risk to the health of workers handling this type of substance and have not provided a comprehensive analysis of the alternatives available on the market to replace DEHP, and socio-economic analysis has also shown no obvious economic benefits. Therefore, given also the danger of DEHP as a toxic substance to health, which is included in Annex XIV to reach, It seems appropriate to me to reject applications for authorisation and to safeguard the protection of human health and the environment.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) is a manufactured chemical that is commonly added to plastics to make them flexible.
