It meets the criteria of the REACH Regulation as it is a substance with endocrine disrupting properties and having serious effects on human health. For this reason I agree that the Commission should reject the applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled PVC containing DEHP, thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Phthalates are chemicals, obtained by industrial distillation from oil, which are commonly added to plastic to make it flexible. There are phthalates in the floors and wall coverings, even in the office stationery and toys. There are low molecular weights, the most dangerous for human health and the environment, and high molecular weight, considered safe by the European authorities. This substance, already classified as toxic, can be replaced by a number of other substances that are less dangerous. The motion for a resolution considers that the draft implementing decision exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 and calls on the Commission to submit a new draft rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled product containing soft DEHP PVC. My vote can only be in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. – I consider the authorisation of use for DEHP, a substance whose toxicity as an endocrine disruptor is widely demonstrated — may cause cancers, malformations and infertility, among other adverse health affections, unacceptable. An initiative, moreover, confirming, together with paralysis in the regulation of endocrine disruptors, that the Commission puts the interests of multinationals before public health in this area. Such authorisation cannot be justified for technical reasons, taking into view the existence of substitutes for that chemical, and puts the health of workers exposed to it at risk. This is a serious precedent and I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to submit a new draft implementing decision which would reject all applications for authorisation to prepare recycled soft PVC preparations containing DEHP. I believe that such an objection would be disproportionate. It would also apply to non-recyclable materials. Moreover, the question of a formal nature, i.e. whether Parliament has any power to oppose implementing acts at all, is questionable. I believe that a threshold should be set for the use of DEHP to be considered safe and strict rules for monitoring the use of this phthalate. This would be in line with the recommendations of the Opinion of the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA). There is also a need to discuss the use of DEHP for recycling in industry, as the production costs of new PVC compared to recycled are 28 times higher. I therefore voted against a resolution which does not authorize the use of DEHP without exception.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of objecting to the Commission’s draft measure that grants to certain legal entities such as chemical and PVC manufacturing companies authorisation of the use of DEHP phthalate. DEHP PVC has been widely used in everyday products, such as artificial Christmas trees, textiles, furniture, shoes, building materials, etc. and is considered a toxic to reproduction, an endocrine disruptor and immune toxicant, according to the REACH regulation. Possible consequences include genital malformation, and it can significantly increase the risk of male infertility. The wide and continued use of DEHP is a serious threat to our health, and in line with the recommendation of the European Chemicals Agency and its Risk Assessment Committee, the substance should be fully prohibited in Europe. Moreover, the Commission’s authorisation did not provide comprehensive analysis of the alternative or an acceptable risk assessment of health impacts.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution calls on the Commission and the Council not to allow the recycling of plastics containing the flexibilizing additive DEHP for the production of PVC for the manufacture, among other things, of shoes or floor coverings, because of its toxicity to reproduction. DEHP has been the main phthalate of common use for the past 50 years. Under reach, it has been classified as a substance of great concern, and cannot be used without the authorisation of the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA). The use of DEHP is also prohibited in the production of toys, children's items and cosmetics. The Commission proposed, in a draft decision that requires the Council's approval, to allow the recycling of old plastics containing DEHP for the manufacture of new products. DEHP is known to disrupt the endocrine system of mammals, including a decrease in the level of testosterone in the fetus. It can thus affect the rate of development of the individual as well as his reproductive abilities. For these reasons, I have decided to oppose the Commission's draft decision.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection. Indeed, I am against granting an authorisation for this product for which there are safer alternatives for health. In addition, the European Chemicals Agency's report has not been able to demonstrate the complete safety of this product and the ability to guarantee and control its proper use.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported this resolution because I believe that the European Commission should not allow the recycling of plastics containing the flexibilizing additive DEHP for the production of new products. DEHP is known for its toxicity. It disrupts the endocrine system and can affect the individual's rate of development as well as his reproductive abilities. Recycling needs to be further developed and encouraged, but this argument cannot justify the use of substances whose waste can be dangerous. I am also concerned that the operators who have applied for DEHP recycling authorization have not demonstrated that workers will be adequately protected from health risks.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This objection was intended to prevent the marketing of phthalate bis (2-ethylhexyl) or DEHP. While the harmfulness of phthalates has long been proven by numerous scientific studies, the Commission is once again far behind on the subject. By providing for a general legislative proposal on the ban on phthalates only in 2016, the Commission is currently doing nothing to protect consumers from the dangers these chemicals pose to the health of citizens. All means are therefore good to, if not better, individually ban certain types of phthalates among the most harmful, of which DEHP is a part. So I voted for its ban.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ I disagree with the objector's concerns and support these authorisations on grounds of increasing the predictability and transparency of the REACH authorisation procedure and promoting the circular economy. Under this procedure, a substance of very high concern cannot be used after a specified date unless authorised; the sunset date for DEHP was 21 February 2015. The authorisations now under consideration would only allow the continued use of recycled PVC to which DEHP was added when first manufactured. It wouldn't permit DEHP to be added to recyclate materials.   There is agreement that DEHP is an endocrine disruptor, but contrary to the objector's assertions, there is also no scientific consensus that a threshold for safe use cannot be identified and applied for endocrine disruptors.  Most importantly, the ECHA’s assessment committees considered that there would be minimal risk to consumers from articles made of recycled PVC, and the implementing act includes monitoring conditions to improve worker protection. The objection should account for the wider implications of not granting authorisation, which includes the circular economy aims, and the prospect of increased environmental damage. Environmental damage costs of manufacturing virgin PVC have been calculated as EUR 394 a tonne, and EUR 14 a tonne for recycling PVC waste.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Positive, because the use of DEHP and similar ingredients, cause endocrine activity disorders with direct effect on human health.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 DEHP was included in the list of 553 category I candidate substances of chemicals that have been shown to have harmful endocrine effects on at least one species using intact animals. It was also one of the first six compounds to be phased out under reach. However, DEHP should be identified as a substance of high concern, as it is a substance with endocrine disrupting properties, for which there is scientific evidence that it is likely to have serious effects on human health. I therefore agree with a new draft rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled flexible PVC containing DEHP.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Phthahighs are a family of industrial chemicals used to make PVC plastic flexible and as solvents in cosmetics and other consumer products. Studies indicate that these chemical compounds can affect the liver, kidneys, lungs and hormonal and reproductive systems of mammals and are therefore included in reach due to their classification as a toxic substance for reproduction. This proposal for objections relates to the commission's draft implementing decision granting an authorisation for the use of bis phtharate (2-ethyl-hexyl) (DEHP). This act of implementation presupposes a broader authorization for the use and formulation of recycled PVC containing DEHP. This would lead to a continued presence of hazardous substances in products made of recycled material, thereby perpetuating the use of hazardous substances through recycling rather than their replacement. This objection also considers that the Commission's draft implementing decision, which proposes to authorise the use of these products for another 7 years, exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006, and calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft decision by submitting a draft rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled flexible PVC containing DEHP. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the resolution is positive from a public health perspective.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because there is no doubt that OSH rules need to be adapted to more advanced and stringent standards in several Member States. In this respect, the Commission's action can have meaning and effectiveness.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the objection pursuance to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: granting authorisation for uses of phthalate di (2-ethylexyl) ester (DEHP), because the use of DEHP and similar ingredients causes endocrine activity disorders with direct effect on human health.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ DEHP is as a substance of very high concern and, already in 2000, it was included in Annex 1 setting out the candidate list of 553 substances under category I of chemicals that showed evidence of endocrine disrupting activity in at least one species using intact animals. On 12 December 2014, the Member State Committee (MSC) unanimously agreed to the identification of DEHP as a substance giving rise to an equivalent level of concern due to its endocrine disrupting properties in the environment(6); the MSC unanimously acknowledged that, in the case of DEHP, there is scientific evidence on endocrine disrupting activity and on the causal link between this activity and adverse effects on human health. I therefore supported the call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft rejecting the applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers set out in the relevant regulation. There are a number of questions regarding the authorisation of the use of these substances.  I am concerned that DEHP has been shown to adversely affect the hormone system in mammals due to a decrease in testosterone levels.  Furthermore, scientific evidence shows that DEHP exposure during sensitive periods of development can cause irreversible effects on the development programme, which have serious effects on development and reproduction and are considered particularly serious for human health and wild species.  It is known that DEHP can be replaced by a number of substances and that the applicants have not provided a comprehensive analysis of the alternative options available on the market for the uses requested in order to replace the use of DEHP.  In the light of the above, I consider it appropriate to call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft rejecting applications for authorisation for recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the view that DEHP is included in Annex XIV to Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 (REACH Regulation) because of its classification as a category 1B substance, toxic for reproduction and which is on the list of candidate substances in the REACH Regulation because of its toxic properties for reproduction. The European institutions must legislate always taking into account the security of European citizens.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision on the granting of an authorisation for the uses of di-2-ethylfrtalate (DEHP) under Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 because I believe that the ENVI Commission has taken the right decision to prohibit the use of this substance by means of the objection voted on today. I believe that health is an absolute value that the European Commission has a duty to promote and defend even by sacrificing certain economic freedoms.  Given the available scientific evidence and the tests carried out, I agree with the follow-up to the various scientific reports which classify DEHP compounds as substances toxic to reproduction and place them in the category of endocrine disruptors.  We have a duty to protect European workers from the possible consequences of long exposures to these substances. I therefore welcome the large majority in which Parliament rejected the proposed implementing act and call on the Commission to definitively ban the use of this substance in the circular economy.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the rejection of Article 106 of the CRP: Authorisation of uses of diethylhexyl phthalate (DEHP) for purely technical and political reasons, as the European Commission is using the instrument of implementing powers here, although the area is not covered by the agreements with Parliament. I cannot agree with such an overstepping of competence.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. DEHP is a chemical used in plastic production. As an important component, it makes the plastic to be produced more elastic. However, DEHP can also pose a significant risk to human health and the environment. That is why I support this motion.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new draft rejecting the applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP, given the Commission is accountable to the European public for protecting citizens and the environment from hazardous chemicals, while promoting innovation, including in the area of safer chemicals and products to foster a resilient economy.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The REACH Regulation includes DEHP within substances with highly concerned properties whose use requires prior authorisation at European level. In this motion for a Resolution we oppose the authorization that has been granted for its use since no adequate impact studies have been carried out to assess both the risk and benefits that the use of this substance would have.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is intended to prevent the authorisation of DEHP, a derivative of phthalate. This product is already identified as an endocrine disruptor, presenting a retrioxic risk, i.e. a risk to fertility. As a result, it had not been authorized in a previous application.  But this time, the European Commission is ready to allow it, when there are reliable substitutes.  In fact, the European Union has been "warned" by the United States and the WTO that regulations on endocrine disruptors would be bad for global trade. The US government is concerned that a possible European regulation on endocrine disruptors could "undermine European imports of products from American agriculture".  It is therefore understandable that public health is not the priority, neither of the Americans nor of the European Commission, which stubbornly refuses to make a proposal on endocrine disruptors, thus showing a suspicious wait-and-see attitude on this subject.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this non-binding motion for a resolution, which calls on the Commission not to authorize DEHP (Dietil hexyl phthalate). It is a well-known toxic substance. It has been proposed to be included in the list of substances of high concern about its effects of endocrine alteration. It is found in Annex XIV to the REACH Regulation due to its toxicity to the reproductive system. DEHP is a phthalate, a group of chemicals that cause the feminization of males of exposed species. These substances affect the endocrine system of fauna and, potentially, also that of humans. It can cause breast and testicle cancer, congenital malformations and infertility, among other adverse health effects. Due to its disrupting properties of the endocrine system, a safe exposure threshold cannot be set for DEHP with sufficient certainty. Environmental, health, medical, cancer prevention advocates, have joined women's organizations and medical organizations to strongly oppose DEHP's authorization in PVC materials, due to its high toxicity. European regulations have already restricted their use in toys and child care items.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to prevent the commercialization of phthalate 2 bis (DEHP), a toxic chemical component suspected of having neuroendocrine effects. Phthalate 2 bis is already banned in toys and in most electrical and electronic devices, but remains used in many products, including consumer items containing PVC (plastics, textiles, shoes, etc.).  In view of the availability of safer alternatives that can replace this component, and given that the expertise of the European Chemicals Agency has not been able to conclude that this product is fully safe for health, and has failed to demonstrate the possibility of effectively monitoring and framing its use, I have felt that we should not renew the authorisation of this substance.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the objection pursuant to Rule 106: granting an authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl)phthalate (DEHP). EHP should be identified as a substance of very high concern because it meets the criteria set out in Article 57(f) of the REACH Regulation in that it is a substance with endocrine disrupting properties for which there is scientific evidence of probable serious effects on human health, which give rise to a level of concern equivalent to that for other substances listed in points of the REACH Regulation.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the objection as proposed by the ENVI committee. Since there is a high risk that DEHP can affect the human reproductive system, and its application in PVC products is not well specified, I cannot support granting authorisation for use of this substance.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the objection of granting an authorisation for uses of bis (2-ethykhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP) under the REACH Regulation. DEHP is a highly toxic substance placed on the hazardous substance of very high concern list by the REACH Regulation because of its reproductive toxicity that can lead to male infertility even after very short exposures to the substance. Substances defined as hazardous substances of very high concern may not be placed on the market unless authorised for a specific use that has been granted by the EC (European Commission) through an implementing act. The application for the use of DEHP as a plasticiser in the production of recycled PVC plastic that was approved by the EC shows significant deficiencies in evidence of safe use and bases the authorisation on assumed socio-economic benefits. Furthermore, according to the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA), the application failed to give the necessary safety data or any adequate controls of health risks to workers, therefore although the key issue at stake here is the health risks to the workers exposed, my objection also refers to the larger concerns about the toxicity of DEHP for the general public.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this motion as DEHP has been identified as a substance which poses serious risks to human health and wildlife species. Scientific evidence on DEHP shows that exposure during sensitive time windows of development may cause irreversible developmental programming effects leading to severe effects on development and reproduction in both humans and wildlife.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. This opposition rejects the granting of an authorisation for the use of diethylhexyl phthalate (DEHP) in recycled PVC. This opposition rejects the authorisation decision of the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) on the grounds that it is incompatible with REACH. REACH is the European regulation on the registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemical substances. ECHA found that there is a minimal risk to consumers. The objection ignores far-reaching impacts on the circular economy, which is intended to promote recycling in Europe, as well as increased environmental damage from the production of newly produced PVCs without recycling. I voted against the objection because I consider scientific advice to be important and I do not want political disputes to determine the legislation. Parliament should support the circular economy and promote transparency with regard to REACH. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished, because it leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. \u2012 Chemicals legislation is now in the application phase. Reach's core is the Agency's assessment of particularly dangerous substances. It is generally recognised and scientifically proven that DEHP causes infertility and irreversible changes in men even after short exposure. The Agency also clearly states this in its positive decision. Nevertheless, the Commission is proposing to approve the substance. The preliminary data provided by the applicants were incomplete and the health risk analysis could not be carried out thoroughly due to the lack of data. Although the burden of proof is on applicants, the Agency supplemented the application as its own work. The application of REACH is a learning process that is still at an early stage. I hope that this objection will send a clear signal to the Commission, the Council, the applicants and the Agency. There's still a lot of learning to do.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision issuing authorisations for the use of di (2-ethylhexyl) phthalates (DEHP) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013. 1907/2006 Of Parliament and the Council, as this requires the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision. DEHP is an extremely toxic substance, prohibited under REACH as it causes health problems for workers exposed to it during the recycling process. There are also concerns about its public health implications and there is no concrete data on the health risk control carried out for workers, and I therefore support this resolution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text obstructs the marketing authorization of DEHP, an endocrine disruptor. This product is present in many everyday elements consisting of recycled PVC.  The Commission still refuses to make a proposal on endocrine disruptors.  Thus, the only levers available to parliamentarians are objections to delegated and enforcement acts. The Commission seems to be disinterested in the health cause and of the citizens.  I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Today I voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP) along with my fellow colleagues. We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the objection to the granting of authorisation to phthalates bis (DEHP). Indeed, phthalate bis-(2-ethylhexyle) is a highly toxic product and the European Chemicals Agency has not been able in its report to convincingly demonstrate that the use of this product was not dangerous and that control of its proper use could be guaranteed satisfactorily.  There are also alternatives to this substance less harmful to health, making phthalate bis-(2-ethylhexyle) useless. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to ban the use of phthalate bis-(2-ethylhexyle), because there are safer alternatives for health than this product.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to raise the dangerousness of bis (2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP), a substance commonly used as a plasticizer because of its adequate properties and low cost. Scientific evidence suggests that it contains properties that disrupt the endocrine system and have adverse effects on the reproduction and health of newborns, women and workers. Under REACH, DEHP is one of the first six compounds to be removed from circulation. The resolution disapproves of the Commission's measure authorising the use of the substance for 7 years because the measure will generalise the manufacture of consumer products in recycled PVC containing DEHP and will violate the REACH regulation and the principles of the circular economy. For this reason, I voted for it.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on granting permission for the use of phthalate bis-(2-ethylhexyle), DEHP. DEHP is a dangerous product, alternatives exist, it may not be allowed for targeted applications in consumer goods.  I also supported the amendments recalling the genital malformations suffered by newborns exposed in utero to DEHP, and stressing that public health takes precedence over recycling targets.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I consider the authorization of use for DEHP, a substance whose toxicity as an endocrine disruptor is widely demonstrated — being unacceptable — and may cause cancers, malformations and infertility, among other adverse health affections. An initiative, moreover, confirming, together with paralysis in the regulation of endocrine disruptors, that the Commission puts the interests of multinationals before public health in this area. Such authorisation cannot be justified for technical reasons, taking into view the existence of substitutes for that chemical, and puts the health of workers exposed to it at risk. This is a serious precedent and I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Health-hazardous phthalates should not endanger consumers. But the question is professional and not political, which is a dangerous phthalate.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 DEHP is included in Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006 (REACH) due to its classification as a category 1B reproductive toxic substance. The Commission is accountable to the European public when it comes to protecting citizens and the environment from hazardous chemicals. The Draft Implementing Decision of the Commission exceeds the powers provided for in the Regulation, so I supported the objection of members of the European Parliament, as I consider it well founded and that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing decision and submit to the Committee a new draft on the rejection of the application for authorisation of the composition of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 Bis(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (DEHP) is an organic chemical compound used as a plasticiser. Even with france and Denmark banning the use of this compound in chemical production on their own without waiting for the relevant European Union legislation, DEHP is still a very widely used substance on the EU as a whole (around half the plastic industry) which, unfortunately, has not yet been a complete substitute. For almost five years now, the European Commission has been planning to significantly restrict or ban the use of DEHP in a way or another. One of the primary reasons is the potential harm this substance can cause, for example, to children when they often put different toys and other objects in their mouths. There is also potential damage in terms of fertility, kidney function, as well as in cases of use of medical instruments. In other words, it would be quite logical in the perspective to abandon the use of DEHP, but there must be a rational correlation between the desire to protect our citizens and our consumers – young children first – and economic development in the sense that there is still, as mentioned above, a full replacement for this type of phthalate.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament rejected the European Commission's proposal to grant authorisation for the composition of recycled soft PVC containing bis(2-ethyl ethyl)-phthalate (DEHP). This substance was already classified in 2006 for its composition and effects as a toxic substance for reproduction. It is striking that, despite the existence of suitable dehp alternatives, the applicant did not submit their comprehensive analysis for use as set out in the request. The EP drew attention to the obligation to protect human health and the environment.  This was the clear reason why the European Parliament called on the Commission to come forward with a new proposal rejecting the application for authorisation to use DEHP.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's implementing decision on the authorisation for the use of phthalate di (2-ethylexyl) ester (DEHP) pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this opposition. It is an objection procedure that allows an MP to object to an act of execution.  Here, the rapporteur opposes the authorisation to use DEHP. This product is a derivative of phthalate, and is present in many everyday objects. It diffuses through contact, and is known for its endocrine disruptor properties. It should be noted that the issue is at another level: the European Commission stubbornly refuses to make a proposal on these endocrine disruptors following pressure from the United States and the WTO. Such a European regulation would have consequences on world trade and curb "European imports of products from American agriculture". The health of citizens therefore seems secondary to the Commission. We are opposed to that attitude.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which makes it clear that the EU should not authorise the recycling of plastics that contain the banned softener diethylhexyl phthalate (DHEP), to make soft PVC items such as footwear and floor coverings, because it poses a reproductive toxicity threat to exposed workers and could render their male foetuses sterile.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Bis (2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP) is a substance that increases the flexibility of plastics. Its action as an endocrine disruptor has been recognized as well as its irreversible effects on development and reproduction. However, the Socio-Economic Analysis Committee concluded that "the socio-economic benefits derived from the uses covered by the application outweighed the risks arising from these uses to human health" thus allowing the Commission to authorize the use of this substance by act of execution. The report before us opposes this decision because of the high toxicity of this substance and the existence of a wide range of deH replacement substances. I'm voting for this report.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The purpose of the text is to obstruct the marketing authorization of DEHP, an endocrine disruptor. This product is present in many everyday elements consisting of recycled PVC. For the time being, the Commission refuses to make a proposal on endocrine disruptors. Therefore, the only levers available to parliamentarians are objections to delegated and enforcement acts. Indeed, the commercial stakes are high and the Commission shows little interest in the health cause and the citizens. Naturally, the member therefore supports this objection.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision XXX granting authorisation for the uses of bis phtharate (2-ethyl-hexyl) (DEHP) under Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council. DEHP should be identified as a substance of great concern. The DEHP fulfils the criteria laid down in Article 57(f) of the REACH Regulation, as it is a substance with endocrine disrupting properties, for which there is scientific evidence that it is likely to have serious effects on human health. It is extremely important that EU citizens are aware of the danger of these substances.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ DEHP is classified under EU law as toxic to reproduction, and Member State representatives in the EU Chemicals Agency are unanimous about its endocrine disrupting properties. Therefore I chose to vote in favour of the objection to authorise DEHP’s use.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome the European Parliament's rejection of the Commission's draft decision on plastic recycling containing DEHP.  I join the majority of my colleagues who have expressed their concern about this phthalate, which is known for its ability to disrupt the endocrine system, in their vote. Since this chemical is considered "very worrying" under the REACH regulation and to the extent that the effects of endocrine disruptors on human health must be fully taken into account, the shortcomings of the application for authorisation convinced Parliament to oppose the Commission's proposal.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 DEHP is a known toxic substance of significant concern due to its toxicity to reproduction and disruption of the endocrine system in the environment. We have more and more evidence of adverse effects of the substance on humans, yet this substance is used in everyday products. Since the substance is not chemically linked to plastic, it easily escapes into the environment, which I find an alarming fact. Companies have not been able to ensure a sufficient level of risk control or demonstrate whether the socio-economic benefits outweigh these health risks. There are also safer alternatives, but a comprehensive analysis of alternatives on the market has not been presented. Parliament is therefore asking the Commission to submit a new proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on objection pursuant to Rule 106: granting an authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). DEHP is a phthalate, a group of ‘gender-bending’ chemicals which cause the males of species to become more female. These chemicals have disrupted the endocrine systems of wildlife, causing breast and testicular cancers, birth malformations and infertility, to name just a few. Moreover, it is also a suspected carcinogen and a neuro and immune toxicant. DEHP in PVC is widely used in everyday products in a very wide range of PVC consumer articles such as artificial Christmas trees, textiles, furniture, shoes, building materials, etc. Furthermore, it is still the chemical that is most commonly notified to the EU RAPEX system as posing a chemical risk. Safer alternatives are available. Alternatives for the uses of DEHP in PVC and for the uses of PVC containing DEHP products and articles are available on the European market, including alternative substances, materials, processes and technologies.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 DEHP is a widely used substance in PVC, but it is not chemically bound to plastic and thus easily leaks into the environment. There is scientific evidence of the endocrine disrupting effect of DEHP and the cau cauve link between this effect and adverse effects on human health. The Commission has submitted a draft implementing decision which would allow applications for authorisation to use recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.  Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety points out in its report that it considers that the draft Commission implementing decision goes beyond the implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 and therefore recommends that Parliament call on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing decision and submit a new draft rejecting applications for authorisation for recycled soft PVC containing DEHP. I supported the proposal.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to prevent the marketing authorization of DEHP (a derivative of phthalate), which is an endocrine disruptor. At the time of his previous application, he had not obtained marketing authorization because of his re-toxic risk. Today, the Commission wants to authorise it. However, this product, present in many everyday products (especially recycled PVC products), is easily transmitted by contact.   It is clear that both internal and external pressures (the United States and the WTO push for the authorisation of this substance in the name of international trade) partly explain the Commission's position of being reluctant to put forward a proposal on endocrine disruptors. The Americans were also concerned about a possible ban on endocrine disruptors in the European Union that would threaten European imports of products from American agriculture.  In other words, public health is being relegated to the background in the name of free trade. So I voted for this critical report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which opposes the use of phthalate bis-(2-ethylhexyle) (DEHP) in the European Union.  The European Chemicals Agency has not been able to demonstrate the safety of this toxic product, which has been shown to have harmful effects on the reproductive system. It is therefore necessary to maintain its ban and to favour existing alternatives for industrial use.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will grant authorisation based on several legal conditions of use for the following substance: bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP).

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection to the granting of permission to use bis(2-ethylhexyl)-phthalate (DEHP). The Chemicals Registration Regulation (REACH) refers to this substance as a substance of serious concern, but allows its use on condition that authorisation is obtained from the European Commission, acting in close cooperation with the European Chemical Agency. I criticise the requests that were the subject of the objection vote for too broad a definition of industrial use, so that risk analysis cannot be reliably carried out and harmful effects excluded. I concluded, together with most of my colleagues, that the applicants were unable to demonstrate that they adequately controlled the risks associated with the use of DEPH. Granting an authorisation would thus, in my view, put at health risk not only workers who come into contact with this substance, but potentially all citizens who may encounter this substance in products of normal consumption.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the rejection under Article 106 of the Rules of Procedure, since I consider the use of diethylhexyl phthalate to be extremely dangerous and, in principle, oppose it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Given that DEHP is dangerous and has harmful effects on the environment and human health, the spread of this chemical needs to be regulated.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. I believe that the Commission should not grant business operators the right to use Bis (2-ethylhexyl) phthalate.  It should be noted that this chemical is dangerous and associated with infertility, cancer, negative effects on the brain. In addition, scientific evidence has been provided on the negative effects on endocrine activity and the causal link between these activities and the adverse effects on human health.  It should be noted that the authorisation would create a very inappropriate precedent for future authorisation decisions under REACH. The use of this substance should therefore be removed promptly from all remaining applications in order to ensure adequate protection for human beings and to eliminate adverse health effects.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the objection to the authorisation of the use of DEHP for the production of soft PVC due to the adverse effects on the health of workers in the production of PVC that could be caused by the use of DEHP.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Di (2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) as a category 1B reproductive toxic substance is on reach's list of substances precisely because of its reproductive toxic properties. Also, the substance poses a potential danger to human health because it accumulates in the body (it is bioacumulative) and affects the endocrine system. The most exposed to the negative effect of this compound are pregnant women and young children. This compound was used as a plastic softener in the manufacture of artificial trees, tablecloths, floor tiles, shower curtains, garden hoses, rain clothes, dolls, toys, shoes, medical equipment (pipes, catheters, bags).  The requirement to extend the use of this substance in recycled plastic products is not a good solution as it would allow this substance to be retained in product cycles. I supported this resolution because I consider it necessary to prevent further authorization of this substance. In this way, this toxic substance will come out of use on the European market and production cycles, which is certainly important in the context of the coming package of circular economy regulations.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to prevent the marketing authorization of DEHP (a derivative of phthalate) which is an endocrine disruptor. At the time of his previous application, he had not obtained marketing authorization because of his re-toxic risk. Today, the Commission wants to authorise it. However, this product, present in many everyday products (especially recycled PVC products) is easily transmitted by contact. It is clear that both internal and external pressures (the United States and the WTO are pushing for the authorisation of this substance in the name of international trade) partly explain the Commission's position of being reluctant to put forward a proposal on endocrine disruptors. The Americans were also concerned about a possible ban on endocrine disruptors in the European Union that would threaten European imports of products from American agriculture. In other words, public health is being relegated to the background in the name of free trade. So I voted for this critical report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 I support the proposal to submit a new draft on the rejection of the application for authorization of the composition of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP with regard to its harmfulness in terms of reproductive toxic properties and endocrine disruption in some animals. In line with reach's core objectives – protecting human health and the environment, promoting alternative methods for assessing substance hazards and increasing competitiveness and innovation – given the widespread distribution of this substance in everyday use and consumption, and as it has not been demonstrated that non-authorisation would result in social and economic costs, I support this proposal as necessary to protect the environment, people and the animal world.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support the motion for a resolution submitted in accordance with Article 106(2) and 3. Rules of procedure on the Commission's draft implementing decision XXX issuing authorisations for the use of di-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalates (DEHP) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of Colleagues of Pavel Poc, Kateřina Konečná and Bas Eickhout. DEHP is a substance for which there is unanimous agreement from Member States that, due to its properties, it has been identified as a category 1B reproductive toxic substance, as confirmed by the mechanistic findings.  There is also scientific evidence of the harmfulness of this substance and the causal link between this action and the adverse effects on human health. It is considered a very dangerous substance because it can cause irreversible consequences on development and reproduction, and adverse effects can also occur at a later age, although a certain period of time has passed since exposure. The opinion of the Socioeconomic Analysis Committee shows that the report on the basis of which the authorisation application was submitted contains significant deficiencies, including a lack of a health impact assessment to identify the residual risk.  I agree with the objection of my fellow MEPs, as the adverse effects can affect the quality of life of European nationals and the environment for which the EU institutions are responsible.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support the European Parliament's resolution strongly calling on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new proposal rejecting applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled softened PVC containing DEHP. The European Union must do its best to protect the health of its citizens. We cannot allow any compromises, we cannot succumb to the pressures of a business that perceives the use of DEHP through the lens of low production costs. DEHP is contained in PVC and is commonly used in everyday products such as clothing, furniture and building materials. Since it is not chemically bound to plastics, it is easy to release into the surrounding environment. It is a 'reprotoxic' substance that disrupts the proper functioning of the hormonal system and is particularly dangerous for pregnant women. We must at least ensure that European DEHP products do not contain them. Clear rules for the recycling of such products, in particular plastic recycling, also need to be laid down.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the objection to the permit, even though it also affects one of the Czech companies. I believe that the use of this DPEH phthalate may put a real threat to public health and the environment at risk. Moreover, I believe that the appellants have not convincingly supported the authorisation that they will be able to control the risks described.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I am opposed to the granting of an authorization for this product called DEHP. The European Agency responsible for granting the authorisations has not been able to fully demonstrate that this product is not toxic. However, there are alternatives.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the resolution Authorisation for uses of bis(2-ethylhexhyl) phthalate (DEHP). We recognise the sensitivity and the importance of this issue and we believe that each Member State should decide in what measure the prohibition should take place.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In 1999, when I arrived in the European Parliament, the European Union banned the use of six phthalates in children's toys, the most common of which was DEHP. This chemical component, derived from phthalic acid, is used as a plasticizer and has been evaluated as an endocrine disruptor, therefore dangerous to human health. This characteristic justifies the extension of the ban in 2005 to all soft PVC childcare items containing phthalates. The European Parliament has again sounded the alarm this afternoon about the massive use of DEHP in everyday objects by adopting a resolution opposing the authorisation of the recycling of plastics containing the PLASTICifier DEHP for the production of PVC. This is contrary to the opinion of the European Commission, which would support it. The reasons given are not convincing: the recycling technique would justify continuing to use substances whose waste can be hazardous and a marketing authorization would allow manufacturers to reduce their production costs. For MEPs, there is no doubt that allowing the production of PVC containing DEHP would be a very regrettable precedent for future authorisation decisions taken under the REACH regulation.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. Parliament has sent a clear message to the Commission by refusing to recycle DEHP. Because they felt that it would be too expensive to use PVC plastic without DEHP (phthalate), three companies had asked to be able to recycle this plastic even when it contains this dangerous substance. In assessing the demand for these companies, the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) has clearly highlighted the disastrous effect of DEHP on the hormonal system.  ECHA has shown the irreversible consequences for the fetus and the risks of developing testicular dysgeesia syndrome (penis malformation and non-descent of the testicles in the bursas often resulting in a decrease in sperm quality) if a pregnant woman is exposed, even for one day, by her work in a PVC recycling plant containing DEHP.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal to allow three European recycling companies to recycle plastics containing the flexibilizing additive called "DEHP" in PVC production. DEHP has properties that disrupt the endocrine system and there is scientific evidence for its harmful effect on human health, resulting in cases of male infertility in exposed workers.  In addition, I stress that the authorisation of the substance is based on the assessment of socio-economic benefits without providing a health impact assessment of workers or a comprehensive analysis of alternative solutions available on the market. Finally, the argument for promoting recycling does not justify the use of hazardous substances and it would be unacceptable to tolerate such a risk of infertility solely on the basis of economic benefit.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. DEHP is included in Annex XIV to the REACH Regulation, due to its classification as a toxic substance for reproduction. In fact, it was one of the first six compounds to gradually disappear under the Regulation. On 12 November, the European Commission presented a draft implementing act on DEHP. According to the opinion of the Risk Assessment Committee, applicants for the grant of authorisation did not demonstrate that the health risks to workers arising from the requested uses are adequately monitored in accordance with the REACH Regulation and that authorisation should not be granted on this basis. The Socio-Economic Analysis Committee also confirmed that there were significant deficiencies in the applicant's socio-economic analysis, including the total lack of a health impact assessment identifying risk to workers. I have therefore supported Parliament's motion for a Resolution which considers that the Commission's draft Implementing Decision exceeds the powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 and demands its withdrawal and the submission of a new one rejecting applications for authorisation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. As of 2000, the European Commission's communication (COM(1999)0706) to the Council and the European Parliament on a Community strategy on endocrine disruptors included DEHP in Appendix 1, which lists 553 candidate substances that appear to be disruptive to the endocrine system. DEHP is a toxic substance for reproduction. With the EU executive having to protect European citizens and their environment from dangerous chemicals, I voted for the European Commission to withdraw its proposed application for implementation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution seeks to object to a draft Commission implementing decision authorising the use of this toxic chemical – DEHP – on a continuous and continuous use of recycled materials for another 7 years. It is known that the substance DEHP is part of the list of industrial chemicals used in plastics, cosmetics and other types of consumer products and is considered a toxic substance, capable of causing problems to human health. For this reason, I agree with the adoption of this proposal to object to the use of this substance, not only because of its toxicity, but also because, in formal terms, it is something that goes beyond the sphere of implementing powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006, and I therefore support the rapporteur's position to withdraw the Commission's draft decision and submit a new draft rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled flexible PVC containing DEPH.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection.  In voting for this text, we oppose the granting of the use of an authorisation of the highly toxic bis-(2-ethylhexyle) phthalate (DEHP), for which some safer alternatives for health exist.  Indeed, the European Chemicals Agency has not been able in its report to demonstrate the total safety of this product and the possibility of guaranteeing and controlling its proper use.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection under Article 106 of the Regulation concerning the granting of an authorisation for the uses of di-2-ethylylfrtalate (DEHP) because this substance, after various scientific studies, has been found to be toxic and dangerous to the health of European citizens. I therefore believe that the European Parliament's decision to reject the european Commission's application for authorisation for the use and recycling of DEHP-containing materials is right.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this non-binding motion for a resolution, which calls on the Commission not to authorize DEHP (Dietil hexyl phthalate). It is a well-known toxic substance. It has been proposed to be included in the list of substances of high concern about its effects of endocrine alteration. It is found in Annex XIV to the REACH Regulation due to its toxicity to the reproductive system. DEHP is a phthalate, a group of chemicals that cause the feminization of males of exposed species. These substances affect the endocrine system of fauna and, potentially, also that of humans. It can cause breast and testicle cancer, congenital malformations and infertility, among other adverse health effects. Due to its disrupting properties of the endocrine system, a safe exposure threshold cannot be set for DEHP with sufficient certainty. Environmental, health, medical, cancer prevention advocates, have joined women's organizations and medical organizations to strongly oppose DEHP's authorization in PVC materials, due to its high toxicity. European regulations have already restricted their use in toys and child care items.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution by the Environment Committee and was glad to see that it had the overwhelming support of my colleagues. There are very real concerns about the health implications of DEHP. Identified as toxic to reproduction and an endocrine disrupter affecting the environment, it is very worrying that the Commission granted a broad authorisation for a substance associated with birth defects and abnormalities. The aim of the REACH regulation is to ensure a high level of protection of human health and the environment, yet the widespread use of this substance would likely pose a threat to both. There is no justification for this authorisation, especially considering that safe alternatives are available.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's call on the Commission to withdraw the relevant draft implementing decision and instead prohibit the recycling of plastics containing the toxic phthalate DEHP for further use, as this toxic substance poses specific and professional publicly named health risks. Nor should the idea of recycling materials, which I generally support, justify the further use of substances with hazardous impacts. I hope that the Member States will also join in today's Position of the European Parliament and the Commission will reject the proposal for authorisation of the formulation of recycled softened PVC containing DEHP.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I consider the authorization of use for DEHP, a substance whose toxicity as an endocrine disruptor is widely demonstrated — being unacceptable — and may cause cancers, malformations and infertility, among other adverse health affections. An initiative, moreover, confirming, together with paralysis in the regulation of endocrine disruptors, that the Commission puts the interests of multinationals before public health in this area. Such authorisation cannot be justified for technical reasons, taking into view the existence of substitutes for that chemical, and puts the health of workers exposed to it at risk. This is a serious precedent and I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection raised by the rapporteurs because It does not seem fair to give permission to use DEPH to a small number of recyclers, which will have a negative impact on European recyclers, undermine innovation and competitiveness in Europe and result in the loss of credibility that the recycling sector presents. DEHP is known as a well-known toxic substance. DEHP is widely used, and both EU citizens and the environment are exposed. However, there are safe alternatives. Tenderers have not met all the conditions for authorisation to be granted, and 90% of the authorisation application process has been classified as confidential by tenderers with the consent of the European Chemicals Agency. Although I understand the interest of industrial secrecy in exceptional situations, I consider it a priority and decisive for industry to act in a clear and transparent manner.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this objection, because if the ban was introduced immediately, it could be damaging to UK industry.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I am of the opinion that the Adoption by the Commission of legislation authorising the use of bis(2-ethyl ethyl ethyl)-phthalate (DEHP) was not a happy step, in particular because of the prevailing concerns about the harmfulness of this substance. I was therefore in favour of the proposal for an objection by which the European Parliament calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing decision and to submit a new proposal on the refusal of applications for authorisation of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the EP's position calling on the Commission to withdraw its implementing decision and to submit a new proposal rejecting the application for authorisation for the composition of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP. DEHP is contained in many types of PVC widely used in everyday consumer products such as textiles, furniture and building materials. This substance is chemically linked to plastics and thus easily escapes into the environment. However, we should be vigilant against the use of DEHP, as current scientific evidence suggests that exposure to these compounds at a sensitive time can have serious effects on human health, in particular it can have serious effects on reproduction. In addition, the adverse impact on human life caused by exposure during the early stages of the life cycle can only occur in later stages of life. Phthalates known to interfere with the endocrine system and toxic for reproduction should not appear in products that are freely available to the public and can also be encountered by children. The Commission is also responsible for protecting citizens and the environment from hazardous chemicals. It is therefore inconceivable that innovation in product production would put human health above that.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In the vote on the European Parliament's objection, which called for the abolition of the exemption allowing the use of bis(ethylhexyl)-phthalate (DEHP) in production, I abstained and did not support this objection. My position was motivated by the unequivocal opinion of the Czech Republic and also of the European Commission, which we have entrusted with the power to adopt sub-statutory standards in this matter. At this time, there are no serious reasons for banning DEPH. On the contrary, such a move would hurt manufacturers who do not yet have a commercially acceptable alternative to the substance. However, it is clear that in the future it is necessary to support the development of these very alternatives so that the DEPH exemption can one day end up in the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this report as the Commission supports this report since the Commission in the draft implementing decision on the labelling of di-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalates (DEHP), dibutyl phthalates (DPB), benzyl butyl phthalates (BBP) and diizobutyl phthalates (DIPB) as particularly worrying substances under Article 57(f) of Regulation (EC) No 1000/2013/ 2013/ 2013. 1907/2006 The European Parliament and the Council shall endeavour to designate DEHP as a substance of particular concern.  I further supported the proposal because the applicants did not demonstrate on the basis of the information available in the applications that the health risks to workers' health arising from the uses for which the application is submitted are adequately controlled, in accordance with Article 60(2) of REACH. It is also not appropriate, in the opinion of the Risk Assessment Committee, to issue an authorisation based on that provision.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The Scientific Committee on Toxicity, Ecotoxicism and the Environment regularly conducts research on dangerous substances in food and other products, with the aim of reducing the risk of disease. Dangers to human health and the environment arising from the use of di (2-ethylhexyl) phthalates (DEHP) should be considered a priority in the periodic review of the list of restricted substances, as these high-risk substances have been found to be particularly dangerous for children. These toxic substances were found in cosmetic preparations, laundry softeners and children's toys. It is therefore proposed to gradually reduce the use of these products.  In order to facilitate the transition and mitigate possible socio-economic consequences, an appropriate transitional period should be granted, allowing economic operators to apply for exemption from substance restrictions, in accordance with Article 5 of the Regulation. Directive 2011/65/EU.  I support the Council's proposal to gradually reduce the use of high-risk substances, which are found in everyday products, with a view to preserving human health and the environment.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal, given that it is in direct contradiction with scientific knowledge and may ultimately do more harm than good to the environment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of DEHP and similar ingredients cause endocrine activity disorders with direct effect on human health.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. PVC containing DEHP is very present in everyday consumer products, such as textiles, furniture and construction equipment. Considering that DEHP is not chemically related to plastic, it spreads easily into the environment. An application for authorization should focus on the use of the substance and the fact that the substance is present in recycled materials is not to be taken into account in granting an authorization.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to avert the Commission’s proposal to authorise the recycling of old plastics containing diethylhexyl phthalate (DHEP) into new PVC products. DHEP is a softener banned by the EU’s REACH regulation. There is scientific evidence that proves its negative impact on human health, especially its toxicity to male reproduction. DEPH is dangerous for workers that manufacture the products in which it can be found, such as textiles and furniture. Moreover, it is not chemically bound to the plastic and can leak to the environment. I therefore supported the opinion that the Commission should not allow the recycling of plastics that contain DHEP.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against an objection to the issuance of a provision for the use of di-(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (DEHP) because I consider that this complaint was submitted on the basis of disproportionate, factually incorrect data, and that the implementation of this proposal would reduce the recycling of PVC even though it proved safe to use.  Namely, the aim of the complaint is to refuse new permits for the continued use of this substance in recycled PVC, and to authorize the continuation of the use of it only when it is added to production. Since the Risk Assessment Board states that the minimal risk to consumers is precisely from items made from recycled PVC, I believe this proposal is completely unfounded.  In addition, the wider effects of disapproval of dehp use, such as reducing recycling and increasing environmental pollution, are not taken into account. Given that the production of new PVC items is EUR 394 per tonne and recycling is EUR 14 per tonne, I believe that this prohibition would be an additional financial burden to the economies of the Member States, so I did not support it.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Commission Implementing Decision XXX granting authorisation for the use of bis(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (DEHP) as I believe that the use of the substance DEHP should be prohibited because it is extremely harmful to health. This would also encourage companies to innovate to use in their products other substances that are not harmful to health and do not affect hereditary material as well as phthalates.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this non-binding motion for a resolution, which calls on the Commission not to authorize DEHP (Dietil hexyl phthalate). It is a well-known toxic substance. It has been proposed to be included in the list of substances of high concern about its effects of endocrine alteration. It is found in Annex XIV to the REACH Regulation due to its toxicity to the reproductive system. DEHP is a phthalate, a group of chemicals that cause the feminization of males of exposed species. These substances affect the endocrine system of fauna and, potentially, also that of humans. It can cause breast and testicle cancer, congenital malformations and infertility, among other adverse health effects. Due to its disrupting properties of the endocrine system, a safe exposure threshold cannot be set for DEHP with sufficient certainty. Environmental, health, medical, cancer prevention advocates, have joined women's organizations and medical organizations to strongly oppose DEHP's authorization in PVC materials, due to its high toxicity. European regulations have already restricted their use in toys and child care items.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The resolution aims to prevent the authorisation of DEHP, a derivative of phthalate. This is an objection under section 106 of the enforcement regulations.  This product is already identified for its endocrine disruptor properties, its retritoxic risk. He had not crossed the caudine forks of the marketing authorization in a previous application. This time, against all odds, the Commission is ready to authorise it. This product is present in many everyday products, especially recycled PVC products, from shoes to windows. This product can easily be spread by contact. There are also alternatives identified as reliable. The Commission stubbornly refuses to make a proposal on endocrine disruptors, the work in progress suggests a proposal by the end of 2016. The only levers available to parliamentarians are the objections to delegated acts and acts of execution over the water. Under purely sanitary exteriors, commercial issues are very important. The EU has already been "warned" by the United States and the WTO that regulations on endocrine disruptors would be bad for global trade.  It should be noted that public health is only very secondary during these exchanges. I therefore support this proposal.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 the European Parliament's resolution on the draft decision on the granting of an authorisation to use phthalates aims, on the one hand, to emphasise the economic and social need for the acceptance of the recycling of these plastics, which are clearly proven to be toxic, and, on the other hand, to contribute to the protection of the health of citizens heavily affected by DEHP phthalates. At this stage, we have sufficient data on the cumulative effect of these substances, phthalates already present in our tissues at a dangerous level, affecting the endocrine system and fertility. The most exposed categories are pregnant women and children. I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it necessary that, in the next period, the European Commission should come back with a new proposal that would drastically limit the recycling of lightPVC containing DEHP phthalates, as well as products from materials containing this harmful substance to the human body.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission aims to use bis(2-ethylhexyl) phaate (DEHP), dibutyl phaate (DBP), benzyl butyl phaate (BBP) and diizobutyl phalated (DIBP) in accordance with Article 57 of Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The DEHP should be identified as a substance of particular concern by means of a draft implementing decision identifying DEHP as a substance of particular concern in accordance with Article 10(f) of Regulation (EC) No 1258/2001. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this non-binding motion for a resolution, which calls on the Commission not to authorize DEHP (Dietil hexyl phthalate). It is a well-known toxic substance. It has been proposed to be included in the list of substances of high concern about its effects of endocrine alteration. It is found in Annex XIV to the REACH Regulation due to its toxicity to the reproductive system. DEHP is a phthalate, a group of chemicals that cause the feminization of males of exposed species. These substances affect the endocrine system of fauna and, potentially, also that of humans. It can cause breast and testicle cancer, congenital malformations and infertility, among other adverse health effects. Due to its disrupting properties of the endocrine system, a safe exposure threshold cannot be set for DEHP with sufficient certainty. Environmental, health, medical, cancer prevention advocates, have joined women's organizations and medical organizations to strongly oppose DEHP's authorization in PVC materials, due to its high toxicity. European regulations have already restricted their use in toys and child care items.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution that addresses the identification of DEHP as a substance giving rise to an equivalent level of concern due to its endocrine disrupting properties in the environment. In the case of DEHP, there is scientific evidence on endocrine disrupting activity and on the causal link between this activity and adverse effects on human health.  Recycling should not justify the perpetuation of the use of hazardous legacy substances, whereas DEHP is a legacy substance, and has also been recognised as such by the industry concerned and I agree with the Parliament previous potions on ‘resource efficiency: moving towards a circular economy’. I strongly believe that the Commission is accountable to the European public for protecting citizens and the environment from hazardous chemicals, while promoting innovation, including in the area of safer chemicals and products to foster a resilient economy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft Implementing Decision and to submit a new one rejecting applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP, since the draft Commission Implementing Decision is considered to exceed the powers provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006. In order to prevent this from happening, I believe it is necessary to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I consider the authorization of use for DEHP, a substance whose toxicity as an endocrine disruptor is widely demonstrated — being unacceptable — and may cause cancers, malformations and infertility, among other adverse health affections. An initiative, moreover, confirming, together with paralysis in the regulation of endocrine disruptors, that the Commission puts the interests of multinationals before public health in this area. Such authorisation cannot be justified for technical reasons, taking into view the existence of substitutes for that chemical, and puts the health of workers exposed to it at risk. This is a serious precedent and I therefore voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'In view of the danger posed by the substance DEHP because of its negative impact on the environment and human health, I voted in favour of this objection, so that the European Commission would not allow plastics containing this substance to be recycled.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Parliament rejected by a very large majority (603 votes in, 86 against) the request to specifically allow the recycling of "PVC plastics containing DEHP", a chemical belonging to the phthalates group used to make plastic more flexible. This substance is an endocrine disruptor that disrupts the human reproductive system. Considered dangerous, it has been gradually withdrawn from the European market since 2014, but can be used on the basis of a specific authorisation. The Commission wanted to authorise recycling for a period of seven years, on the grounds that phthalate-free plastics would be too expensive, while the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA), which assessed business applications, highlighted the disastrous consequences of the substance on the hormonal system. Several amendments tabled by the GUE/NGL and the Greens have strengthened the scope of this text, including calling for the use of DEHP in all remaining productions to be abolished as soon as possible. I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution which puts human health before economic competitiveness.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 DEHP is a toxic substance well known, among others, for its endocrine disrupting effects. Unfortunately, DEHP is widely used to place citizens highly exposed to its toxicity. We have doubts about the evaluation of the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA), as 90 % of the authorisation application process has been classified as confidential by tenderers. This context implies that relevant information, such as details on exposure and production volumes, has not been disclosed. In this way, we do not understand the Commission's implementing decision, which proposes to authorise the use of these products for another 7 years, and we instead propose to suspend the application for authorisation.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the rejection of the authorisation of uses of diethylhexyl phthalate (DEHP) under Article 106 OF the CRP.  It is a question of the scientific question of whether DEHP can be used. The dispute revolves around the question of whether there is a scientific threshold of harmfulness to be determined. I have followed my group's line in deciding.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I was in favour of this resolution of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, which enjoys the broadest acceptance and support of the colleagues of the committee responsible.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. Fthatopes are a family of industrial chemicals used to make PVC plastic flexible and as solvents in cosmetics and other consumer products.
