Studies indicate that these chemical compounds can affect the liver, kidneys, lungs and hormonal and reproductive systems of mammals and are therefore included in reach due to their classification as a toxic substance for reproduction. This proposal for objections relates to the commission's draft implementing decision granting an authorisation for uses of bis phtharate (2-ethyl-hexyl) (DEHP). This act of implementation presupposes a broader authorization for the use and formulation of recycled PVC containing DEHP. This would lead to a continued presence of hazardous substances in products made of recycled material – thereby perpetuating the use of hazardous substances through recycling rather than their replacement. This objection also considers that the Commission's draft implementing decision, which proposes to authorise the use of these products for another 7 years, exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006, and calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft decision by submitting a draft rejection of applications for authorisation for the formulation of recycled flexible PVC containing DEHP. We voted in favour.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the European Parliament Resolution on the draft Commission implementing decision granting authorisation for the use of bis(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (DEHP) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council (D041427 - 2015/2962(RSP)) by calling on the Commission, to withdraw the draft implementing decision and to propose a new one rejecting the authorisation applications for the formulations of recycled soft PVC containing DEHP, as it has been scientifically demonstrated that DEHP acts as an endocrine disruptor and that there is a causal link between this activity and adverse effects on human health.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to get rid of my compliments to the committee responsible, which has produced an excellent report. Many people did not agree at the outset whether this report would then be over-politicised. So a good result! I would like to say once again that I, too, am really interested in us pursuing the issue when it comes to taxes and tax justice. I am also looking forward to further work by this committee, and I look forward to further results.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly I must say that I think you always do a very good job in the Chair. I would much prefer a ‘Speedy Gonzales’ type of Vice—President than a dithering slowcoach, which we occasionally have as well, but I will not go into details. Referring to this explanation of vote, regretfully – and unusually for us in Fine Gael in the EPP – we voted against our Group on a certain number of measures, and also against the final report, which is unusual. We did so because this is a very strong issue for our country, and we also think that the report goes overboard in, as they say, calling on the Commission, etcetera, to do certain things when certain investigations are going on right now. Tax is a national competence. This has been recognised in various referendums we have had. We think, in particular, that trying to move to the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) is not in our interest and, therefore, we voted against the report. There are many good measures in it, but overall we think it is leaning in the wrong direction.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – I can join colleagues in saying that your style of operation is indeed very correct, but when it comes to the nature of the case, about tax rulings, I want to state that an effective, fair taxation policy is the cornerstone of the economic stability of any country. It is clear that, while there are countries in the world that could almost completely eliminate the tax burden due to the wealth of natural resources, this is not possible in the European Union. Here our Member States need to be cored, colleagues, among a wide variety of tax types: income, social, corporate, excise, flat-rate, progressive tax, value added tax, several others. But it is clear that everyone has the right to work and receive a salary that would be enough after the relevant taxes to fully cover all the necessary expenses: food, housing, various family items, etc. The same applies to companies, so that they have the resources to pay taxes and workers' wages, etc. But on the way out, I can state that the document is good enough, and I support it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I abstained from this report, I did not support it. And that's why it's what some of my pre-speaking people have already suggested. For me personally, it is difficult to enforce a common tax base for direct tax, namely the income tax of a legal entity. I ran here for a centre-right party in the Czech Republic, which clearly stated in its programme that it would not seek to unify the rates and tax bases of direct taxes. So I must keep my promise to my constituents and maintain and promote autonomy for direct taxes, autonomy for individual tax systems. I still believe that healthy competition between tax systems in the individual countries of the European Union is beneficial. Of course, it cannot take the form of unfair competition or tax dumping, as some countries such as Luxembourg have done.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, the main constraint on a government wishing to raise taxes is international competition. You can raise your tax up to a certain point and then the money begins to flee to friendlier jurisdictions. It is a reality that is becoming more and more true as modern technology facilitates capital movement globally. We can complain about it, we can try and legislate against it, but we cannot stop it. The only way in which we can tackle the loss of revenue as a result of tax avoidance is by making our own tax regime more attractive, which brings me to the fundamental argument against tax harmonisation. The more you centralise, the more you make it a uniform rate, the more you take away that constraint and allow governments to help themselves to more and more without any oversight. Hands up anybody in this Chamber who thinks that harmonised taxes will be harmonised downwards?

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, essentially this to me shows that there are two honest positions in terms of membership of the European Union. You either take the federalist approach and recognise that, for everything that the European Union tries to do as a whole, it requires then to harmonise taxation, it requires then greater powers, greater centralisation, and you embrace that. It is an honest position. It is not a position that I personally share. The other honest position is to say that actually, that is not what the United Kingdom requires; that we are better as an independent, self-governing nation, as the world’s fifth largest economy; that we want to be good neighbours with Europe: we want to trade with Europe but we do not want European government. Those two positions are honest. What I find very difficult is the third way: this idea that we can somehow be in Europe but act as a brake pedal on Europe. That is not fair on the UK; it is not fair on the rest of Europe either. We need to be honest: are we in or are we out?

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The work of the TAXE Commission has served to demonstrate that tax agreements were in breach of competition rules, as well as evidence of the complicity of Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem in this scandal. The report, however, only partially reflects our demands. On the one hand, tax avoidance practices are denounced and the Commission is asked for ambition in its proposals for transparency and fiscal harmonisation. But many of these requests do not go beyond good intentions and the ties between multinationals guilty of tax avoidance, the Member States and the Commission are not adequately investigated for lack of documents and political will. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted against this report which I believe is an attack on Member States tax sovereignty. The European Parliament’s special TAXE Committee report was an elaborate PR stunt which was weak on matters of importance such as the need for full transparency while simultaneously attacking the principal of national sovereignty on taxation matters. It is my belief, that it does not serve the interests of the ordinary Irish citizen to have our sovereignty relinquished through any attempted tax harmonisation. The report provided an opportunity for parliament to demand transparency and accountability in both the European and International Taxation system, but the majority of MEPs rejected measures that would have facilitated this. Instead, they adopted a number of disconcerting provisions which fundamentally undermine taxation sovereignty. Sinn Féin want tax fairness and transparency to be placed at the centre of any Taxation Legislation and this extends to ensuring that a more equitable Corporate Tax System is implemented. But all matters relating to the setting of Tax Rates must remain a matter of national competency and the European Parliament has no right to attempt to attack sovereignty in this way.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. 'I abstained on this TAXE report for the following reason. Yes, multinationals have to pay taxes. It cannot be that small and medium-sized enterprises and workers bear all the burden. 'Yes' to transparency in order to combat tax evasion and to place all Member States before their responsibility. However, I say 'no' to a supranational tax union at the same time. This TAXE report, with its CCCTB (common consolidated tax base) is in any case a first step towards such a unified European tax system. That's when I drop out. The solution to combating harmful tax practices lies with the Meeting of Heads of State and Government, not the Commission.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In response to the public debate on procedures for binding tax information in the Member States and the Luxleaks affair on tax advantages for corporations in Luxembourg, the European Parliament set up a Special Investigation Committee (TAXE). In the report adopted in plenary, the European Parliament calls for a tougher approach and a tougher crackdown on tax avoidance. The effective tax rate of some multinationals for profits made in European territory is close to zero percent. The fact that this is unfair to medium-sized and small businesses is self-inquitable and harmful. I therefore welcome the call for a common corporate tax base and for greater transparency in the previously secret agreements between EU countries and multinational companies. This also entails the requirement that multinationals in all sectors be required to disclose in their annual accounts a set of aggregated information by Member State and third country in which an establishment exists. However, as this country-specific reporting would be unreasonable for SMEs, I am pleased that Parliament has adopted an amendment from the PPE-DE which provides for sMEs to be exempt from this obligation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The TAXE Committee has delivered its final report on tax rulings and other aggressive tax optimisation measures in the European Union. His work, following Luxleaks, has more generally raised awareness of the montages of some unscrupulous multinationals allowing them to evade almost any tax. The damage to the public finances of the Member States is significant: 10 to 15 billion euros per year for France, for example. Since most of these schemes are illegal, new forms of regulation need to be found. This text makes recommendations to Member States and the Commission, which are based on the implementation of transparency measures and the limitation of rescripting opportunities and similar measures relating to tax competition, as long as they prove unfair. In the end, the report shows an awareness, but does not prejudge the measures that will be taken. On the rescript exchange directive, a corollary to TAXE's work, the Council's position of 6 October was disappointing. So I voted for it, despite some reservations.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to combat tax evasion. I support the principle that multinationals must pay their taxes where they make their profits. I believe that at present, corporate tax competition , which encourages aggressive tax planning and tax evasion, without any common framework - is harmful. In addition to the loss of public revenue, I consider it unfair that large companies pay very little tax on their profits while citizens and SMEs have to pay the full price.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to find ways to prevent aggressive tax planning. The proposal sets out recommendations to combat aggressive corporate tax planning and evasion. I support the proposal to oblige multinational companies to publish their financial data by country of operation, to introduce a common consolidated corporate tax base, to publicise tax arrangements between EU countries and those companies, while at the same time better protecting whistleblowers. I agree that multinationals should pay taxes in the country where the value of goods and services is created.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this crucial report in the fight against multinational tax evasion.  This text highlights three essential measures to ensure the effectiveness of the fight against tax evasion by multinationals. 1. All the rescripts of multinationals, without exception, must be able to be analysed and verified. The finance ministers propose not to control the rescripts of more than 5 years, this makes no sense. In addition, the European Parliament proposes to control national and international rescripts. The European Council forgets international rescripts.  2. Rules are only effective if there are sanctions. The European Parliament proposes to sanction. The Council does not provide for any sanctions.  3. You can't be a judge and a party. The Council of Finance Ministers wants to be the reference body responsible for verifying and regulating tax rulings. It is up to the Commission to take on this role to ensure more fairness. Parliament, in voting on this report, has made strong commitments to combat tax evasion. It is now essential that the Council and the Commission do the same.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I would like to thank the TAXE Special Commission for the work it has done during all these months so that today we could vote on this very important report. Parliament has carried out an extensive work plan and meetings with very important appearances to try to clarify what was called the 'LuxLeaks case'. I hope that, with the adoption of this report and its provisions, the European Commission will present us with certain measures to agree with the Council to eliminate the problems we have known so far in tax material

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report, in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, has raised a general awareness of the schemes of some unscrupulous multinationals that allow them to evade almost any tax. The damage is estimated to be up to 15 billion euros per year for France alone.  The mandate of the TAXE Committee will be extended by 6 months to allow for some confidential documents, but we have to decide today on the final report for which I am in favour.  This text makes recommendations to states and the Commission, in particular on transparency and limiting the possibilities of tax optimisation. These include, for example, Luxembourg's tax rulings, the parent/daughter company regime and the taxation of patent income in the Netherlands, or the Irish IS rate.  I broadly support this text, particularly for sanctions against multinationals that engage in this fraud. I am also in favour of enhanced protection for whistleblowers. I also believe that better cooperation between states is a good thing.  But I do not support a European harmonisation of IS rates because I remain committed to the sovereignty of states in tax matters.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, which I supported with my vote in favour, identifies the ways in which many multinationals have evaded or avoided the tax payable to host countries, causing serious damage to the economy and to the whole community.  The report also demonstrates very clearly the responsibility and full involvement in this scandal of Jean-Claude Juncker, who currently holds, in an unacceptable way in my opinion, the office of President of the European Commission.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which sets out decisions on taxes and other measures of a similar nature or effect. LuxLeaks has drawn the attention of the public and the media to these issues, revealing the questionable tax practices promoted by accountants in one particular Member State. The Commission's investigations and the work of the European Parliament, carried out in the presence of its special committee, have shown that this was not the only case, but a widespread practice in Europe and beyond in which tax measures are being taken to reduce the common tax liabilities of certain large corporations, so that the national tax base is artificially increased at the expense of other countries (some of which are subject to austerity measures). Such actions, which often lead to a loss of the link between the place where the value is created and the place where profits are taxed, are not limited to tax rulings, but include a wide range of harmful tax practices applied by national tax authorities inside and outside the EU. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to use all available instruments to promote a more coordinated approach towards developed countries in order to promote greater reciprocity in tax matters, in particular through the exchange of information with the United States following the entry into force of the Foreign Accounts Tax Enforcement Act.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Empty state reapers and fair burden-sharing are increasingly prompting the Member States of the European Union to coordinate the fight against tax fraud and evasion. It seems that the subject has become permanent in the EP, as it has also set up a new commission to confirm this. This report shall be presented for the first time. As we all see, the collateral consequence of the long-running economic crisis is an increase in demand in the EU and globally for the discovery of hidden incomes, which the European Commission estimates will shorten member states' revenues by tens of billions each year.  The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis appears to increase the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must continue to commit ourselves to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals already put forward in tax fraud cases and to implementing the measures already adopted.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support the Tax report and other measures of a similar nature or impact. This is the final report of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or impact. After 10 months of investigation into tax rulings and other measures and discussions, the conclusions and recommendations in the final Report were presented. There is now a new tax justice program. After almost 10 months of investigation, findings and recommendations, it is aimed at improving tax coordination and cooperation in the EU in the fight against aggressive tax planning.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. If we share the observation made in this report, that there are: - many loopholes in the tax systems of European countries that allow multinationals to successfully engage in the exercise of tax optimisation; - too many tax rulings; - too many disparities between Member States; we cannot accept some of its recommendations, including harmonization of IS rates, although we support OECD recommendations on this, sanctions against multinationals that have defrauded, and whistleblowers. We remain in favour of the principle of unanimity in tax matters, and look positively at the incentive for cooperation between neighbouring states in tax matters, as advocated by this text. For all these reasons I'm voting for.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to combat the tax optimisation practiced by large multinationals in order to massively reduce the taxes they have to pay. The loopholes in national legislation, which the large groups exploit unscrupulously, create financial harm to the Member States which, in the case of France, amounts to more than 10 billion euros per year.  To this end, the report calls on states to strengthen their cooperation in data exchange in order to detect more quickly companies engaged in these irregular tax arrangements. In addition, It is recommended that Member States put in place transparency measures and limiting the possibilities of rescripts. Finally, the report proposes to harmonize the basis of corporate tax in order to focus competition on rates and to better regulate transfer prices between subsidiaries of the same company.  We fully support the measures unveiled in this report, although we consider this project to remain unambitious. On the other hand, we formally oppose the harmonisation of the IS rate, which limits member states' budgetary levers as part of a cyclical policy. So I voted for this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report of Parliament's Special Committee on Tax Arrangements and Commission Investigations revealed that activities aimed at reducing the overall tax debts of certain companies are a common practice at Member State level. I stress that the restructuring of national budgets in the wake of the economic crisis has significantly reduced the staff of tax administrations and favoured tax evasion and avoidance. Similarly, the growing difference between legal and actual tax rates for multinational companies confirms that derogations granted by Member States from the tax regime contribute to the increase of the budget deficit in the long term. Unfortunately, the lack of convergence of tax systems in the EU encourages preferential national regimes and creates favourable legislative frameworks for abuses. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe that a coordinated fiscal policy between Member States can ensure a level playing field for firms within the internal market.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report contains an in-depth analysis of the "modus operandi" through which a wide variety of multinational companies have been allowed tax avoidance and/or evasion practices. There have also been previous responsibilities of people currently of importance in the European institutions (Juncker).  It points to some measures, although not sufficient, to prevent them, proposing – among other things – coverage for those who provide information on these practices, including journalists. I am voting in favour.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of the special committee TAXE which had been set up in the wake of the revelations of the LuxLeaks scandal. The aim of this committee was to highlight and address the unbridled and unfair competition between Member States in the tax field. The report calls for more fiscal convergence between EU Member States and greater transparency.  Unfair tax competition between Member States too often benefits large multinational companies at the expense of SMEs and European citizens. In this sense, it is essential that companies pay their taxes in the country where economic activity is carried out. I consider this report to be an essential step towards the necessary tax harmonisation within the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted positively on the report on advance tax rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect. I firmly believe in the need to guarantee the principles of transparency and the protection of savings. I have already pointed out on several occasions that the lack of tax harmonisation between Member States leads to fiscal competition and dumping which seriously distort economic competition and the proper functioning of the single market.  The reality lies in the difficult coexistence of 28 different corporate tax regimes and the difficulty of harmonising the corporate tax base. These and many other bodies are answerable by the proposal for a directive and the report, to which I voted in favour, aware of the need to eliminate asymmetries between tax systems as soon as possible and to improve cooperation within the EU, given that these critical issues weigh on other taxpayers, including SMEs and citizens.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which I believe is an attack on Member States tax sovereignty. The European Parliament’s special TAXE Committee report was an elaborate PR stunt which was weak on matters of importance such as the need for full transparency while simultaneously attacking the principal of national sovereignty on taxation matters. name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I firmly believe in tax transparency and the fight against tax fraud, but this does not mean the mandatory introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). The EU is not a homogenous area and not all regions in the EU face the same economic realities, be it for their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources. While the report did contain some useful points on transparency, which we supported, we are of the view that questions of tax of the nature of CCCTB must remain an issue of national competence since they reflect the different economies of Member States. We are convinced that a one-size-fits all approach is not the right way forward for Europe as inevitably it would be the EU’s smaller economies, such as Malta, that would bear the disproportionate brunt of such policies.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the Luxleaks revelations, the European Parliament decided to set up a temporary committee to investigate the issue of taxation and tax arrangements. Unfortunately, this committee is not a committee of inquiry and does not aim to highlight Juncker's clear political responsibility, as also confirmed by the recent revelations in Spiegel which only reiterate what everyone knows, but which no one wants to admit about the work of the former Luxembourg Prime Minister. It was clear from the outset what the difficulties of this committee would be in carrying out its mandate. For example, all tax arrangements should also be public and verifiable by European citizens. In the light of the above, the M5S Europe delegation has decided to abstain.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – I endorse the conclusions reported by the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, set up to probe into the tax-dodging scandals revealed in last year’s Lux Leaks. The amount we lose to tax evasion every year has been estimated to be in the region of the whole budget of the EU. Those who constantly bang on about fiscal consolidation and the need for balanced budgets should bear this in mind when faced with the inevitable budget shortfalls, with the actual ordinary taxpayers ending up on the losing side, as usual. We are only talking about a modicum of transparency and minimum standards to avoid the most egregious practices that lead us down a race to the bottom, punishing working people first and foremost. Yet, getting information from the Commission, Member States and corporations has been like pulling teeth. Many champions of austerity on the right of this Parliament have been denouncing the conclusions as punitive. But the punishment has been inflicted on the most vulnerable, whereas the multinationals with the will and resources to dodge tax have been getting away with effective rates which are a joke, and that, in many instances, is an understatement.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report contains positive elements in the fight against tax evasion and the existence of tax transparency. However, on the issue of imposing a uniform corporate tax rate on all Member States, we strongly disagree and react. Not everything in the EU is unified and there are huge variations on many issues, particularly information. After all, each country has its own peculiarities and comparative advantages, and any leveling in the tax field essentially wrongs and undermines the countries that have invested and emerged in the financial sector. With the same false rationale for a single tax rate in the EU, a single rate of VAT, uniform taxes and prices on consumer goods and many other absurdities must be imposed. In the economy you cannot impose flattening regulations that will eventually lead to distortions and incalculable damage to some economies. I believe that the EU does not have the right to impose such policies that are not only not aiding the development of economies, but at the same time create the image that the EU is implementing free measures in the economy. Setting tax rates is a matter and a right of the Member States and I think it is wrong to try to overturn it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The TAXE report contains some positive proposals to improve tax justice in Europe and to some extent demonstrates the negative impact of austerity policies pursued in recent years. However, although positive elements can be seen in the final version of the report, I abstained from voting for specific reasons. Although the responsibility for tax dumping in Europe has not been fully substantiated, the report does not seek to extend the current mandate, and there is still no access to necessary documents. The majority of private undertakings have not responded to the TAC until after constant invitations, and there is still no possibility of creating a legal basis for sanctions against private individuals. Moreover, the contradictions of President Junger during his testimony to the TDG are obvious. At the same time, it does not go any further on the key issues relating to TAXE, beyond what the European Commission has already proposed. It is important that tax decisions are made public and that legislation on tax secrecy is changed. Moreover, there has been no clear commitment to broaden the tax base and I believe that the interim period foreseen before the completion of unification will not be able to restrict tax competition between Member States.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. The so-called "LuxLeaks" scandal, at the end of 2014, brought to light controversial tax practices that exist in many Member States.  The public outcry has led to the establishment of a special commission on tax measures and other measures, which was set up in February 2015, to shed light on tax systems in all EU Member States, in order to examine ways to end unfair tax practices and to combat tax fraud in Europe.  With this report, the European Parliament reiterates that multinationals in all sectors must indicate in a clear and comprehensible way in their budget, broken down by Member State and by third country in which they have an establishment, a series of aggregated information, including their economic performance before tax, taxes on the income statement, the number of employees, the assets held and the basic information on tax decisions (country by country). Finally, it is explicitly emphasised that SMEs that are not multinationals are exempt from these obligations.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because I appreciated the objective of fair taxation.  However, I have serious misgivings about what many members have tried to say when reading this report: trying to escape a state that takes on taxes much more than it gives for public services is natural to say the least. At the same time, it is understandable to try to attract investment by leveraging fiscal attractiveness, especially through greater efficiency of public machinery in some (other) countries.  I therefore hope that we can achieve cooperation that will make it possible to pay the right thing in the right place, and not to have to waste time with diversions that do not produce any economic benefit to the territories.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Irish EPP Delegation regrettably voted against this report. While there are many positive aspects in this report, overall we believe that Parliament has gone beyond its mandate in relation to tax matters in this instance. Taxation is a national competence and this is clearly not respected in the report. Member States should have full power to set their corporate tax rates and the consolidation of corporation taxes across the EU is clearly a form of tax rate harmonisation. The EU’s competence on tax matters is to ensure that corporate tax systems are fair and transparent; if these conditions are fulfilled, tax competition should be considered a positive thing for Europe

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we need a full clarification of all the 'conspicuous' corporate tax practices of the Member States concerned. For me, this also includes the mandatory ad hoc exchange of information on national tax rulings, so that fair tax competition can be made possible in the future. Tax deals end up leading to tax losses and a tax increase for all other taxpayers. That is why we Members of the European Parliament, as representatives of our citizens, have a duty to play our part in the fight against illegal tax avoidance and tax evasion practices.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in which the European Parliament reaffirms its desire to put an end to aggressive tax planning by multinationals and to adopt a new set of fiscal policies and to ensure a fair tax system, based on the principle of taxation in the country where profits are generated, thus avoiding distortions of the internal market and unfair competition practices. I also welcome the Commission's efforts to promote the automatic exchange of tax information, as a future European and international transparency standard.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I firmly believe in tax transparency and the fight against tax fraud, but in my view that does not mean the mandatory introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). The EU is not a homogenous area and not all regions in the EU face the same economic realities, be it for their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources. While the report did contain some useful points on transparency, which our delegation supported, we are of the view that questions of tax of the nature of CCCTB must remain an issue of national competence since they reflect the different economies of Member States. We are convinced that a one-size-fits all approach is not the right way forward for Europe as inevitably it would be the EU’s smaller economies, such as Malta, that would bear a disproportionate brunt of such policies.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has decided to set up a special committee to investigate the issue of taxation and tax arrangements.  The text of the report has been rather satisfactory, as many of the points listed as necessary are the same points that we have been advocating for a long time, such as public and comprehensible country-by-country reporting, a full CCCTB to be carried out in the immediate future, an automatic and comprehensive exchange between Member States on tax arrangements. There is also a strong criticism in the text of the work of some EU countries that have never been cooperative, as is the European Commission itself, which has flattened out the Council's positions. The multinationals, which are the main culprits and beneficiaries of these agreements, are also under attack for their behaviour.  The text approved in the TAXE Committee at the end of October is therefore good, even if we have been too soft on the issue of transparency, because in our opinion all tax agreements should also be public and verifiable by European citizens. For these reasons, which I do not think are of minor importance, I am abstaining.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The work of the TAXE Commission has served to demonstrate that tax agreements were in breach of competition rules, as well as evidence of the complicity of Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem in this scandal. The report, however, only partially reflects our demands. On the one hand, tax avoidance practices are denounced and the Commission is asked for ambition in its proposals for transparency and fiscal harmonisation. But many of these requests do not go beyond good intentions and the ties between multinationals guilty of tax avoidance, the Member States and the Commission are not adequately investigated for lack of documents and political will. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Through the practice of advance tax decisions, the tax authorities of a Member State provide a company with how corporate income tax will be calculated and, on the basis of that decision, companies choose the most tax-advantageous country.  This widespread practice in the European Union harms competition in the European single market and Member States' budgets, and the negative effects have an impact on European taxpayers, including small and medium-sized enterprises. Parliament's resolution condemns this practice of aggressive tax planning by multinationals and calls on the Commission and the Member States to put an end to this situation.  I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that the measures proposed to curb this widespread practice in all Member States can be effective; in particular, it calls for greater transparency and the complete exchange of information on tax matters, a simplification of administrative procedures with the tax authorities, the creation of a common mandatory corporate tax base, sanctions for multinationals that rely on tax havens.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Report makes recommendations regarding an improvement in transparency related to the taxation measures applying in EU Member States. I agree with these recommendations and fully support measures designed to promote full transparency in national tax treatments. However, the report also proposes measures that implicitly or explicitly would introduce tax convergence and harmonisation on an EU-wide basis. This goes against the interests of smaller economies of the EU, which lack the endowments of the larger economies. Their flexibility in policy-making is already constrained, among others, by the convergence in VAT rates, state aid rules, the single currency and the six pack/two pack rules applied to their budgets. Reducing the tax flexibility of such economies would further increase these disparities, which is unfair, dysfunctional and unacceptable. Tax competition should remain part of the limited array of decision tools available to national economies. For these reasons, I voted against the Report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ This report recommends direct taxation and tax harmonisation powers for the EU. I do not think that taxation is an EU competence and cannot support a report which is proposing this. Therefore I voted against this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report presents the European Parliament's recommendations to strengthen the fight against aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. Following the "LuxLeaks" scandal at the end of 2014, which exposed the existence of controversial tax practices in some Member States, the European Parliament responded to citizens' questions by setting up a special temporary commission dedicated to the tax system in February 2015 (TAXE commission).  Considering that it is unfair for large companies to pay very little tax on their profits while small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens must pay the full price, the report suggests requiring multinationals to report on country-by-country financial data, and introducing a consolidated common corporate tax base. Parliament also calls for making Member States' tax arrangements with these companies more transparent.  Supporting these objectives and considering that the work of this committee has accelerated reflections on the fight against tax evasion, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. In the face of the economic and fiscal crisis that has shaken Europe for several years, it is important that the EU commits itself to the establishment of a European tax system that does not favour one country over another. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which will allow multinationals to pay their taxes where they make their profits.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: in writing. ‒ GUE/NGL welcomes the substance of the report by the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect (TAXE). It contains useful proposals for greater tax justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on tax fairness. Despite our many contributions to the report’s final shape, we abstained in today’s vote for the following reasons: political responsibility for tax dumping in the EU has not been fully established and the report does not call for the necessary prolongation of the current mandate; access to documents by the Council, the Commission and Member States remained unsatisfactory; multinational corporations only responded after repeated invitations to TAXE, no legal base for sanctions could be established yet and they could not be interrogated thoroughly. Moreover, contradictions by the Commission President, Jean-Claude Juncker, during his testimony to TAXE were not followed up.  Substance-wise, core issues lack ambition beyond what the Commission has proposed already. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws adjusted. We welcome the idea of consolidating the tax base. However, we miss a clear commitment to broadening the tax base and we criticise the interim period before consolidation which allows for cross-border loss/profit offsetting and no further backstops to prevent tax competition between EU countries.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The tax ruling is one of the first important responses of the European institutions to the Luxleaks scandal.  It was the European Parliament that spent the most money through the ECON and TAXE Committees to denounce this scandal. In fact, since there is free movement of capital in the Single European Market, the current system of purely national collection should be exceeded in order to allow an appropriate exchange of information between the competent authorities. With this report, Parliament is calling on the Member States to review the set of laws that allow favourable tax regimes at national level, making these states de facto 'tax havens'.  These operations at a time of financial crisis and economic difficulties for many European families are unacceptable. Taxes must be paid in the states in which they carry out their activities, not in those where there is better tax treatment. Parliament strongly calls for solidarity between The Member States to be respected, and for a return to a system of trust between States and industry and citizens through a body of laws harmonizing the tax authorities of the Member States.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, the European Parliament has set up a special committee to investigate corporate tax evasion and evasion in the European Union.  A serious and comprehensive overview of the methods used by multinationals has been drawn up and several recommendations have been made to combat these practices contrary to the principle of equality before tax.  For this issue concerns not only Luxembourg but many other European countries which have granted, at the card, extraordinary tax advantages to a particular entity, or even to states, leading to unwelcome distortions of tax competition. One answer is possible: tax harmonisation within the euro area.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. Following the revelations of the LuxLeaks scandal, a special committee has been set up in the European Parliament: the TAXE Committee. I voted for his final report on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect. This text supports the creation of a consolidated common corporate tax base (ACCIS). As a result, companies will have to pay taxes in proportion to their profits in all European countries where they operate.  Further, with regard to our historical positions and the expectations of European citizens, I voted in favour of an extension of the Committee's investigations into state aid and transfer pricing for the companies mentioned in the LuxLeaks. I am also in the interest of introducing the country-by-country reporting mechanism for multinationals, as do the OECD and the French National Assembly. Finally, I think it is essential to protect whistleblowers.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Empty state reapers and fair burden-sharing are increasingly prompting the Member States of the European Union to coordinate the fight against tax fraud and evasion. It seems that the subject has become permanent in our Parliament, since we have been given the right to set up a new commission to confirm this, and the first 'product' of this has finally claimed a place on our plenary agenda. As we all see, the collateral consequence of the long-running economic crisis is an increase in demand in the EU and globally for the discovery of hidden incomes, which the European Commission estimates will shorten member states' revenues by tens of billions each year.  The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis appears to increase the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance. I see that, in parallel, we must also take decisive action in the various international for a, such as the OECD and the G20, so that others follow Europe's example and that no one can slip away from their efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion at global level. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must continue to commit to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals already put forward in tax fraud cases and to implementing measures that have already been adopted.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I supported in plenary the interim report presented by the TAXE Committee on ways to combat the tax optimization practices uncovered by the LuxLeaks scandal. This text is far from perfect, but it has the advantage of maintaining the pressure, including media, on multinationals (which have refused to be auditioned) and states that engage in large-scale tax-encircling operations and sit on the rules of "free and undistorted" competition of which they are the other champions.  The report also raises the right questions about transparency, the role and protection of whistleblowers, the separation of advisory activities from the public and the private sector. It outlines solutions for the allocation of the consolidated common corporate tax base, some of which could be returned to the EU budget as its own resource. He called for the reform of the 'code of conduct' group, a place of cooperation on corporate taxation which should provide for a stronger political presence, making it accountable to the European Parliament.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The report contains direct taxation and tax harmonisation powers for the EU that I cannot support. Too few of the UK delegation’s amendments were taken on board. We had tried to emphasise the benefits of fair tax competition, emphasised the important role of state aid rules acting as a deterrent in Member States’ compliance, underlined the fact that issues relating to direct taxation are a national prerogative and that changes to Council unanimity rules would require changes to the treaty. In addition, the ECR tried to make the report a bit softer by mitigating the alleged misconducts by MNCs and Member States. However the final report does not reflect our amendments.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Our desire to curb tax and other financial fraud is commendable. What is worrying to me, on the one hand, is that a number of Member States have been reluctant to answer the Commission's questions and that almost all multinational corporations have refused to participate in Commission meetings. This suggests to me that these companies have a clear reluctance to participate in the adoption of new rules.  The other thing that strikes me is that the proposals for amendments made by our group, as well as those we supported, tabled by our EPP and ALDE colleagues, were not accepted.  I also worry that all the proposed measures will either not be respected by certain Member States of the Union, or if they are respected, they will only affect SMEs that are the main taxpayers and will not affect MNIs, which are most likely to have armies of lawyers, financiers and accountants constantly seeking loopholes in the laws to save their employers taxes.  I am also concerned that if we tighten the measures too much, a number of current large EU taxpayers will take their companies to the so-called "no-go zones". offshore areas, which, instead of helping to improve collection, will reduce the Union's money. That is why I do not support the report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although the report contains many positive elements in terms of ensuring a fair tax system, in fact there are points and proposals for guidelines aimed at large companies continuing to avoid tax and to subject more tax burdens to small and medium-sized enterprises that are not networked like multinationals. The multinationals ignored invitations to submit data requested by the TDSA and it was not possible to establish a legal basis for sanctions. For all the above reasons, but also because the introduction of common taxation throughout the Union would be an unacceptable assignment of National Sovereignty, I am voting against the report as a whole. The solution is the abolition of the Single Market and the introduction of the obligation for Companies to set up subsidiaries in the countries they want to operate, which will be taxed on the spot.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Empty state reapers and fair burden-sharing are increasingly prompting the Member States of the European Union to coordinate the fight against tax fraud and evasion. It seems that the subject has become permanent in our Parliament, since we have been given the right to set up a new commission to confirm this, and the first 'product' of this has finally claimed a place on our plenary agenda.  As we all see, the collateral consequence of a long-running economic crisis is the increased demand in the EU and globally for the discovery of hidden incomes, which the European Commission estimates will shorten member states' revenues by tens of billions each year. I see that, in parallel, in the various international for a, such as the OECD and the G20, we must also take decisive action to ensure that others follow Europe's example and that no one can slip away from their efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion at global level. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must continue to commit to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals already put forward in tax fraud cases and to implementing measures that have already been adopted.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The proposal addresses questions about how companies operating in several countries handle corporation tax and the extent to which Member States report on state aid linked to corporation tax. It is important to have transparency on these issues and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the proposal as a whole. However, I voted against the proposals relating to a common tax base.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 A fair tax system, based on the principle of taxation in the Member State where profits are generated, the presentation by multinationals of financial information country by country, the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base, the creation of a common EU-wide definition of tax havens and the protection of whistleblowers are some of the actions proposed by the European Parliament. Most large multinational companies operating in Europe pay effective rates of 5%, sometimes lower than this amount, even in countries where the nominal tax rate is around 30% and more. The European Parliament wants multinational companies in all sectors to disclose, in their financial statements, broken down by Member State and by third country in which they have establishments, a range of aggregate information, including pre-tax profits or losses, taxes on profits or losses, the number of workers, assets held and basic information on tax rulings (country reporting). This information should be made available to the public, possibly in the form of a central register at EU level.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it does not take enough account of the establishment of transparency measures.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. We have always said that the free movement of capital would lead to worsening tax erosion and avoidance, and would facilitate the transfer of profits, which would damage public coffers. The creation of the single market has proved to be beneficial to multinationals and detrimental to workers and SMEs.  In the name of competitiveness and the attraction of foreign investment, Member States compete with each other. Multinationals, in an unceasing search for profit, aided by large consultants and with the connivance of policy makers, dictate the rules of the game. Luxleaks and tax commission investigations showed that while governments designed tax decisions and laws that allowed multinationals to minimise their tax rate and encouraged them to transfer profits, in the name of compliance with the PEC and burned, the need for tax revenues, stability and the tranquility of financial markets, they dictated so-called austerity policies (worsening labour taxes , reducing the progressivity of direct taxes and cuts in public spending). The report voted today sins because it did not make public the tax rulings that were taken, by not quantifying the size of these decisions, their impact on the tax revenues of the different Member States and for being soft on those responsible for those decisions.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on early tax decisions as certain tax practices should be managed within the Member States; there is also a real risk that a collective EU response to combat tax evasion would put the EU itself in an unfavourable position compared to other global competitors.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ GUE/NGL welcomes the substance of the TAXE Committee report. It contains useful proposals for greater tax justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on tax fairness. Despite our many contributions to the report’s final shape, we abstain in today's vote for the following reasons: Political responsibility for tax dumping in the EU has not been fully established and the report does not call for the necessary prolongation of the current mandate. Access to documents remained unsatisfactory by Council, Commission and Member States. Multinational corporations have only responded after repeated invitations to TAXE, no legal base for sanctions could be established yet and they could not be interrogated thoroughly. Moreover, contradictions of the President of the EU Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, during his testimony to TAXE, were not followed up.  Substance-wise, core issues lack ambition beyond what the EU Commission has proposed already. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws adjusted. We welcome the idea of consolidation of the tax base. However, we miss a clear commitment to broaden the tax base and we criticise the interim period before consolidation which allows for cross border loss/profit offsetting and no further backstops to prevent tax competition between EU countries."

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Many Member States have introduced or intend to introduce measures to address tax avoidance, in particular with regard to limiting the deductibility of interest, anti-abuse rules, a better definition of permanent residence. Without a cooperative approach, unilateral measures taken by Member States against base erosion can contribute to increasing complexity, creating new mismatches and, as a result, more opportunities for tax evasion within the internal market. The latest proposal from the European Commission aims to move towards better coordination of Member States' tax systems with a view to strengthening the internal market, tackling double taxation or double non-taxation and preserving the right of Member States to collect taxes effectively.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which contains an analysis of the practices through which a wide variety of multinational companies have been allowed to carry out tax avoidance and/or evasion practices. In this context, there is no doubt about the role of the scandal linked to Luxembourg and Mr Juncker.

text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although the report contains many positive elements in terms of ensuring a fair tax system, in fact, there are points and proposals for guidelines aimed at large companies continuing to avoid tax and to subject more tax burdens to small and medium-sized enterprises that are not networked like multinationals. name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the final report of the Special Committee on tax rulings that, after 10 months of investigations on tax rulings and other harmful practices, many hearings and committee delegations, presents the TAXE Committee findings and recommendations. In particular, I welcome the call on the Commission to speed up the presentation of legislative modifications for the prompt establishment of a compulsory EU-wide Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) with a short and concrete deadline in order to introduce the ‘consolidation’ element. I support mandatory and public country-by-country reporting, automatic and mandatory exchange of information regarding all tax rulings that are still valid, registered in a central directory to which the Commission has full access; and a common European list of tax havens, ‘independently of their location’ based on comprehensive, transparent, robust, objectively verifiable and commonly accepted indicators.  Finally, we have a new agenda for tax justice, which will allow major improvements in tax coordination and cooperation in the EU to fight aggressive tax planning.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that we must continue to commit to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals already put forward in tax fraud cases and to implementing the measures already adopted. The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis appears to increase the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance. In various international for a, such as the OECD and G20, we must also take decisive action to ensure that others follow Europe's example and that no one slips out of their efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion at global level.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report, especially with regard to its priorities for transparency. I believe that the Union can become an example and a global leader in terms of tax transparency, but this requires targeted and effective measures.  I urge that transparency and support for tax administration investigations be given critical importance in order to increase public accountability of multinationals.  I also consider it important that transparency can have a strong disinvestment and change behaviour, both through the reputational risk of non-regulatory firms and by providing information to competent authorities, which can then adopt corrective measures and penalties. In my opinion, a balance must be struck between the need for transparency and the need to protect sensitive commercial interests and compliance with data protection rules.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the EU's progress towards a European tax system to eliminate distortions in this important area between Member States. We must prevent companies, mostly multinationals, as well as individuals, from benefiting from existing distortions in order to avoid paying their taxes. Similarly, the tax authorities of the Member States share very little tax information between them, which impairs the fight against tax evasion.

As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I congratulate Mrs Ferreira on the important result achieved in the report of the TAXE Special Committee launched by the European Parliament. The S&D Group has played a very important role since the start of the special committee's work in underlining the priorities for a fairer and more transparent European tax policy.  The scandal of tax havens and the frequent phenomena of circumvention must stop: Europe cannot tolerate such distorting mechanisms for the single market and our social model to remain in some Member States. The CRIS Committee's report puts forward very concrete proposals which we now hope the Commission will take on, not least because of the precise commitments made by President Juncker in this regard before Parliament.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on advance tax rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect because I believe that the proposals made by the TAXE Special Committee on transparency and coordination of tax rulings, on the common tax base, on the protection of whistleblowers, and finally on the country-by-country relationship are very timely and necessary to tackle in a concrete and precise way long-established problems such as tax evasion and avoidance in the EU , and consequently multinationals pay fair taxes and, above all, where profits are generated. We are faced with a paradox, which the TAXE Committee has clearly highlighted, on the one hand the multinationals that say they are prepared to pay taxes and in return claim a level playing field, and on the other hand the need to create equal rules throughout the EU. Therefore, I fully agree with taxe's conclusions that the synthesis of this paradox should be found in the review of corporate taxation in the EU, in the substantial reform of the corporate tax framework, through the creation of a corporate tax base (CCCTB), through appropriate legislative instruments and effective actions to combat tax dumping practised by many Member States.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report adopted today (24.11.2015) was intended, on the one hand, to describe tax control in the EU Member States and, on the other hand, to make recommendations on this matter. This was the result of six months of intensive work by the TAXE Committee, including expert hearings, as well as delegations to a number of Member States to explain how to interpret and apply national tax legislation.  Given that tax fraud and tax avoidance cause trillions of euros in losses to the EU budget each year, specific issues related to corporate base erosion and aggressive tax planning practices have been studied in detail at international level. Globalisation and the digitisation of the economy have completely changed the way markets work. Today, most large companies are cross-border, requiring international tax rules, and corporate tax models were created in the first half of the 20th century, when such activities were limited in scope. Mismatch between national rules and loopholes facilitate tax evasion.  In conclusion, it is necessary both to strengthen national measures to combat tax fraud in the Member States and to take a coherent EU stance on this phenomenon.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Together with my colleagues in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I am campaigning for companies to pay their taxes in the countries where economic activity actually takes place in the future. To this end, it is important that we have a better exchange of tax data in the future. This is the only way to develop uniformstandards. Until member states work more closely together on this, there will continue to be potential tax loopholes for resourceful companies. Once again, we see that joint action in Europe makes us stronger.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TAXE report, because the work of the TAXE Committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem across Europe. It costs billions every year: billions that should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services. For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which ordinary people are the losers. This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these dreadful practices once and for all. Now it is time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK government – to listen to the will of the people and to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ First of all, I would like to thanks the special committee for the elaboration of this report following the Lux Leaks scandal that highlighted questionable tax practices allowing 340 big companies to realize big tax savings. I supported this report that puts forwards recommendations to avoid aggressive tax practices and distortion of competition.  I however condemn the fact that several documents that were asked by the special committee were never disclosed; I therefore voted in favour of a six-month extension of its mandate to allow the committee to complete its work. I also supported amendments calling for full access to the documents of the Code of Conduct group and for the creation of a public register of companies at EU level in order to prevent aggressive and harmful tax practices and fraud and improve transparency.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This report is the conclusion of the special commission on the tax ruling scandal, better known as the "LuxLeaks" affair. For decades, countries such as Luxembourg have allowed multinationals, particularly in the digital economy or finance, to relocate their profits in order to evade all or part of the tax. As a result, France has suffered a shortfall of about 10 to 15 billion a year. The National Front has always supported in the European Parliament the texts to combat tax evasion and evasion. We thus endorsed the end of banking secrecy with Switzerland on 1 January 2018 and voted on the reports to combat aggressive tax optimisation. It was in this continuity that I voted in favour of the final report on tax rulings. In particular, it provides recommendations to Member States and the Commission on transparency and tax competition. As France is one of the least tax-competitive countries in the Union, the most restrictive measures will not harm us...

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I welcome the most important part of this report, which contains useful proposals for greater fiscal justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on fiscal justice. However, I abstained in this vote for the following reasons: responsibility for the collapse of tax systems in Europe has not been fully attributed, and the report does not call for the necessary extension of the current mandate; access to documents remains unsatisfactory on the part of the Council, the Commission and the Member States. Multinational corporations have only responded after multiple invitations to the commission, no legal basis has been established for sanctions and have not been thoroughly questioned; Moreover, the contradictions in Jean-Claude Juncker's speech have not been clarified.  In substance, the report does not go beyond the Commission's own proposals. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws should be adjusted. I welcome the idea of a consolidation of the tax base. However, I miss a clear commitment to broaden the fiscal base and criticize the transition period before consolidation.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, because I am not in favour of a common consolidated tax base. In particular, I do not agree with paragraph 170, which undermines the principle of unanimity in the Council, because I believe that every Member State should have a veto on tax policy. I regret that the European Parliament has adopted a report which encroaches on the competences of the Member States in order to harmonise tax law in the European Union. Uniform rules in this area are unnecessary and detrimental to the competitiveness of Member States.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TAXE report, because the work of the TAXE Committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem right across Europe. It costs billions every year: billions that should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services. For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which ordinary people are the losers. This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these dreadful practices once and for all. Now it is time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK government – to listen to the will of the people and do something to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. This report is the result of the work of the TAXE Committee, which, after nine months, is issuing a number of very interesting proposals. I have therefore voted in favour of him and I hope that his recommendations will be followed by effect as soon as possible.  The unfair tax competition that is taking place in Europe today is aberrant in many ways. The unanimity rule that applies on these issues is quite damaging. It allows a few countries to benefit from it at the expense of the many. Above all, it allows multinationals to reduce their taxes in a scandalous way.
