In the face of this situation, the TAXE Committee recommends, among other things, the implementation of the ACCIS - a consolidated common corporate tax base - which would allow for a common system for calculating the corporate tax base. With the publication of country-by-country information (CBCR), it is a matter of requiring publicly traded companies to make public information about their activities and the taxes they pay in all the countries where they operate. Also mentioned are the automatic exchange of information, the drafting of lists of tax havens and the protection of whistleblowers.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect because after the Lux Leaks revelations, legitimate questions were raised from the media and from citizens, also given the complexity of this topic. This report tries to provide clear answers to these questions.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats voted in favour of the TAXE report. We see this as an offensive and partly visionary text that drives the debate forward on issues of tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. Not all recommendations may or should be implemented in the near future, but it is nonetheless useful that a clear and concrete agenda is now being established. It is important to emphasise in this context that the tax rates themselves in this area must essentially remain a national matter. It must be up to the Member States themselves to decide how high the tax rates need to be in order to secure sufficient revenue in public budgets.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Empty state reapers and fair burden-sharing are increasingly prompting the Member States of the European Union to coordinate the fight against tax fraud and evasion. The subject has become permanent in the European Parliament, as we have been given the right to set up a new commission to confirm this, and the first 'product' of this has now claimed a place on our plenary agenda. As we all see, the collateral consequence of a long-running economic crisis is an increase in demand in the EU and globally for the discovery of hidden incomes, which the European Commission estimates will shorten member states' revenues by tens of billions each year.  The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis appears to increase the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance. I see that, in parallel, we must also take decisive action in the various international for a, such as the OECD and G20, so that others follow Europe's example and that no country can slip away from efforts at global level to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must continue to commit to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals already put forward in tax fraud cases and to implementing the measures already adopted.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The ESA/BPA is in line with the substance of the TAXE committee's report, which contains useful proposals for greater fiscal fairness and highlights the negative impact of austerity on tax justice. Nevertheless, we are abstaining from today's vote for the following reasons: Political responsibility for tax dumping in the EU has not been fully attributed and the report does not call for the extension of the committee's present mandate. Access to Council, Commission and Member State documents was unsatisfactory. Multinational companies responded only after repeated calls from TAXE and no legal basis for sanctions was created and therefore the companies were not adequately interrogated. Also, inconsistencies in Jean-Claude Juncker's statements during his testimony were not clarified. As far as the substance is concerned, on the main issues the report does not propose measures other than those already proposed by the Commission. Tax rulings must be made public and tax secrecy laws adapted. There is no commitment to try to increase the corporate tax base.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ While I welcome the report on Tax Rulings and other Measures similar in Nature or effect as it deals with many important tax issues, I voted against mandatory CCCTB. CCCTB should be optional. Furthermore, I do not support the EP perspective on the unanimity rule on Taxation matters. Ireland secured a protocol in a recent referendum guaranteeing the unanimity in Tax matters and I fully support this position. The Commission have already launched a public consultation to help identify the key measures for inclusion in the relaunch of the CCCTB proposal. Ireland maintains a strong position that tax is an issue for Member States and I will examine the Commission’s new proposal when it is published with that in mind.  The report overall has a lot of  very positive aspects, in particular that whistle-blowers whose revelations promote the public interest should be better protected, increased transparency, Taxpayer Identification Number (TIN) and the simplification of the tax system.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ The Irish EPP Delegation regrettably voted against this report. While there are many positive aspects in this report, overall we believe that Parliament has gone beyond its mandate in relation to tax matters in this instance. Taxation is a national competence and this is clearly not respected in the report. Member States should have full power to set their corporate tax rates and the consolidation of corporation taxes across the EU is clearly a form of tax rate harmonisation. The EU’s competence on tax matters is to ensure that corporate tax systems are fair and transparent; if these conditions are fulfilled, tax competition should be considered a positive thing for Europe.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The European Parliament responded to the Luxleaks revelations by setting up a special committee on the role and impact of tax rulings. I supported the creation of this special committee and voted in favour of the report. ALFA is committed to ensuring that all companies and all citizens are taxed according to their capacity and actually pay these taxes. We need a functioning European regulatory framework in tax law. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Empty state reapers and fair burden-sharing are increasingly prompting the Member States of the European Union to coordinate the fight against tax fraud and evasion. The subject has become permanent in Parliament, and a new commission has been set up to inquiry such matters. One of the consequences of the long-running economic crisis is an increase in demand for concealed income in Europe and globally. The European Commission estimates that tax evasion and fraud shorten member states' revenues by tens of billions each year. The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis increases the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance.    To this end, we must also make our voices heard in various international for a, such as the OECD and the G20. We must also take decisive action to ensure that others follow Europe's example and that no one slips away from their efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion at global level. I believe that we must continue to commit ourselves to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals on tax fraud cases and to implementing the measures adopted. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of the TAXE report, because the work of the TAXE Committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem right across Europe. It costs billions every year: billions that should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services. For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which ordinary people are the losers. This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these dreadful practices once and for all. Now it is time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK government – to listen to the will of the people and do something to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ I am proud to be a supporter of the Tax Justice campaign and, as this Parliament’s longstanding rapporteur on Corporate Social Responsibility, have always argued that the fair payment of tax and transparent reporting of doing so is an integral obligation for responsible business.  Corporate tax evasion costs the UK GBP 9 billion a year, with small and medium sized businesses paying 30% more tax than their multinational counterparts. This is unfair and wrong. I am proud to have helped win European rules requiring transparent payments by extractive companies, and hope today’s vote will be a staging post towards establishing full country-by-country reporting for corporate tax payments, which the European Council has promised. I am very disappointed that one of the Conservative MEPs for my own East of England constituency voted against today’s measures. He should explain why our small businesses have to pay taxes that big business doesn't; and why his party which says it is pro-business refuses to back action which creates a fairer business environment for all?

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ While this Report suggests a number of positive measures, I remain of the view that Member States should retain full competence over decisions concerning taxation and I disagree with the notion that the EU should have tax powers. I therefore I voted against all text concerning the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) including paragraphs 29, 97, 114, 116, 117, 118. On the other hand, I voted in favour of protecting Whistleblowers (Paragraph 143, Amendment 21) and supported the call for the Commission ‘to fully implement the EU Ombudsman’s recommendations regarding the composition of expert groups’ (Paragraph 127). Moreover I welcome measures to increase transparency regarding the activities of multinational companies is essential for ensuring tax administrations are able to effectively combat BEPS (Paragraph 135). The positive aspects in the report allowed me, on balance, to support it in the final vote.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 The negative effects of tax evasion of multinational companies are borne by all other taxpayers, including small and medium-sized enterprises. A comprehensive legal framework for fair corporation tax in Europe must therefore be established. In the report of the Special Committee, we make it clear what we expect from the Member States and the European Commission: a comprehensive package against aggressive tax planning. All companies must pay taxes in countries where profits are made. For many years, multinational companies have reduced their taxes through preferential offers in different Member States. Therefore, taxes supporting our health, education and infrastructure services have been paid almost exclusively by SMEs and citizens. This situation has become unbearable, particularly during periods of harsh budget cuts in social assistance expenditure.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on Tax Rulings and other measures of a similar nature or impact, as I believe that taxation models have changed and modernized, especially in today's time of globalisation and digitisation of the economy. The report highlights the need to adopt a balanced and fair tax policy that will be an integral part of structural reform in the Member States, which I fully agree with, as I think national and international rules on taxation need to keep pace with the development of the business environment.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The final report of the TAXE Committee on tax rulings and other aggressive tax optimisation measures in the EU, in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, has more generally raised awareness of the schemes of some multinationals allowing them to evade almost any tax. The damage to the public finances of the member countries would be severe, in the order of 10 to 15 billion euros per year for France, for example.  Since most of these schemes are illegal, new forms of regulation need to be found. This text makes recommendations to Member States and the Commission, which are based on the implementation of transparency measures and the limitation of rescripting opportunities and similar measures relating to tax competition, as long as they prove unfair. In the end, the report shows an awareness but does not prejudge the measures that will be taken. On the rescript exchange directive, a corollary to TAXE's work, the Council's position of 6 October was disappointing.  Despite some reservations, so I voted for it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason I voted against.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 A year after the publication of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', a report was submitted to the Plenary of the European Parliament containing proposals for the European Commission to prevent the evasion and tax cuts of multinational supranational companies in the European Union. The controversial practices against which this EP has defined themselves distort competition in the internal market and reduce the revenue of state budgets. The steps discussed in the Special Committee on Tax Rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect include a more efficient exchange of information between member states' tax authorities or harmonisation of the way in which corporation tax is calculated (not its rates). As a member of the committee concerned, I have been dealing with the issue for a long time, which is why I supported this report.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Elisa Ferreira and Michael Theurer on tax rulings and similar measures by their nature or effect. This report follows on from the work of informing Member States about tax practices towards businesses. The report highlights the lack of willingness of Member States to tackle unfair tax practices and stresses that transparency must be the order of the day but should not disadvantage European companies. Harmonising practices within member states therefore remains necessary. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to make corporate taxes fairer in Europe. It is indeed important that multinationals pay their taxes where they make their profits without organising tax competition between Member States. The report calls on states to agree on a consolidated common corporate tax base, common definitions of tax terms and greater transparency of tax rulings.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I agree with this report. It calls for a more transparent level playing field in the mediation of insurance, the offer and the information, as well as better consideration of changes in the business behaviour of insurance companies and reinsurers. The aim is to provide consumers with the same level of protection, despite the differences between distribution channels. In order to ensure that the same level of protection applies and that consumers benefit from comparable standards, in particular in the area of information disclosure, a level playing field between distributors is essential. The report ensures this by means of a number of technical measures and would make it possible to buy insurance cover where it offers the best conditions, and not necessarily in the country where you are staying.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 Full tax evasion, tax shifting schemes and aggressive tax planning were, are and will be one of the greatest challenges facing the European Union. The Member States of the European Union have lost huge sums of money as a result of these unfair tax transactions, and this has profoundly hampered fair competition. I support the fact that large multinational corporations should pay taxes in the Member State where they carry out their economic activities and make profits, rather than legally shifting that profits to other Member States which grant tax credits to those companies. I fully support the right of states to compete in the field of taxation, but this competition must be fair. I agree that Member States need to coordinate their tax laws more in order not to create loopholes that companies would use to reduce the tax due.  I repeat that I support fair competition between the countries of the European Union in the field of taxation and believe that tax legislation should remain a national responsibility. Unfortunately, the report consists of proposals that would undermine the sovereignty of the Member States in this area, and i therefore abstained in the vote. Each Member State currently has the right to shape its own tax policy, and these rights must be maintained. I believe that certain points in this report undermine the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to tax matters and could therefore have a negative impact on the practices so far. Latvia should be able to tax in such a way as to promote entrepreneurship and attract investment.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the report, as it calls on multinational companies in Europe to publish information on their profits, taxes and activities in every country in which they operate. Labour MEPs have been calling for this measure for years, as it will allow governments and citizens alike to see where multinationals make their money and where they pay their taxes. The report also calls for greater action to be taken against tax havens, by agreeing a common definition of the term and then applying sanctions against those companies which make use of them in order to avoid paying tax.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The European Parliament has responded to the Luxleaks revelations by setting up a special committee on the role and impact of tax rulings. I support this report: ALFA is committed to ensuring that all businesses and all citizens are taxed according to their capacity and actually pay these taxes. We need a functioning European regulatory framework in tax law. The coordinated report calls for measures such as a common corporate tax base and the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings. These measures are designed to make competition between Member States more transparent and the rules of the game clearer. The measures will help to make discrimination in the field of international tax law more difficult. They restore fair conditions of competition both between Member States and between companies. Tax competition between Member States will be maintained. It helps to tame state actors in their spending behaviour, ties them to the wishes of taxpayers and encourages them to innovate. The right of states to decide fully autonomously on the level of tax rates is not restricted. But tax justice would be greatly improved by the measures, for the benefit of citizens and the middle class.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Empty state reapers and fair burden-sharing are increasingly prompting the Member States of the European Union to coordinate the fight against tax fraud and evasion. It seems that the subject has become permanent in our Parliament, since we have been given the right to set up a new commission to confirm this, and the first 'product' of this has finally claimed a place on our plenary agenda.  As we all see, the collateral consequence of a long-running economic crisis is the increased demand in the EU and globally for the discovery of hidden incomes, which the European Commission estimates will shorten member states' revenues by tens of billions each year. The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis appears to increase the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance.  I see that, in parallel, in the various international for a, such as the OECD and the G20, we must also take decisive action to ensure that others follow Europe's example and that no one can slip away from their efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion at global level. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that we must continue to commit to accelerating the adoption of EU proposals already put forward in tax fraud cases and to implementing measures that have already been adopted.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention for this report, because I am not in the position to support it even if some of our amendments were included in the report. One main problem is that this report does not give explanations on the political responsibilities of top EU officials. Furthermore, the document was not accessible while many Member States and multinational companies did not comply with information requested by the EP’s TAXE Committee. Even if this report goes a step forward, I cannot fully support it.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: in writing. – GUE/NGL welcomes the substance of the TAXE Committee report. It contains useful proposals for greater tax justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on tax fairness. Despite our many contributions to the report's final shape, we abstain in today’s vote for the following reasons: Political responsibility for tax dumping in the EU has not been fully established and the report does not call for the necessary prolongation of the current mandate. Access to documents remained unsatisfactory by Council, Commission and Member States. Multinational corporations have only responded after repeated invitations to TAXE, no legal base for sanctions could be established yet and they could not be interrogated thoroughly. Moreover, contradictions of the President of the EU Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, during his testimony to TAXE were not followed up.  Substance-wise, core issues lack ambition beyond what the EU Commission has proposed already. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws adjusted. We welcome the idea of consolidation of the tax base. However, we miss a clear commitment to broaden the tax base and we criticise the interim period before consolidation which allows for cross border loss/profit offsetting and no further backstops to prevent tax competition between EU countries.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. As we know, there is no internationally agreed definition of tax rulings, except for a Reference from the Commission, which defines them as communication, agreement or any other instrument or action with similar effects.  I have decided to support this measure because the function of these decisions should be to provide legal certainty for the taxpayer by reducing the financial risk to honest businesses. Unfortunately, their use is instead linked to the dynamics of corporate tax avoidance which has a direct impact on national budgets and on the distribution of the tax burden among categories of taxpayers.  I welcome the work of the special committee responsible in this area, but I also consider it vital that all Member States, as well as the European institutions, make constant efforts to prevent harmful tax practices and to promote fairer and more effective corporate taxation in the EU.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I approved the report presented by the SPECIAL committee TAXE, chaired by my colleague Alain Lamassoure, proposing several essential recommendations to address the problem of advantageous tax provisions negotiated between states and companies (tax registers), which contribute to the erosion of tax bases and damage the state of the Member States' public finances. I also voted on paragraph 142 of the report, in order to ask the Commission to propose the creation of a legislative framework to protect whistleblowers.  Similarly, I supported the call on the Committee to put in place a number of instruments to ensure that they have this legal and financial certainty, without approving the idea of the creation of specific European bodies which could prove to be expensive. I consider that the establishment of a legislative framework protecting whistleblowers while ensuring compliance with "business secrets" is of great importance. I also wanted these instruments to be reactive and effective, supporting the idea of a protection mechanism for whistleblowers who would turn to the public in the absence of a response from the relevant authorities within a month of being notified of the situation.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. After the LuxLeaks scandal, concerning tax evasion by multinationals with the complicity of governments and tax administrations in some European states, Parliament created a special TAX committee. Our concerns about the scope of the mandate, the limitation of investigative powers and the willingness to use it to whitewash those responsible have been confirmed. The political responsibility of the European Union for tax dumping has not been established. The state report has been defaced with amendments from the right. Finally, the responses of the Commission or some companies have been patchy or absent. However, the report before us contains useful proposals and reflects the negative impact of austerity on fiscal justice. So we wanted an extension of this commission in order to shed light on these practices. But it has hampered conservative, socialist and liberal groups. Everything was then done to close this commission after the adoption of its first report. I therefore abstained because I refuse to be involved in a manoeuvre to bury a file as fundamental as tax justice and I support the continuation of the investigation.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on tax rulings and other aggressive tax optimisation measures in the Eu. The work of the TAXE Committee, in the wake of the LuxLeaks case, has more generally raised awareness of the schemes of some unscrupulous multinationals that allow them to evade almost any tax, by exploiting loopholes in Member States' legislation or taking advantage of their differences.  The damage to the public finances of the member countries is severe, and would be in the range of 10 to 15 billion euros per year for France.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The work of the TAXE Commission has served to demonstrate that tax agreements were in breach of competition rules, as well as evidence of the complicity of Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem in this scandal. The report, however, only partially reflects our demands. On the one hand, tax avoidance practices are denounced and the Commission is asked for ambition in its proposals for transparency and fiscal harmonisation. But many of these requests do not go beyond good intentions and the ties between multinationals guilty of tax avoidance, the Member States and the Commission are not adequately investigated for lack of documents and political will. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The European Parliament responded to the Luxleaks revelations by setting up a special committee on the role and impact of tax rulings. I supported the creation of this special committee and voted in favour of the report. ALFA is committed to ensuring that all companies and all citizens are taxed according to their capacity and actually pay these taxes. We need a functioning European regulatory framework in tax law. The coordinated report calls for measures such as a common corporate tax base and the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings. These measures are likely to make competition between Member States more transparent and the rules of the game clearer. The measures will help to make discrimination in and through international taxation more difficult. They restore a level playing field, both between Member States and between companies. Tax competition between Member States will be maintained. It helps to tame state actors in their spending behaviour, ties them to the wishes of taxpayers and encourages them to innovate. The right of states to decide fully autonomously on the level of tax rates is not restricted.  But tax justice would be greatly improved by the measures – for the benefit of citizens and the middle class.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am against tax harmonisation in the form of a common consolidated corporate tax base. The proposal 'supports the introduction as soon as possible of a complete and mandatory common consolidated corporate tax base'.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ There needs to be a consensus between Member States to leave less room for tax fraud. Member States should apply internal tax laws complemented by tax agreements under Union supervision. As a result of tax fraud, the Union's loss of around 1 billion euros in potential tax revenues or the global annual loss of over €50 billion in national budgets is estimated. Preventing tax evasion and tax avoidance requires cooperation between Member States' tax authorities. Accordingly, Croatia provided the EU with the requested data in 2015. A coherent approach at EU level is increasingly needed to address common challenges such as tax evasion between Member States. Monitoring should be carried out to ensure that national tax policies comply with EU policies. In this context, it is important to create a specific assurance that companies in one country do not have an unfair advantage over competitors in other countries, and to ensure compliance with the principle of non-discrimination and free movement in the single market.  Consequently, I supported the report of MP Elise Ferreira and MP Michael Theur.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Speculation, tax havens, tax evasion, fraud, speculative capital transfers will prepare every european citizen by hundreds of euros a year. European states lose more than a thousand billion euros a year. Individual tax policy puts other economies at a disadvantage. Common procedures are the solution. If a country does not cooperate, the Commission must intervene. Member States' tax systems, which are significantly different in defining the tax base and the amount of the tax rate. Although the area of tax policy falls within national competence as a matter of priority, cross-border trade, the free movement of capital and labour, globalisation and the digitalisation of trade and the market will require some fundamental tax policy issues to be set up by the EU. Structural changes in the Member States and the EU must therefore also include a fair, balanced and transparent reform of tax systems.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Writing. The work of the TAXE Special Committee has paid off? I have attended all the hearings , from trade union representatives, business associations, big-four audit firms to journalists who have played a key role in publishing controversial tax practices. We have been able to shed some light on the tax avoidance policies of companies and Member States. The costs to the detriment of honest taxpayers and small and medium-sized enterprises amount to at least EUR 70 billion.  So our demands rightly mean that frameworks for fair tax competition must be created and loopholes closed for multinational companies. Qualified staff in tax administrations must be recruited to fulfil their duty of control. We need clear transparency rules to eliminate conflicts of interest. Finally, agreement on the principle that companies tax their profits where they are generated seems to be in sight. A responsible tax strategy must become part of any corporate social responsibility reporting. A success for the EPP is the exception for small and medium-sized enterprises in the disclosure of accountability reports, which will be drafted in the future on a country-by-country basis. I agree with the idea that our mandate as a special committee should be extended because we have been deprived of a number of documents so far. The interim report adopted today can only be a first step towards greater tax justice in the EU.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect because they are not sufficiently documented, and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/11/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for it. This was the report of the TAXE Committee, Parliament's special committee, which wanted to hear from multinationals in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal. This committee has become aware of the actions of unscrupulous multinationals that exploit legal loopholes in the Member States' system of legislation and thus manage to evade almost any tax. As the hearings took place late, it was suggested that the mandate of this commission be extended for another 6 months. The commission's report suggests sanctions against multinationals and their boards guilty of fraud, proposes an overhaul of the tax code of conduct and calls for enhanced protection for whistleblowers. On the other hand, we remain firmly opposed to the proposal to harmonize rates for direct taxes. Nevertheless, this report shows an awareness and goes in the right direction.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on advance tax rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect. The 28 tax systems in force in the European Union are very different, both as regards the tax base and as regards rates; The national preferential arrangements and the aforementioned un coordinated fiscal framework at EU level are due to the lack of cooperation between Member States, which has a serious impact throughout the Union, precisely because the Member States do not take into account the consequences that fiscal measures have on other countries. It is therefore essential to develop a fair fiscal policy as an integral part of Member States' policy in order to have a harmonised fiscal situation. Considering that tax rulings also cover a wide range of practices in the Member States, ranging from ad hoc policies to clearly defined enforcement of the law, it is also emphasised that lower corporate taxation in some Member States can guarantee relatively higher tax revenues than guaranteed by higher tax rates.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report and support its basic message that multinationals should pay fair tax and pay their taxes where they make their profits.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report dealing with tax rulings and related measures. It has been around a year since a special committee of inquiry was set up in the European Parliament in connection with the Luxleaks scandal. I supported the establishment of this committee as well as the extension of its mandate. Statistics show that the EU loses EUR 1 trillion a year in taxes, roughly equivalent to the annual GDP of Spain, the EU's fifth largest economy. So it's an alarming number. I am convinced of the need for joint Eu cooperation in this area. We must work together to combat tax evasion, tax fraud, tax havens and aggressive tax planning. However, the report also foresees harmonisation of taxes and fiscal policies in the EU. I do not think that the Member States are prepared for this. In my opinion, tax issues and fiscal policy should remain the full competence of individual Member States. For this reason, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the tax proposal as it is also aimed at stemming the current economic crisis.  The LuxLeaks scandal, on the one hand, and aggressive tax planning by multinationals on the other, were a priority objective on the political agenda of the Member States, the EU, the OECD and the G20. Despite this, no clear progress has been made to date. The report by Mrs Ferreira and Mr Theurer seeks to point out that, in this context, many countries have finally introduced measures to combat tax avoidance, in particular with regard to limiting the deductibility of interests, anti-abuse rules, measures aimed at excluding companies that engage in misconduct from public procurement, and the publication of tax planning mechanisms aimed at making the tax system regain greater credibility.  At the same time, we certainly want a cooperative approach, without which there would be further opportunities for tax avoidance in the internal market.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. With the adoption of the report of the special committee TAXE, the European Parliament is not completing a cycle, but must instead open a new stage of voluntarism for tax justice. Corporate inequality in taxes and unfair competition from states in this area have for too long eluded the priorities of the European Union.  This text sets out real projects on the table to combat these practices and simplify taxation in Europe. The ACCIS, this consolidated common tax base, is the main weapon against tax avoidance schemes. The text also reaffirms the European Parliament's strong position on transparency: the rescripts of states must be exchanged while they are still valid and the Commission must have access to them; and multinationals must comply with a full country-by-country and public publication of information.  The EU institutions now have the opportunity and the duty to continue their work in the direction of this path opened by the TAXE Committee. The Council, above all, bears the responsibility of giving law to the proposals we make. Involved from the outset in the work of the committee, I voted enthusiastically - and hopefully - on this report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report contains some sensible proposals, but it ultimately aims at further centralisation of the EU. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ The Irish EPP delegation regrettably voted against this report. While there are many positive aspects in this report, overall we believe that Parliament has gone beyond its mandate in relation to tax matters in this instance. Taxation is a national competence and this is clearly not respected in the report. Member States should have full power to set their corporate tax rates and the consolidation of corporation taxes across the EU is clearly a form of tax rate harmonisation. The EU’s competence on tax matters is to ensure that corporate tax systems are fair and transparent; if these conditions are fulfilled, tax competition should be considered a positive thing for Europe.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In the wake of the LuxLeak case, concerning the revelations of tax evasion by Luxembourg, a special commission was set up. The report before us is the result of his work. The report "underlines the growing gap between legal and effective tax rates, particularly in the case of companies operating globally" and calls for "automatic exchange of information to apply to all rescripts issued by or on behalf of the government or tax administration of a Member State or its territorial or administrative entities".   But beyond the good promises, I note that Mr Juncker's effective role in setting up these tax-rescript mechanisms is largely ignored in the report, despite very vague responses at his hearing. In addition, many multinationals have refused to answer MPs about their tax practices: Amazon, HSCBC, Mc Donalds, Philip Morris...  I therefore abstain on this report and ask for the requalification of the special commission TAXE in committee of inquiry or at a minimum for the extension of the mandate of the special committee so that it can continue its work.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The TAXE Committee has delivered its final report on tax rulings and other aggressive tax optimisation measures in the EU. His work, in the wake of the LuxLeaks affair, has more generally raised awareness of the schemes of some unscrupulous multinationals allowing them to evade almost any tax. The damage to the public finances of the member countries would be severe, in the order of 10 to 15 billion euros per year for France, for example. Since most of these schemes are illegal, new forms of regulation need to be found.  This text makes recommendations to Member States and the Commission, which are based on the implementation of transparency measures and the limitation of rescripting opportunities and similar measures relating to tax competition, as long as they prove unfair. In the end, the report shows an awareness but does not prejudge the measures that will be taken. On the rescript exchange directive, a corollary to TAXE's work, the Council's position of 6 October was disappointing. Despite some reservations, therefore, I am voting in favour.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. One of the main tax policy priorities at EU level should be to promote greater cooperation between tax administrations in controlling and combating fraud and harmful tax competition. I have voted in favour of the report on advance tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect, which provides, inter part, for the exchange of information to be strengthened (where a tax agreement is concluded between a country and an undertaking, it will be automatically communicated to the European Commission and other countries).

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ We do need better tax transparency tools and better progress in our fight against tax fraud, but that does not mean the mandatory introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). Not every state in the EU faces the same economic realities, be it for their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources.  While the report did contain some useful points on transparency, which I supported, questions of tax of the nature of CCCTB must remain an issue of national competence since they reflect the different economies of Member States. A one-size-fits all approach and the CCCTB is not the right way forward for Europe as inevitably it would be the EU’s smaller economies, such as Malta, that would bear the disproportionate brunt of such policies. I therefore could not support the report.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The globalisation of the economy is changing the way individual markets operate. Most companies are currently transnational in nature and structure, thus going beyond national tax rules. There is a need to put in place a fair tax policy within the framework of member states' structural reforms. The uncoordinated tax framework is the result of a lack of cooperation between Member States. Improvements could occur with automatic and systematic exchange of information, but the current monitoring framework is not effective because the requirements set are not respected. Mismatches between tax systems at global level justify base erosion and result in significant tax evasion. I stress that action only at Union level will not be sufficient to address these issues. I welcome the Commission's commitment to promote automatic exchange of information as a future European and international standard of transparency. Tax rulings should aim at providing legal certainty, improving transparency and increasing cooperation between Member States in tax policy at Union level. I am of the opinion that the Member States should remain full of the power to set their corporate tax rates. However, I insist that tax competition in the EU and vis-à-vis third countries should take place within a clear framework of rules in order to guarantee fair competition between companies in the internal market.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ As far as taxation at EU level is concerned, I have always been in favour of transparency, coordination and exchange of information, including on an automatic basis. I will always agree with recommendations and fully support measures targeting abuse, enhancing transparency and addressing instances of harmful tax competition in the area of corporate taxation as promulgated by international standards. At the same time, I am not in favour of a move towards an EU—wide basis to introduce tax convergence and harmonisation in direct tax matters. It is important to keep in mind that small economies do not face the same economic realities and domestic market size, geographical proximity or resources as big ones and they therefore need a certain latitude in tax policy otherwise a one-size-fits all approach can place them in a disadvantaged position. I also have reservations about the mandatory CCCTB provisions and a financial transaction tax. In this context, I voted against this report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Special Committee on Tax Exemptions and other measures similar in nature or effect was established in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', which became public about tax exemptions in Luxembourg. In its report, the Special Committee recommends that Parliament state that the European Commission has not fulfilled its role as guardian of the Treaties as set out in Article 17(1) of the Treaty on European Union, as it has not acted on this matter and has not taken the necessary steps to notify the Member States and enforce their obligations, although it has had evidence that they are not fulfilling their obligations. It also proposes to state that the Commission has breached its obligations under Article 108 of the Treaty of Lisbon relating to the functioning of the internal market by not previously opening an investigation into State aid. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The FN voted in favour of this initiative report, not to give a white-seing to the Union's action on tax matters, but to signify a desire to put an end to the aggressive tax optimisation practiced with impunity by some multinationals who take advantage of the complacency of certain European states, to the detriment of the public finances of other states such as France (estimated shortfall 15 billion euros per year).   The SPECIAL committee TAXE has had to deal with the ill will of the European Commission, of which President Juncker is the main culprit in the LuxLeaks scandal, of some states as well as multinationals that have often evaded questions and requests for documents.  European countries need to move towards more collaboration. The implementation of OECD measures against BEPS (Accis, transfer pricing controls, etc.) must thereby be welcomed in order to relocate the tax where the profits are generated. However, the legitimate fight against aggressive optimization cannot be the means of imposing a fiscal union, which would put an end to the principle of unanimity in this matter and remove part of the sovereignty of States.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Globalisation and the digitisation of the economy have radically changed the global value chain and the way markets work, with most large companies currently having a transnational structure that needs to go beyond national tax rules. I vote in favour of this report, which advocates new financial rules for transnational trade, greater control of national tax systems and new rules to prevent certain Member States from providing lower taxation but could generate more profits. I also believe that combating aggressive tax planning by multinational companies has been a prominent place on the political agenda of Member States, the EU, the OECD and the G20, and it is essential to adopt the principled position that a company has to pay taxes where it operates and not where it has its tax headquarters, thus avoiding legal financial subterfuge , but not ethical, of companies.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report follows the establishment of the TAXE Committee on Tax Rulings and other aggressive tax optimization measures in the EU in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, which revealed the unscrupulous attitude of multinationals abusing tax optimisation through accounting schemes to avoid tax, with the complicity of the Luxembourg authorities (the first of which, the current President of the European Commission).  In total, almost 10 to 15 billion euros a year in tax revenues for France have soared.  This text recommends the adoption of transparency measures (publication of country-by-country information) and limiting the possibilities of rescripts, or the adoption of a common tax base (ACCIS) to focus tax competition on rates. It takes up the OECD's BEPS proposals as a whole.  While some recommendations are critical (consolidated common base) in that they mark a further step in the Europeanisation of tax policies (at the expense of the bilateral nature of the conventions), this report must be seen more as an awareness. In these circumstances, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, which aims to force companies to pay their fair share of taxes in the countries where they make a profit. In particular, this text recommends the establishment of a consolidated common corporate tax base at European level in order to put an end to unfair tax competition between Member States, which, in particular, allows multinationals to avoid tax. I strongly support this measure because it will help to effectively combat large-scale tax evasion, which is unbearable for taxpayers who are dealing with their own taxes with difficulty.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this report we intend to stress the need for a balanced and fair fiscal policy as an integral part of structural reforms in the Member States. Sufficient resources will have to be put in place to work effectively to prevent and identify aggressive tax planning, tax evasion and tax avoidance, as well as to combat such practices, which result in a substantial erosion of the tax base. Fiscal policy and competition policy must be seen as two sides of the same coin in the internal market. The lack of political will to achieve convergence of national fiscal policies often leads Member States to opt for a bilateral approach, while a common approach would be more effective. In the absence of a cooperative approach, unilateral measures contribute to greater complexity, giving rise to new asymmetries and, consequently, to further opportunities for tax avoidance in the internal market.  We therefore call for a coordinated approach and the promotion of greater reciprocity. We call on the Member States to respect the principle of taxation of profits in the territory in which they are generated and on the Commission to fulfil its role as guardian of the Treaties by ensuring full respect for EU law and the principle of loyal cooperation between Member States.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Special Committee on tax rulings by Member States was set up in February 2015 to shed light on all Member States’ tax rulings and examine ways to end unfair tax practices and combat tax evasion in the European Union. I have voted for this report that seeks transparency on tax rulings.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I believe that the problem of tax rulings needs to be addressed, but I regret that there have been many unfounded, irrational and dysfunctional proposals put forward by left-wing Members, which unfortunately devalue the importance of the report. Examples are proposals for the creation of new institutions, and thus new administrative burdens, in the form of a European body responsible for collecting sensitive business information and conducting investigations or a Pan-European Fund for the Protection of Whistleblowers.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The report gives an example of the LuxLeaks scandal, which drew public and media attention to issues related to corporate tax base reduction and aggressive tax planning, revealing questionable tax practices. Stresses that tax avoidance by some MNPs can lead to near-zero effective tax rates for profits. Recognises that, in the wake of the economic crisis and in the wake of the Luxleaks scandal, attempts to tackle the aggressive tax planning of MNAs occupy one of the first places in the political agenda of the Member States. The report calls on the Commission to fulfil its duty as guardian of the Treaties by ensuring that EU legislation and the principle of sincere cooperation between Member States are fully respected. It also calls for an investigation into the role of financial institutions in helping harmful tax practices. I support the resolution.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report on tax rulings and other measures of similar effect or nature calls on the Commission to reassess and strengthen the existing mechanisms and resources of competition policy. In particular, the aim is to eliminate discrepancies between tax systems. I abstained from voting on this report because, in addition to the proposals, which are very technical but very sensible, the competences of the Member States are to be greatly reduced.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Recent tax scandals have shown that corporations are ignoring tax rules and that Member States are not adequately monitoring tax liabilities. A level playing field must be ensured for all businesses in taxation.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 It should be noted that at present one of the most passionate political issues is preferential tax agreements. It should be noted that the lack of political will to ensure convergence of national fiscal policies encourages Member States to choose a bilateral approach, although the overall approach would be more effective.  In particular, it is necessary to ensure a comprehensive, transparent and effective automatic exchange of information on tax matters and to consider a proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base. Only by implementing these framework conditions will it be possible to properly curb the transfer of profits and costs and prevent scandals like LuxLeaks.  I believe that it is appropriate to move towards stronger coordination of member states' corporate tax systems. However, it is essential to ensure that the right of states to apply effective taxation is preserved. In the same way, the requirement of unanimity should be taken into account in decisions on tax matters in the Council of the European Union.  In view of the fact that access to certain documents has been restricted and other obstacles have been created, I believe that the activities of this Temporary Committee should be extended in order to examine political responsibility for these cases in more detail.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The TAX Rulings Committee in its recent conclusion, behind the well-known findings on favourable tax regimes for multinational monopolistic groups, conceals the relentless reality: that tax evasion, tax avoidance and the overall tax immunity regime legally enjoyed by monopolies are a legal consequence of the capitalist system and the nature of the EU, as a transnational union of capital.  The freedom of movement of capital is enshrined in its founding treaties as a supreme principle and forms the basis of the "legitimacy" of its tax privileges. References to the reduced taxation of large groups are a challenge, as the whole finding is in the interest of strengthening the competitiveness/profitability of enterprises.  Proposals are made for cooperation and exchange of information between tax authorities, while it is welcomed that corporate profit tax rates in the EU between 1995 and 2014 fell from 35% to 23%, and that the state revenues of the 28 Member States from corporation tax were only 2.6% of THE EU's GDP, which shows the size of labour-popular income tax evasion. That is why monopolies and their power supported by the EU and the urban states must be overthrown in order for the people to become the owner of the wealth they produce.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their excellent work and, in the hope of increasing transparency in the field of legislation and tax rules, I have decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – EUR 1 trillion a year: that is how much tax evasion and tax avoidance is costing European tax payers every year. I support the report that urges for better tax ruling measures among EU and, in particular, the special focus that is made on multinationals’ preferential tax treatment. If multinationals are treated in the same way as domestic firms, this would help entrepreneurship activities, which I am promoting and fully supporting as a MEP.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The report on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or impact contains recommendations on acceptable tax practices and calls on Member States to introduce and comply with them. While there is a developed culture of tax payments, at least in the more developed Member States of the Union, cases of tax avoidance occur using so-called 'creative accounting', leading to the problem of base erosion and profit shifting. That's something to be vigorously fought.  In Croatia for a number of years we have had problems with tax collection, which significantly affects the deficit of the national budget and this report is one of the steps in changing this situation. I join the members of the Special Committee in calling on Member States to respect the principle of corporate taxation where it is generated, as this is the only correct way. I also advocate transparency and public availability of financial statements of multinational corporations and believe in the imminent establishment of a common consolidated corporate tax base.  I also join the call on the Commission to adopt new guidelines on State aid because we in Croatia often encounter the problem of defining them and thus the (in)possibility of granting them. I consider this report to be a complete overview of the current situation and a good guideline for establishing a fairer taxation system in the EU internal market and I will therefore support it.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report follows the establishment of the TAXE Committee on Tax Rulings and other aggressive tax optimization measures in the EU in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, which revealed the unscrupulous attitude of multinationals abusing tax optimisation through accounting schemes to avoid tax, with the complicity of the Luxembourg authorities (the first of which, the current President).  In total, almost 10 to 15 billion euros a year in tax revenues for France have soared.  This text recommends the adoption of transparency measures (publication of country-by-country information) and limiting the possibilities of rescripts, or the adoption of a common tax base (ACCIS) to focus tax competition on rates. It takes up the OECD's BEPS proposals as a whole.  While some recommendations are critical (consolidated common base) in that they mark a further step in the Europeanisation of tax policies (at the expense of the bilateral nature of the conventions), this report must be seen more as an awareness. In these circumstances, I have decided to vote for this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ After ten months of investigation into tax procedures, there has been new insights that could improve tax coordination and cooperation in the EU. With its commitment to transparency, protecting citizens from harmful tax practices and more severely sanctioning those responsible for it, the S&D group has succeeded in contributing to the importance of the report. In particular, we highlighted the need to establish a common consolidated corporate tax base for the entire EU level, and to introduce a binding and automatic exchange of information between Member States on all applicable tax judgments and procedures registered in the Central Directory, which was not met with enthusiasm among individual groups in the EP. We consider that a common European list of tax ryes should be established on the basis of transparent, understandable, objectively verifiable and generally accepted indicators that citizens would also have access to. There is an increasing need to adequately protect whistleblowers and create an independent body to gather information and conduct investigations, and our proposal is to form a common European fund for whistleblowers. The EU does not have a high-quality legal framework that imposes sanctions on companies, banks and financial advisers involved in illegal tax avoidance practices or aggressive tax planning, which is inadmissible, although some EP members believe 'pillars of shame' should be avoided. But the fight against tax fraud and malfeasance should also be approached decisively and radically.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ According to EU estimates, a billion euros of potential tax revenues are lost annually due to the combined impact of tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance, and global annual losses in national budgets caused by tax avoidance are estimated at at least €50 billion.  While each country has an interest in using its national legislation in combination with a network of tax agreements to promote itself as an investment country, I agree that there is a need to establish consensus among all Member States, as aggressive tax planning, harmful tax regimes and tax fraud run into fertile ground in an intricate and uncooperative environment. In my view, the fight against tax evasion and avoidance requires greater openness of tax authorities and closer cooperation, and the willingness of Member States to provide the necessary information at the request of EU authorities is essential.  Croatia belongs to the countries that provided the requested answers on this issue, namely 7 July 2015. Given that Croatia is a developing country, the negative effects of harmful tax practices affect it more than developing countries. Therefore, developing countries, including Croatia, expect protection by the EU on this issue in order to achieve a level playing field when it comes to the collection of corporate income tax that belongs to them.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect, as I believe that tax fraud and aggressive tax planning must be put to an end. In the European Union, up to EUR 1 trillion of potential tax revenues are lost annually due to tax fraud, evasion and shadow economy activities. This situation is not acceptable and fair for both ordinary citizens and SMEs. They are forced to bear the tax burden instead of large multinational corporations, which, under current opaque systems, can circumvent regulations and avoid paying taxes. More specifically, I supported mandatory and public country-specific reporting. That is, a system that would be available to tax administrations and contain more detailed information. He voted in favour of greater coordination between the Member States to whose competence direct taxation belongs and which must establish a common framework and approach to finding solutions to more link the places where value is generated and where profits are taxed. I also called on the Commission, with my vote, to start working on the legal protection of whistleblowers, whose role was crucial in the outbreak of the Luxleaks scandal. I also supported the Commission's role in sanctioning Member States and companies in the event that harmful tax practices are perly and effectively withheld.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 After the LuxLeaks scandal, which broke on 5 November 2014, in which questionable tax practices promoted by audit firms in a given Member State were disclosed, it was possible to expose the use of secret agreements providing for complex financial structures aimed at obtaining drastic tax relief.  A balanced and fair fiscal policy must therefore be developed as an integral part of structural reforms in the Member States. It was therefore necessary to reach agreement on the obligation for multinationals to declare the profits obtained in the various States and on a common tax base. I voted in favour of this report so that transparent and law-asrespectful behaviour can prevail.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for the Ferreira/Theurer report of the SPECIAL committee TAXE, chaired by Alain Lamassoure, following his work to inform on harmful tax rulings and administrative tax practices in Europe. This special commission was launched after the LuxLeaks scandal. It was time for Europe to replace the inaction of the Member States. Concrete actions will have to follow the ambitious objectives of this parliamentary committee. The sums involved are so enormous that, when brought back into the Member States' budget, they could contribute to the stimulus policies that live up to our ambitions.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ The motion calls on the Commission to act and, in particular, to progress the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) by which the EU intends to harmonise taxes across the EU and thereby prohibit beneficial tax competition between Member States, and for this reason UKIP voted against.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. This is a report that calls for Member States and the EU institutions, which share political responsibility for the current situation, to put an end to harmful tax competition and cooperate fully in order to eliminate both disparities between tax systems and all measures that create the conditions for large-scale tax avoidance by many multinational companies. For many years, large multinationals have been able to reduce their tax contributions through advantageous negotiations with different Member States. This resulted in the tax bill supporting health services and education, for example, being borne mostly by SMEs and the average citizen, excluded from these unfair tax offers. They are not isolated cases, there is a systematic and organized practice that is at least tolerated by states. This vicious circle must be broken by strengthening transparency, control and sanctions. A year after the LuxLeaks scandal, the European Parliament is passing a report seeking to put an end to an unacceptable and unfair practice for all honest taxpayers, a relevant decision at a time when budget cuts in social services are being demanded.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The vote on the report of the Special Committee on Tax Rulings, to which I supported, was highly anticipated, as this subject has made public opinion nervous. As a reminder, the LuxLeaks scandal, which began on November 5, 2014, has made it possible to realize the extent of secret agreements for companies to obtain drastic tax cuts.  However, it is thanks to these taxes that a state can carry out an inclusive social policy, support the investments necessary for our society, enable young people to benefit from the best possible education system, etc.  It was therefore important to me at the time to set up a special committee in the European Parliament to shed light on these criticised tax practices and, above all, to propose recommendations, in particular to put an end to harmful tax competition between Member States. As such, I would like to reiterate my desire to see a proposal for a consolidated common corporate tax base quickly arrive on the benches of Parliament. This would be a first step towards more fiscal union in a Europe that suffers from its unfinished federalism.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The tax practices carried out in some Member States of the European Union are highly controversial and have raised a debate about their nature and legitimacy at European level. That is why a special temporary committee on tax rulings was set up in the European Parliament a few months ago and other measures were adopted aimed at ending unfair tax practices and combating tax evasion in Europe. Furthermore, It seems to me important to point out, among other measures mentioned in the report, that corporate profits taxes are now calculated using common methods, so as not to repeat past situations and avoid new controversial cases. Because I consider the measures in the report to be positive overall, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report, which was adopted by the TAXE Committee, a special commission that was set up last February in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal.  After nine months of work, this report makes several tax recommendations in order to respond in particular to the over-bidding of certain states regarding the tax advantages offered to multinationals. Tax competition must no longer take place in opacity or injustice. The report thereby recommends the introduction as soon as possible of a consolidated common corporate tax base (ACCIS) at European level, enabling an end to preferential regimes.  It also calls on Member States to systematically share their tax and other tax information which affects other Member States.  Finally, it should also be noted that the report calls on the Commission to make a legislative proposal on the protection of whistleblowers.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on tax rulings and other similar measures by nature or effect, as I believe it is necessary to combat crimes of tax evasion and avoidance in the European Union.  The main objective of the report is above all to increase transparency and tax fairness so as not to put European companies at a competitive disadvantage. Parliament supports the introduction of the CCCTB (common consolidated corporate tax base) and country-by-country reporting for multinational companies of a great deal of information such as profits, taxes paid and tax arrangements.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I welcome the most important part of this report, which contains useful proposals for greater fiscal justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on fiscal justice. However, I abstained in this vote for the following reasons: responsibility for the collapse of tax systems in Europe has not been fully attributed, and the report does not call for the necessary extension of the current mandate; access to documents remains unsatisfactory on the part of the Council, the Commission and the Member States. Multinational corporations have only responded after multiple invitations to the commission, no legal basis has been established for sanctions and have not been thoroughly questioned; Moreover, the contradictions in Jean-Claude Juncker's speech have not been clarified.  In substance, the report does not go beyond the Commission's own proposals. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws should be adjusted. I welcome the idea of a consolidation of the tax base. However, I miss a clear commitment to broaden the fiscal base and criticize the transition period before consolidation.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The work of the TAXE Commission has served to demonstrate that tax agreements were in breach of competition rules, as well as evidence of the complicity of Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem in this scandal. The report, however, only partially reflects our demands. On the one hand, tax avoidance practices are denounced and the Commission is asked for ambition in its proposals for transparency and fiscal harmonisation. But many of these requests do not go beyond good intentions and the ties between multinationals guilty of tax avoidance, the Member States and the Commission are not adequately investigated for lack of documents and political will. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for more tax harmonisation across the EU, which I am against. Nation states should manage their own affairs in relation to taxes.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report from the TAXE Committee. Aggressive tax avoidance and evasion is a problem across the EU, as the committee has shown. Billions of pounds every year are not being applied where they should; the individuals who are involved in this activity are taking all the advantages of being a part of a society and not contributing their fair share. This is billions which could be invested in schools, hospitals and public services, and for too long, governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax, which makes ordinary people who do pay their taxes the losers at the expense of the super-rich. It is now time for the governments of the EU – especially the Tory government of the UK – to listen to the will of the people and actually do something to end this completely unreasonable practice.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 Multinationals now often abuse existing tax policy legislation to adjust their taxable profits and reduce the overall tax burden. It is important to combat these practices. At the same time, however, this situation must not be used to enforce the EU's common tax policy, which is the exclusive competence of the Member States. For this reason, I had to vote against this proposal when I resolution on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent LuxLeaks scandal has directed public view of the ways in which large multinationals aggressively tax planning. The revelations that corporations use tax operations that allow them to pay almost no taxes is not new, but after this scandal it was possible to point out specific companies and specific practices. For this reason, the European Parliament has set up a special committee of inquiry, which has now come up with its report, which contains all the most important measures to prevent such dubious tax operations. I believe that the existing corporate taxation models, which were created in the first half of the 20th century, are not suitable for today's globalised and digitised economy, because most large companies now have a supranational structure. I therefore support the proposals which, according to the results of the investigation, should lead to a reduction in corporate tax cuts. First of all, the Commission should conclude the legislative form of a common consolidated tax base for corporations at Pan-European level. It is also necessary to establish a central register for the exchange of information on national tax rulings and a European list of tax havens. Last but not least, European legislation should better protect whistleblowers, because it is only thanks to them that such cases can be detected. I trust that the committee's work will continue, because tax avoidance is a problem that we will encounter regularly in a globalised world.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
