text: Writing. The Committee's report on tax rulings is a response to a number of examples of questionable tax practices by some Member States that have been disclosed in the past year. These tax practices have undoubtedly had a negative impact on other countries, including those which have to implement austerity measures. I am surprised that, in practice, the Member States have not honoured the old commitment to inform each other of tax practices that could affect another country. More importantly, in some cases, it is precisely through the exploitation of grey areas of tax systems that they have contributed to distortions of competition in the European internal market. Promoting an attractive business environment and attracting investment is certainly very important these days. However, the manipulation of tax systems for this purpose is an intolerable measure. The report requires, inter alia, that multinationals make public all their tax rulings, including information on their business, and propose a European Common Consolidated Tax Base in order to avoid exploiting differences between member states' tax systems, which is why I voted to support it.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax rulings, i.e. the tax practices put in place by large multinational companies to keep the contributions paid to the tax authorities artificially low. The eight months of work of the TAXE Committee have made it possible to analyse the aggressive tax planning practices, which are considered to distort competition, implemented by multinationals in some Member States. It was therefore necessary to propose a legal framework aimed at re-establishing tax justice, ensuring that multinationals provide unbundled 'country by country' data on profits made, taxes paid and subsidies received from states, and comply with tax burdens in the places where they make the profits. For the S&D Group, the fight against unfair tax practices is a political priority: multinationals that have benefited for years from favourable agreements negotiated in various Member States must participate, like other taxpayers, in public spending on services and infrastructure. Among our proposals included in the report, I would mention in particular the relaunch of the draft common corporate tax base, the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings and support for the oecd working group's plan of recommendations on taxation.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The European Parliament responded to the Luxleaks revelations by setting up a special committee on the role and impact of tax rulings. ALFA is committed to ensuring that all companies and all citizens are taxed according to their capacity and actually pay these taxes. We need a functioning European regulatory framework in tax law. The coordinated report calls for measures such as a common corporate tax base and the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings. Tax competition between Member States has so far been maintained. It is, in my view, a central liberal element. Tax competition helps tame government actors in their spending habits, ties them to taxpayers' wishes, and encourages them to innovate. Although tax competition has so far been maintained through tax rates, I fear that the Commission could abuse this first step towards tax harmonisation in the future. If it were to harmonise tax rates later on in accordance with the tax base, tax competition would be abolished. I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 We must do everything we can to make the fight against tax evasion and fraud as effective as possible, but at the same time we must also strongly reject any attempt to limit the tax sovereignty of the Member States. The entire European economy would suffer from this.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this report because it is important to keep companies in Europe and attract new ones, but this should not take the form of potentially harmful tax mechanisms. It is therefore important to focus primarily on boosting investment and creating additional economic activity due to reactions to similar measures launched in neighbouring countries or the correction of what are considered existing inequalities between Member States.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TAXE report because the work of the TAXE Committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem across Europe. It costs billions every year: billions that should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services.  For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which citizens are the losers.  This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these dreadful practices once and for all. Now it is time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK government – to listen to the will of the people and do something to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒In the LuxLeaks scandal, confidential documents on more than 500 private tax deals between the Luxembourg tax administration and more than 300 multinational corporations were released between 2002 and 2010, and revealed how widespread secret deals on complex financial structures were with the aim of drastic tax cuts. LuxLeaks did not prove to be the only example of problems of its kind, so the Commission adopted a tax transparency package on automatic information sharing between Member States in relation to their tax rulings of March 2015, and an action plan for a fair and effective corporate tax system in the EU in June 2015. The Commission underlines that these texts can only be considered as first steps in the right direction and that a coherent framework of legislation and administrative coordination for the benefit of SMEs, as well as those of multinational corporations helping to generate genuine economic growth, is urgently needed.   Since this proposal advocates equal rights towards all those who pay their share of tax fairly, I fully give it my support.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the steps that facilitate or even directly lead to tax harmonisation in the European Union. Real competition between tax systems is essential for the European Union's competitiveness.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or with similar effect. We all want a more effective, fair and transparent tax policy. We must put an end to the practices of unfair tax competition. I welcome the fact that the report stresses the need to establish a balanced and fair tax policy as an integral part of structural reforms in the Member States. We need better cooperation between Member States in terms of better coordination of measures and exchange of information.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although the report contains many positive elements in terms of ensuring a fair tax system, in fact, there are points and proposals for guidelines aimed at large companies continuing to avoid tax and to subject more tax burdens to small and medium-sized enterprises that are not networked like multinationals. The multinationals ignored invitations to submit data requested by the TDSA and it was not possible to establish a legal basis for sanctions. For all the above reasons, but also because the introduction of common taxation throughout the Union would be an unacceptable assignment of National Sovereignty, we are voting against the report as a whole. The solution is the abolition of the Single Market and the introduction of the obligation for Companies to set up subsidiaries in the countries they want to operate, which will be taxed on the spot.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The need for fiscal adjustments and fair burden-bearing as a result of the crisis appears to increase the readiness of EU Member States, which have traditionally been reluctant in tax matters, to step up and coordinate action against tax fraud and avoidance. In various international for a, such as the OECD and the G20, decisive action must also be taken to ensure that others follow Europe's example and that no one can slip away from their efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion at global level.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax rulings, which is an important milestone in our fight against corporate tax fraud. The report provides detailed and clear guidance to Member States and the Commission on how to reduce tax avoidance by multinationals. The country-by-country report, the sharing of information on national tax determinations, the blacklist of tax havens, the common consolidated tax base and the definition of uniform tax definitions are all proposals that contribute to the creation of a transparent tax system and ensure that smEs and citizens are no longer almost exclusively subject to the tax burden. I was pleased that the report clearly states that taxes must be paid in the Member State where profits are made, thereby avoiding unfair competition. There is a need to establish a comprehensive legislative framework for corporate taxation in Europe, with this principle at the heart of it. There is serious work behind this thorough report in detail. If European governments commit themselves and take over our recommendations in an appropriate manner, we can put an end to the practice of tax instruments in Europe for good.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the final vote on the report presented by the Special Committee set up by the European Parliament, which wanted to deepen the issue of taxation and tax arrangements secretly granted between 2002 and 2010 by the Luxembourg Government to multinational companies (Luxleaks scandal).  We have been calling for a long time for clarity for those responsible for and beneficiaries of these agreements and for the banks involved to clarify the reasons given for avoiding or circumventing millions of euros in taxes. The situation in Europe is paradoxical: we have millions of citizens who are suffocated by taxes as a result of austerity policies, and on the other hand tax havens (facilitated by the absence of customs) which create situations of unfair competition between Member States. The current President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, has been the cornerstone of the entire Luxembourg system. Although the report voted on has positive and acceptable features, unfortunately 1) it makes no reference to the political responsibilities of Juncker (former Prime Minister of Luxembourg and his Finance Minister for almost 20 years) and 2) the special committee has been too soft on the issue of transparency; For us, all tax arrangements should also be public and verifiable by European citizens.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 European integration is a complex process in full swing. An essential component of it, in addition to the political and monetary component, is the fiscal dimension. Member States' tax systems are still far too different to have a coherent system at Union level. This leads to development gaps and living standards between Member States. For these reasons, there is a need for greater harmonisation of fiscal policies at European level. This process is not possible without monitoring in the case of each Member State by independent and impartial actors whose activity must not be affected by the interests of the State actors concerned. Following monitoring, recommendations will be issued to establish a minimum level and a maximum level of taxation at EU level. At the same time, a comprehensive database of 'tax havens' will be developed and the fight against intra-Community tax evasion will be more effectively regulated. States or commercial actors that do not comply with these regulations will have to bear the consequences and pay the penalties set by the European institutions. This will generate new Union revenues, which can be used for the development of the Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I want to shed some light on the LuxLeaks case. The LuxLeaks scandal, which erupted on 5 November 2014 with the publication, by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, nearly 28,000 pages of confidential documents establishing more than 500 private tax arrangements between the Luxembourg tax administration and more than 300 multinational companies between 2002 and 2010, revealed the extent of the use of secret agreements using complex financial structures to obtain drastic tax cuts. In many cases, Luxembourg subsidiaries, with a turnover of several hundred million euros, maintain only a small presence and have only a reduced economic activity in Luxembourg.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that answers some of the questions that emerged in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal. Breaking out in November 2014, it revealed private tax arrangements between the Luxembourg tax administration and more than 300 multinational corporations, which allowed them to achieve major tax reductions. The report makes several recommendations, based on the investigation by the European Commission and by Parliament’s Special Committee. Following a critical overview of corporate tax practices in the Member States, it calls on them to adopt concrete measures to prevent tax fraud. Among them is simplification of tax systems, respect of the principle of profits taxation in the place they are generated, creation of an EU legislative framework for tax competition in the EU, coordination on advance tax rulings, increasing transparency by extensive country-by-country reporting system available to tax authorities.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The LuxLeaks scandal, which erupted almost a year ago, demonstrates that multinationals enjoy tax advantages that hinder the financing of public authorities and break the tax tie. The European Parliament has mobilised. We advocate the creation of a country-by-country accounting reporting obligation for multinationals. We also propose the creation of a 'consolidated common base' so that the tax criteria are harmonised at European level. We call for full transparency in the tax rulings, i.e. the gifts and rebates granted by Member States to companies, and we demand greater protection for whistleblowers, who have notably made public the scandal of Luxembourg's practices. I strongly support this report, as it allows for concrete progress in ending tax evasion and evasion. This is a great step forward, but we must continue towards a European tax on multinationals, the only instrument capable of definitively ending tax dumping in Europe. At a time when the European budget is in crisis and reaches the limits of the multi-year financial framework, these additional resources are essential for us to face the challenges we face.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. The report of the Deputies of Mr Ferreira and Mr Theurer deserves support for several reasons. Issues related to the irregularity of the so-called tax base of legal entities and the practice of aggressive tax planning have been known and analysed at international level for at least a few decades. LuxLeaks' scam drew public and media attention to these issues by revealing the discreet tax practices advocated by audit firms in a given Member State. The Commission's investigation and the work carried out by a special parliamentary committee have shown that this is not an isolated incident, the use of tax measures to reduce some of the general tax obligations of large companies in order to artificially increase the national tax base to the detriment of other countries, including states pursuing austerity policies. It is a reprehensible practice that is widespread in Europe and beyond. This requires a strong reaction from the European Parliament, as the introduction of this practice into public scrutiny should be an element of democratic control.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The TAXE Committee was established with the aim of examining application practices for Union State aid and tax laws related to tax rulings and other similar measures. In particular, the Committee is the European Parliament's response to the LuxLeaks affair, in which it was revealed that many multinationals were given unfairly favourable tax arrangements by the state of Luxembourg. I fully agree with the proposal that all Member States should combat the widespread problems of tax evasion and tax avoidance, however, unlike the rapporteur, I do not agree that this should be implemented at Union level, but I strongly advocate maintaining national sovereignty in the tax policy segment in the hands of individual Member States of the Union, as defined in the basic Treaty through the unanimous decision rule in the Council.  The compromise reached in the Committee is not balanced and encroaches on the principle of subsidiarity because it advocates the harmonisation of taxes and some other proposals that cannot possibly get my support, such as mandatory common consolidated tax for multinational corporations, definition of the minimum tax rate, strong criticism of unanimous decision-making in the Council on tax matters, etc. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or with similar effect, as it is essential to shape Europe's fiscal future and to change the tax system so that taxes are paid where added value and profits are actually generated, and harmonisation of tax bases is also necessary. This resolution is an important step forward in the fight against tax evasion and offers transparency of transactions, as automatic exchange of information becomes mandatory.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I welcome the most important part of this report, which contains useful proposals for greater fiscal justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on fiscal justice. However, I abstained in this vote for the following reasons: responsibility for the collapse of tax systems in Europe has not been fully attributed, and the report does not call for the necessary extension of the current mandate; access to documents remains unsatisfactory on the part of the Council, the Commission and the Member States. Multinational corporations have only responded after multiple invitations to the commission, no legal basis has been established for sanctions and have not been thoroughly questioned; Moreover, the contradictions in Jean-Claude Juncker's speech have not been clarified.  In substance, the report does not go beyond the Commission's own proposals. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws should be adjusted. I welcome the idea of a consolidation of the tax base. However, I miss a clear commitment to broaden the fiscal base and criticize the transition period before consolidation.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The European Parliament responded to the Luxleaks revelations by setting up a special committee on the role and impact of tax rulings. I supported the creation of this special committee and voted in favour of the report. ALFA is committed to ensuring that all companies and all citizens are taxed according to their capacity and actually pay these taxes. We need a functioning European regulatory framework in tax law. The coordinated report calls for measures such as a common corporate tax base and the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings. These measures are likely to make competition between Member States more transparent and the rules of the game clearer. The measures will help to make discrimination in and through international taxation more difficult. They restore a level playing field, both between Member States and between companies. Tax competition between Member States will be maintained. It helps to tame state actors in their spending behaviour, ties them to the wishes of taxpayers and encourages them to innovate. The right of states to decide fully autonomously on the level of tax rates is not restricted. But tax justice would be greatly improved by the measures – for the benefit of citizens and the middle class.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Last year we discovered that about 340 multinationals had secured privileged deals with Luxemburg in order to avoid paying taxes on their activities all over Europe. Other Member States have done similar deals. Our committee has made several proposals to fight this situation, taking into account the weak state of our finances. Dear colleagues, what multinationals do not pay, SMEs should not compensate with a higher tax burden. Simplification of our tax systems, a Common Corporate Tax Base to ensure fair competition and much higher transparency criteria in corporate financial statements – these are all fundamental reforms we need. It is disappointing that some Member States like Spain have been so reluctant to make public tax ruling and multinationals privileges. We Catalans also want a new state to lead in this fight for a more fair and reformed tax system that does not give privileges to multinationals against SMEs and citizens, putting at risk our welfare state.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. On the proposals of the TAXE Committee, I support the harmonisation of the corporate tax bases, in order to concentrate competition on rates. I also support the requirement to publish information by country and the principle of non-double taxation such as minimum taxation. I support the sanctions against the multinationals that defrauded, as well as the revision of the Code of Conduct on Taxation, which was supposed to identify and eliminate unfair tax practices as early as 1998 and which was a complete failure. I am also in favour of enhanced protection for whistleblowers. On the other hand, I remain strongly opposed to harmonizing rates for direct taxes. I remain committed to the principle of unanimity in tax matters, guarantor of the sovereignty of states. In the end, the report shows an awareness but does not prejudge the measures that will be taken. I therefore choose to vote for this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Aggressive tax planning practices and erosion of the corporate tax base have been known and analyzed internationally for several decades. But the LuxLeaks scandal, which erupted in November 2014, brought these issues to the attention of the public and the media, revealing questionable tax practices promoted by consulting firms in a particular Member State. These fiscal behaviours separate the place where the value is created and the place where the profit is taxed. Moreover, it is not limited to tax rulings, but includes a wide range of bad tax practices, applied by national tax administrations of the European Union, but also from outside it. I voted in favour of this resolution because public monitoring is a practice that is part of the exercise of democratic control, and these practices can persist as long as they remain undisclosed.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 on November 5, 2014, the Luxleaks scandal, which erupted thanks to the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, uncovered some 28 000 pages of confidential documents between the Luxembourg tax administration and more than 300 multinational companies recording more than 500 private tax agreements between 2002 and 2010, shed light on the prevalence of secret arrangements with complex financial structures designed to obtain drastic tax breaks.  Since there is a need to take meaningful action against tax evasion and fraud, I therefore supported the report, as well as the continuation of the work of the TAXE Committee.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I welcome the most important part of this report, which contains useful proposals for greater fiscal justice and reflects the negative impact of austerity on fiscal justice. However, I abstained in this vote for the following reasons: responsibility for the collapse of tax systems in Europe has not been fully attributed, and the report does not call for the necessary extension of the current mandate; access to documents remains unsatisfactory on the part of the Council, the Commission and the Member States. Multinational corporations have only responded after multiple invitations to the commission, no legal basis has been established for sanctions and have not been thoroughly questioned; Moreover, the contradictions in Jean-Claude Juncker's speech have not been clarified.  In substance, the report does not go beyond the Commission's own proposals. Tax rulings should be made public and tax secrecy laws should be adjusted. I welcome the idea of a consolidation of the tax base. However, I miss a clear commitment to broaden the fiscal base and criticize the transition period before consolidation.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on tax rulings and other measures similar in nature or effect. The resolution calls on Member States and EU institutions, which share the political responsibility for the current situation, to put an end to harmful tax competition and fully cooperate in order to eliminate mismatches – and refrain from creating further mismatches – between tax systems and harmful tax measures which create the conditions for massive tax avoidance by MNCs and tax base erosion within the internal market. I also agree with the call on Member States to notify the Commission and other Member States about any relevant changes to their corporate taxation law that could have an impact on their effective tax rates or on any other Member State’s tax revenue. I think it is necessary to stress that the Member States that play a pivotal role in facilitating tax avoidance should take responsibility and lead the efforts to improve tax cooperation within the EU, therefore I supported the resolution.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a report that deals with a very important issue today in Europe such as tax evasion or the need to reduce the so-called fiscal gap between countries. It is important to make further progress in transparency and in the exchange of information on tax rulings, which this report deals with successfully. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the taxE Commission's final report, which originated in the wake of the scandal known as 'LuxLeaks', because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, provided that the Council follows the recommendations of the approved document, and which contains the following main elements: (a) not limiting the automatic exchange of information to tax rulings considered 'cross-border';  (b) mandatory country-by-country reporting by multinationals; (c) the possibility of sanctioning States and undertakings involved in pernicious tax practices; (d) a complaint to the Commission to take the necessary legislative measures to introduce the Common Corporate Tax Base, including the consolidation element; (e) protection of whistleblowers from business irregularities; (f) European list of tax havens; (g) reform of the Code of Conduct Group. The report also criticises the Council's exclusion of the Commission from the automatic exchange of information system in the context of the revision of the 2011 Directive.  As a socialist, this matter is an absolute priority.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 If this is the result of 8 months of investigations aimed at shedding light on the Luxleaks scandal and identifying incisive actions to counter the unacceptable phenomenon of tax avoidance and abuse by large multinational companies and unfair competition practices between states, I am convinced that the expectations and questions of European citizens have largely remained unanswered. Although the recommendations of the TAXE report contain important countermeasures to combat circumvention, such as public country-by-country reporting extended to all multinationals, the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base and essential protection measures for whistelblowers, we are still a long way from achieving full transparency, which is the first step towards putting an end to this problem.  In fact, the report not only renounces to denounce the undeniable political responsibilities of those who have endorsed and encouraged these practices also thanks to a regime of total secrecy, but continues to keep citizens, investigative journalists and civil society totally unaware of the privileged treatment reserved for multinational groups through tax rulings concluded with governments, which will remain accessible only to tax authorities.  For these reasons, while acknowledging that some important progress has been made, I was unable to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The work of the TAXE Commission has served to demonstrate that tax agreements were in breach of competition rules, as well as evidence of the complicity of Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem in this scandal. The report, however, only partially reflects our demands. On the one hand, tax avoidance practices are denounced and the Commission is asked for ambition in its proposals for transparency and fiscal harmonisation. But many of these requests do not go beyond good intentions and the ties between multinationals guilty of tax avoidance, the Member States and the Commission are not adequately investigated for lack of documents and political will. That's why I've decided to abstain.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ This is a report that I very strongly supported, because the work of the TAXE committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem right across Europe and can therefore only be properly met with a pan-European response. It costs the nations of Europe billions every year: billions that could and should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services. For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which ordinary people and the services we all use are the losers. This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these dreadful practices once and for all. It is not enough to simply talk a good game about clamping down on loopholes and ending morally-dubious tax practices, it is now time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK Government – to listen to the will of the people and do something to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report which contains some of the recommendations made by the Commission and the European Parliament's Special Commission in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal. The report calls for a balanced, fair and transparent fiscal policy.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. After the revelations of the LuxLeaks case, the European Parliament set up a special commission to investigate the tax evasion practices of multinationals.  While I can only welcome the fact that these practices are finally being investigated, the conclusions are not really up to the challenge, despite a number of positive elements: recognition of the responsibility of several countries in setting up aggressive tax regimes to promote these practices, recognition of the need to make multinationals pay their taxes where they make their profits and to do so, publication of corporate tax data. Unsurprisingly, this survey was met with resistance from key players. The specific responsibilities of certain politicians, such as Mr Juncker and Mr Dijsselbloem, are obviously hidden. Nor has it on the fact that several Member States and multinationals have refused to comply with the Commission's requests.  Worse still, the EPP and the S-D have done everything possible to put an end to the special commission. An agreement was finally reached, thanks to the mobilization of the Green and GUE/NGL groups, for the establishment of a new commission of inquiry but whose powers will be reduced. So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. These practices designed to circumvent national tax authorities in order to drain profits into territories where they are not taxed, such as tax havens, are deeply linked to the current process of European integration which has in the free movement of capital one of its main advantages and in globalisation its main consequence. Were it not for the disclosure of successive tax scandals at a time when the European peoples are suffering the effects of austerity policies, we would probably still be living with these crimes in total impunity. It was, therefore, the indignation of public opinion, the real engine that propelled this whole plan of good intentions. The report under discussion today is still incomplete. We have fought against various obstacles in these months. We still have no access to documents of great importance for a correct assessment and clearance of facts. Every day new elements emerge involving senior European officials and which have forced an extension of the mandate of the TAXE Commission. As an incomplete report, we abstain, in the conviction that work will continue, confronting the European institutions with their responsibilities, but also with their action plan announced last June, which has made little or nothing progress.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report contains some sensible proposals, but it ultimately aims at further centralisation of the EU. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of a report that clearly defines the instruments to be put in place to make tax justice more efficient.  Measures are envisaged that will improve fiscal coordination and cooperation in Europe in order to combat aggressive tax planning through transparency and a code of conduct on taxation.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. The fight against tax evasion by multinational companies can only be done through Europe-wide cooperation in order to effectively dry up tax havens.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect. The EU has no competence in the field of tax law. And that's a good thing. As usual, the institutions are collectively trying to use a scandal at Member State level (Luxleaks) to unduly expand their powers. The Commission is therefore putting forward a proposal for EU-wide corporate tax legislation, and Parliament is discussing issues that do not concern it. All this under a President Juncker, who was responsible for the scandal in his old role, but who does not want to know about it in his new one. I can say with a clear conscience that the most stable barrier to maintaining an EU that is at least rudimentarily competitive is tax competition between Member States. It preserves the diversity of Europe and allows the high-tax continent to be internationally competitive for tax purposes. Let us hope that at least the Council refuses to shift its tax powers to the EU.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TAXE report, because the work of the TAXE Committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem right across Europe. It costs billions every year in lost revenue: public money that should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services. For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which ordinary people are the losers. This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these cynical practices once and for all. Now it is time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK government – to listen to the will of the people and do something to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the TAXE report, because the work of the TAXE Committee has shown that tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance is a problem right across Europe. It costs billions every year: billions that should be invested in schools, hospitals and public services. For too long, both governments and multinational corporations have been involved in a race to the bottom on tax – a race in which ordinary people are the losers. This report sets out a number of bold recommendations to stop these dreadful practices once and for all. Now it is time for EU governments – and especially the Tory UK government – to listen to the will of the people and do something to end tax fiddling for good.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Slovakia is a country that, on the one hand, suffers from tax evasion by large companies, but on the other it has weak infrastructure, so it has to offer investors tax advantages in order to create jobs here. Our interest is therefore in the intersection between eliminating tax evasion and fraud and preserving the tax sovereignty of the Member States. I therefore support the unification of tax terminology in the EU, as well as the introduction of an obligation for multinationals to provide profit and tax data for each country in which they operate. Decisions on their taxation in individual states must not be covered by confidentiality. However, I have doubts about the need to introduce a common consolidated corporate tax base – I believe that such a move should be preceded by a technical debate on its implications for less developed Member States.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on tax rulings, as tax competition favouring multinational companies should be put to an end.  The revenue losses for many states are really huge and there should be initiatives at European level immediately. At a time when millions of ordinary citizens, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises, are being asked to pay unaffordable taxes, it is unacceptable that large companies end up paying almost no taxes.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the fight against tax evasion and am aware of the need to detect unfair corporate tax practices and to take the necessary measures. Indeed, we have a year since the LuxLeaks affair broke out, which exposed Luxembourg's unfair tax transfer practices, at a time when Jean-Claude Juncker, the current President of the European Commission, was Finance Minister and Prime Minister of Luxembourg. Thanks to him, companies avoided paying billions of euros in taxes, and he robbed us, the Member States and EU citizens, of substantial sums in the form of income tax payments. However, the fight against tax evasion must not be used for further deeper INTEGRATION of the EU, for example by introducing a common consolidated corporate tax base, which is a risky step towards a single EU tax policy. Member States must determine their own tax policy.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as I believe that multinational companies should pay the taxes where they generate the profit. Current tax competition leads to aggressive tax planning and evasion practices. Not having a regulatory framework at Community level is detrimental to European citizens. It is not fair that large companies sometimes pay reduced taxes on their profits, while citizens and SMEs do pay their share. Transparency is essential to ensure that everyone follows the same rules of the game.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Following luxleaks' revelations last year, Parliament decided to set up a special committee to investigate the issue of taxation and tax arrangements.  The outcome of the work is summarised in this report, which analyses the current situation and outlines recommendations for the future. The final text is rather satisfactory, as many of the points listed as necessary are the same as those I have been advocating for a long time: public and comprehensible country-by-country reporting, a full CCCTB to be carried out in the immediate future, an automatic and comprehensive exchange between Member States on tax arrangements.  There is also a strong criticism in the text of the actions of certain countries which have never been cooperative, as is the Commission itself, which has flattened out the Council's positions; the multinationals, which are the main culprits and beneficiaries of these agreements, are also under attack for their behaviour. The approved text is therefore good, including adequate protections for whistleblowers and underlining the negative role of consulting firms and banks. What is lacking, however, is a clear reference to political responsibilities; Moreover, it is too soft on the issue of transparency, because, in my opinion, all tax arrangements should be public and verifiable by citizens.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the final report prepared by the European Parliament's Special Committee on Tax Rulings on a fairer application of corporate tax in the Member States of the European Union. In view of the national tax policy pursued by Luxembourg's then Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker, which was veily shaped as a paradise for large companies, the President of the European Commission now has the opportunity to show his neutrality towards his country as well. The mandatory requirement for large companies to report profits and taxes paid in each Member State will limit the distortion of competition incompatible with the European single market mechanism. Unfortunately, sometimes such tax policy-distorting initiatives have also come from Latvian non-governmental organisations. At the same time, I would like to stress that this report does not legitimise efforts to create a common EU tax system as a general common eu tax system, because prosperity and accumulated capital, from which tax policy guidelines are also followed, are very different among Member States because of objective circumstances. Moreover, it is unacceptable that, in the context of taxation, small and medium-sized enterprises at European level have so far been placed in a worse position than large ones.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report dealing with cases of favourable tax agreements that have occurred between Luxembourg and large multinationals. Although I deplore practices where states conclude agreements with large companies in order to increase their own attractiveness to multinationals and thus increase their own competitive advantage in tax competition, I refuse to support the idea that tax harmonisation at European level, including compulsory consolidated corporate tax or a common definition of a minimum tax rate, is necessary to prevent such practices.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on advance tax rulings and other measures of a similar nature or effect (2015/20667INI), because it includes very significant advances in the crucial fight against aggressive taxation, which calls into question the single market, competitive transparency and the financing of the European social model. The report highlights the excellent work of the Special Committee on tax agreements and other measures of a similar nature or effect, and in particular by its co-rapporteurs, Elisa Ferreira and Michael Theurer. It also identifies that, more than non-harmonisation of fees, it is the non-harmonisation of criteria for the calculation of tax able and the absence of the exchange of information between Member States on these matters which create the conditions for intolerable tax avoidance and aggressive competitiveness between Member States, resulting in a game of negative sum for the union's interest.  I also believe that the work of this committee should be continued, taking into account, in particular, the information which was not possible to access during its term.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Fraud and tax evasion, aimed at circumventing national tax authorities in order to drain profits to territories where they are not taxed, such as tax havens, are deeply linked to the Process of European Integration, which has in the free movement of capital one of its mislocks and in globalisation its main consequence. Were it not for the disclosure of successive tax scandals at a time when the European peoples are suffering the effects of austerity policies, we would probably still be living with these crimes in total impunity. Because this is an incomplete report, we abstained.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on tax decisions and other measures of a similar nature or with similar effect because I believe it is necessary to introduce additional measures to combat tax avoidance at national level within the EU and the OECD, as uncoordinated responses can lead to additional inconsistencies and opportunities for tax avoidance. The resolution's recommendations are in line with the principle of sincere cooperation between Member States as defined in the Treaty on European Union, as coordinated cooperation between Member States is necessary to prevent base erosion, not unilateral introduction of preferential arrangements in order to attract investment.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report because it focuses on the symptoms and not on the problems that give rise to them. The full weight of the report rests on coercive and social control measures, which add to the problem of extremism the deterioration of our freedoms. We cannot combat the problem with more fear, generating more fear. As we indicated among the seven urgent measures to combat terrorism that my delegation sent to the members of this House, Martin Schulz and Federica Mogherini too, legal or police measures alone are not sufficient. We understand that to avoid radicalization it is essential to strengthen cohesion and social inclusion strategies; and, in particular, education, as the path that can offer future alternatives for a cohesive and supportive society.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I strongly believe radicalisation is one of the major challenges we are facing. Over 5 000 EU citizens have left to fight for terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria. We cannot continue to run behind the facts, whether it is radicalisation in the UK, in Belgium or in France or the rest of the EU. We have to look at prevention, and it is clear that EU action has important added value when it comes to curbing radicalisation, and given that this is an issue that does not stop at national borders – think about social media giving a platform to those manipulating individuals in such a way that they radicalise in total isolation from the rest of the society. It is an issue that Member States are not able to address effectively by themselves, but where the EU can. It is key that we work together to find real solutions without compromising our civil liberties and cracking down on fundamental rights.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Terrorist Attacks in Paris are the sad climax of Islamist terror to date, and one did not have to be an intelligence expert to be able to predict them. Now, therefore, it is necessary to be determined and also honest. However, there is no sign of this in this report – neither of determination nor of honesty. They have been reluctant to call things by their names, namely Islamism. In Europe, human lives are not threatened by fundamentalist Christians or Jews, but by extremist Muslims. And to say this openly is contrary to political correctness. The rapporteur did not seem to have dared to fight against them either. If the Union's political leadership does not show determination in defining the opponent, but only speaks completely naively about better reintegration of returnees, then unfortunately we have already capitulated to God.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I was also happy to support this report, because I consider the problem of radicalised citizens to be extremely dangerous. Individual countries of the European Union cannot solve this problem on their own. If today there are around 5,000 Europeans in the Middle East who are jihadists and want to return to the European Union one day, that is an extraordinary danger and a potential source of terrorism. So I am very happy that there are a number of specific things in this report, such as the commitment to adopt or complete work on the PNR directive by the end of this year. This is a thing that has been lying here for a long time and needs to be completed. I am glad that there is a consensus that it will only be a criminal offence for European citizens to be trained with terrorist organisations, and I am very glad that we will finally be able to keep a close eye on the external borders. These are specific things that I welcome, which is why I supported the report.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the first and most obvious reaction to the deadly attacks in Paris was again to point to the glaring holes in our security systems. Indeed we do need stronger borders, better information systems, more controlled access to the terrorist data and more efficient information exchange in order to protect civilian lives. Just as important, however, is for us to come to terms with the fact that these killings were perpetrated by European citizens. If we want to make the world a safer place, we must start by understanding what drives thousands of European citizens to embrace violent extremism and indiscriminately take lives at home and abroad. Although necessary, repressive measures are not sufficient to tackle extremism. As has been pointed out by the head of one of the more successful anti-radicalisation initiatives in Vilvoorde in Belgium, if we want to prevent more people from falling into the hands of terrorist organisations, we must attempt to strengthen those bonds with family and the wider community that the recruiters have tried to break.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The figures are already appalling: 5 000 Europeans are fighting against our own values in Iraq and Syria. Growing up in the European Union, they usually have every opportunity to democratically change things they do not like, but they choose the terrorist route here. That is why it is important to look at the situation. The report is balanced for me. Of course, we need to improve social conditions – that is right. On the other hand, however, we also know that it is possible to say that the environment shapes human beings, but even if all social matters have been clarified, evil is probably part of our human existence, and we must of course also combat and pursue this with legal means. This requires a European response, and European solutions are needed. Finally, I would like to say that we have now written enough reports. I would also ask for implementation. I would also ask the Member States to make the necessary financial resources available.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá mé ar ais sa groove mar vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir anseo agus dar ndóigh i bhfabhar na tuarascála féin.  Rud amháin gan dabht ar bith a thaispeáin na hionsaithe sceimhlitheoireachta i bPáras ná go bhfuilimid go léir i mbaol, gach duine i ndomhan an iarthair is naimhde iad do ISIS. Agus tá sé sin feicthe i bhfíseán atá díreach foilsithe acu. Labhraíonn siad faoi chomhcheilg an diabhail. Tá liosta 60 tír acu, agus mo thír féin san áireamh. Dá bhrí sin caithfimid a beith ar an airdeall; caithfimid a bheith aontaithe; caithfimid a bheith díograiseach chun troid ina gcoinne.  Caithfimid go háirithe ár dteorainneacha eachtracha a threisiú agus freisin PNR a thabhairt isteach. Chuir sé áthas orm gur vótáil 637 as 690 i bhfabhar an mholta sin inniu. Táimid ag aontú. Caithfimid leanúint ar aghaidh mar sin.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, the recent attacks in Paris and Mali have clearly shown that radicalisation and terrorist threats have no national borders and require adequate measures at European and global level. To avoid dramas of this magnitude in the future, we need to focus efforts on ensuring prevention.  In this regard, I warmly welcome the Paris Convention of Education Ministers, which aims to nurture pan-European values such as freedom, tolerance and the fight against discrimination among adolescents through education from an early age. Europe is going through difficult times and it is time to realize that we need to invest in inclusive education that creates responsible, tolerant and world-wide citizens who are able to distinguish facts from opinions. I stand by the view that educational institutions need to cultivate critical thinking among young people, helping them to properly understand and judge information in the context of the Internet and social networks and thus be less vulnerable to manipulation and propaganda.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – There is a very simple question here: why did the Capital of the Kingdom of Belgium become such a terrorist site in Europe in the Member States of the European Union and in recent days? The answer is simple. The European Union became the victim of its own story of success. Of course, the same freedom of expression, other fundamental values, must remain in the number of our fundamental values. Radical social elements must not be allowed to use our values to propel our views with impunity among our citizens. The same applies to open borders policy, freedom of transfer of financial resources within the community and also outside, because terrorists, other radicals are free to use this opportunity to support their organisations and to sponsor terrorist acts. Good cooperation between Member States and between the European Parliament's external partners is also a much more active counter-action by terrorist groups.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, if we want settlers and their children to integrate, we have to offer something into which to integrate. We have to project a sense of shared purpose, of common patriotism that can embrace all our citizens. What do people see when growing up in Europe? They see the idea of the nation state derided and traduced; they are told that the whole concept of national identity is both passé and dangerous. Consider the experience of a boy of, say, Moroccan origin, growing up in Molenbeek. What are his life experiences? His every interaction with the state will have taught him to despise it. If he was taught any history at all in school, it will have been presented to him as a hateful chronicle of racism and exploitation. He sees the two linguistic communities in Belgium identifying within themselves, rather than at federal level. But where does that leave him? What is there for him to be part of? Is it any wonder that a minority of people in those communities begin to cast around for a stronger, bolder, more self-assertive identity? The way to defeat a bad idea is with a better idea. There is no worse idea than Islamic State and no better… (The President cut the speaker off)

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, I would just like to say that it is not you I am getting at particularly, it is the whole system – the EU has been far too fast. What is terrifying – and I am speaking about this issue here – is that laws, or rather freedoms, in Europe are being lifted faster than you can sell a prize bull at a cattle auction. I think that is terrifying to most British people watching today’s performance. I know we have a lot of stuff to get through. Perhaps we should get through less stuff and we would get it through better. I am concerned also that the Left and the Liberals are covering their mistakes with open door immigration by trying to have a radical, rapid, authoritarian legislation brought in, which I do not think is in the interests of either catching these criminals or indeed of liberty in Europe. So there are two things that are a threat. Firstly, there is the speed of passing laws, which no one has properly considered. Secondly, there is the fact that the Left is trying to cover their tracks and their mistakes by bringing in authoritarian laws.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, the 1996 Education Act in the United Kingdom requires that schools teach from a politically-neutral perspective. I have a concern specifically on this report where an amendment was passed after paragraph 25, I believe, which states that it is Member States’ duty to guarantee that their education systems respect and promote EU values and principles. I do not see it as being the responsibility of the British Government to politicise our education system in this way. I believe that fundamentally, what education should be about is teaching children and giving them the skills to think for themselves, not telling them what to think. For that reason, as well as various others which will, I am sure, be articulated by my colleagues, I felt it necessary to vote against this report.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I have just voted against a report on the prevention of radicalisation and terrorism in Europe, a report that has actually been symptomatic of why the EU is not capable of stopping this kind of thing. We have had a debate on it where all sorts of things were thrown out: ‘oh, the terrorists, it’s because they’re poor’; ‘oh, it’s because they don’t have a chance’; or ‘it’s because we’re harsh towards them and people speak out against immigration – oh, that’s why’. Trying to understand reasons and always missing the point – always, because people are not actually on the ground floor seeing this – and then deliberately shying away from the fact that obviously, mass immigration has something to do with it, because you are bringing in large numbers of people and you do not know who they are. It is obviously there. Let us not be politically correct. And then at the end of this farcical debate we have the most ludicrous voting session where, frankly, most of the people in the Chamber do not even know what they are voting for. Their hands are up, down, and no one knows what is happening. It has got passed through. I voted against it. It is an utter nonsense.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent terrorist attack in Paris highlighted the problem of the religious radicalisation of European citizens and so-called foreign fighters, European citizens who left for Syria to join the ranks of terrorist organisations. The situation must be tackled on several fronts; on the one hand, such phenomena must be prevented by implementing social inclusion measures through the promotion of preventive actions, and on the other hand, the exchange of information and deterrence measures must be strengthened, also aimed at preventing the departure and/or anticipating the return of citizens enlisted in terrorist organisations. Despite what the rapporteur has said, the text focuses on repression, including on the Internet; This measure is certainly necessary, but without the necessary preventive measures, it can be ineffective if not detrimental to the objective we have set one another. Furthermore, excessive measures risk violating the rights of all European citizens; 'those who are prepared to give up their fundamental freedoms in order to achieve a small temporary security deserve neither freedom nor security'. For these reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations since it is done from the outset without the will to go to the root of inequality, the absence of perspectives and alternatives, and xenophobia, which pushes young people into such positions, but simply aims to stigmatize entire groups. Counter-terrorism is not worth shortcuts, and that is just what this report seeks through the recommendation of populist measures. In addition, the work of European agencies such as Europol is enhanced, totally opaque to the scrutiny of citizens and institutions, and their ties to countries with little guarantee of respecting human rights such as the theocratic monarchies of the Persian Gulf are strengthened. They are also intended to cut rights and freedoms on the network, as it recommends the possibility of removing content from the internet without a prior court order. Another of my concerns concerns is the criminal, as it is committed to allowing the segregation of prisoners on the basis of their cultural origin. These, among others, are the main reasons why I voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this report for a variety of reasons. Whilst the report included some positive aspects in relation to addressing issues of intolerance, marginalisation and discrimination, on the whole the report contained too many negative aspects and I had to vote against. These negative aspects included; the extension and enhancing of the remit of EU agencies such as Europol, the request of enhanced control of the EU’s borders, the calls for the isolation and segregation of prisoners, the report's commitment to the introduction of European PNR and the call for enhanced cooperation with third countries including Israel, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and LAS states. These aspects of the report meant I had no option but to vote against it.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. In stark contrast to her own television appearances, in which she defends Christmas stalls and the Christian history of Europe and criticises the dubious role of the oil states, mrs Rachida Dati made this report bogged down in a politically correct gunk. To be sure, it contains some concrete and good measures to prevent radicalisation, such as the separation of detainees and the specialised training of prison staff. But anyone who believes that Islamic jihadism can be countered by the manipulation of internet search engines and by telling attractive narratives and preventative messages on the net is naive. If there is a call for a comprehensive strategy, it also means to me, and perhaps above all, that conclusions must be drawn from the failing EU borders policy, more than the pink-cloud story. The powers and resources transferred to the EU in this area should be re-transferred to the Member States so that they can effectively control their borders again and pursue a return policy (such as the expulsion of criminal aliens, returned Syria fighters, hate imams,...). That is the best form of prevention. I could not therefore approve this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In response to the problem of so-called 'foreign fighters', this own-initiative report proposes all measures to prevent radicalisation and the recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. The report focuses on prevention, especially online, in prisons and through education. I welcome the fact that this resolution advocates both the rapid completion of an EU Directive on Passenger Name Record (PNR) and the drawing up of a blacklist of European jihadists and jihadist terror suspects. The horrific attacks in Paris have once again shown once again that terror knows no borders. That is why coordinated action and enhanced cooperation between the Member States are essential. I therefore support this resolution and express myself in favour of full European intelligence cooperation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. A few passages from this report will suffice to explain our opposition to this report. Small florilège: "Terrorism and radicalization lead to many amalgamations towards religions, which in turn lead to an upsurge in crimes and hate speech motivated by racism, xenophobia or intolerance (...)"; "Terrorism cannot and should not be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization"; it proposes "to call upon tutors or assistant advisers in the process of deradicalisation of EU citizens who have returned from combat zones disappointed with their experience, so as to support them in their reintegration into society through appropriate programmes"; "Europe's diversity and multicultural communities are an integral part of its social fabric, and are an essential asset." With these kinds of proposals, the citizens of the Member States of the European Union can take comfort and conclude that in Brussels the fight against terrorism is not taken lightly! It should also be noted that this report is in favour of the implementation of the NRNP, a liberticidal and ineffective procedure which we are opposed to. So I voted against this text

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, as the attacks in Paris once again underlined the urgent need for coordinated action by Member States and the European Union to prevent radicalisation and combat terrorism.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. It is now clear that the fight against terrorism cannot be based so on military and police retaliatory measures and on increasing security measures. It is also imperative to tackle the deep and complex causes that lead to the radicalisation of European citizens, the overwhelming majority of whom are young.  The European Union must therefore pay particular attention to the marginalisation and uprooting of these young people in order to give them back the horizon of expectations that they feel are now destitute. To this end, it will be necessary to convene the whole society and various areas of knowledge and action. It is also an ideological battle against fear and the values that are most dear to us.  At the same time, the EU must provide itself with more effective legislation to combat online radicalisation and to enable better coordination and exchange of information between our police and secret services.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – As many members of the European Parliament did I also voted in favour of this report. The current situation in Europe is more than worrying. Our core democratic values of respect, liberty and tolerance are under attack. We have reached the state when a delay of finding possible solutions to radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organizations can't be ignored. The fact that all terrorists were European citizens is shocking. Thus it is of utmost importance to tackle the root causes of the problem. Actions, collective efforts and decisions are needed here and now. We must improve the cooperation and exchange of information among law enforcement authorities of the EU Member States, strengthen our measures against terrorist financing and the use of the intelligence information could be much better. Moreover, we can´t forget that countering radicalisation in our real world is as important, as in the virtual world. We need to ensure that grievances among marginalised members of society are address effectively.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to prevent the radicalisation of Europeans. There are more than 5000 EU citizens who have gone to fight in iraq and Syria. As repressive measures are no longer sufficient today, this report highlights the actions relating to the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. I support the proposed measures: strengthening the prevention of terrorist radicalisation in prisons, the prompt removal of illegal content on the Internet, which incites violent extremism, the development of a system for alerting members of the community to radicalisation, monitoring of 'foreign fighters' in Europe and better cooperation between EU countries on this issue, intensification of the exchange of information between EU States and Europol, confiscation of potential terrorist passports and their financial assets, enhanced screening of their return to the EU and the establishment of a European blacklist of jihadists and suspected terrorists , the fight against Islamic State in Syria and other countries, strengthening the protection of the EU's external borders, combating the financing of terrorism and the illicit trafficking of arms.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The tragic events in Paris require a multifaceted response that is both safe and preventive. This report addresses several important aspects in this regard. In terms of prevention, it stresses the need for Internet service providers to work together with the authorities, but also on the role of education, social policies and actions in neighbourhoods. It also stresses, both preventive and repressive, the absolute need to increase Member States' cooperation in the collection and exchange of intelligence, particularly through tools such as SIS II, VIS or ECRIS. States must feed these databases in order to maximize the effectiveness of combating these barbaric acts. I also supported the amendment calling, in view of the current situation, for the urgent strengthening of controls at the external borders of the Schengen area. This reinforcement and the exchange of information are essential if we are to maintain the Schengen area and ensure the security of our citizens.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. I approved Mrs Rachida Dati's report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations, because, even if it is insufficient, this report by the former Minister of Justice of my country is going in the right direction and can be a tool in the fight against the terrorist threat to the Member States of the European Union. There is therefore no need to quibble over certain details and paragraphs of this text which show too much lewdness in the face of the Islamist threat or even blindness about the true nature of this threat. I regret, among other things, that this report does not dare to point the finger at the risk posed to our society by the arrival of too many migrants; at the potential risk of terrorists infiltrating them, it should not be added the epidermal rejection that this can cause in the population and the serious social unrest that can result. However, this report highlights many of the weaknesses of the current policy in this area, and I welcome that.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report and share the speech made today by the Chairman of my group, Guy Verhofstad. Terrorists do not respect national borders, so we must have security and intelligence over borders. If we have to choose between sovereignty and security, the security of our citizens must prevail. This leads me once again to ask for the coordination of all the police and, in our case, the coordination with the Ertzaintza of the spanish state's security forces so that, on an equal footing, I can access the data necessary for the fight against jihadism.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations is a politically correct, communitarian and Europeanist report. It is a catalogue of good feelings, but it is finally time to realis that the European Union cannot change anything in this matter until we question Schengen, free movement and continue to open our borders wide.  This report refuses to associate terrorism with "no religion, nationality or civilization" thus denying the problem of mass immigration to Europe which can no longer integrate and assimilate and which some terrorists take advantage of to pass as "refugees". In the name of European humanism, we should welcome all communities and "live together" on a daily basis.  Finally, the solution found would be in the completion of an EU directive on passenger records (PNR) before the end of 2015. It is proven that this measure has no use since terrorists now have many other means of movement, facilitated by this europe. This PNR will only serve to make yet another record of citizens without any effects for safety.  So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not share the positions supported in this report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations by our colleague DATA. The massacres in Paris clearly show that terrorism in Europe is a threat that must be combated and condemned in every forum and by all means.  The text in question, on the other hand, confines itself to mildly condemning terrorists and extremists, rejecting the idea of closing borders and reintroducing controls. This text is far removed from the reality and needs of our citizens, and for these reasons I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have abstained from this report. Radicalisation is an important issue, but this report is used to carry out more monitoring of people and to give power to internet service providers to share information with Europol and Member States. Moreover, far too much focus was on young people who were radicalised into Islamist organisations without recognising the great dangers of far-right radicalisation.  However, some good things went through, such as recognising that social and economic aspects contribute to the radicalisation of people and that religion itself is not the problem but misinterpretation of it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
