text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which discusses the prevention of the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. The terrorist attacks in early 2015 showed the urgent need for the European Union to take action to combat terrorism and prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. Although the tragic events of early 2015 helped the EU institutions and Member States decide to step up their efforts to prevent radicalisation, action has long been called for in this area. Combating the radicalisation of EU citizens is still an important area of competence for Member States. However, a collaborative European approach is needed in order to effectively combat the threat posed by these radical EU citizens who can move freely within the EU. As the radicalisation of EU citizens is rapidly spreading, repressive measures are no longer sufficient. The European Union must adopt a new strategy that is more based on prevention. This report therefore highlights the active actions relating to the prevention of the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. The purpose of this report is to make recommendations on a strategy to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of European EU citizens. This should address various factors contributing to radicalisation. The study on how new foreign fighters are recruited must provide effective solutions for each sector and each platform that promotes radicalisation.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed. It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Radicalisation in Europe, especially by Islamic fundamentalists, is a major problem that unfortunately deepens. The recent terrorist attacks in Paris show that the EU must take more decisive action to prevent radicalisation, which mainly occurs in ethnically and socially deprived areas of major European cities. A concrete example of this is the Molenbeek Saint-Jean Brussels district, which has gained an infamous reputation as the European capital of jihadism.  The fight against the radicalisation of EU citizens is primarily the responsibility of the Member States, but the mutual cooperation of states, particularly in the area of the exchange of intelligence on these individuals, is crucial for preventing radicalisation and terrorism. A common approach is therefore needed, as these are EU-wide issues. The latter is malnourished in ensuring an adequate level of safety and this needs to be changed. I also supported the report because it is about developing a comprehensive strategy to prevent radicalisation, which must provide longer-term solutions for the security of European citizens. We must be ruthless towards terrorists.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The report voted on today comes at a time when it is essential to rethink the role that the European Union can play in preventing the radicalisation of certain sections of the population, especially the younger ones, which have proved more vulnerable than the phenomenon.  The tragic events in Paris in recent days and the flow of European 'foreign fighters' who have been leaving for years for Syria and Iraq show us how crucial it is to focus on prevention and how important it is to do so with a view to action that is as coordinated and shared as possible at European level, aimed at removing the causes of radicalisation and not just its effects.  The report reiterates the importance of day-to-day and widespread work, which intervenes where the risk of violent extremism is greatest, such as in deprived neighbourhoods, through action to promote social inclusion and reduce the sense of marginalisation, or in prisons, which all too often become centres of radicalisation. Furthermore, it is, of course, necessary to promote control over the emergence of radicalisation, by facilitating the exchange of information between the authorities and by strengthening supervision of the Internet, which is all too often used by terrorist networks as a platform for the recruitment and dissemination of fundamentalist ideas.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. \u2012 It would have been wiser and more useful, given recent events, to postpone the vote on this text, if only to update it and, why not, to tighten it up. This report does not condemn the terrorists with the necessary firmness, nor do those who support morally and financially the extremism behind it. It criticises the possible closure of internal borders (but is it true or not that wanted No 1 in Europe is running freely between Member States?); some extravagant amendments which would like to introduce – at our expense! - social inclusion programmes for so-called 'foreign fighters' returning to their country after training in Syria or the Middle East. Today, the middle way that this Union and this Parliament like is no longer sustainable or desirable: it is time to take serious and concrete decisions, for example by completely abolishing Schengen, which is a not secondary cause of the 'free movement' of terrorists. What do we still have to wait for?

name: David BORRELLI
text: in writing. Mr President, I abstained on the vote on Mrs Rachida Dati's own-initiative report because, although I believe it is necessary to stop the radicalisation of those who go to fight in Syria alongside terrorist organisations, it was not possible to vote in favour of the too vague text proposed by the rapporteur.  In fact, although it is very difficult to prevent a European passport holder from returning to Europe, at the same time it is now more necessary than ever to find a way of blocking foreign fighters. I am convinced that, in line with the important actions provided for in the text, aimed at strengthening the exchange of information and deterrence measures to prevent the departure of European citizens, it is now essential to monitor foreign fighters on their return to their EU country of origin.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report on combating radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens to terrorist organisations. Member States have basic competences in the fight against radicalisation of EU citizens. However, a common EU approach is needed to make the measures effective. The aim of this report is to make recommendations on the EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation of European citizens. The reinforced steps of this phenomenon mean that law enforcement measures are no longer sufficient and it is recommended that a more prevention-based complementary strategy be adopted.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations is a politically correct, communitarian and Europeanist report. It does not involve Schengen or the absence of borders. The report stresses that terrorism cannot be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization. It also stresses that Europe's diversity with its multicultural communities is an integral part of its social fabric. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorist activity is an extremely serious event, the global nature of which and the increasing level of threat of which place the phenomenon as a priority on the political agenda of the Union and the Member States. This phenomenon must be tackled with hardness and speed in order to be defeated. We need to go and influence where terrorism feeds, preventing the recruitment and training of new recruits.  Terrorism is like a stream: it is not enough to contain it or contain it, it must be blocked at the source. It is necessary to facilitate the exchange of good practices on deradicalisation, to dismantle terrorist recruitment networks on the ground, to prevent radicalisation through education and social inclusion (with a particular focus on Internet activities and the role of prison recruitment), to strengthen the links between internal and external security in the EU, to prevent the departure and to anticipate the return of radicalised European citizens recruited by terrorist organisations , strengthen deterrence measures against the radicalisation of terrorism and the exchange of information between the various police and intelligence forces.  Only by activating this global approach will we defeat terrorism. Repression alone without education and social inclusion is by no means enough.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report was intended to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. It must be noted that this politically correct, communitarian and Europeanist text does not address the roots of the problem of the free movement of individuals in the Schengen area and the lack of resources granted to the intelligence services. The amalgam would be precisely not to designate the enemy we face, namely Islamic fundamentalism, the real scourge of the 21st century. However, it is not by voting on the EU Passenger Records Directive (PNR), which amounts to controlling all air travellers in Europe, that this threat will be eradicated, not least because these terrorists do not always use this mode of transport. Above all, it is essential that national governments focus first on individuals at risk and exchange data on those suspected of belonging to the jihadist movement. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent terrorist attacks once again confirm our need for investment in preventive measures than in reactive ones. As for the involvement of European citizens in radical organisations and terrorist attacks, urgent action is needed in order to be able to control this growing phenomenon. Given that so far around 5 000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations and other military formations, we cannot remain indifferent to the new realities. There is a need to act and prevent the rise of this number of people through concrete and democratic actions, and in this respect European cooperation is essential for the effective and effective exchange of information between the competent institutions. There is also a need to make coordination of internal and external policies more effective in order to ensure the removal of the significant terrorist threat in the EU. I voted in favour of the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations because we now, more than ever, need as many tools as possible to help a phenomenon that is constantly accelerating and is taking on a considerable scale.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Our delegation cannot support this report signed by the former Minister of Justice of the Sarkozy government, of the PPE Group. The text does not condemn terrorists with the necessary firmness, nor do those who morally support the extremism that undersoes it. It is a report which criticises the possible closure of borders and which, in many other respects too, I cannot support. There is no doubt that some amending proposals are outlandish, calling for social inclusion programmes to be introduced for the so-called 'foreign fighters' returning. In view of the seriousness of the recent terrorist events, the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has tried to make amends by tabling amendments, but which are not in a position to change direction to a poor quality text such as the one voted on in committee.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The presence of terrorism and its fight has a long history in Europe, which dates back to its world appearance. Naturally, Islam is not the only religion misused to legitimize terrorist acts, and terrorism is not only religiously motivated. Given the frequency of last year's attacks in Europe and the departure of European citizens to Syria, the phenomenon of radicalisation increasingly present in the EU must be combated with a number of preventive measures. Reactive measures are only necessary in emergency situations, and as far as the phenomenon of radicalisation present in the EU is concerned, I believe that the method of action with high efficiency is to combat through preventive measures. I support this report because concerted European action is needed to combat extremism, radicalisation and terrorist recruitment in prisons and on the internet, to strengthen the exchange of information on radicalisation with terrorist tendencies in Europe, but, above all, to prevent radicalisation through education and social inclusion.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. The report calls for more collaboration between Member States, particularly with regard to the exchange of information on persons under surveillance. He points out that radicalization must also be combated where it is most present, in prisons. Radicalized inmates must be excluded from other prisoners so that they cannot indoctrinate other prisoners. Education must be the foundation of the fight against radicalisation. In this, internet search operators have a responsibility when they leave videos promoting terrorism within everyone's reach. We have to penalize these operators. I hope that these measures put forward by Parliament will be the subject of a European strategy against radicalisation as soon as possible.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. I abstained in the final vote on the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations because my conscience prevented me from supporting a text that so clearly renounced the use of prison policy as an instrument to combat terrorism. We Spaniards know what we're talking about and I couldn't be complicit in a mistake that I wish didn't translate into dead. As other aspects of the text are very positive, I decided to abstain so as not to be complicit or obstructionist.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on preventing radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. The report has highlighted that the phenomenon of radicalisation is widespread in Europe, perhaps more than we expected.  The sad events in Paris have shown that one of the consequences of radicalisation is the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. Effective prevention policies and the strengthening of intercultural dialogue between different religious communities are needed to limit both phenomena. Secondly, the exchange of information between the intelligence services of the Member States must be stepped up in order to dismantle the terrorist networks and to target money laundering that funds criminal and terrorist networks. In line with what the report says, I believe that a strategy to combat extremism, radicalisation and the recruitment of terrorists within the EU can only be truly effective if developed in parallel with a strategy of integration and social inclusion.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report included some positive aspects in relation to addressing issues of intolerance, marginalisation and discrimination. However, there were a number of negative provisions which included; the extension and enhancing of the remit of EU agencies such as Europol, the request of enhanced control of the EU’s borders, the calls for the isolation and segregation of prisoners, the report’s commitment to the introduction of European PNR and the call for enhanced cooperation with third countries including Israel, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and LAS states. These deeply concerning undemocratic aspects meant I had no option but to vote against it.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I strongly believe that society has no place for discrimination based on races, religions and ideas. In addition, I am concerned that more than 5 000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations, so we should cooperate to fight against the radicalism and recruitment by terrorist organizations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text offers some interesting ideas and certainly the proactive attitude that emerges from it, aimed at preventing the onset and spread of the phenomenon of foreign fighters, is positive.  However, the report is unbalanced in a repressive sense and, in particular with regard to the use of computer media, there is a risk that this will involve a disproportionate restriction of personal freedoms. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I consider it essential that we start preventing radical phenomenon, for example, in school curricula or on the Internet, where hate speech and radical views are spreading. I also support the proposal to introduce a so-called European list of jihadists so that we know exactly who needs to be targeted. It is clear that all these steps will cost something, and therefore there is a need to discuss, at the same time, an increase in security resources.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Written. This year alone, Europe has been repeatedly hit by terrorist acts. Most recently, with the horrific attack in Paris, it has become clear that we need to address the root of the problem, radicalisation.  Often the terrorists are European citizens who were born and raised here but have been radicalised and recruited to commit atrocities. That practice needs to be stopped. That is why we support the report's message on combating radicalisation and recruitment.  However, we are far from in agreement with all the tools presented in the report. Despite this, we have chosen to support the report. Our position is that the EU should contribute where it brings European added value, for example through the sharing of best practices, police cooperation and, above all, PNR.  At the same time, however, we are opposed to the EU having to provide detailed regulation, for example on tackling radicalisation in prisons. Here we believe that the countries' own authorities know best how to deal with this problem.  But we agree that we must learn from each other in Europe, that we must stand together and that we must work together against this common evil. That is why we voted in favour of the report and because the signal from the European Parliament that we must cooperate on anti-radicalisation is important.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris call for coordinated actions by all EU Member States to prevent radicalisation and combat terrorism. The resolution lays down concrete proposals for an integrated strategy to combat extremism, which should mainly be implemented online, in prisons and through education and social inclusion. The resolution stresses the need to strengthen intercultural dialogue through education systems in disadvantaged areas in order to prevent marginalisation and promote social inclusion. The resolution is important and we support it unreservedly.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I chose to support the measure. The report aims to make recommendations for a European strategy to prevent radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations.  Over and above the difficulties that this type of calculation entails, the number of European citizens who have left for Iraq and Syria with the intention of fighting alongside terrorist organisations is currently estimated at 5 000. This phenomenon is taking on considerable proportions in some Member States, but in reality the whole of the European Union is affected by the challenges and problems that these 'foreign fighters' represent.  The fight against the radicalisation of European citizens remains primarily a matter for the Member States. However, a concerted European approach is essential in order to effectively a foil the threat posed by radicalised European citizens who can move freely within European territory. Nevertheless, the European Parliament wishes to stress its attachment to the protection of fundamental freedoms, the compression of which can never be accepted.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the terrorist attacks carried out since the beginning of 2015 have shown the need for the European Union to act urgently in the fight against terrorism and the prevention of the radicalisation of European citizens. Furthermore, in the face of the acceleration of this phenomenon, repression measures are no longer enough and the European Union has an obligation to adopt a new strategy, more focused on prevention. The fight against the radicalisation of European citizens remains primarily a matter for the Member States. However, a concerted European approach is essential in order to effectively a foil the threat posed by radicalised European citizens who can move freely within European territory. Finally, I am convinced that the rapporteur would, however, like to emphasise the attachment to the protection of fundamental freedoms: under no circumstances will the European Parliament call into question, in its proposals, respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms and expression of European citizens.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Today’s vote is above all a strong signal for the European Commission and the Council who must implement this reports proposals. The European Institutions must take responsibility, as we did today in the European Parliament. European citizens are watching us, their expectations are immense. If we do not respond to these expectations, we would be exposing European citizens to barbarians.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. This report, the result of this year's attacks in Paris, has gained greater acuity from the recent criminal acts in Paris. It focuses on one of the most important issues in the fight against terrorism, which requires a comprehensive set of measures, both at the repressive and preventive level. Prudence asks us not to legislae in reaction to the events, much less that we give in to security drifts. To give in to our core values would be to grant a victory to the terrorists. As regards radicalisation, this report presents a good diagnosis and a set of valid solutions that should be pursued, including, but not limited to, preventive measures in prisons and schools or harmonisation of the criminal framework. The focus on action at local, proximity and not only at European level and coordinated action between States is of particular importance. I voted in favour of this report despite disagreeing with some points which seem excessive to me.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens are two very serious dangers to which our European society is currently subject. The numbers are alarming to say the least: the number of foreign fighters is estimated at 5 000 European citizens who have travelled to Iraq and Syria to join terrorist groups. The seriousness and seriousness of the latest attacks in Paris, as well as the serious state of alarm in Brussels, require us to take a tougher approach, not only aimed at repression, but above all at prevention. The aim is to prevent such events from happening again at all costs and, above all, to give in to the temptation to live in a climate of constant terror, by renouncing one's values or changing one's habits because of a threat perceived by European citizens as continuous and inadequitable.  The damage caused by this situation does not only concern the well-being of people, which is undoubtedly of primary importance, but also that of businesses and businesses. We can no longer allow this, so I voted in favour of this report, agreeing with its spirit and its proposals.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Member States retain the core competence in combating the radicalisation of EU citizens, but a concerted EU approach is needed to be effective in combating the threat posed by radicalised EU residents and citizens. It is now estimated that over 5 000 EU citizens have left to fight for terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria, so we urgently need an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens and present a thorough analysis and a wide range of proposals that covers: recruitment on internet, the radicalisation in prisons. We need to establish a mechanism of alert and support to the families. Member States should exchange information on the internal and external dimension of the threat, de-radicalisation process, how to prevent departures and anticipate the returns.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations since it is done from the outset without the will to go to the root of inequality, the absence of perspectives and alternatives, and xenophobia, which pushes young people into such positions, but simply aims to stigmatize entire groups. Counter-terrorism is not worth shortcuts, and that is just what this report seeks through the recommendation of populist measures. In addition, the work of European agencies such as Europol is enhanced, totally opaque to the scrutiny of citizens and institutions, and their ties to countries with little guarantee of respecting human rights such as the theocratic monarchies of the Persian Gulf are strengthened. They are also intended to cut rights and freedoms on the network, as it recommends the possibility of removing content from the internet without a prior court order. Another of my concerns concerns is the criminal, as it is committed to allowing the segregation of prisoners on the basis of their cultural origin. These, among others, are the main reasons why I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The multiple terrorist attacks, mostly in Paris, have highlighted the lack of effective security strategies at European level.  The European Parliament considers in its resolution that the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations is of prime importance. Therefore, in the resolution for which I voted in favour, both the Commission and the Member States are called upon to take a number of measures: it is necessary to prevent violent extremism and terrorist radicalisation in prisons or on the Internet, the exchange of information on the radicalisation of terrorism in Europe must be strengthened and effective and dissuasive criminal justice instruments must be strengthened.  I also believe that it is important to strengthen internal and external security links in the EU and to increase controls at the external borders in order to identify inbound and outbound flows. Finally, I believe that the Member States and the Commission must promote the exchange of good practice on deradicalisation and promote education and social inclusion.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The recent tragedy in Paris, as well as other terrorist attacks that took place in Europe this year, have shown that european citizens are often the perpetrators of attacks. More than 5,000 of them are estimated to have joined terrorist organizations such as ISIS and Jabhat al-Nusra. Bearing in mind how dangerous individuals from extremist backgrounds can be, the European Union should take decisive action as a matter of urgency to prevent further radicalisation of its citizens and those temporarily within its borders. As you can see, the repressive measures currently in place are not enough. Parliament's resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations proposes that preventive measures be applied more widely. Attention has been drawn to the need to improve the system for monitoring and exchanging information on persons coming from outside the EU's external borders and moving between Member States and analysing websites with a view to spreading content praising terrorism. An important point is also the call for greater education of those at risk of radicalisation and dialogue between leaders of different communities. Recognising the complexity of the problem, emphasis was also placed on the need for coordination at all levels, from local to international. I believe that the adoption of the resolution will improve security in the European Union and prevent the trend towards increasing extremist attitudes.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Member States have core competence in combatting the radicalisation of EU citizens. However, a concerted EU approach is needed to be effective. The aim of this report is to make recommendations on an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation of European citizens. The quickening pace of this phenomenon means that law enforcement measures are no longer sufficient; the report recommends to adopt a complementary strategy based more on prevention. We need to have an effective EU-wide effort that tackles radicalisation, and for this reason I gave it my support.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this timely report. The prevention of radicalisation must be at the heart of our counter-terrorism strategy in Europe. Enhanced cooperation between EU Member States is vital in tracking the sources and extent of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. This report makes a number of excellent recommendations on prevention strategies, from greater use of the European Cybercrime Centre, enhanced information sharing strategies, sharing of best practices globally, and direct prevention work within prisons. I also wholeheartedly endorse the report’s call for the EU PNR Directive to be adopted by the end of the year – PNR is a vital tool in the fight against globalised terrorism and crime in the 21st century. For all of these reasons I voted in favour of the report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes to define a joint European strategy to combat extremism and the recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations, with an emphasis on education and social inclusion. The report focuses on online and prison recruitment. Proposed measures include confiscating passports, monitoring returns to the European Union of citizens who may have been radicalised, and establishing a blacklist of European jihadists and suspected jihadist terrorists. In addition, the report recommends separating radicalized prisoners, strengthening intercultural dialogue and establishing support systems such as telephone lines.  Finally, Member States are called upon to strengthen their cooperation and the rapid exchange of information between national law enforcement agencies and Europol, to track and monitor suspected terrorists and potential "foreign fighters". Considering that one of the major challenges of terrorism, as the attacks of 13 November in Paris have pointed out, is radicalisation on European soil, I voted in favour of this report which makes strong and necessary proposals.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The overwhelming vote of my report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations testifies to the unity of the European Parliament, across political divides, in the fight against barbarism and terrorism.  It is a strong appeal to the European Commission and the Member States for the measures we are proposing to be put in place quickly. The criminal responsibility of the Internet giants, measures to prevent radicalisation in prisons, the European PNR, the establishment of systematic controls at the external borders of the European Union, the establishment of a European TFTS: all these measures must be undertaken as soon as possible. More than a duty, it is an obligation. The safety of European citizens is at stake. Let's live up to our responsibilities.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the DATI Report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. Two weeks after the Paris attacks, the vote on this report has a particular resonance, European cooperation must be an obligation and a political duty. Thus, this resolution should enable criminal responsibility for the major Internet companies, systematic checks at borders outside the European Union, a containment of radicalisation in prison and the drying up of foreign terrorist financing, but above all the establishment of a European PNR (Data of European Passenger Records). This essential measure is slow to come to light because of the blockade of socialist MPs. With the adoption of this report, the European Parliament is facing its responsibilities in the fight against terrorism. It is the turn of the European Commission and the Council to do the same by implementing these measures!

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed.  It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is in a hot light after it was radically revised by my colleagues from the LIBE Commission in order to highlight, in the strategy to prevent and combat violent extremism, coercive means such as strengthening the exchange of information and experiences between Member States, particularly at the police and judicial level. , but also instruments related to mediation, social inclusion and the fight against discrimination, through, for example, citizenship education, community volunteering and support for the work of street educators. The final version of this report also ensures that refugees and migrants who should not be equated with terrorists should not be stigmatized. Finally, this report once again draws attention to the fundamental issue of the commitment of internet companies to do more to detect and remove hate messages and calls for murder. Radicalization affects all social circles and the internet is the main vehicle.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed. It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report poses itself as a true champion of the politically correct European and communitarian.  While it claims to prevent the switch to terrorism of citizens of European origin, it does not identify the real causes, nor does it name them. Islamic fundamentalism is not a sui generis entity, without attachment, without origin or foundation. Mostly from our suburbs and from the Islamic communitarianism that reigns there, it cannot be fought by living together and declarations of intent totally dissociating it from Islam and its fundamentalist drift. I cannot endorse a report that does not identify the true ins and outs of terrorism that kills hundreds of our compatriots. So I voted against this Dati report.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ There is much within this report which I can support, including calls for the EU-PNR Directive to be adopted by the end of the year. I support calls in the report for enhanced cooperation between Member States and the need for additional initiatives in the fight against cross border crime including community based initiatives. I also support the need for additional mechanisms which will enhance the expedient and efficient exchange of information between national law enforcement authorities. The ECR Group held the rapporteurships for both the opinion in the CULT committee (Mr Dzhambazki) and the opinion in the AFET committee (Mr Tannock).The ECR was happy with the overall outcome of the committee vote, where the compromises included a large number of the ECR Shadow Rapporteur's amendments.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: (ECR), in writing. \u2012 The report is a good step towards a more successful European cooperation towards preventing radicalisation and I supported it. Action at European Union level is necessary, at least aimed at cooperation and exchange of good practices. A common network to exchange information about the problems of radicalisation can also be called a good step. But as I have said many times, and I will continue to repeat it – it is necessary to eradicate the main problem, military action against the terrorist organization Daesh and its occupied territory is needed, closing borders for the flow of immigrants and immediately extraditing illegal immigrants residing on our territory.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because it contains a number of positive ideas. We know from the past that extremism does not belong to a particular religion, ideology or population group, as some in this House would like us to believe. This report recognises the importance of participation and community engagement, based on trust, so that signals can be identified and identified in a timely manner without an entire community being considered suspicious. National security depends on local security, and local organizations need adequate resources, as does the RAN network. We need to improve the use of our existing intelligence and strengthen agencies such as Europol. That is a much better investment than collecting flight passenger data (PNR) of which I am not in favour. I also express my concern about some of the proposals for tackling extremism on the internet. I want illegal material removed as soon as possible, but within a legal framework. Encryption is a means that can be both positive and negative. EU citizens recruited for violent extremism pose a danger both inside and outside our borders. Cooperation with third countries should be based on clear principles.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Preventing the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by extremist/fundamentalist organisations must also include direct action actions. The assumption that Europe marginalises multicultural communities means that we accept that we are wrong and not all those who, as guests, do not comply with the laws and do not respect the morals and traditions of the societies in which they wish to join. The Schengen Treaty is problematic, and open border policy and mass migration cause social disorder and pose a security threat. The report does not adopt enforced solutions such as closing internal borders and fully restoring border controls at national level. Finally, instead of stopping all cooperation, all aid and imposing sanctions on Turkey, which feeds immigration, gains from traffickers and supports ISIS, the report proposes to strengthen cooperation with it.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed.  It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of citizens by terrorist organisations, because it includes some important steps in tackling a critical problem for Wales and Europe today. We need a detailed and effective long term strategy on which countries can work together.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The report addresses a very topical and important subject for the safety and security of society, namely prevention to prevent the radicalisation of young people in particular. However, this should not necessarily be confused with counter-terrorism measures, as these are people who have already been radicalised. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole but have voted against certain elements on counter-terrorism which I believe should be dealt with in a different context.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The report in question is taking a number of measures to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, such as the self-proclaimed Islamic State, or Daesh. More than 5000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations and other military formations, including the ranks of the self-proclaimed Islamic State/Daesh, Jabhat al-Nusra and other formations outside the EU, in particular in the Middle East and North Africa region. The fight against terrorism remains essentially the responsibility of the Member States, but "European cooperation is essential for the effective and efficient exchange of information between police forces" in an area of free movement of persons. A strategy to combat terrorism, radicalisation and terrorist recruitment in the EU can only take effect if it is developed in parallel with a strategy of integration and social inclusion. I voted in favour.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it does not focus on real terrorism, that stemming from radical Islamism.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with the need to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, which may pose a threat to EU security, I believe that the recommendations in the report relate to actions that are not always informed about effectiveness, adequacy and proportionality.  A more in-depth analysis of the social, economic and cultural context in which these phenomena mature should be the starting point for an effective prevention strategy based on respect for fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This report proposes separate measures, supposedly in the name of combating terrorism, which deliberately go around the root of the problem, not contributing to its solution, to increasing citizens' security or to a coherent strategy of cooperation between states that combat and, above all, prevent terrorism. On the contrary, this report underlaws the strengthening of individual freedoms, insisting on the pilgrim thesis of the false freedom-security dichotomy, and supports a militaristic view of alleged combating terrorism which, rather than weakens, strengthens the logics of hatred, war and terrorism.  Measures such as the drafting of a Directive on indiscriminate passenger identification records, the strengthening and centralisation of the power of Europol, Eurojust, CEPOL and the various EU information systems, the obligation for Member States to make certain information and data available, the criminalisation of internet companies, the weakening of computer encryption systems, are worrying aspects of this document , and are essential guarantees, freedom and guarantees.   We voted against it. The response to terrorism necessarily involves combating its deepest causes – political, economic and social – and defending and affirming the values of freedom, peace, democracy, sovereignty and independence of states, solidarity between peoples.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. U2012 We must show unity in the fight against terrorism, but we must also emphasize the prevention of radicalization and this is achieved by attacking the roots of the problem, that is, by focusing on funding networks, avoiding radicalization in prison or improving border controls. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the Dati report.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that a European strategy to prevent radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens is necessary and imminent, an objective that requires an analysis of the different vectors of radicalisation; a study of how new "foreign fighters" are to be recruited must make it possible to suggest effective solutions in each sector. For these reasons, I voted in favour of Mr Dati's motion for a resolution.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because I do not believe the report adequately addresses the issue of radicalisation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union must stop the radicalisation of the citizens of individual Member States, which unfortunately often leads to their going to war on behalf of terrorist organisations that commit the most heinous acts against the civilian population. It is now estimated that more than 5000 citizens of the European Union are already fighting for these terrorist organisations. In Paris on 13 November, terrorist organisations showed us how horribly cruel they can be and that they will stop at nothing. It is no longer enough just law enforcement measures to combat the accelerating of this phenomenon. The European Union must adopt a new strategy that is more strongly based on prevention. With effective action, the representatives of the Member States and the institutions of the European Union must contribute to never repeating such a terrible disaster on the civilian population. However, when combating radicalisation, we must not forget respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms, especially freedom of expression.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is madness. The text does not condemn the terrorists with the necessary firmness, nor do those who morally support the extremism behind it. It is a report which criticises the possible closure of borders and which, in many other respects too, we cannot support. Not to mention a number of amendments which would like to introduce social inclusion programmes for so-called 'foreign fighters' returning to Europe.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. In order to protect citizens we must look towards the root causes of the abhorrent attacks that have recently happened in Paris. Through a combined approach we can show solidarity with the French people and stamp out the spread of extremism.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Member States have core competence in combatting the radicalisation of EU citizens. However, a concerted EU approach is needed to be effective. Law enforcement measures are essential but no longer sufficient; a complementary strategy based on prevention must also be adopted.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is timely in the current context, because the fight against radicalisation must become one of our priorities.  The resolution specifies that radicalization cannot be confined to Islamist radicalization alone and should not be associated with a religion, nationality or civilization. The text addresses all aspects of this phenomenon, emphasizing the preventive aspect in prisons and on the internet. We also stress the importance of strengthening and improving the speed and efficiency of information exchange between Member States and relevant European agencies. Finally, we recall the need for a multi-dimensional approach that also encompasses the role of education and the development of counter-speech based on respect for human rights and opposition to violence.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ The attacks in Paris highlighted the urgency with which the European Union needed to take action on combating terrorism and preventing the radicalisation of its citizens. Member States have core competence in combating the radicalisation of EU citizens; however, a concerted EU approach is needed to be effective. It is now estimated that over 5 000 EU citizens have left to be trained by terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria. According to European law enforcement agencies and intelligence services reports, efficient prevention of radicalisation should start where the recruitment occurs in the first place. I voted in favour of this report and hope that the concrete measures proposed in this text will be implemented as quickly as possible.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am convinced that schools and education play an important role in preventing radicalisation. Schools play a key role in promoting social inclusion, critical thinking and non-discrimination. It is important that Member States encourage educational institutions to offer courses and curricula aimed at strengthening understanding and tolerance, in particular with regard to different religions and ideologies. Fundamental values and the democratic principles of the Union, including the need to educate human rights, must be a top priority.   I believe that it is the duty of the Member States to ensure that their education systems respect and promote EU values and principles and that the functioning of these systems does not go against the principles of non-discrimination and integration.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in the face of the once again finding of the need to articulate at European level a common and forceful response to combat radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. We must work tirelessly to prevent the radicalisation of citizens living in the EU, using integration measures as a priority, necessary and essential as the first line of prevention. But it is also necessary and inevitable to have a joint structure: to deepen police cooperation that will lead us to a European federal police that can benefit from a European penal code already provided for in the Lisbon Treaty. And, in the same sense, we must be able to make more progress on the common policies we should already have, such as the common asylum policy and the common iInmigration policy, and give a real sense of state to the policy of cooperation and development.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Citizens' security must return to the heart of the EU agenda. Today's report proposes measures of decisive importance to combat terrorism and radicalisation: we need an immediate implementation of the European PNR system, systematic controls at the external borders, measures against radicalisation and fundamentalism. After this vote, words must quickly become concrete actions and the European institutions must take responsibility for them.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The tragic events that have hit Europe in recent days make firm and peremptory action by the Union all the more urgent. , calling for help from the large network operators to take responsibility for ever greater control of illegal content on the Internet, by carrying out decisive and structured shared intelligence activities, in particular by hindering all forms of money laundering and covert financing of terrorist networks.  I support the report for a strategy to prevent the radicalisation of terrorism: this is the time for responsibility and Europe can only address it if it presents itself united and solid, open to dialogue, but vigilant and constantly supported by a strong system of cooperation and sharing of information and action plans.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the EP resolution on preventing radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. The dramatic terrorist acts in Paris have left, in addition to grief and dismay, an awareness of the seriousness of the threat perpetrated by ISIS and the so-called "foreign fighters", the European fighters recruited into the ranks of the Islamic State. As demonstrated not only by the events in Paris or recent events in Belgium, but also by the attacks in Beirut, Tunis or Sinai, the fight against terrorism and the prevention of radicalisation, often caused by the perverse use of religion, cannot be confined solely to Europe.  With regard to the awareness that no state is immune to the fanaticism of ISIS, it is necessary to strengthen European and international cooperation through a more effective and efficient system of exchange of information between national intelligence and to implement a global strategy for preventing radicalisation and the recruitment of terrorists.  In the fight against terrorism and radicalisation, I consider the role of education, education and training against all forms of racism, discrimination and intolerance in favour of social inclusion, a sense of belonging and the formation of a critical conscience in all European citizens to be fundamental.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. We need to be more involved in the area of preventive measures to avoid increasing radicalisation of young people. The terrorist attacks in Paris have once again brought this issue to our attention painfully. We must solve this serious security problem. It is therefore important to actively support states in implementing preventive measures.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that sets out recommendations to counter radicalisation that can lead to violence and terrorism and to address the issue of EU citizens adhering to extremism and returning from war scenes. These recommendations range from prevention strategies, through education and social inclusion, but also online and in prison; to de-radicalisation programmes and the dismantling of terrorism network.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because today, more than ever, we are suffering the consequences of a tragic phenomenon that forces us to mourn and fear. Paris mourns its victims, Brussels locks its citizens at home, Rome, Berlin and the rest of Europe look suspiciously at people, things, noises, trigger daily alarms. Europe must respond with measures that increase the freedoms of its citizens, in order to make them free to go out on the streets and return to life, not with restrictions.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which demonstrates the total lack of lucidity of The Europeanists in the face of the terrorist threat. Far from questioning the opening of borders and Schengen, this report is the panegyric of communitarianism and immigration. The most worrying thing about this report is the emptiness of its proposals: in particular, it is called for the implementation of a communication strategy to prevent radicalisation, to encourage the exchange of good practices between Member States in the face of the rise of terrorist radicalisation in prisons, or to encourage educational institutions to propose programmes aimed at strengthening understanding and tolerance... The Dati report goes even further in ideological blindness by calling for the strengthening of the dialogue on security and the fight against terrorism with countries like Saudi Arabia or Turkey... On the other hand, the European MEPs rejected the common sense amendments tabled by our group, which proposed, among other things, to restore systematic controls at national borders, to stop mass immigration, to stop support for Islamist groups in Syria or to prevent the return of jihadist fighters to Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted against this initiative because, despite efforts to reconcile the positions of the different groups, this initiative continues to focus more on the symptoms than on the problems that cause them. More weight is given to coercive and social control measures, which add to the problem of violent extremism that of the deterioration of our freedoms. As we set out among the seven urgent measures to combat terrorism that our delegation mailed to President Schulz, Vice-President Mogherini and all Members of the European Parliament, legal or police measures alone are not sufficient to solve the problem. The best way to combat extremism is to make people feel part of a cohesive society and cultivate economic and social opportunities in vulnerable communities, both in Europe and in the countries suffering from this phenomenon. Strategies that promote the cohesion and social inclusion of people from diverse cultural, ethnic and national backgrounds need to be strengthened, and in particular the role of education as the only way that can offer future alternatives to youth to steer them away from radicalism and violence.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which stresses the need for a common definition of ‘foreign fighters’ to permit criminal proceedings against them. The report calls on EU Member States to share good practices with regard to exit and return checks and freezing citizens’ financial assets in order to prevent them from taking part in terrorist activities in conflict areas in third countries. It also calls supports the increase in exchange of information among Member States’ law enforcement bodies and EU agencies such as Europol (police cooperation), Eurojust (judicial cooperation) and Cepol (police training) as well as making better use of tools such as the Schengen Information System. Such an exchange of information will help Member States to tackle the growing problem of radicalisation among people in Europe.

text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The Paris attacks demonstrate this more than ever: preventing radicalisation is essential in the fight against terrorism. The vast majority of the perpetrators were born and lived in Europe: in France or in our neighbours. The European added value is therefore indisputable to prevent radicalisation: methods that work well in one European country must be able to be shared with others, or information about European fighters travelling to or returning from Syria must be able to be more shared between states. That is why I have spoken in favour of this parliament's report which calls for the implementation of a European action plan to prevent radicalisation. While the original text focused excessively on repression, we managed to enrich it to make it more balanced and to emphasize the need to respect fundamental freedoms. Our influence has been instrumental in reminding us of the importance of education and policies of inclusion and non-discrimination in the prevention of radicalization and in avoiding the amalgamation between religion and terrorism. The ball is now in the Commission's court.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. In order to notably further address the root causes of radicalisation, as well as the need to exchange best-practices on de-radicalisation programmes relying on a community-based approach.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats chose to vote in favour of the report on preventing EU citizens from being radicalised and recruited by terrorist organisations.  We abstained on Amendment No 50 because of the unclear wording. We support border controls at the EU's external border with the aim of detecting whether suspected terrorists are trying to enter the EU. However, these must never lead to people with protection needs being denied entry to the EU's external borders, which would be contrary to EU and international law. We supported the verification and prosecution of people who have fought for IS and who return to be checked and prosecuted if crimes have been committed. Finally, the report also contained problematic wordings about the role of internet companies in removing content 'that contributes to the spread of violent extremism', which we did not support. Nevertheless, we chose to vote in favour of the report in the final vote. The EU and its Member States need to do more to prevent violent extremism.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed.  It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP people's party delegation.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Dati report, although it has improved in some respects (some of the 95 ESA/BPA amendments were accepted in LIBE), nevertheless maintains its negative orientation. The logic of measures of repression, authoritarianism and the suppression of individual freedoms prevailed. A real war against terrorism and violent extremism will be one that will, on the one hand, dismantle Euro-Atlantic support for armed fundamentalist groups in the Arab world, and on the other hand will address the socio-economic factors that lead to despair (poverty, unemployment, underdevelopment, impoverishment, racism, marginalisation), but also the political factors that accumulate anger and indignation among the Muslim world. We are therefore voting against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which sets out Parliament’s main priorities and recommendations on the issue of countering radicalisation leading to violent extremism. Following the tragic attacks in Paris both this month and at the beginning of the year it is apparent that almost all the perpetrators were home-grown and both the EU and Member States must do all they can to fight the radicalisation of our citizens and threats to our internal security with a coordinated and cross border approach. The key word here is prevention and we must fight radicalisation with proactive measures such as close cooperation between law enforcement agencies, effective management of our external borders and targeted cooperation with third countries, inter-cultural dialogue, the role of the religious community in countering fundamentalism, hate speech and terrorist propaganda, and through the education of social and civic values to prevent marginalisation. It is important to remember that respect of fundamental rights must always be to the fore and to avoid stigmatisation of any particular community whether they are Muslims, refugees or migrants.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because a united EU approach is needed to be effective in combating the threat posed by radicalised EU citizens who may move freely around the European Union. It is now estimated that over 5 000 EU citizens have left to fight for terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria, and intelligent services warn on the major challenge and threat posed by their return to the EU in particular given the latest developments in Syria. This report proposes recommendations on a EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens. It focuses on factors such as; recruitment on the internet, radicalisation in prisons, measures to be taken through education and awareness campaign and the need for exchange of information between Member states among other proposals. Preventing the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens is an urgent necessity to overcome these terrorist organizations and in order to restore safety within the EU.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The report lists various measures that should be taken at European level to combat terrorism. It is precisely the recent terrorist attacks in Paris that have highlighted the urgency of such measures. The report deals in particular with the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations and calls for an action plan on the part of the Commission. Among other things, the rapporteur highlights the problem that radicalisation often takes place in overcrowded prisons, which is why guidelines and training for staff and educational programmes for prisoners to prevent radicalisation in prisons are to be implemented here. Other areas of action include the fight against online recruitment, training in educational institutions, the need for an EU Directive on PNR and enhanced cooperation between law enforcement authorities in the Member States within existing systems. These include, for example, the Schengen Information System (SIS) and other platforms. As the proposed measures are aimed at safeguarding freedom and the rule of law in Europe, I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the euro must be abolished because it leads to strife and discord in Europe!

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is now a decades-old tradition for the People's Party faction to provide a forum for discussing the topicality of interfaith dialogue in the European Parliament. Just in the days leading up to the Paris attacks, our task force held a groundbreaking meeting on the possibilities of curbing radical Islam. Last week, for the first time, MPs and imams who rejected the extremist interpretation of Islam discussed the causes of interfaith tensions and the directions for joint action. Today's report underlines the importance of education and interfaith dialogue as key areas for preventing radicalisation. The events in Paris have reinforced our findings in our working group that, in today's difficult times, there is a real need for a partnership of credible teachers, regular dialogue, as extremists spread distorted, misinterpreted interpretations of Islam among our citizens.  Today, we certainly see that religion remains a fundamental European cause. We must recall that religious communities continue to be an integral part of society and their importance will not diminish in the future. I also agree with the report's approach that the fight against radicalisation should not be limited to certain extremists, such as Islamist extremism. We therefore have a shared responsibility to reduce further forms of religious radicalism. Today's report is yet another sign of the people's party's commitment to continuing dialogue and finding solutions together, and I therefore supported its adoption.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. The terrorist attacks in France, Lebanon, Mali and Tunisia in recent weeks have provided crucial lessons about the determination of jihadist terrorists, their structure and organization. These murderers have no national borders and blithely insult our principles and values. The example of Abdelhamid Abaaoud's entry and exit into the Schengen area, which has been under a European arrest warrant, reveals the danger to citizens because of the lack of communication and disunity of European states. We must put an end to the debates and take the steps that have taken too long to fight the Islamic State and its "madmen of God". Operationally, we need the European NNP including intra-European journeys. It's a priority. We must also strengthen the means of Frontex and Europol and facilitate access to cross-databases of security services, customs and intelligence. Finally, I welcome Rachida Dati's proposals on the prevention of radicalisation in prisons and on the Internet (accountability of internet operators, public awareness in schools and health, exclusion of radicalised individuals in prisons, training of imâms...)

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ Last month, I visited mosques in Luton, Harlow and Cambridge and asked some of my own Muslim constituents what they wanted the strategy we are agreeing today to say?  They said Europe must recognise – as we do – how mainstream Muslims abhor violence, condemn terrorist attacks and believe these contradict their great religion not uphold it. They back plans for rehabilitated foreign fighters to be able to speak in schools to present the reality of what terrorism really is. They applaud us saying terrorism is an issue of crime not of religion. I talked to one mother who lost her child as a foreign fighter and shared her grief. If she cannot truly be held to be responsible for the actions of her son, how can any of us in politics justifiably seek to blame the whole Muslim community for the warped actions of the terrible few who choose the path of violence? Deal with grievance amongst young Muslims I was told: from unemployment locally to international grievances over Palestine.
