But above all, treat Muslims as partners in our anti-radicalisation strategy not its object, as we treat Muslims as full and equal citizens in European society.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has found common ground on how to tackle the recruitment of terrorists and this is to be commended.  It is crucial that we do not allow people to confuse radicalisation with the ongoing refugee crisis as some politicians are seeking to do.  Member States must cooperate with each other and with all their communities to ensure that terrorism is actively combatted.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this report is to make recommendations on an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation of European citizens. Law enforcement is essential, but it is no longer enough. A complementary strategy based on prevention should also be adopted.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 For years, the countries of the European Union have been blind to the increased activity of Islamic radicals. Policymakers paralyzed by the fear of political correctness did not even have the courage to correctly name the threat. This can be seen in the debate and in the report voted on today. As the fire is avoided in it the names of Islam and Muslims. Today, however, they are the backbone of most terrorist groups threatening Europe. If we can't come together to identify the threat and name it, how are we going to fight it.  Europe itself is now a rope on which it will hang in a few years.  It opens borders wide while not being able to control who enters Europe. It was among the migrants who were the Paris bombers. They could easily cross the road from Greece to the French capital. How many times on this road did they get help and free travel from the authorities of other European countries? In Paris, they bought weapons. If French citizens had more legal weapons, they could repel the attack. Today, instead of giving weapons to Europeans so that they can defend themselves, they are discussing how to restrict access to it.  This bloody example shows that the most effective defence is to close the EU's external borders to migrants while strengthening the monitoring of Muslim communities in Europe while increasing the amount of weapons they possess.  It is time for the European Commission to pull the glasses of political correctness and see the problem.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on combating the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens to terrorist organisations coming to plenary at a particularly sensitive time dealing with the consequences of the recent terrorist atrocity in Paris and facing new threats almost daily. The escalation of the consequences of this process can have a devastating impact on the security of EU citizens and is contrary to European values. This large, dangerous and complex problem must be solved by acting on various aspects of its causes and its manifestations. First of all, it should be noted that the causes of the ongoing terrorist radicalisation have not been sufficiently studied. It should also be emphasized that the causes of radicalisation are not religion but perverse abuse of religion, and the problem cannot be seen only as religious radicalisation, but there is also political radicalisation. Efforts should be stepped up and all aspects of Member States' counter-terrorism cooperation should be stepped up, information on terrorist radicalisation in Europe better exchanged, cross-border law enforcement cooperation should be strengthened, attention should be paid to radicalisation in prisons, terrorist radicalisation online, radicalisation prevention by education and social inclusion, accountability and the important role of religious communities in countering hate speech and terrorist propaganda, deter terrorist radicalisation , prevent departures and pay particular attention to the return of radicalised European citizens recruited by terrorist organisations, act towards deradicalisation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This text is unacceptable for a number of reasons, including, I quote: "Terrorism and radicalisation lead to many amalgamations towards religions, which in turn lead to an upsurge in crimes and hate speech motivated by racism, xenophobia or intolerance (...)", "terrorism cannot and should not be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization", proposes "to call upon guardians or assistants advisers in the process of deradicalisation of citizens the Union returned from combat zones disappointed with their experience, so as to support them in their reintegration into society through appropriate programmes, "the diversity of Europe and its multicultural communities are an integral part of its social fabric, and that they are an essential asset." It should also be noted that this report is in favour of the implementation of the NRNP, a liberticidal and ineffective procedure which we are opposed to. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My fellow colleagues and I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un—checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against terrorism and ensuring the security of European Union citizens is a top priority for the European Union in the shadow of the recent Islamic State attacks in Paris. Mrs Dati's report is important for this fight because it proposes concrete steps to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens and the possibility of their involvement in IS structures. Some of the steps I have supported with my vote include important measures aimed at combating the possibility of terrorist organisations reaching out to EU citizens online or reflecting on this issue in schools.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Rachida Dati's report on the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. Unfortunately, the attacks of 13 November proved once again the need to respond effectively to the problem of radicalisation. This will require better monitoring and treatment of individuals at risk in prison, a better policy of prevention and deradicalisation and the establishment of effective controls at the external borders of the Schengen area.  Finally, the text calls for the rapid implementation of the PNR file, which has been irresponsibly hampered by the left until now. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and brussels counter-terrorism operations reiterate the urgent need for coordinated action by EU Member States to prevent radicalisation of EU citizens and combat terrorism. I supported the EP resolution because it puts forward a number of concrete and important proposals to address this situation. This is about mandatory and systematic control of the EU's external borders of the Member States and cooperation in the blacklist of European jihadists and suspected jihadists, as well as a common approach to criminalising 'foreign fighters'. The EP should complete the EU Directive on passenger name record as soon as possible. No less important is to deter potential fighters from joining terrorist organisations and prevent the spread of violent extremism in the Internet and prisons, as well as the fight against radicalisation through education and social inclusion.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I do not agree with the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. It is regrettable that the report clearly fails to identify the actual causes and the basic symptoms of radicalisation, but that this has been almost completely ignored. The preventive measures against terrorism contained in the report are also not materially covered in the motion for a resolution, which is why I cannot vote in favour of this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent tragic terrorist attacks in Paris and elsewhere in the world have once again opened the eyes of the Member States of the European Union, as well as the authorities responsible, for not doing enough to prevent EU citizens from going to war in Syria and their possible radicalisation. I believe that this is another step in how we, Europe, can tackle the problem of terrorism at its roots, so I supported this report in the final vote. The resolution highlights certain proposals to help combat the radicalisation of EU citizens, such as the creation of a common EU blacklist of alleged extremists, a common approach that citizens returning after the war back in Europe could be subject to certain controls and their actions increased. One of the very important points that this resolution included was the commitment made by the European Parliament to complete work on a directive by the end of the year, which would finally allow the creation of a single European Union register of air passenger data, thus allowing the competent authorities of the Member States to exchange relevant information and make the fight against terrorism more effective. At present, without this common passenger name record and without uniform European Union rules on the exchange of relevant data in the European Union in terms of security, there is a 'black hole' that makes our countries an open and very beneficial target for future attacks, so it is necessary to reach agreement on the introduction of such a register as soon as possible.

name: Rikke-Louise KARLSSON
text: In writing. I voted for this report in favour of enhanced cooperation and the need for strong initiatives in the fight against cross-border crime.  Several waves of unprecedented attacks have just been carried out, notably in France, Denmark or Belgium, by individuals who have proven to be radicalized citizens of a European country or migrants who have taken advantage of the current massive flows of refugees. The recent events in Paris show that Europe needs, in particular, a permanent re-establishment of border controls, thus the reconstituted customs infrastructure (which can take five years), better cooperation and data exchange between intra-European and obviously non-European intelligence services, and to tackle the ideology behind these acts. I believe that this struggle requires, in particular, in the long term, that we regain a will and an ability to assimilate each and every one, regardless of their origin or religion, that is to say to welcome it generously into our culture, our values, our history and our common national project. I also believe that women and girls, here and wherever necessary, must be strongly supported and encouraged to rebel against daily family or social oppression, and to initiate a revolution in mentalities.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The core to fight against terrorism and radicalisation in the EU lies in effective and rapid information exchange. PNR is long overdue and has been constantly blocked by ALDE in this house.  EU needs a functioning PNR before the end of 2015 to prevent terrorist acts in Europe. Further, I support the rapporteur in her efforts to prevent radicalisation in prisons, notably separating individuals preaching radical ideologies. I welcome the move by Belgian authorities who decided to isolate one of hate-preachers from other prisoners.  The internet has become an efficient tool for terrorists in spreading hate-speech and recruiting new members. Internet service providers have to assume concrete responsibility to eliminate any hate-preaching and radical terrorist-aiming messages. EU member states have to be prepared for criminal prosecution if ISPs fail their responsibility. The Europol cybercrime centre needs access to data, availability of the latest technology and more staff not only monitor individuals, but also flows of money, weapons and trafficking. EU institutions and Member States can enhance their role primarily by providing them with adequate legal and budgetary framework!

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The devastating attacks in Paris brought to light all the shortcomings of EU intelligence cooperation, data sharing and surveillance. We are now coming to terms with reform that must be done to defeat ISIS. Europe’s strategy to prevent radicalisation should start from the understanding that the current refugee crisis represents an opportunity to confront discrimination, intolerance and hostility in our own lives. We must not mix the challenge of refugees and the challenge of terrorism. Amidst fear and pessimism, we must remain true to our values – upholding freedoms and human rights.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Written. This year alone, Europe has been repeatedly hit by terrorist acts. Most recently, with the horrific attack in Paris, it has become clear that we need to address the root of the problem, radicalisation.  Often the terrorists are European citizens who were born and raised here but have been radicalised and recruited to commit atrocities. That practice needs to be stopped. That is why we support the report's message on combating radicalisation and recruitment.  However, we are far from in agreement with all the tools presented in the report. Despite this, we have chosen to support the report. Our position is that the EU should contribute where it brings European added value, for example through the sharing of best practices, police cooperation and, above all, PNR.  At the same time, however, we are opposed to the EU having to provide detailed regulation, for example on tackling radicalisation in prisons. Here we believe that the countries' own authorities know best how to deal with this problem.  But we agree that we must learn from each other in Europe, that we must stand together and that we must work together against this common evil. That is why we voted in favour of the report and because the signal from the European Parliament that we must cooperate on anti-radicalisation is important.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The report lists various measures that should be taken at European level to combat terrorism. It is precisely the recent terrorist attacks in Paris that have highlighted the urgency of such measures. The report deals in particular with the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations and calls for an action plan on the part of the Commission. Among other things, the rapporteur highlights the problem that radicalisation often takes place in overcrowded prisons, which is why guidelines and training for staff and educational programmes for prisoners to prevent radicalisation in prisons are to be implemented here. Other areas of action include the fight against online recruitment, training in educational institutions, the need for an EU Directive on PNR and enhanced cooperation between law enforcement authorities in the Member States within existing systems. These include, for example, the Schengen Information System (SIS) and other platforms. As the proposed measures are aimed at safeguarding freedom and the rule of law in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed.  It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on the prevention of radicalisation of European citizens by terrorist organisation. The rapporteur made a lot of compromises; however some of GUE/NGL red lines were not included in the report such as the request to enhanced control of EU's external borders or full cooperation with third countries. Furthermore, I am also against the idea to recruit religious priests for pedagogical role in the prisons. Even if the report tries to give a response on how to prevent radicalisation, I am not in the position to support it.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Terrorism and radicalisation are both transnational and internal problems – no EU country is free from a threat that is no longer sourced solely from the outside but from radicalised groups within the Union itself. Therefore, an effective fight against these phenomena is only possible through a common EU strategy, which must be based on prevention. If the Union wants to uphold the values underlying integration – such as the free movement of persons – it must develop an early response strategy against radicalisation and hate speech and develop a policy of promoting tolerance and inclusion.  I agree with the author of the report on the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, which says that the internet has become a virtual training camp for radicals and a space for recruiting and radicalising potential followers. Developing control, in full respect of freedom of expression and the right to privacy, over hateful content with the cooperation of internet companies is one element of the strategy. Above all, however, a systemic approach is needed to prevent early prevention by promoting tolerance for diversity through formal education, training and social campaigns across the Union. It is equally important to have a policy based on social justice in order to promote integration and social cohesion, which prevents exclusion conducive to radicalisation.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I supported this report because the EU must put all its resources into preventing radicalism and extremism in Europe, which are constantly growing. More than 5,000 young European citizens have joined various terrorist organisations and the tragic events of recent days have underlined the need for coordinated action by Member States to restore Europe's multicultural model. It is now more than clear that keeping problems away from our borders does not keep them off our agenda. On the contrary, radicalism and terrorism are a global threat and we need to improve the exchange of information between national security services and Europol so that suspects can be better identified and ed.  We also need to offer a successful integration model to all European citizens prone to radicalisation. It must cover the areas of education, social inclusion, the fight against discrimination, intercultural and interreligious dialogue.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Writing. The FDP in the EP supports the basic orientation of the report. However, we are opposed to the introduction of a PNR directive. That is why we voted against the report. The problem in Europe is not too few security services or insufficient lists of suspects. Rather, the problem lies in a lack of cooperation within the EU on counter-terrorism.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The terrorist attacks that took place at the beginning of 2015, together with what happened recently in Paris, lead us to act with even greater strength and determination in the fight against terrorism and in preventing the radicalisation of European citizens.  The report highlights worrying figures concerning the number of European citizens who left for Iraq and Syria (5 000) with the intention of fighting alongside terrorist organisations. I have decided to give a positive opinion to the report, because I believe it is essential to make every effort to find an effective and decisive strategy for the problem. It is essential that we do everything in our power to prevent fellow Europeans from being recruited by any terrorist organisation.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. As European cooperation is more necessary than ever in the face of the threat posed by Islamist terrorism, I have endorsed my colleague Rachida DATI's report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations. Indeed, in addition to the establishment of the European PNR (supported by the MEMBERS of the EPP group, but long blocked by a motley coalition of French Socialist MEPs and the elected representatives of the National Front), the containment of radicalisation in prison through, in particular, the training of representatives and religious leaders, and systematic checks at the Union's external borders. , this initiative report also recommends a number of measures that we believe will dry up the financing of terrorism. We call for the compel associations to make their foreign funding public, as well as for the establishment of criminal responsibility for the internet giants promoting terrorism. In fact, the Internet being one of the main vectors of Islamist radicalisation, and especially among young people, I believe that there is an urgent need to hold the internet giants accountable for the risks involved in spreading these hate speeches.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. Rachida Dati's report on the prevention of radicalism is very topical after the attacks in Paris and Saint-Denis. The text calls for common procedures to be put in place, such as confiscating the passports of Europeans wishing to travel to conflict zones or placing under judicial control, on his return, of any European citizen who has gone to fight abroad, with, if necessary, administrative detention pending future criminal proceedings. Regarding prevention, it calls for stricter control of content on the internet broadcasting "violent extremism" accompanied by legal responsibility of internet companies and ISPs. State education and social inclusion work is recommended to prevent radicalization behaviour. The coordination, cooperation of national intelligence agencies and security services is strongly encouraged, particularly through European information systems such as the Schengen system, the future NRP, and European agencies. These measures do not garner my full approval. However, I supported this text, because it is necessary to stand together and above all to support any initiative promoting European coordination which we have sorely lacking.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations for several reasons. First of all, this report relativizes the role of Islamist fundamentalism in the problems we face. How do you want to win a fight when you don't even have the courage to designate the enemy? Paragraph 1, for example, "emphasizes that terrorism cannot and should not be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization." The report advocates communitarian and Europeanist solutions. He supports the introduction of NROs, a liberticidal and ineffective system that is part of the logic of mass surveillance. Every citizen of the Member States is therefore considered a potential terrorist, whereas a targeted approach to at-risk groups would be much more effective.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it lacks courage in not daring to denounce the specificity of Islamist radicalisation. On the contrary, he puts it into perspective by believing that this is just one form of radicalization among others. It is indecent when you consider that 130 people have just been massacred in Paris by Islamists.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This text, of which the rapporteur was none other than Rachida Dati, is a concentration of political correctness, communitarianism and Europeanism. Remaining in common places, evading sometimes obvious truths, he does not question for a moment the Schengen area and its open borders.  It also reaffirms the European Union's commitment to work towards a directive on the creation of personal data records for air passengers (PNRs), an idea to which I am vehemently opposed. Like the almost majority of our Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, I voted against this report.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations since it is done from the outset without the will to go to the root of inequality, the absence of perspectives and alternatives, and xenophobia, which pushes young people into such positions, but simply aims to stigmatize entire groups. Counter-terrorism is not worth shortcuts, and that is just what this report seeks through the recommendation of populist measures. In addition, the work of European agencies such as Europol is enhanced, totally opaque to the scrutiny of citizens and institutions, and their ties to countries with little guarantee of respecting human rights such as the theocratic monarchies of the Persian Gulf are strengthened. They are also intended to cut rights and freedoms on the network, as it recommends the possibility of removing content from the internet without a prior court order. Another of my concerns concerns is the criminal, as it is committed to allowing the segregation of prisoners on the basis of their cultural origin. These, among others, are the main reasons why I voted against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report lists various measures that should be taken at European level to combat terrorism. It is precisely the recent terrorist attacks in Paris that have highlighted the urgency of such measures. The report deals in particular with the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations and calls for an action plan on the part of the Commission. Among other things, the rapporteur highlights the problem that radicalisation often takes place in overcrowded prisons, which is why guidelines and training for staff and educational programmes for prisoners to prevent radicalisation in prisons are to be implemented here. Other areas of action include the fight against online recruitment, training in educational institutions, the need for an EU Directive on PNR and enhanced cooperation between law enforcement authorities in the Member States within existing systems. These include, for example, the Schengen Information System (SIS) and other platforms. As the proposed measures are aimed at safeguarding freedom and the rule of law in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The recent tragic events in Paris and the increased police and military action on the streets of Brussels should make us all aware of the important and dangerous problem of ever-expanding terrorism. A phenomenon that can only be combated by acting together. One of the fundamental values and ideas of the European Union is – now very desirable – common security.  I am very pleased with the implementation of this directive, which has resulted in the preparation of a resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of citizens by terrorist organisations. By voting in favour of it, I fully support its message and concrete solutions in response to people's acceptance of opinions, views and ideas that promote intolerance and often lead to extremism. An estimated 5,000 European citizens have left to fight in the ranks of terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria. Therefore, our actions must not be just punitive actions.  I would like to express my approval of a strategy based more on prevention. Preventive measures such as education, countering violent extremism and terrorist radicalisation in prisons and online, better exchange of information on this issue, and strengthening links between the EU's internal and external security, will be a helpful tool in the joint fight against terrorism. I am pleased that Parliament has once again advocated the security of millions of EU citizens.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree that "the approach to defining the crime of hate speech online and offline, by which radicals incite others to disrespect and violate fundamental rights" should be harmonised, and to 'add this particular offence to the relevant Council framework decisions'. The EU may want to apply this crime to hate speech and calls for violence by radical Islamists, but it can be double-cross and it can also affect critics of Islam. In my judgment, it should be punishable only by incitement to violence, but never by criticism or caricature of religion itself. I do not agree with the introduction of 'training programmes to mobilise, train and create networks of young activists'. This is a completely misguided and desperate EU approach to the threat of terrorism.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The increased incidence of terrorist attacks has highlighted the need to take counter-terrorism measures including combating the recruitment of European Union citizens to terrorist organisations and combating radicalisation. Radicalisation should not be associated with any ideology or faith because it can occur in any of them. The strengthening of terrorism has intensified intolerance towards ethnic and religious communities in several European Member States. The backbone of Union policies must be human rights. A balance needs to be struck between public security and respect for fundamental rights. I therefore supported Mp Rachida Dati's report, as the measures so far have proved ineffective given the increasing risk of terrorism. A new protection and prevention strategy is needed, implying cooperation between all Member States as well as neighbouring countries.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The events of recent months and the inability of the Union and some of its Member States to protect its people point to serious policy failures by the EU. The states have not mastered their fundamental role. A lack of asylum policy, a lack of control over the influx of migrants, a lack of resolution to the problems of poverty in the EU and around the world can have very difficult impacts on people around the world in the near future. It is not only war that is fueling poverty and violence, but it is also true of the contrary. The proposed measures can only produce results if we all realise the responsibility for humanity on Earth and if all the authorities concerned take a responsible approach to implementing these measures. The resources allocated to these measures must not become the subject of corruption and various speculation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, because it is not complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24/11/2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against text. Our ENF group has tabled many amendments to this text in an attempt to get it back on track. As we suspected, none have passed. We are therefore faced with a caricatured text of political correctness, communitarianism and Europeanism. The futility, worse the danger, of this text is so blatant that we prefer to oppose it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report and welcome that it emphasises that terrorism cannot and should not be associated with any specific religion, nationality or civilisation.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on a very topical topic, on preventing radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. It's a very complex subject. I agree with many points in the report, for example, that we must combat the black market in arms, the black market in oil, which is a key source of income for terrorist organisations, and I also agree that those who have gone to Syria or Iraq to join or support terrorist organisations should not be allowed back into the EU. But then there are ideas in the report that I cannot agree with, such as an attempt to completely restrict internet freedom or calls for the urgent adoption of a directive on the exchange of passenger data in air transport. I also do not agree that only the terrorist act carried out recently in Paris is highlighted, but it is no longer mentioned, for example, in the downing of a Russian aircraft in Sinai. I therefore could not fully support the report, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent serious terrorist attacks in France, Belgium, Tunisia and Copenhagen highlight the worrying and continuing presence of the phenomenon, particularly in those Member States that have been, or still are, engaged in non-EU operations in the Middle East and Africa.  The report, which I fully support, aims to prevent terrorist extremism through the fight against discrimination in general, Islamophobia and anti-Semitism in particular. The role of education and public awareness campaigns in the effort to prevent radicalisation on the Internet is also very important, given that the Internet itself, while used by terrorist organisations for training purposes, can provide an effective platform for the dissemination of speeches of respect for human rights and opposition to violence, through , for example, the dissemination of online information programs.  Equally important, mr Dati's report points out, is the dissemination of inclusive education programmes. Finally, the report stresses that systems for coordinating and exchanging information between the authorities are of fundamental importance for a more effective fight against terrorism within the Member States.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The terrible events that have affected our country have finally underlined the urgent need for the European Union to fight preventively against the radicalisation of a growing number of European citizens (an estimated 5,000 of them have joined organisations such as Daesh). It is therefore essential to address the multiple and complex causes that drive some European nationals to become radicalised, by providing comprehensive and appropriate responses. In a relatively surprising way - if we compare the content of the text to the regular electoral protrusions of her "Republican" colleagues - a number of convincing proposals are contained in Mrs Dati's initiative report, which is certainly largely amended by the European left. I share his ambition to fight against the return of "foreign fighters", while pursuing a prevention strategy that simultaneously focuses on schools, prisons, or the internet. I have also supported an amendment which proposes to incur criminal liability for internet providers who refuse, following a judicial request, to delete messages promoting terrorism. I voted for this report which, in the face of terrorism, offers strong guarantees of respect for the rule of law.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Following recent developments in the field of terrorism culminating in the tragic deaths of 130 people in Paris last month, there has been an urgent need to adopt new measures to combat and prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens to terrorist organisations. It is certain that a coordinated European effort will be more effective than the decentralised effort made separately by each Member State. I therefore support this resolution in order to build a new basis and a general overall framework within which we will be able to move in the near future to actively combat terrorism and its various branches. Understanding the consequences and growing threat of violent radicalisation and the adoption of extremist ideas by European citizens and taking into account the fact that some 5,000 civilians are recruited each year to islamic state battalions, I consider it necessary to follow improved practices with the immediate aim of preventing and ultimately achieving international peace and security. Such practices can be the direct and effective exchange of information, the coordination of strategies between States, the modernisation of national policies and the focus on sources and means of influence such as the internet. Of course, security presupposes the eradication by any means of phenomena such as ISIS.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Effective preventive measures against terrorism are only marginal phenomena in this report. Basic causes and symptoms of radicalization are negated. The report scrapes past the real problem. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report exploits emotion following the terrible attacks in Paris. The right and the Social Democrats are trying to get us to pass the Air Passenger Data Exchange Directive (PNR) which has been rejected for several years. This prepares an all-out cross-checking of the personal data of the entire population, without any effectiveness against the threat of attack. The report makes the link between the flow of migrants and terrorists miserably when the only "foreigner" of the Paris attacks was Belgian. Worse, between Imams and radicalization of prisoners.  Ms. Dati acknowledges her government's mistakes on "prison overcrowding," even though she has actively supported budget cuts in the judiciary. It recognizes the crucial role of teachers, but is encouraged to play police by identifying potential terrorists. I note that, finally, it is stressed the need to combat the financing of Daesh through Gulf countries that support terrorism.  I am voting against this report and its hastily amended amendments, taking advantage of the emotion to pass a repressive arsenal without any proven effectiveness in the face of the threat we face.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This highly anticipated report was hopeful, but it turns out to be very disappointing. Indeed, despite the current climate, this text still demonstrates angelism towards radical Islamism by advocating the establishment of socio-educational processes. For example, the report proposes to "call upon tutors or assistant advisers in the process of deradicalisation of EU citizens who have returned from combat zones disappointed with their experience, so as to support them in their reintegration into society".  The National Front considers these measures to be very dangerous for our society. He also opposes the NRL, a liberticidal and ineffective project. The Member thus votes against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. 'A concerted action at European level to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations is essential.\ But this prevention also involves stronger cooperation, greater and effective control and the existence of instruments to combat terrorism. The European Union needs a passenger identification record (PNR), it needs the regulation of the Smart Borders, which will allow for more effective and rigorous control, needs to work closely with the exchange of information between national authorities and needs to monitor the proliferation of social networks and the recruitment of European citizens that is developed in this way. It's not enough to say we won't give in to fear. You have to act. We must fight to eliminate extremism that is attentive to our values, our way of life, our existence. We can't be kidnapped in our own house.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report makes recommendations on an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens which encompasses a wide vary of proposals from recruitment on the internet, to education as well as highlighting the need for the exchange of information between Member States. I voted in favour of this report as a cohesive strategy is needed within the EU.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The attacks in Paris and their victims are, for us, literally an unmistakable challenge to do everything possible against the radicalisation of Europeans by terrorism and its global spread. In a situation where it is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have gone to fight alongside terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria, I consider the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations to be more than important. However, with regard to all the technical measures that are intended to address the already consequence of radicalisation and to limit the risks arising from it, the main idea of this report must also be closely respected, and that is to prevent this phenomenon. In this context, questions must be asked very seriously about its causes. One of these is the statistics that depression is suddenly the first cause of health problems among young people between the 10 and 19 years old. Let us look for context, including the loss of family transfer of values and the unassuttering relativism that is increasingly becoming the principle of political decisions in Europe.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, which aims to make recommendations on an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation of European citizens. The quickening pace of this phenomenon means that law enforcement measures are no longer sufficient and therefore this report recommends adopting a complementary strategy based more on prevention. That is why I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs states that the radicalisation of European citizens poses a real security threat to Europe, EU Member States and neighbouring countries. Punitive measures against the acceleration of this phenomenon are no longer sufficient and a coordinated European approach is needed in order to effectively combat the threat posed by these radicalised European citizens, who have free movement on European territory. The report focuses on preventing the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations. It makes recommendations on a European strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens.  I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The latest attacks in Paris once again highlight a gap in the internal security of states due to the presence and movement within the Schengen area of combatant European citizens and recruitment by terrorist organisations. The attacks in Mali and Tunisia show that insecurity is a global problem. It is therefore necessary for the Union to act in a coordinated and joint manner with Member States and other organisations in preventing the recruitment of European citizens into the ranks of terrorist organisations such as Daesh. It is estimated that more than 5000 Europeans have already entered, mostly from Belgium and France. This document serves as a recommendation for the future European Strategy on this topic. It referred to the need for the authorities to ensure stricter control over the Internet and websites that incite hatred, as well as the need to foster a preventive role among the incarceoured population, the role of education and school, the sharing of information between intelligence services, the control of external borders for the prevention and anticipation of the return of recruited citizens and the proper monitoring of these citizens. I voted in favour because I believe in the need for intercultural dialogue and more coordination, because terrorism is not religion, it is not any civilization or nationality.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This Dati report shows an incredible political angelism and correctness. Indeed, it promotes ever more communitarianism and Europeanism to fight terrorism without questioning Schengen and the total opening of borders. Dogmas remain despite the seriousness of the situation. He bends to the cathodic catechism by stating that terrorism "cannot and should not be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization", or that the "diversity of Europe and its multicultural communities are an integral part of its social fabric" while it is obvious that multiculturalism leads to multi-conflict societies. Moreover, the only response to radicalization and recruitment by terrorist organizations is the PNR, which concerns only air transport, when the terrorists of the Paris attacks took other means (especially the migrant route) to reach France from Syria. The Europeanist torpor seems unwavering.  I have of course voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. The attacks that killed 130 people and injured 350 in Paris on 13 November, 17 people also killed in January 2015 in Paris, and the disaster averted last August on the Thalys train in Belgium, demonstrate the absolute need for the European Union and the Member States to mobilise urgently against those who seek to destroy our common area of freedom. This text, which aims to combat preventive and judicial against radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations, calls in particular to detect the departures and returns of terrorists to and from the Union by the establishment by Member States of the systematic and mandatory checks planned at the Union's external borders.  I naturally voted for this measure, as well as for the completion of the Passenger Records Directive (PNR) before the end of 2015. It is important to note that, despite the obvious need for this instrument to combat terrorism, 14 Socialists still opposed it, as the French socialist Sylvie Guillaume did in the committee vote on 15 July.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. With the terrorist attacks of 2015, our freedom is targeted. All of Europe is concerned. I voted to strengthen the security of European citizens and fight against radicalisation: the Passenger Name Record (PNR) which will collect people's movements and will be a valuable source of information on suspects, the strengthening of systematic controls at the external borders of the European Union, the criminal responsibility of the internet giants in the dissemination of images and statements promoting the radicalisation of young people and anti-radicalisation in prisons. It is through the development of intelligence, the strengthening of Frontex, the strong cooperation between the 28 Member States that we will effectively combat radicalisation and terrorism.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the scale of the phenomenon of foreign fighters, involving more than five thousand European citizens, I welcome the proposal aimed at preventing radicalisation.  The military escalation in the Middle East and North Africa and the continuing conflicts in the region call for action to support, in traditional methods of legal prosecution, concerted action at European level to prevent radicalisation by acting on the causes. Despite the fact that the Member States have competence in this area, credible and effective measures against conscription can only include strategic coordination at European level, which can be achieved through the exchange, subject to full compliance with international conventions on human rights, information and good practice. I also support the recommendation to the European Commission on cooperation with international institutions and the preparation of studies to arrive at a legal definition of the phenomenon of foreign combatant. Equally important is the setting of guidelines on the prevention and isolation of the phenomenon in prisons, the overcrowding of which is a means of catalyzing it, and in the network, understood as a powerful platform capable of conveying messages of hatred and incitement to fundamentalism. Finally, I stress the importance of schools as a means of promoting tolerance, civic education and the instrument of social inclusion.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. It gives a very good way to tackle a problem that has become central, especially in France, but which, in view of the number of departures to Syria, affects many European countries. It is an excellent report, but it should not obscure the need to address the problem at the national level by returning to a real integration policy.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 At this difficult time, it is particularly important for the European Union to act as a credible and active actor in the fight against terrorism. It is not enough to stress the seriousness of the situation and the importance of a common, decisive reaction. We need to create tools that bring real solutions, and this report is a good starting point for this.  A threat of this size requires more than cooperation between Member States, we need to bring in additional allies and strengthen our relationship with those that already exist. I believe that cooperation with Russia, for example, can be successful. To do so, however, we must put aside our differences and prioritise our common goals. Early access to information plays an all-important role in the fight against terrorism. It is therefore important to work with the right partners to gain data to prevent possible attacks and expose terrorist groups.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The terrorist attacks at the start of 2015 highlighted the urgency with which the European Union needed to take action on combating terrorism and preventing the radicalisation of its citizens. I have voted for this report that will make recommendations on an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I support the rapporteur's view that, without a coordinated and integrated approach to the causes for which so many people are choosing the path of radicalisation and terrorism, including in the Member States, we will not be able to combat the effects of this phenomenon. It is essential that States work together to find the best strategies and exchange best practices and effective measures that can also be applied in the territories of other states. Education and combating discrimination through social inclusion, especially among young people, are also cornerstones in the context of any strategy to combat radicalisation, globalisation and terrorism, and these must be taken very seriously.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Dati's report, which I believe is a useful contribution to solving the burning problem of European security. I see its importance in correctly naming the weaknesses of today's legislation, which should be filled with quality legislation to effectively combat the threat of terrorism and other forms of serious crime. I consider it important, inter alia, to establish a common definition of 'foreign fighter' for the purposes of prosecuting persons who can be described in this way. Given the growing activity of radical groups (not just Islamists) on the Internet, it is necessary to ensure stricter monitoring of hate-incitement websites. In this respect, I have high hopes for the newly established Europol Internet Content Reporting Unit, which is tasked with detecting illegal content and supporting Member States. I think that lower tolerance for these events is a way to gradually improve the situation today.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This report ranges from well-intentioned to naive proposals to those that further jeopardise our security. An example of this may be the serious proposal to reintegrate Islamist returnees. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this initiative report which highlights the urgent need to take action against the radicalisation of young Europeans and their recruitment by terrorist organisations, in the wake of the attacks in Paris on 13 November 2015.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The biggest problem with Europe's internal security is the criminals who are EU citizens who have been involved in ISIL's activities in the Middle East and their like-minded associates. EU countries must, in their law, make travel a serious crime in order to plan or implement an act of terrorism. Foreign fighters who move to and from ISIL are foreign fighters who are returning from isil are a major security risk to Europe, as at some point some of these people will return to Europe with new ties, skills and radical extremist ideas. The time has come to stop looking past this problem, and these people cannot be allowed to disturb the peace of millions.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Terrorist acts are one of the most dangerous threats to every state, democracy and public security.  It should be noted that terrorist organisations are active in the EU, trying to expand by recruiting new members and treating EU citizens as their targets. It is therefore essential to pay particular attention to the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations.  In particular, action is needed to identify and punish not only terrorists, but also their recruiters, teachers, funders and perpetrators of attacks, as well as to ensure support for victims. A multilateral framework and a broad-ranging strategy are therefore needed. Prevention of radicalisation must ensure adequate protection of human rights. In addition, it is essential to ensure that measures such as the segregation of prisoners are applied only on a case-by-case basis and should be based on a court decision.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report escalates "counter-terrorism hysteria", focusing on the "radicalisation" that is at the heart of the EU's "counter-terrorism policy". Radicalism, in a sense linked to emancipation from urban ideology and the struggle for social progress and change, is transformed by the EU and civil political staff into synonymous with "terrorism" and "intolerance".  It is confirmed that the real objective of the "fight against terrorism" is not the criminal gangs of "jihadists" and other creations of the EU and its allies who equipped and supported them as instruments of their imperialist plans, but the labour movement that opposes capitalist barbarism.  In order to tackle "radicalisation" it is proposed to strengthen the already giant suppression network (Europol, SIS, VIS, "European Counter-Terrorism Centre") by new means: Europol's dedicated internet monitoring service, electronic passenger file (PNR), exchange of personal data between secret services, open telephone lines inviting workers to become moles, turning education into a propaganda instrument of EU "values" and teachers into traitors of "any worrying change in the behaviour" of pupils!  The people must, through their struggle, prevent the nightmarish plan that the EU and governments are preparing to suppress their rights and struggles.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 We adopted today the report on the prevention of the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations which provides concrete proposals for an integrated strategy to combat extremism, which should mainly be implemented on the internet, in prisons as well as through education and social inclusion.  The phenomenon of fighters travelling from Europe to different parts of the world to join jihad is not only amplified, but is expected to continue in the coming years. Moreover, the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, Beirut, Mali, Tunisia show that not only Europe is the target of terrorism, but the entire international community. The dissolution of Iraq, Syria and Libya has led to an outbreak of terrorism and radicalisation. In view of the increase in this phenomenon, the repressive measures are no longer sufficient. The most important thing is the radical fight against terrorists where they are trained. If the international community seeks to eradicate terrorism, there must be sincerity between us.We must turn to those who have equipped ISIS militarily, economically and politically.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un—checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Paris attacks and the tense situation in Brussels have shown that the terrorist threat in Europe is serious, real and dangerous. It is clear that the European Union must do more to ensure that barbaric acts such as those of 13 November can no longer occur. I am convinced that the only weapons at our disposal are greater coordination of European intelligence services to combat the radicalisation of European citizens and, on the other hand, actions aimed at better social inclusion of all those potentially marginalized and manipulated subjects of terrorist associations. It is for these reasons that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Given the recent times of turmoil, the focus of this report is of even greater importance than ever before. An estimated 5 000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations fighting in Iraq and Syria and it is crucial for us to take the precautions needed to prevent the radicalization and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organizations. Adopting a report on this issue reflects the commitment of the European Parliament to tackling radicalisation and taking further precautions against terrorist threats.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support Rachida Dati on creating environments to prevent that religion, an expression of an individuals search of gratefulness, plenitude and love is being used as an excuse for barbarism, regression and terrorism. It is also in our endeavours the chance to foster the creation of environments that would avoid radicalisation by encouraging constructive dialogue among different faiths and religions.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. According to data from 2012 to the end of 2014, about 250 nationals from our neighboring Bosnia and Herzegovina went to fight under the banner of ISIL in Syria and Iraq, and 51 nationals returned. Although a law has been in force in BiH since last year, according to which nationals are banned from foreign warfare, so far none of the BiH citizens have suffered as a result. Terrorism experts argue that ISIL should not manage followers. It is enough just to spread propaganda, and it does so through the media, especially social networks while terrorist cells organize themselves. Social networks have thus become a place for recruiting extremists and terrorists and arranging crimes, posting messages and spreading hatred. Following the Paris attacks, some groups announced that 900 profiles had been deleted from the social network Twitter after a list of ISIL-affiliated profiles was published.  It is necessary to raise awareness and through various campaigns prevent new joining extreme groups. Europe must act jointly through all possible mechanisms to prevent further spread of extremism and radicalisation. Internet companies are required to report and remove illegal content that incites violent extremism.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This Dati report shows an incredible political angelism and correctness. Indeed, it promotes ever more communitarianism and Europeanism to fight terrorism without questioning Schengen and the total opening of borders. Dogmas remain despite the seriousness of the situation. He bends to the cathodic catechism by stating that terrorism "cannot and should not be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization", or that the "diversity of Europe and its multicultural communities are an integral part of its social fabric" while it is obvious that multiculturalism leads to multi-conflict societies.  Moreover, the only response to radicalization and recruitment by terrorist organizations is the PNR, which concerns only air transport, when the terrorists of the Paris attacks took other means (especially the migrant route) to reach France from Syria.  The Europeanist torpor seems unwavering.  I have of course voted against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. I fully support the joint efforts of Member States to address the problem of radicalisation and recruitment of Union citizens by terrorist organisations in an innovative manner with this resolution. It is important to acknowledge that repressive measures are insufficient, that is, it is necessary to act proactively and preventively. In particular, I would refer to the part of the resolution highlighting the importance of education and social inclusion as a factor in integrating and preventing radicalisation. There is a need to insist on a greater role for education in fostering critical thinking, promoting non-discrimination and tolerance, teaching about the importance of human rights, as well as fostering different forms of study and educational exchanges that subject young people to different religious, ethnic and other groups. For this reason, I express my regret that the civic education program in Croatia has not fully come to life in implementation as originally conceived, since the principles set out in this resolution are precisely its foundation. I also believe that a very important part of the resolution that draws Member States' attention to the importance of training religious leaders to engage in the dissemination of the principles of non-discrimination and tolerance, which are part of their moral knowledge anyway.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ As the phenomenon of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens is a global phenomenon, urgent action is needed, not only at local or European level but internationally. I believe that active exchange of views and information, in particular national intelligence services and the adoption of preventive programmes for security, counter-terrorism and deradicalisation, are key to deterring the threats posed by terrorist groups. In this regard, cooperation with countries in the Middle East, North Africa and the Western Balkans and supporting their efforts to stop the movement of foreign fighters is important.  Specialist training programmes should be introduced for all actors in preventing radicalisation, in order to be able to detect any suspicious changes in human behaviour and to react appropriately by directing them against recruitment in terrorist organisations. It is certainly necessary to prevent the spread of hate speech online and to prevent radicalised prisoners from connecting in prisons. While the fight against terrorism is the responsibility of Member States, it should be stressed that terrorism should not be linked to any religion, nationality and civilisation.  Consequently, I agree with my colleague Dati's report, as a harmonised European approach is necessary to harmonise existing legislation in an area where the free movement of European citizens exists.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ First and foremost I would like to say that terrorism cannot be associated with any specific religion, nationality or civilization. I also will echo the report by saying that unless the spread of terrorism can be addressed, the risk of EU citizens joining extremist groups and returning home is something that needs to be stopped. To this end the Council should disclose its action plan and guidelines regarding the EU’s strategy for combatting recruitment and radicalisation. Another area that this needs to be addressed in is in our prison system. In doing so, we must continue to fully respect the human rights if inmates. Overall, to stop the spread of radicalisation we need to focus on the benefits of education and inclusion. With these aims we can help to end stem the flow of EU citizens to terrorist and extremist groups and promote peace.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the Paris attacks, the urgent need for coordinated action between Member States to prevent radicalisation and the fight against terrorism was highlighted.  In the non-binding draft resolution, Parliament supports a common EU strategy to combat extremism and the recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations, to be applied in particular on the web and prisons and through education and social inclusion. Other measures include confiscating passports, freezing financial assets, controlling potentially radicalised people returning to the EU and creating a "black list" of European jihadists and suspected jihadist terrorists.  The text recommends separating radicalised prisoners, strengthening intercultural dialogue and creating support systems, such as emergency numbers, through which family members and friends can get rapid help, for fear that someone is becoming radicalised or may be about to leave the EU to participate in a terrorist organisation. In order to combat terrorism, Europe must use all available resources and, above all, it must seek common answers. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I am pleased that Parliament has finally spoken out on the prevention of radicalisation. This is a long-term work that my colleague Rachida Dati has done over the last 10 months, and I would like to congratulate him on that. We have been able to introduce the necessary concepts and instruments. To combat the lies of terrorist networks, let us set up real deradicalisation centres, isolate radicalized individuals in prisons, create digitized strike forces to counter propaganda, empower the internet giants for the content they allow to be disseminated. In particular, I stress the PNR, the European database of personal data for air travellers, which could serve as databases of dangerous people. The left blocked it in 2013. The recent tragic events in France showed us that we were unfortunately right. The file has just been released, and negotiations will soon be concluded. Among Republicans, we will always remain committed to the fight against radicalization and terrorism.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against radicalisation of European citizens who are being recruited by terrorist organisations is, at first instance, the competence of the Member States. Nevertheless, the effectiveness of the strategy in this fight lacks a concerted and anchored European approach to prevention. In this context, the prevention of terrorism involves the prevention of radicalisation, in prisons, on the Internet and in the public space in general, through education and social inclusion which, in schools, promotes the critical spirit and promotion of non-discrimination and, outside these, reduces the risk of economic and geographical marginalisation, which are determinant in the radicalisation of alienated and excluded young people. On another plane, the exchange of information on terrorist radicalisation in Europe is also a vital tool for combating the radicalisation of European citizens. However, some Member States continue to say they are to cooperating in sensitive areas, such as the exchange of information and strategic information. I voted in favour of this report, hoping to see the strategy against radicalisation of citizens strengthened.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for yet more EU interference, legislation and agencies. The report included paragraphs such as the principle that ‘foreign fighters’ should be allowed to return to Europe; that national education systems and religious leaders should promote EU values; that the Commission should create EU guidelines for prisons, and also called for an EU definition of ‘hate speech’, which would no doubt mean anyone who criticise the EU or the free movement of people. One of the biggest issues is that the EU’s free movement of people is allowing terrorists and weapons to move freely across Europe un—checked. UKIP is not against individual countries working together and sharing intelligence to catch terrorists, but in order to protect our country we must leave the EU and reinstate sensible border controls with European countries to stop this open door immigration.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The fight against terrorism is a fight that the whole of Europe must wage. It is an ordeal that affects us all and calls for more European solidarity. Among the actions to be taken, the issue of preventing radicalization leading to terrorism is of importance. Let us stop talking about "foreign" fighters, they are Europeans who are attacking other Europeans. The terrorists who carried out these horrific attacks in Paris were French or Belgian. Let us also stop the dangerous amalgamations between Muslims and terrorists, on the one hand, but also between terrorists and refugees, they are the first victims of Daesh. It is to demonstrate their commitment to this fight that MEPs adopted this report today. Even if the text voted would have benefited from being more concise and targeted, it still results in a balanced whole, thanks to the influence of the European socialists. It presents a set of concrete proposals aimed at preventing radicalisation, including acting on the origins of this phenomenon; in prisons, on the internet and on social networks, recalling the fundamental role of the school and mobilizing all stakeholders involved.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The report by Rachida Dati on the prevention of radicalisation adopted this afternoon allowed MEPs to deliver a clear message: yes we are at war with Daesh and terrorism. And the dramatic attacks in Paris 13 days ago, the ones foiled in Brussels again this weekend, show that no one is immune to religious fanaticism. I voted for all the amendments that toughen the measures and sanctions taken against the various actors of terrorism: both recruiters and hate preachers, both jihadist fighters and sponsors, whether they are on European territory or about to enter. Europe must regain control of its borders. This requires an unwavering firmness towards "foreign fighters" who must be locked up in establishments adapted to their return to European soil. And by the expulsion of hate preachers who are rampant in Salafist mosques. Other more technical aspects of counter-terrorism need to be strengthened: the criminal responsibility of website providers and the need to thwart the encryption of communications by terrorist organizations. Because the safety of European citizens is not negotiable!

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The radicalisation of Europe's increasingly tempted young people is helping to strengthen the power of Daesh and poses an increasingly worrying threat to the safety of European citizens. It is for this reason that I have spoken in favour of the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, which proposes solutions at European level, the only one relevant to the internationalisation of terrorism. This text proposes to tackle the main factors of radicalisation, specifically jihadist propaganda sites, by strengthening surveillance on the Internet and by disabling recruitment platforms. In addition, prisons are also a breeding ground for this radicalization and should therefore be subject to specific measures to separate radicalized prisoners from other prisoners. With regard to surveillance inside and outside the Schengen area, the establishment of a European blacklist of radicalised, or suspected radicalised persons is recommended with the aim of promoting cooperation and exchange of information between Member States.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. Stopping radicalisation is an indispensable priority in the fight against terrorism. There is a need for stronger resources and better collaboration with the communities most affected by this phenomenon. The report also reminds us that the terrorist threat cannot be associated with the refugee crisis, especially since they are fleeing the same threat. Moreover, the terrorist attacks in Paris have highlighted many shortcomings. Intelligence services, the judiciary and the police not only need more personnel to function effectively, but their collaboration with the services of other European countries has become an emergency. The joint investigation teams within Europol or Eurojust need to be strengthened and given a substantial budget to improve cooperation. Environmentalists point out that mass surveillance (PNR in particular) is not a guarantee of effectiveness: it would be more appropriate to allocate these resources to strengthen the police and security forces so that they can effectively monitor already known suspects.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. The barbaric acts in Paris demonstrate the need for determined action to prevent radicalisation or recruitment of citizens by terrorist organizations. That is why I have approved this text which proposes key measures in this context. Of these, I stress in particular a first axis, that of prevention. It will be done in particular through education, integration or concrete support to relatives when they fear that one of their own will become radicalized or go to join a terrorist organization.  There is a second axis to emphasize: limiting the spread. In this respect, with regard to the internet, we know that it can convey the best and the worst, and therefore sometimes illegal content or promoting terrorism. It is absolutely necessary to act at this level and have that content erased. With regard to prisons and the supervision of radicalized prisoners, the necessary decisions must be taken to counter the spread of extremist ideas and contain radicalisation. All this obviously does not make us forget that more generally - and we are working on it - a comprehensive counter-terrorism strategy is needed, with coordinated actions, mandatory and systematic controls at external borders, a PNR more than ever indispensable, among others.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The fight against the radicalisation of European citizens remains the responsibility of the Member States. However, a concerted European approach is needed to effectively combat the threat posed by radicalised European citizens who can move freely on European territory. Today, more than 5000 European citizens who have left to fight in the ranks of terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria are estimated to be in the ranks of terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria. The aim of this report is to make recommendations for a European strategy to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens. Some of the measures include preventing violent extremism and terrorist radicalisation in prisons and on the Internet, preventing through education and social inclusion, strengthening the exchange of information and good practice at various levels, or dismantling terrorist networks. Respect for the fundamental rights and freedoms of European citizens will, however, always be a concern of the European Parliament.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level.
