We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The attacks in Paris once again highlighted the urgent need for coordinated action by Member States and the European Union to prevent radicalisation and better combat terrorism.  The resolution I supported presents concrete proposals: the establishment of a European blacklist of suspected jihadists and terrorist jihadists (Member States are asked to put any foreign fighter under judicial control); The need for mandatory and systematic checks at the EU's external borders; strengthening the exchange of information between national authorities and Europol in order to identify and monitor suspected terrorists, as well as confiscating their passports and freezing their financial assets; the need to strengthen intercultural dialogue in order to prevent marginalization and encourage integration.  Finally, in order to prevent the dissemination of hate messages and the apologies of terrorism on the Internet, the adopted text also provides for the immediate erasing of illegal content and calls on Member States to consider legal action, including criminal proceedings, against social networks and service providers who refuse to respond to an administrative or judicial request to delete illegal content or promote terrorism.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The unqualified barbaric acts of terrorism that have followed in recent months in Europe have led to a consequent increase in security measures. However, these attacks were not only used to echo the real alarm of terrorism currently in force, but to recall the importance of continuous strengthening and the need to speed up measures to prevent acts such as those recently in Paris. With the ultimate goal of eradicating the problem of terrorism, the European Union has taken important measures to this end. The report in question aims at strengthening some preventive measures concerning both the radicalisation of European citizens and the speeding up of European cooperation processes between Member States. Unfortunately, more than 5000 European citizens have defected to countries such as Syria or Iraq to thicken the war ranks of terrorist groups. Cooperation and exchange of information at European level is therefore essential to prevent the free movement of these citizens, between their countries of origin and the other members, whose motivation is to commit terrorist acts. In this way, European concertation on such a delicate matter is necessary - more than ever , which is why I approve this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The attacks in Paris on November 13th reminded us of how imminent the terrorist threat is; more than ever, we must show unity and solidarity to fight it.  The EU and the Member States must coordinate to fight terrorism. I have supported this report, which makes a series of concrete proposals.  Better coordination of Member States' actions will help stem radicalisation in prisons, call into question the criminal responsibility of internet giants or dry up the foreign funding needed to recruit European citizens. In order to ensure the safety of citizens, it is essential to ensure mandatory and systematic checks at the Union's external borders. The text also emphasizes the need to strengthen intercultural dialogue not only through education systems but also in disadvantaged neighbourhoods in order to encourage social integration.  Finally, I supported the request for a European NNP as soon as possible.  The European Parliament is sending a strong message and calling on the European institutions and Member States to coordinate their efforts and provide concrete responses to the resurgence of the terrorist threat.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary for the European Union to act urgently in the fight against terrorism in order to guarantee and protect the security of every European citizen.  I agree with the European Parliament's desire to adopt an inclusive approach with the aim of presenting a comprehensive analysis of the prevention of radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens, not forgetting the importance of protecting fundamental freedoms.  The text, which has been in the works for some months now, has become particularly topical following the Attacks in Paris and their consequences.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because the text does not condemn terrorists with the necessary firmness, nor those who morally support the fundamentalism and violent actions that result from it.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted against this initiative because, despite efforts to reconcile the positions of the different groups, this initiative continues to focus more on the symptoms than on the problems that cause them. More weight is given to coercive and social control measures, which add to the problem of violent extremism that of the deterioration of our freedoms. As we set out among the seven urgent measures to combat terrorism that our delegation mailed to President Schulz, Vice-President Mogherini and all Members of the European Parliament, legal or police measures alone are not sufficient to solve the problem. The best way to combat extremism is to make people feel part of a cohesive society and cultivate economic and social opportunities in vulnerable communities, both in Europe and in the countries suffering from this phenomenon. Strategies that promote the cohesion and social inclusion of people from diverse cultural, ethnic and national backgrounds need to be strengthened, and in particular the role of education as the only way that can offer future alternatives to youth to steer them away from radicalism and violence.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report because it contains a number of positive ideas. We know from the past that extremism does not belong to a particular religion, ideology or population group, as some in this House would like us to believe. This report recognises the importance of participation and community engagement, based on trust, so that signals can be identified and identified in a timely manner without an entire community being considered suspicious. National security depends on local security, and local organizations need sufficient resources, as does the RAN network. We need to improve the use of our existing intelligence and strengthen agencies such as Europol. That is a much better investment than collecting flight passenger data (PNR), which I am not in favour of. I also express my concern about some of the proposals for tackling extremism on the internet. I want illegal material removed as soon as possible, but within a legal framework. Encryption is a means that can be both positive and negative. EU citizens recruited for violent extremism pose a danger both inside and outside our borders. Cooperation with third countries should be based on clear principles.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. This year alone, Europe has been repeatedly hit by terrorist acts. Most recently, with the horrific attack in Paris, it has become clear that we need to address the root of the problem, radicalisation.  Often the terrorists are European citizens who were born and raised here but who have been radicalised and recruited to commit atrocities. That practice needs to be stopped. That is why we support the report's message on combating radicalisation and recruitment.  However, we are far from in agreement with all the tools presented in the report. Despite this, we have chosen to support the report. Our position is that the EU should contribute where it brings European added value, for example through the sharing of best practices, police cooperation and, above all, PNR.  At the same time, however, we are opposed to the EU having to provide detailed regulation, for example on tackling radicalisation in prisons. Here we believe that the countries' own authorities know best how to deal with this problem.  But we agree that we must learn from each other in Europe, that we must stand together and that we must work together against this common evil. That is why we voted in favour of the report and because the signal from the European Parliament that we must cooperate on anti-radicalisation is important.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations since it is done from the outset without the will to go to the root of inequality, the absence of perspectives and alternatives, and xenophobia, which pushes young people into such positions, but simply aims to stigmatize entire groups. Counter-terrorism is not worth shortcuts, and that is just what this report seeks through the recommendation of populist measures. In addition, the work of European agencies such as Europol is enhanced, totally opaque to the scrutiny of citizens and institutions, and their ties to countries with little guarantee of respecting human rights such as the theocratic monarchies of the Persian Gulf are strengthened. They are also intended to cut rights and freedoms on the network, as it recommends the possibility of removing content from the internet without a prior court order. Another of my concerns concerns is the criminal, as it is committed to allowing the segregation of prisoners on the basis of their cultural origin. These, among others, are the main reasons why I voted against it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent serious terrorist attacks have reaffirmed the need to join forces to counter the radicalisation of young European citizens and their recruitment by terrorist criminal organisations.  The report adopted today by a large majority is the European Parliament's contribution to a complex debate that tragically dominates the international stage. Since terrorism does not stop at national borders, the European Union can and must play a decisive role in preventing radicalisation, in cooperation and in the exchange of information between Member States. It is estimated that as many as 5 000 Europeans have decided to join terrorist organisations. The time has come to give a European response to a common and global threat so that the current scenario does not take on an even more serious and dramatic tone. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report, in the hope that words will be voted on in concrete steps to ensure security and stability for our societies.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 We live times of great anguish and with an almost generalized feeling of insecurity. To prevent perennial loss of freedom, we must act now and establish rules that must be understood as temporary. It is from this perspective that I voted positively for this report. Action must now be put to achieve normality in terms of individual freedoms and clarity of action as quickly as possible. The future of Europe is not a stimulus to denunciation or the use of "blacklists". Unfortunately, at present, we will have to deal momentarily with these types of instruments.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it calls on the Commission to complete various tasks such as more EU propaganda in schools. I believe that the issue of radicalisation should be resolved by individual nation states and not the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Of course I understand that radicalisation of so-called ‘European fighters’ is an incredibly complex and dynamic issue and is based on countless socio-economic and political factors, both globally and locally. The increase of terrorism and radicalisation in recent years has coincided with an increase and upsurge of hate crime and hate speech, motivated by racism and intolerance. This report addresses many of the issues which are affecting these individuals who choose to go on to commit such heinous acts. Things as simple as addressing the need for a common definition for what constitutes a ‘foreign fighter’ would go a long way to address these problems. Allowing states to exchange information not only to find and capture these people, but also exchange best practice of exit and return checks and freezing citizens’ financial assets, in order to prevent them from taking part in terrorist activities where they could. And this is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I was in favour of the Dati report for a number of reasons. The radicalisation of European citizens poses a serious challenge to the European community. I very much welcome the inclusion in the final form of the report of many observations made by the shadow rapporteur of the EKR and, overall, this strategy for preventing radicalisation. The need to coordinate EUROPOL, EUROJUSTU and CEPOL is a prerequisite for preventing and detecting radicalisation, as is cooperation with Internet providers to stop radicalisation taking place on the Internet.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report states that more than 5 000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations and other military formations beyond the EU's borders, especially in the Middle East and North Africa region. I am concerned that the increase in population radicalisation in countries beyond the EU's borders affected by internal conflicts is also increasingly threatening the security situation of EU countries. I supported the resolution because I believe that, in the existing situation ( if it is not too late), it is necessary to focus on preventing radicalisation and eliminating the factors that condition it. Although the fight against terrorism and the prevention of radicalisation and the acquisition of European citizens by organisations fall primarily within the competence of the Member States, I support all EU activities that can suppress the manifestations of extremism and the process of radicalisation. I believe that only with an effective and rational approach will we achieve effective and effective law enforcement results in order to combat the cross-border threats posed by terrorism. However, I continue to consider it a priority to stop the trade in weapons of any kind, which currently pose the greatest threat to European citizens.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The topic of preventing radicalisation and recruiting European citizens into terrorist organisations would be important, even if there were no wave of migration and terrorist attacks. The European Parliament's report provides a comprehensive view and proposes solutions at both Member State and EU level. We must learn from the risks of a multicultural society, which are ghettos, excluded localities, poorly educated and unemployed generations of young people who do not have a life perspective. The great risk is, on the one hand, the proclamation of radical Islam in mosques in Europe and, on the other hand, the radicalisation of anti-Islam fighters also within Europe. In our report, we propose a number of practical measures against radicalisation in prisons, better control of the Internet as a platform for the rapid spread of terrorist propaganda, better education and work with vulnerable youth and parents. We also need more effective work by EUROPOL and EUROJUST, or better interconnection of internal and external security instruments. But none of this will be enough if there are more disappointed and frustrated young people who will easily prey on radical ideology. Every person seeks the meaning of his life, and this is also related to his spiritual need. Europe is built on Christian foundations, and we should not give up the spiritual wealth of our predecessors. What we need is a combination of freedom and responsibility, solidarity and security.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. It is known that to date more than 5000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations and other military formations. The recent terrorist attacks in France, Belgium, Tunisia and Copenhagen have clearly shown that the presence and movement of 'foreign' fighters, who are often EU citizens, on the territory of Europe and in the neighbourhood pose a threat to its security. The report sets out some good measures in the fight against terrorism and the prevention of radicalisation. As such, I can mention the definition of 'foreign' fighters, the improvement of information exchange measures, measures to prevent radicalisation on the Internet, a proactive policy for deradicalisation and integration, and measures to prevent violent extremism and radicalisation in prisons. All these grips are based on knowledge of complex and dynamic processes concerning terrorism and radicalisation. But they also want to prevent further stereotypes about religion that can lead to an escalation of hate crimes and hate speech that promote racism, xenophobia and intolerance. I believe that European cooperation is essential for the effective and effective exchange of information between law enforcement authorities in order to combat the cross-border nature and threats posed by terrorism, radicalisation and the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. I agree that a common European approach is necessary and will bring added value for coordination or harmonisation, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on preventing radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations, which addresses a very topical and urgent issue. Following the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, it is more necessary than ever to take coordinated action by the Member States and the European Union to prevent radicalisation in our communities and to combat the forms of extremism that develop, particularly in places of detention or on the Internet, focusing on education and social inclusion. Since 2012, more than 4 000 young Europeans have left for Syria to fight alongside Daesh, young people born, raised and radicalised in Europe. Against the phenomenon of 'foreign fighters', we propose the creation of a blacklist of jihadists and suspected jihadists, signalling the urgent need to give a common definition of 'foreign fighters' in order to be able to initiate criminal proceedings against them when they return to EU territory.  Although this resolution has been used to include security proposals, such as the mere strengthening of external border controls, as the Social Democratic Group we have focused on the real issue under discussion, which is to prevent the radicalisation of our young people and prevent them from becoming assassins of terrorist organisations such as Daesh.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Terrorism and violent extremism must not be linked to any religion, country or population alone. They are often an expression of a socio-economic context where low education and unequal distribution of wealth and opportunity are a breeding ground. Those who want to combat terrorism and radicalisation must tackle the roots of evil. We must also dare to question our trade relations (including arms trade!) with certain countries (Saudi Arabia).  Collecting more data about all people is not a solution. We're just making the haystack bigger. The screening of internet data can only be done in a clear legal context. It still doesn't exist. The report rightly calls for good cooperation between governments and Internet service providers with a view to removing illegal content.  We need to exchange good practice, support families so that they can identify and tackle radicalisation more quickly. Strengthening instruments, such as Europol, Eurojust and SIS, can lead to more efficient cooperation. You can't just fight fear with more security, especially if it comes at the expense of privacy. We must ensure that human rights are respected, and we must not confuse refugees with terrorists. Our basic values of democracy, freedom, equality and solidarity must be respected above all else.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The report lists various measures that should be taken at European level to combat terrorism. It is precisely the recent terrorist attacks in Paris that have highlighted the urgency of such measures. The report deals in particular with the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations and calls for an action plan on the part of the Commission. Among other things, the rapporteur highlights the problem that radicalisation often takes place in overcrowded prisons, which is why guidelines and training for staff and educational programmes for prisoners to prevent radicalisation in prisons are to be implemented here. Other areas of action include the fight against online recruitment, training in educational institutions, the need for an EU Directive on PNR and enhanced cooperation between law enforcement authorities in the Member States within existing systems. These include, for example, the Schengen Information System (SIS) and other platforms. As the proposed measures are aimed at safeguarding freedom and the rule of law in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Radicalism and extremism have their origins in frustration. Young people have come to feel like they don't have a life perspective. We can only change this by promoting employment growth, the quality of education and an open approach to discussing their problems.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the report on preventing radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens into terrorist organisations today, inter alia, because it brings new ideas that, if put into practice, will help to counter security threats on our territory. A large area in the report is devoted to preventing terrorist radicalisation on the Internet, because a substantial part of the indoctrination and recruitment process takes place here. While I am a proud supporter of freedom of expression, I agree with the statement that there should be the possibility of taking legal action against internet companies that refuse to comply with the legal authorities' request to remove illegal content from their internet platform, and that, as a last resort, such action can be regarded as aiding and abetting comparable criminal intent or negligence. In the wake of the recent Paris attacks, evil must be confronted on all fronts, always with the principle of legality at its side, but harshly and uncompromromously. For the same reason, I supported the idea of harmonising the definition of a crime in the case of online and offline hate speech, which radicals encourage others to disrespect and violate fundamental rights.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report because it reminds that Member States continue to have competences in the fight against radicalisation of EU citizens. Furthermore, I believe that a common approach to the EU is needed and that EU actions need to be effective in combating the threat of radicalising EU citizens who can move freely in the European Union. An estimated 5,000 EU citizens are fighting on the side of terrorist organisations in Iraq and Syria, with intelligence services warning of the high danger and challenge of returning them to the EU.  This report adopts eu recommendations and strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens and presents a thorough analysis and proposals that prevent online recruitment. The report proposes measures to be taken primarily through education and awareness campaigns, a warning mechanism and support for families.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which stresses the need for a common definition of ‘foreign fighters’ to permit criminal proceedings against them. It calls on EU Member States to share good practices with regard to exit and return checks and freezing citizens’ financial assets in order to prevent them from taking part in terrorist activities in conflict areas in third countries. I am firmly in favour of the proposed increase in exchange of information among Member States’ law enforcement bodies and EU agencies, a measure which is necessary in order to effectively combat terrorism.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. More than 5,000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations and other military units, in particular ISIS.  Accordingly, the aim of this proposal is to call on the Commission to put in place as soon as possible an action plan to implement and assess the EU strategy to combat radicalisation and terrorist recruitment. This can be done by sharing best practices and pooling skills in the European Union, assessing measures taken by Member States and working with third countries and international organisations, based on full respect for international human rights conventions. In order to keep the number of recruited citizens to a minimum, it is necessary to combat the strengthening of terrorist radicalisation in European prisons and online. Important factors in the fight against recruitment are disabling terrorist networks, fostering the exchange of good deradicalisation practices, strengthening links between the EU's internal and external security, and better sharing of information on terrorist radicalisation in Europe. I fully support this proposal because its objective is the safety of citizens, so all these measures should be taken in order for this goal to be achieved.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal and welcome the measures that serve to combat terrorism without restricting the freedom of innocent people.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. Following the attack on Charlie Hebdo earlier this year and following the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, we need an intensified, effective and unified fight against terrorism. All knowledge must be pooled in the European Union and best practices exchanged between Member States. We also need enhanced cooperation between the intelligence services of the various Member States and an enhanced Europol agency. By strengthening the system of exchange of judicial information and preventive cooperation in the field of terrorism, we will take a major step forward.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report 'Preventing radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens into terrorist organisations', the timeliness of which is clear but which was initiated by the Group of the European People's Party before the attacks in Paris. It must be said that this is not a legislative process and is therefore a contribution by the European Parliament to the debate on effective means of preventing radicalisation and means of responding to the activities of already radicalised persons. This is, in particular, an appeal to Member States with competences to respond to these dangers. New dangers, such as the use of the Internet for recruitment to terrorist organisations, need to be addressed in the context of a general debate on how best to ensure a sufficient level of security and freedoms.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Undoubtedly we are in favour of the need to immediately neutralize ISIS. But the report proposes many measures to suppress and limit civil liberties. The recommendations of our group to produce a report focusing on analysing the factors leading to violent extremism and putting forward substantive proposals for prevention have unfortunately proved fruitless.  The report, among other things, proposes measures such as strengthening the security forces (Europol), cooperation with third countries such as Saudi Arabia, where there is a massive human rights abuse at home, a demand for the "recruitment" of volunteers and officials to informants and increased controls on the internet leading to internet guardianship. We have therefore voted against the report, as the measures proposed are directed against democracy, freedom and human rights. A real war on terrorism and violent extremism will be one that will, on the one hand, dismantle Euro-Atlantic support for armed fundamentalist groups, while on the other hand it will address the political and socio-economic factors that lead to social impoverishment and marginalisation, causing anger and indignation among the Muslim world.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Preventing the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by extremist/fundamentalist organisations must also include direct action actions. The assumption that Europe marginalises multicultural communities means that we accept that we are wrong, and not all those who, as guests, do not comply with the laws and do not respect the morals and traditions of the societies in which they wish to join. The Schengen Treaty is problematic, and open border policy and mass migration cause social disorder and pose a security threat. The report does not adopt enforced solutions, such as closing internal borders and fully restoring border controls at national level. Finally, instead of stopping all cooperation, all aid and imposing sanctions on Turkey, which feeds immigration, gains from traffickers and supports ISIS, the report proposes to strengthen cooperation with it.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report because, because of the serious security challenge facing the EU as a result of the recent terrorist attacks, I consider it not only to be extremely topical, but also thorough, revealing all the essential sides of the subject. I agree that the EU can only meet this challenge in a uniform way, with prevention at the heart of it.  In particular, I consider it crucial to prevent the radicalisation of young people and, in my political activity, I have always called for restrictions on extremist, xenophobe, anti-Semitic, anti-minority, undemocratic content on the Internet and on media channels and to counteract their influence in education. (As a Hungarian MEMBER, I am particularly sensitive to these aspects, as extremist views are also having an impact in my own country, while the government itself is spreading anti-foreigner rhetoric rather than effectively preventing it, even linking the refugee crisis to terrorism.)  With regard to the possibilities for improving EU cooperation, I consider it a virtue of the report to point out the importance of closer exchange of information within the EU and better cooperation with third countries. I also consider it an important finding that combating terrorism and radicalisation should not mean the resuffing of European fundamental civil liberties principles.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The adoption by the European Parliament of a resolution to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations by such a large majority demonstrates parliament's unity in the fight against barbarism in our region and more. However, the measures proposed in the EP report must be implemented as soon as possible in order to be effective.  Stopping radicalisation inside prisons, systematic checks at the Union's external borders or better and more frequent monitoring of social media are some of the methods proposed by the EP in the fight against radicalisation of European citizens. Now both the Member States and other EU institutions must implement the recommendations made by the EP, otherwise we may prove to be completely vulnerable in the face of increasing danger.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorism is one of the most prominent negative phenomena of our time. Beyond the root causes underlying its production, it is to be assumed that this phenomenon will increase in the coming period, under the influence of the destructive activities openly promoted by the so-called "Islamic State". Although the main competences for combating terrorism belong to the Member States, a coherent strategy within the Union is needed in order to stop the rise of this phenomenon. One of the directions in which it must be acted is to prevent violent extremism and terrorist radicalisation in prisons. Another direction is to prevent terrorist radicalisation in the virtual environment, which has an important influence towards mobilising terrorist militants.  The main tools for preventing radicalisation in society are the education system and social inclusion, which must be supported at European level. At the same time, however, Member States must improve the exchange of information on terrorist radicalisation on the continent and strengthen terrorist deterrent strecrecing instruments, such as border control, including among their own citizens. Member States' actions must also aim to break up terrorist cells, both within and in the EU's neighbourhood. For these reasons, this document should be adopted without delay.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. This is a text that has no legislative value or binding force. Nevertheless, we had to address the issue of radicalization. Indeed, 5,000 European citizens have joined terrorist organizations and other military formations, including the ranks of the Islamic State group, the al-Nusra Front and other organizations outside the European Union, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa regions. This phenomenon continues to accelerate to a considerable extent. It's time to act!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which sets out recommendations on the issue of preventing radicalisation of EU citizens leading to violent terrorism. Over the last year, Europe became the target of terrorist attacks led by its own citizens; I believe a concerted EU approach is needed as regards preventing and countering this radicalisation. In particular EU cooperation should be intensified as regards the exchange of sensitive information and I am in this respect in favour of finalising the EU PNR by the end of this year. EU cooperation also needs common standards and judicial control for terrorism prosecution as well as a harmonised approach to the definition as a criminal offence of hate speech. Lastly, as we know radicalisation is to a large extent happening through the Internet and social media, I find of utmost importance to intensify the cooperation between Internet companies and Member States for the identification of people involved in terrorist organisations.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Writing. The FDP in the EP supports the basic orientation of the report. However, we are opposed to the introduction of a PNR directive. That is why we voted against the report. The problem in Europe is not too few security services or insufficient lists of suspects. Rather, the problem lies in a lack of cooperation within the EU on counter-terrorism.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. We have just been hit in the heart of Europe by terrible attacks. These crimes are no longer perpetrated by individuals from third countries, but by European, indoctrinated and radicalised combatants It is the whole of our continent that is affected, we must act in a coordinated way at European level. The Dati proposal risked turning prisons into places of indoctrination, and we have largely amended its report to ensure that the multiple causes of radicalisation are properly taken into account. We call for the creation of a European Counter-Terrorism Centre, which could, for example, act against the spread of violent extremism on the internet. We particularly stress the need for a specific prevention policy: ambitious education and social integration policies and the ideological response are effective tools for preventing the radicalisation of young people. Beyond the security measures envisaged by Mrs Dati, we need a comprehensive strategy. Prevention, the preservation of our rights and freedoms must be integrated into our devices in order to build an effective long-term response against radicalisation.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. The recent events in Paris must serve as a warning that concrete and effective measures are needed to combat terrorism, but I firmly believe that it is our duty to work within the framework of the democratic values that we defend and that are under attack.  We need to improve and coordinate internationally the intelligence services that we have, to combat arms trafficking, to monitor and stop the funding of terrorist organisations. We also need to invest in education and social inclusion in order to prevent whole areas of our cities from becoming no man's land. Intercultural dialogue with different religious communities must be the basis of every measure. Terrorism is not the prerogative of a single religion or nationality.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. \u2012 The terrorist attacks in Paris have made it clear that the European Union must act in the fight against terrorism and to prevent the radicalisation of EU citizens. While the fight against radicalisation remains primarily a matter for the Member States, a coordinated European approach is needed.  It is estimated that more than 5 000 European citizens have travelled to Iraq and Syria with the aim of undergoing training by terrorist organisations. This poses a real security threat to the whole of Europe.  Punitive measures alone are no longer sufficient. The EU needs a new strategy based on prevention. As this report focuses on a proactive approach to the radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations, I voted in favour of it as a member of the FIDESZ people's party delegation.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. Ms Dati included in her report important postulates for European security, which I voted for. She said that European action was needed to prevent the radicalisation and crackdown on European citizens by terrorist organisations. These actions are needed to stop this intensifying phenomenon, to stop the exodus of European citizens into conflict zones, to stop the radicalisation of the local community and to prevent other acts of terrorism. In addition, the preparation of an action plan to implement and evaluate the EU strategy in the fight against terrorism must be a priority, on the basis of the exchange of good practices and the harmonisation of competences within the European Union, the evaluation of the measures adopted by the Member States, with full respect for international human rights conventions and a multi-pronged approach.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report proposing solutions to cross-border and European Union-wide problems on countering radicalisation and recruiting European citizens to terrorist organisations.  Indeed, the recent terrorist attacks in Paris clearly show that better cooperation is needed between the Member States of the European Union, but also between other bodies such as EUROPOL, CEPOL and EUROJUST to prevent and detect the radicalisation of European citizens. In my view, this attack fully confirms the assumption that European citizens who have gone on training in Syria are returning to Europe in large numbers with the aim of carrying out terrorist attacks.  I therefore support the call for the European Parliament to adopt passenger data records as soon as possible, which should be a new effective measure in the fight against crime and terrorism. I also believe that we must not only focus on preventing radicalised citizens from returning to Europe, but we must stop their recruitment and radicalisation at the outset, and we could achieve this by implementing recommended strategies to prevent radicalisation in prisons and by preventing them through education and social inclusion, as well as by combating the spread of propaganda material for radicalisation online.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations because I believe that radicalisation and extremism must be vigorously resisted through various measures, including through tightened external border controls, rapid and effective exchange of information between Member States, online and prison prevention, and social inclusion and education of those groups most susceptible to such extremism.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ The report contains many important recommendations. We need to support programs to counter radicalising of youth and to promote tolerance and exchange of best practices in this area. We need to fight hate speech in Internet and ensure responsible approach of media to hate speech in their materials and in commentaries posted online. We need also to foster training and cooperation of religious leaders who are moulding public opinion and may prevent incitement to hatred and violent extremism in places of worship.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this initiative because, despite efforts to reconcile the positions of the different groups, this initiative continues to focus more on the symptoms than on the problems that cause them. More weight is given to coercive and social control measures, which add to the problem of violent extremism that of the deterioration of our freedoms. As we set out among the seven urgent measures to combat terrorism that our delegation mailed to President Schulz, Vice-President Mogherini and all Members of the European Parliament, legal or police measures alone are not sufficient to solve the problem. The best way to combat extremism is to make people feel part of a cohesive society and cultivate economic and social opportunities in vulnerable communities, both in Europe and in the countries suffering from this phenomenon. Strategies that promote the cohesion and social inclusion of people from diverse cultural, ethnic and national backgrounds need to be strengthened, and in particular the role of education as the only way that can offer future alternatives to youth to steer them away from radicalism and violence.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report lists various measures that should be taken at European level to combat terrorism. It is precisely the recent terrorist attacks in Paris that have highlighted the urgency of such measures. The report deals in particular with the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens by terrorist organisations and calls for an action plan on the part of the Commission. Among other things, the rapporteur highlights the problem that radicalisation often takes place in overcrowded prisons, which is why guidelines and training for staff and educational programmes for prisoners to prevent radicalisation in prisons are to be implemented here. Other areas of action include the fight against online recruitment, training in educational institutions, the need for an EU Directive on PNR and enhanced cooperation between law enforcement authorities in the Member States within existing systems. These include, for example, the Schengen Information System (SIS) and other platforms. As the proposed measures are aimed at safeguarding freedom and the rule of law in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The recent brutal terrorist attacks in Paris have confirmed once again the urgency of this security situation and threats coming from inside our Member States. The issue of European foreign fighters going to Syria and coming back is now obvious to everybody and cannot be ignored. On the contrary, all Member States authorities must act. At EU level we must implement and finally create a European PNR system. It should be a mandatory system with automatic exchange of information. I am also in favour of foreign fighters who have gone to Syria to fight being deprived of their nationality if they return to Europe.  It is essential to control social media such as Twitter and Facebook in order to better understand their communication and recruiting strategies.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is extremely politically correct, communitarian and Europeanist. It does not involve Schengen and open borders. Some examples: Paragraph 1: "emphasizes that terrorism cannot and should not be associated with any religion, nationality or civilization". Paragraph 28: "underlines that Europe's diversity and multicultural communities are an integral part of its social fabric, and that they are an essential cultural asset." Paragraph 38: "reaffirms its commitment to work towards the completion of an EU Directive on Passenger Records (PNR) by the end of 2015". I therefore vote against this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Radicalization is a concept used to describe the phenomenon by which certain people embrace views, views and intolerant ideas that could lead to violent extremism. In recent years more than 5,000 European citizens have joined terrorist organisations and other military formations, such as the Islamic State organisation and others outside the European Union, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa region, and this phenomenon is taking on a considerable scale. Recent terrorist attacks in France, Belgium and Copenhagen highlight the security threat posed by the presence of these radicalised people, who are often EU citizens. There are already a number of instruments in Place in Europe to deal with the radicalisation of European citizens, and in this context the EU and its Member States should make full use of these instruments and try to strengthen them in order to respond to the current challenges to the security of States. In this respect, it is necessary to cooperation between Member States in sensitive areas, such as the exchange of secret information, as well as to establish joint action to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. The report underlines all these issues and I therefore voted in favour of it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight against terrorism, the prevention of radicalisation of European citizens and the recruitment of terrorist organisations remain primarily the responsibility of the Member States. However, European cooperation is essential for the effective and effective exchange of information between law enforcement authorities in order to combat terrorist threats of a cross-border nature. A coordinated European approach is therefore needed, which adds value to the compatibility and, where appropriate, coordination of existing legislation in areas where european citizens free movement, as well as in the prevention and prevention of terrorism. The fight against trafficking in firearms should be a priority for the Union in the fight against serious and organised international crime. That is why I supported the report.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in the territory of some Member States of the Union show that the European Union must act urgently in the field of combating terrorism and preventing the radicalisation of European citizens. Radicalization is a complex phenomenon that is based on a number of global, sociological and political factors. Today, more than 5,000 European citizens are considered to be foreign, radicalised fighters who have joined terrorist organisations. When we talk about radicalisation, we need to have an overview of the factors that contributed to radicalisation. It is a huge challenge to understand why these citizens have chosen this path because the causes of radicalisation can be both socio-economic, ideological, personal and psychological and, for this reason, radicalisation must be understood in the context of the situation of each individual concerned. The European Parliament's report addresses radicalisation in detail, calling, among other things, for the establishment of an action plan for the implementation and evaluation of the EU strategy to combat radicalisation and recruitment for terrorist purposes. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted against this initiative because, despite efforts to reconcile the positions of the different groups, this initiative continues to focus more on the symptoms than on the problems that cause them. More weight is given to coercive and social control measures, which add to the problem of violent extremism that of the deterioration of our freedoms. As we set out among the seven urgent measures to combat terrorism that our delegation mailed to President Schulz, Vice-President Mogherini and all Members of the European Parliament, legal or police measures alone are not sufficient to solve the problem. The best way to combat extremism is to make people feel part of a cohesive society and cultivate economic and social opportunities in vulnerable communities, both in Europe and in the countries suffering from this phenomenon. Strategies that promote the cohesion and social inclusion of people from diverse cultural, ethnic and national backgrounds need to be strengthened, and in particular the role of education as the only way that can offer future alternatives to youth to steer them away from radicalism and violence.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations because I believe it is extremely important to cope with this issue, in order to prevent unwanted consequences that could follow in the future. Radicalisation has become a term used to describe the phenomenon of people embracing intolerant opinions, views and ideas which could lead to violent extremism and the resolution sets out concrete proposals for a comprehensive strategy to tackle extremism, to be applied in particular in prisons, online and through education and social inclusion. The important part of the resolution is the chapter about Preventing radicalisation through education and social inclusion where we also called on the Commission to support Member States in carrying out a communication campaign to raise the awareness of young people and of supervisory staff as regards issues of radicalisation and encouraged the establishment of close cooperation between all civil society actors at national and local level, and of greater cooperation between actors on the ground, such as associations and NGOs.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This report makes recommendations to develop a European strategy to prevent radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations by developing interesting proposals on internet recruitment, radicalisation in prisons, measures to be taken in education and citizen awareness campaigns, alert mechanisms, the need for exchanges of information between Member States and many other elements. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a timely exercise in what Europe can do to prevent European citizens from being radicalised, especially on the network, and recruited by terrorist organisations. We need to learn to intervene the contents of the network that encourage violent extremism; to also intervene the socialization of terror in prisons; to prevent not only arms trafficking, through these sophisticated means, but also the financing of such indoctrination; and freeze their assets, all at European level. We must learn to cooperate police to share information about those 5,000 Europeans who have entered and left after being trained for terrorism somewhere abroad. But we must also denounce that austerity and the collapse of education, inclusion and integration policies in particularly vulnerable marginalized and collective neighbourhoods have made many young Europeans willing to embark on this crazy spiral of destructive and self-destructive violence, and declare themselves willing not only to kill, but to die killing. This is the challenge we must solve. I hope that this report will give European added value to the terrible challenge that terrorism poses to Europe.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Written. I do not believe that the resolution is the ultimate solution to the question of how to prevent european citizens from being radicalised and recruited by terrorist organisations. The resolution contains both positive and negative calls. Some of the positives are that terrorism should not be associated with specific religions or nationalities, that data collection and other investigative measures must be carried out in accordance with the core values of EU law and international human rights standards, and that arms smuggling and illegal weapons must be combated. I voted against the call to finalise the Eu PNR Directive. It is more important that the individual police authorities of countries cooperate with each other and that we invest more resources in the ordinary police and security police work. The decisive deradicalisation work takes place on the ground and requires the efforts of municipalities, authorities and civil society.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations since it is done from the outset without the will to go to the root of inequality, the absence of perspectives and alternatives, and xenophobia, which pushes young people into such positions, but simply aims to stigmatize entire groups. Counter-terrorism is not worth shortcuts, and that is just what this report seeks through the recommendation of populist measures. In addition, the work of European agencies such as Europol is enhanced, totally opaque to the scrutiny of citizens and institutions, and their ties to countries with little guarantee of respecting human rights such as the theocratic monarchies of the Persian Gulf are strengthened. They are also intended to cut rights and freedoms on the network, as it recommends the possibility of removing content from the internet without a prior court order. Another of my concerns concerns is the criminal, as it is committed to allowing the segregation of prisoners on the basis of their cultural origin. These, among others, are the main reasons why I voted against it.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ After the appalling attacks in Paris, the need to prevent terrorist attacks of this nature recurring is undoubtedly critical. This cannot be achieved with an inadequate response at a European level. This report emphasises the necessity of creating a common framework for dealing with foreign fighters. The recent tragedies have brought into sharp relief the report’s recommendation that European law enforcement must cooperate more to effectively combat terrorism in all of its forms. Furthermore, to counter radicalisation in programmes, the separation of prisoners must be considered. The report also refers to radicalisation on the internet, which provides specific challenges given its global and cross-border nature. We need to prevent the internet being used to radicalise people across Europe by having a proper counter-radicalisation strategy that encompasses the internet. Only with a European approach can we solve this problem.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I support this proposal, which makes a number of recommendations to prevent radicalisation among our own European citizens. On 13 November 2015, there were horrific terrorist attacks in Paris by some of our own citizens. A more European coordinated approach is needed to combat the radicalisation that leads to such terror.  We need to move with our time and realize that radicalization often happens through the internet or social media. I have therefore chosen to take a stricter approach to internet companies so that such attacks can be better avoided in the future and that such terrorist organisations are not provided with a digital platform to recruit people.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in January 2015, Parliament addressed the issue of terrorist radicalisation of Europeans. I abstained on this report, which was debated after the deadly attacks in Paris, because, while it has positive elements, it focuses mainly, as in other areas, on security and repressive measures, the prevention aspect being weak and very vague. In addition, the resolution calls for the urgent adoption of the Air Passenger Data Directive, including intra-European flights. It also proposes that internet service providers become police assistants. Internet surveillance is necessary within a strictly limited framework, should not lead to confusion of roles and must remain under the control of the judge. The condemnation of people returning from Syria or Iraq cannot be done without regard to the reasons for their return and without taking into account the changing profiles of those who have left to join these areas. Repression is not enough, otherwise there is not even a need to talk about prevention. A large number of measures in different areas are needed, avoiding widespread stigma and suspicion.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The report proposes a set of separate measures, supposedly in the name of combating terrorism, which deliberately go around the root of the problem, not contributing to its solution, to increasing citizens' security or to a coherent strategy of cooperation between states that combat and, above all, prevent terrorism. On the contrary, this report supports the EU's deliberate strategy of censure of democratic freedom and individual freedoms, insisting on the pilgrim thesis of the false freedom-security dichotomy and supports a militaristic view of alleged combating terrorism which, rather than weakens, strengthens the logics of hatred and war.  Heinous crimes such as those committed in Paris, or as have been perpetrated in various places around the world for years, put the need for a peace policy in international relations and respect for international law, which puts an end to interference and aggression against sovereign states, particularly in the Middle East region, which have led to the resurgence of terrorist groups.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Effective preventive measures against terrorism are only marginal phenomena in this report. Basic causes and symptoms of radicalization are negated. The report scrapes past the real problem. I therefore reject this report.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Writing. I voted in favour of prevention, as some of the established politicians were finally pulled out of their multicultural dream world by the Paris attacks and seem to realize that they have brought not diversity and love, but social hardship and death with their open-door policies. Although not all points correspond to my political view, it is a step forward for the security of Europe's borders and for the internal security of all countries within the EU.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. This report simply misses the point. It deals with the radicalisation of EU citizens. In doing so, he navigates around the two real problems: firstly, the connection between Islam and terror and, secondly, the connection between constant military intervention around the Arabian Peninsula and its consequences. If you are silent from the beam in your eye, you don't have to swear by the sliver in your finger.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations. The terrorist attacks in Europe in 2015 highlighted the urgency with which the European Union needs to take action on combating terrorism and preventing the radicalisation of its citizens. I agree that the EU and the Member States should become more involved in preventing radicalisation, and of course a concerted EU approach is needed to be effective in combating the threat posed by radicalised EU citizens who may move freely around the European Union. The European Union has to adopt a new strategy based more on prevention. The aim of the report is to make recommendations on an EU strategy to prevent the radicalisation and recruitment of EU citizens.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the wake of the terrorist attacks that have affected Europe and the significant increase in the number of radically minded EU citizens, a project has been drafted to present the best ways to address this problem. One issue concerns the elimination of foreign fighters' travel within the EU. The recommendations address segregation in prisons, as well as the introduction of educational and community initiatives. International cooperation in the EU in the fight against terrorism, exchange of practices that will help to tackle radicalisation on a global scale, is also important. Particular emphasis is to be placed on closer cooperation between Europol, CEPOL and Eurojust, which are to contribute to the prevention of radicalisation.  It is worth mentioning here the mission of internet companies. Together with uniformed services, they are tasked with detecting any online activities that are closely linked to radicalisation. Thanks to the compromises, which have achieved a significant number of amendments, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to maintain a Schengen area without border controls, in which citizens can move freely from one state to another (whether for work or as tourists), a unified European attitude is needed, because terrorists also have the same freedom of movement. The exchange of information between Member States is a first and fundamental prerequisite for success. The failure of states to anticipate the departure of recruited young people to war abroad, as well as their return, is often a vulnerability. The report calls for the adoption of the Passenger Name Record Directive, which Parliament has blocked in the past for fear of misuse of citizens' personal data and violation of their right to privacy. Specific measures also concern the separation of prisoners who have already been supporters of violent extremism or have gone through the recruitment of terrorist organisations, from other prisoners, stricter control of hate-inciting websites, the promotion of tools for the easy and rapid reporting of illegal content on the Internet, whether directly via the Internet or via the so-called 'hotline', a whole series of measures relating to education in schools, etc. The key to prevention, however, is, in my opinion, a family that has long been not taken into account by state policies at all.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The EU united must remedy any security deficit within it. Defending citizens' freedom and protecting them from any threat are fundamental values of the Republic and therefore our priority. Of course I voted in favour of this report, which lays down the conditions for effective prevention, but also for preventing the recruitment of European citizens to terrorist organisations.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I would also like to thank Mrs Dati for her excellent work with this report. The PPE Group has identified urgency in the fight against terrorism and the prevention of radicalisation for the European Union and for the Member States. Terrorism cannot be defeated unless all tentacles are addressed. The radicalisation of young Europeans is one of the biggest risks. We must use all the instruments in our hands to prevent radicalization. We have to put special focus on prisons and the net. The EU should work with internet companies and social media and urge them to remove illegal online content to prevent this plague from spreading.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on preventing radicalisation and the acquisition of European citizens by terrorist organisations. In the face of recent terrorist attacks, the European Union must face up to the question of what leads young people to sympathise with terrorist organisations, what are the roots of the departure of alarming numbers of young people to Syria and how we can prevent their radicalisation. In my opinion, the report maintained the necessary balance and encouraged the Member States, in particular, to cooperate with each other, to exchange good practices and policy coordination so as to proceed as effectively as possible on this issue, which significantly affects the whole of the European Union.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against terrorism needs real action, but above all it needs actions taken together. The events in Paris and the subsequent developments make us very clear how crucial a fight against European terrorism, European intelligence, a European army is. Only by sharing strength and information will we succeed in what is one of the most important challenges of our time. To continue to show division on this issue, as well as being ineffective, is against the principles of the European Union. More unity then, in order to be able to combat the terrorist threat and to move towards a real European Union.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The report proposes a set of separate measures, supposedly in the name of combating terrorism, which deliberately go around the root of the problem, not contributing to its solution, to increasing citizens' security or to a coherent strategy of cooperation between states that combat and, above all, prevent terrorism. On the contrary, this report supports the EU's deliberate strategy of ceding democratic freedom and individual freedoms, and supports a militaristic view of alleged combating terrorism which, rather than weakens, strengthens the logics of hatred and war.  The imposition of measures that are attentive to rights and freedoms, which always accompanies the increase in the escalation of militarization of international relations, of war and of interference and destabilization of sovereign states, feed the growth of racist, xenophobic and fascist forces, and their action of terror. Heinous crimes such as those committed in Paris, or as have been perpetrated in various places around the world for years, put the need for a peace policy in international relations and respect for international law, which puts an end to interference and aggression against sovereign states, particularly in the Middle East region, which have led to the resurgence of terrorist groups. We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations because I believe that it is reasonably recognised that coordinated European action to prevent new acts of terrorism is necessary to manage it. The proposed measures, such as the deletion of terrorist content from the internet, the exchange of all relevant information between Member States and Europol, as well as the withdrawal of travel documents, the freezing of finances, personal surveillance and the up-to-date maintenance of the 'black' list of jihadists, are the main measures relating at the moment to only around a few thousand, perhaps tens of thousands of European citizens.  The strategy for combating extremism, radicalisation and the recruitment of terrorists within the EU is only successful if it develops in parallel with the integration and social inclusion strategy of the young people who are the most vulnerable populations. The aim is to integrate this vulnerable population into society in the field of work and schooling, as well as leisure. If we do not equip young people with values and competences that will guarantee them "functional" inclusion in European society, we have fallen not only on the task of deradicalisation of young people, but also in building the EU. If we are not successful, we will face sustained cultural collisions, social and political tensions.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, I agree with the diagnosis of the report: instability in employment, low wages, indiscriminate outsourcing and, in general, precarious working conditions are factors that contribute decisively to increasing labour accidents and worsening the health of workers.  When a company does not do its safety duties, dramas such as that of fifty mercury-poisoned workers occur at the Asturian zinc factory in my region in Asturias. In the end, we pay for occupational diseases, all in the form of loss of productivity in our economies and higher expenditures for our national health and social security systems.  I also take the gender approach to this report because Europe needs global conciliation policies, rather than continuing to overexplod women with doubles and triple days.  And my vote for this report and its recommendations is positive, but I also want to make a warning to the European Socialists, because continuing to support austerity policies and TTE means continuing to delve into precariousness ...  (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is important and right that the EU has presented a new strategic framework for better health and safety for the more than 217 million workers for the period 2014 to 2020. For me, it was crucial that the strategic framework takes three points into account: the prevention of work-related diseases, which takes account of demographic change and better implements the existing rules. In my view, it is important that the more than 20 existing EU laws on health and safety at work are better implemented in the interests of workers. Only when we have succeeded in doing so can we think about new rules. After all, it is above all the companies that have to go along with it. It is mainly small and medium-sized enterprises that have to deal with the flood of regulations. In my view, the best practice examples for the implementation of the directives, as called for in the report, help here. However, I believe that, overall, we have found a good balance between health and safety at work in this report, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, the precariousness of employment relations, irregular rhythms, illegal days and the high rotation of contracts are the root cause of the increase in occupational accidents and diseases. Also in my country, Spain, after serious labour reforms. Quality employment and trade unions are crucial in risk prevention and the development of occupational health and safety strategies. We do not share a reduced social dialogue in the responsible European agency, EU-OSHA, or cuts in its resources. Having said that, I would like to refer specifically to endocrine disruptors. DEHP's authorization and willingness to eliminate occupational health from chemical risk regulations (REACH) are irresponsible acts. A serious public health crisis such as asbestos is being hatched, a crisis that will remain unresolved as long as it remains present in buildings and facilities in Europe. We call for a unified framework of protection and compensation for those affected by asbestos and occupational diseases such as silicosis. No economic interest can be above workers' rights.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, raising labour standards and the level of occupational health and safety is not just in the interest of workers but also in the interest of companies’ productivity and competitiveness, the sustainability of social security systems and of society at large. We need clear and efficient rules in the field of health and safety at work and rigorous application regardless of the size of employers. This does not preclude however, taking into account the specific situation and needs of micro and small enterprises and the provision of special assistance to them in the implantation of health and safety legislation. I also strongly agree with the call from the report that we should step up our measures against undeclared work, as it is undeclared workers that are most exposed to work-related accidents.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Schulze spoke from the heart of my heart in his explanation of vote. Nevertheless, this is yet another typical report, which, on the one hand, can only be accepted. All the things that have been mentioned are correct. Of course, we also want occupational health and safety and accident protection at work, and we naturally want to shape and standardise this at European level – that is all right. However, we must, of course, be careful not to create a flood of bureaucracy, which in the end, in the end, simply burdens small and micro-enterprises in particular. When we talk about best practice, it is not about best practice in terms of bureaucracy, but about best practice in terms of implementation. In the end, this is also my admonition to the relevant colleagues in the technical committee to take real care here that we do not obscure the good that we really want to achieve by means of a flood of bureaucracy. In the end, this makes us implausible and, in the end, would also encourage scepticism about the European Union.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We have just voted on the Strategic Framework on health and safety at work. For Sweden, for many years, through the provision of trade unions and national political decisions, we have taken many important steps in protecting workers, both in terms of occupational health and safety at work. The Swedish model, which I defend and stand up for, I do not want to see a watering down of the EU's way of sticking its fingers in this area as well. That is why I am also voting against this proposal. The EU has a constant desire to stick its fingers in increasingly national affairs. Unfortunately, it rarely gets for the better because a "one size fits all model" repeatedly turns out to be complete failures. If you are a Member State of the European Union, then you should also understand the importance of taking responsibility for their workers and their safety, without the EU having its pointer and pretending that it understands better than national governments do.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – The European Union's strategic framework on safety, health at work for the period 2014-2020 is a highly necessary document. This, incidentally, sets goals that our community must achieve by the end of this decade. A number of cases: social dialogue, fulfilment of legal obligations, improvement of working conditions, including in terms of psychological risks, ensuring equivalent competition, etc., etc. All this will result in a gradual reduction in the unemployment rate. This is important because every person is guaranteed the right to work and the right to good working conditions is guaranteed. And the paradox is that at this point in time in the world and in my country latvia there are also conditions where the quality of the work is low, but the result is high. We need to think about human well-being in the workplace. Support.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The strategic framework for health and safety at work deserves particular attention. The own-initiative report states that workers are entitled to the highest level of protection, regardless of the size of the undertaking, the Member State or the type of contract. We have tabled amendments, which have been incorporated into the final text, asking states and the Commission to encourage and develop standard procedures for simplifying OSH (health and safety at work) obligations for SMEs, stressing the need to take into account the well-being of workers in the context of the introduction of new technologies and working practices. We have also called for an increase in the financial resources for the removal of asbestos in all states. Unfortunately, the economic crisis and austerity policies have reduced the economic resources of businesses, especially SMEs, but this must under no circumstances lead to a reduction in OSH resources. Although there is still much to be done, this is a step towards greater protection for workers, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. U2012 The precariousness of employment relationships, irregular rhythms, illegal days and the high rotation of contracts are the fundamental cause of the increase in occupational accidents and diseases. That is why quality employment and trade unions are crucial in risk prevention and the development of occupational health and safety strategies. The rapporteur's report shares this position, as well as asking for the EU strategy to address such important challenges as the gender approach or ageing workforce, as well as specific risks such as endocrine disruptors or exposure to asbestos. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it aims to improve the Commission’s strategic framework on workplace health and safety by making it more robust and effective in terms of monitoring, implementation and compliance.  The report calls on the Commission to consolidate Member State strategies in consultation with social partners and the EU-OSHA Agency, to improve European-wide data collection on work-related diseases and to facilitate compliance with EU OSH legislation by micro and small to medium enterprises by promoting the exchange of best practices.  It also recognises the vital role that strong labour inspectorates play in enforcing health and safety at work and urges Member States to evaluate the capacity of their labour inspectorates to enforce OSH law. I support the raising of standards when it comes to workers’ rights across Europe through EU-wide instruments such as this.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
