text: Writing. Health and safety at work are an important fundamental interest of society. I believe that every worker, without exception, has the right to the highest level of health protection in the workplace. In concrete terms, the European Commission and the Member States should set indicative targets for reducing occupational diseases and accidents at work. That is why I support the report on the EU's strategic framework for health and safety at work 2014-2020.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The current European normative framework for improving and preventing risks from the working environment consists of 25 directives derived from a framework directive taken in 1989. The proliferation of legal texts shows the inanity and profound stupidity of the European project as it is conceived today.  The policy framework is aimed at simplifying legislation under REFIT, while Parliament wants to undertake new work to expand the forms of employment covered by this framework and to address new challenges. Thus, Parliament would like to do more to support SMEs for better implementation of the framework agreement on occupational health and safety, better monitoring its implementation, and to ensure that there are sufficient and trained labour inspection services. Together with my colleagues from the National Front and the ENL Group, we believe that undertaking new work to increase standards and strengthen control over their implementation does not appear to be the priority in the current context. A revision of the Detached Workers Directive must be the priority. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for more EU legislation, targets and funding. It is therefore natural for me, as an MEP elected with a mandate for leaving the European Union, to vote against such a report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it identifies several important challenges facing European employers and employees in this area. It is extremely important to address these challenges, which requires legislative and non-legislative initiatives.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to strengthen the safety and health of workers. Every year, more than 4 000 workers die as a result of accidents at work, and the number of fatal work-related diseases exceeds 150 000 each year. All workers, irrespective of the size of the employer, the Member State of employment or the nature of the employment contract under which they were hired, shall be entitled to the highest level of health and safety protection at work. I agree with the importance of improving the results of the implementation of the Member States' Strategic Framework for Health (MSP) in order to improve the health and safety situation at work and to ensure a level playing field for businesses. An ex-post evaluation of the practical implementation of the EU MSS Directives in the EU should be carried out. Action is needed to promote compliance of SMEs with the requirements and effective management of the MSS.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Every year, more than 4,000 workers die in the EU as a result of workplace accidents and more than 150,000 die from work-related illnesses. Through this report, which I supported, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to act decisively to protect workers from new cancer risks and psychological conditions such as burnout and stress. This includes re-examining the limits of exposure following new scientific knowledge, systematic monitoring and monitoring of workers subjected to psychological risks, including stress or burnout, or the fight against asbeste.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Union's strategic framework on occupational health and safety 2014-2020. It is a strategic framework that we must promote by emphasizing that all workers are entitled to the highest level of protection in terms of health and safety in the workplace, which must be guaranteed regardless of the size of the undertaking employing them, the type of work, their contract or the Member State in which they work. Specific labour strategies should be developed covering all forms of employment provided for in Union legislation in this area and having clearer and more efficient rules.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Since 1989, the principle of establishing standards to improve the prevention of risks related to the working environment has resulted in a European legislative framework comprising around 25 directives. Standards are multiplying in all possible areas. This complicates the application of national law and the practical implementation. The Commission wants to simplify legislation under REFIT, while Parliament wants to undertake new work to expand the forms of employment covered by this framework, and to deal with emerging risks such as psycho-social or musculoskeletal disorders. Parliament wants to support SMEs to promote the framework agreement on occupational health and safety or to ensure the training of labour inspection services. I believe that a simplification of the legislative framework is necessary, just as many work-related accidents affect unreported jobs, and it would then be more useful to revise the directive on seconded workers, for example.  I voted against this text because, although I believe that improving health and safety at work is important, we cannot continue to impose complex standards on businesses.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In order for the European labour market to be driven by fair and profitable competition and not the source of shameful and harmful social dumping, the rules on health and safety in the world of work must be harmonised and respected by all Member States, especially those in the East. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – In 2014 the Commission published the EU Strategic Framework on Occupational Health and Safety 2014-2020, which seeks to address three main challenges: further improving and simplifying existing standards, improving the prevention of work-related diseases taking into account new risks, and addressing ageing labour. But it lacks an ambitious agenda for establishing legislative proposals to improve the situation of workers in terms of existing and emerging risks in addition to occupational diseases. This report sets out Parliament's position on the new strategic framework, which calls on the Commission to submit concrete legislative proposals on better occupational health and safety and to turn its 'strategic framework' into a real strategy on occupational health and safety, so that once the planned review in 2016 has been carried out, more concrete legislative or non-legislative measures will be included in the framework , as well as application and execution tools. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's position on the EU strategic framework for safety and health at work proposed by the Commission for the period 2014-2020. In this strategy, the Commission identifies a number of important challenges faced by European employers and workers in the field of health and safety at work. Every year, more than 4 000 workers die as a result of accidents at work, and the number of fatal work-related diseases exceeds 150 000 each year. All workers, irrespective of the size of the employer, the Member State of employment or the nature of the employment contract under which they were hired, shall be entitled to the highest level of health and safety protection at work. As noted in the EU Strategic Framework on Safety and Health at Work, effective management of occupational safety and health for micro and small enterprises remains a challenge. Action is therefore necessary to promote compliance of these enterprises with the requirements and effective management of the safety and health of workers.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular to ensure the highest protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. Furthermore, the People's Party's position is that it is not possible to focus on a health problem, but to take into account a new generation of health risks. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ As rapporteur at FEMM, I am satisfied with the extent to which my report has been adopted. It is important to highlight the specific risks at work due to their physical and social diversity. I am sorry that the part of my report relating to maternity leave has not been adopted, but I am satisfied with the appreciation of muscular bone disease, stress, sexual harassment. I also highlighted the need to determine the maximum amount of toxins in the workplace at EU level.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because health and safety is not only crucial for employees but is also beneficial to the productivity of business. The economic crisis cannot be an excuse for cutting corners on safety in the workplace and this report reiterates that point. I particularly welcome the fact that this report highlights the health and safety risks of precarious employment. This type of work, which is becoming increasingly common, undermines existing occupational health and safety structures and can exclude workers from training and access to occupational health and safety services. Precarious work is also associated with mental stress due to job insecurity. This report calls on the Commission to eliminate this type of work. The reiteration of the need for labour inspections to ensure compliance with health and safety and to help to deter undeclared work is also to be welcomed.  Austerity policies in many EU countries have led to a reduction in the number of labour inspectors, which is to the detriment of worker’s rights, including their right to a safe and healthy working environment.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to health is a fundamental human right, recognised throughout Europe. Nevertheless, more than 4 000 people die each year in the Union as a result of accidents at work and the number of deaths caused by fatal occupational diseases exceeds 150 000 every year.  Although the protection of health and safety at work has made great progress over the last twenty years, there is still – especially in some countries – significant room for improvement to be achieved. Every human life is precious and every death at work is a loss for the whole of society: for this reason we must be courageous, to prevent bereaveve and accidents that fall on all of us, both morally and economically. The advantages, including economic ones, of advanced policies on health and safety at work have been well documented since the early 1990s: greater protection of workers' health and safety means a trend increase in productivity and workforce participation, as well as greater sustainability of public social security systems.  The economic costs of accidents at work and occupational diseases are all the greater when safety legislation is imprecise or poorly applied.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. 25 EU directives are already aimed at preventing risks related to the work environment. Since 1989, the Framework Directive has guaranteed Decent working conditions for European employees, but leaves it possible for Member States to grant them additional social gains. This type of harmonisation helps to combat social dumping by some Eastern European countries. However, introducing additional constraints and adopting a stricter regulatory framework does not seem to make sense, especially in times of economic crisis, as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) would suffer from this type of measure. In addition, the text calls for improving the prevention of accidents and occupational diseases at European level, which will lead to a proliferation of legislative measures that will complicate its transposition into national law and its practical application. Finally, the text proposes to integrate the regulatory framework new emerging risks such as psycho-social or musculoskeletal disorders. So I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Starting from one of the objectives of the European Union in terms of the fact that all workers are entitled to the highest level of protection for health and safety at work, we need to focus our attention on the need to promote a safe and healthy working environment for workers throughout the working cycle. I believe that there is a need for greater investment in risk prevention policies, as well as in promoting, developing and supporting the culture of prevention in terms of health and safety at work. This prevention, as well as increased attention to the cumulative effects of occupational risks, creates added value for workers and society as a whole. Given that the health and safety risks of workers are largely similar across the Union, the EU has the role of supporting Member States in addressing risks in an effective way and ensuring a level playing field across the EU. I voted in favour of the Report on the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020 because this framework is a concrete means of providing workers with safer working conditions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Precarious work is on the rise as new forms of work and new technologies have brought out new health and safety challenges in the workplace (OSH), which need to be addressed by the new EU strategy for 2014-20, through legislative and non-legislative initiatives.  While maintaining, with regard to the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity, a general reservation on new and more intrusive Community legislation, there is no doubt that OSH rules in several Member States (mainly the East) must be adapted to more advanced and stringent standards. In this respect, the Commission's action can have meaning and effectiveness. I am voting in favour.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. One of the European Union's priorities is to ensure a safe and healthy environment for workers working in the European Union. With this in mind, it is essential to develop a new eu policy framework for occupational health and safety. It is true that social policy remains a competence of the Member States. However, a European approach allows for a useful and necessary exchange of good practices in order to ensure that European citizens have the best possible working conditions. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the need to match the labour market to the challenges we are currently facing.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. There are many reasons why we should promote a safe and healthy working environment for all workers. Firstly, there are still more than 4 000 people who die every year as a result of accidents at work, while the number of deaths due to fatal occupational diseases exceeds 150 000 a year. In addition, the economic costs of accidents at work and occupational diseases are very high and immediate measures must therefore be taken at European level. Strong action must therefore be taken, not only to improve and strengthen the protections for workers provided for in the current regulatory framework. The text of the proposal strongly supports the protection of health and safety at work, and that is why I have chosen to vote for its acceptance.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to improve the strategic framework on health and safety, making it more robust and effective in terms of monitoring, implementation and compliance. It calls on the Commission to consolidate national country strategies in consultation with social partners and the EU-OSHA Agency and improve data collection on work related diseases.  The economic crisis has contributed to the aggravation of working conditions in some instances, including increases in reports of work-related stress. With the implementation of austerity policies, it is essential to discuss the ‘social’ cost of workplace accidents resulting from non-compliance by some employers who consider health and safety at work as a cost. Preventing occupational risks and promoting health and safety in the workplace are fundamental ways of maintaining better working environments.  As this report goes towards raising the standards of workers’ rights, I voted in favour.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this because employees should have the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace. The PPE was able to achieve points concerning new generation work-related risks they might face and require Member States to promote rehabilitation and reintegration measures for their older workforce.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the strategic framework, the Commission identifies a number of major challenges facing employers and workers in the field of safety and health at work.  The report she has drawn up on this subject is very positive and incorporates a good number of our requests, including the simplification of obligations for SMEs in this area, the encouragement of social dialogue in this area, the need to take into account the health and psychological well-being of workers in the context of the introduction of new technologies. It is also pointed out that the economic crisis and austerity policies have reduced the resources of companies, first and foremost SMEs, but that this must not, under any circumstances, lead to a reduction in resources allocated to health and safety at work. I certainly voted in favour.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – We spend most of our waking time at work, and yet far too many working environments and conditions are damaging to people’s physical and mental health. That is why we are calling on the Commission to present concrete legislative proposals regarding better health and safety at work. Equal opportunities for labour rights and public health care should be accessible to all. Women and vulnerable groups and citizens in rural areas are in particular need of improved coverage and working conditions, as health and safety indicators demonstrate.  The financial and economic crisis should not be used as an excuse to undermine occupational risk prevention policies as this approach is neither acceptable nor effective. Nor should the alleged administrative simplifications , contained in the REFIT programme lead to lower health and safety standards for workers. All workers, regardless of the size of their employer, the Member State of employment or the type of employment contract under which they are hired, have a right to the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace. The implementation, compliance and enforcement of health and safety provisions must be improved, new and emerging risks tackled and the fight against work-related diseases stepped up.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report rightly states that workers, including those in the public sector, are entitled to the highest level of protection with regard to health and safety at work, which must be ensured regardless of the size of the employer, the type of job, the underlying contract or the Member State of employment.  At the same time, the Commission is invited to develop work-specific strategies covering all forms of employment, under the EU regulatory framework on safety and health at work. The need for clear and effective rules in the field of THYS is stressed.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the EU strategic framework for health and safety at work in 2014-2020 addresses a particularly important issue. Every year more than 4000 workers in the European Union die in an accident at work, and occupational diseases have also risen sharply in recent years.  The resolution focuses on the right of workers to enjoy the highest level of protection with regard to health and safety at work and calls for concrete measures to reverse the effects of the economic crisis by helping businesses seeking to improve safety and health at work.  Particular reference is made in the report to the adverse effects of precarious employment on occupational health and safety. For all the above reasons I considered the resolution to be of particular importance and voted in favour of it.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure. Every year more than 4 000 people die as a result of accidents at work and the number of fatal occupational disease deaths exceeds 150 000 per year.  Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and, while we do not disase the considerable progress made in the field of health and safety at work over the years, workers are still exposed to serious health and safety risks. With this report, Parliament states that it is essential to take action to promote compliance with existing legislation, to ensure effective management of health and safety at work by SMEs and to increase the human and financial resources allocated to labour inspectorates so that they can carry out the tasks for which they are responsible.  Finally, the European Parliament stresses the need to improve the collection of comparable data on occupational diseases and exposures and that psychosocial risk factors, which are a growing problem for employers and workers across Europe, need to be addressed.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I would like to point out that more than 4 000 people die each year as a result of accidents at work and the number of fatal occupational deaths exceeds 150 000 a year. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and, while we are not disasing the considerable progress made in the field of health and safety at work, workers are still exposed to serious health and safety risks. In addition, as noted in the EU's OSH strategic framework, the effectiveness of workplace health and safety management remains a challenge for micro and small businesses to this day. That is why it is essential to take action to promote compliance with current legislation and effective management of health and safety at work by these companies. Finally, psychosocial risk factors, which are a growing problem for employers and workers across Europe and which are seen as a major challenge, must be addressed.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Every year, more than 4,000 workers die from accidents at work, and the number of occupational diseases with fatal outcomes amounts to more than 150,000 per year. Good working conditions that safeguard good physical and mental health are a fundamental right of workers and, although considerable progress has been made in the field of health and safety at work over the years, important risks to workers' health and safety persist. I believe it is vital to develop specific European strategies covering all forms of employment, and national strategies for health and safety at work should be to monitor progress in these areas in other Member States. On the other hand, a better level of implementation of these rules must persist and be demanding to comply with the rules by the working entities, and the work of national labour inspections is essential. Particular attention should be paid to new forms of employment as well as to new technologies that pose new challenges to health and safety at work.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Christensen's report because I agree that the prevention of occupational risks and the promotion of health and safety at work are essential tools for creating and maintaining healthier and safer working environments. All workers, regardless of the size of the undertaking in which they work, the Member State or the type of employment contract, are entitled to the highest level of protection in the workplace. Also because health and safety at work have a positive impact on the productivity and competitiveness of companies, as well as increasing the sustainability of social security systems.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This report stresses that employees have a right to the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace, and welcomes the Commission’s Communication on the EU Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. It is important to address new generation work-related risks such as psycho-social risks. Member States need to promote rehabilitation and reintegration measures for older workers and we need to consider concrete measures on work-related disorders. The employer also plays a role but is one of the stakeholders and measures should not involve just this stakeholder alone.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur points out that, regardless of the size of the company in which they work, the Member State of employment or the type of employment contract, all workers are entitled to the highest level of OSH protection. The effectiveness of workplace health and safety management remains a challenge for micro-enterprises and small businesses to this day. The level of implementation by Member States must be improved in order to improve the health and safety of workers and to ensure a level playing field for businesses. Precarious work is on the increase, while new forms of work and new technologies have brought out new challenges in the field of health and safety at work, which remain to be addressed. The Commission identifies and welcomes these extremely important challenges facing European employers and workers in OSH matters, and presupposes the launch of legislative and non-legislative initiatives, within the strategic framework on health and safety at work for the period 2014-2020.  I am voting in favour because this strategy can improve and guarantee protection in the field of safety and health at work.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. U2012 The precariousness of employment relationships, irregular rhythms, illegal days and the high rotation of contracts are the fundamental cause of the increase in occupational accidents and diseases. That is why quality employment and trade unions are crucial in risk prevention and the development of occupational health and safety strategies. The rapporteur's report shares this position, as well as asking for the EU strategy to address such important challenges as the gender approach or ageing workforce, as well as specific risks such as endocrine disruptors or exposure to asbestos. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Health and safety at work is a fundamental interest of society as well as an investment that positively affects the productivity and competitiveness of companies as well as enabling the population to work in good health.  Although considerable progress has been made in recent years in the field of health and safety at work, much can and must be done, especially in the risk areas indicated by the European Commission. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution calling on the Commission and the Member States to take all necessary measures to protect the health and safety of workers.  In particular, I believe that indicative targets for reducing occupational diseases and accidents at work should be developed and action must be taken in those sectors where workers are most at risk by ensuring stricter protection. In addition, I believe that we need to improve the exchange of good practices between Member States and develop instruments that make it easier for SMEs to comply with their obligations in the field of health and safety at work.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 4 000 workers die in accidents at work each year, and the number of work-related fatalities is more than 150 000 per year. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe, and although significant progress has been made over the years in the field of health and safety at work, there are still greater risks to the health and safety of workers. The report, which I voted in favour of and which responds to the Commission Communication on the EU Strategic Framework 'Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020', emphasises the highest level of protection of the health of employees and welcomes the relevant EU strategic framework, although it lacks specific legislation, such as the MSD Directive. The report points out that the economic crisis has exacerbated job insecurity and atypical employment rates, but that the importance of health and safety at work should not be lost in mind. Among other things, the report urges the Commission to prioritise sectors where workers are most at risk and to develop guidance and encourage the exchange of good practices with regard to the implementation of health and safety policies at work.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020 identified many important challenges facing European Union employees and employers, but it lacks an ambitious agenda for concrete legislative proposals to improve the situation of workers with regard to existing and new and emerging risks as well as work related diseases. Likewise it does not adequately address the implementation, compliance and enforcement of existing legislation. The own-initiative report deals with these issues, proposing also a new legislative initiative and the setting of binding targets to improve the occupational safety and health for workers. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that ensuring a level playing field across the EU and eliminating unfair competition and social dumping are crucial and I believe that labour inspectorates play a key role in ensuring respect for workers' right to a physically and mentally sound and sound working environment and in providing advice and guidance to employers , in particular SMEs and micro-enterprises. I also believe that Member States should be encouraged to comply with the ICO's labour inspection standards and guidelines, to ensure sufficient staff and resources at labour inspectorates and to improve training for labour inspectors, in line with the recommendation of the European Economic and Social Committee.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report highlights the importance of the right of workers to have the highest level of health and safety protection in the workplace. Expressing a positive view of the European Union's strategic framework for occupational health and safety for the period 2014-2020, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to make legislative proposals, particularly on musculoskeletal disorders. Together with my colleagues in the EPP group, we have also called for measures to deal with new labour risks, such as psychosocial risks. Considering that occupational health is an essential element for professional development, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the EU's occupational health and safety policy framework to strengthen worker protection. It is essential that the Eu strengthens its arsenal of instruments to combat unreported work, harassment and violence in the workplace and to combat, among other things, the causes of musculoskeletal disorders in the workplace.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Health and safety at work are fundamental rights in Europe and, while not disresuasing the considerable progress made over the years, workers are still exposed to serious risks.  In the strategic framework for 2014-2020, the European Commission has identified numerous and significant challenges for European employers and workers. Meeting these challenges is extremely important and requires legislative initiatives and not, that is why, in order to achieve the objective of ensuring a safe and healthy working environment for all European workers, further concrete measures should be included in the regulatory framework. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that all workers have the right to adequate levels of protection in the workplace.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. There are 160,000 deaths from occupational diseases and 4,000 deaths from work-related accidents in Europe every year.  Every worker must have a safe and healthy work environment. It is a fundamental right and it has an effect on the economy. Maintaining healthy workers has direct and measurable effects on productivity and also contributes to the sustainability of social security systems. The European Union must ensure an effective and simple occupational health and safety framework. This requires better application of existing rules, including helping small businesses to engage in a prevention approach.  If legislation needs to be simplified to eliminate unnecessary administrative burdens, this should not in any way lead to lower standards.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. Every year, more than 4,000 workers die from work-related accidents and more than 3 million are victims of serious accidents resulting in a work stoppage of more than 3 days. It is our role, as MEPs, to ensure a safe and healthy working environment for the 217 million workers in the Union. That is why I voted in favour of the Christensen report on the European Union's strategic framework for occupational health and safety.  This resolution reiterates the importance of occupational health and safety in achieving the EU's active ageing target, while stressing the importance of communication and information to ensure better enforcement of standards. I think it is important to have a comprehensive strategy on the subject of endocrine disruptors that have adverse effects on workers' health.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular the highest level of protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. Furthermore, the people's party's position is that it is not possible to focus on a health problem, but to take into account a new generation of health risks. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is an important aspect under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and in particular in the case of harassment in the workplace, the existing CXXV. tv. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. This report focuses on workplace injuries — which remain a major cause of death, approximately 4,000 deaths each year — and work-related fatal illnesses estimated at more than 150,000. As the labour market evolves, this paper focuses on new workplace hazards related to precariousness and net-economy occupations. It calls for monitoring and review of comparable data on psychosocial risk factors to assess exposure levels and prevent their occurrence. I have, of course, voted in favour of this report which shows that Europe is also social and that the harmonisation of policies also requires a better way for all workers in the Union.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular to ensure the highest protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. Furthermore, the People's Party's position is that it is not possible to focus on a health problem, but to take into account a new generation of health risks. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is an important aspect under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and in particular in the case of harassment in the workplace, the existing CXXV. tv. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report on the further introduction of standards for the prevention of risks related to the working environment is once again contributing to European regulatory inflation. By trying to add to the labour code again, and the pressure on employers, this report misses a reality that takes away a great deal of its effectiveness. The majority of workplace accidents occur in unreported employment. While reducing occupational risks is a relevant objective at European level, simplifying the legislative framework under REFIT is a top priority. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR will establish two key votes on the MSD Directive and the development of a programme of psychosocial risks. If both references are deleted I can support the report otherwise I will vote against the report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020, as I and my EQF colleagues are convinced that there is no need for such a framework and European OSH legislation.   I believe that the legal framework at national level is sufficiently comprehensive and clear, but I must point out that it has often been ignored. Therefore, we must focus on the implementation and compliance of labour safety rules by workers and employers, not on creating new and new frameworks that remain only on paper.   My position is that this is entirely within the remit of the national states, where there are already structures in place and in place to monitor compliance with health and safety at work.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The negative impact of precarious work on the health and safety of workers in Europe demonstrates the need to adopt a targeted approach to improving the health and safety situation of these workers, while it is imperative to improve the collection of comparable data on occupational diseases and exposure to dangerous factors and to identify good prevention practices.  We are voting in favour of this report as many workers are still exposed to asbestos in their workplace, so it is important to improve the protection of workers from exposure to carcinogens and mutagens, as well as from ergonomic risk factors, and new initiatives at EU level and better integration of THYM into other policy areas are needed.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular to ensure the highest protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is an important aspect under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and in particular in the case of harassment in the workplace, the existing CXXV. tv. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Every year more than 4,000 workers die from work accidents and the number of occupational diseases with fatal outcome swells to more than 150,000 per year. Labour is ageing in many Member States and demographic changes in Europe point to the need to promote a safe and healthy working environment for all workers throughout the life cycle.  In the EU Strategic Framework for 2014-2020 for health and safety at work, the Commission identifies several important challenges facing European employers and workers in the field of health and safety at work. The effectiveness of health management and safety at work remain a challenge for micro and small businesses. For this reason, action is essential to promote the effective compliance and management of health and safety at work by these companies. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I am opposed to an additional stacking of standards.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The report stresses the strategic importance of defining safety and health at work (ASS) policies for the period 2014-2020. Despite some more negative aspects, which we do not follow, such as the association of this strategic framework with the neoliberal EU 2020 strategy, the report contains other undoubtedly positive and important aspects.  The definition of ASS policies is defended and encouraged, linking them to undeclared work and false self-work, gender equality and combating harassment, the need for "balanced" working hours, or access to public health services — issues of the greatest relevance. Associated with the promotion of these measures is the promotion of adequate training and representation of workers in the formulation and supervision of ASS policies. These are reasons for our vote in favour.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. The EU's strategic framework on occupational health and safety takes a step forward in protecting workers' rights, and promotes increased protection of safety and health in the workplace. From our group, we believe in the importance of shielding these rights, as well as addressing potential next-generation diseases in a more specific way and tailored to the needs of the worker.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Union's strategic framework on health and safety at work 2014-2020, as I consider the latter weak in the management of new emerging risks and occupational diseases. The strategic framework touches on many issues which must not be overlooked, but which can be managed through existing laws.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. "For us Conservatives, it goes without saying that the EU Member States have effective legislation that guarantees everyone who works a good working environment. Each country has both a responsibility and an obligation to introduce satisfactory labour protection legislation, which includes everything from musculoskeletal disorders to bullying in the workplace. However, there is no added value to more common EU legislation in this area. On the other hand, it is good that Member States are coordinating their policies and exchanging experience with each other in order to improve national legislation.  We have therefore voted in favour of this, but against the demands made for more EUROPEAN legislation in this area.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of health and safety at work is at a very high level in Europe and has always been one of the main priorities in the european Commission's drafting of strict legislation. Nevertheless, 4 000 workers die every year as a result of an accident at work, and the number of fatalities is more than 150 000 every year, so the room for improvement is quite considerable here, as workers in the Member States of the European Union are ageing and demographic changes in population composition must also be reflected in the adopted Strategic Framework of the European Union in the field of health and safety at work for the period 2014-2020. I therefore welcome the fact that the European Commission has identified the burning problems faced by European employers and employees on a daily basis. In order to achieve the objective of a safe and healthy working environment for all European workers, additional concrete measures should be included in the framework. We must see reality, and it is the case that the labour market in Europe has changed in the last 20 years. Precarious employment is on the rise and new forms of employment, as well as new technologies, have created new challenges that need to be addressed urgently.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because there is no doubt that OSH rules need to be adapted to more advanced and stringent standards in several Member States. In this respect, the Commission's action can have meaning and effectiveness.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The negative impact of precarious work on the health and safety of workers in Europe demonstrates the need to adopt a targeted approach to improving the health and safety situation of these workers, while it is imperative to improve the collection of comparable data on occupational diseases and exposure to dangerous factors and to identify good prevention practices.  I am voting in favour of this report, as many workers are still exposed to asbestos in their workplace, so it is important to improve the protection of workers from exposure to carcinogens and mutagens, as well as from ergonomic risk factors, and new initiatives are needed at EU level and better integration of THY in other policy areas.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it broadly addresses the right issues and supports SMEs which bear the largest burden when it comes to this type of regulation.  It is about time the Commission and Parliament scrutinised legislation and simplified it when necessary. Changing outdated legislation is a step in the right direction in the battle against red tape for businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering that every year more than 4 000 workers die due to accidents at work and the number of fatal work-related diseases amounts to more than 150 000 on an annual basis, an EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work is very much needed.  The framework will allow the identification of many important challenges facing European employees and employers, but it still lacks, however, an ambitious agenda for concrete legislative proposals to improve the situation of workers with regard to existing and new and emerging risks as well as work-related diseases. I welcome the call for the Commission to revise Directive 2004/37/EC, adding more binding exposure limit values on the basis of scientific evidence; the call for a proposal for a comprehensive legal instrument on musculoskeletal disorders; the call for the development and implementation of a programme for systematic monitoring, managing and support for workers affected by psychological risks. The financial and economic crisis should not be used as an excuse to undermine occupational risk prevention policies as this approach is neither acceptable nor effective. Nor should alleged administrative simplifications lead to lower health and safety standards for workers.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular to ensure the highest protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is an important aspect under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and in particular in the case of harassment in the workplace, the existing CXXV. tv. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour, fully aware of the importance of improving and enforcing occupational health and safety legislation. Each year, more than 4,000 workers lose their lives due to workplace accidents, and the number of fatal work-related illnesses amounts to more than 150,000 each year. We must fight the causes that lead to the loss of life of European workers. It is necessary to improve the degree of implementation by Member States in order to improve the health and safety situation of workers and to ensure a level playing field for businesses.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to health is one of the fundamental rights of EU citizens. That is why it is unacceptable that thousands and thousands of deaths at work or from occupational diseases should occur every year. Not only that, all the studies confirm that greater safety at work is not only absolutely essential from an ethical point of view, but also economically advantageous, with an increase in productivity. With this report, therefore, we as a Parliament have set legislative and non-legislative priorities to be followed in order to ensure that citizens can finally work in conditions of complete safety.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU strategic framework on health and safety at work 2014-2020 because I strongly agree with the need to put in place stronger actions and legislative instruments to protect workers against new risks of cancer, from psychological diseases such as stress. We need a level playing field and a higher level of protection and safety at work for all workers wherever they work in the EU. This is required by established data, according to which more than 4 000 workers die from accidents at work and more than 150 000 deaths due to work-related diseases every year. I therefore supported the EP's demands, namely the revision of the directive on carcinogens and mutagens at work, with the addition of mandatory measures in relation to exposure limits on the basis of scientifically established values; the introduction of legal instruments in the field of musculoskeletal diseases, the development and implementation of a monitoring, management and support system for workers suffering from stress diseases, the development of national action plans for the safe removal of asbestos and the provision of common indicators for the protection and definition of work-related diseases.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. We need a set of measures to specifically reduce health risks in the workplace while promoting the health and safety of workers. A key to success is a clear distinction between work and private life. It is also important to proceed with the necessary sense of proportion. What we need is a fair distribution of the burden without over-regulation. In particular, for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are already heavily burdened by international competition and the economic crisis, new rules must be quick and easy to implement.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014 and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training and tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses. We have called for the Commission not to pursue a policy of regulation in the area of occupational health and safety as well as adopting a targeted approach to precarious employment and the negative effects that this has on occupational health and safety.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. ‒ More than 4 000 people die every year in the EU due to an accident at work and 150 000 suffer from work-related diseases. However 24 EU directives regulate health and safety at work which have been only partially implemented in Member States. A different approach is therefore needed to address this issue. It was with this in mind that I supported this report.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it sets specific objectives to be achieved. Safety at work cannot just be a statement, we need to act where the risks are greatest. Starting from the differences between countries to achieve high standards respected by all. To recognise that all too often in small companies the rules are less observed to protect workers in SMEs as well. You can't get sick working, you can't die at work. The key must be risk prevention.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is based on a broad and inclusive view of occupational health and safety and has incorporated many of the amendments of the GUE/NGL Group. Relevant aspects include the mention that all workers are entitled to the highest level of protection in the field of health and safety in the workplace, regardless of the size of the undertaking, the Member State or the type of employment contract.  At the same time, four key aspects included in the text make us vote in favour: (a) SMEs: the effectiveness of occupational health and safety management remains a challenge; it is essential to give them information and facilities; (b) labour inspections: increased staffing and resources are essential to carry out their functions: (c) social dialogue: it aims to move forward to provide training and promote the figure of health and safety representatives; (d) gender references: important references to ending stereotypes about the lower danger of work performed primarily by women.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014 and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training, tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures, as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020 because a large number of workers die due to accidents at work and the number of fatal work-related diseases amounts to more than 150 000 every single year! That must stop. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and even though considerable progress has been made in the area of occupational health and safety throughout the years, major risks to workers’ health and safety continue to exist. The economic costs of work-related injuries and illnesses are significant and the highly challenging nature of many new and emerging risks calls for immediate measures to be taken at EU level.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights in order to ensure the highest protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. The PEOPLE's Party position has taken a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new, under-established and impact-assessment legislation and to legislate in breach of member states' competences.  Furthermore, the People's Party's position is that it is not possible to focus on a health problem, but to take into account a new generation of health risks. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is an important aspect under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Thus, in line with the direction of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party, I supported the PP line in the final vote of the report.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Commission's report on health and safety at work is one of the most reactionary reports. In particular, it considers that new measures should be taken for R&D because life expectancy needs to be linked to work. It also includes this report in the context of simplification of European legislation (REFIT), for which there are already indications that it is a direct attack on social rights, since it will leave issues at the discretion of the Member States, but will be able to direct them through its economic policies and decisions.  Parliament's report is a very good own-initiative report, which places particular emphasis on support for small and medium-sized enterprises and integrates workers' trade unions into the consultation groups for R&D decisions at both state and company level.  Particularly important is the fact that a proposal which again links life expectancy with work has been removed, as well as the fact that a large number of amendments concerning the participation of workers and the risks at work from carcinogens have been included and adopted in the compromise amendments.  For the reason that the own-initiative report is much better than the Commission's report, we are voting in favour of it.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this report on the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020, which is a follow-up to the Commission Communication of last year. Although this is an area already heavily regulated by national and European legislation, more than 4 000 EU workers die due to accidents at work every year and those suffering from work-related diseases amount to more than 150 000 annually. We need a simplified framework that protects workers while keeping abreast of new and emerging risks and allows employers, particularly SMEs, to easily implement and enforce its provisions. I was pleased to support in particular provisions which called on the Commission to consider submitting a proposal for a legal act to combat harassment and violence at work, and on Member States to fully implement the Working Time Directive, and for employers and policymakers to ensure and facilitate a sound work-life balance in relation to domestic work and employees who also have care responsibilities in their private life.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because employees have a right to the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace. Every year more than 4 000 workers die due to accidents at work and the number of fatal work-related diseases contracted stands at 150 000 every single year. Even though much progress has been made over the years in regard to occupational health and safety, major risks to health and safety for workers continue to exist. The economic benefits of ambitious policies in the area of occupational health and safety are well documented and include higher productivity and labour force participation as well as increased sustainability of social security systems. The economic costs of work-related injuries and illnesses are significant and very costly.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. I voted against the Christensen report on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. In principle, the report contains a number of good points aimed at strengthening safety at work and reducing bureaucratic hurdles for small businesses. however, paragraph 26 calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive legal instrument on musculoskeletal disorders (MSE). Indeed, MSEs are some of the most common causes of disease in everyday work, which is why existing national regulations are in place. The ALFA rejects an EU regulation on the grounds of subsidiarity, because the bureaucratic burden of European legislation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, is not proportionate to the added value it creates. The ECR Group's attempt to remove MSE regulation from the text failed, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of mr Christensen's report because I believe that a good compromise has been reached during the negotiations and, as a result, we will vote on a text that addresses many of the important challenges facing employers in the field of OSH. I am particularly pleased that the report has room for two points. Firstly, attention has been drawn to the growing phenomenon of new and precarious forms of employment and their negative impact on the health and safety situation at work, including the mental health of workers. Secondly, I welcomed the fact that the report highlights the effectiveness of OSH management in micro and small enterprises. It is clear that the level of protection of their employees must be as high as in larger workplaces. However, we must be aware that it is more difficult for micro and small employers to comply with standards and requirements. I therefore believe that micro and small enterprises should be subject to specific supervision in this regard, and above all, it is important to ensure that OSH law, both European and national, is clear, transparent and easy to implement.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular to guarantee the highest level of health and safety at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action. Among other things, the adoption of a new Directive on musculoskeletal disorders and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because this position took a balanced and moderate approach. It does not wish to create new rules that are not sufficiently robust and without impact assessments and to legislate in breach of member states' competences. Furthermore, the People's Party's position is that it is not possible to focus on a health problem, but to take into account a new generation of health risks. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is important under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Thus, in the final vote on the report, I supported the People's Party line.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Labour colleagues, I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014. This is why we have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training. We need to tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures. We have called for the Commission to pursue a policy of regulation in the area of occupational health and safety as well as adopting a targeted approach to precarious employment and the negative effects that this has on occupational health and safety. The health and safety of pregnant women and women who have recently returned to the workplace after giving birth must also be paramount.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ In my own East of England constituency, the Health and Safety Executive reports that there were 11 workplace deaths in the last year, more than 8 000 workers suffered injury and no less than 125 100 people estimated to have been made ill through their work. It is surely right to seek to do everything possible to seek to avoid each and every one of these? Today’s report will save lives, prevent injuries and improve occupational health – through emphasising proper training, tackling disease caused by asbestos and other carcinogens and by implementing screening measures. It also provides an opportunity to give European Parliament backing to the British TUC’s ʽdying to workʼ campaign, which I helped receive in Brussels alongside fellow Labour MEPs.  Offering employment protection to those suffering from a terminal illness would give every person affected the choice of how to spend their final months and the peace of mind to know their job was protected and the future financial security of their family guaranteed. Let us stop people from dying but, where they do whilst still in the world of work, let us give them dignity in their final months.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ It is vital that in improving health and safety at work we encourage a culture of prevention. All workers, regardless of where they work, ought to expect their health and safety to be adequately protected. I welcome this report and voted in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial crisis should not be used as an excuse to undermine risk prevention policies in the workplace. The Commission and the Member States should improve the collection of reliable data on occupational diseases, exposures and risks across all sectors. The Commission must put forward concrete legislative proposals on health and safety at work and thus turn its 'strategic framework' into a real strategy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the 2014-2020 EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work Report, as it brings many necessary changes in this area. I believe that every employee has the right to the highest quality level of health care and safety in the workplace regardless of the country or company, and the type of work involved. Greater attention should certainly be paid to those sectors where workers are exposed to the greatest risks, so more detailed guidance on the implementation of OSH policies needs to be drawn up.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. At present, the European regulatory framework for improving and preventing risks related to the working environment is fragmented into 25 directives, under the aegis of a framework directive dating back to 1989. This particularist approach finds its limits during the transposition phase in the national law of the Member States, even more so when they are applied. The policy framework is aimed at simplifying legislation under REFIT, while Parliament wants to undertake new work to expand the forms of employment covered by this framework, and to address new challenges. Parliament wants to do more to support SMEs for better implementation of the framework agreement on occupational health and safety, better monitoring of its implementation, and ensuring that there are sufficient and trained labour inspection services. Our political group believes that undertaking new work to increase standards and strengthen control over their application does not appear to be the priority in the current context. We also note that a high proportion of workplace accidents affect people in unreported jobs. As such, a revision of the Seconded Workers Directive would be more useful. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – My colleagues and I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. We are not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ole Christensen's report on the 2014-2020 Occupational Health and Safety Framework. The aim is to ensure a high level of health and safety for all European workers. The report also takes into account the specific needs of SMEs in their compliance with these standards. I also support the implementation of a strategy on exposure to endocrine disruptors, which have adverse effects on workers' health. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to stress that all workers have the right to the highest possible level of health and safety protection in the workplace.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I do not agree with the report on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. While it remains important to prevent various problems in the workplace, particularly in matters of the health and safety of workers, this should remain the decision-making power of the individual Member States. Employment relations and actual working conditions vary widely between Member States. As a result, any attempt at regulation at EU level with consolidated rules would undoubtedly result in enormous overreach of competence.

name: Rikke-Louise KARLSSON
text: In writing. Once again, the Union wants to meddle in what is none of its business and risks undermining what our democracies have built very well without it. Indeed, the Scandinavian countries - I am thinking of my country, Denmark in particular - have been considered a social model for the whole world for a long time: 1.6% of our country's national wealth devoted to labour market policies alone with clear effects on the health of Danish workers (europe's best rates), a culture of dialogue and social compromise. , the ongoing training of employees, the inclusion of post-traumatic stress disorder in the list of occupational diseases eligible for compensation, etc. The time has come for the Brussels institutions to understand that its one-size-fits-all suits for twenty-eight different nations are not suitable for real Europe and systematically fail.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the strategy, as although considerable progress has been made in the area of occupational health and safety in the last number of years, much remains to be done. In the UK in the last year, 142 workers were killed at work, 611 000 injuries occurred, and there were half a million new cases of ill health brought on by work. It is shocking that Tory MEPs voted against EU action to protect workers. The EU is protecting UK workers from the Tories scrapping their rights and its fight for health and safety at work is one more reason why the people of Britain are better off in the EU.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The report advocates strengthening workers' rights, in particular to ensure the highest protection of health and working conditions at work. The report welcomes the Commission's strategic framework for 2014-2020, but expects further concrete and legal action, including the adoption of a new Musculoskeletal Disorder Directive and a revision of the Carcinogens Directive. I voted with the People's Party because the PP position took a balanced and moderate approach: it does not want to create new legislation that is not sufficiently well-founded and without impact assessments, and to legislate in breach of the competences of the Member States. Furthermore, the People's Party's position is that it is not possible to focus on a health problem, but to take into account a new generation of health risks. This includes the treatment of psychosocial disability, which is an important aspect under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and in particular in the case of harassment in the workplace, the existing CXXV. tv. Thus, in the final vote of the report, I also supported the PpE line.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: In writing. This report underlines the right of all workers to be protected in the area of occupational health and safety. Although the European Union's strategic framework includes a large number of important policy areas, additional measures must be taken to achieve a higher level of protection: improved implementation of EU targets at national level, increased support for SMEs in achieving these goals, increased participation by social partners and labour inspectors. , a recovery in the effects of the economic crisis and new forms of precarious work. For this reason, I voted for it.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The report must be supported, as the safety and health of workers are our common cause. Alarming statistics show how many victims of profit-making still have today. It is unacceptable that the governments of some countries are put their citizens at serious risk simply in order to further increase the profits of multinationals. It would also be helpful to ensure safety if a single regulation finally stated that workers cannot be employed until they die, but that, for example, after 35-40 years of employment, everyone of all ages is entitled to retire.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament sees the EU Programme on Safety and Health at Work as much needed to ensure equally high standards and improve working conditions across the EU. It should be noted that, according to statistics, cancer and chronic diseases, and workplace accidents account for the highest proportion of work-related deaths in the European Union. Member States must therefore pay greater attention to prevention in this particular area. Attention must be paid not only to the physical but also to the mental health of workers, as work-related stress and stress also have a significant impact on the efficiency of work and on the well-being of workers and their families and can have long-term consequences. It is also necessary to ensure that people with disabilities are integrated into the labour market by enabling safe work and taking due account of their needs.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. All workers have the right to the highest level of protection in the field of health and safety at work. Nevertheless, the figures shown in the report show an alarming situation, as more than 4 000 people die each year as a result of accidents at work, and the number of fatal occupational disease deaths exceeds 150 000 a year.  I agree with the call for concrete measures to deal with this emergency and I have decided to vote in favour, as one of our priorities must be to ensure a safe and healthy working environment for all European workers.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The Christensen report on occupational health and safety is a step in the right direction as we call for new legislation to limit risks and workplace-related harassment or violence. This was an opportunity for us who worked on the subject in the Committee on Employment to reintroduce the issue of musculoskeletal disorders, which had been under the reach of the Commission for too long, as well as taking into account the risks associated with new ways of working or the manipulation of new substances. For example, we ask for the texts to be updated on the limit values of carcinogens or mutagens, not only by revising the limit values of exposures, but also the "cocktail" effects (when different materials or molecules are manipulated and can combine). Finally, we call for the development of a comprehensive strategy against endocrine disruptors (substances that have an impact on our DNA). I therefore welcome the adoption of this report by a large majority of 536 votes to 95 and 28 abstentions.
