It is now up to the Commission to show the determination we have asked it to take on these new labour risks and to tackle others that have been identified for too long.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it unreasonably multiplies the standards imposed on companies.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. U2012 The precariousness of employment relationships, irregular rhythms, illegal days and the high rotation of contracts are the fundamental cause of the increase in occupational accidents and diseases. That is why quality employment and trade unions are crucial in risk prevention and the development of occupational health and safety strategies. The rapporteur's report shares this position, as well as asking for the EU strategy to address such important challenges as the gender approach or ageing workforce, as well as specific risks such as endocrine disruptors or exposure to asbestos. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I voted against the Christensen report on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. In principle, the report contains a number of good points aimed at strengthening safety at work and reducing bureaucratic hurdles for small businesses. However, paragraph 26 calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive legal instrument on musculoskeletal disorders (MSE). Indeed, MSEs are some of the most common causes of disease in everyday work, which is why existing national regulations are in place. The ALFA rejects an EU regulation on the grounds of subsidiarity, because the bureaucratic burden of European legislation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, is not proportionate to the added value it creates. The ECR Group's attempt to remove MSE regulation from the text failed, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am certainly against bullying in the workplace, but it is not up to the EU to address this.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. I supported representative Ole Christensen's report because I believe that every employee has the right to protect health in the workplace, which is one of the fundamental human rights. The EU Framework Strategy on Health and Safety at Work should advocate improving the prevention of workplace-related diseases, facilitating access to the workplace and adapted jobs for people with disabilities and chronic diseases.  It is also necessary to pay attention to the impact of workplace conditions on psychosocial health. I believe that working conditions in the Member States are not yet levelled and that it is necessary to insist on their equalisation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The right of all employed people to enjoy the highest health and safety at work is unquestionable. Despite the high level of legal protection that is in place, this is not always applied consistently.  Therefore, 4000 people die every year as a result of accidents at work and another 150 000 result in a deadly disease. These figures make it clear that new solutions and measures corresponding to current working conditions and, at the same time, threats to employees, must be constantly adopted, with emphasis on prevention. To this end, the institutions must be responsible for overseeing the performance of work in the exercise of their powers more consistently. They must place emphasis on taking preventive measures and must constantly educate their staff.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the EU strategic framework for health and safety at work in 2014-2020, because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Although we are in favour of improving occupational health and safety at national and European level, we can only regret the increase in standards imposed on companies. The two institutions (Parliament and Commission) have a different approach: the Commission wanted to simplify the framework and Parliament finally made it more complex, by expanding the forms of employment concerned, resulting in an unbalanced text. Rather than imposing unnecessary additional constraints on Member States, we prefer to vote against it.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. Every year more than 4 000 workers die due to accidents at work and the number of fatal work-related diseases amounts to more than 150 000 every single year. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and even though considerable progress has been made in the area of occupational health and safety throughout the years, major risks to workers’ health and safety continue to exist.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 All employees are entitled to the highest level of health and safety protection in the workplace and must be guaranteed regardless of the size of the company for which they work and the Member State in which they work.  Good health is a fundamental right in Europe. The European Union aims to prevent accidents at work and to ensure a safe and healthy working environment for all European workers. Further concrete measures should therefore be included in the regulatory framework.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on occupational safety and health, a subject that I, as a doctor, have addressed particularly during the last legislative period. It is clear that accidents at work and occupational diseases are a serious burden on society and must be prevented so that employees enjoy good health so that they can work until they retire properly. At the same time, new research on occupational diseases (e.g. likelihood of developing various diseases by age group), psychosocial risks such as workplace stress, negative effects of certain substances, e.g. asbestos or nanomaterials on human health, etc.) should be responding. In the report, we therefore call on the Commission to develop an employment strategy that would apply to all types of employment within the OSH regulatory framework and, together with the Member States, to set indicative targets for reducing occupational diseases and accidents at work, while respecting the latest peer-reviewed scientific knowledge. I fully agree with the content of the report, which is why I supported it in the vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Christensen's report aims to establish a strategic framework for safety at work in the period 2014-2012.  The issue of health and safety at work is a fundamental social issue and, for this reason, I am voting in favour of this project. The prevention of risks and accidents is, in fact, a strategy to protect a fundamental interest in society, considering that it could positively affect the productivity and competitiveness of companies, as well as increasing the sustainability of social security systems and allowing the population to work in good health until they reach the legal retirement age.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report exceeds the EU's competences on this issue in many areas. While it is important to address these problems, regulation at EU level with firm rules is the wrong way to go, as labour standards have also grown differently in the member states and are not always of equal importance. I therefore reject this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In the European Union, more than 4,000 workers die from work-related accidents each year and more than 3 million suffer serious accidents resulting in a work stoppage of more than 3 days. The report notes that "cancers are the leading cause of work-related mortality, followed by cardiovascular and respiratory diseases", demonstrating the deplorable quality of working conditions in the EU.  But the report is satisfied with hollow words calling for "a culture of mutual trust and learning encouraging employees to participate in the development of a healthy and safe working environment" while it is mainly a matter of enforcing "the application of occupational health and safety legislation in the Member States".  Finally, the report highlights the fundamental role of labour inspectors and states that it is important to "ensure that labour inspection services have sufficient staff and resources". Given their constantly declining numbers I allow myself some doubts as to the achievement of this goal. I vote for this report without any illusions as to its effects.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The policy framework in question is aimed at simplifying legislation under REFIT, while Parliament wants to undertake new work to expand the forms of employment covered by this framework. Parliament wants to do more to support SMEs for better implementation of the framework agreement on occupational health and safety, better monitoring of its implementation and better use of labour inspection. The National Front believes that undertaking new work to increase standards and strengthen control over their implementation does not appear to be the priority in the current context. It is also necessary to point out that a high proportion of work-related accidents affect people in unreported jobs. As such, a revision of the Seconded Workers Directive would be more useful. The member thus opposes this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU strategic framework for health and safety at work for 2014-2020. The number of workers who die every year from occupational accidents and the number of occupational diseases with fatal outcome is extremely worrying. The economic and social costs of accidents at work and occupational diseases need immediate action at EU level.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this draft report as it underlines employees’ rights to the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace, while stating more concrete legislative measures to be included in the EU Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Despite a large number of guidelines to ensure a healthy working environment for workers, we still count 4,000 fatal accidents at work each year and the number of fatal work-related illnesses continues to peak at 150,000 per year. The continuous evaluation and adjustment of risk prevention measures and the incitement to behavioural changes for all the actors involved in the work process therefore remains a priority.  At the same time, the labour market in Europe is undergoing major changes. People will work longer in the future, change jobs more often and build more flexibility into their careers. Ensuring well-being and health at work adds value to society as a whole and helps people to age in an active and healthy way. In this context, we must continue to take concrete preventive measures that maximize the risks of accidents and illnesses in workers.  In addition to continuing attention to tackling chronic work-related conditions, it is also important to carefully identify new challenges, such as psychological and social risks in the workplace, and to take preventive actions to achieve physically and mentally safe and healthy working environments for all European workers. Good health is, after all, a fundamental right in Europe and prevention remains the best approach.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Since good working conditions are a fundamental right of its citizens under the Charter of Rights of the European Union, I welcome the presentation of the EU Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. In particular, I join the need to address psychosocial risk factors, which are currently a growing problem for employers and employees across Europe. In fact, the economic crisis has led to an increase in job insecurity, which has also been reflected in the fact that, according to a Europe-wide survey, up to half of employees experience work-related stress on a daily basis, with around half of all missed working days related to it. Moreover, these absences are usually longer than those arising for other reasons. The costs entailed by this are estimated at national level in billions of euros. Case studies show that good management of health and safety at work leads to higher performance and profitability. Each euro invested in it will thus return up to EUR 2.2. In most countries, the cost of accidents and occupational diseases generally ranges from 2.6% to 3.8% of GDP.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to present concrete legislative proposals regarding better health and safety at work and to this end to turn its ‘strategic framework’ into a real strategy on health and safety at work. The financial and economic crisis should not be used as an excuse to undermine occupational risk prevention policies as this approach is neither acceptable nor effective. Nor should alleged administrative simplifications (REFIT) lead to lower health and safety standards for workers. All workers, regardless of the size of their employer, their Member State of employment or the type of employment contract under which they are hired, have a right to the highest level of protection regarding health and safety in the workplace. The implementation, compliance and enforcement of health and safety provisions must be improved, new and emerging risks tackled and the fight against work-related diseases stepped up.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 4 000 workers die in accidents at work each year, and the number of work-related fatalities is more than 150 000 per year.  The economic benefits of ambitious policies in the field of health and safety at work have been demonstrated and include productivity and labour market participation and increased sustainability of social security systems.  The Report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs argues that, since the economic costs of accidents and illnesses related to work are not only significant, but also involve significant challenges as carriers of many new and emerging risks, and that addressing these risks requires the use of legislative and non-legislative initiatives, immediate action at EU level should be taken and the EU strategy on health and safety at work 2014-2020 should be complemented by additional concrete measures. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Health and safety at work are essential for society, assuming beneficial investments in the productivity and competitiveness of companies, in addition to improving the sustainability of social security systems and enabling people to enjoy good health until retirement age. I support that the prevention of occupational risks, the promotion of health and safety and the protection of workers at work are essential factors for the improvement of working conditions and, consequently, for the protection of workers' health, favoring, in turn, socially and economically, workers and society in general. The European Union, in accordance with Article 153 TFEU, will support and supplement Member States' action in improving the working environment in order to protect the health and safety of workers. I believe that national strategies for health and safety at work, which should be in line with EU guidelines, are key and contribute to the progress made in this area in the Member States.   Unfortunately, the economic crisis has caused some labour instability and reduced business revenues and this situation cannot re-relegate the importance of health and safety to the background.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report relates to the strategic framework published last June by the Commission. This framework aims to improve the prevention of risks related to the work environment. It guarantees minimum working conditions in the EU, but leaves it possible for Member States to put in place stricter measures. This report aims to undertake new work to expand the forms of employment within this framework and to deal with emerging risks, such as psychosocial disorders, or the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive. Being resolutely against the fact that the Union is interfering in the labour legislation of the Member States (knowing that it is the main destructive force), and considering that the current context does not lend itself to the introduction of new standards to be useful to say the least theoretical, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for harmonization of occupational health and safety strategies in the European Union. This text reminds us that the number of fatal accidents or illnesses at work differs enormously between Member States. It calls for the Eu to have a strategy in place to ensure that as many people as possible can work in good health conditions.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly support this resolution, which is an inescapable battle of civilisation for us. It is, in fact, unacceptable that more than 4 000 people a year can die as a result of accidents at work and 150 000 people today as a result of diseases linked, with an irrefutable cause, to their working conditions.  The European Union is at the forefront of preventing these phenomena, which amount to EUR 2 million and EUR 160 million per year respectively. This does not alter the fact that the Commission must promptly and zealously follow the recommendations of this resolution on the revision of the directive on exposure to carcinogens, the creation of monitoring services for workers subject to psychological risks and the fight against social dumping.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I have not been able to vote for this report, but I fully support the position of the EPP Group and the French delegation to adopt this report. It reiterates the right of employees to the highest level of protection in occupational health and safety. However, any new proposal by the European Commission will have to be based on sound evaluations in order to avoid multiplying the requirements in this area, which could lead to their illegibility and thus have a negative impact on employees and businesses.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Every year more than 4 000 workers die due to accidents at work and the number of fatal work-related diseases amounts to more than 150 000 every single year. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and even though considerable progress has been made in the area of occupational health and safety throughout the years, major risks to workers’ health and safety continue to exist. I voted for this report that will improve the health and safety situation of workers and ensure a level playing field for businesses.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it makes a very accurate analysis of the needs for health and safety at work in the EU. The Commission's strategy in this area, coordinated with national strategies, should correctly ensure a high standard of health and safety at work for European citizens. It is a right that citizens have, but also an obligation on the part of employers, whether private or public, to ensure this standard. Unfortunately, in the context of the economic crisis, many companies, as well as the public sector, have had drastic cost cuts and redundancies. This has often led to situations where workload has become higher and, in some cases, more dangerous for remaining employees, which has put and endangers both human safety and health. The Commission and the Member States must work together to find a common approach to this problem, and I am referring in particular to the implementation of effective strategies to ensure a standard level of employee safety and health, with clear penalties for those who do not comply with this standard.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report on an EU strategic framework for health and safety at work makes labour inspectorates particularly crucial in the effective enforcement of health and safety legislation at work. I voted against this report because the regulation should be left to the Member States.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which reiterates the need to strengthen the European strategy on occupational health and safety. The economic crisis seems to justify budget cuts in these areas, while occupational health and safety risks are responsible for the increase in the number of workers in precarious situations. The report calls on the Commission to effectively combat the precarious work that plunges large numbers of European citizens into situations of instability and social isolation, and thus calls on it to report on the new diseases to which workers are exposed, particularly in the face of the development of new technologies. It also reiterates the importance of increasing inspections at work, fundamental tools for preventing precariousness, at a time when they are constantly declining under the Commission's austerity policy.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and, although significant progress has been made over the years in the field of health and safety at work, there are still major risks to the health and safety of workers. Further action is therefore needed at EU level and this is also the aim of the framework.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted. Each worker must be provided with safe and healthy working conditions. Citizens' health and working capacity are at the heart of the economic and social well-being of each country.  The problem of human safety at work is particularly acute and it is therefore necessary to establish clear and effective rules in the field of occupational safety and health in order to introduce stricter protection of workers. Legal regulation needs to be reduced, but not to reduce the level of safety and health at work. Particular attention must be paid to the safety and health of workers in small and medium-sized enterprises. The strategy must strike a balance between a high level of protection and the administrative burden on businesses. Workers' education, training in collective bargaining and agreements between the social partners are important tools to improve the safety and health situation at work. The importance of bullying and the fight against harassment and violence at work must be given particular attention to the identification of appropriate measures.  In order to implement the prevention of work-related diseases and new and emerging risks, Member States should make more efficient use of European funds.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The "cost" to be limited or else as an "investment with a positive effect on the productivity and competitiveness of companies" is treated as the health and safety of workers according to the relevant report discussed in the European Parliament and voted against by the European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece.  The report says defiantly that it is in the interests of companies to take safety measures, as otherwise they will have to pay costs for accidents at work and diseases. These security measures, moreover, cynically call for them to be such, that is to say cheap, that companies can meet their costs with European funding. Revealing is that the prevention of accidents at work is part of the strategy for "active and healthy ageing", namely to ensure that workers work until they are old enough, reducing the distance between retirement age and death. The conclusion is obvious: as long as the keys to the economy are taken by business groups, health and safety in the workplace will be sacrificed on the altar of their profitability. Workers need to demand safety and hygiene measures and the recruitment of permanent staff by organizing their fight for an economy and power that will be the criterion of popular needs, not capitalist gain.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is unacceptable that in times like these there are still too many workers who lose their lives in Europe in the performance of their duties. It is essential to guarantee every European worker maximum safety and protection of health and life. I therefore welcome the fact that the Eu ropean Union has decided to include rules and provisions in the legislation on safety at work which guarantee a higher level of safety at work for European citizens. I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. Cancers are the most common cause of work-related death, so we need to protect workers from the effects of carcinogens and mutagens. People must be guaranteed a safe and healthy working environment. An effective and strategic approach is needed to prevent occupational diseases and accidents and to pay greater attention to the combined effects of occupational risks, which creates added value for workers and society as a whole, and I therefore support this report, which calls on the Commission and the Members to develop appropriate policies on the ageing of the population. I believe that the regulatory framework for safety and health at work should also promote healthy ageing, and we can also contribute to achieving the objective of active and healthy ageing for all workers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Recent crises in the agricultural sector, disruptions caused by political crises, but also other known problems in the agriculture sector, in Croatia and other members of the European Union, have reduced the number of family farms leading to significant depopulation of rural space.  In these circumstances, public health institutions shall also be closed, reducing the availability of adequate public medical care and care for the rural area, both citizens and agricultural employees. Women in rural areas are particularly exposed to these negative trends, as they have more difficulty exercising their labour and health rights. They are often deprived of basic healthcare and the availability of specialist cancer screenings. I welcome this report precisely because it recognises the need to protect workers' rights and equal access to public health services for all its citizens, regardless of where they live and work. In particular, the report shall take into account the situation of a woman in rural areas and other vulnerable groups of citizens who need sufficient protection at work and the necessary medical care available in the event of an accident at work.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report relates to the strategic framework published last June by the Commission. This framework aims to improve the prevention of risks related to the working environment. It guarantees minimum working conditions in the EU, but leaves it possible for Member States to put in place stricter measures. This report aims to undertake new work to expand the forms of employment within this framework and to deal with emerging risks, such as psychosocial disorders, or the revision of the Maternity Leave Directive.  Being resolutely against the fact that the Union is interfering in the labour legislation of the Member States (knowing that it is the main destructive force), and considering that the current context does not lend itself to the introduction of new standards to be useful to say the least theoretical, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Drastic changes in the modern world of work also have negative consequences for workers in terms of new health and safety threats. The main objective is to ensure a safe and healthy working environment for all workers throughout their working lives, which is not only a basic human right, but also has a positive economic impact in terms of labour productivity. That is why it is particularly important that the S&D Group has fought to insist on stricter controls and concrete measures in the form of binding objectives, labour control and social dialogue in the workplace in the field of health and safety of workers. Among the main threats to be addressed are carcinogenic substances and mutagenics to which workers are exposed, exposure to asbestos, but increasingly psychological and psychosocial factors such as stress related to precarious forms of work and violence against women in the workplace.  I am pleased that Croatia has also been actively working in the last few years to solve problems such as administrative undercapacitation, non-compliance with regulations and inadequate monitoring and analytics, but better supervision in the field of safety and health still needs to be done, which is one of the most important goals of this European framework.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒Human capacities are the most important backbone of the development of the European Union, so workers' health and safety are an essential precondition for the sustainable development of the European Union. Accordingly, it is undoubtedly necessary to follow research that clearly reveals to us the causes of health impairments such as problems of a mental nature, musculoskeletal diseases, the onset of specific cancers and the consequences of excessive number of working hours. Regardless of the benefits for growth and development, it is necessary to take into account the gender dimension, implement initiatives to reduce stress caused by the unequal position of different vulnerable groups, especially women.  According to the surveys conducted by the Ombudsperson for Gender Equality on Gender Under-Representation in Croatia, the data suggest that Croatia is moving within an average EU framework, which is often used as an excuse. Given that underpresentation cannot be fully explained by structural barriers, an unfavourable attitude towards women is clear. It is therefore necessary to prevent such behaviours and harassment of either sexual or any other kind through all possible legislative frameworks. In these respects, the EU must ensure sufficient financial and human resources and establish clear objectives and indicators to fulfil its obligations to protect health and safety at work, with a focus on a strong gender perspective and equal accessibility to public health services especially in rural areas.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. – I am glad that Parliament has voted in support of occupational health and safety. It is important that all employees across all sectors have the right to the highest level of protection in the workplace. Furthermore, specific measures need to be put in place in order to improve health and safety at work. However, it is disappointing that the current EU-OSH framework was delayed and in the future it should be done and applied in a timely and effective manner. The next step is enforcement; legislation is only effective if it is enforced. I encourage Member States to ensure equal opportunity and protection of labour rights, as well as rights to health care, especially for those who are most vulnerable in society.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Health is a fundamental right and, despite significant progress in occupational health and safety (OSH) over the years, European workers are still exposed to serious health and safety risks.  The report stresses that employees are entitled to the highest level of protection and welcomes the Commission communication on the EU Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. The report also calls on the Commission to revise Directive 2004/37/EC on carcinogens. I voted in favour of adopting this text because I believe that the European Union must contribute to creating a working environment that puts people and their well-being at the centre.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the definitive form of this report presented to us sets realistic objectives and does not merely propose declaratoryly the achievement of objectives that cannot be achieved. Health and safety at work are among the important values we profess in Europe, so I am pleased to support the report for the above reasons.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. With this report, we take stock of the tools and areas of work for a strategic framework for occupational health and safety. Better European coordination will improve our tools. However, I stress endocrine disruptors: we know that exposure to these substances is dangerous to workers' health, so we need a comprehensive strategy at European level to combat them.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report as it calls for more EU legislation, targets, funds and interference on the issue of health and safety law. UKIP is not against good and sensible health and safety rules, but the only people who should create laws to protect workers are our democratically elected and accountable government, not unelected bureaucrats in Brussels.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Every year, more than 4,000 EU workers die from work-related accidents and the number of work-related fatal illnesses rises to more than 150,000 each year. It is therefore with enthusiasm that the European Parliament has supported the Commission's proposal on the European Union's strategic framework on occupational health and safety. The stakes are high, the text concerns the 217 million European workers, that is to say whether the regulation of labour is an essential point of the legislative activity of the European institutions. This strategy is timely and will be able to respond to the important challenges that arise: better application of existing rules, improved prevention of work-related diseases, while taking into account the ageing of the European workforce. In practical terms, this will include further strengthening national strategies, helping small and very small businesses to comply with the rules with evaluations, simplifying legislation, better statistics to assess issues and finally strengthening coordination with international organisations. An effective strategy, at the service of the worker, over the long term.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Every year, there are no less than 4,000 deaths from work-related accidents in Europe and more than 150,000 fatal illnesses directly or indirectly related to working conditions. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Union's strategic framework for occupational health and safety provides concrete solutions to strengthen workplace safety conditions while simplifying current legislation, whose administrative complexity penalises the functioning of our European SMEs and micro-enterprises.  The aim of this text is to foster dialogue between business leaders, governments and social partners in order to encourage the adoption of adequate and effective measures, particularly with regard to workers exposed to asbestos, but also in the prevention of psychosocial risks linked to stress and ever-increasing work demands. Finally, the fight against social dumping represents a real opportunity to harmonize working conditions from the top in Europe. For all these reasons, I voted for this text.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: In writing. This report, voted by a large majority, must shake up the Commission, which is dragging its feet to improve the living conditions of workers in the company. The European Parliament has called for better protection of employees from carcinogens and mutagenic substances by calling for the Commission to set more limits on exposure limits to these substances. This is essential in the construction sector where employees are often exposed to asbestos and tar, among others. It also recognises the dangers posed by endocrine disruptors, substances that are particularly harmful to women in particular. But we must go further, and that the Commission should present a strategy as soon as possible to prevent its risks.  It is equally essential to recognize the risks associated with stress, especially burnout. According to the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work, more than half of workers report that stress at work is common. In Europe, stress is the second most talked about work-related health problem. It was therefore urgent for Parliament to alert the Commission on this matter.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. Every year, more than 4,000 workers die from accidents at work and the number of occupational diseases with fatal outcome swells to more than 150,000 per year. Despite all the progress made, much remains to be done. Identified several important challenges facing European employers and workers in the field of health and safety at work, this is the time to move forward with legislative proposals aimed at raising the level of health and safety at work across the EU. In addition to an important set of proposed measures, this report does not forget the increase in precarious work (and the impact it has on workers' mental health) and the new forms of employment linked to new technologies, which have posed new challenges to health and safety at work that need to be addressed.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In 2014, the Commission published the EU Strategic Framework on Occupational Health and Safety 2014-2020, which seeks to address three main challenges: further improving and simplifying existing standards, improving the prevention of work-related diseases taking into account new risks, and addressing ageing labour. But it lacks an ambitious agenda for establishing legislative proposals to improve the situation of workers in terms of existing and emerging risks in addition to occupational diseases. This report sets out Parliament's position on the new strategic framework, which calls on the Commission to submit concrete legislative proposals on better occupational health and safety and to turn its 'strategic framework' into a real strategy on occupational health and safety, so that once the planned review in 2016 has been carried out, more concrete legislative or non-legislative measures will be included in the framework , as well as application and execution tools. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Every year in the EU, more than 4,000 workers lose their lives in the line of work. More than 150,000 people die from work-related illnesses. Every effort must be made to prevent these human tragedies from happening again and to adapt the legislation to the realities on the ground, in order to ensure its proper application. If there is one issue on which the "social triple A" targeted by the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, depends, it is that of the health and safety of European employees. For me, the simplification of our regulations aimed at making EU legislation simpler and more efficient (the REFIT programme drawn up by the European Commission) cannot in any way weaken the rules governing occupational health and safety. I am also convinced that it is with the help of the actors on the ground that we must define the best policies to implement.  Better working conditions, and consequently a reduction in accidents and diseases, benefit not only workers, whose physical integrity is preserved, but also social security systems, thus strengthened, and also the competitiveness of enterprises.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Health and safety at work are extremely worrying and require coordinated work by the European institutions. Around 4,000 workers die each year in accidents at work and 150,000 suffer from diseases related to their work/work environment. Precarious work, new technologies, the high age of European workers, have been some factors of change in our work fabric. These factors are challenges that need pressing and effective solutions capable of halting this scourge. To this end, preventive measures should be strengthened and tighter supervision. Examples such as productivity, labour participation and the very sustainability of the social security system are positively the result of a set of measures and bets on rethought and implemented health and safety at work policies. I therefore think it is important to support this own-initiative report on the EU Strategic Framework for Labour Health and Safety 2014-2020, so that positive and more effective measures are considered for a safer and more predictable European labour future.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Every year, more than 4,000 workers die as a result of work-related accidents and more than 3 million people are affected by serious accidents resulting in a work stoppage of more than 3 days. In the face of these alarming figures, Europe must act and find solutions to occupational health and safety; I therefore voted in favour of this report, which covers the new EU strategic framework for occupational health and safety in 2014 to 2020. There is an urgent need for better implementation of existing health and safety rules and improved prevention of work-related diseases. Health and safety within companies must be a priority and information must be better disseminated as it is the source of better performance and competitiveness. It is also about improving enforcement controls and strengthening the coordination of national labour inspections. Finally, it is important that all these measures can be implemented in a simple way, so as not to penalise our SMEs and TPEs.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's strategic framework for health and safety at work 2014-2020 as I believe it is of fundamental importance to protect workers.  Member States must endeavour to ensure that prevention and safety measures relating to workplaces are applied and/or improved. Even today, more than 4 000 people are estimated to lose their lives as a result of accidents at work, and in Italy there has been a dramatic 11% increase in white deaths from January to August 2015.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I agree with the need to adopt ever higher standards of health and safety at work.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is based on a broad and inclusive view of occupational health and safety and has incorporated many of the amendments of the GUE/NGL Group. Relevant aspects include the mention that all workers are entitled to the highest level of protection in the field of health and safety in the workplace, regardless of the size of the undertaking, the Member State or the type of employment contract.  At the same time, four key aspects included in the text make us vote in favour: (a) SMEs: the effectiveness of occupational health and safety management remains a challenge; it is essential to give them information and facilities; (b) labour inspections: increased staffing and resources are essential to carry out their functions: (c) social dialogue: it aims to move forward to provide training and promote the figure of health and safety representatives; (d) gender references: important references to ending stereotypes about the lower danger of work performed primarily by women.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 4,000 workers die every year as a result of workplace injuries, but the number of work-related fatalities is still many times higher, reaching up to 150,000 cases per year. Both of these high figures are alarming and measures must therefore be taken to radically reduce them. We should also focus on ensuring that these measures are consistently respected. Anyone can be the victim of a workplace accident. For these reasons, I also supported the report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. U2012 The precariousness of employment relationships, irregular rhythms, illegal days and the high rotation of contracts are the fundamental cause of the increase in occupational accidents and diseases. That is why quality employment and trade unions are crucial in risk prevention and the development of occupational health and safety strategies. The rapporteur's report shares this position, as well as asking for the EU strategy to address such important challenges as the gender approach or ageing workforce, as well as specific risks such as endocrine disruptors or exposure to asbestos. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this framework as it calls for more EU health and safety regulation. SMEs are already tied up with large amounts of health and safety regulations and they do not need any more.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014 and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training, tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses. We have called for the Commission to pursue a policy of regulation in the area of occupational health and safety as well as adopting a targeted approach to precarious employment and the negative effects that this has on occupational health and safety.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I appreciate the progress that has been made in the area of health and safety at work in recent years, but I must also point out critically that, despite these achievements, there are still many problems in the workplace that threaten workers. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that it is essential, within the strategic framework, to continue to take further measures that will guarantee even greater protection for workers and create a level playing field for all companies, regardless of their size, location or sector of activity.  I also supported the resolution because I believe that Europe needs to ensure even safer and healthier working environments for more than 217 million workers in the EU. I am convinced that any investment in health and safety at work will make a positive contribution to growth and higher labour productivity, a reduction in the number of accidents and a rarer incidence of serious diseases. It is important that, on the basis of the measures taken, we successfully follow up on existing legislation in the field of health and safety at work, thereby contributing to better and more effective compliance in all Member States and businesses. I expect that, with the adoption of a strategic framework, much greater attention will be paid to older workers, disabled workers and women who require special measures in the area of health and safety at work.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report does not have direct legislative implications, it is a strong appeal to the work of the EU institutions and Member States in the field of OSH. Given the high number of small and micro-enterprises in the EU, the call on the European Commission and the Member States to step up efforts to collect data on the actual application of the rules in this area and data on occupational diseases can only be welcomed. The aim is to establish more clearly the health indicators and definitions of the most important occupational diseases, which need to be fully addressed at Union level and to seek solutions to prevent them. The European Commission will then have the opportunity to target those Member States where ineffective implementation of EU rules may occur when monitoring the practical application of OSH directives in individual Member States. On the other hand, Member States' labour inspectorates should have access to available data on entities that repeatedly violate OSH rules. I also welcome the exchange of information between labour inspectorates in the Member States and the call for the gradual elimination of precarious forms of work. Workers who are parties to atypical employment contracts are the most vulnerable from this point of view and usually have difficult access to OSH services and training.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution proposing to launch an EU strategy on health and safety at work for the period 2014-2020, which calls on the Commission to take decisive action to protect workers from the risks that may arise in the workplace.  Every year more than 4 000 workers die as a result of accidents at work and more than 150 000 suffer from diseases related to working conditions, such as various forms of cancer or psychological disorders such as stress and severe nervous breakdown. Although important progress has been made in recent years, also thanks to the work of the European Commission, which has identified the risks and challenges to workers' safety, it is now necessary to propose legislative measures to improve the level of protection both in terms of health and safety at work.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. After months of delay, the European Commission presented its new 2014-2020 occupational health and safety strategy. It outlines three major challenges: the implementation of existing health and safety rules, the prevention of work-related diseases and the ageing of our EU workforce.  This report is the official response of the EP to this and has been reinforced by several green amendments which focus on 'better prevention than cure'. We call on the Commission to come up with a comprehensive strategy on occupational exposure to endocrine disruptors. We ask for recognition of risks associated with stress at work, including burnout. The existing directives on health and safety at work should also not be eroded by the European Commission's REFIT programme, which seeks to simplify legislation, which can also have negative consequences for the health and safety of workers. In order to help SMEs reduce their administrative burdens without compromising the health and safety of their employees, new tools are being developed to make risk assessment easier to comply with the legislation. I support this report because it puts the health and safety of workers first. That's crucial.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. I voted against the Christensen report on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. In principle, the report contains a number of good points aimed at strengthening safety at work and reducing bureaucratic hurdles for small businesses. However, paragraph 26 calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive legal instrument on musculoskeletal disorders (MSE). Indeed, MSEs are some of the most common causes of disease in everyday work, which is why existing national regulations are in place. The ALFA rejects an EU regulation on the grounds of subsidiarity, because the bureaucratic burden of European legislation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, is not proportionate to the added value it creates. The ECR Group's attempt to remove MSE regulation from the text failed, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained in the vote on this report. N-VA absolutely endorses the importance of a high level of protection of human health. The Union's action can support and complement national policies, but it must respect the policy autonomy of the Member States. Unfortunately, the report before us does not sufficiently respect this division of powers. On the other hand, the N-VA delegation welcomes the strong encouragement of the exchange of good practice, the call for consistent and transparent rules to make it easier for companies to comply, and the particular focus on SMEs.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report, because as the board has pointed out, I believe that all employees are entitled to a high level of occupational safety and also the right to a high level of care. I welcome the Commission's Framework on the Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020 and emphasise the need to adopt a clear legislation with concrete measures. I also support the report, as workplace health and safety are basic societal interests, as well as investment that has a positive impact on the productivity and competitiveness of societies and also improves the sustainability of social security systems and allows people to work healthy until the statutory old-age pension. Workplace accidents and occupational diseases are high burdens for society, and improvements in OSH across Europe can contribute to the economic recovery and achievement of the Europe 2020 targets.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014 and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training and tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses. We have called on the Commission not only to pursue a policy of regulation in the area of occupational health and safety but also to adopt a targeted approach to precarious employment and the negative effects that this has on occupational health and safety.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of this strategy is to highlight the importance and interconnectedness between health and workplace safety. Since often the working day lasts more than 8 hours it is necessary to ensure good working conditions that will also protect the physical and mental health of each individual. All employees, including those in the public sector, are entitled to the highest level of health and safety in the workplace to be guaranteed regardless of the size of the company, type of work, basic contract or Member State of employment. Health and safety in the workplace are basic social interests, as well as investment that has a positive impact on the productivity and competitiveness of societies and also improves the sustainability of social security systems and enables people to have health in the workplace until the statutory old-age pension. I fully support these strategies with a view to improving the health and safety at work and stressing the need for specific measures to offset the effects of the crisis by helping businesses seeking to improve safety and health at work.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. Of course, I support greater protection of health and safety at work. However, the challenges presented in the proposal lead to increased regulatory burdens and overpriced employment, which will ultimately harm most of those to be protected by the proposal. I also have doubts as to whether the challenges presented comply with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU Strategic Framework on Safety and Health at Work for the period 2014-2020. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union is clear in this area and says that every worker has the right to healthy and safe working conditions that respect his dignity. The economic aspect is also important here. Ensuring safety and health at work must be an investment for the employer, not a cost, as the costs incurred as a result of occupational diseases and accidents at work are much higher than the costs incurred by employers as a result of occupational health and safety policies.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 For us as the Left, Health and Safety in the Workplace is above all an inalienable right to work, which is not understood without the active and substantial contribution of workers. For us it is inconceivable that more than 4 000 workers die in the European Union every year as a result of accidents at work. The participation of workers cannot therefore be limited to declarations, but must be ensured at all levels of decision-making, from the level of the undertaking to the level of the State, where workers' trade unions and social partners will have direct and active participation.   Our main concerns were included in the report. In fact, we consider the development to be very positive that Parliament's report makes no reference to the interconnection of life expectancy with work, which is unfortunately highlighted in the Commission's report. As an ESA/BPA we will not tire of fighting against this anti-labour measure, which removes the right of workers to enjoy their old age and pension as they wish.  For the above reasons we voted in favour of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The negative impact of precarious work on the health and safety of workers in Europe demonstrates the need to adopt a targeted approach to improve the health and safety status of these workers and it is imperative to improve the collection of comparable data on occupational diseases and exposure to dangerous factors as well as to identify good prevention practices.  We are voting in favour of this report as many workers are still exposed to asbestos in their workplace, so it is important to improve the protection of workers from exposure to carcinogens and mutagens, as well as from ergonomic risk factors, and new initiatives at EU level and better integration of THYM into other policy areas are needed.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission to take stronger steps to protect workers' health in order to reduce new risks of disease and psychological disorders (e.g. stress and burnout). As the report points out, around 4,000 people die every year from accidents at work, while work-related fatalities affect more than 150,000 people every year. The Commission has already done a good job of identifying risks and challenges for workers, but the report calls for further action. I agree, for example, that reduction targets should be established for diseases and accidents at work, that workers' rights should be protected regardless of the size of the workplace. I support the development of a national action plan for the necessary asbestos screening and registration, and the need to define common health indicators and definitions for work in order to reduce employment diseases. I believe that we should call for joint action at EU level in the interests of workers, in order to ensure that people in all Member States can do similar work with reduced levels of health risk. Unfortunately, with the deepening of the economic crisis and irresponsible government policy, workers' wages in Hungary have not increased in nominal terms, but health risks do, as employers often try to save money in order to preserve jobs and profits.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Good working conditions protecting physical and mental health are a fundamental right of workers. It is well known that prevention costs are significantly lower than those associated with the treatment of occupational diseases, and therefore both companies and Member States should take all measures to reduce the risk of occupational diseases.  The European Parliament's report properly emphasises the need for the European Commission, Member States and businesses to work together to develop an EU OSH strategy. Furthermore, it is important to pay particular attention to the needs and difficulties of compliance by micro and small and medium-sized enterprises when creating an EU framework on health and safety at work, so that the legal framework does not become a significant obstacle to their development.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The incidence of accidents at work and deaths from occupational diseases has reached an alarming level. For these reasons, more effective safety regulation and combating health risks at work are required. The regulations should aim at limiting exposure to carcinogenic and mutagenic substances, avoiding the development of locomotor deficiencies and psychological risks caused by stress and avoiding exposure to asbestos. At the same time, the participation of the social partners and social dialogue at all levels are required in order to achieve adequate protection of the safety and health of workers, irrespective of the size of the employer, the type of activity, the Member State or the type of contract. The financial and economic crisis as well as administrative simplifications (REFIT) should not be used as an excuse to lower safety and health standards for workers. A special chapter is the challenges and risks to women in the workplace. They must be vigorously combated, as must the incidence of violence against women in the workplace. The implementation of high European rules on the protection of workers can help to improve the situation at international level by including these requirements in all EU trade agreements with third parties. For these reasons, I support this commendable initiative.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the text. Occupational health and safety is a fundamental interest of society as well as an investment that has a positive impact on the productivity and competitiveness of businesses, improves the viability of social security systems and allows people to work in good health until the legal retirement age. As a reminder, work-related accidents and occupational diseases are a considerable burden on society and improving occupational health and safety in Europe can contribute to the economic recovery and achievement of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, for which little progress has been made so far towards the target of a 75% employment rate for 20-64 year olds.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Over the last year the European Union has been working on the drawing up of an improved framework for a safe and healthy environment. I supported this report, which proposes some new measures to be included in this framework. Although safety at work is already heavily regulated, accidents and work-related diseases still kill thousands of workers per year. This proves we urgently need a simplified and more effective legislative framework, through which, in particular, we should better address the specific situation of SMEs. In line with the objective of better regulation I support new legislations when based on tangible data and thorough impact assessment and therefore I am calling on Member States and the Commission to improve the collection of data in this sector.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission has developed a multiannual action strategy that identifies priorities and common objectives in the health and safety legislation segment, while at the same time trying to establish a framework for coordinating national policies.  The latest strategy covers the period from 2014 to 2020 and is an attempt by the Commission to improve Union legislation within the REFIT programme in this segment, which currently constitutes a simultaneous revision of 22 legislative acts. While I support certain parts of the report that go towards supporting SMEs, simplifying and exchanging good practices, I am concerned by proposals that focus on prevention rather than risk management; unfounded calls to increase resources based on IOS definitions; calls for the Commission to develop and implement a programme for systematic monitoring of psychosocial risks; call for legislation in the segment of workplace bullying and in the segment of musculoskeletal disorders, etc. I consider those calls to be a crude and unnecessary encarication of the principle of subsidiarity, as the same objective is more effectively achieved at the level of the already existing legislation of individual Member States of the Union and therefore cannot support them.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the EU Strategic Framework on Safety and Health at Work for the period 2014-2020 because it brings many important oSH challenges, both for employers and for employees. I believe that all employees are entitled to a safe and healthy working environment. Although OSH has progressed over the years, there are still many risks for employees. It is therefore necessary to improve the supervision of the situation in this area by Member States, thus also providing support to labour inspectorate with resources and to enable them to carry out their work efficiently and effectively.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is based on a broad and inclusive view of occupational health and safety and has incorporated many of the amendments of the GUE/NGL Group. Relevant aspects include the mention that all workers are entitled to the highest level of protection in the field of health and safety in the workplace, regardless of the size of the undertaking, the Member State or the type of employment contract.  At the same time, four key aspects included in the text make us vote in favour: (a) SMEs: the effectiveness of occupational health and safety management remains a challenge; it is essential to give them information and facilities; (b) labour inspections: increased staffing and resources are essential to carry out their functions: (c) social dialogue: it aims to move forward to provide training and promote the figure of health and safety representatives; (d) gender references: important references to ending stereotypes about the lower danger of work performed primarily by women.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. I voted against the Christensen report on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020. In principle, the report contains a number of good points aimed at strengthening safety at work and reducing bureaucratic hurdles for small businesses. However, paragraph 26 calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive legal instrument on musculoskeletal disorders (MSE). Indeed, MSEs are some of the most common causes of disease in everyday work, which is why existing national regulations are in place. The ALFA rejects an EU regulation on the grounds of subsidiarity, because the bureaucratic burden of European legislation, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, is not proportionate to the added value it creates. The ECR Group's attempt to remove MSE regulation from the text failed, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Having good working conditions to protect physical and mental health, apart from being a fundamental individual right of workers is a positive value in itself that benefits all parties – first, the worker and, secondly, the productivity and competitiveness of enterprises – while it can also contribute to economic recovery and improve the sustainability of social security systems. I agree to support any measures to improve the working environment to protect the health and safety of workers.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Engaging work to increase standards and put in place tighter control of their application does not appear to be the priority in the current context. Moreover, it is well known that a high proportion of work-related accidents affect people in unreported jobs: a revision of the Detached Workers Directive would be more relevant. While reducing occupational risks is a relevant objective at European level, simplifying the legislative framework under REFIT is a top priority. It is high time to stop multiplying the standards that weigh on companies. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis has led to increased job insecurity and a reduction in business earnings, especially for SMEs, and this should not lead to a loss of sight in the importance of health and safety at work. Improving occupational health and safety across Europe can contribute to the economic recovery and achievement of the Europe 2020 targets, namely achieving an employment rate of 75 % among the population aged 20 to 64. Health and safety at work is a fundamental interest of society, as well as an investment that has a positive effect on the productivity and competitiveness of businesses and also improves the sustainability of social security systems. Cancer is the leading cause of work-related death, followed by cardiovascular and respiratory diseases, while work-related accidents are a small proportion of deaths. There is therefore a need for improved conditions and strong legislation on health and safety at work to prevent such situations. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the EU's Strategic Framework on Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 4 000 workers die in accidents at work each year, and the number of work-related fatalities is more than 150 000 per year. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe, and although significant progress has been made over the years in the field of health and safety at work, there are still greater risks to the health and safety of workers. In the EU Strategy for Health and Safety at Work 2014-2020, the Commission identifies a number of important risks faced by European employers and workers in the field of safety and health at work. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: in writing. \u2012 A healthy, functioning society needs healthy people, and a healthy workplace environment will improve employee productivity. Promoting health and safety at work and protecting workers at work are essential for improving working conditions and, consequently, for protecting workers' health. The European Parliament's report draws attention to this important issue and calls on the European Commission to revise health legislation at work. Improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the legislative framework in this area is essential for the protection of workers. The report also makes a number of recommendations on improving legislation on occupational diseases and stresses the importance of protecting workers from exposure to carcinogens, mutagens and substances toxic to reproduction. The provisions of the report also draw attention to the need for an increased exchange of information and best practices between Member States and the importance of supplementing current resources in order to increase the efficiency of labour inspectorates. The working conditions must be in accordance with the legislation in force, it is not only a responsibility of law enforcement bodies, but also of employers and employees. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is based on a broad and inclusive view of occupational health and safety and has incorporated many of the amendments of the GUE/NGL Group. Relevant aspects include the mention that all workers are entitled to the highest level of protection in the field of health and safety in the workplace, regardless of the size of the undertaking, the Member State or the type of employment contract.  At the same time, four key aspects included in the text make us vote in favour: (a) SMEs: the effectiveness of occupational health and safety management remains a challenge; it is essential to give them information and facilities; (b) labour inspections: increased staffing and resources are essential to carry out their functions: (c) social dialogue: it aims to move forward to provide training and promote the figure of health and safety representatives; (d) gender references: important references to ending stereotypes about the lower danger of work performed primarily by women.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it is important to acknowledge the facts, such as that every year more than 4 000 workers die due to accidents at work and the number of fatal work-related diseases amounts to more than 150 000 every single year. Good health is a fundamental right in Europe and even though considerable progress has been made in the area of occupational health and safety (OSH) throughout the years, major risks to workers’ health and safety continue to exist. The workforce in many Member States is ageing and the demographic changes in Europe point to the need to promote a safe and healthy working environment for all workers throughout their working life cycle. Furthermore, the labour market in Europe is changing. Precarious employment is on the rise and new forms of employment as well as new technologies have brought about new OSH challenges that remain to be addressed. The negative impact that precarious employment has on workers’ mental health in Europe points to the need for a targeted approach to improve the health and safety situation of these workers.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report highlights that employees have the right to have the highest level of health and safety protection at work and welcomes the Communication on an EU strategic framework on occupational health and safety for the period 2014-2020. We are talking about a balanced report, so I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. U2012 The precariousness of employment relationships, irregular rhythms, illegal days and the high rotation of contracts are the fundamental cause of the increase in occupational accidents and diseases. That is why quality employment and trade unions are crucial in risk prevention and the development of occupational health and safety strategies. The rapporteur's report shares this position, as well as asking for the EU strategy to address such important challenges as the gender approach or ageing workforce, as well as specific risks such as endocrine disruptors or exposure to asbestos. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. We spend a lot of our time at work, therefore it is imperative that we are allowed to work in a safe environment. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014, and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training and tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses. We have called for the Commission not to pursue a policy of deregulation in the area of occupational health and safety and instead adopt a targeted approach to precarious employment and the negative effects that this has on occupational health and safety.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this plan because better well-being and better health on the work floor contribute to a better society as a whole. We all need to work longer in Europe because of an ageing population. This strategic plan can ensure that we age in a more active and healthier way, through prevention.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Every year, more than 4,000 workers die from work-related accidents and more than 3 million are victims of serious accidents.  The number of accidents at work has decreased in recent years, but progress in the area of prevention, health and safety at work in the EU remains below what might be expected.  This Parliament's report calls for respect to the maximum level of protection for health and safety in the workplace for all workers, regardless of the size of the company that employs them, and an assessment of the practical implementation of occupational health and safety directives in the Member States. The importance of social dialogue and worker representation in reducing the negative impact on the physical and mental health of workers of the increase in precarious work in the Union requires addressing psychosocial risk factors. It's all said and said. This report is a pavement of good intentions.   I voted in favour, but without illusions about the possibility of having them implemented by the Member States.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We note the importance of defining health and safety at work (ASS) policies as the EU's strategic definition for the period 2014-2020. We do not follow the report in its federalist perspective, with references to the Union's ability to support and supplement the action of states, or in the relationship of this strategy with the Europe 2020 objectives or in the need to implement European-wide legislation and strategic guidelines, in particular the OSS Strategic Framework. Despite these issues, the report refers to and encourages the definition of ASH policies, linking it to undeclared work and false self-work, gender equality and combating harassment, the need for "balanced" working hours, or access to public health services. Associated with the promotion of these measures is the promotion of adequate training and representation of workers in the formulation and supervision of ASS policies.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report exceeds the EU's competences on this issue in many areas. While it is important to address these problems, regulation at EU level with firm rules is the wrong way to go, as labour standards have also grown differently in the different Member States and are not always of equal importance. I therefore reject this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 Rising white deaths call for Eu ropean Union action to improve the physical and mental condition of workers. The health of the worker is a fundamental right and a positive value in itself and as such must be protected at all costs and with all the necessary instruments. I have therefore voted in favour of a report which puts the human being, his dignity and respect for life in all its dimensions, at the centre of the production process.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution. Safety regulations in the workplace are first and foremost a national task. The EU has never been able to prove in a sustainable way that it is adding value to this important issue today. The EU Commission even implicitly admits this, because its EU strategic framework for health and safety at work contains many important areas of action, but sets specific objectives. This proves that the EU would like to deal with an issue here and that it really cannot, because the Member States and national legislation can regulate this policy area quite well even without the EU.

name: Julie WARD
