text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014 and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training, the tackling of diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures, as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses. We have called for the Commission not only to pursue a policy of regulation in the area of occupational health and safety but also to adopt a targeted approach to precarious employment and the negative effects that this has on occupational health and safety.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the highest level of protection for health and safety in the workplace. In the UK alone, there were 142 work-related deaths in 2014 and Labour MEPs have called for a strategy to emphasise the importance of proper training and tackle diseases and cancers caused by asbestos and other carcinogens by implementing appropriate screening measures as well as proper measures for those working with chronic or terminal illnesses.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Parliament's resolution on health and safety at work, although I had reservations about the terminology used for 'gender equality' in some language mutations in this text. As I reiterate, I fully support the principle of equal treatment between women and men, while respecting the specific differences that are biologically conditional and relate to the mission of a woman as a mother. I find the use of the term 'gender' in contexts that speak of the need to take into account women's specific health and safety needs in the workplace, or their greater vulnerability as potential victims of sexual harassment and bullying by male co-workers or superiors, as it distracts from real problems. I will therefore continue to draw attention to the need to harmonise translations of Parliament's resolutions and working texts.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Health is an inalienable right of workers. In every profession, in every workplace, safety rules must be observed without discounts. The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs stresses, inter alia, compliance with both the relevant EU strategic framework and national frameworks for the benefit of European citizens.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, which I supported, provides that all workers, regardless of the size of the company in which they work, their Member State or the type of employment contract, are entitled to the highest level of health and safety protection at work.  The effectiveness of workplace health and safety management remains a challenge for micro and small businesses to this day. The level of implementation by Member States must be increased in order to improve the health and safety of workers and to ensure a level playing field for businesses. The European market is changing: precarious work is on the increase, new forms of contract and new technologies have brought out major health and safety challenges. The economic crisis and austerity policies have certainly reduced the economic and financial resources of companies, but this must, under no circumstances, lead to a reduction in resources allocated to health and safety.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the Commission communication on the strategic framework. However, such a framework needs to be filled in with specific legislative measures, such as the Muscle Disorders Directive. Social dialogue, worker representation and management deployment are important for successful risk prevention in the workplace. I believe that greater efforts are needed, both at Member State and EU level, to ensure training for health and safety representatives and to promote the use of their services. In my opinion, it is also important to prevent risks in the areas of mental health, where psychosocial disorders, for example, occur as a result of new fields of employment.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the EU Strategic Framework for Health and Safety at Work. I believe that the idea of health and safety at work is very important, and preventing health problems, whether physically, with a special focus on MUS disorders or psychological disorders that may arise as a result of adverse effects at work, should be an important part of European policies. Unfortunately, however, the proposal contained a number of elements which, on the contrary, I could not support, in particular the call on the European Commission to present new comprehensive legal instruments to deal with this issue. I am of the opinion that not every situation requires the creation of new and comprehensive legal instruments that would only contribute to the total amount of legislation and which could ultimately lead to even greater uniformity within the European Union.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The report stresses the importance of defining health and safety at work (ASS) policies as the EU's strategic definition for the period 2014-2020. There are, in the report, federalist frameworks, with which we do not agree, with references to the european Union's ability to support and complete the action of states; the relationship of this strategy with the Europe 2020 objectives; the need to implement European-wide legislation and strategic guidelines. Despite these issues, the report refers to and encourages the definition of ASS policies, linking it to undeclared work and false self-work; gender equality and combating harassment; the need for a "balanced" working hours; or access to public health services. Associated with the promotion of these measures is the promotion of adequate training and representation of workers in the formulation and supervision of ASS policies. Overall, it is a positive report and we have voted in favour.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the EU Strategic Framework on Safety and Health at Work for the period 2014-2020, as I believe that it proposes a number of measures to improve working conditions that protect physical and mental health, inter alia, calling on the Commission and the Member States to eliminate through work through a targeted approach and also to take household work into account and to ensure and facilitate an appropriate work-life balance.  Health and safety at work is an investment with a positive impact on the productivity and competitiveness of a company, as well as improving the sustainability of social security systems.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral question to the Commission on the elimination of violence against women in the EU by Iratxe Garcia Pérez on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (O-000126/2015 - B8-1105/2015) (2015/2855(RSP)).

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, more than nine million women have been victims of gender-based violence in Europe. It is difficult to say this figure without being ashamed; it is difficult to say this figure without understanding that behind the numbers there are truncated lives, lives of women who have been killed by machismo, by the machismo it kills, by those who think that women are their property, by those who understand that society is not egalitarian. And in the face of this figure, in the face of this reality, today, 25 November, we have the responsibility, we have an obligation to raise our voices, to avoid silence, to commit ourselves, to work to end the largest social scourge that the world currently has and which Europe currently has. We have to take responsibility. It's time to leave the ads, it's time to leave the words and it's time to act, because women can't wait any longer, because day after day we see in the media, in the news, as there are women who, just because they are women, are killed, their lives are truncated and the lives of their sons and daughters are truncated.  We need to live in a more egalitarian society. We need to make commitments: it's our obligation, it's our responsibility. And that is why we are launching a number of questions to the European Commission today. This is not the first time that this debate has brought us to Parliament's plenary and we hope, with today's debate, to have the European Commission's commitments for all the work that needs to be done from now on.  We want to know when the European Commission is going to present the strategy of equality between men and women. This Parliament has already ruled on what the content of this strategy should be, and it is essential for us that a large part of the policy aimed at equality between men and women takes priority in the fight against gender-based violence.  But besides, we want to know other things. The European institutions have already taken some steps in this area. The victim protection order was an essential element. Less than a year ago, the deadline for Member States to transpose has been met. We want to know when the European Commission intends to make known to us the assessment of how the implementation of this European protection order has worked.  But we also understand that it is essential that legislative action can be taken. This is not the first time, Mrs Jourová, that you have heard this complaint from the European Parliament. Only with measures to support organizations, with awareness-raising programmes will we not solve this situation. It is necessary to legislate because legislation is a compromise, the legislation implies an obligatory compliance with the legislation by the Member States to combat gender-based violence.  We have heard on many occasions to say that there is no level of competition in Europe to combat gender-based violence, but we do not resign ourselves and believe that things can be changed, because – I have said it more times in these debates – if we have managed to give Europe competences in the fight against the economic crisis, we will also be able to seek the skills that Europe must have to combat gender-based violence , to fight for a fairer and more egalitarian society.  So let us all look for one - the Council, the Commission, Parliament – to seek that legislative capacity, because we cannot continue to wait, we cannot continue to make announcements that are simply left in that, in compromises, and which then do not translate into realities.  We are talking about women's lives, about the lives of half the population of Europe. They deserve our respect, they deserve to be aware that it is in our hands to do much more than is being done so far.  This is an issue that should involve us all, all institutions, at all levels. It is already necessary to join all efforts because women deserve it; because the memory of all those who have been killed by sexist terrorists deserves our work; because we are talking about the future of our generation, but also that of our daughters; because it's our responsibility and it's our obligation.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for raising this very important and serious subject on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. It is an important political signal that both Parliament and the Commission decided to join the UN Women’s Orange Day campaign to mark the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women and to light up their buildings in orange today. Violence against women remains a challenge in every country in Europe. In 2015 women are still beaten, humiliated, raped, mutilated, stalked, harassed and forced into marriage. Violence happens in their homes at the hands of their partners or family members. It happens in the workplace or in education from colleagues, fellow students, professors or bosses. It can happen on the streets or online from strangers. We know that one in three women in the EU has experienced physical or sexual violence or both. Violence has a lifelong impact on the health and wellbeing of victims, as well as on their families. This in turn has an impact on the economy and society as a whole. Promoting gender equality and combating violence against women go hand in hand. Women need to be empowered to leave abusive relationships and to challenge violence when they encounter it. They should not be hampered in fulfilling their potential in the workplace and in society. I will present in December a detailed Commission plan and commitment on improving gender equality in the years to come. I am prepared to submit also to the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) the proposal for the Gender Strategic Document for the years 2016 to 2019. We have worked on this with all stakeholders throughout this year, and your input in the process was also very valuable. Among the priorities it will include further measures to support Member States in preventing and combating all forms of gender-based violence. Regarding gender-based violence, the Commission is taking a determined and comprehensive approach based on legislation, awareness-raising and funding, as well as improving knowledge and data collection. I will start by focusing on legislation. The EU adopted legislation to prevent violence against women and to protect and support its victims, including in areas such as sexual harassment, trafficking in human beings, sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography. Our modern victims’ rights in the Victims Directive, on which we have worked closely with you, just entered into force on 16 November this year. This will have a huge impact on some Member States, for instance those which will have to establish victim support structures, which are of key importance for gender-based violence and which do not exist in all Member States yet. You can count on my commitment that the Commission will be guiding and monitoring the effective implementation of this piece of legislation, as well as the broader legal framework. We have to ensure that available protection measures are actually granted to persons at risk and applied in practice. Since January 2015, victims of domestic violence have benefited from reinforced protection when travelling or moving to other EU countries. Protection orders granted in their home country can circulate across EU borders. The transposition situation is encouraging. Thanks to enforcement procedures initiated by the Commission, we now have national rules transposing the European Protection Orders Directive in 21 Member States. I am glad to inform you also that on 9 October the Commission published a roadmap on future accession of the EU to the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention. The roadmap is a first concrete step towards accession to this powerful tool to combat violence against women and domestic violence. EU accession to the Convention would reflect our commitment to combating human rights violations and discrimination, both within and beyond the EU. The Commission also supports awareness-raising and concrete grassroots actions by Member States, civil society organisations and European networks. This year, EUR 8 million was allocated to combating violence against women under the Rights, Equality and Citizenship Programme. We have also empowered advocates for change among female genital mutilation-practising communities, trained services for victims of sexual violence in universities to better respond to incidents and young victims’ needs, and supported Member States in sensitising the general public to this problem. I am proud to inform you about last week’s decision to award a total amount of EUR 4.3 million to nine international projects combating violence against women linked to harmful practices. Within the framework of this awareness-raising work, I am also committed to putting into place focused actions on violence against women in 2017. We are currently planning future activities and would welcome your cooperation. I would also like to say a few words about the importance of improving our knowledge about the causes of gender-based violence on a regular basis. It is essential because it allows for monitoring of the situation across the EU and also helps us to formulate and implement better policies. My services are working with Eurostat and the European Institute for Gender Equality, two key actors in this area which, I believe, can help to fill the gaps. Finally, let me be clear that I see a need to address cyber-violence against women and girls – an emerging form of violence. We have EU legislation and policies on children’s – including girls’ – safety and protection from bullying, abuse and exploitation online. In addition, the Commission has launched a EUR 3 million call for proposals to combat sexual harassment and sexual violence against women and girls, including through new technologies and social media. Proposals are now being assessed.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, thank you for your commitment to the victims. Today is International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women and some can still wonder why this day. Well, because it's critical that society reacts. All efforts are few to raise awareness and promote strong actions to put an end to this scourge, which we cannot get used to. The dynamics of "I don't see, I don't hear and I don't talk" have to end. It is necessary to break that wall built with the fear and loneliness of the victim, because the one who wins, in the face of that desperate silence, is the aggressor, who feels strong to continue to mistreat, harass and, at worst, kill that woman whom he claims to love. Most cases of violence against women come from their partner and, in the case of children, from people around them. It is important that victims report, but to do so they have to feel protected. I am therefore proud to have been rapporteur for the European Order for the Protection of Victims, so that national restraining orders are recognised in any European country, which promotes the safety of women fleeing their assailants. There is still a long way to go in European legislation. That is why we have put forward this oral question, in order to know what European strategy the Commission is carrying out. Greater commitment is needed to eradicate this human rights violation, which is a consequence of inequality between men and women. An estimated 35% of women and girls experience some form of physical or sexual violence throughout their lives. And this has to stop, because I firmly believe that if we work in education, also in prevention, in victim protection and, of course, in greater control of aggressors, we can avoid so much pain caused by these violations, which so often even young women do not distinguish. Love doesn't have to hurt or control, and of course it doesn't have to kill. I also welcome the use of minors in this new Directive.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, I do not want to recall the figures, you have mentioned them. Indeed, one in three women in Europe today is a victim of violence. Behind these women, these numbers, there are human beings. They are our daughters, our sisters, your wives- gentlemen, our colleagues, they are the people around us. One in three women! It is true that if we turn around, it means that the person on my right, or the person on my left, is certainly, has been or will be the victim of violence. Should we talk about forms of violence? We know these forms of violence: they are physical, psychological, economic and sexual. The peak of violence, Iratxe talked about it, is femicide. Seven women a day now die from femicide, which simply means dying by being a woman. These include genital mutilation, human trafficking and sexual exploitation.  We want to say, quite simply, enough! That is enough, because it is unbearable to see that today in Europe we practice this laissez-faire in relation to these discriminations. Commissioner, Article 8 of the Lisbon Treaty simply says that we must ensure equality between men and women in Europe. You are the guardian of these treaties in the European Commission. We are simply asking you to be able to implement these treaties, not to make plans and steps. Sometimes it is easier to defend property rights than simply to defend the right to live. We therefore ask that you defend the right to live for everyone and for the 50% of the population in Europe.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Since 2004, Parliament has been regularly talking about violence against women. There is the UN CEDAW programme, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. There is the EU's Daphne programme for the implementation of the UN programme.  But what is violence against women? Are we not all against violence – especially against the weaker, in other words also against women? Of course we are. But the EU would not be the EU, and the UN would not be the UN if they did not sometimes hide their ideas behind vocabulary. Words make politics. Words are politics. Can we even oppose a decision condemning violence against women? No, you can't. By the way, also not violence against men and boys. But beware: according to the UN definition, it is, for example, violence against women if she cannot have an abortion, because it is forbidden, for example. A woman who is not allowed to have an abortion is then a victim of violence in the statistics. No matter how you stand on abortion, that's the wrong way to go. Let us be honest in politics: we all reject violence against women.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, violence against women is not only a women’s issue. Gender violence is also a men’s issue and, above all, a sad and a shameful reality. As has already been indicated in different interventions, at some point in their life, one in three women and girls experience physical or sexual violence from men. Most shockingly, almost half of this violence is committed by the partner of the victim, causing 2 500 deaths every year in the EU. That is seven women each day losing their lives because of sexual assault, domestic violence, relationship abuse or female genital mutilation. Let us recognise that, for too long, men have avoided the issue of violence against women and often cast it aside as being just a women’s issue, and I think that is the problem. As long as gender violence is seen as a women’s issue, men disconnect and we – men – must break the violence. Impunity for committing violence against women should be a thing of the past and justice needs to prevail for all those women who are victims. For that to happen, I would say to the Commissioner that I think we need an EU-wide strategy to combat violence against women. Many EU countries do indeed have laws today protecting women against such violence, but there are also many others that do not have them and which could do much better. The Istanbul Convention, initiated by the Council of Europe, in fact obliges countries to fully address violence against women in all its forms, to prevent it, to protect the victims and to prosecute the perpetrators, but so far the reality is that the Istanbul Convention has only been ratified by 12 Member States of the European Union. That is why I think we need to do something special, namely EU accession – the accession of the whole European Union – to the Istanbul Convention so as to close the loopholes in European and national legislation, to protect women far better and certainly to condemn countries with blood on their hands. So zero tolerance in the fight against gender violence is, in fact, the only way to address it, and we – not only women, but men and women – must unite and speak out, and that means break the silence. (Applause)

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Violence against women is a terror that goes on in silence. It takes lives and it shrinks our living spaces. We live in a culture that actually accepts that men's violence and abuse of women can continue. It is a culture that keeps public figures who have committed blatant abuses of the bodies of girls and women on their backs, or even pays tribute to them. I am thinking of former IMF base Dominique Strauss-Kahn. I think of the singer of Noir désir, Cantat, who murdered his girlfriend. I'm thinking of Roman Polanski. The list can be made longer with men from all our countries. We are here today because this Parliament has called for European legislation with minimum levels to combat violence against women, and we are not going to let go of that issue. In solidarity with the women of Europe and the world, I call for the Istanbul Convention to be ratified now. I demand the right to legal assistance and specially trained police and social services. I demand a judiciary that provides justice for those who are vulnerable. I call on the EU Member States to draw up action plans to combat gender-based violence. I also call for women's shelters – women's shelters that work day in and day out with women who have been victims of gender-based violence – to be properly supported and resourced. They are a source of knowledge and they are our fellow sisters in this work. I also want girls to have access to feminist self-defense. It is an obvious way to strengthen self-esteem and strength in young girls. We must stand up to the violence that restricts our lives against the culture of violence and the culture of silence that we have. A culture that blames women and woos men. We have to break with it. Silence contributes to the invisibility and continued abuse of women and girls. The absence of proposals from the Commission is a form of invisibility. The silence of the Commission and the Council on combating this specific violence against women is serious. It is even unacceptable.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, this morning we have spent more than three hours on a priority debate on the Paris attacks and the terrible terrorist threats that come to us, and now we are going to have less than one to talk about the greatest cause of violent deaths across Europe: violence against women, which strikes us every day and with much more intensity than any terrorist threat.  The figures have already been said, but I will repeat them because they are terribly monstrous: one in three European women have experienced some form of violence and one in four, some sexual assault.  Is Europe going to recognize you once and for all? This is our first security issue. And how do we deal with it? Some Member States of the European Union still have laws that conceal, protect or disguise this violence.  In this question we present to you, Commissioner, we ask you for solutions, urgent solutions, because every day women are killed by someone who believes themselves to be their master and lord, to the point of taking their lives, and every day many women must flee and leave their home, despite being the victims, in order to seek some safe haven.  We can't wait. We need strong pressure against those governments which do not do what they should, because they are complicit in the killers, and we are urged by a European directive against sexist violence. We need the maximum involvement of the European institutions.  Mrs. Jourová, I see you resigned. You complain about the problems of competence, but , as our colleague Maria Arena has already said , all the Treaties of the European Union say that we are the guarantors of equality, and what greater attack on equality than this sexist violence, than this violence against women. He's got us by his side, he's got Parliament by his side, but act fast, please.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today, on this symbolic day, we note, with deep regret, that even in states where the Istanbul Convention has been ratified, or in states, such as Italy, where there are laws against violence against women, problems continue to persist both in the application of laws and in terms of the application of a just penalty, which is all too often not strict with regard to those who commit such crimes. There are laws that do not guarantee victims. We all know that, thanks to appeals and reductions in sentences, the perpetrators do not completely discount it and often we only get to increase the anger of the sharpening towards the victim, even considering the very long time between the denunciation of stalking and the decision of a judge. We must therefore act today on three areas: prevention, protection and punishment. In parallel with all the preventive measures, we must call for a tightening of penalties and, above all, the certainty that they will be discounted in order to prevent the culprit from easily returning to a happy and regular life, unlike women who are victims of violence, who will bear the physical and moral signs throughout their lives.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, has it occurred to this place to put its own House in order before lecturing others in how they should behave? I have been subjected to verbal abuse and near physical violence in the Brussels and Strasbourg Parliament. Firstly, in one of the meetings I attended as an MEP, one of my fellow British MEPs called me ‘a stupid fucking woman’. He was overheard by a number of other MEPs and also members of staff. Is that acceptable? Secondly, an MEP from the Green Left called a female colleague ‘trash’ in another debate a few weeks ago. Is that acceptable? Thirdly, I have been stalked by a misogynistic journalist who works for an EU media outlet. He arrived to interview me drunk, holding a glass of wine at 10 o’clock in the morning. His second attempt was to doorstep me on leaving the plenary here. He is a big guy in terms of girth, and actually height. He had clearly been drinking again; he had a large camera precariously held on his shoulder and yet he pursued me at pace along the corridor outside here into a glass partition. If he had slipped, he could have crushed me. I am told he has a hatred of women, particularly those who are successful, and my politics. Is this acceptable? Yes, it seems that abusing women from the centre-right is OK. If a man from this side of the House turned to one of your women and called her the things that we have to put up with in this place, there would be outrage, there would be sanctions imposed, a statement by the President. Do I have any support in here? Silence. That tells me everything I need to know.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, in today’s society, violence against women is taking ever more unacceptable forms. We have only to look at the impact of human trafficking and the impact that this has on the lives of millions of women who are being sold into a life of sexual exploitation and abuse. While I accept Mr Verhofstadt’s point that this type of violence is not only directed towards women, on this, the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, I am bolstered by the strides made in my own constituency of Northern Ireland with the introduction of the Human Trafficking and Exploitation Bill. It is a great example of regional legislation which tackles this evil in society, and should act as a precedent for other Member States. I want to take this opportunity to also highlight the work of Women’s Aid in Northern Ireland, a voluntary organisation addressing domestic and sexual abuse by providing refuge accommodation to women and their children who have suffered mental, physical or sexual abuse within the home. This organisation has helped to rebuild lives through a range of programmes and support services.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for this discussion. Yes, we all have to do more; not only the European Commission, we must act at all levels. You mentioned that the Commission is the guardian of the Treaties and especially Article 8, which is the equality article. I am very much concerned about equality and I want to bring about effective actions using effective instruments. You call for new legislation. I said clearly that we are going to accede to the Istanbul Convention. As regards a possible new directive on combating violence against women, I myself do not think that a new directive is something that will solve the problem quickly. Just look at the process of preparing European legislation. I am not criticising it, but even if we find a legal basis for this, it would take several years to bring it into force in the Member States and to allow it to do its work. So I am talking about other instruments. I am declaring here that there is a problem with the legal basis for legislation, because violence against women is a criminal wrongdoing. So it is up to the Member States to use their competences in criminal law. We can, and we must do what we can. We will do it through accession to the Istanbul Convention, which gives us the competences to act also in the legislative sphere. What I see as the more efficient instrument is to invest the available funding into efficient awareness-raising, into campaigning, into support for grassroots organisations and civil society and into the training of experts and professionals in order to further help the victims of violence. As regards other actors who the Commission is prepared to support, we must first of all talk about the Member States that we are supporting, but at the same time who we are pushing to enforce legislation which must improve the situation. We must speak openly about society as such, because violence against women in many Member States is happening with silent acceptance within society as if it is something normal. In some Member States this is even silently accepted by the media. So we should look in this direction and together try to improve the situation. Local communities must not be blind and deaf. They must understand that something is happening around them. Let us speak about the victims themselves. Ladies and gentlemen, I have the recent statistics and the research saying that only 15% of violence against women has been reported to the relevant authorities. Yes, the victims remain silent, and that is also because they do not have enough trust in the authorities that they will act to help them. This is what the Victims Directive is about: that victims should not fear reporting violence and that they could expect efficient support from the relevant authorities. And finally – and Mr Verhofstadt mentioned this – we should consider men themselves. Yes, they must also do something to improve the situation. I was in Sweden recently where they have very good programmes specifically focused on men, who have an essential role to play in combating violence against women because, without their understanding that the situation must improve, we cannot change anything. This is a complex issue. This requires a list of many measures done by many different actors on many levels. So let us do it. I am committed to going into more detail about the Commission’s concrete plans when discussing the gender strategy in mid-December at the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – Violence against women is the most widespread violation of human rights in the world, affecting all strata of society. In the EU, 9 million women have been victims of sexist violence. While we need to raise our voices and fight these crimes every day and from all walks of life, on November 25, International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, it must serve to seek greater visibility and mobilize consciences. Institutions must act to defend women's equality and eradicate sexist violence by adopting legislative measures, by activating the 'parallel clause' to include gender-based violence between the criminal areas set out in Article 83(1) TFEU. We need approved studies and statistics and a European strategy. It is also important that all States and the EU itself ratify the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Fight against Violence against Women. The Commission must present without further dissemination a new equality strategy that includes specific measures against gender-based violence and follow up on the EP's request for a European Year against Gender-Based Violence.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. – Gender-based violence is a universal phenomenon that affects women of all ages, apart from their education, income or social position. It is a problem that we live today in our societies whose gravity must be addressed taking into account its breadth and complexity. Therefore, each State must necessarily take legislative measures in its domestic systems to prevent and punish such conduct of violence against women.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – The International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women is an occasion to draw the EC's attention to this problem again. National or non-governmental organisations have national or non-governmental organisations to provide hotlines for women, adolescents and children who have experienced violence. Each of the organizations tries with its experience and means to assist those in need. This fragmentation and non-comordination of efforts cannot lead to a single policy, accurate statistics and effective measures to overcome women's problems.  I find that the Rights, Equality and Citizenship programme could finance the creation of a common European platform for quick and easy access to it by all women who have suffered violence. To this end, there should be both an EU-level body and authorities in the Member States to jointly carry out a common policy of preventing and supporting the fight against violence against women.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –All violence against women is an undeniable evil that must undoubtedly be fought and tackled. This is an issue that unites us all. What divides us is the choice of instruments. Each Member State has laws prohibiting violence and providing for penalties for the use of violence. I believe that new instruments, such as the Istanbul Convention or the proposed EU directive on combating violence against women, will do nothing to actually combat violence. Instead, they are mainly used for ideological struggle with the traditionally understood family, with the values on which our civilization is based, used to promote gender ideology.  If violence against women continues to affect our societies today, it is because no law will ever completely eliminate crime. But we can take action to reduce the scale of this phenomenon, which often increases in pathological environments characterised by unemployment, alcoholism and other social problems. By improving the living conditions of these communities, we will reduce the scale of violence, including against women. This is the best way we can help women.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Despite undoubted progress in the area of equality between women and men, gender-based violence, the most radical form of discrimination, accompanies millions of women every day in Europe and worldwide. Violence against women is universal and affects all Member States, which is why the European Union as a whole should develop a common strategy to combat it. The Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women, recognised as the gold standard for anti-violence policies, is one of the most effective legal tools in the fight against gender-based violence. The Convention makes it clear that nothing, including elements of religion or culture, can justify violence, and prevention is rightly based on linking anti-violence policy to gender equality policy. The Istanbul Convention also guarantees the introduction of concrete, effective measures in the fight against violence, such as a 24-hour hotline and shelters for victims of violence or interrogation procedures to protect against secondary victimisation. The popularity of the Convention is evidenced by the fact that 25 EU countries have already signed it, twelve of which have ratified it. In order to support and speed up these processes, everything must be done to ensure that the EU accedes to the Convention as a party. That is why today, on International Day against Violence Against Women, I call on the Commission and the European Council to implement as soon as possible the already outlined plan for the Accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. – Violence against women is a timeless social problem that concerns all the Member States of the European Union without exception. Having succeeded in establishing the protection of basic human rights through the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, such as the right to human dignity (Article 2) and the right to non-discrimination on grounds of sex (Article 21), it is time to deal with the effective implementation of measures at national and pan-European level to effectively reduce what is plaguing today's society.  The european survey by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) carried out in 2014 pointed out that a large proportion of women who have suffered physical and sexual violence do not resort to the Police or other victim support organisations. This leads to the ambiguity and lack of the data necessary to recognise the true extent of these crimes of violence within European territory.  I would like to stress that despite all the legal efforts that have been made to date with the example of Community Directive 29/2012 and the Istanbul Convention, there is much more to be done in order to significantly reduce violence against women, which affects not only the victims but also their social environment.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. Today is International Day against Violence against Women. Today you dress in a precise color, you stick a white pin on your jacket, you read the dramatic data on women who are victims of violence. It is quite right that a day has been set up to remember the women who have been through it, but it is not enough to make any women pass by. When we talk about solutions, we usually focus on the moment when the situation has already degenerated: we must ensure that women find the courage and listening to denounce their assailants, create reception and support structures. When we reasoned about the causes, we talked about machist culture, how to educate men to respect their wives, sisters, friends, daughters. I myself have often written and talked about all this. I still consider this to be valid and important. However, I have learned that to change things we cannot wait for others to change. It's got to be us. Starting with a fundamental point: violence against women is combated by women's employment. It is only through work that we can become masters of ourselves, autonomous, safe.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – Violence against women is an area that must not only remain on the Agenda of the European Union but must also merit the intensification of the instruments that support policies aimed at combating this scourge. The scale of the problem was evident in an investigation by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights in 2014, which surveyed 42 000 women from 28 Member States. The survey results are revealing: about 13 million women were subjected to physical violence in the preceding twelve months, of which 3.7 million were the target of sexual violence. There is therefore no doubt that this issue deserves. Violence against women is an attack on one of the most elementary rights of the human person, it is an attack on fundamental rights, on individual freedom. A European Union that believes in the full development of the personality of citizens and citizens must not fail to intervene so that this kind of attitude can be part of the past.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. – In Europe, 18% of women have been victims of stalking since the age of 15. About 12% of girls have experienced some form of sexual abuse or assault by an adult before the age of 15, and one in 20 women have been raped since the age of 15. Violence against women is still a major problem with a high level of obscurity, as many women do not dare to report it. Violence against women is also often tolerated in society. We finally need a Europe-wide strategy to combat violence against women successfully.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. On this International Day to Combat Violence Against Women, the results of the latest European study are appalling: 33% of European women, 36% of Belgian women and 47% of French women have been victims of physical or sexual violence. The Istanbul International Convention, which would make the fight against violence against women effective and have consistent legislation, has only been ratified by 8 of the 28 Member States.  The inaction of some States makes them accomplices. 33% of women over the age of 15 are victims of physical or sexual violence in Europe, 45%, even if psychological violence is also taken into account. With 36% in Belgium or 44% in France, are these countries more conducive to male violence? "Not necessarily! Indeed, these figures are based on the number of women who end up confiding in themselves about the horrors they have experienced. The countries with the highest numbers are often the ones where victims dare to talk about it the most and override the law of silence," explains the PS MEP.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – The findings of the recent and most comprehensive pan-European survey on violence against women carried out by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights show that this shameful form of violation of women's fundamental rights continues to take varying forms and a huge extent in all countries of developed Europe. At the same time, it is a largely insufficiently reported crime. This means that we still have a long way to go in political and legislative terms to bring this major problem to its true dimension.  The EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, the most comprehensive legal text of international law to date, is considered necessary. Europe must include in all its new policies and strategies on gender equality - in the fields of employment, education, health and new technologies - the issue of combating gender-based violence. We as the European Parliament have an obligation to find more ways to encourage women, victims of violence, to speak out and bring perpetrators to justice, especially in the countries of the European South, where incidents of non-reporting of violence are particularly high.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the outcome of the Valletta Summit on 11 and 12 November 2015 and the G20 Summit on 15-16 November 2015 (2015/2902(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Valletta Summit on Migration has enabled us to give concrete expression to the Union's commitments. Strengthen our political cooperation with African partners at all levels to address the root causes of illegal migration and to combat migrant trafficking and human trafficking. The final declaration and action plan approved in Valletta reflect the success of this approach in advancing dialogue and cooperation with African countries. Let me stress, first of all, the high level of participation of European and African countries. A large majority were represented at the level of heads of state and government. This is a testament to the political importance that everyone in Europe and Africa is attaching to the challenges we are currently facing. Now it is a matter of ensuring that these political commitments also translate into such firm commitments in the implementation of the action plan. I would like to highlight the most innovative aspects of the documents adopted. First, the essentially pragmatic and operational nature of these texts based on a number of well-identified actions in each area of intervention. These actions aim to promote sustainable economic, social and environmental development. The summit agreed on the implementation of 16 priority initiatives by the end of 2016, as the first response.  Secondly, the action plan must be read in an overall logic. The implementation of the various measures must therefore take place in parallel. The five chapters of the action plan are the fight against root causes, irregular migration, legal migration and mobility, protection and asylum, the prevention of irregular migration and migrant trafficking, return, readmission and reintegration. These chapters form a package that fits our joint priorities. Advances in one area will allow progress to be made simultaneously in other areas. Thirdly, the content of the action plan is fully in line with the conclusions of the European Council and the Council on the importance of the return and readmission of irregular migrants. For the first time in the Euro-African dialogue on migration, there is a clear and joint commitment to implement specific measures to facilitate the sustainable return and reintegration of irregular migrants.  As stated in the summit's final declaration, cooperation on return and reintegration can only strengthen Europe's migration and mobility policy, making it more efficient and comprehensive. Finally, we are committed to allocating the appropriate resources to the implementation of these measures using all available financial instruments as well as the New Union Emergency Fund. We have also decided to use the existing dialogue structures, the Rabat and Khartoum processes, as well as the European Union-Africa dialogue on migration and mobility to monitor the operational aspects of the action plan.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on the G20 summit, I would now like to report on the results of the summit in Antalya, to which the Union was represented by the President of the European Council and the President of the Commission. The G20 results are positive for Europeans. There are many points of convergence between the G20 and the European Union in assessing the current situation and the priorities identified. In its statement on terrorism, the G20 condemned the cowardly attacks in Paris and Ankara. He noted that terrorism cannot and should not be associated with a religion, nationality, civilization or ethnic origin. In fact, what was amply expressed this morning during the debate. The G20 also stressed its determination to work together to prevent terrorism by strengthening cooperation in full compliance with the central role of the United Nations and in accordance with Security Council resolutions and the UN's global counter-terrorism strategy. G20 leaders also took an interest in the financing of terrorism and called for the rapid implementation of the Financial Action Task Force's standards in all jurisdictions. In addition, they stressed the importance of a comprehensive approach based on the willingness to address the factors that promote terrorism. I will not dwell on the migration side of the work that I have just referred to on Valletta, so I will focus on the economic issues that have been discussed at the G20 or, less, on some of them. In Antalya, leaders focused their work on the G20's priority objective of achieving strong, sustainable and balanced growth. They reaffirmed their commitment, expressed in Brisbane last year, to increase the overall GDP of G20 countries by an additional 2% by 2018. At the root of this ambition is the fact that global growth is uneven and still below expectations, despite positive prospects in some major economies, including the European Union. At this stage, half of the commitments in the G20 growth strategies, which include both demand support measures and structural reforms, have already been implemented, resulting in more than one-third of the 2% target. In addition to the commitments made in national growth strategies, I would like to emphasize the G20's focus on investment, particularly in the case of country-specific strategies for this year. These strategies bring together concrete measures to improve the investment environment. I am particularly pleased to see that in Antalya, special attention has been paid to private sector participation in small and medium-sized enterprises and financial intermediation and that Antalya's action plan has a direct reference to the investment plan for Europe. Investment is one of our top concerns. In this regard, I would like to welcome the fact that the European Parliament has approved the candidates for the positions of Executive Director and Deputy Executive Director of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. We can now look forward to seeing it become fully operational. On international taxation, which was also on the agenda of the leaders, they endorsed the package of measures concerning the erosion of the tax base and the transfer of profits. They recognized that broad and consistent implementation would be essential to ensure the effectiveness of this project, particularly with regard to the exchange of information on advance cross-border tax decisions. An inclusive framework for the implementation of the BEPS project will be developed by the OECD in early 2016. Taxation is another major common priority for the Eu and the G20 and the Presidency is actively pursuing its work to combat tax evasion and evasion and aggressive tax optimisation. In particular, the Council has recently reached an agreement on the automatic exchange of information on advance tax decisions and this directive will be adopted in December. In this context, the report of the SPECIAL committee TAXE will certainly be a valuable contribution to the continuation of debates in this area. Let me conclude by briefly mentioning the progress or rather the lack of progress in implementing the IMF quota and governance reforms, agreed in 2010. In this area, the top priority for the G20 as well as for the European Union remains the implementation of the reforms, but the United States has again been asked to ratify them as soon as possible, which it has, of course, not yet done. In this area, as in the other areas of work of the G20, the Presidency will continue its efforts to ensure that Europeans follow a common line within the G20 on the issues under discussion and thus protect and promote our common interests in the best possible way. The EU's work ahead of the G20 finance ministers' meeting in Hainan in December is already underway. This will be the first meeting under China's G20 presidency.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, this is not the first time we have met here to discuss the refugee crisis, but at the Valletta Summit we focused mainly on saving lives and fighting the smuggling of human beings, something we have discussed in this very Hemicycle several times, and we did so with our African partners, as there is no other way to effectively manage the current and future migrant and refugee flows. The issue of migration is here to stay. Demography and economy tell us so. The first message that we shared in Malta was this: migration and refugee flows are a phenomenon that concerns both Europe and Africa, as we are all at the same time countries of origin, countries of transit and countries of destination, in Europe and in Africa. There are more migrants and refugees on the move within Africa itself than from Africa to Europe, and we are together in this: in Africa and in Europe. This is the basis of our partnership. Building walls on our frontiers is no solution, and it definitely is not an option in the middle of the sea. That is evident to everybody. It will not stop migration; it will only weaken our international standing and our credibility. The current migratory and refugee crisis has sparked strong emotions in recent months, including in Europe: good ones and bad ones, compassion as well as fear. But our duty as politicians is to act rationally. We must finally put in place a mechanism for human mobility fit for the 21st century, a mechanism that stems irregular migration and the exploitation of human suffering, including through return and readmission agreements, but also a mechanism that allows effective legal mobility to the benefit of both countries of origin and countries of destination, and their societies. Mobility can benefit both Europe and Africa. It must happen legally and safely, not by turning the Mediterranean and the Sahara into mass graves. This is the core message of Valletta and the basis of our partnership, of our common work, with our African friends. To do so, as the Presidency just reminded us, we focused on five clusters of actions in Malta. One: addressing root causes of irregular migration and forced displacement; two: legal migration and mobility; three: protection and asylum; four: the fight against irregular migration; and five: return, readmission and reintegration. We identified within those clusters nearly 90 individual broad actions that we will implement before the end of 2016. Let me be completely sincere with you today; you know me by now, I always tend to be so. The conversation – especially the preparation of the summit – has not been easy at times. It has been tense at times, not only between the Europeans and the Africans but also within the two different groups – among Europeans and among African countries. But I think our discussion has helped us a lot, as we managed to find common ground and an understanding on all the most relevant issues. As happens quite often in our work with our African friends, the preparation was sometimes tense, but the summit itself and the beginning of the follow-up on implementation were extremely positive and fruitful. Our approach to our African partners is not about putting money on the table and asking for readmission in exchange. I am also very clear on this here, just as I was with our African friends. It is not about using development aid as a bargaining chip in our negotiations on migration management. That would not only be against all our values but also against our own interests, because it would not work. The right approach – the approach we suggested to our African friends – is to develop common instruments and the related means, including financial ones, to effectively manage together a complex phenomenon that concerns both Europeans and Africans. We have a common issue to deal with. We have to develop useful and effective tools, and we have to allocate resources to have those tools effectively implemented. It is a partnership. Yes, there is a strong link between how we invest our development money and how we manage migration. That is clear. In the long run, migration will only be manageable if we favour Africa’s growth and stability. This is why in Malta we signed the Constitutive Agreement of a Trust Fund for Africa. As President Juncker mentioned this morning, this has already been on the table as a Commission proposal for some months. But in Malta we actually signed the starting point of this Trust Fund, which is an additional tool to tackle the root causes of poverty and irregular migration. The Commission is putting EUR 1.8 billion into it and Member States have started to top up that figure, and I encourage them to continue to do so consistently – and I underline consistently. It will finance job opportunities, especially for young people and women. It will prop up projects focused on addressing the root causes of forced displacement. It will reinforce the resilience of communities touched by the transit of migratory flows, build capacity in management of refugee flows and migration flows (which are in nature quite different one from the other) and focus too on support to internally displaced people, which are all things that our African friends tell us they need support on, because they themselves are hosting on their territory hundreds of thousands of refugees and migrants, something that as Europeans we hardly realise. At the same time, we have started to draw up a new system to discourage irregular flows and develop dialogues on legal mobility. This includes more cooperation from our African friends on readmissions as well as on the capacity of host countries and host communities to reintegrate returnees. I myself have been in Ethiopia to a project that we finance on facilitating the reintegration of returnees, not in that case from the European Union but from a different region, and I have seen with my own eyes that young women and girls especially – but also young boys, very young ones – if supported, and if their communities are supported in offering them a decent and an open perspective for the future, are not only glad to be back but are also passing on a message to their fellows citizens that embarking on dangerous trips across the desert or across the Mediterranean is not necessarily a good idea. Again, I stress in parallel that we have to strengthen the legal and regular channels for migration, because that is the safe way of tackling mobility among us. The fight against the smuggling and the trafficking and the work to strengthen resilience must go hand in hand. This is the reason why we agreed to implement in parallel the actions of all five clusters; together, not one before the other. The next steps will build on the Rabat and Khartoum Processes – we do not need to reinvent mechanisms, we have to use correctly the existing mechanisms – through a number of meetings at senior official level but also by identifying already now, together with our African partners – not only national governments but also local authorities and NGOs – concrete projects to be financed by the Trust Fund in partnership with all our African friends. In this respect I have engaged in these months in high-level meetings with African partners, from countries of origin and transit, and also themselves of destination. I can quote some numbers that are really impressive. I have done so in Ethiopia, in Niger, in North Africa – all of their countries – and last week again in Chad, where, let me say with a certain pride, for the first time the European Union was invited to the G5 Sahel Summit – just one week after the Malta Summit – which is, I believe, testimony to the fact that the political partnership among us is strong and is getting stronger. We are trying to build a stronger partnership with Africa, a partnership that is fit for the huge challenges ahead. Let me be very clear on this: while we focus on the challenge of migration, we have to keep in mind that we have plenty of other common issues. We need to build a partnership with Africa, because our partnership with Africa is not limited to migration or the management of refugee flows. It is part of a much bigger picture. In the current crisis, governing migration is among the interests we share, Europeans and Africans alike. But again, we have security on our table, we have climate change on our table; we have development, energy, counter-radicalisation and job opportunities for our youth, in Europe and in Africa. We have a proper political – and not only political – partnership that includes plenty of other issues, one in which migration management is one of the pieces of the puzzle that brings us together with them. On all of these issues – and especially on security, but mainly on migration, which is the issue of today’s debate – we can only deal with these different challenges together. Valletta was a first step. We have started building trust between us and also rational solutions that can stand the test of time. This is the challenge of our generation, and the cooperation of this Parliament and of Europe as a whole will be crucial to its success. Also because again, and I stress this, our partnership with African countries is not limited to institutions at governmental level. We also need to look beyond that. The refugee crisis was also part of the discussion at the G20 Summit in Antalya, as was mentioned. The European Union called on the G20 to contribute to a coherent international response to the crisis in the spirit of international solidarity. Our G20 partners acknowledged that the current crisis is not just an issue for Europe but a global one. They agreed to support efforts to protect and assist refugees, including through increased humanitarian aid and resettlement, and to improve the capabilities of international organisations, which is key for us as well. The statement also underlines the need to address the root causes of these unprecedented refugee flows, I stress again, all over the world. Of course, the summit focused very much on the response to the terrorist attacks in Paris. The G20 leaders have unanimously condemned these terrorist acts and pledged to increase their cooperation in the fight against terrorism. As you know and as was mentioned, a separate statement was adopted on this issue. They also stressed the importance of a comprehensive approach to countering terrorism, founded on relevant UN Security Council resolutions, and the UN Global Counter-Terrorism strategy. They undertook specifically to tackle the financing channels for terrorism and foreign terrorist fighters, which we know very well is going to be key if we really want to put an end to this. Let me also address briefly the economic and financial outcomes of the summit. The overall focus was on the continued but uneven global recovery. The euro area was not in the spotlight, thanks to the progress we have made on our own economic policy strategy. The summit focused on developing economies, stressing the risks that raising inequalities posed to economic growth. In particular, the leaders focused on youth employment and pledged to reduce by 15%, by 2025, the share of young people at risk of being permanently left behind in the labour market. G20 leaders reaffirmed the objective to lift the G20 collective gross domestic product by an additional 2% by 2018. Updated national growth strategies were set out in the Antalya Action Plan, which endorses several European initiatives, including the Investment Plan, the Single Market Strategy and the new Trade Strategy. New country-specific investment strategies were adopted to improve the investment climate and policy recommendations on small and medium enterprises financing. This complements our efforts under the European Plan for Investment and the Capital Markets Union. The G20 agreed on a loss-absorbing capacity standard for global systemically-important banks. This is important to ensure that taxpayers do not have to bear the burden of global financial stability in the future. A crucial step forward was made towards a fairer global business tax regime so that companies pay taxes where they make their profits. Leaders adopted the G20 OECD-based erosion and profit shifting package of measures, including mandatory exchange of tax rulings to counter harmful tax practices. I will stop here. I am looking forward to hearing the views of this House, which I always value a lot, but I will have to ask to be excused for now. I have just seen that the scheduled time for the debate is two hours and 40 minutes and as we are late, I am afraid I will have to leave you before the end of the debate. I have asked Commissioner Stylianides to be here for the reply, as I will have to join all my colleagues, not only from the European side but also from the Mediterranean side, as tomorrow we will celebrate together the 20th anniversary of the Union for the Mediterranean. You will understand better than I how relevant this meeting will be, at this particular moment, to send a message of unity across the Mediterranean, across our cultures, across our societies, standing together in front of the many challenges we have migration-wise, but also security-wise. So I apologise if I am not here to respond to your observations, but I will be here most of the time to listen to them very carefully. (Applause)

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, Mr Minister, this migration crisis is not the first facing Europe, but it is the first of these characteristics and dimensions and, of course, we are at the beginning. So let's be realistic. The reasons for the crisis are clear: war, poverty, climate change, hunger, disease, lack of opportunity. Any of us would do our best to get to Europe if we were in one of those situations. As long as these problems remain across our borders, the unstoppable flow of migrants and refugees will not end. That is why the Valletta summit has been so important, because, for the first time, Europe and Africa have looked each other in the eye and told the truth: if we do not change the terrible reality of Africa, it will be impossible to maintain the comfortable reality of Europe. On the other hand, we all share a priority, As Mrs Mogherini has already said: to do what is possible, to save the lives of those who are at risk, by the circumstances in which they live or by the long journey to which they are subjected by human traffickers. And we must congratulate ourselves on the reach of important agreements at the Valletta summit, such as the fight against mafias or cooperation with countries of origin and transit. This summit has also served to approve a trust fund for Africa, which is a major step forward. But let us keep in mind that, without sufficient euros — and the Member States must put them — the results of the Valletta summit will become wet paper. And the same will happen if development aid is left by intermediaries and does not meet their objectives. Let us be realistic, no country in the European Union can stand up to this crisis on its own. We have common problems, but also common capabilities. If we don't use them in common, we'll fail. Ladies and gentlemen, we are a community of solidarity and shared values. For us the words "dignity" and "human rights" have a high meaning. That is why we must make clear, once again, an issue: we cannot mix immigration and terrorism, because those who knock on our doors do so by fleeing terrorism. Just as Europeans spend the twentieth century fleeing Nazism, communism, fascism or war, now many citizens come to Europe persecuted by those same enemies. Refugees are not terrorists, they are their victims. Refugees don't hide terrorists, they run away from them. To be afraid of refugees by terrorists is to make them pay for terrorism twice. With the attacks in Paris, London or Madrid, Europeans are in an extraordinary and exceptional situation. Well, this situation is the daily lives of refugees knocking on Europe's door. It's unbelievable that there are those who don't understand it yet. Still, let's be realistic. We must strengthen our external borders so that no one is tempted to build new internal borders. Schengen is a collective success that we cannot put at risk. States with external borders have a great responsibility to others, and those without external borders must be involved in their protection. There is no country in the world that does not defend its external borders, and if the European Union were to leave its external borders, it would not last a week. In short, Mrs Mogherini, Mr Minister, we have a lot of work ahead of us. This crisis is not going to end tomorrow, nor is it going to end in a year. It is, as has been said, a crisis for an entire generation. Therefore, what we need is not single-summit measures, but a real common policy of immigration and asylum. That must be the effort of the entire legislature.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, Madam Vice-President, world peace is under threat at this time. We must do everything possible to ensure that tensions between Russia and Turkey do not degenerate. An international investigation is needed to understand what has happened, but in the meantime the Russians are refraining from retaliatory action. If anyone thinks that through this incident we can sabotage the construction of a broad alliance against Daish, they are very wrong. We will be united against terror. The European Union's action is decisive: to mediate and to reach common ground, to facilitate an understanding. This is our mission and it is the real weapon against terror. And this is the excellent work that Vice-President Federica Mogherini is doing.  The alliance with muslim countries must not be limited solely to the fight against Isis. In recent decades, mainly because of the bush administration's misconceptions, the area of instability has spread like wildfire and now affects not only the Middle East but also Central Asia and black Africa. Having contributed to the current disaster, the West – and I am referring to our American friends – must not retreat into splendid isolation.  We need an offensive, first and foremost a diplomatic one. We must make it clear to our partners in the region, but also to ourselves, that the time from ambiguity is over. You cannot sanction Daish in words and then tolerate your citizens ing it. We must be clear, even with ourselves. In the past, we have made mistakes in our relations with many Arab countries. The time for double standards is over – it must be over – so radical Islamists are bad except those with whom we do business. On the Valletta Summit, I do not hide our only partial satisfaction, I say this frankly to the Vice-President. We said this yesterday in our group. Progress has certainly been made. However, the tacit exchange between African and European rulers that has characterised our nations in recent years has been re-proposed, at least in appearance. In exchange for some funding, African governments pledged and pledged to slow migration flows. The Trust Fund for Africa is a good thing but currently has little financial resources. You're right. We do not need to make a do ut des but to make a political and economic pact with Africa. That's what it takes! Not a utilitarian approach for us but an approach aimed at enhancing cooperation, with equal dignity, between us and Africa.  I will end on a note that I think is true: we must not be afraid of terrorism. This continent, our Europe, with its history, with its strength, with its resources, has the capacity to annihilate a handful of fanatics and bastards. In order to do this, however, we must remain calm, be united and avoid the mistakes of the past that we are still paying for.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned at the start the issue of Turkey and the tensions with Russia. Would you not agree with me that, as a country of 75 million people – and only about 9% of the land mass is actually in Europe – the worry is that migratory pressures emanating from any Turkey membership of the EU would overwhelm the capacity of European Union countries to absorb migrants and that Turkish accession should now be off the table: no Turkey in the EU?

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a blue card question. Excuse me, my colleague, but frankly I do not understand what the subject of Turkey's accession has to do with the debate we are having. However, I am not at all opposed to Turkey's accession, provided that Turkey complies with the criteria and parameters that we have laid down for any candidate country. It is essential for us that Turkey respects human rights, pluralism of information and respect for the Kurdish minority. It is not a question of how many people Turkey has. If we were to do this, we would have a very simplistic conception of the European Union and the accession and enlargement process.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I welcome a number of the initiatives taken by those representing our interests in Valletta. Whilst migration may not have dominated the news in the last week or two, that does not mean that the challenges we face have faded away. Valletta highlighted the need for more international cooperation, but it also illustrated that Europe needs to harness all of its political will and political persuasion to find solutions for the humanitarian crisis before us. Valletta was an important step, but I believe that, in many ways, there were also a number of missed opportunities. Valletta should be seen only as a starting point for the more ambitious agreements we must arrive at in the future. The missed opportunities I referred to include the need to find agreement on readmission policies. Readmission and returns must form a central focus of our long-term cooperation with our non-EU partners. It is a fact that our asylum systems simply cannot work if these agreements are not in place. Merely having more avenues for legal migration and for more EU funds will not solve the problem. Those legal avenues will never be able to satisfy the demand and the desire to come here. I agree that the economic development of African nations is an important long—term goal for the EU. Development in African countries will provide opportunities and a real future for young people in their own home countries, avoiding skills shortages there and developing those countries as future trading partners for ourselves. But Europe needs solutions now, and Europe needs to stabilise the current situation. Returning those who do not qualify for asylum has to be part of the solution. By reducing the number of economic migrants entering the EU illegally, we increase the opportunities we are able to offer the most vulnerable refugees caught up in the conflict. This was an important summit, and African nations especially have an important role to play. But we will now look to extend the hand of cooperation further afield. We have a crisis of global proportions which requires a global, as well as a European, response.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I have mixed feelings about the Valletta summit. And I would say to Mrs Mogherini: helping and cooperating with Africa – yes, but outsourcing our problems to Africa – no. Not at all! I happen to know – and I gave the figure a few minutes ago – that the estimation is that there are between 12 and 15 million refugees in Africa – between 12 and 15 million! From time to time they do a better job there than we do.
