In Ethiopia, to give that example only, nearly 300 000 refugees have come into Ethiopia from neighbouring countries since the beginning of this year. So helping them, cooperating with them – yes. But seeing them and saying ‘Oh it is now your problem and you have to stop migration’, I say that is not serious. We have to take our own responsibilities. I think at the summit maybe it would be better to do other things rather than trying to discuss readmission agreements that never happen. I have negotiated readmission with Prime Ministers – not one but at least three or four readmission agreements – and they were signed but never implemented in reality. It is a waste of time. For example, I see this afternoon Jean Louis Borloo. Jean Louis Borloo is out of politics now, but he has started a very important initiative – ‘Energy for Africa’ – to try, with private and public funding, to build up something that is absolutely needed for that continent: a huge investment in energy so that every family and every company in Africa has this possibility of having an energy supply. That is the way forward, not outsourcing our problems; not saying: ‘Ah, I tried to take them back’. The way forward is to help them not only by public means, but also, for example, with initiatives like Energy for Africa, where there is a huge programme that is key for the future of that continent. The second thing that we can do and which we do not do – and I am very pleased that the Commission has now published a scoreboard – is to simply do what we have said. Implement what we have pledged. We are the champions of pledging worldwide, but we are maybe the last in the ranking when it comes to paying. There is an enormous difference in Europe between pledging and paying. I shall give you a list I have taken from the scoreboard – and I am pleased that the Commission has started with the scoreboard. We have a shortfall of EUR 1.7 billion in the African Trust Fund. Pledged but not paid. We have a shortfall of a half a billion euros in the Syria Trust Fund. Promised but not paid. Then, concerning the refugees: there are five countries which have taken refugees from Italy and Greece – not more than that. We have been discussing this for months here, but there are only five countries which are doing their job. There are 129 refugees relocated from the 39 600 that have to be relocated from Italy; well, 130 have been relocated. The same in Greece. There are 66 400 refugees – or more, naturally – there who are officially to be relocated. There have been 30 relocated. It is not I who am saying that, it is the scoreboard of the Commission. Maybe it is not all the fault of Luxembourg, certainly not. I am a very big champion of the Luxembourg Presidency, but it is your responsibility to put that to the Council. Finally, let us work on a migration strategy in the European Union, which we do not have, and also on this European border and coastguard. I hope in the December Council that this European border and coastguard can finally be decided by the heads of state and government.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the results of the Europe and Africa Summit in Malta on migration, as well as that of the G20 in Antalya, on global development were poor. Both resulted in general declarations and greetings without specific commitments due to the disagreements of the participating States.  In fact, the only practical result came from the informal summit, immediately after the Malta summit, concerning the granting to Turkey of an amount of EUR 3 billion as a contribution by the European Union and the Member States to the needs of the numerous Syrian refugees residing on its territory. It was a justifiable decision, given the facts of the moment, since Turkey is home to around two million refugees and their maintenance is a major economic burden.  However, yesterday's development of the downing of the Russian aircraft by the Turkish air force retroactively reinforces suspicions about Turkey's role in the Syrian problem. Since it is obvious that this makes it even more difficult for a broad consensus to fight the criminal Islamic State. But unless the Islamic State is fighting, it is impossible to bring peace to Syria and end the refugee drama. Europe must deal more rigorously with the semi-authoritarian Erdogan regime that acts as a troublemaker in the region.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – The Paris attacks, the war in Syria, the Russian warplane shot out of the sky by a NATO member, the total chaos in Libya and, oh yes, the refugee crisis. We have a lot to worry about and you would say that it is precisely at a time when European Member States should count their blessings and invest in cooperation with each other and with neighbouring countries. This is not the time to be selfish or lonely.  And when I hear the High Commissioner say that this was a summit that was not about simply buying it off but about partnership, I think that was the summit that you wanted and that I wanted to have. But when I look back, I see no different from European Member States that were selfish, which were united, a summit that culminated in: how can we use already earmarked development money to stop immigrants? A summit in which Member States were not at all prepared to pay money. A summit where we actually turned over money. We've moved free with jars that already existed.  European countries hoped to strike deals with African countries to take back migrants, to set up asylum procedures outside our borders, to strengthen border controls. And in search of quick solutions, Member States seem willing to turn a blind eye to human rights situations in countries with dictatorial regimes such as Eritrea or Sudan or countries with military regimes that are almost indistinguishable from a dictatorial regime, such as Egypt.  People fleeing violence and oppression and buying off the oppressor can stop a refugee for a short time, but in the long run the situation becomes unworkable. That's what we learned from the past, right? We have bought off Ben Ali, Gaddafi, Mubarak, Assad and if the weekend summit goes ahead we buy off Erdoğan. And what we did in Valetta was help al-Bashir and Afewerki.  Mr President, what you and I want is to act fairly and invest fairly in Africa. Giving people the opportunity to work legally in Europe and not to have to get on those boats. Transform our trade policy, implement our agricultural policy, not clear their seas. That's making sure that people don't have to migrate, but they can if they want to.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, frankly, I still do not understand all these celebrations for the Valletta Summit. The Europe that showed itself at that summit is still a broken Europe and, let me say, frankly hesitant. I all believe that we all agree – or at least almost all – on the need to tackle the tragedy of the migration crisis, cooperating precisely with third countries and transit countries. But if we then look at the reality of what we are putting in place, we have to note that there is only EUR 1.8 billion in this Trust Fund. How many have the Member States of the European Union given? Seventy million euros: nothing! A small tip that can't even clean up a shred of the dirty conscience of their respective governments.  And the doubt, unfortunately, that many States want to interpret this aid for the umpteenth time, in the sense of turning it into a simple stimulus, a sting for repatriation agreements without really addressing those root causes: the fight against hunger, poverty and exploitation, is a doubt that unfortunately remains well founded. Think that as far as I know, Malta has contributed EUR 250 000! I think that the cost of the summit borne by Malta in organising it was far greater than the donations it made.  Nor is there any proper distinction to be made between the other states: perhaps we will find Eritrea compared to Tunisia or very bad examples equated with examples that are virtuous, which, despite a thousand difficulties, are fighting for the affirmation of the rule of law. If we then compare this aid to the EUR 3.1 billion given to Turkey alone for fear that it will again open the taps of the migratory flow in order to put pressure on European policy, as it has done so far, I would say that the comparison is disheartening. I think he was right, Macky Sall, the Senegalese President, when he said that this aid is not enough, that we must instead combat fraud and tax avoidance, which takes eur 50 billion from African countries every year. But if I then consider that we cannot even solve the problem of tax avoidance in our own home, given what we saw yesterday, as far as the TAXE Committee is concerned, since we cannot be credible in this area either, since we still do not even pay the right compensation for the sale of natural resources, the distress is growing. , also taking into account the Schengen Agreement which, in the meantime, as an emblem of European integration, becomes a symbol of a mad race towards implosion, between walls, barbed wire, beatings and clashes between the Member States. I'd say we still don't learn from the past. I would also say this to President Pittella, when he spoke about counter-terrorism without mentioning that our states and our governments are still doing business with the Countries of the Persian Gulf. The situation is serious, indeed very serious: but there is still no seriousness on our part.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – How strange, how completely deprived of all common sense the European Union has been when it opened our national borders to the whole world in our place, is yet another sign of the news that arrived a few days ago, so between the folds of Paris terrorism and martial law in Brussels, Moroccan residents are now buying planes en masse to Turkey. In Turkey they rent a boat and take the Balkan route, the European Union route to Germany, the Netherlands and of course last but not least to Belgium. No question of asylum or fleeing war. Just a matter of a better life. It is true that the price of air tickets is doubled, because even in Morocco the European Union stands for the free market. The authorities of the European Union, the majority here in Parliament, you have held yet another useless and unfortunately implausible summit in a long series of migration summits with an abracadabra of proposals and politically correct newspeak as a result and nothing else. Only more and more immigration.  Last time you went to sword to sink the vessels of the traffickers. This time - with all my respect for your efforts, Commissioner - you were going to give african leaders, the dictators, colleagues in Africa better. Ridiculous just! The problem with your successive peaks is that, like the wizarding apprentice in the Disney cartoon of the same name, you can no longer control the excesses of free movement of people and you continue to tinker on the basis of the same concept, over and over again. Moreover, you govern against the wishes of your own people. Only the Member States can try to regain that public confidence. You failed. You've brought us to the edge of the abyss. And you are no longer credible and no longer equipped with the necessary authority. In other words, I would urge you to withdraw modestly and leave it to the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the Valletta Summit and the G20 in Antalya was once again a Hollywood-style blockbuster where theatrics, smiles and meaningless findings are left.  Listing problems doesn't necessarily mean knowing how to solve them. Talking doesn't mean you're ready to accept or even enforce policies. To declare that you are an advocate of legal migration flows, human rights and freedoms, but to close your borders and put your country at high risk levels by imposing a multitude of prohibitions, shows inconsistency of reasons and actions. Calling Putin into military cooperation against ISIS , but acknowledging sanctions against Russia, shows that you are insane.  Each summit proves that we have a shortage of leaders and an excess of interests of people who supposedly promote democracy and dialogue, but drown out every nationalist voice and avoid talking to nationalist parties. The threat is not nationalist patriotic parties, but ostrichism, patriarchy - when it is in our interest - and your idealism.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think the message from Valetta and Antalya was as clear as it was right. In order to meet the global challenges of our time, the international community must come closer together and share responsibility. Of course, we Europeans must shoulder our responsibilities, as has been pointed out today. However, it is not only the European Union's turn to tackle irregular migration, for example. In this way, the African countries themselves can also make their contribution. It is about better governance, it is about economic growth, it is about creating prospects for young people in their home countries and better involving civil society. As the European Union has been highlighted, we in the European Union are helping to do this in a very concrete way, for example through the Emergency Trust Fund to support African states. In any case, one thing is certain: Valetta is only the beginning of a longer process of systematically tackling the challenge of migratory flows. I would like to make one further comment on the Antalya Summit. This is where the firm signal has been sent that the G20 countries are stronger than terrorism. And this challenge cannot be tackled militarily alone. A large number of measures are now needed. Indeed, the European intelligence services must cooperate better than they have done so far. So-called foreign fighters returning to Europe must be monitored more closely. At European level, including here in Parliament, we must work to complete the current data-related projects, such as the PNR Directive, and also the Data Protection Directive, quickly, and our European agencies, such as Frontex and Europol, should be strengthened. That is why I can only agree with my group's request from this morning's debate: the words, the agreements and the decisions must finally be followed by action!

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has We very much agree with what happened in Valletta. A broad partnership with African states is important for both sides. It is not just about refugees, it is not just about repatriation. It is about better living conditions there and about concrete aid for good governance, aid for the economic development and development of the states for the people who live there – including for refugees. You can't do it without money. I very much hope, Mrs Mogherini, that the Member States will not let you down again, that they will replenish the fund you mentioned with additional payments. Because we have to make our own share, otherwise we will end up getting the bills all at once, and that is what we call the refugee crisis. I also very much agree and believe that the colleague from the EFDD who is just leaving has been wrong. Yes, Turkey must also get money from us. But it is not money for Mr Erdogan to be able to build a new palace, but for the people there – the refugees – to have better living conditions than before, and so that they do not all continue to feel that they must continue to travel to central and northern Europe. You can also live a decent life there for a certain period of time. I believe that this is something that we should support, and I hope that the Heads of State or Government of the Member States will support it at the next summit. There is one point on which I do not agree with you, and I do not agree with you either, Mr McAllister. That is what the Antalya Summit is about. What you said about the refugee issue cannot be surpassed in general places: "The scale of the ongoing refugee crisis is a global one." Wow! "There is a need for a co-ordinated and comprehensive response." "We call upon all states to contribute." No, what we would have expected from the states that have expressed themselves so well there is what they want to make concrete contribution to solving this problem, and there really has been nothing but bubbles on the refugee issue.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: – At the Migration Summit in Valetta, heads of state of the European and African countries discussed the refugee issue. The result is a common action plan. The fight against the influx of illegal immigrants is rightly a top priority, as is return and deportation. It was also agreed that Greece and Italy would improve their asylum procedures. They would also increase their reception capacity.  But these two EU countries have often made empty promises in the past on the registration and reception of asylum seekers. The reality is that the asylum crisis has been raging for over a year. But we still do not have functioning hotspots at the EU's external borders. Greece and Italy have already received many millions of euros, but hardly any migrants are still registered. This afternoon we voted on a new investment package of EUR 1.5 billion, among other things, to address these pain points. But we wonder if the money will be used properly. Mr Tsipras and Mr Renzi, it is now really time for action. No more excuses!

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Mr President, the fight against poverty, aid to minorities in difficulty, the fight against political instability, the role of climate change in the displacement of populations, how many times have these findings not been made?  "Responsibility to protect", the best document from my point of view ever written, at the request of the United Nations, on the correlation between poverty, insecurity, poor governance, inter- or intra-national warfare, had already described the current problem in a relevant way fifteen years ago. While I can only welcome the goodwill of the leaders of the Commission, the European External Action Service, Mrs Mogherini and the Luxembourg Presidency, who have been involved in the preparations for the Valletta summit, it is nevertheless necessary to remain dubious about the enthusiasm of the Member States, to say the least, to assume their responsibilities in implementing the conclusions of the summit. The Member States, at least twenty-five of them, plus Switzerland and Norway, have announced a contribution of 81 million. Compared to the $1.8 billion announced, this is just 6% of the total amount. But who are we kidding? But what do we expect as European parliamentarians to call on Member States to come to our Parliament to account for how they intend to honour their commitment made in Monterey and renewed in 2015 as part of the European Development Consensus in Addis Ababa. From summits to international conferences, from international conferences to summits, the same story is always told of the desire to increase official development assistance to 0.7% in relation to gross national income. We're on the move, the only thing that moves is the deadline. We see the solution on the horizon, while specifying that the horizon is a line that recedes as we move forward. When the deadline arrives to meet its commitments, the Council extends the deadline by fifteen years. Not all of them, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and soon the United Kingdom should be exempted from this criticism.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, with this summit in Valletta, it is claimed to establish an action plan with the countries of origin and transit of migrants to prevent tragedies and address the causes of migration. But what dialogue are we trying to establish? On what subject? With whom?  In fact, aid is increasingly subject to measures to prevent migrants from leaving their country and to re-admit them when they have managed to reach the European Union at the risk of their lives. Yes, it is a matter of outsourcing our policies even more. Aid pledged under the Millennium Development Goals continues to be pushed back. Worse, many Member States, including France, are disengaged and dragging their feet, including to feed the trust fund, which is itself largely abounded by the European Development Fund. Where are the new measures?  Neighbourhood countries are increasingly host countries. Can we continue to turn a blind eye to the living conditions of migrants in these countries? Their rights, including the right to asylum, are decoys and the debate on countries of origin is shifted, ready to cooperate with the worst dictatorships, such as those in Sudan and Eritrea. Not all countries are on the same level. Train Eritrean border guards, strengthen the capacity of the Sudanese justice system, but who are we kidding? Will we go to quadrangular returns between the countries of the Horn of Africa?  Legal channels are closing more and more and mobility is just a beautiful speech. Pragmatism, rationality, you tell us. No! Cynicism and eye powder. I'm sorry, I don't believe it.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, in the Valletta conclusions, you are saying that the first priority should always be to rescue lives, and I can very much agree with that. It is a pity that those calls are usually missing from Council conclusions, unfortunately. It is indeed a very noble call, but what do we see happening in practice? In practice, there is hardly any legal way for refugees to enter the European Union to find the protection that we actually want to give to those people. Refugees still have to risk their lives crossing the Mediterranean in very small boats, and one of the very few legal possibilities for refugees to come to Europe in a safe way is now under attack. That is family unification. We all should be able to sympathise with family unification. No one wants to be separated from their family, and to be together with your family is also a vital part of integration. But now several governments are attacking the possibility for refugees to be reunited with the family they had to leave behind – that they lost on their way to Europe. I think this is outrageous, and it is absolutely inhumane. We should never stop family unification – the right of children to be together with their parents, the right of parents to be together with their brothers, sisters and their children. Currently we do indeed have a lot of refugees in Europe, because there are a lot of reasons why people have to flee. But if we all stood together as the European Union and acted in unison, we could easily face this challenge. Therefore, I want to ask the Council what initiatives it is planning to get all Member States on board to help in facing this challenge in a humane fashion. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: , a question asked by raising a 'blue card'. – Thank you for your vote, but do you not think that the lives of many people are still being put at risk, because we have done nothing to implement the European Council's April findings on the fight against industrial illegal immigration, on the fight against people smugglers' mafias. I am very disappointed with La Valletta, because neither have we heard anything about the implementation of these promises, nor today in President Mogherini's speech. Do you not think that it is time to really take these measures and not to persuade people to go across the sea?

name: Ska KELLER
text: blue-card answer. – Colleague, the most effective way to address traffickers and fight smugglers is to open legal and safe ways for refugees.

name: Petr MACH
text: – Mrs Mogherini, Mr President, the terrible acts of terrorism that have taken place in Paris, what is happening in Brussels, is, after all, the result of a mistaken policy of inviting migrants to Europe.  And I am terribly sorry for how far this policy of multiculturalism has come. I had the opportunity recently to meet the commander of the Kurdish militia in Syria, and she told me that when they liberated one Syrian city from the Islamists, they found a camp where people from Europe were trained, not to fight on the Islamic State side in Syria, but to return to fight in Europe. And we are now being forced into migration quotas. But we cannot accept migrants for one single reason, and that is our own security. If we want to help someone for humanitarian reasons, let's set up a refugee centre in Turkey and let whoever we examine into Europe. We are dealing with the biggest security crisis here, and you, Mrs Mogherini, have decided to damage our main ally in the Middle East, Which is Israel, and force it to mark products. To label them as Jewish products from the West Bank. You don't dare russia to label Crimean products, or China to label Tibetan products, or Turkey to label products from the North Cypriot Republic of Turkey. You dare israel, and I am ashamed of this policy. And what did you arrange in Valletta, Malta? That millions of euros will be sent to Africa to do such nonsensical projects as those financed here in Europe. Why don't you push for a free trade with African countries so they don't have to have orange quotas, fig quotas, date quotas. Why would you rather send them charity and still want to destroy their economy?  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – I would like to ask whether you really do not see any good in this Valletta Summit, one of the ideas of which was really to dam the influx of migrants heading for Europe? That was the idea of that meeting. There were, for example, extremely good projects for the development of population registers and identity cards, because the European Union does indeed want – and I do not necessarily agree – to return the desired immigrants to their country of origin. Don't you even see this as a good thing?

name: Petr MACH
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – That is exactly what I would have liked, but what has not happened in Malta. An agreement with an African country or with Turkey for a refugee facility to be set up there, perhaps financed by the European Union. There for refugees to register and remotely to apply for asylum in Germany or other countries that want them. And to go to these countries after the vetting. But if no one wants them, if they don't get asylum remotely, they wouldn't be able to come to Europe. But this summit in Valletta, Malta certainly did not.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, in the face of migration flooding, the European Union has demonstrated its usual angelism by opening its borders wide. This is no surprise, Schengen is a sieve. However, in recent times, her discourse has changed, and she seems to have been won over by the panic, like Mrs Merkel, who opened her arms to 800,000 migrants, in fact more than a million, before closing Germany's borders.  But, in its panic, the Union has just made two mistakes in the wake of the Valletta and G20 summits. The first is Turkey. The EU gives it three advantages so that it agrees to keep on its soil the 2 million Syrian refugees there, 3 billion euros, visas to allow Turks to enter Europe and the relaunch of the process of accession to the Union. It's too expensive to pay and it's too naively trusting a state that has betrayed us, playing a double game with Daesch. We will lose our 3 billion and we will have in the Union, the Turks, the Syrians and Turkey. The second error concerns Africa. The EU is giving it 1.8 billion euros to help it manage its migration flows and its 15 million refugees. It has thus succeeded in the feat of offending Africans, who have not failed to compare this sum with the 3 billion offered to Turkey. A partnership with Africa of a completely different magnitude should be entered into, including aid for its economic development to secure its populations.  Weak with its false friends, arrogant with its potential partners, the Union proves, alas, once again that it is unable to manage the migration crisis. The conclusion is clear: the Union is no longer credible, it is not the solution to the problem, it is the problem. It is urgent to replace it with a Europe of nations that respects the sovereignty of states.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Both summits have shown what mistakes we have made in the past, otherwise they would not have been necessary. Instead of helping people where their home is, where their home is, today we are dealing with the influx of millions of people. Why are they fleeing? You always talk about flight and displacement, but 80% of them are refugees from poverty. They flee because they have no perspective in their own homeland. I can imagine that Mrs Mogherini is struggling to argue with these countries at such summits. Nor is it given the means to change that. What is the point of giving 3.5 billion to the Turks today to create refugee camps where generations of refugees, like the Palestinians, can live to keep them from Europe? What good is it to talk about repatriation to Africa when people have to run away because they have no prospects for themselves, for their families and for their future?

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by High Representative! What do these two summits have in common? First of all, the key message at each of these meetings is about the migration crisis and its consequences, including the security implications. The EU-Africa Summit aimed primarily at mobilising neighbouring African countries and integrating them into countering both the causes and sources of migration, and was combined with the Decision on financial assistance to African countries of EUR 3.6 billion from the Union in the form of a trust fund. This is a good start to building a policy that is supposed to dry up the sources of migration. At the same time, it is a sad truth that the UN World Food Fund lacks money for food aid. This exacerbates the problems where there are large concentrations of refugees.  Secondly, we are under pressure from events, migratory pressure and acts of terror, such as in Paris. With the protection of the Union's borders still weak. Unfortunately, whether we want it or not, the citizens of many Member States combine security threats with migration. Borders need protection and this is effective, especially in the eastern Mediterranean. Although there are good examples, such as Spanish, where borders are effectively defended and migratory pressures are reduced. We have repeatedly said that legal channels of migration are needed, but these legal channels of immigration are impossible to open if we do not have secure border protection. This is an important task for the Member States, and no one will do this for the Member States, even in cooperation with Frontex. Thirdly, effective cooperation between the security services and the exchange of information is needed in order to effectively counter any negative phenomena, including smuggling, terrorism and money laundering.  (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. If the interpretation was good, and I suppose it was good, and you rightly called it shameful that there is no money for certain of our objectives at European level. I think there's more shame than that. Valettán had the head of government of an EU member state, Viktor Orban of Hungary, who found himself saying afterwards: "All terrorists are migrants." He also had another nice sentence: "The quota - I mean the refugee quota - is only for the spread of terrorism throughout Europe."  What does your party family think of this? Thank you very much!

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – In my speech, Dear Friend, there was no statement that we spend too much money on migration problems. Rather, we can see that these funds are not enough, in particular to counter act in places where sources of migration are being created. That was my intention.  I welcome with some the creation of a trust fund, which concerns in particular the fight against migration in African countries. On the other hand, I have expressed myself as follows, that often migratory pressure and migration itself by some citizens, or by a large and even part of the citizens of the European Union, are associated with security threats.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, with all the dissatisfventures we may feel about the results achieved, it must be acknowledged that the Valletta summit has had at least two positive elements. The first has been to broaden the humanitarian and territorial focus of the problems we face. The second has been to take the only effective, value-based approach we can take: the approach to co-responsibility and cooperation between the two continents.  As we broaden the focus, we have considered that Africa has been, is and will unfortunately remain a continent of displacement, a continent of emigration.  It has been in the past: just a couple of decades ago, by hundreds of thousands, sub-Saharan migrants arrived on or died trying to reach the coasts of Spain or Italy. It will continue to be so because two of the four major humanitarian crises are located in Africa – Central African Republic and South Sudan. It will continue to be because there are other African crises, such as Mali, in Nigeria, in general, throughout the Sahel. It will continue to be because climate change will affect Africa more than any other continent, and it will continue to be because if no one can stop those escaping war, it will also not be able to stop those escaping hunger and disease.  And so, also by broadening the territorial approach, he has found the key to shared responsibility: it is not about money in exchange for returns; it's not about money in exchange for withholding migrants. It's about sharing responsibility and putting in place an action plan that attacks the real causes of emigration.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Europe has forgotten about security. In a fateful way, European leaders have closed in on virtual federalist bubbles and forgotten about the outside world. Today, European states are not capable of defence. We give EUR 143 million to FRONTEX, which protects the external borders, and it costs EUR 32 billion to compare the united States' border protection alone. The Paris attackers were French and Belgian citizens. They are descendants of refugees who have come to Europe, and we must ask why they have not become second and third generations convinced citizens of their states. Where are the causes of the spread of hatred and fear? About 40 million Muslims profess jihad, an armed struggle against infidels, according to research by the British think-tank Quilliam. That is the 40 million people who might want to exploit the refugee crisis today to infiltrate Europe. And thousands of them are really already on our continent.  In our democracy, we have allowed hate preachers to operate in prisons for the thinking of young Muslims. In addition to the winged statements made by European politicians, I have so far lacked sober leadership for the 21st century. Will Europe take extensive security measures, or will we live in fear of which city they will choose next?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I think it is rather pathetic that we are conducting this discussion in this way after a meeting characterised by the fact that the governments of our Member States seem to be completely in the face of the crisis that people around the world find themselves in. All energy seems to be used to protect selfish special interests and no effort is being put into trying to solve the challenges we face. When the world is on fire and people are seeking refuge here in europe, from war, destruction and persecution, the greatest interest of its members seems to be to ensure that no refugee comes to their own country. At least not someone who has the wrong skin color or the wrong religion. You are talking about people in a way that brings back to the darkest epochs in European history. Europe must be better than this. We must be able to maintain an orderly, functioning migration policy that respects the right of asylum in each country. The Dublin Regulation has failed and it is unreasonable to leave full responsibility to first countries of arrival. It is equally unreasonable to continue in this selfish way. Europe knows more, and we should realise that we are the richest continent in the whole world. If we don't do this, who's going to do it?

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that I am facilitated in many of the things I would like to say from what President Mattarella said this morning, in particular by referring to how odious the overlap dictated by a xenophobic culture is between the issue of migrants and the issue of combating terrorism.  I am trying to speak on the merits of the conclusions of the summit we are talking about, I have to say with almost no enthusiasm, because I believe that this summit, as many NGOs say, has basically contributed to a further process of externalisation of borders, rather than support for cooperation, and I also believe that we cannot reason about the root causes of the migration process without talking about the war. , of the wars we have already made in Iraq, Afghanistan, Libya and Syria.  And I address Mrs Mogherini, who accepted Hollande's appeal: I hope that the future of this Union, that its cement, will not be in the call to war, because war feeds more terrorism. The fight against terrorism is being done by building peace and building cooperation.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Swedish Greens' basic position is that all people should be allowed to move, but no one should have to flee. Today, however, the situation is not that, but voluntary migration is a very small part and much smaller than the involuntary one. You call them irregular. I say involuntary, and I do so because the people we are talking about do not actually leave their countries because they want to, but because they have to. They leave because of climate impact, they leave because of poverty, because of conflicts, because of war and oppression, for many different reasons. They are being forced to flee, but at least we should not call them illegal, as was said earlier. You say irregular. I believe that it is involuntary migration that is at stake. I am pleased that the Valetta meeting actually raised the issue of the root causes as the first point of the five points, because these are the root causes we need to work on if we are ever to be able to come to terms with this involuntary migration that is actually at stake.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, so the European Union decision-makers decamped to Valletta. Not a bad destination for a wintry mid-November. But what about those Serbian refugees – 5 000 per day, so they estimate – I wonder how they feel? Deliverables? Quite frankly, nothing. At best, not much. Surprisingly, the European Union has to a certain degree my empathy, namely: constructed policies and plans but overtaken by events. But, European Union, these were events of your own making. Surely the European Union’s own risk and outcome analysis should have identified that a plan effective for a small number of well-educated refugees might work, but for an absolute deluge of economic migrants and some genuine war-impacted refugees it is never going to work. Does anything emanating from the Valletta event change or address what is happening? It does not. Do the carefully-crafted words make it any less likely the individuals will avoid hazardous, death-enhancing journeys for an economic future in the European Union? It does not. The European Union promises to address root causes and fails miserably. Words, words and more words, as usual – in fact, three pages and 2 000 words of nonsensical doublespeak – lots of acknowledgments, recognitions and words like that. Would it not be nice – and honest with our citizens – if, for once, the European Union would admit failure, stop the sticking-plaster approach and definitively halt the people movement and pan—European flow? Yes, it requires a proper rethink, but anything else is merely perpetuating the problem, the outcome and, ultimately, the terminal fractures in the European Union concept, and the latter point is the only one I agree with.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are here talking about yet another pointless extraordinary summit on immigration. But what did you discuss in Malta? But, above all, what are we talking about here today? Today, all of you – the Commission, the Council and the vast majority of Members – should apologise to the citizens of Europe. You who have said for so many years and still today continue to say that immigration is a great opportunity for Europe. You who have not yet understood that we cannot take in more immigrants. You who continue to say, despite the massacre in Paris, that we must welcome, integrate and love us. The one held in Valletta was a table with so many absent Heads of State and those who were present or were silent or deaf. But you, Mrs Mogherini, are optimistic and come and tell us that everything has gone well in Malta, which Europe has finally understood. I ask you: why did it take so many years to realise that identification centres had to be made in Africa? That cooperation with Africa needed to be increased? My group and I have been saying this for many years: unheeded. Your fine words are ridiculous and, unfortunately, you are not credible as Europe is not credible. Now, after what happened in Paris, words are not enough. Action must be taken, done, now and courageously. We cannot wait a year or even a month, we cannot wait for the next summit.  Years and years of senseless reception, without the necessary controls, have allowed thousands of illegal immigrants into Europe, of whom we now know nothing. We are vulnerable because we are unable to protect our external borders and our internal borders are no longer there. Illegal immigrants and Islamic terrorists are quietly circling. Schengen must be suspended immediately without ifs and buts.  A question, Mrs Mogherini: but had you not decided that 160 000 refugees should be relocated immediately? As a result, 150 refugees have left Italy and Greece. And then a courtesy: you have Renzi's cell phone number. Call him and explain to him what country Saudi Arabia is, where he went on 8 and 9 November. It's not a business partner. It is rather a country that finances terrorists; it is a country where Shari'a exists; it is a country where four people were beheaded on the days of his visit! While Renzi had his picture taken with the interior minister, the prince and the king, four people were beheaded. A disgrace to Renzi, but I think it's a shame for her too. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question, Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question. I had already given a sign a few times, because I heard a lot of points here that showed that the solution was not in Europe, whereas we think that the solution lies in more Europe.  Ma'am, you have just said in your speech that we must have less Schengen. My question to you is: do you really think that we can solve the problem by returning to guarding one's own borders? I believe that the solution lies in more Europe, better protection of external borders and better European intelligence.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Given that my passport was checked when I came here to Strasbourg – rightly so! I think it is right to control the borders, because the terrorists went unpunished, from Belgium to France and also came to Italy. Those terrorists have come near my house and therefore, for the sake of security, for the sake of the citizens, the controls must be there: less freedom but more security.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by If the restoration of the old borders were good, it would be even better to make the boundaries between Bavaria and Württemberg, between Champagne and France, between the Basque Country and Spain. There are still old walls around Paris. I propose to renew these walls and put the guards on the walls so that they make sure that no one goes to Paris. This is the logical consequence of what you are saying. We have to do something different, we have to not be intimidated. Ladies and see, 130 people are killed in Paris, 4,000 people are killed under the wheels of cars every year in France. Cars are 30 times bigger problem than terrorists, and we don't hysteria because of cars. We cannot be intimidated by terrorists, we are supposed to do business as usual and end. We must return to European values, that we are not afraid of death, we must reject the acquis communautaire, restore the death penalty for terrorists of course. It cannot be that they can kill us and we cannot kill them. We must go back to Europe, reject the European Union, go back to Europe.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, at the Valletta summit, Europeans and Africans concluded a political declaration and an action plan. But, on reading, these measures are totally derisory and disappointing in view of the urgency and seriousness of the situation.  Africa's population is 1.2 billion, and within 30 years it will have an additional one billion. The European Union is currently facing an emergency: to stabilise the migratory flow. But it must also foresee the future and, if Africa fails to develop, there will be even more migrants, more young people who, all connected, will seek their future in Europe, which is still the eldorado in their eyes. Today, two-thirds of Africa's population does not have access to energy and light. Access to energy is access to water, access to clean water, access to health, education, employment and security. Yet Africa has real potential for renewable energy development. What it lacks is the capacity to invest. So what to do? The G20 has recognized the urgency of limiting global warming to two degrees in 2100 compared to the pre-industrial era, but will COP 21 be able to resolve the funding issue? We need $100 billion a year by 2020. Help third countries move to a decarbonized economy.  If we want to reduce and stop the migration flow, Europe must help African countries, help them educate their children, train their youth and provide them with local employment. But no development is possible in a modern world without energy. Too much time has been wasted.  So, yes, the Member States must take urgent and decisive action, otherwise future generations in Africa and Europe will blame us for our immobility. In return, African states must do all they can to be partners in the European Union and fight terrorism, illegal immigration and radicalisation. Finally, it is time for the Union for the Mediterranean to be not just an empty shell.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, from Valletta I want to take a message: the European Union remembered that it was close to Africa and that Africa's development conditions were an issue for it. Thank you, Madam Vice-President, for reminding us that we are not going to haggle, to negotiate this aid for Africa's development in exchange for a halt to migration. These are two very distinct cases.  Europe has a responsibility to Africa. I remember a time when Member States were mobilised to implement the resolutions they had taken together to provide 0.7% of their GNP assistance for the development of spaces, such as the Economic Area of Africa. These are numbers that we don't even quote anymore! We must rediscover this trend, this ability to cooperate with those who are struggling in regimes and in regions that do not know economic development in a serene way.  From the G20 summit, I accept the commitment to combat the financing of terrorism. So, as Europeans, we have to go further. We have to be consistent. When we ask here for country-by-country information, what do we ask for? We are asking that our multinationals pay their taxes where they make their profits, here and there. These are very concrete measures that, in the spirit that prevailed in Valletta, we could implement. Similarly, when we call for an end to imports of minerals from conflicting regions, we are contributing to fair remuneration, appeasement and economic development, under better conditions, of Africa.  This is our responsibility: to continue tirelessly the work for a renewal of cooperation, in the interest of Africa and in ours as well, with a mobilization against this crazy finance, this taxation that escapes the interest of European citizens, but also of Africans.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The summits of Valletta and Antalya have not produced any landmark results. A steady stream of migrants is still reaching Europe, and disagreement in the EU is deafening. As more and more countries close their borders, Mrs Merkel wants to open Europe to all. The more sensible ones among EU governments are not taking part in this. The EU in particular is dependent on cooperation. Merkel's single-handedness has done enormous damage here. It is astonishing that virtually the entire German Bundestag, which otherwise argues very pro-European, accepts this permanent damage to the EU. It would be helpful if the parties in Germany were to take note of the European reality and the different opinions of our neighbours.  The quotas now demanded by Mrs Merkel and propagated in Germany are just another word in favour of raising ceilings. One is slowly oneanother of reality – in Germany and in Europe. It would be better, however, if we were to move forward with courage instead of just just running behind.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: Mr President, a hope, a statement, a good thing.  A good thing, let us first of all - and say it loud and clear in front of Mrs Mogherini - the organisation for the first time of an EU-Africa summit, putting each other on an equal footing at the same table. A somewhat half-hearted observation, and many of us said this tonight: we are making big announcements. We are announcing summits, international conferences, a G20 that has been put on the agenda for the first time. But what is the record? As both have said, these meetings do not present results that live up to expectations, nor live up to the essential and fundamental questions that are put to us. However, these opportunities could have been used to provide realistic responses to emergencies. And then, of course, a hope that Africa and Europe have destinies that are not strictly common, but which are inextricably linked and which require us to cooperate more and consolidate our approaches. In conclusion, before giving lessons here or there and especially to African countries, Europe must show its ability to manage in a humanistic and appropriate way the strategic issues that are ours, in particular the migration crisis with the countries of Africa.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, well I do not know about the rest of you, but the conclusions from the Summit did not fill me with optimism at all. Were they the best that they could come up with? When I read through the conclusions I must say I despaired – and how dare me, with the life that I have. Throw a few jobs and scholars at the people who are being persecuted – to entice them to stay in conflict zones? To try and help to stop the flow of irregular migration, what we need are immediate, meaningful steps to address the humanitarian crisis at Europe’s borders. The people fleeing these conflicts and oppression from Libya, from Eritrea, from Yemen, are not ʽirregularʼ anything. They are not migrants. They are desperate human beings attempting to escape the horrors of war. They are refugees that need safe and legal access and routes. They are refugees who need their fundamental rights, and freedom, and dignity protected by the EU. The scenes of a 3-year-old boy, washed up on a beach like a wave – he should never have been found dead on a beach. He should have been playing on a beach, and we should never forget that image. Therefore, it is up to us, and we have a responsibility and a duty to do much, much more. Those conclusions were absolutely shameful! Disgraceful! We should all hang our heads in shame if that is what we are recommending to address this awful problem. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. – I am very impressed and i too have obviously been very touched by the images. This lady talks about what needs to be done and who should do what. But my question to this lady is: what does she do herself? How many refugees has she taken into her home at this time to lead by example?

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: blue-card answer. – Unfortunately for us in the north of Ireland it is a reserved matter, which means it is still in the hands of the British Government. However, our government in the north of Ireland has said that we will take a thousand, and by now we are still putting things in place. Work is being done by the Executive, by the Office of the First and Deputy First Minister, by the Department of Social Development (DSD) and by many groups and organisations which are obviously prepared to do a lot more than you have done, because that image obviously did not affect you enough.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is astonishing that all of a clear time, when many people are coming to us, there is much more talk about combating the causes of flight, that this is suddenly booming. I remember that For many years, like many others, I have spoken of the need to increase development cooperation, to combat the real causes of flight: an unjust trade policy, an unjust fisheries policy, the European Union's agricultural policy. But back then, I always felt like talking against rubber walls. All of a clear now, the suspicion is that the main aim is to deter the refugees, to isolate us and to say: please do not do any more. There are promises – indeed, also at the Valetta Summit – how much money will be paid now. But where can we believe that this is finally coming? The promises to pay into the Climate Fund – now, just before Paris? How can we believe that this will really happen if, for example, the 0.7 target for development cooperation has never been achieved in the past? We need action here, not just new promises!

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let us be clear about this, ladies and gentlemen: at these summits in Antalya and Valletta, an opportunity has been missed, especially with history. Because they could be summits where we were marking red lines, where we put firm points for the future and summits that could be talked about, in the future, as moments when something has changed.  However, nothing has changed since these summits. It was the time, it was an opportunity to discuss the root causes of emigration and to focus precisely on what may be the policies of the future and to avoid these great migrations, especially from Africa. But they were also summits where economic priorities could be discussed, those who finance the large global arms market; you could mark a red line not to be crossed to understand what is behind the great terrorist movements and the great migrations.  An opportunity with history has been missed; an opportunity that could have been a moment that we would remember in the future has been missed.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would have expected, on the part of the newly released High Representative, a few clear words, after everything that has been said in recent days about the grand coalition, about the criminal act, an act of war being waged by the Turkish caliphate against a Russian aircraft on a counter-terrorism mission. Yet this statement, this position, has not been made, at least in this House, and I regard it as a very serious and very significant fact. Europe continues to be cowardly and continues to trust Caliph Erdoğan, think about it!  With regard to the African summit, I can say that if Europe's African policy emerges from the results of the Valletta Summit, God forbid! Practically absolute nothing. There is nothing concrete about the re-dents: yet there is the Cotonou Agreement which should safeguard our rights and see them respected. The High Representative keeps talking to us about his African friends; I'm glad he's got all these friendships, because friends are clearly spoken of. So African leaders need to be clear about re-dents. Because this is an obligation to which they are also bound by agreements concluded under the aegis of the African Union. But no one says that. No one, speaking of Africa in this House, spoke of the waste that in these decades of post-colonialism has been made by multinationals on Africa's goods, mineral and natural resources, which is the cause of immigration. The Pope will certainly talk about it. We must await the results of the Pope's excellent and important visit to Africa to hear words of condemnation, which perhaps even from this House, starting with the High Representative, could have been expected and then the conclusions of the G20: painful, grotesque! The biggest concern has been to say that it is not Islamic terrorism: a disgrace! Fallaci was right: this Europe is and remains cowardly!

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we here are wary of saying that there is no link between terrorism and immigration. In some respects it is true, but we also know that it is precisely this link between terrorism and immigration that has already shifted public opinion heavily, for example, to France. It will not be enough for us simply to repeat: 'there is no link between terrorism and immigration' to change this perception and then to be true to the end. We explain this by saying, for example, that many of these terrorists are European citizens who were born in our cities, who grew up in our neighbourhoods.  Yes, it is true: but if we have not been able to integrate these citizens who have arrived, who have grown up here, how are we going to welcome these many who are coming and that we should welcome and integrate? What? By what model? We have to take a reality bath because we have tolerated the intolerable. We tolerated shari'a practicing and applying in our neighborhoods. There is an extraordinary association in Italy that helps Islamic women, which for years and years has been telling us that many women come from their countries and have a worse life in Italy than they would have had in their country. That polygamy is to somewhat tolerated by us, for example, whereas in their countries it is now banned. It is a crazy contradiction but we have tolerated it. Then we must get out of this cultural relativism. We must go out and I quote Carlo Nordio again, which I mentioned today, because we are in danger of renouncing our freedoms: "It has never been – nordio argues – so serious and current the danger, which does not reside in the legal measures announced by Paris or in even the most restrictive ones being studied and approved. The risk, on the other hand, stems from the insidious progressive abdication that Western culture has been exhibiting towards so-called different cultures for years and perhaps decades".  We must recover from this disease, otherwise ten or one hundred thousand Valletta summits will not be enough to solve the problem.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Thank you, President-in-Office. Africa is in a state of war, the Middle East, Europe is in a state of war. Hundreds of thousands of desperate people are fleeing to European soil today. We are still shocked by the brutal attacks in Paris, the new threats of terrorism. If we don't react together, if we surrender to fear and start railing with walls, it won't protect anyone. Countries have already built more than 235 km of fences on the Union's external border, and we have paid more than €175 million. That didn't stop people, it just diverted them to other routes, the Balkan route, where the situation is boiling today! Today, at the initiative of Slovenia and Croatia, the leaders of the Western Balkan countries meet in Zagreb. In recent weeks, Union leaders have taken a series of measures, including in Valetta, raising funds for emergency aid, establishing safe and legal routes to Europe, moving, registering people. But where are these promised actions today? The chaos on our borders is getting bigger every day. Many countries, including my Slovenia, feel that they are left to themselves. I am concerned that most of my fellow citizens today believe that fences are the right solution.  Europeans are losing confidence. Countries no longer trust each other, we place our responsibility on each other. We'll all pay the price.  The refugee and migrant crisis is an exceptional challenge for the Union, but it is far from being a threat to its existence. If they could manage immigration, they'd also be able to identify security threats before they even happen. If we do not know, countries will continue their own policies, which lead to very dangerous isolation rather than integration. Then Schengen will be seriously compromised.  The europe of the future awaits the even greater challenge of integrating people into our society, who are and will remain on European soil, and we do not want to create a new ghettoisation, from which the problems of youth radicalisation, where violent extremism is growing, are now ing. I recommend seeing the film Mediterranean, which was among the finalists of the Lux Prize yesterday, about illusions and stereotypes.  Italian President Mattarela said here today: no country will be able to cope alone, no matter how proud or strong it is. And I agree with him.  Let us act as long as it is time for Europe, for Africa, for all people who have the right to live in peace and stability anywhere.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – Unfortunately, I think that, in general, the 5-point action plan for the Valletta Summit cannot be implemented properly, because the money is much less than, for example, in a deal with Turkey, for the resettlement of refugees and the protection of borders. And why is this happening? This is because the political career of some European Union leaders depends on the ability to stop this Turkish-Greek border crossing. In my view, the 5-point plan, however, should have been to quickly return those who do not acquire refugee status. The longer they remain in their illegal status in the European Union, the more they submit to the threat of criminality of extremism. The G20 In the climate that was in the context of terrorism, about his roots, I think that the citizens of the European Union do not believe that jihadists in Europe grow up for generations and are the only ones who live in Europe and are EU citizens, and no potential jihadist is among those who enter this year during illegal migration. I also do not believe that, by bringing together these families with related ties, those who will enter the EU this year, combined with those who have already lived here, will reduce the acceptance of jihadism in the European Union.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, I would have really liked to have welcomed the results of the Valletta summit, but unfortunately I was hungry. If the final declaration is full of good intentions, the action plan that concluded it is in fact a motley package that juxtaposes rather than integrates the demands of some and the reluctance of others. In short, disappointed Europeans, frustrated Africans. Small balance sheet!  And, frankly, I cannot find that the creation of a 1.8 billion euro trust fund deserves the dithyrambic praise of some. This sum is paltry compared to the real needs and future needs of the African continent. It is paltry compared to the 20 billion we already inject each year for the benefit of African development. In general, we do little for the countries that are managing, improving and really helping us. I am thinking, in particular, of Morocco and Tunisia. On the other hand, we will give three billion to a country, Turkey, which allows smugglers to act freely, which shamelessly takes advantage of the daesch oil trade, which bombs the Kurds and which, by shooting down a Russian plane, to mortgage the creation of a grand coalition against Daesch.  There is a real question to be asked.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Mr President, yesterday was a sad day for everyone who believes in a Sweden and Europe that take responsibility and welcome refugees. A beacon of hope for many refugees, Sweden turned off its lights and decided to more or less close borders and all but stop the so-important right to family reunification. A colleague spoke about it earlier. My party does not share this decision – this is not the way forward. It is not the way forward for Sweden and it is certainly not the way forward for Europe. Nor are the Valletta actions the way forward. What is taking shape is a regime for holding back refugees, making African countries a buffer zone, making them responsible not only for holding but even for stopping refugees. The focus on smuggling, on fighting irregular migration, on returns, on cooperation with dictatorships such as those in Eritrea and Sudan, are proof of this. This is not the way forward. I repeat that we have to find a way forward, and the focus should be on finding legal ways. But also we also have to strengthen our capacity to receive the people seeking protection and to share this responsibility. And so my question is very honest here: why are the Council and the Commission not putting all – and I mean all – their efforts into this point? Where is your priority list heading? It should not be to outsource our borders, it should be to receive refugees in a dignified way and to share that responsibility. (Applause)

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – So, valletta and G20 meetings. Once again, it has been politically correct to mention that terrorism cannot be associated with any religion or ethnic group. I would like to point out that terrorists apparently do not read messages very much or listen to press conferences, because in recent days there have been videos in the public space, when one great god is necessarily mentioned against the background of various conflicts. Gentlemen, neither Europe nor the countries surrounding it and the problems arising from them can no longer be seen through pink glasses. Fundamental decisions must be taken today and there is a need for immediate return to their countries of origin for persons who have crossed the external borders of the European Union without identity documents. There is a need for permanent controls and surveillance at the external border of the European Union. Decisions on the amortisation of the effects of a weakening economy are needed. And terrorist actions and the fight against them do not serve economic growth.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – The expectations of the naïve Europhile elite for the Valetta summit were high, as deals would be made with African countries so that illegal immigrants would be taken back immediately. The flow of illegal immigrants from Africa would now be really contained. But, Mr President, of course, in line with the general failure of the European Union, nothing has been done about this at all. Because, of course, the whole of Africa was only after one thing. More money from the Europeans and they have received it. Hundreds of millions of taxpayers' money on top of the billions africa already receives was pumped into a trust fund. But it wasn't just taxpayers' money to keep African countries happy. No, Africa also gets simpler visa procedures.  This summit has proved to be a major fiasco. Billions are going to Africa again, and as a thank you, more African fortune seekers are coming to the European Union. And if it is up to my party, the Party for Freedom, not a penny more to go to Africa and we spend our tax money in our own country and close our borders.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. We are past the Valetta Summit, and the difficult weeks of the migrant crisis in itself are now overshadowed, to say the least, by the terrorist attacks in Paris, but I can say that it is being overshadowed. I believe that it is necessary now to talk about the lines behind the intremies of popular movements. I ask you, have we been struck by lightning in this series of events that we are witnessing or expected? The experience of the Arab Spring was clear in terms of the extent to which democracy can be exported to areas where presumably the conditions are not yet met. It also follows from this failure that social theories about Western prosperity, which enter the spiritual mainstream, and the popularity of these theories have led to the current migration of people. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. We are now at the fortn running a race against time for Schengen, for the rescue of Schengen. I heard with a bad taste in my mouth that we were starting to talk about mini-Schengen, as if we had given up on this competition in the first place. You can't give up a race, you have to fight to the very end. Schengen, free movement, is the part of European integration that we can say every citizen feels within the European Union. This is an achievement that, if it fails, fellow Members, everything can fall! We must therefore use all means to protect this EU symbol. It is a regrettable fact for me that the European political elite always defends its dead-end policy by saying that terrorists, terrorists in Paris, are not fresh migrants, but second- and third-generation immigrants, so the policy of open doors is not dangerous and does not need to be changed. But the point is that the generational explanation is that Muslims who settled in the 1970s were looking for jobs and prosperity, but not the current migrants. I ask that we review our theory so as not to put the EU acquis at risk. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'Blue Card question' (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned – in translation at least – that, if Schengen falls, that is the end of the European project. Well, for a country like mine – the United Kingdom, which is outside Schengen – that is slightly bizarre. It is saying that we should not really be in the European Union at all. I have no problem whatsoever in showing my passport when I cross back into my country. It is perfectly clear, sadly, that Schengen, no matter how well intentioned, was facilitating the movement of criminals, terrorists, arms and weapons, with no border checks. But also there was no exchange of information between police forces and security services and a weak external border of the European Union. Clearly, you cannot have this. You either have to have a strong external border and a Schengen or, basically, the reintroduction of national controls. My country also has a problem now because of what is happening in Calais. So how can you say Schengen is indispensable to the European project? Explain, please.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Blue card answer. " Thank you very much, Congressman, for your question. This is not about passports, Congressman, this is about the internal market. It is that one of the european Union's greatest opportunities is to complete the internal market. There is a technical part to this, including Schengen. If it's just about the passport, I'd be happy to show you my passport when I'm going to your country. As a matter of fact, citizens understand little of the internal market, but they can easily understand the existence of Schengen. What we do agree on, however, is that we are legisming in order to comply with it, and we are sitting here to talk as much as possible about economic growth and job creation, which requires the internal market and Schengen.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, I was proud to represent the S&D Group in Valletta. I greatly appreciate that it was our own former colleague, Prime Minister Muscat, giving such European leadership, and I was inspired by efforts to find solidarity between Europe and Africa in tackling the refugee crisis. We do need more, not less political will, and we must not be deflected by the terrorism outrages. Refugees are the victims of violence, not its perpetrators. Did the summit fall short? Of course. My Group argues for safe legal routes for migration as an essential part of combating illegal migration. We are in favour of a more-for-more approach but do not see sufficiently more. We are opposed to tied aid conditionality and insist there must be genuine new money, not recycling of existing development assistance, if new cooperation from our partners is to be expected in return. We need high numbers to be resettled when developing countries already house over 86% of the world’s refugees. In seeking readmission agreements, Europe must be far more robust in standing out against any suggestion of forced return. The long-term solution to the refugee crisis can only come in conflict resolution, sustainable development and good governance, which prevents people from wanting to leave their homes in the first place. Last month I met refugees, not in Africa but in Lebanon, but all were parents seeking to save the lives of their children. There are no waves, no walls and no watchtowers high enough that would prevent those families from fleeing. Which of us would do differently? We meet today as the fragile European unity on this issue, including from my own country Great Britain, appears to be approaching a breaking point. There are those opposite who celebrate European disunity and who would close European borders altogether. The way we resist those political pressures on this side is through respect for international law and by appealing to the basic humanitarian instincts amongst the people we represent and which we feel ourselves. There must be order, there must be fairness within our societies, there must be integration, but above all there must be humanity. That is why we say ‘refugees welcome’. We say it today, we said it yesterday and we will say it tomorrow. (Applause)

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Mr President, the European Commission's decision to stop refugees still in Africa is good. But only so far. How long will Europe be just the piggy bank and pay a "peace of mind" fee? Instead of money to protect Europe's borders, we will pay for social programs in Africa. Europe should form a coalition with Russia, with the United States of America against the Islamists, not pay for the social systems of corrupt African regimes. If so, we even need to bring the debate on the introduction of the death penalty for terrorists back to the European Parliament. Why did you promise the European Commission to Turkey to support them for Turkish Stream, to sell Russian gas as Turkish to Bulgaria and Europe? They made the decision "in the dark" and without debate in Parliament. Shame! Erdogan brazenly racketeering three-and-a-half billion a year to protect us from refugees. Are we turning this sultan into a European king? At the same time, we hear the information that it is his regime that trades with the Islamists and buys oil.  Stop supporting Turkish Stream. Let's not kiss Turkey. We need more money from countries like Bulgaria, which are members of the European Union but are dependent on Turkey and Russia.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, the tragic events in Paris are all too often wrongly linked to the asylum crisis. I would like to make it quite clear that one has nothing to do with the other. However, I also find it difficult to talk about emergency measures when what we really need is a long-term plan. That is precisely the point that I am missing from this summit. Some Member States still believe that the European problem has nothing to do with them. However, because it is a European problem, it affects us all, and it can only be solved together. It also seems to me that everyone is hoping that winter will give countries some breathers. But it is unlikely that the increased risk of refugees should be used to make us sit back. I would also like to clearly support the efforts and efforts of the High Representative and to stress that the summit commitments of the Member States must finally be called for and implemented – both in terms of the money pledged and the staff pledged. I believe it is time for us to stop announcing and actually get it implemented.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, thank you very much and for introducing Greece, I must tell you that the European Union's management of the crisis appeal is also described in one Greek word, common in most European languages: hypocrisy. It is hypocritical to maintain the Dublin Agreement; it is hypocritical to say that FRONTEX oversees Europe's external borders; it is hypocritical not to admit that refugees come from wars in which we participate or even provoke them; it is hypocritical for the G-20 to meet in Turkey to tackle terrorism and refugees and not to talk about it; Turkey's role in this matter; it is hypocritical to justify Turkey shooting down the Russian aircraft because it violated Turkish airspace when Turkish aircraft violate Greek airspace every day and Mrs Merkel proposes joint patrols; it is hypocritical when 160,000 refugee relocations were decided and all that has happened, it was bad propaganda involving Mr. Schultz. , Mr Avramopoulos and the Prime Minister on the relocation of thirty, I repeat thirty, refugees from Athens to Luxembourg. But Commissioner, as B kurt used to say, when hypocrisy gets poor quality then you have to tell the truth.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, the Valletta summit was supposed to address the current migration crisis from Africa, the Middle East and beyond. Now, the causes of migration are poverty and conflict. Africa and the Middle East languish in poverty because of their endemic corruption. Some parts have the added problem of centuries-old murderous conflicts between rival factions of the religion of peace and love. The summit’s action plan could be boiled down to two main points: to give another EUR 2.5 billion to these countries, and to open up migration to yet more millions of people.
