The idea of giving aid to impoverished countries is not wrong in itself, but the last thing that we should do is give money to their irredeemably corrupt leaders and governments. Aid should be spent on programmes that directly help poor people in health schemes, infrastructure development, and encouraging economic development. As for opening up what are called ‘regular channels to migration’, this is a betrayal of the peoples of Europe. Living standards are already declining in Europe for various reasons: wage depression because of never-ending waves of cheap migrant labour; the economic idiocy of the eurozone and its austerity policies; competition for social benefits from people who have never paid in a penny in contributions; and the unaffordability of housing because of an artificially-fuelled and never-ending demand on a finite supply. The EU’s response is to open up the borders to yet more millions of poverty-stricken people. It is ironic that Valletta is named in honour of Jean de Valette, the Grand Master of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, who led Malta’s successful defence against the Turkish invasion in 1564. He made an heroic stand. The EU is making a shameful capitulation.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to know, but at these summits, what do these gentlemen eat when they are there? They drink champagne, they eat caviar? How much does each summit cost, given that the results are zero? Let's send them to a hostel instead of these beautiful and expensive places; let them eat with packed dinners and lunch, so at least they will be less pests than they normally are. I used to hear about violence against women. But why is there no mention of the infibulation of Islamists to Islamic women? Here four communists come to tell us what we need to do, but Islamic women are silent about what they suffer from Islam. Or why does this West, which talks so much about not helping those who finance Isis, then give the World Cup to Qatar, which is one of the financiers of Isis?  These are the crap of a Europe that ostriches and puts its head in the sand and then, in fact, does its things under the counter with everyone. This is a Europe that literally sucks at me.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have spoken since the last mandate about the need for the European Union to put in place genuine migration diplomacy. Now we're there. The Valletta Summit clearly set a milestone in international cooperation on migration, for the implementation of joint and multidimensional policies. This must mark a point of no return in a more regular and balanced dialogue with our African partners, but also with other key partners in the Mediterranean and the Middle East, to meet our shared responsibilities. The revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy is also a good opportunity to do so.  With this action plan, the challenge of adopting a multidimensional approach was met. It is a very comprehensive document, but most of the commitments made reflect objectives that have been the european development policy for years. Eleven EDFs and our results were not enough to stem the massive departures. Our development policy can become more economically effective. I would also like to point out that this is an imperative in view of the revision of the Cotonou agreement. Three things I want to emphasize. First, regional integration and capacity building of partner organizations such as the African Union and Africa's regional economic communities. The European Union must support regional mediation efforts and do more in conflict prevention, including through the African peace facility, an instrument we do not know enough about. Second, the promotion of the potential of links between migrants and their community of origin. As outlined in the action plan, remittances must be effectively used for the development of countries of origin. Which brings me to my last point: circular migration. We cannot prevent people from leaving situations of conflict or misery, but we must think in the medium and long term of the incentives for return, because the development of the African continent also depends on the development of human potential, which is indeed the continent's first economic resource. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tim AKER
text: blue-card question. – How can you talk about diplomacy when it comes to migration when this Union, Chancellor Merkel, threw open the doors and said: come one, come all? This Union, and the political leadership of this Union, have decided that there is going to be a free for all. So how can you say that we should do X, Y and Z to curb the flows, when the political leaders of the European Union have basically said there is an open door? You have not restricted the pull factors and it will turn into a free for all.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: "blue card" answer. Mr. Aker, I am not sure I understood the question correctly because it seems to me that it raises two completely contradictory aspects as a question.  In any case, my position is very clear: no Member State can face the challenge of migration alone that we are trying to meet today. Only unity is strength. Therefore, today, it may be high time to learn from what has just happened to us, precisely because we have not been sufficiently united and united. Let us move forward and stop the statements or the contradictions and amalgamations. Now there is room for action and, above all, for common actions.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, first of all, three key words: urgency, urgency.  Yes, there is an urgent need to allow significant funding related to migration. It is true that in Valletta, the heads of state and government laid the foundations for an unprecedented management of the migration situation. This amount of 1.8 billion euros is planned to create a fund for the development of Africa. Yes, it is necessary, but it is not enough, Commissioner, Minister.  It is clear, as Commission President Juncker said recently, that much more needs to be done, namely doubling the stakes. In addition, 78.2 million euros have been put on the table so far. Once again, unfortunately, we feel that words trump deeds. However, we know what is at stake in our aid in Africa's development. We need a Marshall Plan for Africa. It takes 250 billion euros of work to electrify Africa. So it is a program in eight to ten years that we have to allow. It is 5 billion euros of public subsidies a year that we have to find for Africa.  The European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council must therefore mobilise, not only to combat this migration, to enable the development of Africa, but also to fight terrorism. When we see Boko Haram in Cameroon a few days ago, when we see Mokhtar Belmokhtar being the author of the Bamako killings a few days ago, that is the need that on the occasion of COP21, all of us as much as we are, we are there to allow a resolution to take into account this important funding, this Marshall Plan for Africa.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Buddy! I agree with you that words are more important than deeds, and this project, which would be called the 'Plan for Africa', is a very good concept. But do you not think that until it is established, until such a project and plan – a concrete one that is not talked about, empty, complete hypocrisy – until we have worked it out, we should consider sealing the External Borders of the European Union and the possibility of readmission of immigrants?

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: "blue card" answer. "Madam, excuse me for telling you, I think you have not understood the economic stakes, the challenge we face.  It is not a question of being in nationalist protection, as your words imply, it is a question of allowing through our partnership with Africa, not only europe but the whole world, on the occasion of COP 21, to find the financing to develop this young people who will not only find work in Africa, but who, through his work, will also enable the development of this African continent. The European Union and Africa are brothers, we must take this into account and I believe that it is necessary to deepen this axis of development.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Immediately after the European Union-Africa Summit in Malta, an informal summit of European Union leaders began there. It was convened by The President of the European Council Donald Tusk, who made no secret of the fact that his aim was to save the Schengen area. He was concerned about the actions of the Governments of Germany, Austria and Sweden, which temporarily reinstated controls at their borders. President Tusk's reaction was belated, the summit was not a breakthrough. Two days later, two more countries introduced checks at their borders: France and Belgium; caused by the vicious terrorist attacks in Paris. However, no one doubts that this is all linked to the uncontrolled influx of so-called refugees. Pushing for a policy of their compulsory unbundling, in my opinion, will not save the Schengen area and, on the contrary, can contribute to its faster distribution.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, as in all matters, we are here the nationalist vision, closed, which believes that borders must be closed and that all money must be kept for nationals in each place; and then there is the vision that he believes we need to develop European, or even global, responses. From a theoretical point of view, I think there is no doubt: we are interrelated and there is no way to close borders; there is no way to address big problems in a specifically national way. From there, however, the problem begins as well. Thirty-five African states and twenty-eight European states met. A political declaration and action plan are adopted. But if we really believe that solutions should be European, will rapid implementation measures, by 2016, be possible? What about the trust fund? 1.8 billion, and it seems that we only have 81 million; if we really believe in European solutions, is that enough?

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, Commissioner, over the last six months there have been over 25 meetings of European and international institutions on refugees and the fight against terrorism. What's the result? Only a few hundred of the millions of refugees have been relocated, borders in Europe are coming back with walls and armies, solidarity is being cut off and the Member States are not implementing their own decisions either.  European refugee policy has failed. At the same time your strategic ally in the region, Turkey, is blackmailing the refugee and shooting down Russian planes playing dangerous destabilizing games in the region. The zero results of the Valletta conference are exactly the same failure, Commissioner.  Greetings and timidity that hide purpose. You do not hesitate to cooperate even with authoritarian regimes, such as Sudan and Eritrea, with a view to reducing the migratory flows that they themselves have caused, and you insist on readmission when this Parliament has adopted resolutions condemning these regimes.  I'm sorry, but I believe and I'm afraid that in January we'll be talking the same thing.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are discussing yet another summit on migration, which is yet another disappointment. This is yet another disappointment that European governments are offering us. The political declarations of the Malta Summit were supposed to address the root causes – and I stress, the root causes – of migration: the commitment to respect fundamental rights, reducing poverty, promoting peace, development and inclusive economic growth. Well, in fact, none of this!  No measures to really address the root causes of migration; no mention of cooperation without hypocrisy between Member States; no mention of solidarity and the fair distribution of responsibility among the Member States; no mention of the amendment of European asylum legislation, which we all now agree is bankrupt; no mention of legal avenues of access to the European Union, which would protect those in need of international protection and would therefore protect European citizens who find themselves receiving them; there is no mention of better management of funds for immigration and the protection of fundamental rights.  Well, the fear is that once again economic and financial aid will only prove to be an instrument for outsourcing borders, wasting an opportunity that could be really aimed at ensuring better management of migratory flows.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, let me also make a few comments on the Valletta Summit. On the one hand, I welcome the fact that Europe is starting to talk to the countries where the greatest flows of refugees come from, whether refugees on the basis of economic needs or refugees driven from their homes by war. On the other hand, when I look at the conclusions of this summit, then I am relatively disappointed and I agree with my colleagues who point out that these conclusions are not sufficient and that, in my opinion, more and more intensive action will be needed with the countries where the most massive flows of refugees come from. We have spoken so far and have only dealt with the consequences in Parliament. We have spent a lot of time pushing for and debating so-called quotas, and I do not think the quotas are working and will not work. It is also clear that the return policy, the monitoring of the external borders and so on are not working very well. For example, if return policy is to work, then we really need to have partners on the other side, countries where economic applicants will be returned.  The idea of a trust fund, which was also raised here today, is, in my view, correct, but the amount that has been earmarked for the fund is, in my view, very small. It can hardly solve the economic problems of several states. It is also a question of whether this amount can be collected at all, and, above all, there are not very clear rules on how that amount will be controlled and how it will be distributed.  Personally, I would advise the Commission to debate more about greater cooperation with the countries of Africa, to support them, for example, by breaking down certain customs provisions, by supporting trade and by adusborting trade and a way for these countries to develop more. They will raise money through their own business, not through projects that threaten to steal the money often, dismantled. I think that negotiations need to continue in the future and support these countries economically.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, to be honest, the Valletta summit was really motivated on the European side by the need to control the irregular flow of economic migration to Europe. It has, however, stimulated what could become an effective dialogue regarding the economic and social complementarities that should exist between Africa and Europe. Neoliberal globalisation makes this very difficult to achieve. Actually the European Union lacks the tools needed to help generate sufficient employment opportunities in Africa to make economic migration unattractive. Worse, many private projects in Africa, spurred by globalisation, have not served to increase job opportunities in the economy as a whole. Corruption, waste of resources and greater social inequalities have spread, so desperate people go far from home to find work. Europe may be too distracted by the crisis to take the lead in what is really needed: a Marshall Plan for Africa where public agencies take full charge and do not simply delegate initiatives to the private sector or wait for the latter to take them. African development should not be dominated by global free-market forces but planned by agreement and effectively implemented. Many vested ideas and interests will have to change. I hope the Valletta summit was a first step in this very long process. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Mr Sant. You seem to blame the whole of Africa’s problems on globalisation, and yet you do not blame the European Union in any way, shape or form. So do you not feel it is concerning that the European Union charges sugar beet at excessive prices to African countries to the benefit of sugar producers in Germany, or indeed in the production of cocoa beans, so that chocolate is more expensive to be produced in Africa, to protect those producers in Belgium? Do you not think that they have massive repercussions on jobs and prosperity in Africa?

name: Alfred SANT
text: blue-card answer. – Sure, but that reflects multinational corporations’ strategies. They use governments, they use the EU, they use structures that they have to dominate global financial markets to get it the best way, so that is what is happening. Globalisation is actually at the moment manipulating the markets you mention, and this is to the disadvantage of European consumers and of African workers. And that is the reality.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU-Africa Summit in Valletta was a difficult meeting at a difficult time. But it must be clear to all of us: "This was the starting point of a longer process," said German Chancellor Angela Merkel. I would add critically: a process that you have all started far too late. In the current refugee crisis, we are treating symptoms whose causes have grown over decades. We have too often measured european standards and thought that solutions for Africa must be made in Europe – a gross mistake. Europe's partnership with Africa must be put to the test. We need new approaches: coexistence on an equal footing, not a devastating brain drain. We need real support: community services such as health, education, civil protection, infrastructure, electricity and drinking water guarantees.  This must be financed by a financial transaction tax in the ridiculous zero-comma area. It works. Valletta was a far too late start: the right work has only just begun.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: –  Mr President, we have heard much in this Chamber about how the terror attacks have nothing to do with the open-door policy EU leaders foisted upon Members, which saw migrants claim refugee status they were not entitled to. Daesh boasted they would flood our continent with jihad fighters, although Members here in the Chamber derided those of us who pointed this out. We know that two of the murderers involved in the Paris killings came to the continent via Greece, using false Syrian passports. What is this if it is not a direct link between uncontrolled immigration and terrorism? I reject this idea put forward by people like President Juncker that terrorism is a risk we must live with to uphold the EU’s ideals of freedom of movement. The migrant crisis has put the well-being of migrants ahead of the safety of its citizens by making us vulnerable to attack in our towns and cities. Come the UK’s referendum, voters must look at the negligence of the EU when it comes to securing our borders, and vote for independence. (Applause)

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, as has been essentially said here at the Vallifa Summit, I think it is worth focusing some of the attention on the g20 group issue and, in particular, on the approach that the G20 meeting in Antalya took to the issue of terrorism, since it occurred immediately after the Paris attacks of 13 November. What I would like to make clear here is that the fight against terrorism by European countries and, in particular, the European Union must be an unrelenting fight. We must give a clear external response, with military action and with military cooperation with France, with the United States, with the coalition countries, with the Islamic State, and we must also take some measures, such as the approval of the PNR, internally, and others, including a strengthening of schengen's external borders in the context of the European Union. And I think it is very important that we have a great opportunity here to strengthen European cooperation and to strengthen the European Union's presence in security and defence affairs. In particular, I believe that it is essential that we move from the Frontex and other programmes to the creation of a genuine European border guard, which can, with the composition of all European countries, protect the external borders of Schengen and the external borders of the European Union.  It is essential to take this step — without it, we will not have effective control, we will not have an effective defence of our security and we will be vulnerable, we will be exposed to terrorist attacks. There are no economic, social, or sociological explanations for terrorism. Terrorism must be fought without any failure on our part.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – It was highly anticipated: the Summit of European and African Leaders in Valetta, convened by EU heads of government. It should have been an opportunity to formulate a common agenda of migration with more than 60 countries. Unfortunately, this opportunity was not taken and the summit ended in disappointment. The EU showed no willingness to tackle the root causes of migration, such as poverty, conflict, a lack of employment, vigorously. And African leaders were therefore unwilling to agree, for example, on the mandatory readmission of rejected asylum seekers in Europe, something that EU countries insisted on. Unfortunately, as we have seen time and time again in recent months, european heads of government have once again failed to show political courage, ambition and decisiveness, and this will be absolutely necessary if we are to tackle the refugee issue in a decent, effective way. Next weekend there will be a rematch at the EU-Turkey summit. Turkey plays a key role in making the influx of asylum seekers into the EU manageable. It is high time that European governments showed their willingness to contribute to solutions and not just sign treaties and then do nothing with them.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – No terrorist will first obtain a firearms passport and a shopping permit, so that he can then legally buy a gun, register it with the police and commit a terrorist attack. Therefore, no terrorist attacks are also committed with legally held weapons. Terrorists will bring to Europe all the weapons they need because we have reprehensily opened the Schengen border. I consider it a top-notch move to restrict the legal possession of weapons, as most recently proposed by Mr Juncker under the guise of the fight against terrorism. Rather, it seems to me that the European Commission, headed by Mr Juncker, wants to disarm decent people so that they cannot defend themselves. You say you're fighting terrorists, you're actually stealing freedom from decent people. You make it easier for terrorists to do their activities. If you restrict the legal possession of weapons, you will not save a single victim because terrorists do not use legal weapons.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The message of Valletta and Antalya is a common one: we can only move forward if we all assume our responsibilities together at European and global level. We must not forget that international decisions are in the national interest. However, this is precisely where we have a credibility problem. I therefore appeal to the Council: after a summit, start each report to this House and the public with a report on the concrete actions that launched the decisions of the last summit. Our credibility problem is that since Charlie Hebdo, we have not carried out the data exchange across the EU, but only in five countries, that we have not fully stocked the Africa Trust Fund, although it has been decided that the Member States have not stocked up on the Syria Fund, even though we decided that we did not provide sufficient staff to border management, although we decided that we had agreed on support for Turkey, but did not implement it. I must ask the Member States to remember your decisions and take action, only that will create credibility, only that will create trust, only that will create the necessary determination on the way to jointly taking on the challenges of the present and the future. We will only be recognized by the deeds, not just by our decisions. The decisions were good, the signals were sent, but the deeds must be put in place, and we have some catching up to do!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President: Valletta summit, sixty countries brought together and again the feeling and bad taste of a missed opportunity.  A Council whose conclusions do not conclude and propose little, late and in the wrong direction to solve the most imminent problem posed by the European Union at the moment: immigration. Because the approach remains, above all, negative.  And that is why the trust fund, in addition to being ridiculous, 1.8 billion euros, aims, under conditionality, for the countries of origin to accept that the European Union 'subcontracts' them for the effort to contain, return or readmission migrants and even potential asylum seekers.  It is a profoundly wrong approach and the European Union continues to do not develop legal and secure avenues for the promotion of mobility and immigration.  When this legislature started, President Juncker said this was the last European opportunity. The hourglass hasn't stopped counting, but we're going wrong, too little, too late, in the wrong direction and ununited in the face of adversity.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, we are the generation who grew up in a post-war Europe. It was a Europe that fed a starving population, a Europe that won the Cold War and a Europe that successfully reunited a broken continent. But our children will grow up in a totally different Europe, a Europe that will have to confront a completely different set of challenges. The shift of economic power, West to East; the consequence of climate change, of global mass migration; and the rise of fundamentalist Islam: these are next-generation issues, for which Europe will have to find next-generation solutions. Valletta was a good start. But it is just that, only a start. History offers us two lessons here. First, turning the clock back, or retreating into isolation, was never the answer. Second, when the really big challenges come along, European nations are so much more effective when they confront them together, rather than alone.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President, the fact is that important conclusions have been drawn in Valletta and also in Antalia. The mere fact that heads of state and government were there speaks, and is proof, that these two summits were very important. Action plans are important, but if it doesn't come to their implementation, I'm afraid not much has been done. I want to believe that Member States will understand that all international decisions taken, that it is important for those at national level to apply them. Otherwise, there'll be a dead letter on the paper.  We all know that migration is our common obligation not only to the countries of origin, but also to the countries of transit and those countries that accept them, i.e. countries of destination. It is good that our African partners have been fully distinguished in Valletta.  Likewise, the two key issues mentioned earlier by Ms Mogherini are the way in which funds are applied, namely development money and, likewise, how we manage migration crises.  These two questions need to be well answered by us from the European Union. Likewise, it is good that the G20 addressed all issues: from terrorism, through refugees, to the economy and inequalities in society to climate change. These are really questions of both our generation and future generations.  This crisis is a truly large-scale crisis and we must face its course and its consequences. We share common values, we want to share them further, and we want to believe that human life is at the heart of our values. However, we hear these days, both in your discussions, about terrorism and migration and their causality. I don't want to believe they're connected, but it also shouldn't rule out the possibility that some have taken advantage of the refugee wave for the purposes of their terrorist goals. Therefore, I consider this to be a sociological issue, given that most of the perpetrators were born in Western Europe. This needs to be taken seriously. This morning we had a topic about radicalisation in Western Europe and the European Union, so it is time to seriously address integration and identity crisis.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, a partnership for (in response to accountability) development assistance for the benefit of a youth perspective, lots of political messages, announcements of action and financial plans. This is the shortest we can summarize agreed in Valleti with standard discussions on preserving the external borders of the European Union and the Schengen system. The Summit in Malta is already the third gathering in the last 3 months dedicated to migration, so it is the right time to ask ourselves where we have come to with the application of the conclusions that were adopted earlier. For example, instead of Frontex at the land borders within the Union, we are witnessing new kilometres of wire that some members surround other members such as my Croatia.  It is good that the leaders of the European Union and African countries sat at the same table and agreed on the new measures, because effective border control while protecting the dignity of people can best be achieved through trust and cooperation. It is high time to put these measures to mutual benefit by having before our eyes the primary goal of protecting the most vulnerable whose journey across the Mediterranean too often ends in tragedy.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, the migration from Africa is a bit overshadowed by migration from Syria, but that does not mean that it is less serious and it is therefore good that the European Union is investing in security and stability in Africa. Because we need prevention, we need to prevent migratory flows. But prevention alone wouldn't be enough. We also need restrictions, and unfortunately I have not heard anything from this summit about the enhanced protection of the European Union's external borders. I think this is unacceptable, the Commission is not doing enough, we are hearing Chancellor Merkel here constantly repeating the mantra of permanent quotas. She even said that we must choose between permanent redistribution and the Schengen system. I read in a French weekly that 94% of the French would be in the process of reintroduceing border controls, and if the issue is asked this way, I am convinced that European citizens will choose border controls and that Schengen will unfortunately disappear. As long as the European Union, and the European Commission in particular, does not take care of the protection of external borders.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking The choice of the venue of the Council meeting in La Vallant indicates very clearly a reference to the phenomenon that was before the war in Syria began. It seems to me that it is extremely important that we recall the calls made by our colleagues in Malta in the European Parliament for help in the situation of migrants coming in, migrants passing by. This was even before the mass influx.  It is as if it indicates that, in order to solve the problem, it is not enough to focus solely on the problem of the war in Syria. And it is very good that the document that appeared in La Vallant draws attention to a much broader aspect of the whole case, paying attention to the sources of immigration. I am not just talking about refugees, but all kinds of migrations, on the reasons why people are fleeing or moving to better areas and paying attention precisely to the whole complex of issues that will need to be dealt with, not only to end the war in Syria, but also to think very seriously about investing in the countries of origin of the migrants. This meeting in La Valanta has shown that there is no simple process and that even an agreement with Turkey will not do the right thing. It is very good that such a broader perspective has found a place there.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the outcome of the Malta Summit was disappointing: it was good to sit down at the table with the African countries, to try to deal with the situation together, but the usual seuritarian approach prevails on the European side. Nothing about legal access villas for asylum seekers and migrants, the only real way to counter traffickers; nothing about resettlements or relocations. All efforts seem to be aimed at preventing new arrivals.  The Trust Fund itself seemed to suffer from unacceptable conditionality: offered in exchange for repatriation or strengthening borders. It can be a useful tool, but only if we ensure that money really reaches those who need it in order to eradicate poverty and inequality and not for border management, to outsource our borders.  I would not like this to be the idea of some governments that have put the 3 million needed to sit in the bord right. What is 1.8 billion when remittances from Africa are estimated at 23 billion? When hundreds of billions of tax evasion and avoidance of our companies come out of developing countries every year?  So, before we ask and demand from our partners, we will have to work to be credible on the coherence of our internal and external policies.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Mr. President, I welcome the joint conclusions and action plan adopted by La Valletta. Now we have an implementation ahead of us. The European Union, the Member States, must fulfil financial commitments on development aid and contributions to the Africa Fund. But on the other hand, partners in Africa must also take their share of responsibility and start addressing the causes of poverty, wars and instability and mass migration. The causes are serious human rights violations, autocracy, political persecution, lack of rule of law, endemic corruption. That's why I don't think we should be so afraid of a clearer definition of the conditionality of development cooperation.  Another question to answer better is the effectiveness of our development cooperation. Better coordination between Member States in programming is needed, but we also need a better work framework based on measurable results. With limited funds, it is important that we get value for the money being invested.  Finally, it is also important to take into account the recommendations of the European Parliament. A few weeks ago, all political groups within the Development Committee reached a consensus and sent a recommendation to the Committee of the European Development Fund, chaired by the Commission, to reject the adoption of a proposal for a national development cooperation programme with Eritrea. However, despite our recommendation, at last week's meeting of the European Development Fund Committee, this programme was adopted unanimously. We must avoid such situations in the future if we are to be effective in development cooperation and in foreign policy.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Il-Valletta Summit kien opportunità biex l-Unjoni Ewropea u l-Afrika jsaħħu d-djalogu ta' bejniethom. Ġie maqbul pjan ta' azzjoni u ġew allokati l-fondi. Imma dan is-summit naqas milli jagħti l-attenzjoni meħtieġa lis-sitwazzjoni tad-drittijiet tal-bniedem u l-korruzzjoni li qed tifni ħafna pajjiżi fl-Afrika. Stennejt pożizzjoni b'saħħitha dwar il-fatturi li qegħdin jimbuttaw lin-nies 'il boghod mill-Afrika: in-nuqqas ta' governanza, l-inġustizzja soħjali, l-inugwaljanza, il-fl kunitti u l-korruzz fojoni fost iljjjiżi Afrikani. L-Unjoni Ewropea trid turi rieda politika b'saħħitha biex dawk il-miżuri li verament jistgħu jagħmlu differenza jkunu maqbula. Il-mexxejja Afrikani wkoll għandhom rwol importanti. Għandhom l-opportunità li jsaħħu l-kooperazzjoni bejniethom, li jqajmu flower-pajjiżi tagħhom fuq saqajhom. Din il-pożizzjoni i tmurx id f'id mal-korruzzjoni. Għalhekk nappella favur it-twaqqif ta' tribunal dwar il-korruzzjoni pubblika bl-appoġġ tal-Ġnus Magħquda. Tribunal li jidentifika u jindirizza l-korruzzjoni li teżisti fl-Afrika, li gandħha impatt dirett fuq i-ikeittadini fl-Afrika u anke fil-pajjiżi tagħna.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to welcome the agreement reached in Valletta between the European Union and its African partners, because it is only through a common approach that we can deal with the biggest refugee crisis in our history. It is, of course, as other colleagues have already pointed out, that the decisions taken in Malta should be followed by concrete actions and, in particular, sufficient financial contributions from the Member States, otherwise the Valletta objectives will remain a dead letter.  Of the five priority areas of action, two seem crucial to me. First of all, the need to address the root causes of this crisis, because we can no longer be content with temporary solutions. The Union needs to play a more active role in resolving and, above all, in preventing conflicts in its neighbourhood. Finding a political solution to the Syrian conflict is, in this context, of paramount importance. The second priority area of action is the fight against illegal immigration and trafficking of all kinds. The lack of political agreement on a government of national unity in Libya questions our ability to effectively and sustainably combat this illegal immigration to the Mediterranean. Is it not time to consider other options to contain the migrant crisis in the absence of a political agreement in Libya? Supporting mediation efforts between the different tribes of southern Libya could be a avenue to explore.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: – Mr President, we had high hopes at the Valletta meeting, months before that we talked about the expected results, but the news from there is not enough. The only word from the summit was about the €1.8 billion fund being formed, the lack of willingness in the Member States to participate in it and the disapproval of African leaders of insufficient funds.  We expected agreements to create "hotspots" with the countries from which migrants come to be the first crossing point. We expected serious commitments to create working legal pathways. No matter how good solutions Europe has, it cannot make them without its third-party partners. Legal roads are the best way to combat human trafficking. Moreover, it was also not clear the specific general solutions for dismantling the criminal networks of the canalgoers, who send people to certain death either at sea or on balkan roads. There was also no answer to the most important question – how will joint operations on the return of illegal immigrants who cannot obtain refugee status be carried out. This dialogue cannot be complete without the participation of the transit countries – Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, I am opposed, like Mr Juncker, to the migration-terrorism linkage, because, as the Director of Europol himself defended last week, there is no record of that link. Ordered migration is synonymous with shared future, development at source, and at destination; it is a phenomenon that, if we manage it correctly, will always have positive effects. That is why Valletta's agreements are important, albeit insufficient. That is why we must continue to deepen. The relationship between migration and development is commonly accepted doctrine at the United Nations. An urgent and comprehensive response is needed to alleviate the needs of refugees, especially now in the winter, without forgetting to develop the measures in the countries of origin. In this regard, I support fighting the crisis in Syria, the Sahel, Chad or the Horn of Africa, reinforcing state structures, democracy and the fight against terror. I also support the fight against irregular immigration and trafficking and exploitation of human beings, with the improvement of police and judicial cooperation and facilitating return and readmission, with dignity and legality. I also support generating social and economic opportunities in countries of origin; facilitate new legal migration channels, the participation of migrants in their countries of origin, and the greater and better impact of low-cost remittance transfers; and also strengthen border control by improving the management of travel documents and the registration of individuals.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Both the G20 summit and the Valletta summit focused on migration at the heart of their debate. The conclusions contain much of how to combat the causes of flight. The action plan with the African countries was also emphasised and the importance of such a development policy – so far, so good. On the other hand, however, there is now also a trade policy which undermines everything that development policy is about to do. Any perspective is taken away from those countries that want to build an independent and prosperous economy. For example, a European agricultural policy that is heavily focused on exports has the disadvantage of destroying local markets there. Or trade agreements such as TTIP, which set standards that act as trade barriers for emerging economies, thus excluding them from the market. I therefore believe that a structural change in trade policy is urgently needed, because it is only with money alone that the causes of flight cannot be combated.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – At the Vallat summit we saw a fragmented European Union, focused on border control and increased restrictions on the entry of refugees, trying to outsource dirty work, including through readmission agreements that would have, if ever signed, the same role that Berlusconi once had with the facinora Gaddafi. We have also seen African governments demanding more investment and aid, so-called development, for kleptocratic and oppressive regimes, and therefore prolific manufacturers of refugees and migrants, such as those in Sudan, Eritrea and Ethiopia, among others. Let us be clear: the European Union, under the primary responsibility of its governments, has failed to wage wars, conflicts, terrorism, oppression and economic exploitation at its doorsteps or further away in Africa, to which it is bound by historical and human ties. Despite all the rhetoric, the European Union has privileged relations with governments, however corrupt they may be, and does lip service in support of the organization of African citizens who fight against oppression and corruption. As we have been asking here in the European Parliament for a long time, opening legal and secure channels of access for refugees and migrants is fundamental and is the main way to protect the lives of men, women, and children so that they do not have to surrender to the hands of traffickers and throw themselves into the sea. This is also the only way to effectively control our borders and ensure that criminal organisations, including terrorists, do not take advantage of the mess that are hot spots and other arrival points, where there is no resources to make any serious control of who arrives. It is also the only way for the European Union not to continue to feed the human traffickers' business. This is a path that governments sitting on the Council have not wanted to explore. They resist for lack of political courage and strategic vision and, in particular, the importance of synergy in supporting those who are responsible for human rights and good governance in Africa. With valla summits, we have deceived our citizens by failing in legal and moral obligations towards refugees and Africans and, above all, we do not contribute to the security of Europe and globally.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Since the beginning of the incessant influx of migrants from the south and east, European crisis councils and international summits, including valletta and the G20, have been successive. Acknowledging their necessity and partial results, we must nevertheless agree with Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who believes that they are 'going nowhere'. On the contrary, the migrant crisis is getting worse and, moreover, the threat of terror against Europe, which is on an almost apocalyptic scale, has been added. Who is responsible for all this? For the deaths of innocent victims in Paris, for the escalation of uncontrolled and illegal immigration, for the overmining of everyday uncertainty and fear, for the expected collapse of Europe's borders and the Schengen system! Our European and national identities, values and interests are put at risk by those who, with the demagogy of multiculturalism, 'openness' and 'solidarity', are fighting to defend our borders, unwittingly freely freely from the spread of Islamic fundamentalism and contribute to the drastic redrawing of Europe's ethnic-religious map. Until it is too late, we need a review and radical change in the Union's policy on migration and asylum and terrorism.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, how long will we watch from the side how medieval barbarians cut their heads, crucified, down and burned people alive, stoned women, blew us up even in our own cities? Until evil is permanently settled on our continent? The time has come for firm action – we have an economy, we have potential, Europe is an economic giant!  But you know very well that we are not taken seriously politically and militarily. We lack the determination, speed and efficiency to eliminate the dangers. Yes, our development policy must help the countries of Africa and the Middle East to have a perspective on the people there and not be motivated to go to our borders. The countries to which we help and from which migrants are coming must accept their own citizens unconditionally back. It is time to establish pan-European security services with a common command, a pan-European intelligence and counter-intelligence agency. Alone, no country can better cope with the current global challenges. It is obvious that airstrikes are necessary, but insufficient for the ultimate success in Syria.  I hope that the light from the Vienna negotiations and the G20 will not diminish or go out even after the events on the Turkish-Syrian border. Coordinated action by the international community is needed now to eliminate the barbarians and cut off funding for any terrorist movements, no matter where they come from.  Stop talking! Whoever finances and trades directly or indirectly with terrorists is a terrorist engaged in human trafficking, is a criminal. And it must be clear that all such assets in the European Union and other democratic countries will be confiscated immediately and those persons, companies, organisations or governments engaged in such activity must be held accountable.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, while Europe is facing an unprecedented refugee and migration crisis, this summit should have been a step towards dialogue on management of the flows from Africa. Although we have not reached a clear solution, we need to continue this dialogue and concentrate on the root causes of the migration. It is clear that they will not disappear overnight, but there has to be an understanding that this is not only a European problem but a much broader problem. It has been recognised as a global concern, with major political and economic consequences. We therefore have to keep a continuous dialogue with African countries going, as well as with countries of the Middle East. The EU and its Member States should be at the forefront of these initiatives. We have much more to offer than just a safe harbour for refugees fleeing conflicts and failed states. We are a leading partner in development programmes and humanitarian aid all around the globe. Along with the security measures, we need to invest more experience and expertise and also resources in development policies. We have a handful of governments in Europe whose answer to the refugee crisis has been to point to the root causes. I think that now is the time to ask them for their real contribution.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – The Valetta Summit was necessary and useful. I welcome the action plan, the establishment of a trust fund and all other measures to alleviate migratory pressure, intensify efforts to address the causes at source and help the new development paradigm of African countries. I see the Valetta Summit as an expression of understanding of shared responsibility and the will to be partnership and solidarity. The refugee crisis is an out of place in a broader conflict context. The only way to solve it is to improve the context. I would like the Valetta Summit to be followed by a continuous and strategic dialogue between the European Union and Africa.   As I have said already in the debate on sustainable development and post-2016 goals, everything we set out to do can be achieved if our societies live in peace and freedom, if they pay attention to the dignity of everyone and to all identities, regardless of quantity. Achieving peace in our neighbourhood is the first priority. There will be little progress, however, if we shoot at different targets in Syria and the partners shoot down each other's planes. We will solve the European problem if we successfully solve African problems and develop a credible partnership with Turkey.  The unified response by Member States to President Juncker's financial initiative has not strengthened the credibility of the European union. Money is not everything, but dodging solidarity today certainly means a higher bill later.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Mr President, the Valletta Summit in November set an important precedent in that it finally began to address the refugee crisis in cooperation with the African Union states, the way in which the problem is at its heart. As the summit noted, it is essential to address Africa's socio-economic development, promote stability, peace and the building of the right states there. These are necessary but long-term solutions. However, the crisis is in full swing right now, which is why we also need immediate measures. We should realise that the influx of refugees is impossible to stop. People will always do everything in their power to protect their families from civil war and violence. That is why we should focus our efforts on controlling the influx of refugees. The first step should be to prevent further deaths of refugees in the Mediterranean. The European Union must fight relentlessly against organised smuggling networks. Eu Operation Sophia, whose job it is precisely to break up smuggling operations, is therefore the right step. That is why we must also create the conditions for obtaining asylum in the European Union only in specialised centres in third countries, such as the one recently established by the European Union in Turkey.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Valletta sends a message about how crucial it is to address the root causes of irregular migration. This can be done only by working together with countries of origin within a long-term framework. Among five priorities, I would particularly stress the fourth one: to combat and prevent migrant smuggling and human trafficking. It is important because this level has been relatively neglected. There are many signals which show how well the criminal African and cross—Mediterranean smuggling business is organised. New criminal groups are not only profiting from people in need but are, at least partially, motivating, inspiring and channelling the migration flows. The huge amount of money extorted from migrants is being directed to finance terrorism and militant groups and to undermine the EU. Two more observations: economic cooperation and development aid to African countries must be clearly linked with the respective readmission agreements. One of the most urgent tasks is to decide about those who do not qualify for asylum. Secondly, money promised to support our African partners must not be delayed under the guise of commitments. In particular, Member States need to contribute decisively and immediately. As I said, Valletta was a good start, but the bulk of the work is yet to be done.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress that we need to reform asylum procedures following the results of the Valletta Summit.  Europe must speak with one way. But even nation states cannot be squeezed out of responsibility. We cannot underestimate the security risks associated with the rampant influx of immigrants into Europe. At the same time, I would like to say that only those who are peaceful should have the right to asylum and to our assistance. We are aware of our duty to help, we want to be in solidarity with those who really need our help, who are at risk of life. However, the right to asylum cannot be enjoyed by those who do not prove their identity and local origin, who do not cooperate in the asylum procedure and do not dispel any doubts about their security risks. Aid to refugees should be of a temporary nature, if the danger passes, they should also be returned to their original homelands in their interests.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: – Mr President, the events after the Valletta Summit give its outcomes on security a new meaning. Serious commitment to the outcomes of the Valletta Summit and the G20 meeting is assured by the European institutions, but this commitment needs to be equally present from Member States and third countries. Security threats are global, necessitating global response and cooperation – but we would be very mistaken to leave local action by the wayside. Our response needs to be both global and local. We can protect our citizens when we realise that strong internal and border security would be insufficient if our neighbour does not have the same security capacity. Security threats transcend physical borders, and the resetting of physical borders will not protect us but will simply artificially confine us to a bubble. The call to re-establish our internal physical borders shows how fear and terror transcends countries. We need to appreciate that our citizens are reacting out of fear, and we must provide them with security. But it is not more physical borders that we need. We need cooperation and coordination of our resources, reflected in specific actions which do not take ages to be initiated.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacres in Paris disrupted the agenda of last week's G20 summit, forcing leaders to work to find solutions to the terrorist threat. However, European and NATO positions on how and alongside those in action are still a long way off.  I believe that, after the tragedy in Paris, there is no longer any room for division and tactics and that, against the threat of terrorism, as President Mattarella said this morning, we need more than ever a united Europe, capable of decisive action, in Syria, Lebanon and Libya, and of coordinating national intelligence systems amongst themselves. The situation is delicate and complex and must therefore be approached with a shared strategic vision, capable of looking at the long term and taking into account the entire regional chessboard.  Only if we succeed in giving new life to our European identity will we be able to defeat the threat of ISIS and manage the migration phenomenon, including its origin. And on this point, as emerged from the Valletta Summit, closer cooperation between Europe and Africa is needed to combat illegal immigration and therefore the criminal networks that exploit them.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I am pleased that representatives of European countries care about the human rights of migrants and respect for their dignity, as it is necessary to be a good host to those we have chosen to receive. But I still can't help noticing that the priorities of European leaders are quite upside down. Indeed, the political representatives of the Member States and all of us here in this house are not elected by refugees and migrants, but by full nationals of European states. That is why I cannot agree with the individual conclusions that bind our highest priorities to migrants. The main priorities of all European politicians at all levels of government must be the security and prosperity of our citizens, and everything else comes after that. Following the latest terrorist attacks and hostage crises in France and police raids in Brussels, our primary task is to answer many citizens' questions and concerns instead of ignoring their growing dissatisfaction with the policies Europe is running.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: " Mr. President, the real question is, what is in front of us? What happens in the coming months and the coming years? Is the instability and uncertainty that's around us right now, is that something that's going to last for years? What kind of answer do we give to that? Did La Valletta and Antalia really give any answer to this condition we're in today?  I think the results are relatively modest. Of course I support the deals. Of course I support dialogue because dialogue has no alternative. The alternative is just war, and of course we don't want war anywhere. Some talk about big wars coming. Both our allies and the people we support speak. That is why I am sure that we must continue our policy of cooperation with African countries, but we must also, as the European Union, do everything to make sure that the great powers, primarily the US and Russia, start acting together because otherwise we will face even greater challenges than we are today.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the Valletta conference has resulted in another poor performance. There has been no substantial differentiation in the Union's refugee policy and it has again been decided to further strengthen the military solutions and repressive safeguard mechanisms that turn Europe into a fortress. And the effort to distribute refugees fairly and the goal of creating legal and safe routes to Europe has failed again.  On the other hand, the xenophobic approaches of some Eastern European governments are of great concern and must be addressed decisively. Solidarity is not a one-way street to invoke a la cart when we need it. The refugee crisis is not only a problem for the host countries, Greece, Italy and the other Mediterranean Member States, but for the whole Union.  That is why we must strengthen humanitarian aid, immediately promote a fair system of redistribution and relocation of refugees.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The migrant numbers are, of course, unpredictable, and La Valetta has, of course, confirmed this on the migration itself, particularly on modest forecasts or vague figures of what will happen in the future. It is good, however, that this "summit" has sat alongside European, African leaders, humanitarian organisations, that they have agreed on some of the measures that they will, hopefully, start as soon as possible ... (The President interrupted the speaker because of a technical problem and then returned the floor to him.) So, we are reading the different figures on migration flows that will take place in the future, and this meeting in La Valetta is also a confirmation. This meeting, which was held together by European and African leaders and by some humanitarian organisations and associations, also served with some concrete proposals; some, of course, claim that they are too little concrete, others are satisfied with this.  A €1.8 billion fund is to be set up. It is clear that, of course, we need to pay attention to who this fund is going to be, who will be paid in and how we will, of course, exercise control of that. Above all, it is an important agreement between both the countries of origin of the refugee crisis, transit and the countries of destination, and therefore to start addressing those root causes that have caused this refugee crisis in the first place.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Mr President, another EU summit, and again the problems facing this Union are staring them in the face and nothing is done. The first is that Chancellor Merkel and the leadership of this Union said: ‘Come ye, come ye’. So you are welcoming the entire world to the European Union. The second is Schengen and complete open borders within most of the European Union. Third, free movement for anyone with an EU passport ready to work and live in most of the European Union, which is why in recent years we have had record numbers of net immigration into the United Kingdom. Until you deal with that, you will not fix the migrant crisis, and every summer there will be problems at Calais, there will be problems at every single border – the external border of the European Union. Until you deal with that, you will not fix the problems, which is why in the UK we have seen the ‘Leave the EU’ campaign ahead in the polls. If you fail to address that then the United Kingdom will leave the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the Valletta Summit has produced important results, despite the fact that I also hear criticism here. However, I think that this is important to help the countries where refugees come from or through which refugees come to Europe. Immediately after this summit, the Czech Republic signed up to a financial contribution of EUR 600,000. However, I was also prompted to make this speech by The High Representative Mogherini, whose work I appreciate, but I did not understand the words when she said that it is not possible to build a border between Africa and Europe because there is a sea. I hope it was just a misunderstanding. There is certainly a border between Europe and Africa, and the European Union must do everything possible to make the European Union's external borders secure.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, apologies again from Federica Mogherini, Vice-President – as you know, she had to leave to get to the Union for the Mediterranean Summit, the so-called Barcelona Process. I would like to thank you for this frank and dense debate on our partnership with Africa and on the global partnership necessary to manage migratory and refugee flows in Europe. We clearly need to take stock of the Valletta process and, of course, of the talks in the G20 and pass to implementing our commitments, starting from action agreed in the Valletta action plan. This is our task from here to the end of 2016, and we need to engage immediately with our partners to make things happen. Let me take on a few of your questions. Firstly, on readmission and return agreements. As my colleague the Vice-President explained, this is an important part of our strategy, but it is only one part of our strategy. It cannot be decoupled from our other actions. The objective in the medium and long term is to make this phenomenon more manageable. This includes discouraging irregular flows, fighting the smugglers of human beings, working on the readmissions, but also working on the reintegration of returnees. Only if those who get back can find a place in their own societies will they pass on the message that embarking on a dangerous journey towards Europe is not worth the risk. At the same time, we need to work to strengthen and implement the legal channels we have already agreed on. But first of all we need to invest in the future of Africa. The continent has a huge potential; our aid can help unleash such potential. The Commission is doing its share, and we will keep pushing for national governments to follow up on their commitments. I would encourage you all to pass on this message that you have voiced here today, also back home. Secondly, many of you rightly highlighted that saving lives must remain our focus in implementing Valletta. I completely agree. Protection is and remains a key element of our partnership with Africa, both in terms of supporting the huge effort of African partners in offering humanitarian relief to refugees and the internally displaced in Africa, and in terms of a wider and more consistent effort from the EU in terms of resettlement, in close cooperation with UNHCR. Yes, this is a crucial part of our effort to save lives and avoid hazardous journeys. Another key component of our discussion in Valletta has indeed been legal mobility: opening legal, regulated ways and facilitating mobility for bona fide travellers, starting from students, researchers, academics and business operators. It is part of our commitments in the action plan and we will make it happen. This is very important, as you know. As Federica Mogherini said in her introduction, helping Africa’s growth and development is in our own interests. If we disinvested from the continent’s future, we would be hurting our own future. It would be against our values and our interests. This is not an idealistic approach, it is a very pragmatic approach. We need a strong cooperation with Africa, which addresses Europe’s interests and African interests at once. There is no ‘horse-trading’; we are redrawing our partnership on new bases. This includes how we deal with migration, but also our cooperation on peace and security, on development and on counter-terrorism. This leads me another point, raised by Mr Verhofstadt. Yes, a new partnership with Africa is not just about managing mobility, but also tackling the root causes of forced displacement. And yes, investment, industrialisation, opportunities for private actors to engage in a partnership for development in African remains very important. Next, the security aspect of our cooperation. As many of you said, recent events only confirm that we cannot underestimate the threats we are facing. But let us also be clear on something: of course we must improve the checks on our external borders – it is obvious. But, as the attacks in Paris demonstrate, the threat to our own security mostly originates within our own borders. On the external side, the call for more cooperation on security comes directly from our African partners. Cooperating with Africa on security is consistent with our interests: think of the work we can do to control their borders, to fight international criminal networks and to investigate terrorist suspects. Finally, let me thank you once again for this debate and let me assure you that we count on the cooperation of this parliament and on its support in shaping not only migration but at the same time a new partnership with Africa.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, we cannot expect everything from a summit, but I believe that the Valletta summit has launched or perhaps relaunched a process and, as the Commissioner has just said, a process towards a new partnership between Europe and Africa. They are natural partners and not supporting this partnership is ultimately doing ourselves a very bad service.  However, we know that migration and development are two sides of the same reality and that it is not possible to achieve better management of migration flows without involving the countries of origin and without also integrating, in such management, mobility, that is, legal migration. Cooperation, which we have talked about a lot, may need to be reoriented, sometimes reoriented. We need real projects - we also talked about this this afternoon - that improve people's prospects, and that projects in the deep regions of Africa are being carried out for the benefit of the people, because these are the incentives that will convince people to stay put.  But better managing migration also means working with African countries. There are examples of projects where it works. I remember very well, since I was for a few years Minister of Immigration, that we had at one time a big problem of illegal immigration from Senegal to the Spanish islands. Well, it is thanks to cooperation with the Senegalese and Spanish authorities that we have been able to more or less control this illegal migration. New forms of cooperation must therefore be found.  Of course, we also have to live up to our financial commitments. We talked about a Marshall Plan for Africa and probably we will have to come. We do need to have resources, but we also need to make better use of them. The final point will be about conflicts in Africa. I believe that conflicts in Africa produce immigration, produce migrants, produce refugees. But we must never forget that the largest part of the refugees is in Africa itself, and that African countries sometimes also need to be helped to deal with these refugee problems at home. Next week there will be a meeting of the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly. I believe that this will be a new opportunity to revisit this common plan of cooperation, partnership between African countries and Europe. I think it's a great opportunity and an opportunity that we have to seize.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The Vallo Summit was another step in the implementation of the conclusions of the last European Council on migration: to erect europe's fortress walls higher and, in the end, to place barbed wire on top of those walls. This is, in all its rawness, the inhuman nature of EU policy in this area as well. A policy that criminalizes emigration. That assimilates migrants into criminals. A selective and repressive policy and, therefore, yes, ininmane. Because it denies those fleeing chaos, misery and war – which the EU has helped sow – their basic human rights, starting with the right to a better life. They used to call him expulsion, no candy. That is what this is really about, even if they now opt for euphemisms such as "return" or "return". The Conclusions of the European Council have been: expelling more migrants and doing so more effectively. The Vallifa Summit served as a sordid attempt to impose this agenda on African countries, themselves victims of imperialist and neocolonial drive-generating inequality, hunger and misery from migrants. The indigence of advanced values for so-called "aid and cooperation" speaks for itself, as does "conditionality", or let us be clear, the sibiline blackmail that conditions it to the acceptance of EU dictates.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. "I speak to the debate on migration to Europe today on the basis of my very recent experience in the Middle East. Recently, I visited refugee camps in northern Iraq for days with the papal aid organization Church in Need. I met with religious leaders and church organizations coordinating aid. My primary experience is that we fundamentally need peace and local solutions to manage migration. I am convinced that the European countries that once colonized do not have to deal with economic advantage at all prices in this situation. Investments and aid programmes should focus on the resources that are actually available. We need to focus all our efforts on programs to help us stay at home. This is primarily in the interest of refugees, because there is no reason why these ancient communities should migrate thousands of kilometres away, at the mercy of criminal networks, rather than living in their own culture.  My very specific experience is that we need to help internally refugees in two ways today. One is to provide education and the other is to find employment opportunities. In these two areas, there is a clear need for help as soon as possible, and these are also the keys to staying in place. It is a very serious problem that our decision-makers did not recognise the need for these steps much earlier. The situation is quite clear: either we help locally, in coordination, in cooperation with international donors, or the persecuted cannot last any longer, leave their homeland and head en masse to Europe.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. – At the Valetta Summit, EU leaders worked to solve the real problems of asylum. The summit focused on the reasons why refugees are forced to leave their home countries. Improving cooperation with African countries and better use of development resources in order to improve the situation of the people living there can bring about meaningful results in reducing the number of refugees. It is equally important to do everything possible to resolve the current armed conflict and prevent new crises. Turkey can also be an important partner in improving stability in the Middle East and addressing the problems of refugees. At the same time, this should not be a blank cheque: the EU must strictly monitor whether the Turkish Government adequately takes care of refugees and acts in compliance with its international obligations. We must be clear that europe's security now begins well beyond the borders of the Union. In an age of global problems, the European Union must also become a strong player on the international stage. Stronger European cooperation, joint action, effective management of international crises are the paths that help prevent refugees from going on mass journeys, and the solution is not fence building, anti-foreigner propaganda and violations of international law.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Burundi (2015/2973(RSP)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I now ask Minister Schmit to speak on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and The Union's High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. You change your cap...

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: président en exercice du Conseil, au nom de la Vice-présidente de la Commission/Haute représentante de l'Union pour les affaires étrangères et la politique de sécur. – Monsieur le Président, je change de casquette, mais c'est en fait une sorte de prolongation du débat que nous venons d'avoir puisqu'en parlant de crise en Afrique et de problème des réfugiés, car il y a beaucoup de réfugiés venant du Burundi dans les pays voisins du Burundi, on est tout à fait dans le thème débattu cet après-midi. There have been a number of emergency debates and resolutions on Burundi in the last year. Sadly, the situation in the country remains extremely grave, and we believe it is fully justified that we address this issue once again this evening. Both the European Union Ministers of Foreign Affairs and the United Nations Security Council have expressed themselves on Burundi in the last ten days. On the negative side, there is a broad recognition that, on a daily basis, violence in Burundi has reached an extremely dangerous level and that it has been exacerbated by the use of inflammatory and irresponsible language. Regrettably, we have had to condemn once again human rights violations and, of course, to express our solidarity with all the victims and families of the victims. Among those who have suffered is Mr Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, the human rights defender who is well—known and well—respected in this House. The humanitarian community has not been spared either, with the death recently of a staff member of the International Organisation for Migration. I repeat the EU’s absolute condemnation of human rights violations and of violence, whoever is responsible. More positively, we believe there is now a strong international consensus encouraging Burundi to get behind African-led processes which, in the assessment of the EU, provide the only viable way out of the crisis. Most important among these are the implementation of decisions on Burundi already taken by the African Union and the East African Community, and cooperation with the mediation efforts being undertaken by Uganda on behalf of the East African Community. The decision of the ruling party to nominate President Nkurunziza as a presidential candidate earlier this year created a serious division across society and across politics. That division needs to be addressed urgently and comprehensively. I would like to say a word on UN Security Council Resolution 2248, which is, of course, welcomed by the EU. There are three elements in this resolution which I want to stress tonight. Firstly, the resolution calls upon the Government of Burundi and all parties to reject any kind of violence, and demands that all sides in Burundi refrain from any action that would threaten peace and stability in the country. Secondly, it calls upon the Government of Burundi to respect, protect and guarantee human rights and fundamental freedoms for all, in line with the country’s international obligations. Thirdly, it urges the Government of Burundi to cooperate with the East African Community-led mediation to enable it to immediately convene an inclusive and genuine inter-Burundian dialogue in order to find a consensual and nationally-owned solution to the current crisis. You are all aware of the humanitarian situation, and in particular the pressure on facilities in Rwanda, Tanzania and the Democratic Republic of Congo. To date, we have allocated EUR 9 million to respond to the Burundian refugee crisis in the Great Lakes region. At a time when there are many conflicting priorities, we must ensure that attention is not diverted from the very real needs which the current crisis has caused. But at the same time we need to address root causes, and in particular violence and the rule of law. We announced in the summer that we would consider the adoption of individual restrictive measures against those linked to human rights abuses or to obstructing the search for a political solution. We have followed up on that by adopting measures against a number of individuals and will consider broadening the list if circumstances require it. We also undertook to prepare for the special consultations which are foreseen under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement. We have also followed up on that, inviting the Burundian authorities at the end of October to participate in a first meeting, which we hope could be held in December. There are a number of points I wish to stress about Article 96 consultations. Firstly, we want them to focus on the areas where we believe there has been a breach of the Cotonou Agreement and, in particular, human rights and the rule of law. Secondly, the talks are time-limited. We should focus on objectives which are achievable in a three- to four-month period and which lead the way to a longer-term strategy to exit the crisis.
