Thirdly, the consultations will support the activities of the African Union and the East African Community, encouraging as much as possible implementation of the decisions already taken by those bodies and encouraging cooperation with them in mediation, observation and facilitation activities. Finally, and most importantly, we will enter the talks with a positive spirit. The aim is to find a mutually-agreed solution and not to punish. The Cotonou Agreement allows for appropriate measures, including the cutting of aid, but the EU will take all steps to avoid actions which could put at risk already vulnerable populations. This is a point which Commissioner Mimica has stressed to this House before, and it remains true today. To illustrate this, while the EU has needed to make some changes to its assistance package, suspending its electoral support of EUR 8 million in June, withholding budget support payments and putting on hold the finalisation of the Annual Action Programme for 2015, at the same time we are committed to preparing major programmes on health and nutrition, ensuring that funding on existing actions, including those of the 11th EDF 2014 Annual Action Programme of EUR 60.7 million, is used for the purpose it was intended for. I mentioned earlier focus on the rule of law and human rights. This means in practice that we need to concentrate on some specific areas, which I know to be of concern to Members of this House: the media environment, the situation of civil society and human rights defenders, the justice system and disarmament. Arising under these are a number of specific cases of concern, which have been raised in previous debates here. The EU has been supporting Burundi in its efforts to entrench democracy since the Arusha Agreement put an end to years of civil war and laid the foundations for a new era. The spirit of these agreements is for us at the heart of the search for a solution to the crisis. I look forward very much to hearing the views of honourable Members.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is The conflicts in the Middle East and Africa affect us directly. The debates today have shown that all day. This is the third time this year that we have to discuss the situation in Burundi. After President Nkurunziza secured office in July by breaking the constitution, abusing elections, the horrors of this country are not abating. Opposition activists, journalists are being persecuted, more than 200 people have already been murdered and more than 200 000 have left the country. Refugee camps in neighbouring countries, particularly Tanzania, are already overcrowded. People there are already suffering hardship because care can no longer be maintained. That is why the resolutions have now been written enough, and we must finally act! According to the consensus of eyewitnesses, the Arusha trial is no longer effective on the ground. Others have already imposed sanctions: the President of the United States just yesterday or the day before yesterday, he issued sanctions against leaders of the Nkurunziza regime. The UN Security Council – as the Minister mentioned – has adopted a unanimous resolution condemning not only the persecution of people and the murders, but also the revival of the Blue Helmets mission, which was in that country until 2005 and helped to end the civil war. I think that the negotiating mandate that the Commission had is also slowly coming to an end. Of course, we want to help the people on the ground, but all support for the Nkurunziza regime should be stopped. And the fact that Burundi is providing 5 000 soldiers, which we have paid for, in the Somalia conflict should no longer be a reason, but rather a means of exerting pressure on the regime to stop the repression and persecution of its own people.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. –  Mr President, the violence in Burundi keeps escalating. Human rights defenders, journalists and their family members are attacked and murdered. Since President Nkurunziza insisted on continuing with his third term as President, and the politically-motivated killings started in April, at least 240 citizens have been killed. 215 000 Burundians have fled the country and many people are internally displaced. Public executions and silent killings continue. We saw that also during the last three weeks. I welcome the UN Security Council Resolution finally adopted on 12 November calling upon the Government of Burundi and all parties to reject any kind of violence and to immediately convene an inclusive and genuine dialogue with the ruling party and the opposition, both inside and outside of the country. But the sad thing today is that we could see this coming for years, and so it could have been prevented, but the international community chose to look away for way too long, even deciding to close the United Nations Office in Burundi (BNUB) six months before crucial elections. Now it is our duty to act so that a full-blown civil war in the country is prevented. The latest elections that were held in Burundi are not recognised by the international community, and the violence continues. So what is the EU doing in order to put pressure on the current government to comply with the UN security resolution?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The situation under President Nkurunziza is unworthy of a modern society. He is convinced that he deserves a third presidential mandate, and he is actually going against the will of his people, who elected in 2005 and voted for an inclusive and democratic constitution. In the working-class districts of the capital, fighting is taking place against the police, between supporters and opponents of the president, and the hateful messages of burundian leaders are pouring oil on the fire. The crisis is seriously affecting the fledgling democracy, fragile peace and difficult development in Burundi. The situation is dire for the entire Region of the Great Lakes. Burundi is just a dot on the African map, surrounded by Congo, Rwanda and Tanzania. The flow of refugees is increasing humanitarian pressure on neighbouring countries, leading to increased ethnic tensions. I draw particular attention to the problems of the refugee camps. Due to the start of the rainy season in Tanzania, the tents and toilets in the camps are in danger of being flooded, with all the consequences that entails. And a new flow of refugees threatens to make the situation even worse. We must not repeat the mistakes with the Syrian refugees. We must help to take in burundians in humane conditions in the region, with a view to their return later. International players saw Burundi too much and for too long as too little of geostrategic importance. Too small, too little influence. Diplomatic and military efforts focused on Rwanda, Uganda and Congo. As far as I'm concerned, an error of judgment. I hear that the High Representative is concerned now and that has indeed translated into measures. I also agree with you, Mr Schmit, that we should call for dialogue under international and African mediation. However, I would also like to draw attention to the importance of a review of European development policy. My government in Belgium, but also those in the Netherlands and Germany, are showing that development aid to the country is partially suspended, because we know that a large part of international aid is lost to corruption. At the same time, let's choose reorientation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – At a time like today when all our international attention is really focused on terrorism and the fight against terrorism, we must not forget the situation elsewhere. That is why I am pleased that Burundi is also on the agenda here today.  In April of this year, I warned, Mr President, of the debacle in Burundi. We see with all eyes that the whole region is once again being poisoned by one man's ambitions. You yourself said: many human rights violations, many refugees, many deaths. It's not clear where the country is going. The leaders use irresponsible hate speeches like lightning rods. Fortunately, the population is so far smart enough not to respond. But the tens of thousands of refugees are a reality that also burdens neighbouring countries.  The regional powder keg could explode quickly, I said in April, and I also warned of an imminent genocide due to preparations in progress. I would like to repeat this explicitly here today. Mr Minister, I thank you very much for the update. The UN Security Council has clearly chosen a position for the people and against the leaders who cling to power. The African Union is also a partner in achieving a genuine inter-Burundie dialogue. The EU, as burundi's largest donor, can and must mediate perfectly. The talks between the European Union and Burundi under the Cotonou Agreement must urgently lead to a political solution.  We are calling, Mr Minister, again for more security here for Europe. I would also like peace and security to return to the people of Burundi.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, the situation in Burundi has been getting worse since last April. We are witnessing an explosion of violence. Arbitrary arrests and executions are on the rise, killing at least 250 people to date. The interior minister sent thinly veiled threats of mass killing, causing the Tutsis to flee and already taking more than 200,000 refugees. Civil society is subjected to fierce repression. Ten major NGOs, including ACAT, have had their activities suspended and their accounts frozen. They're being harassed. Pierre Claver Mbonimpa is a symbol of this. He escaped an attack, but his own son has just been murdered. Prosecutions must be taken against all those who commit these abuses. Sanctions must be taken. The European Union has triggered Article 96 of the Cotonou agreement, so much the better.  The United Nations has adopted only a minimum text, without providing for the sending of a mission on the ground or sanctions, as originally planned, under pressure from the African Union, in particular, on the grounds that this would only be an internal crisis. Every effort must be made to stop the violence and prevent another genocide before it is too late.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President, since May 2015, over 100 human rights defenders have had to flee Burundi, which has been very much complicated by the fear of repercussions against their families. Indeed, in his speech made on 23 October this year, President Pierre Nkurunziza reminded the community in exile that they should not consider themselves superior to their fellow citizens still inside the country, especially since most of them left their families inside the country. This is truly horrific. I thank the Presidency-in-Office for following up the consultation process under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement by inviting the Burundian government to a dialogue on human rights. Impunity indeed is a huge problem in Burundi, as perpetrators of violence often do not have to face the consequences of their acts. The Burundian authorities must swiftly act here if they want to stop the spiralling of violence, and I believe it is a very appropriate move that the EU, like the US, has introduced personal targeted sanctions against those who are known to be perpetrators of violence. So I very much agree with the United Nations’ intention to consider all possible options against those in Burundi whose acts and statements contribute to the ongoing violence and hamper a peaceful solution. We must indeed avoid a second Rwanda. We should also pay attention to the fact that the African Union has started contingency planning for troop deployments, because that is what now seems to be very necessary to calm down and pacify the situation. One final thing is that there needs to be a national dialogue between all parties.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as has been said, the current Head of Government, now since 2005, in refusing to comply with Article 96 of the Constitution, which prohibits eligibility for a third term of office, has caused and is causing a number of problems in a country that is already in great difficulty. The risk is that the situation will deteriorate for reasons that my fellow Members have already mentioned. In addition, 85% of Burundi's population is made up of Hutu and 15% Tutsi, an imbalance which creates a number of problems between the two ethnic groups and is of concern in an area where the memory of the genocide in neighbouring Rwanda is alive. The tragedy could happen again and the threats are real and real.  The President of the Senate of Burundi even spoke of the pulverization of rebel districts and the Minister of Public Security reminded the Tutsis of their minority status, making it clear that the Hutu people could easily be incited to take action against tutsi. In this climate, freedoms and human rights are increasingly being restricted and human rights issues are being seriously called into question. The decision to close down NGOs that receive foreign funding is the last straw.  We cannot stand by and watch this: Europe has an important task to perform. The European Union recently allocated financial resources from the European Development Fund 2014-2020 to Burundi, among other things to assist burundi in strengthening governance and civil society: ironically! If this does not change, I believe that the European Union must ask itself the question of how to get out of this situation and to use the financial resources to exert all the necessary pressure, so that the political situation in Burundi can return to normal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the deranged situation in Burundi is endangering the lives of thousands of citizens in this African state. Because in Burundi human rights are being massively violated and thousands of people are fleeing as refugees to escape persecution and imprisonment. Among the thousands of prisoners is greek national Spyros Richard Hagabimana.  Mr Schmit, in a speech in this Chamber on 9 September, I informed Mrs Mogherini of Spyros' unjust imprisonment and asked for her intervention in his release. Then, on 15 September, I sent Mrs Mogherini a letter on this subject. Despite my constant interventions for the release of Spyros Hagabimana, despite strong protests on the Internet of thousands of citizens calling for his release, Spiros remains illegally in prison.  Do you know, Mr Schmit, why Spiros was imprisoned? Because he did not agree, as a Burundian police officer, to shoot at the protesters on July 28th. I therefore call on you for immediate intervention by the European Union to release Spiros, because his life is in danger.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, since last June, the situation in Burundi has only worsened, with daily repression and violence, and we have again seen the last decision of the Minister of Justice to close the bank accounts of most of the NGOs now active in Burundi.  This is, of course, to a large extent concern for the Burundian population, but it is also about the stability of the Great Lakes region. So I'll have three questions.  The first: the European Union has opened the consultation planned for Article 96 of Cotonou. It has taken targeted sanctions. What tools does the Union still have at its disposal to try to re-establish a situation that would not be a situation of dictatorship as it is today? The second issue concerns the budgetary assistance to the Burundian state. How can we redirect this aid to civil society, knowing that it is weakened on a daily basis? The third question concerns the situation in the camps in Burundi's neighbouring countries. More than 200,000 people are now refugees in these camps. How can we help these populations?

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Monsieur le Président, "j'ai été interpellé maintes fois au parquet. J'ai été arr'té, j'ai été emprisonné. Et maintenant, j'arrive au stade de mon assassinat. Mais tout'a, je dois le supporter parce que le travail de défenseur des droits de l'homme doit supporter n'importe quel malheur. Je dois absolument continuer jusqu'a the end of ma vie." Those are the statements Pierre Claver Mbonimpa made in Brussels when he recovered from a serious attack just before his son was murdered, when his son-in-law had already been killed.  And this Burundi debate sounds like a past to me. We talked about this; we've been able to act before. We have known for months that the President's third term would lead to an escalation of violence in the country and in the region, and we have done nothing. We always act late, always bad. And now, faced with a situation where we know perfectly well that the region can catch fire, let's do what we should have done months ago.  Our ability to influence through the Cotonou Agreement must be squeezed to the maximum. We must add, in our efforts, the key players in the region, especially the African Union.  Our help must go directly to those who need it, especially to the NGOs, whose situation my colleague Maria Arena was now denouncing.  It's time to think about the direct sanctions on those responsible for the government, who are leading the country into chaos. And the International Criminal Court must follow this situation very closely.  We, for our part, can only demand that it be done now.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Rwanda 1994. Burundi 2015: a new genocide? This question torments my soul and that of many, thinking of the fierce repression and terrible violence that is bloodied the streets of this country.  So far, the news shows 240 dead and 280,000 refugees. There are many corpses in the streets of opponents and even their relatives, such as the son and son-in-law of Pierre Claver Mbonimpa, a well-known human rights activist. The government continues to raise tension: it prevents NGOs from existing; a minister even calls on the nine million Hutu to solve the problem if the police are not enough to stop the opposition mainly Tutsi; a President of the Senate incites genocide, quoting Rwandan slogans.  If we had been more decisive before, perhaps we would have prevented that third candidacy in violation of the constitution by Nkurunziza, which has brought about a fire that can affect the entire region. It is time to think about vigorous sanctions against the current government, of all kinds, to suspend cooperation and isolate those who are inciting hatred and violence, and to be ready for an interposition mission to defend civilians and the weakest. If we don't do that, maybe we'il recriminated thousands of deaths again that could have been spared.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The political situation and the humanitarian crisis in Burundi have tragic consequences for the stability of the country and the region as a whole. In November alone, the number of burundian refugees in the Democratic Republic of Congo reached almost 16,000. Attacks against parties, opposition organisations, journalists, human rights defenders and the murder of their family members are condemnable and must be stopped immediately. The restriction of freedom of expression and the closure of private radio stations, as well as the use of hate speech by senior government officials in the public media, are fuelling an atmosphere of fear, which is why the joint declaration of cooperation on Burundi between the Union, the UN and the African Union adopted at the La Valletta Summit and the sanctions imposed on the country's public officials send a positive signal. In addition, the Burundian Government must immediately enter into consultations under the Cotonou Agreement in order to end the period of lawlessness in the country.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, when we spoke about Burundi for the last time in the 4th month, we all made it clear that we should prevent President Nkurunziza's third candidacy, but that did not happen. What happens next? Of course there will be eclatant human rights violations, persecution of NGOs, all human rights defenders, murders, some are already talking about genocide. Can we really co-finance the regime that sends us refugees? We have double funding for Burundi - I think this is definitely unacceptable and I agree with those who talk about us being able to give clear sanctions to such a regime and do everything to be with those who need it most, to help them at all times whenever we are able.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Burundi is another example of a call for cooperation and reaction from the international community, but as in other cases, it is usually the case that we arrive too late.  The situation in Burundi has been under fire for several years, including this may, when rivers of refugees rolled towards Tanzania, when the cholera period actually occurred, when diseases returned, which, of course, did not occur before. And this chaos, violence, killing in some way continues, and that is the responsibility of our community. If we are talking about co-financing, we are talking about co-financing those projects that lead to peace, co-sie and cooperation, not to killing and terrorism and producing refugees, which we then deal with on our soil later on.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Burundi's history is perhaps one of the saddest on the African continent. After a bloody and years-long civil war, the country managed to achieve stability, and two years ago it was given as a positive example of peace-building. Unfortunately, burundi has been teetering on the border of civil war for several months now, and its people either live in constant fear of oppression or decide to seek asylum in neighbouring countries. Unfortunately, more and more observers are even pointing to the threat of a genocidal conflict. The UN resolution adopted a few days ago condemning the escalation of violence in Burundi is certainly helpful, but insufficient.  I therefore believe that the European Union should step up its efforts in terms of diplomacy, aid, support for neighbouring countries, otherwise we will not only witness another genocide, but also another wave of refugees heading towards Europe.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I am very saddened by the spiral of violence that is repeatedly turning in this country, in a situation where the democratic process there has already been established. I think it is to be appreciated that the European Commission, or the Presidency, is also aware of this danger. And it is important that we demand at least three basic requirements. First, the immediate cessation of violence. That is a clear demand I think of all of us here. Secondly, accelerated aid to refugees. I think that we cannot confine us to the Middle East and North Africa, but we must also be aware of these risks in these other African states. Thirdly, there is a need for a return to democratic processes. I think we have the means and the ability to enforce these three legitimate requirements.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the December part-session.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the elections in Myanmar (2015/2974(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, on 8 November, Myanmar held historic elections contested by 91 political parties and over 6 000 candidates. The people have voted for change, expressing a strong desire to live in a new, free and democratic Myanmar. They have given a clear mandate to Aung San Suu Kyi’s National League for Democracy, with a solid majority in both houses of parliament, to take Myanmar’s democratic and economic reforms to the next level. We are pleased to say that the European Union has been at the forefront of international support for democratic transition in Myanmar, and we very much appreciate that the European Parliament has played a very important role in this respect. On 16 November, the High Representative called Aung San Suu Kyi personally to congratulate her on her election victory. She highlighted the crucial role that our 150-person-strong election observation mission, led by EP Vice-President Alexander Graf Lambsdorff, had played in the holding of peaceful and competitive elections. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Graf Lambsdorff for his commitment and his excellent work as EU chief observer. Myanmar’s democratisation process is, however, not yet completed. The disenfranchisement of the Rohingya and other ethnic minorities remains a matter of concern. In this election, unlike previous elections, the Rohingya could not cast their vote or stand as candidates. None of the big parties fielded Muslim candidates, apparently bowing to the strong influence of radical Buddhist monks. In some ethnic areas no election took place, on security grounds. The EU EOM preliminary statement points out that further constitutional, legal and procedural improvements remain necessary if totally fair and fully inclusive elections are to be held in the future. Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the largest party in Myanmar’s new parliament, is barred by the Constitution from running for President. The military will continue to occupy 25% of parliamentary seats, and, regardless of who forms the next government, three key ministers will come from the army. In that context, all political actors will need to engage in dialogue and work towards a peaceful transition in a spirit of national unity and reconciliation. Despite these challenges, we believe that we have witnessed landmark elections, offering a great opportunity to strengthen democracy in Myanmar. The next critical stage will be the election of the new president in mid-February 2016 and the formation of the next government by the end of March 2016. Although Aung San Suu Kyi has yet to reveal the priorities of the new government, we can expect that democracy, human rights, the rule of law and economic development will be high on the agenda. While Myanmar can count on our support, there are still issues of concern on which we will continue to constructively engage with Myanmar. These include the discrimination against, and the statelessness of, the Rohingya minority. The EU is also worried about Buddhist radicalisation, which has resulted in legislation on the protection of race and religion that is not consistent with the country’s international human rights obligations. EU-Myanmar relations have come a long way since 2011. With the exception of the arms embargo, sanctions were suspended in 2012 and then lifted in 2013. Everything But Arms trade preferences was also reinstated that year. An EU-Myanmar task force, with the active participation of the European Parliament, was set up in November 2013. The EU and Myanmar have stepped up cooperation in the area of human rights. Two rounds of human rights dialogue, led by the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, have taken place since 2014. Myanmar ranks high on our democracy support agenda, and we will look into appropriate follow-up with a view to implementation of the recommendations of the EOM, which will be presented early next year. In recognition of our assistance in the peace process, the EU was invited to sign the nationwide ceasefire agreement as an international witness on 15 October 2015. With other donors we are setting up a joint peace fund to further encourage the process. Last but not least, the EU and Myanmar are currently negotiating an investment protection agreement, and the EU is also part of a labour rights initiative, together with other partners. The EU defined its strategy and priorities in support of Myanmar’s transition process in the comprehensive framework adopted by the Foreign Affairs Council on 22 July 2013 and confirmed in the Council conclusions. The main priorities for engagement, democracy, peace, trade and development and Myanmar’s re-engagement with the international community continue to be valid. Our bilateral development cooperation programme under the 2014—2020 multiannual indicative programme for Myanmar amounts to EUR 688 million and features four focal sectors: rural development, education, rule of law and peace-building support. This is fully in line with the country’s transformative agenda. The EU is also a key provider of humanitarian assistance for vulnerable populations, in particular stateless persons and displaced populations. As Myanmar steps into the future, the scope of our engagement underlines the EU’s strong commitment to further supporting the country’s democratisation. The EU stands ready to play its part in helping to bring Myanmar’s transition process to a successful conclusion.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Together with six other parliamentary colleagues, I was part of the European Parliament's election observation mission to Myanmar. The impressions from this mission are positive. Both the conduct of the voting itself and the count were of high quality. No serious irregularities were reported. The turnout was estimated at around 80%. Since the elections, the current government has declared defeat. Opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and her NLD party received nearly 80 percent of the vote and negotiations are now underway on the formation of a new government. Having said that, it is essential to see the elections in Myanmar in its entire political context. Despite successful implementation and political progress in recent years, the country cannot yet be regarded as a democracy. The current constitution contains elements that are deeply problematic, such as the fact that Myanmar's military power is guaranteed a quarter of the seats in parliament. According to another part of the constitution, Aung San Suu Kyi is prevented from holding the important presidency. In addition, human rights violations are a serious problem. The number of political prisoners is increasing, as is discrimination against minorities. Among the worst affected are rohingyas and other Muslim groups, which have long been subjected to serious abuse and persecution. The challenges for the new Parliament are therefore great. A great deal of political leadership and willingness to reconciliation will be required on Myanmar's continued path to stability and peace, as well as continued support from the European Union.

name: Ana GOMES
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as leader of the European Parliament observation mission, I have had, together with other colleagues, whose very useful participation I thank, for the privilege of attending the most open and competitive elections that the admirable people of Myanmar have ever known, after 60 years of armed interethnic conflict and 50 years of military dictatorship. But it was elections that took place in a legal, institutional and political context that does not correspond to the international standards required by democratic elections.  The constitution imposed by the military junta in 2008 reserves to military 25 % of the seats in the chambers of the national assembly, regional assemblies and sectors of governance, the National Election Commission had doubts about whether it would be independent, the accreditation of candidates and voter registration were manipulated before, during and after the vote. Not to mention the millions of citizens, particularly ethnic minorities, not registered and prevented from voting. Having pointed to the shortcomings, progress must be pointed out, namely that it is the result of the acceptance of the defeat by the party associated with the military, a sign of its decisive role in the organization of the transition, and also to the progress promised by the undisputedly winning party, the NLD of Aung San Suu Kyi, which has promised to commit itself to change for democratic governance, dialogue, national reconciliation and peace. It will not be an easy process, in a country where generals are installed in power and control the administration and major natural resources, and the interethnic conflict and contempt for minorities, especially Rohingya Muslims, who, as has been said, have been prevented from voting and being elected, is frankly rooted, and very worrying is the exploitation by ultranationalist and xenophobic Buddhist forces of this trend.  The NLD therefore has a tremendous responsibility here to counter the racist and discriminatory messages that these forces have conveyed and to show that democratic governance and reconciliation will be truly inclusive and respectful of human rights. We, the European Union, have a strategic interest in supporting the democratisation process, monitoring the peace process, but above all supporting civil society, including political parties and including the NLD itself, because we absolutely also ask for a change in the Constitution.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the National League for Democracy (NLD) victory in Burma/Myanmar’s election this month is certainly an historic milestone, but it is the peaceful acceptance from the military and its politically-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP) which must be truly celebrated. A marked difference on what happened in 1990. The democratic transition over the next few months and years will be difficult, and it is important that the European Union offers all advice and support where appropriate and necessary. But much power is still vested in the National Defence and Security Council, which is outside of the elected government’s control. The military still retain 25% of reserve seats in the parliament, and Aung San Suu Kyi’s moral victory as leader is somewhat undermined by her bizarre legal inability to take office as President as the late wife and mother of British citizens. So keeping the roadmap to democracy on track will be a challenge. There are also concerns as to the plight of the minority Muslim Rohingya people in Myanmar, numbering around a million people. They have been denied voting rights in the latest election on the basis of being unable to prove their citizenship. Aung San Suu Kyi has said little on this issue and it appears that there is little appetite from the NLD to prioritise the fate of the Rohingyas, instead preferring to focus on state- and democracy-building in Myanmar. In achieving these goals there is still a long way to go. But Myanmar may yet prove to be a good example of a transition to pluralist democracy, a process that must be measured in decades, and not in years. Myanmar’s transition to democracy will also be a very welcome addition and boost to the democratic credentials of ASEAN.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in- Thank you for the kind words. I take this as praise for the work of the whole mission and i will pass it on. My mandate will continue until the final report is handed over. That is why I will be concerned in my remarks here on my neutrality, which is related to the office of chief observer.  But one thing is clear: these were truly historic elections. Anyone with even a bit of political flair noticed what hope this election was all about. In this respect, it was good that the European Union was able to make a constructive contribution here – both in advance and also through this observation mission.  Two things were particularly pleasing: one is that there has been virtually no electoral violence – neither before nor afterwards was this a problem. Secondly, many of the problems that were expected before the ballot did not appear on election day itself. The biggest problem, the biggest fear, was on the electoral roll. The people were by and large well found in the lists, so there was no restlessness there either. This result – Charles Tannock has just pointed out a strange constitutional situation, which we have already discussed in our preliminary report – is now putting the country in a very delicate transitional phase, and I would like the European Union to remain involved with all its institutions, to remain committed to helping the country in this. Let me say one thing here: there is often criticism of the crunch in the building when it comes to cooperation between the various European institutions. There is no reason at all to do so this time. The European Parliament, the Chief Observer, the delegation, Judith Sargentini, who, as permanent rapporteur, will continue to accompany the country on its path to democracy, have worked excellently with the European External Action Service. We have worked excellently with the Commission, the foreign policy instruments and, in particular, with the delegation under the leadership of a really very good ambassador, which fortunately we can have there, Roland Kobia.  This is a good example of good cooperation between the European institutions. Let us hope that the country also takes good development under the commitment of europeans.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Criticism of the preparation of the elections has been made by colleagues. Indeed, all kinds of people were not allowed to vote. I also share Mr Tannock's analysis of whether Mrs Aung San Suu Kyi will provide space for minorities. But all those criticisms, not to mention what we've seen, is an election day that was incredibly well organized. I especially have to praise the young ladies who manned all those polling stations. It's like they were running elections every day. We saw after the election that the military accepted the nld's gains. This is good news for the start of a new parliamentary democracy. But we're a long way from being there. The military has had 25 years to shape the constitution in such a way that it will be a battle before we can talk about a real democracy here, and that is a process in which we in the European Parliament could also play a role. We have decided together that Myanmar is one of the countries where we want to help parliamentary democracy. It is indeed my job to shape this together with you and that will be quite a task. However, it is a parliament where parliamentarians are not in a group, but in alphabetical order, and if that is the case then parliamentary democracy with a multi-party system is still a long way off.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I had the honour of taking part in Parliament's observer mission, which followed the elections in Burma/Myanmar, a mission led by my very good colleague Mrs Gomes. In Burma, democracy has won – indeed, won – with Aung San Suu Kyi's party, despite a Constitution that still gives the military 25% of the seats and three strategic ministries: defence, the interior and ethnic groups.  We have all heard the atmosphere of this victory in the run-up to the vote. But be ware: although the situation is now on tracks that are difficult to reversible, we are still in the middle of a transition and we must be cautious until the results are officially announced. This is not only because it will be along the path – I hope not decades – towards a fully civilian government and towards a change in the Constitution, but also because the start of change was primarily due to the heroism of St Suu Kyi, so many of her party and so many democrats who suffered unheard of suffering. But it has also happened because of a top-down impulse of the same regime which, in any case, does not want to give up all power.  A new path is now beginning: Burma must be supported, not only to deal with the emergence of war between the various ethnic groups. I visited the refugee camps on the border with Thailand and saw thousands of people without identity, rights and the future, suspended like their huts built in mud. The European Parliament cannot remain inert. Burma must become a federal state that gives everyone a home. The Burmese expect a great deal from us and we must not disappoint them.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, the electoral triumph of Aung San Suu Kyi is one that warrants significant celebration. With official results confirming 77% of the seats, the potential for change within Myanmar should be welcomed and encouraged. Clearly there are significant challenges ahead. The plight of ethnic minorities needs to be urgently addressed and, although both the military and allies of the newly—defeated government have promised to respect these election results, the real test will be to accommodate these groupings within the new regime to ensure stability and a more fruitful future. The EU has the capacity to provide an important supportive role in the changes that will inevitably occur. We should utilise this promising development to strengthen not only Myanmar’s burgeoning democracy but also our relations with the ASEAN region more broadly. The EU’s relationship with ASEAN states is growing, and any assistance the EU can provide should be reinforced. As a member of the Delegation to ASEAN, I was privileged to visit Aung San Suu Kyi in her home a couple of years ago, which remains one of the high points of my time as an MEP. So I would like to take this moment to finally congratulate Aung San Suu Kyi on what was a momentous result for her.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing my sympathy and my condolences for the workers who lost their lives in the jade mine on Monday. These elections represent a milestone in the recent history of Myanmar and its democratic transition. We are, of course, happy with the result and the electoral process, which was completed smoothly. But what deserves even more emphasis is the fact that the people clearly expressed their desire and support for democracy. Our official results show that people frequently supported a symbol of the peaceful fight for democracy, namely the Nobel Peace Prize winner and Sakharov Prize winner Aung San Suu Kyi. But let us not be under any under any illusions: these elections are a good starting point, but only a starting point in what remains a long transition. As we know, the winner will not be able to elect the president. 25% of the seats are in military hands, as are some key ministerial posts. What is essential now is the result, which must be respected by all and followed by national reconciliation. I am encouraged by the fact that the President and the military acknowledge the result. But now it will be necessary to work together for reforms. Europe should stand alongside Myanmar’s fight.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, an important milestone has been reached in Myanmar. I note the report from the EU electoral observation mission, and my congratulations go to Aung San Suu Kyi and NLD, who have won over two thirds of the seats. However, I am concerned that major shortcomings remain – chief among them, as my colleagues have already mentioned, is the fact that Rohingya were disenfranchised and could not vote. Legislation on the basis of race and religion is clearly not consistent with transition towards national reconciliation. Last Saturday we learnt that more than 100 people had been killed in a landslide near a jade mine. Military cronyism is said to be a key cause of poor conditions in the mining industry and to be fuelling conflicts in the Kotchen and Shan states. Conflicts like the one in East Congo have taught us that peace is not possible unless the link between military and business is broken. An important step has been taken in Myanmar with the signing of the extractive industries transparency initiative, but this will lead to change only if implementation is made a priority. The EU needs to support the new leadership in tackling these major concerns and maintaining a positive dynamic in the ASEAN. We have seen major economies like Thailand and Malaysia backslide on human rights issues lately, so I welcome the investment protection negotiations that have been re-launched, and I would like to ask a representative of the Commission, if they were here, or the High Representative, to reflect on possibilities for further engagement that will allow us to provide incentives for change, ensuring maximum coordination between the various instruments in order to make sure that trade and investment reinforce, rather than undermine, human rights and democracy.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, I would also like to commend Myanmar on the conduct of elections with an historical importance. The citizens of Myanmar demonstrated their will, which was translated into election victory for the National League for Democracy (NLD). The crucial question however is: what will happen now? The process brought the country closer to democracy. However, there is still a lot to be done. I want to believe that the NLD will be able to start the reform process in Myanmar. At the same time, national reconciliation and inclusiveness need to be high on the agenda. This will be a true challenge for Mrs Aung San Suu Kyi. We in the European Union have a lot of experience with such transition processes, therefore we should be ready to assist our partners in Myanmar on the road ahead. I want to ask the High Representative to follow the situation after the elections and be ready to propose assistance to the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the people of Myanmar in the elections of 8 November decided to end the sovereignty of the military and junta that have dominated the country for the last twenty-five years.  Millions of people participated en masse in the general elections and gave the victory to Aung San Soo Ki. The Nobel Peace Prize-winning politician who has been persecuted by Myanmar's junta.  But the new democratic government faces significant challenges. First of all, the military must cease to hold twenty-five per cent of the seats in parliament. Secondly, censorship must be abolished. At the same time, forced labour, racism and violation of human rights must be eliminated.  The European Union must stand by Myanmar's new democratic government, which, however, must also ensure the protection of ethnic and religious minorities living in the country, such as the Rohingya, against whom discrimination and oppression by Buddhists continue, as I have repeatedly denounced in this Chamber.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these elections in Myanmar tell us of a fundamental step in the country's history: democracy is finally back. I would also like to thank my fellow Members who have had the honour and the burden of representing the European Parliament at such an historic time.  But now the Government of Myanmar is facing very difficult challenges: on the one hand, finally succeeding in completely reducing the influence of the military, which unfortunately still retains 25% of the seats; on the other hand, there is a country to rebuild, a country that today spends only 1.8% of GDP on health and only 0.8% on education.  GDP growth must lead to an increase in well-being and development for the whole population, and this goes from the fight against corruption but also passes through decisive action against discrimination against the Rohingya population, one of the most persecuted minorities in the world.  Aung San Suu Kyi is used to repeating that fear is the only prison. Let us hope that there will be no prison in Myanmar for change and, as the European Union, we can only support this change.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I have to say that for me, the morning we woke up to the election results that came from Myanmar was a very great opportunity to appreciate the developments that have taken place over the last few years. , which was launched in Myanmar. I think we should also support the activity of the election winner, Ms Suu Kyi, who now has the greatest responsibility. And to ask the High Representative and, of course, the Presidency, to make every effort to support the democratic process that has just started in Burma. The determination, the efforts of the citizens in Myanmar, which was seen on the cameras from the pictures, the happy faces, the smiles, I think we should support them, because that is our future together.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – As a member of the European Union's Election Observation Mission in Myanmar, I asked for the floor in today's debate. Based on my experience on the ground, I agree with all those who described the elections on 8 November as a calm, well organised and transparent event. In yangon and the Bago region, more than a dozen voters have convinced me that those responsible for conducting the election have done their job responsibly and responsibly. Even with high turnout, the Election Day process was conducted smoothly and efficiently.  However, it is also clear that the legal environment, the legal context and the pre-election processes have left much to be wished for. Discussions with NGOs, representatives of ethnic minorities and the media highlighted a number of such shortcomings. The most obvious of these, of course, is the fact that a quarter of the seats automatically belonged to the military. Overall, however, Myanmar, which has a dictatorial history of many decades, took a huge step towards a democratic establishment on 8 November.  The necessary further procedural reforms in relation to elections are dwarfed by the historic fact that the citizens of Myanmar have put their faith in democracy with dignity and an overwhelming majority. I am convinced that the European Union made the right decision when it supported the process of this peaceful transition by organising an election observation mission.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – The most important question following the resounding victory of the National League for Democracy party (NLD) in the recent elections in Myanmar is what Ms Suu Kyi’s plans are for ending one of the world’s longest-running civil wars and for transforming the country into a peaceful federal union by honouring the key promises from the Panglong Agreement. Although it might be speculated that the votes cast for the NLD in multi-ethnic minority states were the result of a tactical decision to weaken the former ruling party, the multi-ethnic national mandate of the new President cannot be denied. Now it remains to be seen what Ms Suu Kyi will do with this mandate and the hopes of ethnic minorities making up around one third of the country.  We are also eagerly awaiting the steps she will take to put an end to the terrible persecution of the Rohingya minority, the members of which were not allowed to take part in the elections. Also, I do hope that in her democratisation efforts Ms Suu Kyi will find a reliable and strong partner in the European Union.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – On 8 November 2015, the first free elections in the history of Myanmar took place. All of the country’s 135 ethnic groups, across numerous religious and socio—economic backgrounds, gathered in order to contribute to this historic moment in the Republic of the Myanmar. The NLD Party, which secured a majority of Union Parliament seats is a great hope for the people of Myanmar. The fact that the elections took place might be just a beginning for creating a new, more democratic society, but it is a significant step forward. This is due to the fact that the elections were a major milestone in the transition process that Myanmar is going through. This is truly a generational transition – after six decades of conflict and five decades of authoritarian rule. Therefore, those elections can be considered a credible sign that Myanmar is really changing. Hopefully the next thing we know is that it will accelerate its international relations and outside support and reinstate national changes.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Georgia (2015/2975(RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me reaffirm the EU’s commitment to continuing with Georgia’s political association and economic integration with the European Union. The High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy / Vice-President of the Commission, Federica Mogherini, paid a successful visit to Georgia on 10 November. We also held our second Association Council meeting in Brussels on 16 November. Commissioner Hahn will be in Tbilisi tomorrow. Our high-level engagement has thus been continuing almost weekly this November. The EU-Georgia Association Council looked at the progress made in the implementation of the EU-Georgia Association Agreement that was signed in June last year.  It also looked at some of the challenges remaining. Regarding progress, we welcomed the good implementation of the DCFTA so far and, of course, the Eurostat reports showing an increase in Georgian exports to the EU. The approximation of Georgian laws to EU standards is progressing at a good pace. At the same time, it is important to make businesses in Georgia aware of the functioning and benefits of the DCFTA. Let me turn to the challenges. There is a need to guarantee a political environment that is calm and respectful.  Steps or statements in the opposite direction need to be avoided. We have stressed in all our contacts that democratic momentum needs to be maintained, in particular regarding the parliamentary election in October 2016, and that we expect the independence and effectiveness of the institutions – including, of course, the Constitutional Court – to be fully respected. The same applies to institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights in Georgia. The forthcoming election campaign will be the first with the Association Agreement in place. We share and support the Government’s stated goal of having free and orderly elections, with an outcome fully recognised as legitimate. It is essential to guarantee media freedom, implying that opposition parties must be given proper access to the media. We also appreciate Georgia’s progress in implementing judiciary reforms. The independence of the judiciary is at the heart of our association. Although the EU does not pass judgement on the merits of individual cases before the courts, we monitor whether our shared principles are being respected. This applies to the so-called high-profile trials, as well as to recent cases such as the private lawsuit against Rustavi 2 and the pre-trial detention of three opposition activists. We will continue to assist Georgia in its efforts to reform the judiciary, to safeguard the rule of law and strengthen the independence of the judiciary. At the Association Council, Federica Mogherini, High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy / Vice-President of the Commission, and Commissioner Hahn welcomed the progress made by Georgia towards visa liberalisation, with many benchmarks already being fulfilled. These efforts need to continue. Though the final decision cannot be anticipated at this stage, we see positive signs for the process ahead of us. Developments in the breakaway regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia were also on the agenda for the Association Council. Vice-President Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn reiterated the EU’s firm support for the territorial integrity of Georgia, within its internationally-recognised borders. The EU remains firmly committed to peace, stability and conflict-resolution, and our policy of non-recognition and engagement in Georgia. The EU Special Representative for the South Caucasus and the crisis in Georgia, the EU co-chairmanship of the Geneva international discussions, and the EU Monitoring Mission are visible and substantial signs of that commitment. The EU has also expressed appreciation for Georgia’s contribution to EU-led crisis management operations and missions in the Central African Republic and Mali, and to the EU Advisory Mission in Ukraine.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: for the PPE Group. Allow me, ladies and gentlemen, a memory. I experienced the revolutionary fall of two regimes in Georgia. The fall of President Gamsachurdia's regime and the fall of President Shevardnadze's regime. I therefore highly appreciate that the last change to the ruling class was made on the basis of democratic elections, and Georgia once again got rid of some of the old Soviet burden. It will be difficult to get out of this inheritance for a long time to come. Examples of this include attempts to reincarnate Josif Stalin's memory, new construction of his monuments, worship at demonstrations. Selective justice and the criminalisation of former political structures are also a burden from the past. We were able to observe it very strongly a few days ago. It was to Stalin that the Minister of Justice of Georgia compared former President Saakashvili at a meeting of our Committee on Foreign Affairs. Even unhealthy tensions between the ruling GD (Georgian Dream) and the opposition UNM (Unated National Movement) are a burden from the past. An example is the current unacceptable events surrounding the independent television station Rustavi 2. After all, pluralism of information and freedom of expression is one of the fundamental values of a democratic society. A few years ago, as a journalist, I filmed a television report on Yevgeny Yugashvili. He is the grandson of the aforementioned Josif Stalin. He lives in Tbilisi. We may think that the marginal Communist Party he founded is ridiculous and not dangerous. But the specter of the past bypasses Georgia and can seriously damage the country. Ladies and gentlemen, last December, we approved an association agreement with Georgia at this point. The agreement is based on strict respect for the principles of democracy, respect for the law, protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. I wish Georgia a lot of courage and strength for this. We need Georgia with a consolidated political scene.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy was presented last week. Its aim is that of revitalising and making more effective relations with the EU’s neighbours. In this context, we should give a new boost also to our Eastern Partnership or, at least, based on a differentiated approach, to the countries showing their readiness for developing relations and cooperation with the EU. Georgia is today a frontrunner from this point of view, and we need to bear in mind its importance for us and the need to stand by a country and people who have shown a clear pro-European attitude. Georgia is a very important partner for the EU in the Black Sea region and, I will also underline, a faithful one in the current dramatic context. After the signature of the Association Agreement, Georgia showed its commitment by making significant progress in the reforms, including in the framework of the visa liberalisation action plan. I hope that the next progress report will confirm all the efforts made by Georgia and that Georgian citizens can be rewarded with the free visa regime. Having said that, I would also like to underline that we cannot take Georgia’s stability for granted; we need Europe to provide all necessary assistance for the reform process, but also to support and reaffirm Georgia’s right for its independence, territorial integrity and sovereignty, keeping in mind the destabilisation process started by Russia in 2008 and recently continued with the signature of the so-called treaties with the breakaway regions of Abkhazia and Ossetia. At the same time, let us be clear, Georgia itself needs to ensure its internal stability, with a fair political environment, cross-party political support for key reforms and also a fair atmosphere in the electoral campaign. Finally, my plea to the EPP Group is: please stop playing politically the case of Georgia, because in this way we cannot help Georgia but, on the contrary, only its enemies.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the illegal annexation of Crimea has caused enormous tension and fear in Georgia, affecting this country and bringing it even closer to the Western security and defence structure. Georgia is the sole non-NATO member participating in the NATO rapid response force. It is also extremely active in our CSDP efforts, as mentioned by the Commissioner, in Mali, the Central African Republic and Ukraine. I would like to praise these efforts. But there are also less positive outcomes of Georgia’s policies. I would like to mention, in particular, freedom of expression and the Rustavi 2 case. Being a long-standing friend of Georgia, I count on changes in these areas. I would like to mention also the existence of political prisoners – opposition leaders imprisoned in Tbilisi and elsewhere. I really count on a major change in these areas, and I strongly support visa liberalisation for Georgia.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, because I am friends with Georgia and the Georgian people, I want to speak frankly and clearly. When business mixes with politics, in the end it's business policy. And so, if you look at what the hyperpresence of Mr. Ivanishvili's economic interests means, whose fortune ranks 153rd on the Forbes list and equals two-thirds of Georgia's gross national product, and checks how the profiles of the members of the Government continually appear — in the presidency, in that of their prime minister , those of seven ministers, that of the Director General of Security — the word ex-worker, former head of Cartu, who is the bank owned by Mr. Ivanishvili, one feels a deep sadness, to understand that we are talking about the same thing: politics and business. Secondly, there is no freedom, no democracy, no freedom of expression and no freedom and judicial independence. I want to mention the Rustavi case and tell our brothers, our Georgian friends that they are facing a credibility test through this case. Act and let justice act. We know that there has been significant, very positive progress in Georgia, but there is still something as essential as the credibility of the judicial system and freedom in the press, issues on which it needs to be deepened. And I also want to talk about ourselves. Look, if we want to be facilitators of the issues, what we cannot do is resolve them as we did in a Resolution on the Black Sea Basin, which calls on Ukraine, the Republic of Moldova and Georgia to integrate into the military field, including by creating a multinational force, and NATO countries are invited to support it. Are we crazy? Don't we know what Georgia's difficult balance means? Do we just care about ourselves? Let us be cautious, let us be realistic, because surely the rapporteur who did it, if Georgia has problems, will not leave his peaceful country.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, Georgia has destroyed infrastructure, an industry destroyed, and yet, even though it has only eleven percent of gross domestic product in the Caucasus region, it is a key country for stabilising the Caucasus. It has excellent energy potential, electricity is now georgia's main export item more than wine or brandy. I would like to say that it is high time that some Marshall Plan for the Caucasus was adopted, which would also open the way to national reconciliation. In the past in Georgia there were excellent cultural and thinker personalities such as Mamardashvili, Begiashvili, Chaavchavadze, Abuladze and others. Today there is misery and decline. I think that culturally these countries are very close to each other, they have considerable potential that we should develop, and there is also one of the few chances to prove the functioning of the Eastern Partnership. Because we can't handle the Eastern Partnership yet. Not in the case of Ukraine, not in the case of Moldova, nor in Belarus, nor in the Caucasus countries. Dear friends, I think it is high time to act and stop empty proclamations. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Negotiating Committee).)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: the blue card. – Colleague, thank you for agreeing to answer my question.  I agree that construction, energy, agriculture are important for Georgia, we wish it good luck and progress. I am a friend of Georgia, but Georgia is recovering slowly from Soviet heritage. But in recent years, seven new monuments have emerged for Stalin. This is the greatest murder that has committed the greatest crimes against humanity. Tens of millions of men, children and women were innocently murdered for one reason: they did not want to become Soviet slaves. Colleague, do you see this monument that was built for Stalin? That's what I'll do when I talk about it.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I think that the question is missing the subject of our discussion today. It was not I who said that Stalin and Mengelec Berija were his political role models, but it was Saakashvili who said that these two were his role models. My country, which was forced, of course, under pressure from Stalin, to change course and also to abandon the original path it had set out after The Second World War. But that's another matter. I think this is an opportunity for historians and not for MEMBERS of the European Parliament. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Negotiating Committee).)

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. - I listened with interest to your words, which sounded very nice. However, I would like to ask, if you were calling for a Marshall Plan for Georgia, will Georgia or the Caucasus not be threatened with a similar rejection of the Marshall Plan as the Communists did after 1945 within Czechoslovakia?

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. Things were much more complicated than the Marshall Plan. I will give one example that shows how unnecessarily politicized the atmosphere was at the time. When the drought came in 1947 and it affected Czechoslovakia, there was a huge crop failure and there were two countries that actually gave the opportunity to obtain grain for our country, but both gave political conditions. The situation was so heated that an offer from the Americans and the Soviets was considered, but a third country that gave no political conditions, Canada, was rejected.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, despite all the shortcomings and challenges in Georgia, I believe that it is one Eastern partner country that is showing that it is very committed to the European future. Five years ago I personally would not really have believed that one day – I could not stop the thought – this country may indeed become a member of the European Union. Of course, at the moment this is still far away, but I think the country is making a great effort and we have to support its European choice because, as we know, the long shadow of Russia is on every eastern partner country. Compared with the previous regime, I believe that the reforms have continued and there have been results. I also believe that despite certain shortcomings the justice reform has continued, and it is quite right that we should pay attention to the Rustavi 2 case in order to show that we do indeed take a very tough line where media freedoms and the independence of the justice system are concerned. We do have some hope and we have some good signals that the Constitutional Court has lately, even in this case, been showing considerable independence in the face of political pressure, and that is what we have to support. And, what is more, I believe that we as the European Parliament have a great task of supporting Georgia and the other Eastern partner associating countries to help them become a part of our community.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner's representative, I will make a slightly broader, more geopolitical statement. We have gone from a unipolar world, characterized by American leadership, to a bipolar world. China today is the second largest economy, and the leading power, by the way, in purchasing power parity. To maintain its leadership, the United States needs Europe. The transatlantic treaty is part of this perspective. Above all, they need Europe to cut itself in two and not to have a multipolar world and an Eurasian alliance. If it were European - and here it is an Alsatian who speaks - the whole policy of the European Commission would consist - in the image of Germanic culture and French culture, which have enabled Europe - to build bridges between two cultures, namely between Western and Eastern culture, and in particular Russia, and would allow the construction of this great multipolar European complex. But you don't want it! You want all countries, whether Serbia, Moldova, Georgia or Ukraine, to make an exclusive choice in favour of a policy contrary to the interests of Europe. You are betraying Europe. You'll be judged!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, the European Union considers Georgia to be a pioneer in the context of the Eastern Neighbourhood policy and supports its territorial integrity and the end of conflicts in the breakaway provinces of Abkhaza and South Osetia.  This policy is correct, but it must also be implemented in the right way, i.e. it must not be directed against Russia's interests. Russia was, and still remains, an important strategic partner for the European Union. This reality has been emphatically apparent at this time when cooperation with Russia is essential in the fight against ISIS.  There is therefore no reason to continue the rivalry between us by using Georgia as a vehicle in this direction. On the contrary, there must be an honest dialogue and cooperation with Russia, especially now that international developments and circumstances facilitate such an approach. Indeed, if we strengthen Georgia's efforts for democratisation and economic development, we will certainly contribute to the creation of a better Europe.  Finally, I believe that the timeless mistakes that led Europe to the tragic developments in Paris give us a measure of pragmatic political behaviour and will not be repeated in the future.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am pleased that you are still allowed to sit in front of a European flag. Your Prime Minister should take this as an example! Georgia is an important, emerging partner for us. The citizens of Georgia are important to us as Europeans because they are oriented towards the European Union, because they work with us. We want to see them in our system of order, we want to see them in our economic area, because that is how the zone of stability in our neighbourhood grows. Our commitment to Georgia is not free of conditions. We expect respect for human and civil rights, we expect the rule of law, we expect pluralism in democracy. The citizens of Georgia also have these expectations. Georgians support modernisation and reform. Politicians and parties need to be more careful with this than before. I am not a Georgian, I am not italian, but I like passion in politics and leadership in political action. But it is wrong for political zeal to destroy cooperation among Democrats. It is wrong for politicians to be exhausted in the struggle for power. It is wrong for the opposition not to be able to play its constitutional role. And it would be wrong to equate media. The citizens of Georgia have expectations of politics: that problems are solved, that progress is achieved, that their country can develop in a European way, free from patronising and interference by its great neighbour Russia. This will be possible if Georgian politics creates social cohesion, if it works for the common goal, if our European dream also becomes the dream of all Georgians!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Mr Gahler, I like your sense of humour, by the way.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, this year marks the 23rd anniversary of the establishment of official diplomatic ties between the European Union and the Republic of Georgia. Our mutual relations have always been oriented towards dialogue and partnership. Last year saw the signing of the new Georgia Association Agreement, which also includes a deep and comprehensive free trade area. With the respective economic reforms under way (industrial, trade, social), the AA-DCFTA should provide the impetus to Georgia’s further development. Progress on the visa liberalisation dialogue, however, could definitely be speeded up. Georgia has advanced in the implementation of the necessary reforms no less or even much more than Ukraine or Moldova, yet the former already has a visa-free regime. The fight against corruption – especially through the establishment of a specialised anti-corruption unit within the office of the Chief Prosecutor in January this year – organised crime, money laundering and human trafficking, the advancement of human rights and media freedom policies, as well as the new progressive law on state employers – and more – already shows that Georgia is more than ready to successfully finish the dialogue. As the High Representative recently pointed out, the country is not only developing its own ties with the EU but also acts as the regional transmitter of European processes in the Southern Caucasus region. Respect for modern democratic values and culture built on historically-involved traditions and customs, especially the important role of the Georgian Orthodox Church and the Patriarch His Holiness Ilia II – this is the Georgia of today. Therefore, both as a parliamentary rapporteur on Georgia and as someone sincerely interested in the further advancement of EU—Georgia ties, I would like to point out that if there is a neighbour with whom the EU could definitely build much stronger relations, it is the Republic of Georgia.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, having just led, on behalf of this Parliament, the first Parliamentary Association Committee meeting with the delegation from this Parliament with our counterparts in Georgia, may I firstly start by thanking my Co-Chair and our counterparts in Georgia, and indeed all of my colleagues who played a very full part in all of those Groups that were present for the duration of the meetings that we had there. It was quite a challenging mission in many ways, but I believe we achieved one thing, and that was to move our relations beyond party political affiliations to a genuinely parliament-to-parliament level, and I think we will serve ourselves well if future resolutions build upon the final statement that we were able to achieve. I thank the Commission for the report on the DCFTA and the Association Agreement. The next step, of course, must be towards visa liberalisation. In terms of the Georgian people, that is their dream in terms of the immediate future. There is a Russian angle and it sends a very powerful signal to the people of Abkhazia and Ossetia that they must invest in this future direction as well. We have, of course, elections approaching very soon, and this is where it is essential that Georgia shows its commitment to European values, and that is best demonstrated by their commitment today to media freedoms.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his very optimistic summary of political developments in Georgia. I wish, Commissioner, you were fully justified in your assessment of what has happened lately. Georgia has made tremendous progress since it regained its independence and, as my colleague Mr Štětina rightfully pointed out, going peacefully through both a constitutional change and a change of government is not a small feat. Many of our countries could be proud of that as well. Having said that, I need to point out that political stability is never a given – never something which we can take for granted. You should actively work on achieving political stability at all times, and this includes respecting the political opposition as a legitimate rival, which is a sine qua non for democratic politics. Likewise, the political opposition is required to understand and work for a peaceful change in government within the bounds of democratic politics. One point I would like to make, the last poll published on 13 October showed that actually there is 12% support for openly pro-Russian parties in Georgia. That is the danger which we need to avoid.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Mr President, Georgia is the EU's priority in its neighbourhood policy and has demonstrated its commitment and commitment to pro-European reforms. After the Rose Revolution in 2003, the country underwent a major transformation from a post-Soviet state under Russian influence to a state that clearly represents its interests and European orientation.  Most of the changes came unfortunately with the high cost of an economic and energy blockade from Russia and armed conflicts in South Ossetia and Abkhazia. The Association Agreement and the FTA will provide Georgia with the necessary guidance to implement the necessary reforms.  However, recent developments related to the proceedings against the Rustaveli 2 television station, as well as pressure on the opposition, are worrying. I was part of a delegation from the foreign affairs committee this July when we visited Georgia and drew attention to the phenomenon of a politically selective judiciary and visited several prisoners from the former opposition, i.e. the authorities.  Also worrying is the situation related to this election year where media freedoms must come into full focus and ensure an equal campaign. Therefore, I want Georgia, a friendly country to my Croatia, to use all the potential it has. We heard the foreign minister and the deputy prime minister, the justice minister a few days ago on the Foreign Affairs Committee. We hope that the reforms they want to implement and the political culture dialogue will go forward and that both the Association Agreement and the FTA, and in particular the upcoming decision, I hope, on visa liberalisation will help Georgia on its European path and accelerate the dynamics and become one of the leading countries in the Eastern Partnership.

name: Kati PIRI
