text: – Mr President, Georgia is, in many respects, a success story. It is the only country in the region that managed a peaceful transition from one government to another – a transition effected in the electoral booths rather than on the streets. Furthermore, Georgia is one of the three countries in the eastern neighbourhood which have stated that they want a closer relationship with the EU. The Association Agreement is the fundament of this – a relationship based on values. The rule of law, human rights and media freedom are at the core of these values. Therefore it is crucial that even the perception of political interference with the judiciary and a free press is avoided at all times. In this regard, to put it diplomatically, the case of Rustavi 2 should have been handled differently. But it is likewise worrying how former President Saakashvili tried to instrumentalise this case to instigate unrest, which is the last thing Georgians need right now. Georgia has to deliver on reforms. Furthermore, there so much instability around the country that it cannot afford deep internal divisions. The threats are external. Three years after the democratic change of government, it is high time for the political forces in the country to unite. An important tangible result of EU-Georgia cooperation might be the abolition of visa requirements for all Georgian citizens, but that could come under threat if the unhealthy political rivalry in the country continues. Are there still problems in Georgia? Yes, certainly. To name a few: the winner-takes-all mentality continues to prevail; the most influential political actor in Georgia is not accountable to anyone; and radical groups keep popping up, although it is a mystery who is financing them. Nevertheless I am confident that, with a genuine effort by all the political forces in the country, the necessary reforms already started under the previous administration can continue, and Georgian citizens can soon reap the benefits of closer cooperation with the EU.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Georgia, among all the Eastern Partnership countries, is the fastest developing democratic principles of cooperation, transparency and pluralism. Georgia's position has improved in virtually all rankings, both in terms of media freedom, the internet, compliance with the law, the quality of civil rights management. These are facts. It is also a fact that pro-European and pro-democracy political sentiment and parties may be threatened by rising populist, anti-European groups. The strength of populist parties comes not so much from the seductive programme proposal to voters, but from the mistakes of the ruling elites, present and past, disillusionment with their attitudes revealed in the eavesdropping scandals. Opposition to the ruling is also aroused by brutal methods of dealing with the political opposition and the opposition media – as was the case recently with Rustavi 2 television. The overlapping problems with the separatist provinces of Abchaya, South Ossetia are causing concern as to whether Georgia will be able to maintain its Western course and the pace of democracy and economic development.  In this context, I would like to draw attention to the issue of visas, which are negotiated between the competent offices of Georgia and the European Union. Visa-free travel between Georgia and the Union would benefit both sides not only for political reasons, but also for economic reasons and in the context of the development of the Bologna Process, which Georgia is pursuing in an exemplary manner. Georgia also needs more Union activity in the media and public relations fields, so that Russian propaganda does not have such an easy field to act. We need to work with the media community, help develop a journalism workshop, but also provide information so that both politicians and voters can build their opinions on a broad and credible spectrum of facts and opinions. The question for your representative, to the Commissioner at this point, about progress in the visa negotiations: do we have a chance, is there any chance of a close final, a positive final, and are we planning media projects or will they be implemented in Georgia?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, in the context of the current European Neighbourhood Policy, I would like to make it clear that those countries that wish to pursue deeper relations with the EU should be fully supported. At the same time, it should be clear that such countries have to live up to certain standards. Georgia is one of the countries which has shown dedication to its European path through political association and economic integration. Georgia should have our support in further developing its relations with the EU just as in defending its territorial integrity. For instance, we should move forward on energy market integration with Georgia through the energy community. Having said that, I would also like to urge Georgia’s political leaders to fight their political battles in the parliament and not via pre-trial detention or jail. There have to be clear lines for the rule of law and fair democratic processes.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, relations between the European Union and Georgia are particularly important, because this country is an important factor for the security of the Caucasus region. Georgia has emerged as a pioneering force for the consolidation and functioning of the Eastern relationship.  The Eastern relationship must primarily be aimed at strengthening the Economic Relations of the European Union with the respective States and, of course, with Georgia. It should aim to ensure the Union's energy security, to develop relations on the basis of mutual benefit, to strengthen trade in goods and services.  However, the Eastern relationship should not be used in some respects as a means of intervention in Georgia's internal political life. Georgia must be left unaffected to define its internal political life sovereignly while ensuring respect for human rights, democracy, civil rights and the rule of law. Only under these conditions can the political situation in Georgia develop positively, in view of the elections to be held in 2016, for which pluralism and the rights of the opposition must be guaranteed.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, Georgia is a country with a rich history and a pronounced national culture. No doubt the country is part of European history and fully deserved only a year ago celebrated the signing of the Association Agreement with the European Union. Particularly impressive is the fact that more than 69% of the population support the agreement and that there is a nationwide consensus on the country's membership in NATO. For many years Georgia was part of the Soviet Union and today seeks its European identity.  As someone coming from a former communist state, I am clearly aware of the challenges young Georgian democracy faces. The disturbing events of recent months are proof of this and we cannot help but tolerate them. However, we must insist that all parties respect the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and media freedom. Georgia needs our continued support to strengthen its European path.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – We have heard a lot of positive thoughts and words about Georgia today – the question is, of course, what is really real – and data on progress, information about a country that can be an example to others. Of course, it is very important how we measure this progress, how we measure the effects of this progress, what these criteria are, and that is why I also asked to speak, because I consider it important that the European Commission and the European Parliament also work together with the institutions here through the pasarela, with the Council of Europe, the Council of Europe, which plays a major role in assessing the human rights and democracy situation. , the situation in the area of justice, freedom of the media, freedom of expression, and sometimes it seems to me that it is necessary for the Commission and the Council of Europe to cooperate even more precisely on these fundamental standards, such as human rights, and to assess progress, because we know that the Council of Europe also has standards already developed.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, when the Georgian Dream won the elections in 2012 and Saakashvili's party was handing over power, it was a great moment of democracy and I think Georgia has shown great transformational efforts. This country not only has great energy potential, but it is a key ally and partner for Europe in the Caucasus. That is why I welcome the reforms that have taken place in this country. I think that it must not be a cover-up, it is important that the rule of law is deepened and not weakened by politicisation. And if Georgia persists in this endeavor, I think it has our hearts open.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, colleagues, as I said in my opening statement, we closely monitor whether our shared principles are respected. We do this as partners, together with Georgia and in the conviction that strengthening democracy and the rule of law, while ensuring a transparent, prosperous and stable Georgia, is in our common best interest, which is fully in line with the priorities set out in the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) review. During her visit, the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy/Vice-President of the Commission, Federica Mogherini, was encouraged by the constructive tone taken by the government and by the parliamentary faction leaders in Georgia. They acknowledge the need to maintain the focus on reforms and to create a safe space for campaigning ahead of next year’s parliamentary elections. There was a question on the issue of visa liberalisation. The visa liberalisation process is based on the outcome of evaluation missions carried out at the end of September/early October and with information provided by the Georgian authorities. We will be reporting on the state of play in December, i.e. next month. Once a final report is issued, the Commission will be in a position to present a legislative proposal to lift the visa obligation. The decision to do so will then lie with the European Parliament and the Council, and the time that would be needed to decide upon such a proposal is difficult to predict, as you know. Let me conclude by saying that the EU-Georgia Association Agreement is a concrete way to activate the full potential of our relations. The focus is on support for core reforms – which are essential – and, of course, on economic recovery and growth, governance and sector-based cooperation, for example in the fields of transport, energy and the environment. We are doing all of this in an optimistic manner because we are in politics, and we believe this is the way forward.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Moldova (2015/2976(RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this is the first time that Moldova has come back to the plenary since the ratification of the Association Agreement one year ago. Several events have taken place since the debate of last year, including parliamentary elections in November 2014 and, of course, a succession of two short-lived governments. All of you have followed the developments in Moldova since then, especially those concerning the big banking frauds, amounting to around USD 1 billion, which is around 12% of the GDP of the country, and the large protest movements and demonstrations which culminated at the beginning of September with a big gathering in Chișinău. While the banking scandal was at the centre of the demonstrations, people have been expressing their discontent more widely, demanding sustainable governance for the country and calling for corruption to be decisively tackled. Despite a decrease in intensity – probably in the expectation of political developments – these protests are still ongoing. The protesters are demanding the resignation of the President and the dismissal of the Prosecutor General and the head of the National Anti—Corruption Centre. They are also asking for the launch of a referendum on the direct election of the President. Recent developments – namely, the arrest of former Prime Minister Filat on 15 October and the subsequent dismissal of the government in a vote of no—confidence on 29 October – dramatically demonstrate the deep divide that has developed between the political parties that were coalition partners. As the EU, it is not our role to interfere in the internal political processes of a sovereign country. It is for the Moldovan political forces to put aside personal and group interests and to work together for the sake of their country. It is for them to make the political choices that take into account the welfare of their citizens, to help modernise the country and make the economy grow. These are the political choices that the European Union wants and is ready to support. We will continue to call for dialogue among the parties. In order to find sustainable solutions to the governance crisis and certainly in order to address pressing needs, we hope that a new government will pursue, as a matter of priority, the implementation of much-needed key reforms. Vested interests and corruption practices currently hinder development in the country and have a heavy impact on citizens’ everyday lives. Moldovan society expects these challenges to be tackled seriously. That was the message of the EU-Moldova Parliamentary Association Committee in its debates and Statement on 21 and 22 September 2015. I am also aware of the frank exchanges the Committee on Foreign Affairs had with the Speaker of the Moldovan Parliament Mr Candu at the beginning of last week. We have to remind our Moldovan partners that our support is conditional upon the implementation of key and genuine reforms and policies. This should contribute not only to regaining the trust of citizens but also to building a more resilient country and offering a democratic and stable business environment. Any new government will face the challenge of dealing, as one of its first actions, with the banking frauds through comprehensive, impartial and effective investigations, with the goal of recovering the diverted funds. Moldovan society will expect any new government to take clear and effective steps against corruption and to proceed with reforming the banking sector, the justice sector and, at the same time, public administration. Moldova is obviously in a difficult economic and financial situation and will need the support of the IMF. This will mean fulfilling certain conditions on energy tariffs, on the restructuring of the banking sector, and on the management of the National Bank. These are also essential preconditions for a possible resumption of EU budget-support disbursements, as well as for the implementation of our ambitious Association Agenda. The situation, as I have already described, reflects problems in the political system and, of course, the gap between the political system and society. This is, unfortunately, the situation, and this is why we need, together with this Parliament, to apply all those preconditions which I have already mentioned.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I believe, Commissioner, that you are right in the current description of Moldova.  We must see that the three pro-European parties won the elections – albeit narrowly – but that they have not been able to build trust since the elections and have not been able to advance with credibility the stated objectives of modernising the country, the rule of law, and the fight against corruption. On the other hand, there are many in these parties who are prepared to achieve these objectives. As a parliamentarian, I can say that these political forces should be supported in finally setting up a decent, pro-European government, because the alternative is a disaster. For this reason, I believe that the European Union, the political families of this House, who are associated with parties there, should organise the necessary cooperation here and help Moldovans to make their decision on the path they are going, which government they form, but that we have an offer of cooperation and that we hope for this reason. , that there is also the responsibility of all those involved to do so in such a way that it is in the sense of a good development. This is no longer a time for personal gain, this is no longer a time for party political games of the past, this is a moment for real commitment in the interests of the Moldovan people. I hope that the talks that are taking place in these days will lead to such decisions and that this should not fail because of the political characteristics and dependencies, because the result will then be unaltered. (Applause)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, one year ago the European Parliament was meeting to ratify the Association Agreement. In doing so, this House acknowledged the reform efforts and ambitions of the Moldovan authorities. A lot of progress had been made, and the ratification was a strong sign of recognition. Moldova was the uncontested front runner of the Eastern Partnership, our favourite success story at that time. Dear colleagues, if we are meeting today in this Chamber to talk about Moldova, it is not to celebrate one year on from, or the first anniversary of, the ratification. To put it quite bluntly, there is nothing to celebrate. In these past 12 months I have met four different prime ministers. The fifth is on the way. The Co-Chair of our Parliamentary Association Committee, a former prime minister, has been arrested on corruption charges; a banking scandal involving all three major banking institutions has made USD 1 billion vanish – this is almost 50% of Moldova’s GDP – and now, more than ever, the country and its people need the political class to offer resolute action and strong vision. Parties are not even able to propose a new executive. The situation in Moldova is grave – so critical that the immediate temptation is to get angry because the process is no longer delivering. It is just disappointing us. The wonderland has turned into the dark side, but we should and will resist that temptation for the sake of Moldovan citizens. They deserve better; they deserve our engagement, our encouragement, and we will be at their side more than ever before. Moldova’s political class has simply failed its citizens, and we are very worried. The political process has no predictability. The political situation is in a perpetual state of instability, a chronic state of crisis. This means only one thing: the needs of the population are not being addressed, reforms are not being implemented and citizens are paying the bill. Moldova needs political leaders to take responsibility. Moldova needs transparent institutions. Put quite simply: Moldova needs a political class which is able to restore citizens’ trust. A new executive confirming the ambitions of the Association Agreement and effectively implementing the reforms needed could finally deliver, and that means the rule of law, an independent and efficient judiciary, a bold fight against corruption and a thorough investigation into banking fraud, bringing those responsible to justice. This is the last chance for the outgoing governing coalition. Once again: this is the last chance for the outgoing governing coalition. The deadline has passed, and there is no alternative to continuing on the path of the current reform agenda. We can see it, and Moldovan citizens can feel it. It is time for political leaders to hear it.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – I recently visited Moldova on a working visit. It is my custom that, when I come to a third country as a Member of the European Parliament, certainly a country with which we have an association agreement, I first go to our highest representative, the European delegation. Well, it must be of the heart that I have rarely heard a blacker situation sketch than in Chisinau. When I asked our ambassador if there was no alternative to the incumbent political class, the answer was a staggering 'no'. At the same time, he told me - and I have realised this - that this political bankruptcy is directly involved in the reputation of the European Union. Tell me who your political friends are. This also means that there is a drastically reduced confidence in the public domain in the road to Europe. We should realise that here, too. Who are we affiliated with? Yet there is still a bright spot. In my country, the Netherlands, there have been Christian foundations for decades that are working around the weakest in the poorest country in Europe. Fortunately, they keep the reputation high. They are also faced with the lack of the rule of law. But I hope that the European institutions will support this kind of citizens' initiatives, because then we have something else in Moldova that we can be proud of.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, a year ago, when speaking about Moldova in my capacity as rapporteur, I remember that I named Moldova as a front runner, a strong leader amongst the Eastern Partnership countries. Moldova was the first to enjoy the visa-free regime within the Schengen area and free trade and association agreements with us, which started to work in good time and to an increasing extent. Moldova has been given all the political tools that the European Union can offer to boost its Europeanisation. There is nothing more that the EU could have done for Moldova. But things started to go wrong – totally wrong – day after day, with the unprecedented banking scandal with no full investigation until now and the clear evidence of corruption throughout all political segments and layers with, I am afraid, no visible efforts made to fight it. The reforms are stuck. Let us be clear about that. That is no surprise, as governments are changing at the same speed as the seasons of the year. In a situation like this, it is probably natural to see people on the streets for several months. It is just a question of when the tension will explode. Today I am sorry to say that, from being a front runner, Moldova has become a symbol of political chaos. Today I call on the political elite of Moldova to please wake up. It is time. Wake up and start demonstrating your political responsibility to your own country and your own people – people who deserve to live in Europe and to enjoy being Europeans.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In just seven years, four parliamentary elections, five governments, numerous changes in the filling of leading state offices, endless diadochen struggles of the political elites and repeated corruption, this puts even Moldova's well-intentioned analysts in need of explanation. Since the recent government crisis, the image has now been taken of the image that the former model student of the Eastern Partnership has become a state in the stranglehold of corrupt oligarchs.  Let me underline that this is the real problem, because nothing has just happened in Moldova, but we have not looked closely for a long time. What analysts have recently characterized as "systemic failure" has always been the case: despite elections, the political system is unstable and corrupt, and despite widespread liberalization, the economy still depends largely on external aid. Of course, a lot has also been done with the help of the EU. But what is the value of regular elections when political and economic power not only goes hand in hand, but is virtually one? What is the value of expensive reform consultations for the administration of justice if one continues to violate basic norms and, for example, simply locks up an opposition leader and active peaceful protests against the corruption of the ruling oligarchs for months, exposes them in some cases to high health risks and severely restricts their rights?  The population is increasingly questioning both the direction of the planned reforms and the integrity of the political class that drives them, a class that, while formally and verbally committed to EU values, then operates according to the oligarchs' own rules.  Let me underline that we must not allow the credibility of the European Union to be further undermined by maintaining an alliance with the wrong people in Moldova. The Commission is called upon to enforce full compliance with the Association Agreement. This is in line with the expectations of the many social actors in the country.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, a very serious opinion poll has been conducted in Moldova recently. Only 39% of the respondents would vote positively on Moldova’s accession to the European Union, whereas accession to the Eurasian Economic Union is favoured by almost 43% of interviewed citizens. This is, to a large extent, the outcome of a situation where the public have started to be fed up with the European Union. Why? Because the European Union is used as a cover-up for very dirty practices in daily politics. I think it is extremely important that today, the two European families – the European People’s Party and the Social Democrats – have acknowledged that they have a responsibility and that they need to use their contacts with their Moldovan counterparts in order to explain that what is going on is no longer possible. We need to make sure that impunity will not prevail in this incredible banking scandal. It is almost impossible to imagine that 15% of the GDP of this very poor country has been put into some wrong and private pockets, and we need to make sure that the culprits and the perpetrators are brought to justice. The justice system has to be able to perform its function.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, you cannot talk about Moldova without talking about Transnistria, the narrow scrap of land occupied by the Russian army under General Lebed. Now, probably, the soldiers in the army are married to Moldovan girls – who are beautiful, by the way – and there is a problem: what to do with that scrap of land? Moldovans and Transnistrians do not want to be in Moldova, especially now when there is such great corruption, and Moldovans do not want to be in the European Union, because they know (which is obvious) that where there is democracy, there must be corruption. So they have democracy and they have corruption, and we have two societies – Transnistria and Moldova – which do not know what to do. Unfortunately I do not think we can do anything with that. I think we should leave the matter to its own fate.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, several colleagues have referred to the fact that in a single year Moldova has transformed itself from the model student of the Eastern Partnership into a country that is no longer at all predictable, where chaos reigns - as someone said earlier. How did it get here? I believe that there are three important factors that have changed the situation. It's Russia first and foremost. Russia's influence on opinion is greater today than it was a year ago. We are facing the failure of a pro-European coalition that was validated at the polls and for a year, instead of finding resources to restart the machine, produced solutions that lasted only a moment and reinforced the political crisis. I think we have a responsibility and Elmar Brok called on the various political families to responsibility. I would say that we should not ask the Communists to do so. I believe that the communist family in Parliament should stay away, as should all russian friends who are also in the European Parliament, who are in support of a catastrophic scenario for Moldova. So I ask them to refrain, not to enter this game. Secondly, I believe that we must respond to the request made in Chisinau at this time to provide European mediation for the construction of a new coalition. We started on a road, we took responsibility, we also provided a perspective for Moldova and other countries through the revised neighbourhood policy. I think we need to get involved, moderating, making possible an alternative path to what the Communists want, to what Dodon's Socialists want, to what Moscow wants in the Republic of Moldova.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, the citizens of Moldova clearly identified what their priority is when they took to the streets last month to bring down the government: it is tackling corruption. It is in our interest to tackle this because it is jeopardising our security. Moldova is an important route for illegal trade in weapons, and not just in AK47s: criminal gangs have also been attempting to sell stolen nuclear goods to IS and other jihadi groups. I understand one attempt was prevented by the FBI, but others could have been successful. It is of major concern that the Moldovan police department investigating this was reportedly shut down under pressure from the government. That is why we need to make the fight against corruption and reform of the judiciary absolute priorities. Clearly, we cannot turn those who are trying to increase their grip on the state institutions for personal gain into our partners, even if they promise pro-European policies in return. Of course, we need to be mindful of Russia playing its usual game of placing pawns to discourage democratic reforms, but stooping to that level will not make our neighbourhood safer or more prosperous. It is important that we, the EU, offer Moldova a clear view of what we have to offer in return for reform. But the government there also has to realise that, first and foremost, these reforms are in its own interest, and it must not be seduced into turning its back on the EU in favour of those masquerading as its allies.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Moldova is experiencing a political crisis triggered directly by the government's resignation, and for several months there have been large public protests expressing disillusionment with citizens by public authorities, especially in the context of the gigantic corruption and the disappearance of nearly a billion dollars from the Moldovan banking sector. On behalf of the ECR Group, I would like to express my concern about the continuing situation in the country and, in particular, the slowdown in the pace of public administration reforms in the area of justice and public finance management, as also recently reported by the President of the Moldovan Parliament at a meeting of parliament's Committee on Foreign Affairs.  However, we appreciate Moldova's commitment to the Eastern Partnership and maintain our support for its integration into the Union. However, we should mention another milestone for Chisinau on this road, namely the signing of an association agreement and the reorientation of exports towards other markets, which now surpasses exports to Russia for the first time in history. Finally, I would like to express my hope that the Moldovan authorities will listen carefully to the voices of public discontent and continue to fight corruption and protect democratic values. We wish our Moldovan partners success, although we Poles know very well that the goals set are not easy to achieve in a situation of blackmail and political and economic pressure from Russia, which, step by step, from Crimea to Donetsk to Abchaya, seeks to rebuild its empire at the expense of the independence and even territorial integrity of its closest neighbours.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: – Mr President, the turbulent history, the varied ethnic structure, the de facto closure between different states – all of this has been a breeding ground for many contradictions in Moldova. When wild privatization and corruption were added to all this, the problem was solved. And it was enough for this climate and soil quality to flourish. So little was enough – as in Syria today. All it took was an agreement between the powers on joint action. But the European Union did not like President Voronin's proposals for an agreement with Russia on The Subnational, Ukraine and other states do not like Moldova's accession to Romania, Washington is using its influence to weaken Moscow's position. That's how the final result came in. And Moldova is one hundred and fourteenth, and the poorest in all of Europe the European Union certainly cannot boast of playing a role in Moldova that would ease political tensions by reducing crime, corruption and political processes. And if anyone wants to look into the eyes of Moldovan women, they have a chance. Here sits grigory petrenka's wife, who is wrongfully behind bars.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – One year since the signing of the Agreement between the European Union and Moldova on trade, on association routes, on customs and other options that open moldova a greater path to the exchange of goods, goods, including in some way labour between the European Union and Moldova. It is also a year since our delegation visited the elections in Moldova, and I have to say that, of course, the so-called pro-European forces won, but they have clearly lost the trust of the citizens. At the time, the vast majority no longer support entry or the way into the European Union, and all of this is actually the result of those who have betrayed trust in some way. Even then, we were talking about the problems of justice, media freedom and the banking system, and this has, of course, proved fatal, and today, instead of talking about progress, we are talking about people on the streets and a worse perspective than it was a year ago.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, with regard to Moldova, I can repeat many elements of my Georgia speech on the basis of the copy/paste principle. Moldova is important to us as a direct neighbour. The citizens of Moldova are important to us as Europeans because they have associated themselves with the European Union, because they work with us. We want to see them in our system of order, we want to see them in our economic area, because that is how the zone of stability in our neighbourhood grows. Our commitment to Moldova is not free of conditions. We expect respect for human and civil rights, we expect the rule of law, we expect pluralism in democracy, we expect clean policies. This is also the expectation of the citizens of Moldova. Moldovans have supported modernisation and reform. They expect the state and the economy to stabilise. The oligarchs are fighting for power instead. Above all, the citizens now want an investigation into the crimes: where is the billion that has been stolen from the banks? I would like our intelligence services to make their findings available to the Moldovans so that the money can be identified and repatriated. The country needs an active government. The country needs an independent attorney general. The country needs an effective fight against corruption. The European Union must impose strict conditions. A detailed contract could help. It must set out reform steps and timetable. EU experts must enforce this route in the ministries. Our support must be made conditional on this.  The citizens of Moldova want better living conditions. The country must not lose more citizens. We do not want to lose Moldova as an EU partner. We must therefore not waste any time. On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I accept that we are exerting influence on the relevant parties that are in contact with us in line with this agenda that we have all set out.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, allow me to take in the official language of the Republic of Moldova, the Romanian language. Ladies and gentlemen, through history, through traditions, through culture, through language, through human ties, through its geographical position, the Republic of Moldova is part of south-eastern Europe, not of the Euro-Asian space. Yes, of course, the Republic of Moldova is in trouble now, but I do not think that the European Union can afford to leave the Republic of Moldova in an area of uncertainty, in an area of fear alongside Ukraine. As you know, the Republic of Moldova has had a frozen conflict since 1991. Ukraine has it more recently in the east as well as in the south with Crimea. We now need to support the Republic of Moldova more than ever to have a viable government, a government that applies the European Union's programmes so that the citizens of the Republic of Moldova benefit from this European Union Association Agreement, to see that their future is with the European Union, the Member States of the European Union, the European world. At the same time it must be said very clearly that there are eastern interests of destabilising the Republic of Moldova and we must counter this, we must support a viable government in Chisinau, we must support pro-European civil society organisations in Chisinau in the Republic of Moldova. The Republic of Moldova must join the European Union, Romania and the other countries. Her future is European.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Moldova is a small, fertile, beautiful country with very great opportunities, but also with very great problems. I think we must also recognise that we in the European Union have failed to tackle the widespread corruption in Moldova and that it may cost us very dearly. It is in the EU's interest to ensure that the latest banking scandal is fundamentally investigated and that those responsible are held to account. In a country that has concluded an association agreement with the EU, only 12% of gross domestic product disappears without a trace. That is totally unacceptable. It undermines apathy, democracy and the confidence of citizens to have a functioning society at all. What we can do is to offer even more clearly legal and financial assistance to ensure that those responsible are held accountable and to contribute to the functioning of the banking system for the future.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Mr. President, while the Moldovan people have expressed their ambition to move closer to the EU, a series of corruption scandals recently and the lack of reforms have lost pace with the European path. For our part, we have supported Moldova in significant reform and financial terms, but the situation today is unacceptable because political elites have brought the country to the brink of collapse, and under the European flag politicians continue to apply the same style of post-Soviet politics.  As a result of the de facto privatisation of the state by oligarchs, Moldova is europe's poorest state and there is a strong need to deoligarchise politics and government institutions. I believe that the priorities of Moldova's accession programme with the EU, the fight against corruption, judicial reform, the economic transition are the right priorities that most moldovan people would also support. In this regard, I believe that we in the European Parliament must call on pro-European political elites, today I particularly welcome the efforts of our committee chairman Mr. Brok, a colleague of Auštrivičius and Cristea, to organize all reform forces, change the atrmosphere and to go down the path that the Association Agreement has set out.  Maybe we could form a similar support group for Moldova, as we currently have for Ukraine. I believe that extending the mandate of the EU Border Support Mission to Moldova and Ukraine, EUBAM, is a very concrete and good move for Moldova. In this regard, the situation in Transnisstra is important for the overall stability of the country and its European path, and we will do everything to get it back on the right European bar.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, every time I am in the Republic of Moldova people always ask me the same question: does the Republic of Moldova still have a chance? I believe that it is our duty, as representatives of the European institutions, to give the Republic of Moldova a European perspective, and to the citizens of the Republic of Moldova a hope, to show them that the Republic of Moldova still has a chance. If we do not give us a perspective, then Vladimir Putin will give it and it will not be good. It will not be good for the Republic of Moldova, but it will not be good for the European Union. The reality is that the Republic of Moldova benefits greatly from the association and rapprochement with the European Union. The Republic of Moldova is the non-European Union state that receives the most European funds per capita. Our duty is to explain to the citizens of the Republic of Moldova the benefits of rapprochement with the European Union and not to leave them prey to propaganda from the east which says that there are no concrete benefits for people from the rapprochement with Europe. We must say very clearly that in 2014, when the Russian Federation imposed an embargo on Moldovan products, the European Union reacted by raising quotas for fruit imports and eliminating quotas on imports of wines. This ensured the existence of agricultural entrepreneurs, farmers. It must be said very clearly to the citizens of the Republic of Moldova who is their friend, who is their enemy. We must say very clearly that the European Union wants a strong, independent Republic of Moldova on its own feet.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Only a year ago Moldova signed an association agreement with the Union, the first of the Eastern Partnership countries to have visa-free travel and wide access to the European market, and moldova's pro-Western course seemed to be unthrealed. In recent months and weeks we have watched Moldova experience a political earthquake, demonstrations in Chisinau protesting against the theft of the century, but also against the corruption of the political elites, the kind of privatisation of the state by oligarchs led to the collapse of the pro-European government, which on 29 October, so quite recently, was forced to resign, resign.  Confidence in the European Union has fallen, and the Monetary Fund has stopped financing previously planned loans, so Moldova is plunged into a deep political and economic crisis, making it very vulnerable to external influence, among other things, from Russia, which would see it in its Eurasian Union.  I am convinced that Moldova deserves more, that it is able to prepare the necessary changes, especially changes in the judicial system, because a functioning judicial system, the conviction of citizens that justice is possible, is the basis for the civic activity and functioning of all practically institutions. And in this context, the question arises: what is our task, what can we do as the European Union to make this mission successful? What exactly, how specifically can we help Moldova? Can we also help combat Russian propaganda, provide the right information, and can we do everything we can not to push Moldova into the arms of the big brother?

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, Moldova was a good example of a success story, with economic growth, well—implemented visa liberalisation and an accession agreement, but Moldovan leaders have made lots of mistakes. The reasons are deep and have roots in the past, meaning there is a lack of transparency and responsibility among the political elites. They have lost credibility, they have lost money from the banking system, they have lost the trust of citizens just one year after the parliamentary elections, and they have lost the unity needed for pro-European development. Divided, the political elites have no power to lead the country. Now they have decided to announce a new election without fully recognising what the results might be. We are on the Moldovan side, but we need, day by day, arguments to promote its integration with the EU. It is our duty to support them on the path to reforms: anti—corruption measures; the reform of state-owned and controlled companies; and the signing of an agreement with the IMF to continue the implementation of EU assistance and balance the budget. It is our duty – as Elmar Brok said – to support Moldova in finding the proper way for themselves. We can settle emotions, but time is running out and Moldovan citizens are waiting for a new leadership – a leadership of trust.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would really like to highlight the chaos or political instability moldova is now in and how necessary our concrete support is. After, of course, the parliamentary elections that took place last year and the collapse of two governments. After expressing so many suspicions of corruption and threats to the banking sector in fact, it is essential to offer moldovan citizens an alternative. Otherwise, their eyes will really turn elsewhere, and I think we all know where they might turn in this room. We must support Moldovan farmers, and we have already done so in several adopted acts, and what Moldova probably needs most today is our firm determination to stand by Moldova even in this difficult time. I firmly believe that we are all standing here in this Chamber in this democratic process in Moldova.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the situation in Moldova is in a state of shock. At a time when huge economic problems have arisen in the country, at a time when corruption is casting a heavy shadow over the political system, at a time when over a billion euros have literally disappeared from the banking system and been transferred abroad, at a time when the political crisis is raging after the overthrow of the government, there is now a serious risk that Moldova will run into violent internal conflicts between the two major political blocs that dominate the country. On the one hand those who want a closer relationship with the European Union through the Eastern Partnership and on the other hand those who want to see their future looking east.  The European Union must contribute to the consolidation of democracy, the blow of corruption and smuggling, but without interfering with the internal political situation and party rivalries in Moldova. Only in this way can the European Union, in fact, contribute to the policy of calm in the region.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank you for your interest, your support and your determination on this very difficult and controversial issue in our neighbourhood, with a lot of repercussions in many aspects. Our discussion today has confirmed that we share the same concerns and that we agree on the need to continue support to Moldova on its path towards political association and economic integration with the European Union, as well as in its efforts to build a democratic society and to overcome the interest of individuals for the sake of the country. Moldovan society expects its leaders to put an end to state capture; to fight corruption, carry out real reforms and recover the funds stolen from the banks. We remain ready to support Moldova in all of this, but it is only Moldovan political leaders who can make it happen. Together with the implementation of the Association Agreement, this is key to enhancing the resilience and sustainability of the country. Thank you for this very rich discussion and for your determination.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Dear Commissioner, honourable Members, with the signing of the Association and Stabilisation Agreement, Moldova has set out the road to deeper European integration. But this process is seriously threatened because there is a lack of political will to accept the necessary reforms in the judiciary, banking sector and the fight against corruption. Moldova is in an extremely difficult political situation - 3 governments within a year! Stagnation in reforms and European integration causes the population to lose faith in institutions, and the state is fragmented. This is a serious problem because there are many ethnic communities in Moldova – along with Moldovans, Romanians and Russians, there are also many large Bulgarian and Gagauz communities. Only with the protection of the democratic, social, political and economic rights of all minorities will Moldova be able to ensure its territorial integrity and the state will be able to move forward towards deeper European integration. Moldova is a European country and we are all connected to it, historically and culturally, and I hope that one day we will accept it as a full member of the European Union.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, like Georgia and Ukraine, Moldova signed an association agreement with the EU a year ago and enjoyed its deep European integration. The European family is the future of Moldova and its people despite the country's difficult historical past. Unfortunately, in recent months we have witnessed numerous violations and deviations from European values in the country. Rising corruption at the high levels of power and the lack of rule of law call into question the country's European path. Civil society's demands for the depoliticization of the judiciary and the fight against corruption are not heard, and this benefits the pro-Russian parties in the country. I therefore believe that the EU should support a new form of government working to meet civil society's demands and restore Moldova's pro-European course. We must help ensure a free electoral process that will proceed in accordance with the highest European standards in order to give the country a realistic European perspective.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the education of children in emergency situations and protracted crises (O-000147/2015 - B8-1108/2015) (2015/2977(RSP))

name: Linda McAVAN
text: author. – Mr President, I am pleased that we have chosen today to debate this issue because today, colleagues, we actually have something to celebrate in the midst of all the gloom in the news about us. We adopted the budget today, and when we adopted that budget we agreed one of the key demands of our resolution which we will adopt tomorrow, namely to increase the humanitarian aid budget for education in emergencies substantially – by EUR 26 million. This is a figure that we proposed in the Committee on Development, and I want to congratulate Arne Lietz, our rapporteur. It is a big step towards the 4% target that we all want to see as part of the EU’s overall humanitarian aid budget, and I know that this is a cause close to the heart of nearly everybody in this room. Certainly, I know that for Commissioner Stylianides it is a big priority, as it is for for my own political group. I know that colleagues from the EPP, the Greens, the Liberals – all those I see here, and our colleagues in many Groups – have shared this view, and I thank you for your support. It was when I went to Turkey with the Development Committee earlier this autumn that I got a real sense of why it matters that we put money into education, because I visited a refugee camp of 17 500 people. I also visited some of the many families in the community and I got a real sense of what it means to the families who come to have to leave their homes and everything else behind and to start again, and also of what it means to a country to have to receive hundreds of thousands of refugees and try and offer education. We saw some excellent projects run by UNICEF and other organisations. In the refugee camp in Kahramanmaraş we saw UNICEF organising schools, paying Syrian teachers a stipend to offer education to the children, and providing a school curriculum. What was offered to those children was not just an education but a sense of normality, and the school was a happier place in that camp. We met children who were orphaned and had been through enormous trauma, but in the school they had a sense of normality: it was a place where they could be like other children. The Commission was providing kites and games and toys, as well as an education. There is one issue, however, which I am concerned about, and that is what happens when children get to the age of 16, 17 or 18 and want to go on to higher education. I think that is where we need to do more – because we met young people in southern Turkey who had lost their sense of hope for the future. They had had plans to go to university, to study and to train, and yet, at 17 or 18, they did not see any outlet. Those are the young people who are getting on boats, risking their lives crossing the Mediterranean, and we have to find a solution for them. I think we could do this with our universities and colleges, by offering scholarships. I am sure there is something more we can do. The message from our resolution was very clear. I know, Commissioner, that you are aware of the problem of the barrier between humanitarian aid and development funding. The Commission is trying to break that barrier down, and we welcome that. We have the new global goals now, on the basis of which we can work to consolidate education, particularly in countries which are precarious and fragile. Our figures show that up to 1 billion children are living in conflict areas in the world today. We will also soon have the report that my colleague, Enrique Guerrero Salom, is preparing for the World Humanitarian Aid Summit, and at that summit, Commissioner and colleagues, we will have to argue to get other players to back our increase in funding for this type of education. Thank you very much for your support. Let us hope we can build on what we have achieved today.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am extremely pleased that we are discussing this point today, and I would like to thank Linda McAvan very much for her support as Chair of the Committee on Development (DEVE). I strongly believe that education for children in emergency and conflict situations is paramount. It is the most powerful tool we have to protect children and to ensure that they can have a better future – a secure future. Education in emergencies is a top priority for the Commission and for me personally. I know that it is a top priority for this Parliament, as Linda has already mentioned in a very strong way. Your actions speak loud. We are together in this and I am truly grateful for your support. Thank you so much again. We all agree: education is the foundation for everything else. It is the strongest shield for vulnerable children, protecting them from radicalisation, protecting them against forced recruitment, protecting them from falling prey to terrorist and other extremist groups, protecting them also from forced marriages, from taking dangerous migration routes. Education is therefore a primary need. I have seen it on the ground during my field visits in emergency and conflict areas and most recently in refugee camps in Jordan and Lebanon, and at the borders with Syria. My point is crystal clear: these people do not need aid only to meet their basic needs. They do not need just food and shelter. They also need dignity. They need hope and a real future for their children. As you rightly stress in your resolution, less than 2% of global humanitarian budgets goes to education, at a time when the number of 60 million refugees and internally displaced persons (IDPs) is unprecedented. Today more than 34 million children are out of school due to humanitarian crises: 34 million children! This must change. We cannot continue with business as usual. New approaches are needed, definitely. Education is not a secondary issue, to be dealt with only in the second phase of an emergency, because education, by protecting children, also strengthens security, and it addresses one of the main causes of migration. Parents and children are not fleeing their homes just to get food and shelter. They are leaving because they also want access to education. In the last few years we have increased our allocation from the EU humanitarian budget to this sector. From the symbolic EUR 2 million in 2012, we reached this year EUR 11 million. This is roughly 1% of our humanitarian aid budget. Now we have to do more: much more. Earlier this year I committed to tripling this allocation in 2016 and reaching the UN target of 4% by 2019. I am really pleased and proud to announce today, in this Chamber, that I will reach the 4% target already from next year. This achievement is not my achievement; it belongs to you as well, because we could not reach the target without your strong support and without your proposal to allocate an additional EUR 26 million, as Linda mentioned, from the EU budget for this specific purpose. Sincerely speaking, your leadership and your actions have made a real difference. Thank you again for that. I am grateful for your crucial help to secure the necessary funds. Let me reassure you from my experience on the ground. Every euro invested in education and emergencies, is an investment for peace. I am working together with my colleagues Johannes Hahn and Neven Mimica, who are doing a great job in this field to meet this challenge, to make sure that children in emergency and conflict situations can benefit from projects in education, as we know through the Madad Fund in Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and the Western Balkan corridors and in the other Trust Fund for Africa, and of course by establishing formal and informal schools through our experienced implementing partners on the ground. This is very important. All of you know very well the real impact of the informal schools, in particular in the Bekaa Valley. We have a collective responsibility to give every child a bright future. This is crucial. Let us renew our collective commitment: no more lost generations of children.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. Mr. President, 37 million children living in conflict-affected areas are not attending school. If we take on average that conflicts last on average ten years, children and their families spend 17 years in exile, then they could say that these are entire lost generations. And we often say that education is a passport to a better future. So what is the future ahead for these children and what is the future of their countries? Children can't wait for wars and crises to end. If we don't put the book in their hands right now, someone else will give them a weapon. In addition to education being the basic right of every child regardless of circumstances, education is also the most effective means of promoting peace, prosperity and stability, thus representing one of the most important investments. That is why for the EPP group, the education of children in emergencies and protracted crises was a priority in the humanitarian aid portfolio. On behalf of the club, I welcome the efforts of Commissioner Stylianides, who has continuously advocated an increase in funding for the area. As many as 1.5 million children will benefit from the EU Children of Peace initiative by the end of the year, as a result of educational projects in 26 countries. So, I welcome this resolution, I also welcome the leadership shown by The President of the Development Committee Linda McAvan and of course I welcome the decision on an additional budget of EUR 26 million for the education of children in crises.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, we have good news: we have 26 million more in the new budget; tomorrow we will adopt this motion for a Resolution which proposes to reach 4%, which the Commissioner has already announced to us. Next month we will surely approve my report for the humanitarian summit in Istanbul, which will also propose to reach this 4%. But we have, along with the good news, a big problem: how to solve the provision of education to so many thousands, hundreds of thousands, millions of children in an emergency situation. Because education is decisive for the future of children, but it is also decisive for the future of the societies of which they are part.  Education and knowledge are the only inexhaustible and irreplaceable energy, and societies that do not have access to them are called to fail in the future. Therefore, to support the education of children is to support families, it is also to support the progress of their societies.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: for the ECR Group. – Millions of children are prevented from attending a school where they could not only gain a sense of security, but also a vision for a better future for both themselves and their country. Given that education is not a priority for countries in crisis and development aid from the Member States of the European Union is alarmingly low, primary school attendance remains inaccessible to many children.  However, we – individuals – can also change this situation. This is through remote adoption programmes that work, I presume, in all EU countries. In Slovakia, for example, it is dedicated to the Dobrota Foundation for Africa, the Slovak Catholic Charity, as well as the Integra Foundation. Each of us can save at least one child by adoption remotely.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the previous Commission for introducing the EU's Children of Peace initiative with the funds obtained by the Nobel Peace Prize to the European Union. Impossible better investment. This year alone will reach more than a million and a half children. I would also like to welcome Commissioner Stylianides' commitment to double emergency education funding by 2019 from 2% to 4%. What great news to hear you today say we will make it in 2016. If we are to achieve the ambitious global goal number 4 – inclusive and quality education for all – a strut of the 2030 Agenda, we not only need to increase its funding, it is also absolutely crucial to coordinate the emergency response programming with the long-term programming required by sustainable development; a 2030 Agenda that is aimed not only at the least developed countries, but at all the Member States of the United Nations that have signed it, that is, all of us. In this regard, I would like to reflect: are we, the Member States, fulfilling the obligation to provide adequate education to refugees arriving on the territory of the Union? According to the 1951 Convention on the Status of Refugees, we must treat refugees as well as nationals with regard to elementary education and give the most favourable treatment possible with regard to different education. We need to create educational corridors and make the most of the technology at our disposal to incorporate as soon as possible the children and young people who arrive in Europe at school or university and that their lives recover as soon as possible, at least a certain tinge of normality, a place where they feel safe. In the midst of destruction, building bridges, bridges between humanitarian aid and development cooperation, sustainably connecting assistance, rehabilitation and development. I would like to end with a phrase which I particularly like and which is contained in the preamble to the Unesco Constitution of 1945. It reads: "Since wars are born in the minds of men, it is in the minds of men that the bulwarks of peace must be erected."

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, we welcome the support of this motion for a resolution to increase European funds aimed at improving the education of children in emergencies and conflict situations.  These months we are watching in horror at the situation of the hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing war in Africa and the Middle East. The future of the children of these families depends on them receiving a good education in the host countries that will enable them to overcome the difficulties of their situation and to grow up as full citizens. We know what we are talking about: Europe was throughout the twentieth century a continent of great migrations caused by war, as well as for economic reasons – as is still the case. We disagree on the privatization approach introduced in the text. Private education management ensures neither greater efficiency nor higher educational quality nor more plurality. We therefore whole-handedly advocate that these funds be geared towards public education.  The economic resources provided by European citizens should be used to strengthen the quality of public education, which has historically proven to be the best tool of any society to reduce inequalities and increase the opportunities of each and every person, wherever they come from and where they are in the situation where they are.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is very important that more attention has been paid recently to the impact of fragility and conflict on people and their lives. We have been able to come to the conclusion that people living in fragile states, in conflicts and in emergency situations are in fact totally deprived of what they need to establish their lives later if the situation becomes calmer and they can resume living ordinary lives. Indeed, we do not know how long people will have to live in camps, and so we need to bring them hope. I agreed with the Commissioner when he said that we need both informal and formal education. One bright example I saw in Zaatari camp in Jordan was that a Finnish NGO called Finn Church Aid actually had a circus school, one for boys and one for girls, where they learned skills, cooperation and to trust their own bodies through acting in a creative way. So let us hope that the four per cent that the Commissioner has already promised for next year will be very well used for education in emergency situations.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, education is vital for every child’s future – that is a fact. But the quality of education a child receives is also vital. In developing nations, private schools are on the rise due to the failure of governments to provide children with a decent education. In Mathare, a slum in Nairobi, 120 private schools now exist and some can cost as little as a dollar a week. This is a fantastic new phenomenon, which is happening organically. Incredibly, governments and NGOs are taking the view that private education should be discouraged, whilst in reality it could be the key in providing more and more disadvantaged children with education. Stop giving failing or corrupt governments our money to provide education for children and encourage the free market and entrepreneurialism in developing nations. Proper education will end the cycle of poverty. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: blue-card question. – I would not deny that we do also need private resources for education, and Mr Gill has given some good examples. However, Mr Gill, do you not also believe that we need to make sure the developing countries raise the necessary revenue from taxation and other sources so that they can provide public education too? Do you not think that international organisations which are supporting governments, such as Global Partnership for Education, are doing a fantastic job by trying to make sure that good-quality education is available for all children?

name: Nathan GILL
text: blue-card answer. – Obviously it is crucial that economies in third-world countries are developed and expanded, because that is how people will get out of the poverty trap they are in. Corruption is one of the biggest stumbling blocks to expanding the economies of developing nations, as it basically takes the wealth from the people and puts it in the hands of corrupt officials and corrupt police officers, etc. So there are many ways in which we can improve the lot of people in the third world. However, education is one of the areas in which we need to ensure that nations can develop their own education systems organically, just like your nation and my nation did.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is very important that today we actually state that children and young people have the right to education and education even when they are refugees or in emergency situations. There are 10 million refugee children, most of them in refugee camps in Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey. Many of them have already lost years of school to conflict.  Yet we know, as you also pointed out, that access to education and psychological support is not a second-half welcome but an integral part of it. It is also a powerful tool for preventing them from violence, trafficking and radicalisation; it is a very strong psychological aid but it is also an element of design of the future for them and their families. Despite the efforts of UNICEF, many NGOs, including individuals, hundreds of teachers, even among the refugees themselves, the resources allocated so far – we know this – are not enough and we very much appreciate that the Commission has taken up the proposal to double the share of humanitarian aid as early as 2016. We are also relaunching another proposal that we made in the Committee on Culture – which was accepted and I thank Mrs McAvan very much – namely to create a humanitarian corridor, opening the doors of European universities to refugee students, even with distance courses.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, can you imagine your own son having to take a rifle instead of a book? Well, this is indeed the reality of many children in the world.  Unfortunately, this European Union sometimes continues, with its double standards, participating in the perpetual generation of international conflicts or looking the other way. And, in parallel, we wash our faces with humanitarian aid programs.  As this motion for a resolution reflects, ensuring quality education for children in emergencies and protracted crises is an absolute priority. We all agree. They are life and they are our future.  What I find incredible is that humanitarian aid issues are intended to be instrumentalized to encourage the privatization of services – which must be fundamentally public, supported by international organizations – such as education in emergencies and protracted crises. The European Union has this responsibility and has this capacity to ensure the rights of all children.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, education is to be regarded as an instrument of the utmost importance in the development path of countries in situations of crisis and prolonged emergency. In these circumstances, we know that children are the most vulnerable, often victims of abuse and exploitation, including sexual exploitation, or easy prey for recruitment by criminal organisations and armed groups. Prolonged crises, however, can generate devastating effects for the correct psychophysical development of children, with the risk of giving rise to the phenomenon of so-called lost generation. In such situations, education is an effective prevention and protection tool for children, with positive long-term effects for developing resilience. This is all the more true for those children who have been separated from their families as a result of conflict or natural disasters. I would like to thank the Commission for its sensitivity, but I would ask that we act promptly to outline a comprehensive aid strategy, including education for children in emergency situations.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the education sector in emergencies and crises is currently among the most underfunded: it receives less than 2% of global humanitarian aid, enough to finance just a third of current needs.  Education must be given priority in these contexts, as it ensures a guarantee of protection for children, at the very time when they are most vulnerable. As Linda McAvan said before: school gives them a sense of normality. Postponing educational activities until the emergency has passed may mean not returning them to school, often condemning them to a future of poverty. And education is the best antidote to radicalization. Let us ensure that support for education is central to projects funded by EU trust funds and find platforms that break down barriers between humanitarian and development aspects, that ensure continuity and coherence to these policies. The time has come for the EU to become the first international donor to reach the target of 4% of spending in this area. I would like to thank Commissioner Stylianides for his commitment and for the good news that we will be making as early as next year.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, as Linda McAvan pointed out, education is a fundamental human right and the right of every child. It is vital in order to be able to enjoy in full all other social, economic, cultural and political rights. It is a catalyst for development, which improves the prospects of other interventions in the areas of health, sanitation, disaster risk reduction, job creation, poverty reduction and economic development. Efforts in this direction will ensure that the principle of policy coherence is respected. I therefore absolutely agree on the need to ensure more integrated, systematic and effective responses to education needs in emergencies, and I strongly believe that the European Union must work with partner countries, other donors, the private sector and civil society to improve educational opportunities for children and young people in conflict situations. Education has to be considered as an integral part of the humanitarian response. All actors must increase their commitment to education by mobilising the education cluster in the early stages of an emergency and by ensuring that sufficient funds are dedicated to it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. The European Union does not have a strong army to deal with conflicts at different ends of the world, but the European Union and European countries are the largest donors of humanitarian aid in the world. This money, if properly spent, gives a much stronger long-term result than weapons and armies. And channelling funding to the education of long-term children in crisis is our effective weapon against poverty, against crime, against terrorism. Quite statistically, around one billion children live in different types of conflict-affected areas. A quarter of them are under the age of 5. 10 million children are refugees, with a further 19 million displaced in their home countries.  The conclusion can only be one – it is not normal, it needs to be corrected. Consequently, I welcome the increase in the European Union's financial assistance from 4.4 billion to 4.7 billion by 2020. In order to make this weapon more effective, we need European Union policy, coherence in this area and an increase in funding. It is therefore important for us not to separate from each other and to do everything necessary for our children. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Yana TOOM
text: blue-card question. – Mr Mamikins, you were speaking about children in conflict regions and refugee camps. But are we ready to face the challenge of educating refugee children in Europe, in European schools? Maybe you have some good examples in your own country, in Latvia?

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: answer to the blue card question. – Thank you, Mrs Toom, for asking this question. But unfortunately, I have to admit that my country, Latvia, cannot boast of a particularly successful integration policy.  I will mention only one thing, in my view, a paradoxical fact. We are talking in Latvia about strengthening the state language, etc., also about increasing the role of the Latvian language, but when in January my country accepts refugees, including children, at present only schools with Russian language have applied to receive these children. And it was refused to do this in schools with the Latvian language. So I don't really have anything to answer your question.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, thank you for appaching my traditional role together with my colleague Marias. I would like to begin by appreciating the commissioner's achievements. I appreciate this immensely, because its success will also help to remove barriers in youth education. I would like to recall that it is here today that we approved the report by My Colleague Dati, which has a section that also deals directly with the issue of education as a means of preventing the radicalisation of young people. I would like to quote that, according to this report, schools and the education process play a central role in helping to promote inclusion in society, to develop critical thinking. I am very happy for the rapporteur's work and I support her because it will help precisely in the education of these children, who are now heading to Europe in a migration wave.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, it is estimated that sixty-five million children live under emergency conditions and thirty-seven million are deprived of basic education due to adverse living conditions. The fact that such a large number of children lack education shows that there is a violation of basic human rights in countries experiencing crises. This is true in African countries, and is much more true in refugee camps in Jordan, Lebanon and on the Syrian-Turkish border.  Lack of education is also a problem in developed countries, such as Greece, which is experiencing the policies of austerity and memoranda and where the education budget is increasingly reduced. In addition, Greece is rapidly deteriorating in terms of children's living conditions, while child poverty is now also having an impact on education and has increased by more than fifty per cent since 2008.  In the face of the lack of education, we therefore welcome the increase in European Union funds announced by Commissioner Stylianides.

name: Julie WARD
